Mama: Forever Be Loved, Mama: Forever Be LovedOne thing that became clear to me is that the image of a divine mother.
A mother whose beauty transcends her appearance and the values she believed in; her capability to sacrifice for her children2019s sake and being so strong even as if all the world2019s against her modest desires.
This is the image of my mother whom I appreciate the most.

Going down memory lane, I didn2019t have a perfect childhood, and neither did my family.
I have only a few moments with my father since he is a seaman we seldom see him in a year.
My mother is the one who is always with me and my siblings; she took care of us and provided us with the things we need.
When my mother and father separated it was when our world turned drastically around.
My father left us with no support.
Amid that very tough time, my mama chose to be strong for us; she held us in her loving arms and bravely accepted the challenge of rearing us as a single mother.\xa0

As a young child then, I cannot fully comprehend how my mama dealt with everything that has happened to us.
I know it was hard and afflictive for us but mama showed us that there2019s no way for us to give up in life, hence she taught us some significant life lessons as we endure daily challenges.\xa0

THE VALUE OF KINDNESS

Mama and I go out for a night walk; sometimes we wander around downtown to buy something at the convenience store or just some items sold along street sides.
One time, we saw a meager old woman who lives on her own in a street corner with her scanty things, she sells some vegetables and lemons and every time we pass by her area Mama buys her goods, every time she did that I noticed that my mama buys her goods not because we badly needed those but with the aim to help that old woman in her deplorable living condition.\xa0

Like those moments, I will never forget how mama exemplified the value of kindness and concern for others.
Even with our neighbors and her friends she shares what she could.
She tells us that being kind is one of the best ways of building a good relationship with other people.\xa0

STAYING GROUNDED

Young as I am, I have big dreams for my mama and siblings.
Whenever I and my sisters as well share our plans and ambitions in the future on our random conversations we just let the stream of ideas flow and enjoy imagining everything and making it all happen on our minds.
Then we end up with determined hearts that someday we will achieve all our dreams as we let the good times roll.\xa0
It2019s a fun time to talk serious matters though.
And as mama hears our hearts out, she beams with hope and reminds us that whatever success we attain in life and wherever our ambitions take us we must keep in mind that we should be humble; have that sense of gratitude to those people who helped us along our way and never forget to stay grounded.\xa0

BE STRONGER

I was a sickly child before; mama even recalled when I was in a critical state due to pneumonia in my early age.
My sisters as well have been ailing when they were young.
With this, my mother is very careful and meticulous about the food that we eat, the vitamins we take and even the clothes we wear.
She ensured that as we grow we are good and sound holistically.\xa0

Now that I am a yuppie and my sisters are all grown-up ladies, our mother continues to make everything go well.
She attends to our needs even on those petty concerns; the solution is in her hands.
Whenever problems come our way we are reminded by how mama dealt with the problems she encountered in her life and on how strong she faced it all.
She wants for us now to be stronger in faith and in conquering life2019s trials.\xa0

***

Our mothers give us so many gifts.
They give us the precious gift of life, of course, but they also leave treasured lessons that can guide us on our journeys even when they are no longer with us.

To our ever-lovely Mama Ging-Ging, Happy 50th Birthday! We will ever be grateful for everything you did for us.
For being our valiant rock and fortress, our hearts remain in you.
You will always be remembered.
2018Til we meet again! We Love You Forever Mama!\xa0

Loving you always, Ken Lloyd, Kimberly and Krystel F.

How to flirt without being creepy, How to flirt without being creepyFLIRTING is a common act done among teenagers whether men or women.
But many "flirting strategies" are often sinister, causing fear or unease to the other person.

In a man's perspective, many would say that the first step in flirting with a lady is by making an eye contact.
Personally, I think that is the second.
Here are steps on how to flirt with a woman without being creepy and flippant.

Step 1: Look at her hands and check if she is wearing a ring.
If she is, move on.
Captain, that ship has sailed! But do not sweat it; more ships will come.

Step 2: Now is the time to make an eye contact.
Do not be a creep.
Take a glance and smile.
Once you catch her attention, look into her eyes for the second time, and light up that face.
Delight!

Step 3: Take the first move.
Approach her naturally.
Do not walk like a gangster or a zombie.
Introduce yourself and open up a conversation.
"Hi there!" That's a good start.

Step 4.
Ask her questions.
"How often do you come here?" If she starts talking, offer some compliments.
"You look good in that dress." Do not ever say, "I like your ass." If things work, offer some place to quench thirst -- a strategy to keep the conversation going.
"Would you want some refreshments?" Then move ahead!

Step 5.
As the t\xeate-\xe0-t\xeate is about to end, test your fate.
You may not see her for the second time.
Get your phone out and ask her for her mobile number.
Worse luck, if she says, "No." But still, stay courteous before you exit the stage.
"I understand.
It was nice meeting you, anyway." 

Then offer a business card.
Leave her with a beaming smile.

Flirting is never easy.
Some may refuse to take it.
Always remember though -- it is a skill learnt through practice and interaction with different kinds of people.
Why don't you start practicing now?

Back from the ashes, Back from the ashesStella A.
Estremera, FOR decades, since the 1970s, Luz Kinilaw at Mini-Forest along Quezon Boulevard has been a landmark of sorts as people continue to seek its juicy grilled panga and fresh knilaw.
Now it is in ashes, but the grilling continues.
Maybe it2019s about time, too.
As more chic restaurants came to be while Luz Kinilaw remained as it was, its wooden floors already weathered with age and its entrance bearing the soot from the daily grilling since the 1970s, and yes, the pungent smell of the seawater outside, locals would prefer to just order take-out, but the ambience still managed to bring in hundreds of visitors.
That was until April 1 at around 6:51 p.m.
when fire broke out at the back of the famous restaurant and burned down 57 structures, including Luz Kinilaw, and damaged seven other houses.
The fire affected 64 owners, 37 renters, and 75 boarded, and injured two residents.
The fire, however, brought greater panic than the damage it actually caused because nearly a year ago, on April 4, 2014, a fire broke out in neighboring Isla Verde and went on to raze houses and establishments in three adjacent barangays --  23-C, 21-C, and 22-C 2013 in an 8.8 hectare area affecting some 3,500 families.
Yesterday, Black Saturday, just three days since the fire and even as Luz Kinilaw2019s structure is still down, the grilling continues, in an adjacent space that was not affected by fire.
The landmark may have gone, but the kinilaw and the sinugba remains.
Hinuklog: MisOr town's community reenactment on the Passion of Christ, Hinuklog: MisOr town's community reenactment on the Passion of ChristFroilan Gallardo, MEDINA, Misamis Oriental 2013 This municipality of 31,154 residents is playing catch up in the world of tourism by dipping into its traditional Lenten play 201cHinuklog,201d a reenactment of the Passion of Christ.
Hundreds of local tourists and residents lined up the streets of this town to watch actors in colorful costumes and good acting performed the Lenten street play last Maundy Thursday and Good Friday.
201cWe hoped the theater tradition of this town can spur tourists to visit Medina and watch our Lenten play every Holy Week,201d Medina town Mayor Ken Ni\xf1o Uyguangco said.

Uyguangco said the town of Medina always has the passion for theater starting with their parents and grandparents who acted on variety shows and school plays staged on makeshift stages during the 50s and 60s.
He said student-trainers later came to Medina, trained the local residents and staged the first Lenten passion street play in 1978.
Uyguangco said the Lenten production has become a passion for Medina residents who always look forward to see the street play every Holy week.
Community endeavor
201cWhat is interesting here is that the characters of the passion play are acted by the local community.
It is really a town endeavor,201d he said.
Uyguangco said the role of Jesus Christ was played by trisikad driver Edu Dorimon while other town residents play the major parts of the Lenten Passion play.
Uyguangco said that despite political differences and economic status, the town2019s folk contributed for the success of the 201cHinuklog 201d a Holy Week event.
Artists from the out of school youths, tricycle drivers, students, retirees, government and private employees, among others, took pride of showing their ability as actors and actresses depicting the participation of people during Jesus2019 remaining days.
201cIn this tech-savvy world, it is rare for a whole community or an entire town supporting the production of the play,201d Judy Aclan of the Department of Trade Misamis Oriental said.
2018One town, one product2019
Aclan said DTI is supporting the town2019s dream of bringing in 201ccultural tourists201d under its 201cOne Town-One Product or OTOP201d program.
The more than 200 artists and production staff are members of Lumadnong Magdudula sa Medina  which has been responsible in bringing to the public this OTOP scheme as tourism destination of the province.
She said there are only three places in the Philippines which have been engaged in 201ccultural tourism,201d one of them is Mindoro which stages the yearly Moriones Festival.
Aclan said Medina residents could enjoy the brisk trade that will be spawned by the popularity of  201cHinuklog201d through trinkets makingg, t-shirts and offering their houses to tourists for home stay.
Production cost
Uyguangco said that last year2019s production cost of Hinuklog amounted to P800,000 for logistics.
The money spent came from the local residents, corporate sponsors and donations from Medinanhons who are already residing abroads.
201cThe Hinuklog event is an activity designed to put Medina on the map and showcase the investment potential of the town,201d Uyguangco said.
Nelson Gasatang, overall director of the play, disclosed that the holding of the 201cPasyon ni Kristo201d was stopped in 1991 for lack of logistics.
201cBecause of the potential of the Hinuklog, we decided to form a council to draw its path sans politics,201d Gasatang said.
 
Since its inception the Hinuklog participants underwent theater workshops to better their acting under the National Council of Culture and the Arts .
More than P500,000 was spent for staging Hinuklog this year which has one overall director and five scene directors.
201cHinuklog, a church based activity is free of politics despite the support from the local government.
It has its own council to plan out its future,201d Uyguangco said.
Gasatang said that while they cannot fully deliver what Jesus experienced, but with Hinuklog they can deepen the consciousness of the parishioners with the message that Christ imparted to the faithful.

PWD among top academic achievers of Pantawid in NorMin, PWD among top academic achievers of Pantawid in NorMin
Pantawid Pamilya grantee Edy Rose Tayab  shows her medals and ribbons with her sister.

LIFE has not been easy for 17-year-old Edy Rose T.
Tayab of Purok 17, Barangay Butong, Quezon, Bukidnon.
She was born with a congenital deformity.
She has no feet and left hand.
But Edy Rose did not let her disability get in the way of achieving her dreams.
She wanted to excel in her class, just like her friends.
201cI want to prove myself that I can do what the normal people can do,201d claimed Edy Rose who added she couldn2019t avoid comparing herself to her classmates.
Having no feet, Edy Rose can walk using her underdeveloped lower limbs without crutches daily.
Her residence is about three kilometers away from Apayao National High School, a challenge she had to face just to finish her secondary education.
201cUsahay makamahay ,201d she said, especially when some or her classmates or even adults would taunt her, saying, 201cNganong ing-ana man imong nilaktan? Mohilom nalang ko.
Pero sa akong galamhan gisakitan nako, .201d
Dream comes true 
Edy Rose, who placed top nine at Apayao National High School of Quezon town this year started focusing on her studies even while in her elementary years.
She is a consistent honor pupil.
201cI enjoy studying,201d Edy Rose said, adding that it was during in her elementary years that she noticed she loves Mathematics.
201cIt feels like I2019m just playing games when it comes to Mathematics,201d said Edy Rose.
She added she loves to answer Mathematical challenges.
Finishing at the ninth place is a dream-come-true for Edy Rose, who plans to take business and accountancy related course in college.
Edy Rose, monitored by Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino  of the Department of Social Welfare and Development , expresses her heartfelt gratitude to DSWD and to President Benigno Aquino III.
201cMagpasalamat jud ko sa DSWD ug ni Presidente PNoy kay natabangan ko nila sa pag-eskwela pinaagi sa Pantawid Pamilya aron makab-ot nako ang akong mga pangandoy,201d she said.
.
Before her enrolment in the program, Edy Rose recalled that her family could hardly send her to school.
201cMay adlaw ko nga walay balon sauna.
Karon kompleto nako og balon ug mga gamit sa eskwelahan,201d she said.

Fellow achiever
Edy Rose is not the only Pantawid Pamilya academic achiever in her school.
Via Calibjo is the Class Valedictorian of Apayao National High School.
Calibjo also received academic awards like the Excellence in English, Excellence in Filipino, Excellence in Mathematics, and Excellence in Science.
Pantawid Pamilya is a government2019s poverty-reduction strategy that provides cash grants to extremely poor households aimed at helping them raise educated and healthy children aged 18 years and below.
 
It utilizes the Conditional Cash Transfer  scheme where beneficiaries receive cash grant provided that they send their children to school, get preventive health check-up, and the parents attend the monthly Family Development Session .
Edy Rose and Via are among the more than 20,381 Pantawid Pamilya beneficiaries who graduated this school year 2014-2015.
Currently, Northern Mindanao has 271,077 active household beneficiaries of Pantawid Pamilya.

Hurdling dire poverty to get college diploma, Hurdling dire poverty to get college diploma
Vergil Alon
Riz P.
Sunio, HIS story is no different to others we saw on television or read somewhere, but the courage he and all the others have is worth emulating.

He barely has money in his pocket since birth, but it didn2019t hinder him to earn his college diploma which he believes is the answer to all the difficulties he and his family have been facing through the years.

For him, the diploma is his passport to lifting him up and his family from such dire poverty.
Meet Vergil Alon, a graduating cum laude student of BSEd in Biology of Mindanao State University in Marawi City who hails from Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental.

Vergil is a Subanen born in Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte from a not-so-fortunate family.
He is third among the brood of seven by Cirilo and Maura Alon.

In his younger days, his mother stayed at home and his father worked as a bus driver2019s assistant but later he was fired.
Left unemployed, he opted to sell 201camakan,201d weaved bamboos used as walls for mostly houses made of light materials, to sustain his family2019s daily needs.
At that time, the amakan was sold at P25 per mat.
He only earned once orders were made.
Vergil and his siblings also helped their father in mat making and delivered them to customers.

Younger years
In his elementary years at Juan Bugarin Central School, Vergil said there were times when they couldn2019t go to school because they did not have money for fare.
201cLagi kaming absent kasi walang pera ,201d he recalled.

When he was in Grade 3, his aunt promised him a gift if he earned an honor at school.
He was able to make it to the fourth spot in the class.
His aunt gave him a pack of small wafers.

It was even harder during Grades 4 to 6.

201cNiabot mi sa point na wala mi2019y rice ,201d he said.

Yet, it didn2019t hinder him to come up on stage to get his awards at school wearing the same shoes every recognition for four consecutive years.

Debts were piling up.
Lenders kept on coming to their house trying to squeeze money from his mother who owed them.
201cDi pa na-deliver , utang na naman,201d he shared.

Left with no choice, his mother left their home 2018to look for money,2019 but even Vergil did not know where his mother went.

Without a mother, he and his siblings had to go to the some hinterland areas to pick camote just to have something to eat.

With all these difficulties at hand, he completed his elementary level landing at the fourth spot.

Life had become more difficult, but Vergil treaded on to high school in Sindangan National High School.

Vergil and his brother were attending school, but when life was made more difficult to come by, Vergil2019s brother quit school and instead sent Vergil to school.

When he was in first year high school, his family moved to Zamboanga City to look for greener pastures.
They had to earn because their debts were continuously piling up.

Vergil did not want to stop schooling and decided to be left behind.
Alone, he only ate rice with coconut meat.
201cKato jud and time na , I really felt alone,201d he said.

Treading to college 
No amount of difficulties stopped Vergil because he graduated Valedictorian at Misamis Occidental National High School in Oroquieta City.
He survived high school by staying in an aunt2019s place and even at his teachers just to continue with his high school.
 
His parents despite financial difficulties supported Vergil to continue to college seeing that Vergil2019s success would lift their formidable life situation.

201dMurag nakit-an pud sa akong family na college na jud ang maka-sulbad sa among problema ,201d he said.

Instead of being discouraged to study and pushed to work, his parents gave their full support sans money, thus, he was able to enter the university as an entrance scholar.

He shared that on his way to MSU Marawi, it was his first time to take a barge from Ozamiz to Mukas in Tubod town in Lanao del Norte.

During his first year in college, his family and his aunt helped each other to eke out something to provide for Vergil2019s allowance, yet it was intermittent and put him to hunger.

Still, he persisted and took some work to earn and buy his food.
He did tutorials, laundry for his teachers and even roommates, became an assistant to a pastor, and a student assistant in his college to sustain him in his studies.

201cKapoy, dili na nimo ma-balance na nagalaba na ka while nag-skwela2026Pero accept the fact na lang nga walang-wala ka, na kailangan mo ang trabahong ito to sustain your needs ,201d he said.
Yet, he persevered and involved himself in various extracurricular activities: dance, debate, quiz shows, and in the college publication.
Working, studying, and extracurricular activities2014he juggled all of these in his five years in college.

 201cStudying in a far school is a challenge for you to look for means to survive.
It2019s a test of resourcefulness,201d Vergil proudly said beaming amid complexities of the challenges he has been facing with.

For five years, he washed others2019 clothes with his bare hands.
Now, he holds his hard-earned college diploma, and best graduating with flying colors on April 15.

English Access Summer Camp, English Access Summer CampMORE than 200 students from different schools in South Central Mindanao gathered at the Regional Major Seminary  last week for the English Access Micro Scholarship Program Summer Camp spearheaded by the Kasilak Development Foundation Inc.
.
The summer camp is part of the two-year program design of the scholarship aimed at providing other avenue for the scholars to explore in developing their communication skills.
Each English Access Student Scholar is required to complete at least 180 hours of after-school English classes given by their English teachers and are also required to render certain hours of community service or involvements.
The Access Scholars were chosen based on criteria and guidelines that our Foundation developed in coordination with the US Embassy and the schools.

But primarily, the major consideration in selecting the students are those that are underprivileged and below average students but has the potential in improving their performance in school as well as leadership potential, said Joemil Saloma Montebon, Kasilak Executive Director.
The program is implemented in partnership with the US State Department through the US Embassy-Manila and Dole Philippines Inc.
and Dole-Stanfilco.
Current partner-schools for School Year 2014-15 and SY 2015-16 with 30 scholars per school are: Tagbina National High School in Tagbina, Surigao del Sur , Impasugong National High School in Ipasugong, Bukidnon , Talandang National High School in Tugbok Dsitrict, Davao City and Araibo National High School in Pantukan, Compostela Valley , and Ginatilan National High School in Kidapawan City, North Cotabato, and Kablon National High School in Tupi, South Cotabato .
"We consider managing and implementing the English Access Program as part of our institutional mission in Kasilak in making meaningful contribution in shaping not just the minds and hearts of these young potential student-scholars but also in preparing and equipping them able to face life's challenges -- in their studies, in their respective communities," Montebon says.
The English Access Microscholarship Program  provides a foundation of English language skills to talented 13-20 year-olds from economically disadvantaged sectors through at least 360 hours of after school classes and intensive sessions over two years.
The Access Program also gives participants the opportunity to gain an appreciation for US culture and democratic values, build personal development skills, and participate in community service initiatives through hands-on enhancement activities.
The program is a high profile, public diplomacy initiative that provides participating US embassies an opportunity to tangibly demonstrate our country's dedication to education and mutual understanding.
The Access Program is a US Department of State-sponsored program and is among the Office of English Language Programs2019 suite of core initiatives, reads the pamphlet about the scholarship.
Pinoy Aquaman takes on Ta\xf1on, Pinoy Aquaman takes on Ta\xf1on
Courtesy: Ingemar Macarine's Facebook account
Liberty A.
Pinili, THE Pinoy Aquaman has decided to champion San Remigio2019s beaches and Ta\xf1on Strait.
To campaign for clean beaches and seas, lawyer Ingemar Macarine will swim today at least 17.6 kilometers across the Ta\xf1on Strait, from Sta.
Fe in Bantayan Island to the Lapyahan in San Remigio.

Macarine said the swim is in support of the Municipality of San Remigio2019s tourism development program.

201cI2019m in the best position to promote clean beaches and seas because I am in the sea ,201d he told a press conference yesterday.
  
Macarine, election officer of Tubigon in Bohol, said it is difficult to influence policy makers so he will focus on raising awareness.
201cI hope that my swim would highlight the importance of clean seas and beaches,201d he said.

He said that having clean beaches and seas is not only beneficial to the environment but also to an area2019s tourism, which creates jobs.
Trash
He said he was disappointed to see plenty of trash during his swim from Olango Island to Mactan in July 2014.
 201cThere was a lot of plastic trash in the sea,201d he said.
   
Macarine said he checked the waters yesterday as part of his preparation for today2019s swim.
He did not see garbage in that part of Ta\xf1on Strait, a protected seascape.
He said, though, that the waves and current would pose a challenge.
 The presence of jelly fish that, according to local fisherfolk usually appears during the dry months, will be another challenge.
He said that the nearest distance between San Remigio and Sta.
Fe, Bantayan is 17.6 kilometers but he will most likely swim 3 to 5 kilometers more because of the current and the waves.
He will swim an average of 3 kilometers per hour.
He will wake up at 3 a.m.
and start swimming at 4 a.m.
after a breakfast of three bananas.
His support crew, which includes navigator Edwin dela Cruz and triathlete Roel Catoto, will be on a motorboat.

Macarine said that he hopes to be able to get past Gibitngil Island before 8 a.m.
to avoid swimming against the current.

Protected
Macarine2019s swim is funded by the Municipal Government of San Remigio, which has established more than 230 hectares of marine protected areas.

The local government also has an active Municipal Fisheries and Aquatic Reform Council and Municipal Environment and Natural Resources Office.

Macarine said he picked San Remigio because of the Municipal Government2019s environmental program and location.

As a marathon swimmer, Macarine is always on the lookout for opportunities to swim more than 10 kilometers in open water.
 He is also eyeing Camiguin and Davao.
His next swim will be in Sarangani on May 10 and in the San Francisco Bay  in California, United States.

Since his first long distance swim in 2013, Macarine had five events with distances of more than 10 kilometers.

Macarine2019s training involves swimming in the pool for at least three hours  three times a week.
In between, he runs or go cycling.

He makes sure to get at least eight hours of sleep every day.
He said that he believes he is prepared for the swim across the Ta\xf1on Strait as he is
no longer bothered by pain in his left shoulder.
Macarine said that despite his family2019s fears, he has never encountered a shark.

5 things to know about Hillary Clinton's decision to run again, 5 things to know about Hillary Clinton's decision to run again
In this March 22, 2014, file photo, former President Bill Clinton  listens as former secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks during a student conference for the Clinton Global Initiative University at Arizona State University in Tempe, Ariz.

WASHINGTON -- The launch of Hillary Rodham Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign marks the end of a long and methodical decision-making process for the former secretary of state, senator and first lady.
While the Democratic political apparatus had been pushing Clinton to run since the day she left the State Department, she waited until last fall to fully engage in the process.
Once she did, Clinton met with dozens of policy and political experts, pored through countless memos and delved deeply into what went wrong with her failed 2008 campaign.
Here are five things to know about Clinton's decision to run:
1.
As Clinton was returning to private life after her four years in the Obama administration, an outside group called Ready for Hillary was pushing her to run for the White House.
At first, the group was a source of frustration for her advisers, who felt it was putting too much pressure on Clinton far too quickly.
But soon, the Clinton team's view of Ready for Hillary would shift from annoyance to acceptance.
The energy the organization was harnessing reminded them of the kind of grassroots movements they jealously watched mobilize around Barack Obama in 2008.
2.
There was plenty that gave Clinton pause as she started weighing another campaign.
She grimaced at the thought of giving up her privacy again.
She worried about putting daughter Chelsea, her husband Marc and their baby in the spotlight.
She felt bad that her candidacy would crowd out Vice President Joe Biden, a longtime friend who was also toying with a White House run.
Clinton was also mindful of chatter that she could be challenged from her party's liberal left flank.
She set up a meeting with Sen.
Elizabeth Warren, whose anti-Wall Street positions were galvanizing progressives and stoking talk that she could launch her own 2016 campaign.
The meeting was as much an opportunity for Clinton to gauge the mood of progressives as it was a chance to size up the seriousness of Warren's repeated denials of a White House run.
3.Clinton campaigned aggressively for Democrats in the 2014 elections, holding 45 events for 26 candidates.
More than half of those candidates lost.
Clinton had expected the results to be bad, but not this bad.
Democrats had run scared, she concluded.
The party had done little to defend its accomplishments on the economy and health care, and done even less to argue what Democrats wanted to do in the future.
Clinton's takeaways about Democrats' failures would guide the final months of her decision-making about running for president.
4.
Though the fall, Clinton delved into meetings with political and policy experts.
As she navigated what a successful campaign would look like, she consulted several operatives who worked for Obama.
Among them: former Obama campaign manager David Plouffe, ground game guru Jennifer O'Malley Dillon, and digital director Teddy Goff.
Clinton also convened long economic discussions that centered on income inequality and the widening achievement gap.
Foreign policy experts gave her their diagnosis of pressing problems in the Middle East and with Russia.
Clinton took hand-written notes and stockpiled multi-page memos.
5.
By the time Christmas rolled around, Clinton had largely settled on running a second campaign, but wanted to make the final determination with her husband, Bill.
The couple headed to the Dominican Republic for their annual vacation at fashion designer Oscar de la Renta's beachfront estate.
Clinton arrived on the island with 500 pages of campaign notes in tow.
She spent her beach vacation wading through the documents and discussing her plans with her husband.
When she returned to New York in the new year, there was no formal meeting with staff or email to friends to announce her candidacy.
Clinton simply started telling advisers to move forward with hiring and find a campaign headquarters.

7 type of students you meet in college, 7 type of students you meet in collegeRuji Peter S.
Abat, IN SURVIVING the traditional school politics, it takes familiarity of the different people you meet in school.
The Athletes -- They generally are either members of the school varsity team or they are simply hanging out with the varsity team.
Girls are easily attracted to them yet some of them turn out to be class bullies.
But mind you, they are ideal partners when there are physically-strenuous activities that you need to accomplish.
The Mean Girls -- They boast of their good looks and their charisma but as the name would imply, they are also bullies preying on the "less-popular" girls.
For some, their presence serves as inspiration for the so-called "ugly ducklings" who would later turn out as beautiful swans.
They become the trend-setter in fashion and ugly-ducklings could take a pointer or two from these mean girls.
The Brainiacs -- A constant name in the honor roll, these nerds excel on virtually all academic subjects.
Everybody wants to sit near this person during exams.
Braniacs despise their fellow braniacs who are gunning for the top honors.
Some would turn out to be helpful but some are also victims of bullying as they forced to work on bullies' assignments in exchange for their safety.

The Artists -- They either excel in drawing, music or other performing arts.
You often see them making doodles when bored in class while some are the centers of attraction during the recess or lunchtime jam sessions.
Others, meanwhile, are the common faces you see during dance intermission numbers in school events and they usually steal the limelight in role-playing activities in class.
The Gamers -- These people are a different type of nerd.
Whether it is hand-held consoles or PC games, these people can't seem to get their games out of their head that their philosophy in life are anchored on the characters they play.
But they could still be helpful especially in preparing reports and papers since their fast hands in gaming would mean fast encoding.
The Bad Boys/Girls -- They slack off and always complain how sluggish the time is when they are in class.
At some point, they even think that their too cool to be in class so they skip it.
Later on, you'd see them sitting near the brainiacs.
The Class Clown -- It's always a light moment with these people as they know a thing or two on how they could make their classmates and teachers break out in laughter.
The Neutrals -- Their neither cool or weird.
They tend to blend in with different cliques making them very sociable persons.
These types of students that you come across in school provide pros and cons but a healthy dose of equal time spent among all these types of students could easily help you get through the school life.
Davao City: Education is here!, Davao City: Education is here!Reuel John F.
Lumawag, DAVAO City is not only the center for business and economic activity in Mindanao but it is also the center of education in the island, being the home of some of the country's top universities.
The city currently hosts five universities, University of Mindanao , Ateneo de Davao University , University of Immaculate Conception , University of Southeastern Philippines , and University of Mindanao.
Addu and UM have been granted an Autonomous Status from the Commission on Higher Education .
It also hosts more than 30 other tertiary institutions, among them are San Pedro College, Holy Cross of Davao College, Davao Medical School Foundation, and Rizal Memorial Colleges, to name a few.
Davao Association of Catholic Schools  executive director Jimmie-loe P.
Dela Vega said over the years educational institutions in the city have been continually upgrading themselves and maintain their quality in accordance with the minimum standards set by the government regulating agencies.
"Beyond complying with the minimum standards most of the schools here in Davao have also voluntarily subjected themselves to a process that aims for a quality beyond what is being prescribed by the government," he said.
Dela Vega said another distinction that makes Davao City as the center of education in Mindanao is that its universities and colleges offers quality education that can level those of the top universities in the country's urban centers, like Manila and Cebu, at a more affordable price.
"Quality higher education at a more affordable rate," he said.
Davao City's overall environment also gives it an edge when it comes to conduciveness of the city for studying.
"Families feel secure to send their children here.
The quality of life and the environment is relatively better compared to bigger cities," Dela Vega said.
He said Davao City enjoys a dynamic academic community with higher education institutions, whether sectarian or non-sectarian.
"There is a lively academic interaction among learning institutions in different areas like research and sharing of best practices," Dela Vega said.
"These I believe are some of the reasons why the quality of higher education of Davao City is at par with other urban centers," he added.
Free to study, free to play, Free to study, free to playMarianne L.
Saberon-Abalayan, NOT everybody gets to study in college for free as it really is costly to take even a two-year or four-year course.
Thus, gifted students avail of different types of scholarships offered by big colleges or universities.
Most popular of which is the varsity scholarship.
Any student may apply, be scouted or recruited for a varsity scholarship.
Exceptional ones get better benefits.
The University of Mindanao , Emar Human and Environmental College, Rizal Memorial Colleges , Jose Maria College , Agro-Industrial Foundation College of the Philippines , Holy Cross of Davao College, DMMA College of Southern Philippines and Mats College of Technology are among those schools in Davao City that have good varsity scholarship programs.
UM has some 240 varsity scholars in most events catered by the Private Schools Athletic Association , according to sports director Joaquin "Boy" Sarabia.
His assistant Vincent Ryan Sarabia said athletes are categorized as Class A or national-caliber ones and class B are those with achievements in regional meets.
A Class A student-athlete enjoys a full scholarship while a Class B athlete gets 75 percent scholarship but both avail of P150 meal allowance per week for three training days, free rubber shoes and  playing uniforms.

PBA Purefoods Star Hotshots' Peter June Simon and Alaska Aces' Samigue Eman are notable products of UM's varsity scholarship program.
Emar, meanwhile, has at least 200 High School and college varsity scholars.
Emar president Ma.
Lita Montalban said, "They never pay anything - free tuition, free miscellaneous, free meals whether they win or lose in a game and free uniforms.
Even graduation fees are free for them."
Montalban, in an interview, added: "I believe that sports is the best intervention for values formation of students to keep them away from gangs and vices.
Our student-athletes give the best advertisement for the school."
RMC sports coordinator Annie Mana-ay, for her part, said they maintain 45 varsity scholars in men's and women's basketball, football and taekwondo.
Their class A1 "national players" are free in tuition and miscellaneous excluding IDs and insurance while class A "regional players" are also free in tuition but only 50 percent off in miscellaneous.
JMC, according to sports director Mark Alemania, keeps some 70 student-athletes who avail of free tuition, free allowance and free board and lodging for those not from Davao City.
Just like the others, JMC also classifies varsity scholars into A+  or A .
While class A+ are free in tuition and miscellaneous, class A receives free tuition but pays minimal miscellaneous fees.
Transportation allowance  is P150 per week for each athlete.
But what sets JMC apart from the rest, Pastor Apollo C.
Quiboloy treats his champions with all-expense-paid trip abroad.
Alemania said, "We have athletes who were sent to Hong Kong as a gift from Pastor Quiboloy."
It's very interesting to note indeed that student-athletes have to maintain passing grades or specific averages to keep their scholarships.
An upside of being a varsity scholar is being able to study for free and enjoy playing the sport one loves like getting the best of both worlds.

Getting the right course, Getting the right courseKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, CHOOSING a course for college is certainly not an easy undertaking for a new high school graduate to do.
High School graduates should sway from choosing courses because of its popularity but instead consider taking courses in line with the demands of the market.

The Commission on Higher Education  last March 25, 2014 released the official list of in-demand and priority college courses for 2014 until 2018.

According to the list, the most in-demand college courses include agriculture, engineering, science and technology, math, information technology , teacher education and health sciences.
The highest in-demand college course goes to the fields of Agriculture and Engineering with 15% followed by Science and Math at 13%.
Information Technology , Teacher Education and Health Sciences came in third at 10% while Arts and Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Business Administration, and Architecture settled at the fourth spot with 5%.
Maritime and Communication were last at 2%.
 
Possible courses under the agriculture field are Agro-Forestry, Veterinary Medicine, Agricultural Engineering, Agribusiness/Management, Agricultural Technology, Fisheries, BS Food Technology and Agricultural Economics.
Other available courses under the Engineering field are Mechanical, Electronics, Communication, Metallurgical Mining, Computer, Biomedical, Chemical, Geodetic, Electrical, Meteorological, Mining, Geological, Sanity Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Industrial Engineering, Civil Engineering, Petroleum Engineering and Bio-Chemical Engineering.
Dr.
Judith Dalagan, mass communication program chair and full-time professor at the Ateneo de Davao University , in an interview with Sun.Star Davao at her office recently, shared that incoming students must be able to identify first the career path they want to pursue, saying:"If you don't know the career path you're undertaking then you would not know how can you equip yourself with the right skills?."
"I know a lot of people who have succeeded in their careers because they knew what they want.
But your degree can only be your passport sometime in the real world.
The real world does not have to put you in that box with what your degree can offer," Dr.
Dalagan added.
She, meanwhile, bared that job mismatch has been a trend or reality here in the Philippines, saying:"We offer a lot computer engineering but we don't have computer industry.
We produced a lot of accounting graduates but we only have few big firms for them."
"But the point here is that even if you don't practice your degree as long as you have that sense of fulfillment in what you're doing and at the same time you've helped the society better economically then you made yourself a productive member in society in your own little way," Dr.
Dalagan said.
 
The Department of Labor and Employment , for its part, encouraged the incoming college students to pick courses that would land them jobs after graduation.
Quick Facts: DepEd's K to 12 Program, Quick Facts: DepEd's K to 12 ProgramKriztja Marae G.
Labrador, WITH the K to 12 program set on full implementation next year, here are the top five things that you need to know about it.
Background
The program, according to the Official Gazette, "covers Kindergarten and 12 years of basic education." The additional years aims to provide enough time for "mastery of concepts and skills, develop lifelong learners, and prepare graduates for tertiary education, middle-level skills development, employment, and entrepreneurship."
The implementation of the program is pursuant to the Enhanced Basic Education Act of 2013 signed by President Benigno Aquino III on May 15, 2013.
1.
K to 12 is being implemented gradually
The Department of Education  began the implementation of universal Kindergarten in school year  2011-2012, new curriculum for grade one and grade seven was rolled out in SY 2012-2013, and new curriculum for grade two and grade eight was rolled out in SY 2013-2014.
Grade 11 is set to be introduced next SY, 2016-2017, and grade 12 in SY 2017-2018.
First batch of K to 12 graduates are expected to graduate on March 2018.
2.
K to 12 enhances Mother Tongue-Based Multilingual Education
Starting in Kindergarten, the mother tongue, or the common language in the area shall be used as the medium for instruction, this, according to the Official Gazette, "students are able to learn best through their first language." From grades one to three, mother tongue together with English and Filipino will be used as language for instruction and will gradually transition to English and Filipino from grades four onwards.
3.
Specialized education for K to 12 students
Upon reaching Senior High School , the program will allow students to choose a specialization from the three tracks: Academic; Technical-Vocational-Livelihood; and Sports and Arts.
The student's choice of career track will define the content of the subjects he/she will take in Grades 11 and 12.
4.
K to 12 graduates are job ready
A student can obtain Certificates of Competency  or a National Certificate Level I  after grade 10 and a National Certificate Level II  after finishing a Technical-Vocational-Livelihood track in Grade 12, provided he/she passes the competency-based assessment of the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority .
NC I and NC II improves employability of graduates in fields like Agriculture, Electronics, and Trade which provides students an option for entrepreneurship, employment, or further education.
5.
Last country in Asia to implement K to 12
According to Rappler.com, prior to the its implementation, "the Philippines is the last country in Asia, and one of only 3 countries  worldwide, with a 10-year pre-university cycle."
With the implementation of the K to 12, Commission on Higher Education -Davao director Raul C.
Alvarez previously said that this will increase the competitiveness of student graduates in the country.

Overcoming life's rocky roads, Overcoming life's rocky roadsIvy C.
Tejano, "IT DOES not matter how long it will take as long as you never give up."
This, according to Marilou Pamaong Padungao, who is a teacher at Kumon Method of Learning Center in Davao City for eight years now.
Born in Katipunan, Alicia, Bohol in Central Visayas in 1990, Padungao completed Bachelor of Science in Education from University of Mindanao in 2013.
Padungao is already a licensed teacher after she passed the Licensure Examination for Teachers  in September 29, 2013.
She may not be popular like the other students in her school but her anecdote is worth pondering for those who just waste the wealth of their parents with their failing grades.
Padungao ventured to Davao City on July 2006 with her ambition to enter a university and finish her studies with the help of her aunt.
But that wasn't what happened.
Due to unexpected circumstance, Padungao's aunt could not financially support her in her studies.
"Ni sabot ko kay pamilyado man gud akong auntie.
Wala ko mabuhat na ni ana.
What I felt that time is fear...
fear that I could no longer reach my dream," Padungao said.
She said instead of her aunt, her cousin gave her tuition to enter the university, but she knew this will not take long.
Her cousin cannot sustain the expenses needed.
"Dili baya may kaya among pamilya.
Tanan kailangan haguan para lang maka-survive.
So, I have to look for other means to be able to survive in Davao," she added.
Padungao said before she left her family and siblings in Bohol, she promised to herself that she would graduate in college and have a decent job here, so she could help them.
She applied for a scholarship at the University of Mindanao where she was assigned as office staff in the Public Employment Service Officer  on 2006.
"Matagaan pa man ko allowance either sa akong auntie or pinsan pero dili man jud na magdugay mao nakahuna-huna pa jud ko mangita ug trabaho," Padungao said.
Padungao started working at Kumon as an assistant teacher in 2007 until she became a regular teacher of the center up to the present.
Despite of the heavy responsibilities on her shoulders, Padungao said she focused on her duties as a working student.
"Naa jud panahon na bation nimo ang kakapoy.
Dili baya dali maging working student.
Buti unta kung akong sarili lang ako ginabuhi, naga-padala pud ko sa Bohol," she said.
"I remember those times na akong dinner is watermelon lang, makakaon man sakto if kaya pa sa budget.
Pugong jud sa kwarta kay ga-board naman lang ko diri," she added.
It took quite some time before Padungao completed her study as there were semesters that she had to stop and focus on her work, to earn enough and study again.
What keeps her going is her faith in God and dream of becoming a full-fledged teacher, which it really happened also because of her hard work.
Padungao is grateful with what she have reached now.
She said if there's one thing she would like to teach to the students nowadays, it perseverance to education.
"I would say it again and again; poverty is not a hindrance for us to achieve our dream.
It is only through education we could attain a better life," Padungao said.

Quick tips to doing well in school, Quick tips to doing well in schoolEdward C.
Lactaoen, BEING in school is a struggle.
What with all the books to study, homework to do and projects to pass, it's a wonder how to keep up with the constant demands that school puts on students.
Luckily, some people who finished schooling with flying colors are here to share with you some advice to do better in school.

2015 Mutya ng Davao Kris Abegail Guanzon graduated from Ateneo de Davao University in 2013 with a degree in AB Mass Communication.
She also graduated with the distinctions of Cum Laude and Humanities and Letters Division Awardee.
Here are three tips from her to help oneself through school:
1.
Set your priorities.
Knowing your priorities as a student makes you more productive esp.
when you are bombarded with deadlines.
2.
Be active in school.
This is somehow a breather from all the academic stuff.
Also, this is an opportunity to be engaged in things you are passionate about.
3.
Take a break! After all the busyness brought by your acads and non-acads, learn to reward yourself.
It can be a quick stroll at the mall or whole-day Game of Thrones marathon!
Hijo Resources Corporation's Digital Marketing and Social Media Specialist, Reymond Pepito, who also graduated with a degree from Ateneo de Davao University in AB Mass Communication and was the Humanities Division Awardee in 2012, while juggling responsibilities with the school paper, Ateneo Debate Varsity and College Editors Guild of the Philippines also has some things to share:
1.
Set a goal.
Always begin with an end in mind.
It is important for you to choose a specific and realistic goal.
By putting value on something that you desire to achieve, it will make you even more motivated to do more in school in any given circumstances.

2.
Make studying a habit.
Confidence is a good thing but over-confidence is negligence.
At some point, be paranoid.
Make sure you've studied your lessons before taking the examinations.
Do not enter the classroom without your accomplished assignments and reports.
More than being a good student, studying is a form of discipline that will make you a responsible person.

3.
Have fun.
Participate in extra-curricular activities like joining the school paper, a sporting club, and the like.
Not all learnings can be found in the four corners of your classroom.
Lastly, Kriza Faye Calumba, who studied BS Food Technology at UP Mindanao and graduated as Magna Cum Laude and Class Valedictorian in 2014, has some advice to share as well:
1.
Learn to accept failure.
Failure is inevitable.
Don't wallow in gloom when you fail an exam or when you don't get a perfect score in a very easy quiz.
Instead of being disappointed with yourself, treat that failure as an opportunity to do better next time.
As Confucius said, "Our greatest glory is not in never failing, but in rising every time we fail." 
2.
Strive for excellence.
You can do more than what you think you can.
Give your best shot in everything and always remember to compete with yourself.
Strive for excellence not only within the four corners of the classroom, but also in your other endeavors.
3.
Get involved.
Practice the art of balancing.
Grades aren't everything.
Be involved - join organizations which will best help you pursue your passion, meet new people.
Make the most of various opportunities for you to be more socially aware, culturally sensitive, and understanding of the plight of others.
Being active in school doesn't only mold you into a well-rounded individual, but also allows you to pursue what genuinely makes you happy.

Also, know your priorities and effectively manage your time.
Learn when to work and when to play.
Don't forget to have fun!

Casas, WE SPEND almost 10 hours in school, coping up with the lessons and joining some extra-curricular activities.
However, school is not all about books, lessons, projects, and assignments.
We also experience a lot of things about life-mostly funny.
Below are some brave testimonials of students and former students who had funny and "embarrassing" moments in school:
Ara, 24, Davao City:
We had a small chitchat with high school friends under our favorite tree during recess time.
We spent the whole time sharing funny experiences about a school event.
When it was my turn to say something funny, it turned out to be so, so embarrassing.
Why? I had colds that time and so, yeah, I ended up with a "bubble" of snot coming out my nose!
Ana, 18, General Santos City:
I was at first year high school that time and the school conducted a symposium on anti-rabies.
We were asked to join the symposium by class and by different year levels.
Together with my girl friend Kristel, we chose to sit at the back and beside my friend was our annoying classmate, Macky.
After the symposium, the guest speakers asked us to submit questions and on a 1/8 sheet of paper.
The question that I formed was "Maam, ingun nila, pag mapaakan ka ug iro, inuman daw ug shoktong? ." I wrote it dowm and due to my craziness, I used one of my classmate's name, who happened a target for pranks.

Fatima, 24, Mati City:
I hated my Grade 1 teacher for scolding me in front of my classmates.
During recess time, I rushed to one of the Indian trees near the quadrangle to cry due to humiliation.
However, my emotion grew into anger and resulted me to carve something that is "below the belt" into the tree against my teacher.
All this time, I thought she didn't know about it.
Lucky me, I still graduate with flying colors.
Many years have passed and we accidentally got to see each other again in a famous restaurant in Davao City.
Without any hesitation, she smiled, approached me and exclaimed: "Hi, Fatima! How are you? You were my favorite student then.
You know why? I could never ever forget what you wrote in that tree." And so, I was left tongue-tied and my face turned as red as blood.
RJ, 23, Davao City:
It was during my math exam when I was in grade 4.
My tummy was feeling funny and next thing I knew, I needed to poop.
But the comfort room at school was not the best place to do waste management.
Then I farted, which was followed by creamy poop.

I was wearing white shorts that time and I knew that there will be a glorious poop stain.
