Tips before shopping, Tips before shoppingAntonio L.
Colina IV, BARELY two months from now, students will be again ecstatic for the opening of the school year.
What makes them more excited though is when parents bring them to shop for new school stuffs.
Here are a few things to consider before deciding to burn your cash on a shopping spree:
Tip 1.
Check budget
Always check how much you can dispense out of your pocket.
From there, make a list of the things you need to buy for your kids, from bags, to notebooks, to pencils, and to new school uniforms.
Tip 2.
Choose quality over quantity
It pays to buy quality products at higher cost if that can last long.
Also, learn from the experiences of the past: which brands can fit best your tykes? Are they the type who give value to their possessions, or the ones, sorry, who are careless?
Tip 3.
Choose value-for-money
But quality doesn't always have to come at a price.
There are products that can assure you of quality at an affordable cost.
Tip 4.
Learn to re-use
Why buy new if you can re-use? That's why, it's important that we choose quality over quantity because you can save up a penny or two in a long run.
And what you've saved up you can allocate to buy additional stuff.
For bags, if you are creative enough, it needs a few decorative touches to make it good as new.
Tip 5.
Never go on impulse shopping
Don't be at the mercy of your impulses when you go shopping, or else you will end up depleting you savings or end up cursing yourself for buying the unnecessary.
Advice: be mindful of things that are needed by your kids.
No more, no less.
An Ifugao town's journey to progress and prosperity, An Ifugao town's journey to progress and prosperityLAMUT, Ifugao -- Called the "Gateway Municipality of Ifugao", this town was once a lowly community with poor road networks and high incidence of poverty.
Although blessed with vast tracts of flat lands and rolling hills, large part of the area consisted of idle and unproductive grasslands mostly used for grazing cattle and other ruminants because of lack of water and irrigation supply.

Agricultural production was also very poor.
The value of land then was very cheap since few people had the patience of toiling and making it productive.
Buyers were scarce with the harsh reality it would be difficult living in the area as travel and communication in the place was hard due to lack of road networks, communication facilities and other infrastructures.

But situation changed with the construction of the Hapid National Irrigation System along the Bulao River of this town in the late 1990s.

From a gloomy and laidback life, the future turned rosy with the place transformed into a bustling and busy commercial and trade center.

Following the completion of the irrigation system, many people became interested in buying and owning lands in the area.
And the value of the once cheap lands skyrocketed.

Still, more people were drawn to reside in the place because of the promise of a bright future.

Soon, the vast tract of flat and grassy idle lands were converted into irrigated rice fields and agricultural farmlands bringing the owners and people bountiful harvest each cropping while other parts of the lands were also excavated and turned into fishponds producing the tilapia fish.

Today, after a decade of the water supply paving the way for agricultural development, the municipality of Lamut is now a 4th class municipality and continuously emerging as an investment frontier rapidly overtaking the rest of the towns of Ifugao in terms of progress and development with a growth rate of 2.28%.

Lamut has a land area of 14,581.25 hectares  with 5,480.18 has.
for agriculture; 5,390 has.
for watershed forestry; 1,550 has.
as pastureland and 1,641.02 as built-up area.
It has a total population of 23,080 .
As of the latest survey of roads, the municipality has a total road inventory of 182.63 kilometers with 18% or 33.5 kms.
 already paved; 81.5 kms.
or 45% graveled and 67.93 kms.
or 37% of it is earth road.

Communication  in the area also  improved basically  through postal communication and speed mail services, local broadcast services, telephone and cellular mobile phone services, internet services, cable television and private satellite dish telephone services.

The town has   two hotels and inns, two banking institutions, three  registered cooperatives,  two registered private financing institutions and 502 registered firms.

Likewise, the construction of a bigger district hospital  at Barangay Banting expanded its role for the accommodation of health services and facilities with a province-wide coverage after the de-commissioning of the Ifugao General Hospital in Lagawe  with its worn out building  no longer fit for operations.

As an emerging agro-industrial center, the municipality has trading centers that function as "bagsakan" or drop-off areas for the wholesale transaction of products and goods.
There is also the Provincial Livelihood Center  that showcases Ifugao products and provides market linkage among buyers and producers.

The town boasts of its  flourishing  tilapia  fish production.
Tilapia  was chosen as the One-Town-One Product  of the municipality with the slogan 201cFish and Development201d .
 The fishpond areas of the place cover a total of 92 has.
owned by 250 fisherfolks with a total of 1,000 farm workers that produce an average of 1,000 tons of fish per annum.

Together with the municipality of Alfonso Lista,  theys made Ifugao the top producer of in-land fish in the Cordillera Administrative Region.
The presence of the Provincial Hatchery and the Regional Hatchery for Pangasius   in the municipality makes  Lamut the center for Tilapia and Pangasius production in the province.

Being the gateway of the province, the town has the comparative advantage as a major link to the lowland provinces of Nueva Vizcaya, Quirino and Isabela offering opportunities to trade and market development not only of the municipality but for the entire province of Ifugao.

Indeed the municipality has traveled a long way to progress and development.
Aside from fish production, it is an investment area for the manufacture of agro-based products, rice and corn trading and milling, production of high value crops, organically grown products, cattle production, agricultural contract growing, agricultural inputs and agricultural financing.

Forever a teacher, Forever a teacherKriztja Marae G.
Labrador, IN FALLING in love, they say "age does not matter."
This proves true for Azucena Tanguanco Bajao, who fell in love with teaching and still continues to live this love by teaching others on the daily walks of life.
Azucena served as a teacher for more than 31 years, wherein her main mission up to this day is to instill moral values not only to children but also to their parents.
"I love to teach children, teaching moral values to them, I am really particular with moral values including the parents, at least I can share my experience and also the religious aspect to them," she said in vernacular.
Azucena was born in Tangalan, Aklan on June 25, 1947 and they moved to Davao eight months after she was born.
Most of her growing up years, she had her grandparents as her guardians.
From them, she learned the values she lives and shares with others.

"I remember before my lola would tell me to sleep early so that I can wake up at 4 a.m.
to study and to never miss church," she said.
Azucena finished her elementary education at Sta.
Ana Elementary School in 1959 and her high school education at Davao City High School in 1963.
She then finished her bachelor's degree in Elementary Education at the University of Mindanao in 1967 and her master's degree in Guidance and Counseling at the International Hardvardian University in 1985.
After her service as a teacher and as a guidance counselor for six years, she became the barangay kagawad in Buhangin proper in 2003 during which she was also the president of the religious group Gamayng Kristohanong Katilingban  at that time.
Azucena has been serving as the Office of the Senior Citizen Affairs  head since 2011.
"I am very happy in helping others," she said.
Being blessed with a loving husband, five children and six grandchildren, Azucena still continues sharing the values she had learned from her lolo and lola not only by living them day to day but also serving as resource speaker to the Davao City Social Services and Development Office on responsible parenthood.
From small to great, From small to greatMaria Gemima C.
Valderrama, THE growth of one is the growth of all.
 This is perhaps the most essential part of cooperatives.
Maco Development Cooperative  just celebrated 25 years of operation.
 In its silver anniversary, Chairman of the Board Manuel M.
Esperanza remembers their humble beginnings with a grateful heart.
Madeco started as a little sari-sari store put up by Fr.
Rolando Macale, the parish priest of Maco which was still part of Davao del Norte then.
Esperanza said it became Maco Consumer Cooperative or Macoco in 1986.
 It grew into nine branches but only one store stood the test of time.
Only Branch 5, he said, was left and determined members turned it into a cooperative.
 But it wasn2019t that easy as Madeco became one of those dying cooperatives in the country.
 
An organization from Canada, Esperanza said, helped Madeco rise to become a cooperative to truly serve not just the people of Maco, but the entire province as well.
 In 1990, Madeco was duly registered with the Cooperative Development Authority as a multi-purpose cooperative.
Cooperatives in the Philippines are recognized with an important role in the development of the nation.
Cooperatives are based on the values of self-help, self-responsibility, democracy, equality, equity, and solidarity.
In the tradition of their founders, cooperative members believe in the ethical values of honesty, openness, social responsibility, and caring for others.
Madeco, in two and a half decades, continues its campaign in reaching out the people in the community.
As a fast growing cooperative, Madeco gives credit to the determination of Francisco and Victoria Capoy, Carmen Gado, Annielita Torreflores, Cerelita Vital, Nenita Costiniano, and Rolando Aceberos, who helped them stand on their own.
After 25 years, Madeco has established four branches located in Maco, Mabini, Tagum, and Mawab with about 80 employees all in all.
 It plans to open another branch in Davao to expand its membership, products, and services.
Madeco has savings and credit where they create the opportunity for people to take responsibility of their own financial resources.
 They encourage members to save and they promote thriftiness so that members will inculcate the habit of saving.
 They look at the members2019 finances and ensure that they are spending less than they earn.
Today, Madeco has payroll servicing, LTO processing, time deposit, share capital, kiddie youth club for 17 years old and below who want to save, and insurance.
The little sari-sari store in 1990 has now become Madeco Mart, a growing mini-mart.
 It is now located in a bigger area and it assists members with sari-sari stores as they are given credit lines and reward cards where they can earn points.
Madeco also engaged in gasoline business since 2009.
 The idea came out to provide a much needed fuelling resource in Maco area.
Today, they have an additional installation of gas pumps.
 The benefits of members who have capital share invested in gasoline include earning dividend and patronage refund based on the purchases they made for the year.
Madeco obviously was an epitome of 201clittle things make big things happen201d.
Esperanza remembers that their first few meetings were held in a waiting shed where they can sit freely and gather together with their favourite maruya and iced water as their snacks.
 He jokingly said that soon they were able to add pancit in that gathering in the waiting shed.
Now they have accumulated a building where they can hold meetings and big gatherings.
 Madeco may not be as big as the other cooperatives but its founders, officers, and members have proven that it surpassed all the different challenges in the phases of economy.
Chairman Esperanza said the present officers will try their best to make Madeco more responsive to the needs of the members.
201cWe do not just want Madeco to survive; we want it to live vibrantly.
 We do not just manage it; we want to create opportunities for all so that Madeco will help build a community of people whose dreams can be realized,201d he said.
The Board of Directors are composed of educators, engineer, accountants, and businessmen.
Chairman Esperanza2019s leadership is supported by the Board of Directors Abenir O.
Labja, Xerlito E.
Torculas, Ramel C.
Tuba, Russel R.
Nuneza, Felixberto L.
Leray, and Marcelino P.
Alicarte.
For them, Madeco will transform communities, build lives, and connect with the global community.
Off the streets, Off the streets

HIS life journey has been trending on social media after his story was posted on Facebook that reached more than 50,000 shares.
From being a street kid to a Development Communication graduate at the Jesuit-run Xavier University in 2014, Rustie Quintana, 25, showed how he has turned the impossible to possible by just dreaming on and working hard to achieve those dreams while putting God first before anything else.
Leaving home, exposing himself to drugs, getting in-out of various rescue centers, and being arrested, all these had become imprints of his life.
He never wanted those dark days in his life but he was just a kid back then.
A misguided one who was exposed to an environment that influenced him in the most indecent way.
 
Giving back
Now that he has something he wants to impart, Rustie spends his time with the street children in Cogon area or Divisoria.
One of his goals is to help get other kids off the streets.
He can2019t give back by giving money, but what he can do is bring them to the Alternative Learning System , if they are willing to learn.
If they can pass ALS, they can proceed to getting vocational courses at the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority .
He meets with the street kids once a week to ask them about their education.
If ever they have questions, he helps them out in any way that he could.
Rustie recalled that a friend, he once took to ALS, now based abroad is doing well.
201cUbanan jud nako hantud makita nako ang impact,201d he said.
Knowing that he is doing well outside, it leaves certain happiness in Rustie2019s heart because he has helped him grow by doing his part.

He wants to inspire the kids by sharing his experiences and talents.
Encouraging them that anything can happen if they so believe that they can.

Defining moment
Rustie used to think that he couldn2019t do it, but a defining moment came to change his mind.

He remembered a time when he was young that while sitting on a tree past midnight and playing his flute.
He was looking on the street kids and it saddened him how they were wasting every moment of their lives.
But what made him cry was seeing an old man pushing a cart.
He cried wondering how he could change things, because he did not want to be like the old man.
 
But rather, he2019d want to grow old with his wife and children.
And see his children have children.
To live in a house they can call home.
A life knowing that everything is in place and worrying is no longer needed.
 
201cPag graduate nako, malipayon kaayo ko kay nakab-ot nko akong goal.
Mao man gud ning akong number one nga gina-ampo.
Dili gud ko makatuo na mahuman jud nako,201d Rustie said.
Despite the difficulties and challenges he met as he entered the university life, Rustie certainly had the drive to finish it.

2018Arts for scholarship2019
Currently, he2019s teaching kids in 201cArts for Scholarship201d workshop with his fellow artist Mauwee Mangcong at Ni\xf1o Maria Learning Center.
They cater to everyone especially the out-of-school youth, scholars, and others.
They not only want them to enhance their skills in painting, but the workshop also offers other modules like dancing and bamboo-flute making.

201cLibre tanan gamit.
Mura sad sila gaanhi para maglingaw-lingaw,201d Rustie said.

There is a summer promo offering at P500 a month and Rustie said that a lot of kids have already enrolled not only to learn but to also have fun.

Worries on work
While doing something on giving back, he has something to worry about2014work.
He2019s been receiving invites for guesting and hiring though, which is not on regular basis.
And what worries him is his family
considering that Rustie is the bread winner.
He has to provide his family their needs, like what a father does.
201cIf mag trabaho ko2019g layo, mapasmo akong pamilya,201d he said.
Also, he doesn2019t have the money to travel that far right now.

He said that it2019s even difficult to look for money to buy rice.
Not to mention the rent they have to pay.
Rustie2019s family has a land in Butuan but it2019s not the same as having it and calling it your own.
 
After his story was published online, he was grateful that people were inspired by his story.
Meanwhile, there are also other people who are judging him and labelled him to be into a 201cdrug syndicate.201d With this, he said: 201cWhen I was doing those things, I was still young.
Nobody taught me what was right, what was wrong.201d 
Although he2019s grateful that people are congratulating him for what he has attained, it2019s not helping him in any way with his living.
201cIf they can donate rice, that would be a big help to me and my family,201d he quipped.

201cDili ko rich, pero rich ko2019g talents,201d he said.

He earns by doing what he does best 2013 using his artistic abilities: 201cIf people are interested to buy my paintings, they are more than welcome to do so.201d
Looking back at everything he has been through, he thanked the people who believed in him, Mother Teresa Foundation, and especially God for helping him become the person he is right now.

Staying at Mother Teresa Foundation for four years has taught him a lot of things.
He learned to have the right attitude, values, and found God that made him into a very prayerful person.

Rustie said that he and God have a special kind of relationship, that God understands him.
201cWithout Him, I wouldn2019t have gone this far,201d he said.

201cKung limpyo imong kasingkasing, ang blessings, moabot ra na,201d he said.

He invests in love saying that 201cwe should do the same as well,201d as placed his right hand in his left chest.
 
201cBlessings do come,201d he said.

201cDili sa ka bright or kabugok sa tawo, paningkamutan jud na nimo,201d he added.

201cOut from nothing, and now it2019s everything,201d he said.

If Rustie conquered the challenges that life threw at him, others can surely do so.

Masbad: Graduation gifts, Masbad: Graduation giftsRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, IT'S graduation season! Congratulations to the graduates of 2015! 
For the college graduates, welcome to the world outside the halls of academe! It2019s a dog-eat-dog world out here as some would say.
But in most cases, it2019s just the world being real.
Nothing fancy schmancy about it.

So, this week I have a few suggestions what to get for yourself as a gift after crawling through college.

Cloud Storage
If you2019re not using any cloud storage until now, you should be.
Moreso if you2019re using smartphones or tablets.
It will save your behind in more ways than one especially if you have critical work files.
Imagine yourself saving those files to a USB drive and minutes before your crucial presentation, those USB drives suddenly don2019t work.
What do you do? That2019s where cloud storage can literally save you and your career.

If you have a Google account, you already have Google Drive.
Use that.
If you don2019t have a Dropbox account yet, get one already.
Use that.
Those are the top two options I2019d recommend because I use them myself and have never failed me.
Oh, they both have apps that you can download to your devices so you can have access to your files 24/7.

Notebook and Pen
Yes, the good ol2019 notebook & pen combo.
Keep it stashed in your bag.
It will be an indispensable pair of tools to keep up with your ever-creative mind.
Let2019s face it, there are a lot of times that an idea of slew of ideas come to mind that you just have to record.
Unfortunately, our electronic devices can2019t catch up to how fast our brains process these things.
The closest things that can are our hands paired with a good writing pen and a notebook to write on.

Look for those quirky notebook designs that speak of your personality.
It can be a lined-page notebook or a blank-page notebook.
It doesn2019t matter.
What matters more here is that it2019s an analog solution to keeping up with your active mind.

A Good Book
Get yourself a book.
Not an eBook.
A book! A physical book with real paper bound together with that definitive smell of a new book when you first open it.
I recommend a non-fiction book; something to help you grow; something to help you develop your inner strengths; something on leadership perhaps.

A book never runs out of batteries and it never needs a cellular or wi-fi signal to be accessed.
It just needs to be brought out of your bag and the pages turned.
Simple.
Glorious.
Exhilarating.

In the end, whatever it is that you2019ll get for yourself as a gift, use it as a tool to help yourself.
Don2019t let it be what dictates how you work or how you solve problems.
Just because your USB drive failed on you doesn2019t mean you can2019t make your presentation.
Be creative.
Be spontaneous.

Life is like a box of chocolates.
You2019ll never know what you2019ll get.

Congratulations again graduates! May your journey be filled with everything that life has to offer and may these mold you into the person you are meant to be.
Village chief is now lawyer, Village chief is now lawyerRhona Goc-ong-Villariasa, SECOND chances are not given to make things right, but to prove that one can do better even after a fall.
He did not succeed in his first hitch in the Bar examination, but it didn't prevent Joseph Patrick O.
Escovilla, barangay captain of Megkawayan in Calinan District, to strive more and try his luck the second time around.
Escovilla is just one of the thousands examinees who passed the Bar exams held in October 2014.
This, for Escovilla, is a big blessing for him, an answered prayer after all the sacrifices and sleepless nights he had.
Based on the results, 1,126 passed the 2014 bar exam out of 5,984 takers or a national passing average of 18.825 percent.
As a public servant, Escovilla tried his best to balance his work as a barangay captain while spending quality time for his Bar review.
"Nagre-review ako five times a week.
Self-review lang ako sa mga coffee shops.
Then I visit the barangay Tuesdays and Fridays, that time yung constituents natin alam na nila na andun ako, kaya by that time pumupunta sila ng barangay for their concerns," said Escovilla, who expressed gratitude to his constituents for their understanding during the crucial days of his review.
"You have to read a lot of books, bale quota-quota ka dapat sa natatapos mong basahin.
You have to study eight subjects, di talaga ganun kadali," said Escovilla, who spent six months of sleepless and tiring days and nights for his review.
It wasn't for the first time that Escovilla took the Bar exams.
He admitted he took the Bar before but he was not able to make it.

He didn't deny that he felt down upon knowing the result, but somehow he realized he needs to exert more time and effort if he want to succeed.

"Second time na to, mas grabe yung first time kasi I was on leave talaga for my review sa Manila, but it didn2019t materialize, so I told myself, dito na lang ako, self-review na lang tayo.
So what I did, report sa barangay, then review, naka-survive din naman," he said.
This second termer barangay captain of Barangay Megkawayan started his law course at Ateneo de Davao University, but finished it at Cor Jesu College last 2013.
He lamented that at his young age he already dreamt of becoming a lawyer.
"Grade 6 sa yearbook namin nilagay ko dun I want to be a lawyer.
Yun yung dala-dala ko till I reach college."
Now that he is a lawyer, Escovilla said this is a big help to someone like him who2019s into public service.
"Mas okay talaga if you are knowledgeable sa law.
Whatever man yung natutunan ko, I will impart this sa mga constituents ko.
Eto rin yung hiningi ko sa Diyos na pag ibinigay niya sa akin, I won2019t hesitate to give it back to the people," he said.
At the age of 27, Escovilla has a lot of plans on his head, not only for the people around him, much more to himself.
A proud son of a businessman named Glenn and a Certified Public Accountant mother named Maria Delia, Escovilla grew in an environment that has much interaction with the public.
His father was also a former chief of barangay of Megkawayan.
"Nasanay nako sa maraming tao, kaya it2019s not hard for me to adjust when I seek for a position sa barangay.
After sa term ng father ko, ako yung pumalit, and since then, till now ang dami ko pang gustong gawin before I end up my term," he said.
Born June 23, 1987, the eldest of four siblings, five years from now, Escovilla dreams of having his own family and a law firm.
When asked if he wants to venture on a much higher position, Escovilla answered: "Sa puso ko wala na, mas uunahin ko muna yung barangay ko.
Marami pa akong gusto gawin, I2019ll focus muna dun."
Escovilla2019s determination to excel despite the adversities is an example of what they say "never say die."
He failed on some aspect but he bounced back on his second chance and tried to do better.

This young public servant believes that even if life sometimes drag him with difficulties, he just imagine that these are just trials that will bring him into something greater opportunities.

Masbad: #PrayforNepal, Masbad: #PrayforNepalRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, I HAVE never been to Nepal.
I, however, have a classmate from my master2019s degree classes who is from Nepal.

Microsoft opens Windows 10 to Apple, Android apps, Microsoft opens Windows 10 to Apple, Android apps
Joe Belfiore, Microsoft Corporate Vice President of Operating Systems Group, demonstrates Continuum for phones at the Microsoft Build conference in San Francisco, Wednesday, April 29, 2015.
While Microsoft has already previewed some aspects of the new Windows 10, a parade of top executives will use the conference to demonstrate more software features and app-building tools, with an emphasis on mobile devices as well as PCs.

Microsoft wants to make Windows 10 the universal software for PCs, phones and other Internet-connected gadgets.
, SAN FRANCISCO 2014 Microsoft hopes to get more people using the next version of its Windows software on all kinds of devices by giving them access to many of the same apps they're already using on Apple or Android phones.
In a major strategy shift, a top executive told an audience of several thousand software developers Wednesday that Microsoft will release new tools to help them quickly adapt the apps they've built for Apple or Android gadgets, so they will work on smartphones, PCs and other devices that use the new Windows 10 operating system coming later this year.
On the first day of the company's annual software conference, other executives showed off more uses for Microsoft's holographic "augmented reality" headset, the HoloLens 2014 although it's not yet for sale.
They also announced the official name for a new web browser, called "Edge," that they promised will be faster and more useful than the Internet Explorer that's been a Microsoft mainstay for 20 years.
All those initiatives are tied to the impending release of Windows 10, the centerpiece of Microsoft's ambitions to regain the stature it commanded when Windows-based PCs dominated the computing world.
Today, after losing ground to smartphones and tablets that run software from rivals Apple and Google, Microsoft wants to make Windows 10 the universal software for PCs, phones and other Internet-connected gadgets.
"Windows 10 represents a new generation of Windows, built for an era of more personal computing," CEO Satya Nadella said during a keynote speech, adding that today's consumers and corporate workers want to have the same experience when they are using a variety of devices.
Although Microsoft has previously shown off some features of Windows 10, it's hoping to enlist an army of software developers as allies in its campaign to build enthusiasm for the new release.
The company is using the three-day conference, called Build, to demonstrate more features and app-building tools, with an emphasis on mobile devices as well as PCs.
"Our goal is to make Windows 10 the most attractive development platform ever," Vice President Terry Myerson said.
To win over consumers who use competing software, Microsoft needs to persuade outside developers, who create software for consumers and corporate clients, it's worth their time to create new apps and programs for Windows 10.
"Getting developer buy-in is absolutely the crucial thing," said J.P.
Gownder, a tech industry analyst at Forrester Research.
He said Microsoft has struggled with a "chicken-and-egg" problem, in which developers have been reluctant to build mobile apps for Windows because relatively few people use Windows phones and tablets.
Currently, there are more than 1.4 million apps for Android phones and about the same for Apple devices, while there are only a few hundred thousand apps that work on Windows phones and tablets.
Microsoft's move to help developers adapt their Apple and Android apps for Windows 10 is a major change from the past, when each company maintained rigid differences in their software platforms.
Microsoft is also hoping to entice developers by promising that apps for Windows 10 will work equally well on PCs, mobile gadgets, Xbox game consoles and even the HoloLens.
The company has another big carrot to wave in front of those developers: Microsoft has already said it will release Windows 10 as a free upgrade to people who now have PCs or other gadgets running the previous two versions of Windows, provided they upgrade in the coming year.
That could help create a huge new audience of Windows 10 users in a relatively short time, Gownder said.
Myerson predicted there will be a billion devices using Windows 10 within the next two to three years.
Apps for all those devices will be distributed through a single Windows app store.
Myerson also said Microsoft will partner with wireless carriers so consumers who lack credit cards can pay for apps on their phone bill 2014 a popular method in developing nations.
Microsoft has not said exactly when Windows 10 is coming, although some were hoping the company would announce a date on Wednesday.
Since he became CEO last year, Nadella has been presiding over a major overhaul at Microsoft.
He has redesigned some of Microsoft's most popular programs for mobile users and invested in new "cloud-computing" services, in which businesses pay to use software that's housed in Microsoft's data centers.
Microsoft announced several new initiatives Wednesday for its Azure cloud-computing service, which has emerged as a fast-growing rival to a popular cloud business operated by Amazon.
Microsoft is releasing new programming tools for Azure clients to create programs for computers that run Apple and Linux software, as well as those that run Windows.

Kid2019s First celebrates 10 years of helping kids be awesome, Kid2019s First celebrates 10 years of helping kids be awesome
Learning takes place as young children touch and manipulate things, interact with people and share their thoughts about their experiences.
This makes learning fun and more meaningful to these children.

TEACHING young children is often said to be more than just a job.
It is a vocation that requires wholehearted commitment and whose results come only in the long term.
For Kid2019s First Discovery Space, their 10 years of patience and creativity now yields a roster of kids who are happy, confident and show an eagerness to learn and explore.
Yet, celebrating the 10-year milestone is no reason to take it easy.
According to school principal Vanessa Morales-Balquiedra, toddler and preschool educators in the country still have much do to.
201cAccess to early childhood education is still limited perhaps because our culture has yet to seriously believe that learning takes place even at the youngest age.
Our government also has to strictly implement legislation by allocating a bigger budget to promote early childhood education and make this a priority,201d she said.
As a highlight of its 10-year anniversary, Kid2019s First has initiated activities to help communities improve their services to learners of any age and background.
Particularly, they will be providing school materials to MovEd.org, a non-profit group that supports daycare centers in indigent communities around the Philippines.
Also, Kid2019s First will be helping raise funds for Starlight Training School for Special Youth in creating their kitchen lab.
The Starlight School, located in Cavite, educates and trains students with special needs the vocational skills and life skills to become active, positive contributing members of society.
201cThe goal is to help Starlight continue their vocational work in helping the young adults in their care learn how to cook, a skill that may assist them to be productive citizens,201d Morales-Balquedra said.
Morales-Balquedra said these two activities extend the current programs and mission of Kid2019s First.
201cOur mission is to provide a safe space where there is respect for diversity, where each child is recognized for his or her own abilities, interests, ideas, needs and respecting cultural identity.
Our Class programs are based on a progressive approach where children learn and explore through first hand experiences.201d
At first look, Kid2019s First Discovery Space may seem like a play date instead of a learning session.
And that2019s the intention: what we adults know as play is actually discovery and exploration for a child.
Together with her partner and Early Childhood Intervention coordinator, Jennifer Teves-Manalo, they create school activities aimed to enhance each child2019s natural curiosity to discover new things.
The school2019s planned daily activities are flexible enough for children to pursue their own interests.
They are given time to experiment, explore, dream and create while they are with their friends.
Kid2019s First also offers early childhood intervention and special education programs and services for youngsters with developmental delays.
Their curriculum uses a range of educational and therapeutic strategies in group and individual settings to promote the health, well-being, and developmental needs of these children.

"Children with developmental delays are welcomed, as inclusion play-based classes are made available for them.
Kids will have the chance to interact through arts, cooking, pretend play and storytelling with their peers, teachers and therapists,201d said Teves-Manalo.
The approach is very 201chands-on201d where the children actively interact with various materials, people and places, so that they have worthwhile experiences while in the center.
There is emphasis on concrete learning rather than abstract learning.
The school also provides music classes, speech and language therapy, occupational therapy, home and school visits, screening, social skills playgroups, preschool inclusion, transition to school, parent and caregiver education and training.
Hence, Kid2019s First can provide families with a central location where they have access to a wide range of quality programs services to meet their needs.
201cWhen I first planned Kid2019s First back in 2003, I had just returned from studying in Columbia University and working in New York.
I was exploring the idea of putting up a preschool here in the Philippines with a more progressive approach compared to what I was exposed to years before that.
 When I went around the area , I was surprised to see a lot of preschools sprouting like mushrooms, mostly which were put up by businessmen and businesswomen and not educators.
The challenge for me then was to push the envelope and raise the standards of early childhood education,201d said Morales-Balquiedra.
Ten years later, Kid2019s First continues with its commitment to fulfill every child2019s learning potential by fostering his or her intellectual, creative, emotional, social and physical development.

Sendong survivor is incoming freshman of UP Diliman , Sendong survivor is incoming freshman of UP Diliman 
CAGAYAN DE ORO.
Rene L.
Principe Jr.
, graduate of Regional Science High School of Cagayan de Oro City, is among the five Pantawid Pamilya beneficiaries who earned academic scholarship with the Department of Science and Technology.

RENE Liboon Principe Jr.
and his family almost drowned to death when Tropical Storm Sendong inundated some parts of northern Mindanao in the evening of December 16, 2011.
Rene2019s family, a beneficiary of Pantawid Pamilya, is among the thousand families here and in Iligan City who were affected by the flash flood brought about by the torrential rains during the onslaught of Sendong.
His father, Rene Sr., woke them up when the water was knee-high inside their house in Zone 4, Pasil, Kauswagan here.
The water reached the roof gutter level.
Rene and his family witnessed the flood water rushed down the Kauswagan area, a barangay along Cagayan de Oro River.
Rene heard adults and children crying for help as they were being carried away by the rampaging waters.
The flood destroyed their house.
It left knee-deep of mud.
They hurriedly went to an evacuation established by Department of Social Welfare and Development  which was some five kilometers away from their house.
Rene recalled that life inside an evacuation center was so hard, considering the sleepless nights and long queues for food and non-food items they mostly needed.
Resiliency
Rene Jr.
was a freshman student of Regional Science High School here when Sendong devastated northern Mindanao and took lives of residents living along Cagayan de Oro River here and in Mandulog River in Iligan City.
Typhoon Sendong submerged personal items of Rene2019s family; including his books and other supplies.
But Rene Jr.
did not let the calamity get in the way of achieving his dreams.
He continued to excel in his classes.
The cash grants of Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program and other interventions from DSWD and donations from local and international humanitarian organizations have helped Rene and his family live back to normalcy during those he described as trying times.
Focus on achieving dream
Rene Jr., youngest among the five Principe siblings, did not stop aiming at achieving his dream in life, who wants to become an Astronaut.
Impossible as it may seem, Rene said he does his best to become a spaceman.
He even said that he is willing to go to Mars and live there for the rest of his life.
Top 1 in his section and a graduate of Regional Science High School here, Rene Jr.
has been a consistent honor student since his elementary.
Despite getting offers of full scholarship from private universities here, Rene Jr.
opted to confirm his interest to enroll at University of the Philippines-Diliman, taking up Bachelor of Science in Physics after passing the UPCAT .
Rene Jr.
is also an academic scholar of the Department of Science and Technology.
                                                                                    
Thank DSWD, PNoy
201cI am very thankful to DSWD for helping poor families like us.
I was able to comply with all the projects and bought requirements for my laboratory projects because of Pantawid Pamilya,201d said Rene Jr.
201cAlso, I thanked President Benigno Aquino III for implementing Pantawid Pamilya through DSWD,201d Rene said, adding that, 201ccritics of the president should look at the fruits of labor of all his projects.201d
201cWe are the living proof of the gains of the administration,201d Rene Jr.
said.
Pantawid Pamilya is a government2019s poverty-reduction strategy that provides cash grants to extremely poor households aimed at helping them raise educated and healthy children aged 18 years and below.
It utilizes the Conditional Cash Transfer  scheme where beneficiaries receive cash grant provided that they send their children to school, get preventive health checkup, and the parents attend the monthly Family Development Session .
Rene Jr.
is among the 20,381 Pantawid Pamilya beneficiaries who graduated this school year 2014-2015.
Currently, Northern Mindanao has 271,077 active household beneficiaries of Pantawid Pamilya.

Some Filipinos take up boxing for several reasons.

A profession.
A fitness regimen.
A method of self-defense.

\xa0
Boxing 201cis an exciting sport,  extreme sport for me,201d he said.
\xa0

\xa0
201cBefore I entered boxing, I knew it was a dangerous sport,201d he said.
201cYou should be prepared to be hurt.
It is hard to be always injured.
You will sustain bruises in the face, your body will feel pain, but that2019s all part of boxing.201d

201cEvery time you fight and win, when the referee lifts your arm , it gives you enjoyment,201d he said.

201cI became patient.
I stopped cursing,201d Sarinas said.

He has around 30 students in a boxing gym in Malolos City, Bulacan.

201cAs a trainer, I want to experience how to teach .
I want to teach to others what needs to be learned.
Just like a business,201d said Borbe.
Boxing used to be an all-male realm.
Not anymore.
\xa0
Rizza Benedicto hits the gym twice a week, pounding the heavy bag or sparring with her trainer.

"I discovered that aside from losing weight, I became physically stronger.
I don2019t get tired when I walk up the stairs, I2019ve become more alert,201d she said.
Boxing also relieves stress, she found out.
201cWhen I box, the stress that had accumulated for the week is released,201d she said.
Benedicto said it was not easy for her to get started on boxing, but rigid practice and encouragement from her trainer and her colleagues in the gym gave her the boost she needed.
\xa0
An online writer, Benedicto is trying to get other women to give boxing workouts a try.

It will help develop your stamina, agility, alertness and the bonus is you lose weight," she said.

Jillian Fernandez, a 27-year-old student at the Emilio Aguinaldo College in Manila, has been into boxing for more than a year.
\xa0

\xa0
201cI'm warning the bad guys: Don2019t mess with me,201d she said.

Gil Vegerano, a newbie when it comes to boxing, said he never thought he could enter into extreme sports because of his asthma.
\xa0
But the 31-year-old said he never had asthma attack since he took up the sport two months ago.

Pacquiao, who will reportedly earn at least $120 million from his megafight with unbeaten American Floyd Mayweather Jr.
on Saturday in Las Vegas, Nevada  has no doubt inspired his countrymen to embrace the sport.

201cBoxing is great for cardio fitness,201d he said.

Dr.
Victoria P.
Guillano, who is a dermatologist and dermatopathologist, juggles her time between family and work in an almost day to day basis.
However, she makes it a point to always place family first.
Guillano originally applied for residency training as a pediatrician at the Davao Doctors Hospital because she enjoys working with children.
Then during one of her facial sessions with Dr.
Carlos R.
Pacheco, she was informed that there was an opening at the Department of Dermatology at the Southern Philippines Medical Center .
"Since I had a baby that time, I thought being a dermatologist is much better because it is not a 24-hour job and I can take care of my kid," said Guillano, adding that being in this field allows her to manage her time well between family and work.
During her free time, she enjoys cooking and baking for her family.
She and her husband, Dr.
Frank Guillano, are also very supportive to their children, Nestor, 17, and Franco, 13, who are budding triathletes.
For instance, Guillano and her husband are on a trip to the United States now but once they return to the Philippines in a week, they will immediately go to Dipolog to witness their children compete in a triathlon.
Aside from being an attentive mother and wife, Guillano also juggles her time between clinics.

On Tuesdays and Thursdays she is at the Alexian Brothers and Wellness Center; on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays she is at the Health Science and Wellness Center of the Metro Davao Medical and Research Center; and from Monday to Saturday she is attending to her patients and clients at the DermPath Dermatology, Laser Clinic and MediSPA, her business venture.

"The business was my husband's idea.

Since she enjoys working with kids, Guillano said in this job she is able to cater to not only adults but also children.
She said dermatology is not only about cosmetics but it is also about treating those with skin diseases.
Aside from being a doctor and businesswoman, she also juggles her time as president of the Psoriasis Foundation of the Philippines, a lecturer at the Davao Medical School Foundation on dermatology, consultant at the Department of Dermatology at SPMC, and head of the Dermatopathology unit of SPMC.
She is also a fellow and diplomat of the Philippine Dermatological Society, member of the Philippine Dermatological Society, and fellow at the American Academy of Dermatology.
Guillano is also a registered medical technologist and received her baccalaureate degree on medical technology from Velez College and her doctorate in medicine at the Cebu Institute of Medicine.
She had her residency at SPMC and her sub-specialty training on dermatopathology at the National Skin Center in Singapore.

Filipino baker makes life-sized cake of Pacquiao, Filipino baker makes life-sized cake of Pacquiao
Zach Yonzon, owner of The Bunny Baker cafe, poses with the life-sized cake of Filipino boxer Manny Pacquiao Saturday, May 2, 2015 at his bakeshop at suburban Quezon city, northeast of Manila, Philippines.
Yonzon who says he was bored with making traditional cakes sculpted the one-of-a-kind life-sized cake in the image of Pacquiao to mark the Filipino champion2019s megabout with American Floyd Mayweather.
Yonzon, says his wife Aila and six of his staff helped finish the 167-centimeter  chocolate cake of Pacquiao with arms akimbo on Saturday after working 24 hours at the cafe.

MANILA 2014 Fans of Manny Pacquiao have a new way of showing how much they love the boxing superstar 2014 by eating him.
Or a life-size replica cake at least.
Zach Yonzon, his wife Aila, and six of his staff helped finish the 167 cm.
 chocolate cake on Saturday after working 24 hours at The Bunny Baker cafe in suburban Quezon City.
Yonzon says it was his wife's idea to bake the cake to commemorate the mega-fight against Floyd Mayweather, which will be on Sunday morning Philippines time.
"Manny Pacquiao is world class, so we wanted to do something equally world class and the only way to do that is to create a cake that was extraordinary," he said.
The cake will be handed out free to customers and friends of the couple after the fight.
The 41-year-old said the biggest challenges were their lack of experience in making life-size statues and formal training in cake design.
Getting the likeness right was the easy part for Yonzon, who is a graduate of the Philippine High School for the Arts.
"The truth is I get really bored with normal cakes," Yonzon told The Associated Press.
"I wanted really something really, really challenging ...
and a life-sized Manny cake is about as challenging and exciting as the cakes come and this is a perfect opportunity to do that."
"I just needed to do something out of the box," added the former blogger for AOL.
He said he based the image of Pacquiao, including a tattoo of a glove on the boxer's left chest, on pictures available on the Internet.
The cake is built around a wooden frame covered in cling wrap.
He said parts of the head and the arms and the calves were made of Rice Krispies.
"It will be interesting to get people's reactions cutting and eating Manny Pacquiao," he said, laughing.
"My wife said we will start with the torso." 
Duchess of Cambridge gives birth to a princess, Duchess of Cambridge gives birth to a princess
Betting odds are written on a chalkboard outside the Lindo Wing at St.
Mary's Hospital in anticipation of Kate, Duchess Cambridge giving birth to her second child, London, Saturday, May 2, 2015.
Prince William's wife Kate entered a London hospital Saturday to give birth to their second child, igniting a national wave of anticipation and a last-minute betting spree on the name of the new prince or princess.

LONDON  2014 A princess is born.
Prince William's wife, the Duchess of Cambridge, "was safely delivered of a daughter" Saturday morning, less than three hours after checking into St.
Mary's Hospital in London, royal officials said.
The newborn's name wasn't immediately announced.
When her brother, Prince George, was born in 2013, royal officials waited two days before announcing his name.
Britons have for weeks been betting that it would be a princess and all the top bets for the baby's name have been for girls.
Alice and Charlotte are the clear favorites, followed by Elizabeth, Victoria and Diana 2014 all names with strong connections to royal tradition.
Kensington Palace said the baby 2014 the couple's second child 2014 was born at 8:34 a.m.
London time  and weighed 8 pounds 3 ounces .
The princess is fourth in line to the throne and the fifth great-grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II.
A royal statement said senior royals "are delighted with the news." The queen marked the occasion by wearing a pink ensemble while carrying out an official engagement in Richmond, North Yorkshire, 250 miles  north of London.
Die-hard royal fans who had been camping for days outside the hospital danced with delight, chanting "Princess! Princess!" and "Hip, hip, hooray!" A town crier in elaborate costume 2014 with no connection to the royal family 2014 shouted out the news at the hospital's door, clanging his bell to welcome the new royal.
"May our princess be long-lived, happy and glorious," said Tony Appleton, reading from a scroll in a booming voice.
Later, hundreds of tourists and well-wishers crowded outside the gates of Buckingham Palace, cheering and screaming as officials placed a traditional birth announcement on a golden easel.
Kate, 33, and her infant were doing well, and Prince William was present for the birth, officials said.
Kate, who wed William in April 2011, gave birth to Prince George at the same hospital in July 2013.
William came out of the hospital in the afternoon, waving to reporters and saying he was "very happy" before driving off to see about George.
Anticipation for the occasion had been building for weeks.
Kate had told a well-wisher earlier this year that the child was due in the second two weeks of April, kicking off what the tabloid press called "the Great Kate Wait." The world's media had set up their positions outside the hospital for days, but were still caught slightly off guard by the speed with which officials announced the birth.
"I'm top of the world," said royal camper Terry Hutt, 80, decked out in patriotic Union Jack gear.
He said he did not expect the birth to happen as soon as it did, but said: "Babies come when they're ready."
"If Diana was here, she'd be very, very proud," he added, referring to the late Princess Diana, William's mother.
Britain's political leaders 2014 facing a hard-fought general election in just five days 2014 rushed to congratulate the couple on the new addition.
Prince Charles had signaled 2014 twice 2014 that he was hoping for a granddaughter, which led some to speculate that he had inside information, even though the royal couple said throughout Kate's pregnancy that they did not know the child's gender.
The monarchy has not welcomed a princess born this high up the line of succession since Princess Anne, the queen's second child, was born in 1950.
Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie, the daughters of Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson, were fifth and sixth in line at the time of their birth.
At 21 months, George is third in line to the throne, after his grandfather Prince Charles and William.
The newborn becomes the fourth in line, bumping Uncle Harry to fifth place.
Thanks to a recent change in law, the new princess will hold her place in the line of succession that for centuries had put boys ahead of their sisters.
The change means that no younger brother will be able to overtake the newborn princess in the order of preference to inherit the throne.
Nonetheless, the princess should not have to worry about one day becoming queen.
Royal succession rules dictate that the throne always passes to the eldest child, and younger siblings only get to step up to the job in rare circumstances 2014 in the cases of an illness, death, or abdication.
The public is likely to get its first view of the newborn when Kate and William leave the hospital, but no time has been set for that yet.

Van Gogh work fetches over $66 million at New York auction , Van Gogh work fetches over $66 million at New York auction 
Vincent van Gogh's The Allee of Alyscamps 
NEW YORK  2014 A painting Vincent van Gogh created while briefly working side by side with his friend Paul Gauguin in the south of France brought in $66.3 million at auction Tuesday.
"The Allee of Alyscamps" was offered at Sotheby's impressionist and modern art sale.
The autumnal scene was painted in 1888 during a two-month period when van Gogh and Gauguin worked together in Arles, France.
The painting, which had a presale estimate of more than $40 million, was sold to an Asian private collector, Sotheby's said.
The auction record for a van Gogh, who died in 1890, is $82.5 million.
Van Gogh expert Clifford Edwards, a professor at Virginia Commonwealth University, said, "To have a canvas from Arles by that very self-taught artist at the height of his work marks the sale as momentous."
The sale also featured six paintings spanning four decades of Claude Monet's career.
The highlight was "Water Lilies," a 1905 version of his beloved pond and gardens at his home in Giverny, France.
It fetched $54 million, topping its high presale estimate of $45 million.
Monet's 1908 painting of Venice with a view of the Palazzo Ducale on the Grand Canal fetched more than $23 million.
It was confiscated by the Nazis from the noted collector Jakob Goldschmidt and was reclaimed by his son in 1960.
It descended to a grandson, who died last year.
The current auction record for a work by Monet is his 1919 "Water Lily Pond," which sold for $80.5 million in 2008.
Sotheby's also offered works from two prominent single-owner collections.
There were two works from Hollywood film moguls Samuel Goldwyn and his son.
"Woman With a Chignon in an Armchair," a portrait of Pablo Picasso's lover Francoise Gilot, sold for $29.9 million, almost doubling its high presale estimate of $18 million.
It depicts her in an embroidered jacket Picasso bought for her in Poland while she was pregnant with their child.
Henri Matisse's "Anemones and Pomegranates" was purchased by the elder Goldwyn two years after it was painted in 1948.
It sold for more than $6 million, in line with its presale estimate.
About two dozen other works from the collection will be offered in a series of sales later in May, June and October.
Samuel Goldwyn Jr.
died in January; his father died in 1974.
The other collection on Tuesday belonged to Jerome Stone, a Chicago businessman and founder of the Alzheimer's Association, who died in January.
It included Fernand Leger's "The Blue Wheel, Definitive State," with a pre-sale estimate of up to $12 million.
It fetched $10.5 million.
Other artists in the collection included Joan Miro, Marc Chagall and Alberto Giacometti.

Tour participants boarded open-air, motorized bancas  that took them to Nalusuan Island -- a marine sanctuary in Cebu with crystal blue waters.
They were also able to feed fish and go snorkeling near Hilutungan Island.
In Bohol, the tour group enjoyed lunch while on a cruise along the Loboc River.
They also met the world2019s second smallest primate, and got to appreciate the unique geological formation that is the Chocolate Hills.
In true Filipino fashion, every meal can be described as a feast with lots of the islands2019 famous sea food -- lobsters, crabs, prawns -- and local delicacies such as the sour soup called Sinigang, the Filipino salad called Ensalada, and the sweet Banana Cue for dessert.
Ambassador Malaya was quick to point out how Cebu and Bohol have been boosting Halal tourism in the area by helping increase the number of Halal-certified food establishments on the island.

The tour group2019s significant number of Muslim participants got their fill of Filipino dishes without worrying about their dietary restrictions.

201cWith Halal tourism on the rise and the increase of air connectivity between Kuala Lumpur and the various island destinations of the Philippines, there are now more reasons for Malaysians to choose the Philippines for their next vacation,201d Ambassador Malaya said.
201cWe are even working on getting more tourists to fly directly to their island destinations without having to change planes.201d
The 2nd Ambassador2019s Tour2019s aim was to re-introduce the Philippines to Malaysians and other nationalities who joined the tour as a complete tropical, heritage, cultural, and eco-tourism experience.
With Cebu and Bohol2019s heritage sites, beautiful waters, and unique geological formations, the tour left the participants looking yearning for more of what the Philippines has to offer.
For a taste of Filipino and Asean art, the participants also attended the opening of an art exhibit in Cebu2019s Qube Gallery where 25 artists from the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia showed their latest works at an art show entitled Kita.
Zainol Abidin Mohamed, one of the tour2019s participants and a second-timer for the Ambassador2019s Tour, said he cannot wait to go back.
201cAfter enjoying the first Ambassador2019s Tour, I decided to bring my family with me.
I booked for 16 people for this tour and we all enjoyed it 2013 my wife, my children, and even my cousin2019s family,201d he said.
He noted how this year2019s tour is even much more extensive with more activities than the first.
He added that he has also been recommending the Ambassador2019s Tour to his friends due to its carefully planned itinerary, reasonable cost, and convenience.

In 2014, the year the Ambassador2019s Tour started, the Philippines enjoyed a 27 percent growth on the arrival of Malaysian tourists compared to the year before with 139,000 Malaysians visiting the islands.
This is the highest and most significant growth rate from the Philippines2019 major tourist markets that catapulted Malaysia into the 9th spot of the country2019s top 10 tourist markets.
201cDefinitely, we would like to see more international tourist arrivals to the Philippines 2013 especially in Bohol and Cebu where the people are greatly involved in sustainable tourism,201d Ambassador Malaya said.
201cThis is their way of life and that2019s one of the reasons why they take good care of their environment and it is something that should be appreciated.201d
With the clamor of tour participants for a 3rd Ambassador2019s Tour, Ambassador Malaya and Department of Tourism Representative Datin Melissa Ong promised to plan and make the next one even better than the first two.

Will it be Batanes? Boracay? Palawan? Or one of the 7,107 islands that has not yet made it to the consciousness of mainstream travelers?
Ambassador Malaya coyly replied that participants2019 reaction to the tour is indeed giving them pressure with regard to planning the next one.
But he promised that people will definitely be even more excited once the official announcement for the tour2019s next destination is made.

LEADavao: Search for achievers, LEADavao: Search for achieversTHE Davao Jaycee Senate launched last April 29 the LEADavao, an undertaking that seeks to recognize outstanding achievements of Filipinos aged 35 and above that have benefited the Davao City community.
The awards program gives focus on the Jaycees goal and mission of providing opportunities that empower people to create positive change.
Through awarding achievers, Davao Jaycees believe this will motivate, inspire and recognize persons who have demonstrated vigor and enterprise in tackling the problems of society and implementing solutions.
JCI Senate Davao Resident is Sen.
Jocy Tagle-Ledesma.
 Project chairman is Sen.
Nick Partoza.

Nominations are now open and deadline for nominations is on or before July 1, 2015.
LEADavao was originally launched in 2003 under the presidency of Sen.
Manuel M.
Orig.
Project chair was Sen.
Nilo Claudio.
 The awardees were Carolyn Arguillas, Margie Moran-Floirendo, Joji Ilagan-Bian, Joey Ayala and Antonio T.
Uy.
Criteria are: The nominee must have reached the age of 35 at the time of filing of his/her nomination; the nominee must be a resident of Davao City for at least one year at the time of the filing of his/her nomination; the nominee must have made substantive and meaningful contributions to the upliftment and well-being of the Davao City community, and the nominee must not be a past LEADavao awardee.
Rules Governing Submission of Nomination:
1.
Nomination for the LEADavao Award is open to an individual engaged in any field of endeavor.
Any person or organization can nominate one or more individuals subject to the requirements outlined in this document.
2.
Nominations should be made on the prescribed LEADavao nomination form and notarized accordingly.
All information therein shall be submitted in English, Tagalog or Taglish.
3.
THE Nominee must sign the nomination form attesting to all stated facts therein; giving consent to an independent body for the verification by the LEADavao Search Committee and the subsequent publication of said facts; and indicating his/her willingness to attend the awards ceremonies, if selected.
4.
A certified true copy of the nominee2019s birth certificate or any equivalent proof of date and place of birth should accompany nomination.
5.
Two  copies of nominee2019s picture  black and white or colored, should accompany the two  copies of the accomplished Nomination Form.
Also, pictures must be submitted in digital form stored in USB.
6.
A one page Executive Summary of the Nominee summarizing important facts and accomplishments and presented in a scrapbook shall accompany the nomination form.
7.
The Scrapbook/ Bidbook in digital form shall be subject to the specifications as indicated in the technical requirements for attachments.
8.
The Nominee/Nominator must submit a CD/ USB with contents as follows: Duly filled up Nomination Form, scanned copies of each page of the scrapbook saved as Pdf file, and a "52019x72019"picture of the nominee.
9.
An original or certified true copy of the nominee2019s NBI Clearance should also accompany the nomination.
10.
All entries must be e-mailed to leadavao2015@yahoo.com and   personally delivered to Annipie Cinnamon Outlets on or before July 1, 2015.
Mailed entries should be postmarked not later than the same date.
11.
The LEADavao Search Committee of the JCI Senate Davao shall be the search body of the project and reserves the right to pass judgment on any issue that may arise in connection with the above rules.
12.
The LEADavao Search Committee will review the entries to ensure that all technical requirements are complied with.
13.
The Screening Committee shall conduct a preliminary selection of the nominees to determine the finalists for consideration by the Board of Judges.
14.
The Board of Judges composed of respected individuals shall select the winners.
Their decision will be final and non- appealable.
They may opt to call the finalist for an interview as they deem fit.
15.
All data/information submitted in connection with the LEADavao AWARD shall be treated with the strictest confidentiality and shall become the property of the LEADavao AWARD BODY of the Davao Jaycee Senate.
Procedure in Making Bidbooks for the Nominees
As part of the scrapbook, the nominator must answer the following questions about the nominee on a separate sheet.
Indicate by number where each answer begins.
Answers must be printed, double 2013 spaced on standard
A4 or letter-size bond paper.
Be as brief and factual as possible.
1.
Describe the career of the nominee.
Please include background, scope of nominee2019s work or activity and the resources utilized in achieving his/her goals.
2.
Narrate the nominee2019s substantive contributions which has led to the upliftment and well-being of the Davao City community.
3.
List quotations, statements of authorities, honors and awards received which are indicative of the nominee2019s achievements and contributions.
4.
Summarize how the nominee has exemplified one or more of the following tenets of the JCI Creed:
That faith in God gives meaning and purpose to human life;
That the brotherhood of man transcends the sovereignty of nations;
That economic justice can best be won by free men through free enterprise;
That government should be of laws rather than of men;
That earth2019s great treasure lies in human personality; and
That service to humanity is the best work of life.

They are all Eve2019s descendants and above all mothers.

She shows a man what sharing, caring and loving is all about2026201d

Commercialized

Advocate against human trafficking , Advocate against human trafficking Ruji Peter S.
Abat, DIFFERENT learning opportunities at the Davao Regional Prosecutor's Office enabled Prosecutor Karl Andre Salcedo to be a staunch advocate against human trafficking.
Salcedo told Sun.Star Davao in an interview that his expectation from the prosecution service was not initially met when he was appointed as an associate prosecution attorney in 2013.

He thought that his job would be just like any other prosecutor who is faced with voluminous complaints to resolve and a lot of court trials to attend to.
"At first, I was expecting na akong trabaho kay magresolve ug case ug daghang trial works.
Pero more of admin ug managerial work diay akong trabaho kay ang RPO-11 man ang representative sa Department of Justice  on the regional level.
So ginapadala ko sa mga forums, speaking engagements ug lain pang mga conferences nga naay concern sa DOJ ," Salcedo said.
This opportunity has allowed Salcedo to grow not only as a prosecutor but as a well-rounded public servant, citing he has to go to every conference or forum prepared while he was also tasked to become acting prosecutor for different city and provincial prosecution offices in the region.
"It is a great opportunity for me to develop my admin and managerial skills and it is good that I am not confined in the court room or office.
Basically, our work is diverse and this has trained me to become more flexible," Salcedo said.
It was then when he became part of the Regional Anti-Trafficking Task Force -Davao that he found his passion in campaigning against human trafficking saying, "I have a soft spot for people who are suffering and when I joined the task force, it opened up a realization that a lot of trafficking victims need help.
So then it became my advocacy."
Salcedo has then conducted talks in various anti-trafficking in persons campaigns and forums and has also aided in investigating and building cases against suspected human traffickers.
But he said that his expectations on the prosecution service came full circle when he was allowed by RPO-11 head Regional Prosecutor Antonio Arellano to handle human trafficking cases.
"I am very grateful to RP Arellano for allowing me to handle trafficking cases because trial work was among the things I was expecting when I decided to join the prosecution service.
But it has become more fulfilling now since it is aligned with my advocacy to help human trafficking victims," Salcedo said.
Latest self-driving Google car heading to public streets, Latest self-driving Google car heading to public streets
In this May 13, 2015 photo, Google's new self-driving prototype car is presented during a demonstration at the Google campus in Mountain View, Calif.
The car, which needs no gas pedal or steering wheel, will make its debut on public roads this summer.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.
2014 The latest version of Google's self-driving car 2014 a pod-like two-seater that needs no gas pedal or steering wheel 2014 will make its debut on public roads this summer, a significant step in the technology giant's mission to have driverless cars available to consumers in the next five years.
This prototype is the first vehicle built from scratch for the purpose of self-driving, Google says.
It looks like a Smart car with a shiny black bowler hat to hide its sensors, and it can drive, brake and recognize road hazards without human intervention.
It has more capabilities than the prototype Google introduced last May, which was so rudimentary it had fake headlights.
The new pod isn't designed for a long trip, or a joyride.
It lacks air bags and other federally required safety features, so it can't go more than 25 miles per hour .
It's electric, and has to be recharged after 80 miles .
And the pod can only drive in areas that have been thoroughly mapped by Google.
At first, it will likely even have a steering wheel and gas pedal 2014 current California regulations require them.
Those regulations also require a driver to be able to take back control of the car at any time.
But Google is lobbying for more flexible regulations.
Google will initially build and test 25 pods, mostly in neighborhoods surrounding its Mountain View headquarters.
It will eventually build between 50 and 100, and will broaden testing to sites that are hillier and rainier.
The ultimate goal, says Google co-founder Sergey Brin, is computer-controlled cars that can eliminate human error, which is a factor in an estimated 90 percent of the 1.2 million road deaths that occur worldwide each year.
Self-driving cars could also improve traffic congestion and transport the elderly and disabled.
Google shocked the auto industry in 2010 with its announcement that it was working on a driverless car.
Brin insists Google doesn't aspire to be a car company, but wants its technology to be adopted by automakers.
"We want to partner to bring self-driving to all the vehicles in the world," Brin told a group of journalists and community members gathered earlier this week to take rides in the prototype.
Convincing drivers that driverless technology is safe is one of the hurdles the company must overcome.
Earlier this week, in response to questions from The Associated Press, Google acknowledged 11 minor accidents in the six years it has been testing autonomous cars.
Urmson says the company is proud of that record, and notes that Google's vehicles have completed more than 1.7 million miles of testing.
He says all but one of the accidents were caused by drivers in other cars; in the only incident caused by a Google car, a staffer was driving in manual mode.
Consumers question whether they can trust self-driving cars to work all the time, who will be liable if there's an accident and how self-driving cars will interact with regular cars, says the consulting firm J.D.
Power and Associates.
In a 2013 survey of U.S.
drivers, J.D.
Power found only one in five was interested in a fully autonomous car.
Egil Juliussen, the principal analyst of infotainment and advanced driver assist systems for the consulting firm IHS Automotive, says Google's "moon shot" strategy is difficult and riskier than just adding features to existing cars.
But he thinks it could ultimately be successful.
Google could make self-driving urban pods for universities or urban centers, for example, or sell its technology to automakers.

Exploring arts and talents, Exploring arts and talents
Photo from Tambayan Center for Children's Rights Inc.'s Facebook page
Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, WITH art known as an outlet in expressing thoughts and emotions, the Tambayan Center for Children2019s Rights had recently conducted a summer workshop for street girls from the different barangays in Davao and Digos City.
The 3-day workshop dubbed as the 201cSummer Integrated Art Workshops201d aims to 201clet every child understand and appreciate their own craft.201d
Tambayan is a non-government organization working with less privileged and discriminated adolescent girls in the street with ages ranging from 9 to 17 years old.
The workshop was held at DCG inland resort in Toril last Tuesday and Wednesday and a culmination activity was held at Tambayan Center along Artiagastreet to showcase the children2019s output.

Tambayan psychosocial worker  LouiseSuamen said that the participants can choose among three disciplines for the workshop: theater, music and visual arts.
The children were taught by renowned artists namely Toni Apat for theater, PopongLandero for music and Mai Ongkiko for visual arts.
Suamen said that there are 29 girls serviced by their organization who participated in the workshop.
She added that these girls are mostly members of gangs, involved in vices and victims of physical and sexual abuses.
201cKini sila nanginahanglan ug maayong proteksyon pud ug pagtagad ,201d Suamen said.
During their recital, other than their enhanced skills, all of their experiences, hopes and aspirations were also highlighted in each performance and artwork that they have shown.
Leslie, one of the girls under the theater workshop, said that it had develop their confidence to show what they have been through.
201cSa theater nakatuon ko naipakita ang mga nakit-an nako ug ma-acting nako, mapasinati nako sa ubang mga kabatan-unan unsa among kaagi ug unsa among naagihan ,201d she said.
For music, other than learning to play some instruments, Sweet and Marbie had composed their own song which pictures their dream of being successful in life.
An excerpt from their song goes: 201cBabangon sa pagkadapa sa bisyo at kasamaan, mabubuhay ng marangal dahil sa akin ay may nagmamahal2026magagawa ko ang lahat ng gusto ko, kung matutupad ang mga pangarap ko.201d
A part of Tambayan2019s office was also turned into a mini art exhibit area for children under the visual arts workshop to display their artworks filled with bright colors and fun patterns.
Some artworks also have motivational words on them such as 201cdon2019t give up.201d
Suamen said that those participating girls who will be interested to join in more training will be included as members of Nakamata .
According to her, as of April, they are looking after 178 adolescent girls while there are currently 73 members for Nakamata.
Suamen said that other than enhancing the children2019s skills on their chosen art disciplines, they are also hoping for the children to use art as a tool to participate in advocating their rights especially to other children in their areas.

OFWs are top buyers, OFWs are top buyersRuji Peter S.
Abat, OVERSEAS Filipino workers are top real estate property buyers in Davao City, said chief of the Plans and Programs Division of the Office of the City Planning and Development Coordinator Engr.
Jose Froilan Rigor.
"OFWs have occupied or have purchased around half of the houses and lots of the top property developers in the city," Rigor said.
He added that businessmen have also been considered among the top buyers, followed by foreigners, retirees and young professionals.
Rigor also said investors continue to invest on Davao City lands for development projects with a growing market.
Rigor said property developers, particularly residential, industrial and commercial land developers, have been the top investors of real estate properties in Davao City.
These developers would either develop subdivisions, condominium and walls while some would develop factories and other industrial spaces.
But Rigor underscored the growing trend of township development, saying: "Townships are self-contained communities and pwedeng maglagay ang mga property developers ng residential, commercial and industrial spaces.
Ang trend is really towards that and that is good because the city wants to decongest the core of the urban centers."
He added that township development can help decongest the downtown areas as residents of Davao City can settle within their own community rather than travelling to downtown.
This, too, according to him, could alleviate the problem on the so-called rush-hour syndrome.
Rigor attributes the growth of the real estate industry in the city to the peace and order situation, governance and feats that the city has acquired through the years.
"We are already established as one of the safest cities in the world and we were also awarded as the most child-friendly city in the county.
We have also passed many ordinances relating to our security and on top of that we have a relatively cheap cost of living here while our water is one of the best qualities in the world," Rigor said.
He added, "These are the reasons why many developers are confident on investing here.
So when there are more developed properties, the number of consumers also grows and we are expecting this growth to be rapid for the coming years."
