Rising towers, Rising towersReuel John F.
Lumawag, THE skyline of Davao City 10 years ago can be characterized by a mix of mid-rise and low-rise buildings with 18-storey Marco Polo Hotel Davao being the tallest back then.
A few years later, Pryce Tower and Landco Pacific Building at the Pryce Business Park were established adding to the changes in the skyline of the city.
In the past four to five years, more mid-rise buildings, mostly of which were residentials, began to rise and continue to change Davao City's landscape.
However, in the coming years, Dabawenyos can expect the skyline of Davao City to drastically change once the high-rise projects of large property developers are completed.
Evidently, among the first tall buildings that will dominate the skyline of the city are the Abreeza Place and Abreeza Residences, which are projects of Alveo Land in partnership with Accendo Commercial Corp.
Both buildings are nearing completion.
Another set of high-rise towers that are also under construction are the Avida Towers Davao, along C.M.
Recto Ave.
 of Avida Land, in partnership with Avencosouth Corp.
When you pass by the area, you can see the busy construction workers working together to put up the building.
Up north, property giant Megaworld is also pouring P15 million for the development of the Davao Park District, a joint venture modern township project with the Dakudao Family, in an 11-hectare  property in Lanang that will feature residential condominiums, business process outsourcing centers and commercial centers.
The first structure to rise in the area is the P1.2-billion 16-storey steel and glass Davao Finance Center , which is expected to be Mindanao's first world-class facility for business process outsourcing  industry.
It is targeted to be completed by 2016.

Suntrust Properties Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Megaworld, is also constructing the One Lakeshore Drive, a four-tower residential condominium cluster that will rise at the 7.2 hectares residential area of DPD, in 2016.
Each tower will be 21-storey high.
These are just some of the projects being developed by Manila-based property developers though there are also those that are currently being developed like the 33 storey Aeon Towers of the FTC Group of Companies Corp.
while Felcris Hotels and Resorts Corp.
 is set to construct three 38-storey tower condominiums at Felcris Centrale.
Davao City Investment Promotion Center  officer-in-charge Ivan C.
Cortez said the construction boom due to the entry of these projects is an indicator of a strong economic activity in the city.
He said that business activities brought about by the construction boom will attract other investors who would want to grab the opportunity to invest in Davao City.
Cortez said the strong growth of real property development in Davao City was triggered by the entry of property developers who invested in the city early like Sta.
Lucia Land Inc.

Rent or buy?, Rent or buy?Marianne L.
Saberon-Abalayan, INCOME stability, or lack of it, is one major consideration before one decides to rent or buy a house.
Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas  Bank Officer 2 Maricel Fuentes Felix said, "It all depends on the current income.
For a young married couple, it's okay to rent a small space with a reasonable rental cost while saving up for equity on a new house and lot  or when they are financially able to amortize for long-term like when availing a Pag-Ibig housing loan."
Since income is vital in measuring one's capability and eligibility to apply for a housing loan, an applicant must consider security of tenure of his or her employment or sustainability of his or her business since most terms of housing loans span from 20 to 30 years.
"If you have the money, buy a house.
Monthly rent of houses in downtown areas usually range from P5,000 to P10,000.
With that amount, you can already amortize for your own housing unit," Felix said in the vernacular.
However, she noted that some don't avail themselves of housing loans for the fear of incurring debts.
"In time, they will realize the waste of renting when they can afford owning their own houses."
When one decides to buy a house, she also said to consider the cost of amortization, that it won't hinder day to day living expenses including food, education of children, medicines, clothes, utility bills  and phone bills, fares or gasoline, among others.
"Most from this generation, we have observed, don't want to be deprived of a comfortable lifestyle so saving up for a house is not their priority.
They would rather spend money for shopping, leisure, recreation and travel," she added.
Felix added to consider the location of the house.
It may even cost more to travel from home to the school or to the workplace when the extra expense on fares could also be saved for down payment or reservation for a new house.
She also urged, "Buying your own house, when you are financially able, is wiser than renting.
Why pay for the rent of a house that will never be yours.
You wouldn't want to make any improvement on a rented house since it's not yours after all."

Choosing a contractor, Choosing a contractorKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, CHOOSING the right contractor plays a vital role in the success of any property development project.
Architect Francisco C.
Santos Jr., FPIA, United Architects of the Philippines , said the contractors' good track record gives an advantage for them to earn the project.
"But before the choosing a contractor of the project, the owner/stakeholder will tap first a financial institution to assess how much budget is needed for the project then will hire a professional architect to design the project plan.
The architect will be getting services of several other professionals including a civil engineer, registered master plumber, electrical engineer among others to proceed to the planning stage before proceeding to the part of the selection of the contractor," Santos said.

Santos, the managing editor of Santos Architecture and Urban Planner, an architectural firm that also specializes in planning, design, urban planning, project designing and such, also bared the bidding of contractors conducted by a government agency and private firms are different.
 
Competitive or Public Bidding is a method of procurement that is open to any interested and qualified party.

The bidding documents must be prepared or issued by the procuring entity or the owner.

The Philippine Bidding Documents contains documents including Invitation to Apply for Eligibility and to Bid , Eligibility documents and data sheet, Instruction to Bidders , Bid Data Sheet , General Conditions of Contract , Special Conditions of Contract , Specifications, Drawings, Bill of Quantities and Form and Qualification Information.
"After namin mabigyan ng mga bidding documents ang mga prospect contractors ng aming project.
Nag-iinvestigate kami ng kanilang financial standing kung capable ba sila then track record nila based sa mga accomplished and ongoing projects nila to make sure they are credibile enough to be awarded with the project," Santos added.
Other agencies such as Bids and Awards Committee , Technical Working Group , consultants, BAC secretariat and end user unit will also participate in the preparation of the bidding documents on government projects while private firms do not need any of these.
A bid security document must also be submitted also by the bidder.
It guarantees the procuring entity that the awarded bidder will follow all the details laid down on the project plan.
If the bidder fails to submit the bid security, his or her bid will be rejected.
The bidder's bid security may be forfeited according to these matters: withdraws its bid beyond the deadline, the bidder does not accept corrections of arithmetical errors, the bidder being considered for award does not accept the award or does not sign the contract within the period prescribed in the bidding documents or the bidder being post-qualified is suspended for not providing the BAC required clarifications within the prescribed period.

Boosting harvest, Boosting harvestKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, THE Department of Agriculture  in Davao Region has implemented some innovations on their farming procedures to further boost the quality and quantity of crops being produced in the region.
Regional Agriculture and Fisheries Information Section  chief Noel Provido, in an interview with Sun.Star Davao at his office on Monday afternoon, said they are proposing the agricultural mechanization, which in turn could help the production yield of the crops and provide bigger incomes for the farmers.
"The post-harvest facilities are also needed by the farmers.
An example of it is the mechanical dryer, through this one, farmers can still dry crops even if it's raining," he said.
During dry season, the mechanical dryer hastens drying period from two to three days to just one day.
Aside from the farm facilities, DA is also improving irrigation systems.
"Irrigation is really important particularly in the rice production, so we really need to upgrade our irrigations especially on a dry season like El Ni\xf1o," Provido said.

With the mild El Nino seen to affect the country's harvest, he said, "One of our programs include rice stocking, providing assistance to the farmers by delivering variety of seedlings and at the same time we are also monitoring the areas for possibility of conducting cloud seeding in some affected areas."
New varieties of next generation rice  are also being developed by DA that could withstand flood and drought.
 
"We are still looking on its characteristics.
When it comes to rice production, regardless if it is tolerant to flood like San Marino-1 or tolerant to drought, what we are looking into is their potential to produce and yield because we want to address food security, that's our main concern," he said.
The next generation rice has been undergoing trials and consultations with the farmers in different communities with regards to its variety and saleability.
"We are conducting researches or National Commodity Testing  for the for rice but this we are involving the farmers.
They  can immediately identify what variety should they prefer," he said.
With the engagement of the farmers during the trials conducted by DA, they now have the say whether they prefer the said variety of the new generation of rice.
Testing areas in the Davao Region for the new generation rice varieties are located at Hagonoy, Davao del Sur and Carmen, Davao del Norte.

Adapting to change, Adapting to changeRuji Peter S.
Abat, AS FARMERS are reeling from the scorching heat brought by the mild El Ni\xf1o, there is a need for them to adapt more sustainable farming methods to increase their chances of producing more crops as soon as the next drought season comes.
Department of Agriculture -Davao El Ni\xf1o focal person Herna Palma said that since their agency has donated over millions worth of assistance for farmers, it is best that they learn various farming methods that could mitigate the effects of extreme heat so they could have a sustainable farm.
"Farmers should also treat El Ni\xf1o just like any catastrophic disaster since it could cost them their livelihood.
That is why they have to incorporate disaster prevention and mitigation methods in their farming," she said.
Palma said one of the effective sustainable farming methods that farmers could adapt is the conservation agriculture, saying its effects are a good start for disaster prevention and mitigation.
"The goals and benefits of Conservation Agriculture is to sequester amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, increase the efficiency of water and fertilizer use, improve soil quality and increase the farm's capacity to withstand extreme events," Palma said.
The effects of El Ni\xf1o are amplified when there is an increase in carbon dioxide emission.
This has then been a challenge to farmers since from the get go, they are already causing too much carbon dioxide emission when they till the land.
But conservation agriculture suggests that farmers should reduce or avoid tilling their land to decrease carbon dioxide.
To increase the soil quality of lands, Palma also suggests that farmers should utilize mulching more.
She described mulching as a method wherein different materials are spread across the surface of the soil.
Palma said mulching can increase the soil's fertility, maintain moisture and prevent growth of weeds.
Types of mulches include bark or wood shavings locally known as bagaso, compost, grass clippings, shredded leaves, straw and salt hay, grass clippings and animal manure.
The most highly-recommended mulch is the straw and salt hay mulch since it wards off soil-born diseases while it is also a low maintenance mulch for farmers since it does not decompose fast.
But Palma discouraged the overuse of animal manure compost since it contains methane, a greenhouse gas that could contribute to the rise of temperature in the environment.
Other than mulching, Palma also said farmers could instead use direct seeding rather than transplanting.
This is because through direct seeding, there can be less soil disturbance and this would mean less carbon dioxide emissions.
Another farming method in the conservation agriculture is the use of cover crops.
Just like mulching, cover crops can correct the nitrogen levels of the soil, prevent weeds from sprouting and maintaining moisture but its added benefits include the absorption of more carbon dioxide in the air and it acts as a natural pest repellant.
Among the most commonly-used cover crops are rye, buckwheat and oats.
DA also recommends the cultivation of drought-resistant crops to prevent losses among farmers.
For rice growers, Palma said the DA recently approved the drought resistant Green Super Rice  line.
Under the GSR line are GSR-5, GSR-8 and GSR-12 but Palma said that these crops are still at the pilot phase.
 But it is expected that these lines will start to produce yields by next year.
She also said they have a wide variety of drought-resistant crops including corn, banana and other major crops grown in the region.
Palma also reminded farmers to avoid excessive use of fertilizer as it could harm not only the crops but the soil composition in general, saying, "Most fertilizers have high nitrate content and too much nitrate on the soil could make it infertile."
But it is not only farmers that should be educated as Palma said communities situated near farmlands should also be informed of these methods so they could also help farmers in fully implementing conservation agriculture.
"Whether there is an El Ni\xf1o or not, farmers should be aware of what they should do to prevent damages to their crops.
After the El Ni\xf1o there is La Ni\xf1a that is why farmers should be prepared in any weather condition," Palma added.
El Ni\xf1o still threatens Davao, El Ni\xf1o still threatens DavaoReuel John F.
Lumawag, DESPITE the recent rains in the evening, the effects of the El Nino phenomenon can still be felt in Davao Region.

The dry spell poses a threat to the region's agricultural industry, which is also its main economic driver.

The aquaculture industry, especially those that are inland, are also in danger for fears of the ponds drying up.
However, Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources  in Davao Region Dr.
Fatma Idris said despite the hot weather, the aquaculture sector in the region remains safe.

She said the region has a Type 4 Climatic Condition, wherein the region experiences rainfall that is more or less evenly distributed throughout the year.
Idris said the region's climate has somehow helped cushion the impact of El Nino on the inland aquaculturists.
"Sa ngayon sa Davao Region, wala pa kaming narereceive na complaints or damages sa fisheries sector (For now in Davao Region, we did not receive any complaints or damages in the fisheries sector," she said.
But Idris said BFAR in Davao City noted lower water levels in catfish  ponds but this is not alarming to them considering that hito is able to survive in ponds with low water levels.
To ensure that temperature levels at the fish ponds are at acceptable temperature for the fishes, Idris said inland fishermen utilize paddle wheels to maintain a cool temperature in the ponds.
She said the agency will provide fingerlings to the inland fishermen in case the situation worsens.
They will only release these fingerlings if the El Nino has subsided.
Idris said they will prioritize the poorest of the poor among the fishermen when dispersing the fingerlings.
For now, she said they are more worried of the La Nina Phenomenon for the inland fisherman than the El Nino because increase rainfall will desalinate the ponds which are intended for salt water fishes.

Meanwhile, Idris said the increase in the temperature is also beneficial for those fishermen or aquaculturists who get their livelihood from the sea.
"We can say the higher temperature has a positive effect to the fishing grounds because the fish in the cooler areas will move to the warmer areas.
But this is only true for the temperature we are having now but if the heat goes to an extreme level then it is not favorable for the fishes," Idris said, adding that the heat temperature now in the region is at acceptable levels for the fishes in the sea.
She said if the weather is too hot, fishes will move to the deeper parts of the sea.
Idris also said the fact that most of the fish farms are in the sea has cushioned the effect of El Nino to the fisheries and aquaculture industries.
"The farmers are the ones who are really affected by the phenomenon because they are dependent on the water for their crops but for the fisheries sector, we already have water and many of those in the industry have their fish cages at the sea," she said.
Despite the little impact of El Nino to the fisheries sector, Idris said the hot weather and the sudden rainfall in the recent weeks caused extreme changes in the temperature at sea, triggering a Red Tide at Balite Bay in Mati City, Davao Oriental.
"Based on the results of red tide monitoring by BFAR and the local government units, shellfish sample collected from Balite Bay in Mati, Davao Oriental is positive for red tide toxins," the agency said in its Shellfish Bulletin last April 24.
She said the agency will conduct a weekly monitoring in the area to determine the level of toxicity of the shellfish in the area.
The agency said all types of shellfish and alamang gathered from Balite Bay are hot save for consumption.

But fish, squids, shrimps, and crabs are safe for consumption provided that these are fresh, washed thoroughly, and internal organs are removed before cooking.
With the ongoing El Nino, the fisheries sector is still in good shape but if things go bad, the agency has already placed its assistance for the farmers.
Mitigating effects of climate change, Mitigating effects of climate changeAntonio L.
Colina IV, AS CLIMATE change threatens the agriculture sector, the government sees the need to bring back the country's forest cover by creating a carbon sink to mitigate its effects.
But advocacy group Philippine Palm Oil Development Council Inc.
 said that reforestation efforts are best done when stakeholders learn to introduce the planting of oil palm either in farms as an intercrop or in the denuded forests.
The think-tank even highly recommended this in the priority reforestation program of the government dubbed "National Greening Program" .
The ultimate goal of NGP is more focused on achieving food security, poverty reduction, climate change adaptation and mitigation.
The total target under NGP is 1.5 billion trees in 1.5 million hectares for a period of six years from 2011 to 2016.
Dr.
Pablito Pamplona, board of director and secretary of PPDCI, said these crops sequester the carbon and thus prevent the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in the process.
The CO2 is one of the greenhouse gasses that worsen global warming by trapping in too much heat coming from the sun.
"Oil palm is found to be a better carbon sink than natural forest because it captures higher carbon/unit area," he said.
A study quoted by Pamplona found that a hectare of three-year-old oil palm trees can sequester 5.8 tons and can go as much as 45.2 tons when these trees are 24 years old as compared to the grassland, which can offset carbon at one ton per hectare.
Also, the planting techniques are just simple, as these crops do not need as much requirements as what other crops do.
First, there's no need to cut the grasses and brushes, much less burning that will only scratch the ground for more environmental risks such as erosion and further damage on the soil.
"Just allow the cut grasses and trees to rot as organic fertilizer for the oil palm trees," he added.
In the reforestation program, the think-tank recommended this crop as it has higher survival rate of 95 percent under harsh grassland environment as compared to other crops.
He was dismayed over the use of commercial crops like cacao and coffee in the NGP, which will later on die, cut, and turn into charcoal by farmers for livelihood to sustain their families.
These two crops, he explained, can survive the grassland's harsh environment when intercropped with oil palm, which prevents soil erosion for its vast root system.
"Oil palm has massive root systems that reduce soil erosion in the sloping uplands," he said.
"A new technique of crop-livestock integration, when applied, shall promote crop diversity and added income in the upland."
In neighboring Asean countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam, restoring the forests has been successful as they succeeded in reforesting their degraded grasslands using common strategy use of oil palm trees and rubber.
Pamplona also discussed the economic gains of the oil palm industry to the farmers, saying the Asean neighbors are successful in bringing down poverty levels.
"Promoting inclusive growth occurs when the poor, upland dwellers, get equal benefits from the economic growth of the country," he said.
The country has been lagging behind its Asean neighbors when it comes to cranking up the number of oil palms planted.
In 2013, Indonesia expanded to 10.5 million hectares of oil palms, followed by Malaysia  while Philippines was the lowest with 72,000 hectares.
According to PPDCI, the income that can be generated with oil palm is relatively higher than other crops; easy to plant and maintain; early maturing and long years of harvest; and provides employment opportunities.
Oil palm is also able to produce more even with smaller areas as compared to coconuts.
Say, to produce 1,000 tons of vegetable oil, this crop only takes 234 hectares while coconut takes 1,190 hectares.
For his part, Davao City Investment Promotions Center  officer-in-charge Ivan Cortez said investors who are willing to invest on oil palm are very much welcome in the city.
In fact, there is one investor, who is a major player in Malaysia's oil palm industry, who came to visit to discuss the matter with the National Commission on Indigenous Peoples .
The firm is looking at 1,000-hectare property in Marilog District.
If pushed through, members of the Ovu-Manuvo tribe will benefit from this venture as they will be tapped in the planting of the seedlings.
The official also said that this partnership will empower economically small farmers, especially the ones who own five hectares of land.
Environmental group Panalipdan Southern Mindanao urged the City Government to study before accepting investments on oil palm expansion in Marilog.
The environmental impact must also be considered before the economic gains.
"Paquibato is supposedly one of the important water resource base areas of the city while palm oil is not grown organically but dependent on chemical inputs which might pollute the local water resources in the uplands and affect the water supplies in the lowlands, a concern that we both shared," it said.
But Pamplona added that among other crops that produce oil, oil palm takes lesser use of fertilizers.
City Councilor Danilo Dayanghirang cited the need to develop the city's upland areas for agriculture as the urbanization of the center is simply not enough to sustain economic growth.
He suggested planting of high-value crops such as coffee, cacao, corn, and rubber as crops that will fit well in the highland communities like in Marilog and Paquibato.

Labrador, SOMETIMES, pushing yourself to your limits may lead you to discovering a whole new side of yourself that you never knew existed.

This was proven true by Louise Suamen, who found her purpose when she decided to go out of her 201ccomfort zone201d in her hometown in Siquijor, Negros Oriental and moved to Davao City to pursue her passion.
Louise is currently working as a psychosocial worker for Tambayan Children2019s Rights Center, a non-government organization working with less privileged and discriminated adolescent girls in the street aging 9 to 17 years old.
A Bachelor of Science in Psychology graduate of Silliman University where she had maintained an academic scholarship and graduated cum laude in 2010, Louise shared that unlike her batchmates, she did not know what to do after college.
201cHalos akong mga classmates nag HR  pero dili gyud nako na feel ,201d she said.
Louise then decided to live with her sister in Manila and worked in tutorial centers but this also did not work for her until she was invited to join an organization named Jesuit Volunteers Philippines, a volunteer organization based in Ateneo de Manila University.
201cI really liked the premise of the organization wherein for one year, they will place you in an area in need,201d she said in vernacular.
This then led her to Tambayan in Davao City wherein she was assigned for one year but then decided to stay as a regular worker back in 2011.
201cI really liked the work here; one thing that really stopped me from leaving is the experience itself, the children,201d she said.
Louise recalls that during her first few weeks working for the organization, she felt intimidated with the children and scared with their occasional visits in the residents of these children that they are monitoring which are mostly located in the known as crime prone areas in the city.
201cBefore, when I look at myself I am really afraid, I do not like tough jobs, I am always in my comfort zone, I do not take risks in life until after college when I saw that landing in a corporate job had no meaning for me,201d she said.
201cThat is when I remembered that I asked God to give me a job wherein I can be an instrument of His goodness and there I found Tambayan,201d Louise added.
Working for the organization for almost four years now, Louise finds pleasure and joy in helping and empowering children with their rights.

201cThe moment I went out of my comfort zone, I found meaning and I realized that if you are not comfortable you can do things that you think are impossible.
Your abilities will be enhanced and your perspective will widen, the way you look at yourself will change,201d she said.
Louise said that even in the future, she will still be pursuing on doing humanitarian work wherein she can really see the direct help given to those in need.
She added that she is also planning to teach and share her experiences to others soon.

Born on November 26, 1989, Louise is the youngest among five siblings.
She finished grades 1 to 4 of her elementary education in Siquijor Central Elementary School and grades 5 to 6 in Siquijor Central Elementary School back in 2002 and high school education at Siquijor Provincial Science High School in 2006.
Foodrunning is sharing, Foodrunning is sharingStella A.
Estremera, AN IDEA has taken shape and has started to grow in Davao City 2013 alleviating hunger by sharing.
A concept observed in the US and Canada by Davao City Councilor Leonardo R.
Avila III last year during his vacation there, there is now a group known as Davao Foodrunners, which has already been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission and just awaiting the release of its signed documents.
201cCan you imagine the bulk of food wasted from all these restaurants in the city? All these are thrown because restaurants will not risk poisoning anyone with spoiled food,201d Avila said in discussing the concept upon his return from his vacation late last year.
The problem, however, is that restaurants will not donate these excess food because of the risk of these getting spoiled in handling since these were already supposed to have been served earlier.
This is where Foodrunners comes in, Avila said.
As a registered organization, Foodrunners take the responsibility over the food they distribute to charity institutions and poor communities all over the city.
Members at present are the councilor and his wife Lorie Trinidad-Avila, Boy and Beth Jolampong, Tony Manahan, Melma Abasolo, Agnes Dacono, Monica Ayala, Vic and Ethel Canizares, Jesse Abrigo, Jon Morales, Alex Britanico, and Dinah Tolentino-Fuentes.
Since they started just this year, restaurants in the city are now responding positively.
201cThere are even restaurants here who allot a day to prepare food specifically for the Foodrunners,201d Avila said last Thursday during his birthday celebration with Badjao families in Matina Aplaya.
Aside from taking full responsibility for any untoward incident regarding the food they distribute and distributing these at the quickest time possible, Foodrunners members have also committed to celebrate their birthdays by sharing.
Thus, Avila celebrated his birthday with an early dinner with the Badjao residents of Kanaan at sitio Seaside 2 in Matina Aplaya.
The simple dinner of rice, pansit, grilled pirit, and kinilaw na tamban was shared by the almost 500 residents of Kanaan.
Indeed, a new movement of sharing has been jumpstarted in Davao.
Butch Aggasid: Tattoo artist on-the-rise, Butch Aggasid: Tattoo artist on-the-rise
Aggasid doing his craft 
INTERNATIONAL tattoo artist Albert John Aggasid is one of the most accomplished and talented tattoo artists in the Phillipines.
 He has been invited to conventions in Europe, the United States and Asia, after a long and storied career of winning both national competitions in the Philipines and international competitions.
His career as a tattoo artist grew from a hobby into an internationally-desired artist as clients from different parts of the worlds fly to the philippines to get a tattoo from him.
Inspired by an acquaintance who had fascinating tattoos all over his body,  he started his career in Cebu using an improvised tattoo machine on willing- often drunk, by-standers who became his first clients.
Mr.
Agassid went beyond commercial fame and taught his skills to other aspiring artists as an Art teacher every summmer.
His works grew from tattooing local and international celebrities with unique styles on portraits, realism, 3D and Tribal tattoo designs.
 He resided in Malaybalay City and introduced the art of tattoos there by Bloody Works, a renknown tattoo business which gained more admirers of his works, tattooing notable people like the families of politicians as well as other businessmen there.
 While doing so, he also established himself at the top of his field by winning several tattoo competitions.
These included the nationally known Kadayawan Festival in Davao city, and "Tatak" held in Cagayan de Oro City.
In 2012, he reigned at the highly regarded 201cPinatikan: Araw ng Davao Tattoo Competition"  where his portrait of Mayor Duterte won him as a Champion.
In 2013, he won as champion with his ethnic design during Bukidnon's first ever tattoo competition under the Black and Gray category and was tagged as the "Black & Gray Tattoo Master".
Perhaps the most well known trophy is the international competition 'Dutdutan2019, which is internationally known as the biggest tattoo convention in Asia, held in Manila where he topped among the hundreds of artists under the "Tattoo of the Day" Category.
With all these awards, he was moved to open 'Ink Digger Tattoo Studio' in Cagayan de Oro City.
Mr.
Agassid is known especially for his portrait and Tribal designs nationwide as well as in the USA and Asia.
But even with his success, he still makes it a point to deliver quality service and responsible teaching.
"Not just to give a nice tatto or to simply satisfy a client.
I want to make sure I could offer them quality work that is worth the pay", he told Sun.Star Cagayan de Oro in aninterview.
Ink Digger offers 3D, Portraits, Realism, Tribal, Watercolor tattoos, Tattoo repair and Cover-ups.
His works can be viewed on the shop's official website .

Hyundai is first to offer Android Auto system , Hyundai is first to offer Android Auto system DETROIT 2014 Hyundai is the first carmaker to offer Google's Android Auto system.
Starting Tuesday, Android smartphone users with a 2015 Sonata can ask dealers to download the system for free.
Drivers must have a Sonata with navigation, which is part of an optional technology package.
Android Auto will soon be available on other Hyundai models.
Android Auto connects to drivers' smartphones and lets them access certain apps, like Google Maps or Spotify, by voice, steering wheel controls or touchscreen graphics on the dashboard.
It locks their phones while in use to help keep drivers' eyes on the road.
Google says Android Auto is expected to be offered on 28 different brands by the 2016 model year.
Hyundai says it expects to offer Apple's version of the system, CarPlay, sometime soon.

PWD finds hope in life after Tesda, PWD finds hope in life after Tesda
Eduardo Ligalig 
A PAINTER, a musician, and a father of two, that's how he described himself at least 25 years ago.

Eduardo Ligalig was a happily married man who painted movie billboards for theaters in Antipolo, Rizal and sings in a band to support his family until 1990 when he met an accident that caused his disability.

He was disoriented for several months, and his leg was broken when a speeding tricycle hit him while he was crossing a street in Manila.
While he was still trying to recover from a head injury and broken leg, he lost his job.
He also finds it hard to go with his bandmates in gigs with his disability.
Without a job and a family to feed, he was broke.

Ligalig thought seeing his two children and wife eat rice mixed with hot water and sugar was the hardest part of being the family's breadwinner but it was only the beginning of the many challenges.

He said he tried selling garlic in the market but he could no longer keep up with his family's needs.
His eldest son was still four years old at the time and the youngest was still an infant.
There are times they had to settle for a bowl of congee, mixed with malunggay, sugar and a little bit of milk for the kids' nutrition.
It was not long after the accident that his wife decided to leave him and bring their children to Davao City to seek help from his in-laws.
 It was in 1998 when he last saw his two children.
"Nakadecide ang asawa ko na iwan ako at dalhin niya ang mga anak ko sa Davao.
Ang hirap pero wala akong magawa ," Ligalig said.

Since then, he has been living alone.
His father died when he was 10 and his mother is already old and could not help him with his finances.

Ligalig's friends would bring him to different provinces and play billiard tournaments or play guitar or other musical instruments just so he could support himself and send money to his children in Davao.

But times became so hard that he hardly could not afford his own personal bills, much more send financial support to his children.

In 2000, he decided to go home to his hometown in Bohol.
Someone gave him a piece of violin and used it to serenade guests in different resorts in Bohol.

"Minsan binigyan ako ng P50 or P70 pero kadalasan wala.
Hindi din naman ako araw-araw nakakapag-tugtog kasi walang tao.
," he said.

He likened his lifestyle to a beggar -- a man with a cane on one hand and a musical instrument on the other.
 He lived in Anda town, in an old house of his grandmother that was damaged by the 7.2 magnitude earthquake.
Several typhoons have past and blew the roof piece by piece.

"Kagabi umuulan dito, hindi ako nakatulog kasi naghahanap pa ako ng lugar sa bahay kung saan hindi ako nababasa ," Ligalig said.
A resort owner where he was playing violin, inspired him to enroll for a scholarship in the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority  and chose bartending in Florance technical school.
"Mahilig kasi ako sa wine.
May mga barkada ako at mahilig ako mag timpla ," he said.
He could not believe that after all those years of public ridicule, he can now proudly tell everyone he finished bartending course in Tesda.
He was absorbed as a bartender in the resort where he used to have his on-the-job training.

After graduation, he already found hope that his life would change for a better and soon realize the dream of reuniting with his children and wife whom he haven't seen since they left.

Without a cellphone or any communication gadgets, his boss and workmates helped him find his children on Facebook and for the first time in many years, he was able to talk to them.

"Priority na gyud nako ako mga bata karun nga naa na koy trabaho.
Sa kadugay na, wala gyud ko nakasuporta nila.
Gusto ko na makahatag gihapon ko bisan ginagmay ," Ligalig said.

Just this month, Ligalig's story to success won as the Best Story  in the Tesda Video Making Contest Year 2.

The winners were chosen from over a hundred of entries and were recognized at the Philippine International Convention Center in Pasay City.
Ligalig received a cash prize of P15,000.
He then used it to pay most of his personal loans and send money to his children.
"Malaki talaga ang pasasalamat ko sa aking school, sa Tesda, kay Sec.
Joel Villanueva, sa aming boss na talagang na bigay sa akin ng oportunidad na maka enrol sa Tesda," he said.
After all the expenses from the trip to Pasay, he was still able to send money for his children.
"Ang akong kalipay ang akong mga anak.
Masaya ako at hindi talaga sila napababayaan ng asawa ko kahit wala akong naibigay sa kanila.
Honor silang dalawa.
Ang panganay ko gusto na nag Criminology ay gusto talaga na mag SAF.
Ang youngest ko na babae gusto niyang mag teacher.
Nalipay ko na maghandom nila.
Nakapadala na ako para makatulong sa mga gastusin, pambili ng sapatos, at uniform.
Sa susunod, pag ipunan ko na talaga ang pamasahe para makita ko na sila.
May trabaho na ako," he said with full conviction.
.
My youngest, my daughter wants to be a teacher.
I am happy just by thinking of them.
I have already sent a little amount of money to help in the finances, to buy shoes and uniform.
Next time, I will really save up for fare to Davao and see them all.
I already have a job.)
Despite the distance and shortcomings as a husband and head of the family, he said his wife has not remarried nor found someone else to replace him.
He gushed as he said when asked about his wife: "Sabi kasi niya ako lang daw talaga ang mahal niya ."
His story can be seen on the YouTube video below, as well as on Tesda VII's Facebook page:

Great @ 15, Great @ 15
Screen shot of Sun.Star website
Mildred V.
Galarpe, GOOD journalism is Sun.Star's core value since it started more than 30 years ago.
In 2000, Sun.Star saw technology as a driving force in the future of news.
Jesus B.
Garcia Jr., Sun.Star chairman of the board, said they were scanning the news environment 15 years ago and saw that digital technology is going to change the media landscape.
"The idea of the website was to prepare the foundations of Sun.Star to be able to meet the needs and demands of the digital age.
That was the basic concept," Garcia said.
Today, the challenge for Sun.Star, Garcia said, is to provide the services of a gatekeeper to sift through the plethora of information that needs validation and verification.
Sun.Star president Julius G.
Neri Jr.
said technology has changed the role of newspapers.
Sun.Star has to adapt and innovate.

"Sun.Star is no longer just a newspaper, but an information provider to give readers the information they want, when they want it, and in whatever platform they choose," Neri said.
He said all the readers have so many choices available to them.
"They have various print publications; they have broadcast media, radio, Internet.
In the Internet alone, there are so many other subcategories.
We have apps, websites, e-papers and so forth.
So right now, the readers are spoiled for choice."
"It is our responsibility to be where our readers are, to remain relevant to them, to give them what they want to know about, what they want to read, when they want it, and in the way that they want it," he added.
The Sun.Star website, at www.sunstar.com.ph, grew with the audience and technology innovations in the last 15 years.
It is among the top performers in the online news industry and is the pioneer in online community journalism in the country, covering 12 major cities.

Now, on the website's 15th year, we celebrate 15 great things of Sun.Star online, mobile and social.
1.
Visually sexy - Taking cue from modern website design trends, Sun.Star adopted a new website design that features more photos and videos.
It runs dynamic galleries and media slideshows on any screen size.
The full screen slideshow is stunning and each slide represents a story.

Other media elements like sound bytes and video clips are also available, providing more life to a story.
These visual enhancements give Sun.Star readers a better reading experience, making www.sunstar.com.ph visually sexy.
2.
Certified mobile friendly - As more people browse websites using different mobile devices, Sun.Star saw the need to optimize and make its site responsive.
The new website is optimized for mobile, as well as for desktop.
It allows easy navigation, with no unnecessary finger movement needed to read the news.
Sun.Star is a Google-certified mobile friendly website.
3.
Thumb-friendly - For users on-the-move, Sun.Star is the way to go.
Multi-tasking is the word of the day and the thumb is the finger to play.
Getting the top headlines and breaking news can be done by thumb action.
Sun.Star's website has been optimized to make sure everything is big enough for easy navigation; spaces between elements are right for thumb clicking.
Sun.Star news is just a thumb away.



4.
Social all the time - Everybody is on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other social networking sites.
Sharing, commenting and recommending are social activities that connect friends, relatives and even enemies anytime, anywhere.
Sun.Star, with its improved website, allows sharing, commenting and recommending stories to social networking site easy and fast.
It provides a facility to comment and discuss hot issues of the day.
It also gives access to readers to connect to their favorite reporters and opinion writers for feedback or a news tip.
5.
Genuinely hyper-local - Sun.Star is the only network of community newspapers in the country.
It provides news from 12 major cities.
Its hyper-local content connects Filipinos here and abroad, making Sun.Star a home to many.
6.
Drone reporting - Sun.Star adopted another way of reporting news using drones or unmanned aerial vehicles to provide readers a wider view of an event.
The aircraft Sun.Star is using is remotely controlled.
Drone reporting shows readers the extent of fire damage, destruction by an earthquake or a typhoon, for example.
It provides vivid images of a sports event like Ironman, the Sinulog street dancing, road protests and a traffic mess.


7.
Live streaming - Sun.Star started live streaming in 2009.
It was something new for a newspaper company to try broadcasting, albeit over the Internet.
A basic camcorder, a free live streaming software and a free broadcasting service allowed Sun.Star to send live images of the Sinulog to the world, for the first time.
Filipinos abroad who saw the festival after years of being away got emotional and sent a deluge of thank-you messages.
Six years after the first live streaming, Sun.Star was able to stream live major festivals in the country like the Kadayawan in Davao, Panagbenga in Baguio, and Masskara in Bacolod, as well as international sports events like Ironman and Ronda Pilipinas.
Sun.Star now offers live streaming in high definition for a global audience.


8.
Webcast  - It is the latest innovation in Sun.Star's broadcast experiments.
Developed from scratch, the webcast is in Bisaya and is aired every noon from Monday to Friday.
The newscast provides updates of the day's headlines in video and sound bytes.
The webcast, that runs for 12 to 15 minutes, is available on replay after the live cast.
It was designed to be the lunch companion of Filipinos in the world.


9.
Video channel - Sun.Star is a content partner of YouTube.
It has "Sun.Star Philippines" as its TV channel, hosting video productions from the daily webcast, special features, live streaming videos and news clips of interviews with news sources or of events.
The channel has more than 6,000 subscribers as of May 2015.
A beauty tip video series by Sun.Star's Beauty Enthusiast columnist Joanna Cuenco is among the channel's offerings.
Subscribe to the Sun.Star channel at Sun.Star Philippines on YouTube to get the hottest videos and latest news.


10.
Read monitor - Read time is a usability feature of the new Sun.Star website.
It was designed to keep the user aware of how long it would take him or her to read the article.
It gives the user an idea of whether to read it now or later.
This feature sets user expectations upfront with the estimated time needed to read the articles.
"Reading so far" is another usability feature that guides the audience on how far he or she has read the story - 20 or 50 percent of the article.
11.
Personal to you - The volume of information online is maddening and annoying.
Sun.Star's app -- My Sun.Star -- showcases personalization of user's interests.
It also provides news bits for people on the move, app specific content and the one-touch access to news of your choice.
It is available on the Google Play store and soon on the Apple store.
12.
E-paper - The Sun.Star e-paper or the electronic paper is the exact digital replica of the printed paper.
It gives you the similar flipping experience of a printed paper in a digital platform.
Sun.Star provides a seven-day trial for those who want to try out the service.
With Sun.Star's e-paper service, you can now check your favorite Sun.Star newspaper online anytime, anywhere.
Under Sun.Star's banner are the e-papers of Sun.Star Cebu, Sun.Star SuperBalita Cebu, Sun.Star Davao, Sun.Star Pampanga, Sun.Star Cagayan de Oro, and Sun.Star Baguio.
The Sun.Star Cebu Yearbook and Sun.Star's Bisdak Magasin are also available.
Subscribe now.


13.
Creative advertising - Content is king, Bill Gates once said this and Google popularized it.
The face of online marketing has changed many times and it continues to create a buzz in the industry.
Some companies doing content marketing use social media  to push content about their brand, article posting , in-person events, e-newsletters, case studies, blogs and white papers and webinars.
Seeing these trends, Sun.Star provides creative advertising packages for advertisers.
It now offers sponsored content that allows advertisers to showcase their brand in text, photos, infographics and video, or in multimedia presentation.
It is labeled as sponsored content but the presentation is the same as the news and other information on the Sun.Star website.
Other creative online packages are now available and could be tailored to fit advertisers' needs.
Check with your Sun.Star advertising consultant for details.
14.
Young and dynamic staff - The people behind these digital improvements of Sun.Star are not just young and dynamic but passionate, dedicated and well-educated.
The Sun.Star Network Exchange  is the office that manages the digital innovations of the Sun.Star media group.
It is an office of 21 people, including a reportorial team in Manila, a perfect mix of young journalism graduates and experienced journalists from top universities like University of the Philippines, Ateneo de Manila, and Harvard University.
The team handles website updating, webcast, multimedia reports, live streaming, and social media campaigns.
Meet the people behind the Sun.Star website.


15.
You - The innovations and creations of Sun.Star are for you, our readers.
We appreciate the comments you left behind and the feedback on our new products and services, as they allow us to work some more and improve our creations.
We also value your appreciation of what we do to inspire us to do better.
Online innovations make Sun.Star future-proof, Online innovations make Sun.Star future-proof
Sun.Star digital products
Jad A.
Conde, WHEN it comes to taking community newspapers to the next level, Sun.Star never fails to exceed expectations.
The media company based in Cebu City has been keeping up with the times to remain relevant and useful amid the rapidly-changing digital landscape.
It has undertaken innovative efforts to match the profound and positive changes in the industry - proof of this is www.sunstar.com.ph, whose design has gone from being fixed to responsive, providing an optimal viewing experience for mobile users.
Sun.Star is also excited to introduce its newest mobile application that will serve its readers, advertisers, and community.
As Sun.Star Network Exchange  editor-in-chief Nini Cabaero puts it, the trick is to be up to the challenge.
"These innovations make us future-proof." As the whole media landscape changes, Sun.Star digs into its core competence - community journalism - as it ventures into digital territory.
New web design
Sun.Star is the first Philippine community newspaper company to go online.
It started as a Sun.Star Cebu website, then was converted into a network website at the same URL, www.sunstar.com.ph, on May 10, 2000, through Sunnex, new media department of the Sun.Star Publishing Inc.
Francis June Ygot, Sunnex web technology officer, said the website must adapt to new digital trends and should embody the latest technologies that not only matter to the business but also to its readers and subscribers.

The Sun.Star website underwent three major design modifications in 2015 alone, transforming it into a more user-friendly layout.
The website aims to achieve an optimal user experience that the design was simplified and it is now easier to navigate.
"The bigger job is to keep it updated and maintained," Ygot said.
"Constant technical supervision plays a very important role in the execution of the company's mission.
This would definitely help increase web presence."
Fresh materials added regularly to the website, accompanied by live streaming of events and video reporting of breaking news, also help increase online performance.
Mobile platform
Sun.Star's commitment to providing the public with news and information at whatever platform leads to the birth of its own dedicated mobile application aptly called, My Sun.Star.
In her one-year fellowship at Harvard University in 2013 - 2014 to study journalism innovations, Cabaero said she found a clear direction to come up with a mobile application separate from the website.
"People spend more time on their mobile devices to look for what is relevant to their daily lives.
They would prefer to go to one application to serve them what they want.
They do not want the online clutter; they want what is only relevant to them," Cabaero said.
Thus, My Sun.Star was added to the Sun.Star family.
Sun.Star understands the need to move toward a greater newspaper reinvention in order to remain ahead of the game.
The launch of My Sun.Star shows that the publication is fearless to push its brand on a different platform accomplished with an innovative and forward-thinking approach.

Sun.Star is following closely the mobile trend path to keep abreast of the complex and evolving mobile community.
The poet Robert Frost called it "the road not taken." A trek solely for the independent, brave and courageous.
Mobile mindset
But an effective mobile application involves more than just a mobile-friendly strategy.
To ensure its mobile presence, it should also understand the mobile mindset of consumers.
My Sun.Star addresses the need for content, form and structure different from its website and responsive mobile site.
My Sun.Star will have a daily summary of the news around the nation in its News Bits section.
Content will be personalized, based on the reader's preference.
Services not available on the website will be introduced on the mobile application.

The mobile application also offers services like Properties, Jobs, Lotto and Obituaries.
"Content on the website may be used on the mobile application, but not everything on the mobile application may be used on the website," Cabaero said.
My Sun.Star, available on the Google Play and Apple store, covers the most important stories from Sun.Star newspapers and networks in 12 major cities around the country.
These are Manila, Baguio, Pampanga and Pangasinan in Luzon; Cebu, Bacolod, Iloilo, Dumaguete, and Tacloban in the Visayas; and Davao, Cagayan de Oro and Zamboanga in Mindanao.
News and information are in English and Bisaya.
Google unveils Android's latest technological tricks, Google unveils Android's latest technological tricks
David Singleton, director at Android Wear, speaks during the Google I/O 2015 keynote presentation in San Francisco, Thursday, May 28, 2015.

SAN FRANCISCO 2014 Google's next version of its Android operating system will boast new ways to fetch information, pay merchants and protect privacy on mobile devices as the Internet company duels with Apple in the quest to make their technology indispensable.
The upgrade will give Android's personal assistant, Google Now, expanded powers of intuition that may be greeted as a great convenience to some and a tad too creepy for others.
Most of the renovations unveiled Thursday at Google's annual developers' conference won't be available until late summer or early fall, around the same time that Apple is expected to release the latest overhaul of the iOS software that powers the iPhone and iPad.
The annual changes to Android and iOS are becoming increasingly important as people become more dependent on smartphones to manage their lives.
Android holds about an 80 percent share of the worldwide smartphone market, with iOS a distant second at 16 percent, according to the research firm International Data Corp.
Both Google and Apple are vying to make their products even more ubiquitous by transplanting much of their mobile technology into automobiles and Internet-connected televisions and appliances.
Google hopes to play a prominent role in the management of home security and appliances with a new operating system called Brillo that will interact with Android devices.
Here's a closer look at some of the key features in the upcoming Android upgrade, currently known simply as "M'':
NOW ON TAP
Google Now currently learns a user's interests and habits by analyzing search requests and scanning emails so it can automatically present helpful information, such as the latest news about a favorite sports team or how long it will take to get to work.
With the M upgrade, users will be able to summon Google Now to scan whatever content might be on a mobile device's screen so it can present pertinent information about the topic of a text, a song, a video clip or an article.
The new Android feature, called "Now on Tap," will be activated by holding down the device's home button or speaking, "OK Google," into the microphone.
That action will prompt Now on Tap to scan the screen in attempt to figure out how to be the most helpful.
Or, if speaking, users can just say what they are seeking, such as "Who sings this?"
Google is hoping to provide Android users with what they need at the precise moment they need it without forcing them to hopscotch from one app to another.
MOBILE PAYMENT DO-OVER
Android M will include an alternative to the mobile payment system that Apple introduced last fall.
Google's response, called Android Pay, will replace Google Wallet for making mobile purchases in stores and applications.
Google Wallet, which came out in 2011, will still work for sending payments from one person to another.
Like Apple's system, Android Pay can be used to store major credit and debit cards in smartphones that can be used to pay merchants equipped with terminals that work with the technology.
Android Pay will also work on devices running on the KitKat and Lollipop versions of Android released the past two years.
PROTECTING PRIVACY
Android M will be compatible with fingerprint scanners so device users can verify their identities by pressing a button instead of entering a passcode.
Apple's iPhones began using a fingerprint reader in 2013.
Besides supporting fingerprint scanners, Android M will make it easier to users to prevent mobile applications from grabbing their personal information.
Permission will only need to be granted to each app if the access is needed for a specific action.
That means Android users won't be asked to share information about their contact lists, photo rolls or locations until an app won't work without it.

WINNING ENTRIES.
 These are the designs that Carmila Marie M.
Santos and Raida Kasim Esmael, 12, from Dadtumeg Elementary School in Kabuntalan town in Maguindanao created which is among the 20 designs that won in the World Food Programme Children's Design Global Competition held in Rome, Italy on February 26, 2015.

Richel V.
Umel, KOLAMBUGAN, Lanao del Norte 2013 Carmila Santos, 12, a student of Guillermo A.
Gemino Elementary School in this municipality, brought honor, fame and pride not only for Kolambugan people but in the entire Filipino nation.
Baicon Macaraya, sub-office Head of the World Food Programme  in Iligan City, told Sun.Star Cagayan de Oro that Carmila participated in the WFP Children's Design Global Competition using pastel colors.

The competition was anchored on the theme: Zero Hunger: Infinite Possibilities.
Macaraya said 150 schools children from the provinces of Lanao del Norte and Sur joined the first level of the competition on February 26, 2015.
 
There were 150 entries and the WFP staff that acted as judges chose only five which included Carmila2019s design that qualified for the national level.

At the national level competition, 13 participants competed with only eight designs selected by the WFP Philippines staff to qualify for the international level in Rome, Italy, the home of the WFP, Macaraya said.

She added that these eight designs selected for international entry included designs from Mindanao participants, three from Cotabato City and two from Iligan City.
Carmila2019s piece ranked among the top five and was sent to Rome.
At the WFP Headquarters in Rome, Macaraya said there were 23 country offices that participated in the competition with 115 art works on show.
Among the 115 works of art, the panel of judges from the WFP Headquarters chose 20 which included Carmila2019s piece and Raida Kasim Esmael, 12, from Dadtumeg Elementary School in Kabutalan town in Maguindanao.

Based on guidelines, the design will be used for calendars, desk diaries, post cards and other merchandise equipment.

"Amo syang gidasig nga kung unsa2019y iyang maayo nga mahuna-hunaan i-lakip nga makadugang ug kanindot sa disenyo og ipadayag ,201d Carmila2019s father said.
 
Carmila thanked her coach and mentor Marie Stele Salac and her school principal, Brenda Gayanelo, who were behind nurturing their collective efforts as they formulated the creative design.

"Wa ko mag dahum nga makaabot akong design sa international level sa competition diin usa kini sa 20 nga napili.

Evacuee
Carmila was among the children evacuees at the height of Kolambugan siege on August 18, 2008 after the Supreme Court declared the Memorandum Of Agreement between government and the Moro Islamic Liberation Front unconstitutional.
Carmila said "I was Grade 1 at that time when we left our place and fled to Ozamiz City to avoid getting into crossfire.

A model of peace and unity, A model of peace and unityRuji Peter S.
Abat, DESPITE the preconceived thought that the Maguindanao province is generally riddled with conflicts due to the presence of rebel groups and cultural and religious differences, a community in the municipality of South Upi where indigenous peoples , Muslims and Christians coexist has become a model of peace, as they have worked together to promote development in their barangay.

At Sitio Iking, Barangay Romongaob, a community composed of ethnic group Teduray, Moro people, mostly Maguindanaoans, and Christians have learned to set aside their cultural and religious biases.
The Romongaob Tri-People's Organization , a group organized through the collaboration of the Mindanao Trust Fund , Bangsamoro Development Agency , the Office of the Presidential Adviser on the Peace Process  and the local government, was organized in 2013 with a goal of fostering unity among different ethnic and religious groups, as well as improving the quality of the residents' lives amid the ongoing armed conflicts in their area.
RTPO president and a Moro local Jade Omar told Sun.Star Davao in an interview that their community has long been bombarded by the conflicts between the Moro Islamic Liberation Front  and government forces, and this has greatly affected their main source of income, which is corn farming.
"Ilang beses na kaming nag-evacuate at malaki ang epekto nito sa aming pangkabuhayan dahil naiiwan namin ang aming mga pananim.
Ang dagdag pa sa problema ay iyong kakulangan sa kagamitan sa pagsaka ," Omar said.
Barangay Romongaob chairman and Association of Barangay Captains  president Reynalbert Insular, in a separate interview, said there has long been unity among the different tribes and religions in the barangay, yet the armed conflicts that have been going on since the 70's has disturbed this harmony.
"Nagkakaroon tuloy ng mga conflicts ang mga tribo dahil sa mga land disputes.
Ang nangyayari kasi ay pag naiwan nila ang kanilang mga lupang pinagtataniman dahil sa giyera, pagbalik ay nahihirapan na silang i-identify kung alin ang sa kanila lalo na pag nasira ang mga boundaries, ," Insular said.
Children have also been greatly affected by the conflicts, as Perlita Laugan, RTPO secretary and a Teduray tribal member, said they find it difficult to send their children to school since their income are significantly lowered after they leave their farms whenever an encounter breaks out.
For RTPO procurement chairman Rodolfo Toriales, being a Christian in an area dominated by IPs has not been a problem as he has learned to adapt to the different traditions and practices of the Teduray and the Muslims.
But he pointed out that the war has been the root cause of poverty in their barangay.
Through the MTF and BDA projects focused on implementing community-driven development in conflict-affected areas, the RTPO had a stronger grasp of unity and this has given them hope that their lives will prosper once they work together.
After going through a series of trainings tackling on values enhancement, financial management, logistics and leadership, the RTPO was able to identify the issues in the community level and how they could manage them.
While the armed conflict has been the primary problem, the RTPO has focused on the surrounding issues of poverty and its corresponding effects to health and education.
MTF program manager and senior social development specialist of the World Bank Matthew Stephens, in a separate interview, said: "The beneficiaries had the liberty to choose the project they want to implement and in the case of RTPO whose livelihood is focused on corn farming, they chose to have a warehouse and solar dryer where they could store their corn harvests."
Other than the storing facility, the MTF has already provided RTPO with traveling corn shellers.
RTPO is part of the different areas in South Upi that has received a total of P406,135.60 for farming tools, P1,264,493.29 for warehouses built solar dryers and P1,762,933.34 for separate solar dryers from MTF, which amasses donations from various international donors.
With the solar dryer, the quality of the grains is maintained, thus giving higher value for the harvest.

The facility and equipment also paved the way for the RTPO to have savings in transporting their products and paying different warehouse handlers in different Sitios now that they have their own.
On top of that, the corn sheller itself is income generating as RTPO collects P10 per use, which the RTPO utilizes for its maintenance and to pay the operator.
 
"We have made agreements which have resulted to the crafting of policies in the use of the facility and equipment and how its proceeds will be used.
It shows that even a small community like ours can understand each other despite our different culture and religion," Toriales added.
Laugan said that with increased income from their harvest as post-harvest losses are drastically reduced, they can now afford to send their children to school.

She also pointed out that through RTPO, gender equality has been promoted in their barangay, saying: "The women of RTPO has equal rights with the men since we also have a big role in making plans and implementing the projects in the barangay.
We are also hands on and what men do here, we women also do."
On the issue of land disputes, Insular said that tensions have eased because of the RTPO.
"It has become easier to mediate because they already know that they have a common goal which is to bring development in the barangay," he said.

Going the extra mile, Going the extra mileMaria Gemima C.
Valderrama, 
ELENA Nasiad Meralles, 46, is no ordinary educator and school head.
 As the principal of Bago Elementary School in Barangay Bago Gallera in Davao City for two years now, Elena is stirred to do more than what is needed.
One of her priorities is to promote the involvement of the communities in schools.
 This is the reason why the Busog, Lusog, Talino  program in their school was sustained to end malnutrition among students with below normal nutritional status.
This is also the reason why Elena was recognized nationwide and was given the 2015 Busog, Lusog, Talino Excellence Award.
 This is the first ever awards program by Jollibee Group Foundation  as they start the tradition of honouring exemplary performance of BLT schools all over the country.
For Elena, the BLT program is not just about feeding the children, but it is also about expressing genuine concern and involving strong leadership.
For 120 days, the identified children are given nutritious food daily as their lunch.

Parents prepare the food and at 11:30 in the morning children are called in at the feeding center.
 Attendance is checked to ensure that every identified pupil is around for lunch.
 They wash hands, pray together, and eat together.
As part of training the kids to become responsible, the pupils return the plates to the lavatory after eating.
Some home economics pupils wash the dishes and clean the area.
Elena remembers that a Grade 1 pupil refrained from being absent because the pupil knows they look for her every eating time.
 The feeding program increased her attendance and she became more participative in school.
201cAbout 85 percent of our recipients have increased weight, improved attendance and grades,201d Elena said.
Some parents, Elena said, have learned different recipes as the foundation provides a menu of nutritious but affordable food.
 They can also exercise meal patterns and other best practices like sanitation.
Elena was the principal of Baliok Elementary School for six years before she was transferred to Bago Elementary School.
 Since 2009 when BLT started, Elena designed a sustainability plan where she focused on resource-generation and she continued what she has started in her new school.
She has managed to get a continuing support from the local government unit where a barangay resolution was crafted for the school to be provided 10 sacks of rice a year.
The school also gets 35 percent from its canteen earnings.
The positive attitude of Elena was one of the reasons why Executive Director Gisella Tiongson of JGF was impressed during the visit.
Elena gave full support to the feeding program and all she wanted was a reciprocated full support from partners and the community.
In the first year of implementation in 2009, JGF allocated 11 pesos daily budget for 120 days to 40 identified pupils for the feeding program.
 The year after, they were given 5.50 daily.
 Since principals were trained to link with stakeholders, the remaining years were up to the principal to sustain the program.
They had bridging leadership training and this was where Elena championed among the rest of the implementing schools in the region.
The training put emphasis on ownership and co-ownership of the program.
Tiongson saw how determined Elena was so she reminded their local implementing partner Davao Doctors College to endorse Elena to the committee to undergo screening.
It was the start of a colourful beginning for Elena.
 
She was chosen to represent Mindanao among the best 10 stories in the commemorative book of the foundation distributed during the summit and to be used as inspiring success stories of change.
Only her story and one from Luzon were played and viewed during the awarding last May 5 in Pasig City.
Yes, hers is a story of change.
Elena proved that leadership is about revealing oneself, accepting feedback, and taking the risk.
She showed the community what she wanted for the school, she listened to the needs of the learners and what the community can probably do, and ventured all the possibilities to involve others.

So the last four years of the BLT program where the principal would look for initiatives to sustain the program, Elena was right in the middle involving everyone to open their hearts and mind.
Elena is a superb mother and wife too.
She is a devoted partner to husband Salvador, Jr.
who is a senior fire officer of the Bureau of Fire and Protection in Bangoy Fire Station.
Together they water the family with love along with their children Jamaica, 20; Jethro, 18; and Joshua, 12.
For Elena, love and trust are the assets in the family while positive attitude is the capital in any successful program implementation.
201cWe can have the support of our stakeholders, let2019s all keep every program sustainable,201d  Elena said inspiring educators like her to keep the ball rolling in their school.
Elena2019s going the extra mile is an act of human dignity to do more than is necessary.
This is an act everyone needs to allow hopefulness to rule.
