For next year, Alip hopes to add more courses like microinsurance, business development services, accountancy, and information technology and build another school in Mindanao.
"Instituting CMDI into a tertiary school is a way of Card-MRI to improve the quality of life of many Filipinos and continually fight poverty in the country," Card-MRI said.

Card-MRI currently supports 1,823 scholars studying in different schools all over the country.

Road sharing: A bold experiment for Edsa, Road sharing: A bold experiment for Edsa
An ambitious experiment to solve the traffic anarchy on Edsa, Metro Manila2019s busiest highway, will be tried out on June 28 by a broad-based movement.
AN AMBITIOUS experiment to solve the traffic anarchy on Epifanio delos Santos Avenue , Metro Manila2019s busiest highway, will be tried out on Sunday by a broad-based movement that brings together government and civic officials, environment advocates and even cycling enthusiasts.
It2019s called the Edsa Evolution: Bayanihan sa Daan , and its organizers said it promotes the principle of road-sharing, commuter and motorist discipline, and the efficient use of pedestrian lanes.\xa0
Basically, Bayanihan sa Daan is a scheme that assigns Edsa2019s five lanes to specific road users, and in the process restore order in the notoriously congested thoroughfare.
The experiment will cover the stretch of Edsa from Mall of Asia  in Pasay City to Ortigas Avenue in Mandaluyong City.
The lane closest to the sidewalk will be reserved for pedestrians, the next lane for bikers, the third and fourth for provincial and city buses, and the fifth for private vehicles.
Private motorists will be allotted only one lane because less than one percent of one million Filipinos own cars.

201cWhy Edsa? If you can do it in Edsa, you can do it anywhere,201d environmental lawyer Antonio Oposa Jr., one of prime movers of Bayanihan sa Daan told a press conference last Monday.
The 23.8-kilometer Edsa passes through six cities, and between 600,000 and one million vehicles drive through it every day.
Oposa was able to involve in the movement the Office of the President, Metropolitan Manila Development Authority , Department of Transportation and Communications , Department of Environment and Natural Resources , Department of the Interior and Local Government , Department of Social Welfare and Development , civil society groups including Clean Air Asia, Philippine Medical Association, National Bike Organization, Firefly Brigade and other cycling groups, Integrated Bar of the Philippines, Partnership for Clean Air Asia.\xa0
201cFor this Sunday, nakausap namin yung mga bus operators na titigil sila sa bus stop.
2018Pag napuno sila, tsaka sila aalis bago sila titigil sa second bus stop which is far away.
Why far away? Because we are encouraging people to walk,201d Oposa said.
City buses will be allowed to load and unload passengers at Mantrade near Magallanes and Ortigas.\xa0
Bus operators assured the experiment organizers they will not field smoke-belching units on Sunday.
The MMDA will make available bicycles for free during the experiment.
 Supreme Court battle 
Before coming up with the proposal for Edsa, Oposa and other environmentalists asked the Supreme Court in February last year to compel government to devote half of all roads to motorized vehicles and/or Filipino-made mass transport systems.
The other half will be for covered sidewalks, all-weather bike lanes and urban gardens.

They also wanted the Department of Budget and Management  to allocate funds for the implementation of the road sharing scheme.
The SC has yet to come up with a decision on the case but whatever the outcome would be, Environment Secretary Ramon Paje had said the government has several plans in motion to help meet the standards and regulations set by the Clean Air Act of 1999.
These include the use of vehicles consuming clean and alternative fuel, establishment of provincial bus terminals outside Metro Manila, installation of fully automated monitoring stations to measure air pollution levels around the capital.
Oposa has high hopes that the road-sharing concept will eventually lead to a safer, convenient and efficient public transport system and improve the air quality along Edsa.
201cTo address the ever-worsening crisis of traffic congestion, we need to change the mindset of transportation 2013 from being about private cars to being about improving public transportation; from wasting road space for the use of a few, to making good use of road use of the public space for the many; from agawan at swapangan sa daan to cooperative heroism on the roads 2013 Bayanihan sa Daan,201d he said.
Aside from the road-sharing implementation, the proponents also plan to grow edible plants on Edsa2019s dividing island.\xa0
MMDA Chairman Francis Tolentino said he will need to consider the public2019s response to Edsa Evolution before adopting the scheme.\xa0
Tolentino said the plan of the Department of Public Works and Highways  for a major repair of Edsa should also be taken into account before the road-sharing scheme is implemented.

5 lessons in NBA final playoffs, 5 lessons in NBA final playoffsTHE showdown between the Golden State Warriors and the Cleveland Cavaliers had come to an end.
The Filipinos are one of the biggest basketball fans in the world.
Some became basketball critics during the first half of the game and concluded that the Warriors are taking control of the game.
They were so confident that the Warriors will walk away with the crown at Game 6 at the Cavalier's home court.
True enough, the Warriors ended their 40-year drought with a victory against the Cavaliers.
I am a Boston fan but I can't help myself but to admire the Warriors at their victory after their long slumber.
 As I reflect after the game, I realized that the life in the court is very much like our ordinary lives.
So, here are the five lessons in life that I've learned from the NBA finals.
1.
Follow your head coach's orders
Let God be the guide of your life.
During a week's stay in the Sacred Heart Novitiate in Novaliches as part of my exposure to Jesuit life, I learned something that keeps coming back regardless of the circumstance I am in: "When you say YES to God, there's no need for plan B."
During the game, the Warriors always listened to their head coach, Steve Kerr.
They absorbed every strategy and plan of their coach.
Their trust on their head coach made them more confident to overcome every obstacle in their path.
That's why they became the top seed in their conference.

Lesson in life: God is your head coach in life.
When God tells you to do something, even if you can't see why, trust that He has a good reason.
He can see parts of the field that you can't.
 Always say YES to God because he will lead you to something better than you imagined, just like what Steve Kerr wants for his team.
2.
Be unselfish and trust your teammates.
Basketball is a team sport that requires cooperation and contribution.
It is not a one-man army game wherein only the superstar will lead the team.
 Everyone must focus, work together and fulfill their individual roles for the common good of the team.
 During the finals, Lebron James is a walking triple double but he wasn't able to carry his team to Game 7.
 Individual greatness can be measured by winning a championship ring especially in basketball but for a person who always thinks of himself, he cannot get one.
Lesson in life: Always contribute, share and cooperate.
In our society today, we need to help each other and contribute to the success of our nation.
What made the state golden in Golden State? It is because they helped each other attain victory.
Let's be a warrior also to help our society so that we can be a GOLDEN STATE.
For politicians, stop being pa-epal in every project that you make.
If you're willing to serve, don't carry your name.
Always think of the people's money that you should use to help them get up and improve our society.
3.
Don't wait for Game 7 to win the championship.
Game 7 is always the highlight of the game in basketball because of the excitement induced by a "do or die" or "win or go home" game.
It is an exciting and nerve-breaking duel between the two teams in reaching the championship title.
However, the Warriors didn't wait for Game 7 to attain their title.
During the first half of the game, they were already in the lead.
Lesson in life: In life, the earlier you finish your task, the more time you have to relax.
In my five years of teaching, the most common problem of students is not bullying, academic performance or teachers.
It is procrastination, the practice of making something in the last minute.
We must get rid of our ma\xf1ana habit if we want to attain success in life.
If we can do it today, we should do it now.
4.
If the plays aren't working, re-adjust the game plan.
During the finals, Cleveland won Games 2 and 3 against the Warriors.
After two consecutive defeats, the team re-adjusted their game plan that led them to victory.
Every great basketball player knows that when your plays aren't working, you have to adjust and then adjust some more.
The varying strengths and styles of different opponents require different tactics.
You have to be able to withstand and respond to whichever attack an opponent uses on you.

Lesson in life: Everyday, we always complain about our work, other people and whatever happened to is.
Sometimes we need to ask ourselves, do we change ourselves? If not, then start changing now as the Michael Jackson hit, Man in the Mirror, says: "I'm starting with the man in the mirror/I'm asking him to change his ways/And no message could have been any clearer/If you want to make the world a better place/Take a look at yourself, and then make a change."
As my co-teacher, Mr.
Ariel Bendo once said "If you want to change the society, start from yourself and you can see the brighter tomorrow that you wanted to see." Before you re-adjust your game plan, make sure to re-adjust or start changing yourself first.
5.
Always give thanks to God.
Stephen Curry is one of the most dominant shooters of the league.
He proved it by breaking the record of the most number of shots posted in a single season set by Reggie Miller.
But what makes Stephen Curry different from other players? In his acceptance speech, he said: "First and foremost I have to thank my Lord and Savior Jesus Christ for blessing me with the talents to play this game, with the family to support me, day in, day out.
I'm his humble servant right now and I can't say enough how important my faith is to who I am and how I play the game." His humility and strong Christian faith makes him one of the most admirable players in the league.
Lesson in life: Sometimes, when we are happy, we tend to forget God.
We only remember him when the world is against us.
We must not forget to thank God in every blessing that we receive.
Even the moment we wake up in the morning is a blessing that we must thank God for because not all people can wake up and start a new life every morning.
Always give thanks to God because with him we can overcome our struggles in life.
Paul said to the Philippians, "I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me."
It is important to learn valuable life lessons by watching the game but success is not all about winning, it is all about learning and experience that will help us grow.
As Coach Wooden once said, "Success is peace of mind, which is a direct result of self-satisfaction in knowing you did your best to become the best that you are capable of becoming."
In the end, it is all about the lesson in life that we must share, success is not acquisition of power, prestige or financial wealth, it is values that we must pass in order to maintain the balance in this world.
So now, start it with person next to you.
Pass it on! 
Masbad: The next extinction, Masbad: The next extinctionRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, WE'VE heard a lot of climate change these past years.

Here2019s the opening paragraph of that article:
In the last half-billion years, life on Earth has been nearly wiped out five times -- by such things as climate change, an intense ice age, volcanoes, and that space rock that smashed into the Gulf of Mexico 65 million years ago, obliterating the dinosaurs and a bunch of other species.

The question now, really, is whether we2019re good-hearted enough to use our collective skills to keep our Gaia breathing and healthy.

A role model, A role modelRhona Goc-ong-Villariasa, IT DEMANDS a lot of hard work and sacrifices just to juggle his work as a Public Information Officer  of a government agency, at the same time, being the single parent to his seven-year-old son.
But for Mario Intong Daray, PIO of Social Security System  Davao branch, he remains optimistic, happy, and full of hope.
He has his father as role model.
While he was born in Kidapawan North Cotabato on July 16, 1957, the family moved to Bohol when he was still a child.

"Grade 1 to 6 lang ako sa Kidapawan, medyo magulo kasi yung lugar namin before, so lahat kami binitbit ng tatay namin papuntang Bohol," shares Daray, who at an early age lost his mom.
Despite of poverty and the hardship of raising eight siblings, Daray added that his father named Getolio, a former music teacher of Notre Dame of Kidapawan, remained enthusiastic, and struggled to provide for all their needs.

After his high school graduation at the Holy Name University in Bohol, he decided to be back in Davao to work, at the same time to continue his schooling.
"For one week, pumasok ako as tagahugas ng plato sa Mekenis Barbecue sa San Pedro, then I tried my luck, pina-apply naman ako ng cousin ko sa Ateneo College canteen."
His employer even enrolled him in Ateneo at a half scholarship grant.

"Pero kahit half scholar na ako di ko pa rin natapos, naka one semester lang ako, mahal pa rin kasi.
I stopped and transferred to University of Mindanao," he said.
Daray enrolled in a two-year Radio Operator Course in UM opening the door to venture into the broadcast industry.
He found work at dxSS Channel 7 in Bangkal.
From 1975 till 1979 he served at the Technical Department, until he became a radio reporter from 1979 to 1984.
"But 1984, nag-close ang dxSS nagkaproblema so tinanggal lahat ng empleyado.
Timing din na graduating na ako sa college.
Kasi while working sa broadcast I continued my college degree sa Rizal Memorial College , kumuha ako ng Commerce," he said.
He started as a temporary teacher at RMC, until the management gave him a permanent position.
For 12 years, Daray taught business subjects.

He said scholarship grants allowed him to finish a degree.
He moved to SSS in 1989 as Member Service Representative assigned at the Member's Assistance Desk.
"For 20 years, akong na-assign to that department then I became an OIC team head sa group."
It was in 2010 when the position for Sr.
Communication Analyst for SSS Davao Branch was offered.
With his skills, ability and experience, and after passing the exams and interview, Daray got the position, and became the frontliner of the agency.

For five years being a PIO, Daray shares that the task is not easy.

"Kung empleyado ka ng SSS, you should be patient, tolerant, caring and friendly.
Yung mga taong lumalapit sa iyo are persons in need," he said.
"Nung bago pa lang ako, di ko yan nararamdaman.
Kasi sa isip ko work then sweldo.
Lagi akong nakakakita ng away, but later on na-realize ko na being an employee of SSS you should have that empathy sa mga members na lumalapit sa iyo seeking some assistance."
Aside from a hectic schedule as PIO, he is also a hands-on father to Daniel, his 7-year-old son.
He disclosed that working and taking care of his son's welfare is not an easy job, but the fulfillment is something he is always proud to share.
"Kahit busy ako sa work, I really try my best to perform my function as a father and mother to him," he said.
Though he still dreams of finding a partner in life, Daray quips that if it's really his destiny to spend this kind of life, he would gladly accept it.
"At this point in my life, I'm not empty, I have my son.
Kung wala siya anong klaseng buhay kaya meron ako? If di man ako makahanap ng partner okay na sa akin, may anak na ako."

Elementary buds reach out to far-flung school, Elementary buds reach out to far-flung schoolLarry P.
Fabian, NANGALISAN, Tuba, Benguet -- For the urban raised and bred professionals, an outreach program to the less privileged, may mean more than a self-reflection of their blessings, but also giving a good example to their families.\xa0
A band of elementary schoolmates from the early 80s started doing this four years ago, but this time brought along their families to show how blessed they are than most other people in far flung places.\xa0
Dr.
Lizalyn Barros-Revilla and her batchmates annually visit Gallano Elementary School in Aringay, La Union, which is located near the boundary of Barangay Nangalisan in Tuba, Benguet.
Gallano is the farthest barangay of Aringay.\xa0
With their family members in tow, and this time, with members of the Philippine Dental Association-Baguio City, they trekked at least a kilometer, including a thirty feet high and forty meter span one-way hanging bridge, before reaching the school where 120 students and their parents had been expecting them yearly.\xa0
Lina , a grade two pupil was one of those who waited.
She and her grandmother walked five kilometers from their home to reach school early for the school kits to be given by the group.\xa0
201cHan nga makaturog, idi pay lang maysa nga domingo kalpas ipakaamo ni teacher da ,201d Lina2019s grandmother revealed.\xa0
Dr.
Jovy Yba\xf1ez, PDA-BCC chairman, immediately proceeded to conduct dental fluoride treatment with other dental volunteers to eager students.\xa0
201cFrom last year, we noticed the lack of oral health care, noticing that most of these children have tooth decay,201d Dr.
Yba\xf1ez explained.\xa0
As others received dental care, the school kits were distributed to the students, where Lina eagerly awaited her turn to be handed her eco-bag filled with needed school materials.\xa0
A wide grin of happiness lit up her face while checking out her new notebooks, pens and pencils, rulers and coloring pens.

201cAda pag surat kun, lola ,201d Lina said as she showed her grandmother her fist full with pencils and pens.\xa0
Dr.
Revilla, on the other hand, showed her two teenage sons how their presence means by letting them hand some of the school kits and talk to some of the students.\xa0
201cI want them to feel how doing these missions are being received and appreciated by these kids, as compared to them where everything is well provided,201d Revilla explained.\xa0
Marichu Trinidad, who came with her husband and small son, also joined in the distribution of goods.\xa0
201cI told my son how poor these kids are and that any help they receive today will help them continue their studies and like him, will one day graduate from school,201d Mrs.
Trinidad shared.\xa0
For now, Lina and the rest of her school mates will have a reason to walk from their homes to their schools, no matter how far, given their free school material and being encouraged to finish their education.\xa0
The batch of SLSCF of 85 will continue to provide lesser privileged public schools and their students with these items even as the funds used come mostly from their own pockets.
They say the payback is the joy they feel after seeing these children appreciate what they receive.\xa0
201cWe hope to give more, but so far this is what our money could just afford for now,201d Revilla said.

201cWe hope bigger and more roundly funded groups with kind hearts can also come to these unrecognized areas who could fix one of their dilapidated and condemned classroom which the school still use,201d she ended.
In-depth report: 4Ps further explained, In-depth report: 4Ps further explainedRuji Peter S.
Abat, SINCE the implementation of the Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program  in Davao Region in 2009, there has been a total 229,871 beneficiaries who have received cash grants from the Department of Social Welfare and Development  in Davao Region.

Davao del Sur made up the bulk of the beneficiaries at 84,510, but this is because Davao City, a chartered city and shouldn2019t have been included in the province, is included.
Davao City accounts for 20,301 of this total.

It is followed by Compostela Valley Province with 56,698, Davao del Norte with 47,838 and Davao Oriental with 40,825.
Beneficiaries are selected based on the data of the National Statistical Coordination Board  while DSWD also utilizes data gathered by its National Household Targeting System for Poverty Reduction .

The figures derived from both databases are then collated in the community level through social workers who conduct house-to-house visits for a more specific validation.
Families may receive as much as P1,400 every month.
Parents get P500 while each child of elementary to high school age get P300.
Only three children are given the cash grant in a family.
DSWD-Davao information officer for the 4Ps Sheryll Fernandez, in an interview with Sun.Star Davao, admitted that the cash grant is just a little, but this already means a lot to poor families.
 
"It is just an assistance for families so that they will have additional allowances to send their children to school and feed them," Fernandez said.

Fernandez reacts to criticisms that the program is but a dole-out.
She said there are conditions that are set for the family to receive the assistance and can thus not be considered as dole-out.
Students receiving the cash grants should at least have an 85 percent school attendance every month while they are also required to visit health care centers for regular checkup.

Mothers, meanwhile, should also have themselves checked in the health care centers and are obliged to attend family development sessions.
If these conditions are not met for the first time, beneficiaries will get a verbal reprimand while the next non-compliance would entail a written reprimand from the regional director.
The third offense would cause the suspension of cash grants for a month while those who fail to comply for the succeeding months may be delisted from the program.

"We strongly believe that it is not a dole out since they have to follow these conditions.
After all, if they follow these conditions we could help families keep their children in school while they can also maintain good health," Fernandez said.

But she was quick to add that they do not directly delist beneficiaries as they let social workers conduct the social case management to identify why some beneficiaries fail to comply.
The social workers are then tasked to conduct interventions in order for beneficiaries to get back to following the conditions.

In relation to the delisting of beneficiaries, data from DSWD-Davao showed that a total of 1,979 were already excluded from the beneficiaries.
Most of the delisted beneficiaries have opted to waive themselves off the program while some were excluded after they were deemed ineligible due to the increase in their salary.

Fernandez, however, admitted that they are also forced to delist the so-called inclusion errors, saying: "Our system is not perfect and there are those who are included even though they are not actually eligible.
So what we do is we let our social workers validate their eligibility and if they are not really eligible then we delist them." 
DSWD has also bore the brunt of having fraudsters who pose as marginalized people and later on social workers would find out that they are actually disqualified for the program.

"Some of the beneficiaries intentionally refuse to disclose their other assets when they are being interviewed by social workers.
We would then discover that they have other properties or assets elsewhere so we also delist them," Fernandez said.

It has been six years since the program has been implemented but Fernandez said none of the beneficiaries have graduated from the program due to the changes implemented by President Benigno Aquino III last year.
Before, cash grants were only provided to children aging 14 and below, yet under Aquino's administration, the cash assistance was extended to those who are on their way to high school.
Those in the secondary level of education, meanwhile, receive P500 each month instead of the P300 that elementary students get.
Due to the extension of the program to high school level, DSWD has yet to fully assess how the 4Ps has actually aided in the entirety of their poverty alleviation programs.

"So far, the assessments come from the success stories of our beneficiaries.
Our monitoring and evaluation also has a case management tool called the Social Welfare Indicator, which determines the level of well-being of our beneficiaries but since the program has extended we have yet to determine when a beneficiary should graduate from the program," Fernandez said.

The levels of well-being, Fernandez said, include survival, subsistence and self-sufficiency.
Those in the survival level could be considered the poorest of the poor as members of the households under this level are usually unemployed and lack the technical skills.

Households within the subsistence level, meanwhile, are those with only one parent or adult member who sustains the family.
Self-sufficient level means at least two members of the household who are skilled enough to land regular jobs.
These indicators have yet to be consolidated but the DSWD still considers 4Ps as one of its flagship programs amid its uncertainty in addressing poverty.

"For as long as this program helps families keep their children in school while keeping families healthy as well, then the program will continue.
Anyway, those who will graduate in the 4Ps are most likely to qualify for other programs of the DSWD," Fernandez added.
In-depth report: No-read, no-write, no more , In-depth report: No-read, no-write, no more Ivy C.
Tejano, TO RISE above the discrimination that Badjaos have been subjected through the past decades is now a mother2019s dream for the rest of her children who can still catch up after being shown what it takes.

Gelin Amelita Rendo said she realized this after going through the Basic Literacy Program conducted by the City Link through the Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program  of the Department of Social Welfare and Development .

The 4Ps is a human development measure of the national government that provides a conditional cash grants to the poorest of the poor to improve the health, nutrition and education of their children.

Gelin is among the Badjao beneficiaries living at Purok 4B, Barangay 23 C, Mini-Forest, Boulevard.
She has eight children named Roni, Freddie, Tambi, Tinang, Totong, Lupin, Mina and Shenie with her husband Rhojz.
 
Reading, writing, 'rithmetic
201cWa rako kabalo sa ilang edad.
Ang magulang minyo na tua nay duha ka anak.
Duha sa ila minyo na, anaay uli-tawo, kini si Tambi nay depekto, uban bata pa tua nag eskwela ,201d Gelin told Sun.Star Davao.
 
The elder five are all out of school, four of whom have only been in elementary school.
Tambi, because of his disability, has not been in school.
The youngest three are still in school.
Lupin is in grade 7 at the Sta.
Ana National High School, Mina is in grade 4, and Shene is in grade 1 at the Roxas Elementary School.
 
Gelin is a beneficiary of the 4Ps for five years already.
She was one of the victims of the biggest fire that raged through three barangays in Quezon Boulevard on April 4, 2014, thus she also received a total of P20,000 cash assistance from the City Government.
She is thankful for 4Ps because it allowed them to send their youngest children to school and for giving her an opportunity to learn as well.

It was in year 2013-2014 when she attended her first Basic Literacy training, which she described as a 201cmemorable and happiest day201d of her life.
201cNag-sayaw pa gani ko.
Lingaw kaayo.
Nakabalo na ko mubasa'g sulat, kabalo napud ko mo ihap.
Kami sa akong bana kahima-o na maninda kay di naman mi dali ma-ilad kay kabalo naman mi moihap ,201d Gelin said.

201cSa una nga wala pa ang 4Ps sigera mi salom sa dagat.
Usahay gapangayo dira dalan, sa mga tawo.
Diri rapud ko naka-agi makasulod hotel ug mukaon tong sa2019mo training.
Mao na importante gayud ange skwela nako sa2019ko mga anak ,201d she added.
  
For now, Gelin said, she does not worry about her children2019s expenses in school, as she learned how to budget the allowance given to them through the 4Ps.
She added that all she has to do is to guide her children and remind them on the importance of education.
  
Marginalized 
The Badjao inhabit the shore and water of the Sulu archipelago.
Others went to Davao, Surigao, Zamboanga and even Manila, among other cities, in search of better livelihood.
 
City Link social worker Elena Bejarasco-Alingalan said that aside from the aid that 4Ps has provided for its beneficiaries, she also find helping the Badjaos through 201cBasic Literacy Program and Life Recovery Program.201d 
201cI asked a close friend of mine who is a teacher, I said teach, naluoy ko sa mga nanay na muadto sa Bankerohan di kabalo mubasa ug muihap .
So, we started to conduct this basic literacy program November 2013 diin monthly sila gitudloan ,201d Alingalan said.

The first module was to teach them to read.
After a year, Alingalan said, she partnered with Nelson Gamao of the Department of Education  to teach the Badjaos in the community to write.
At least 30 Badjaos along with several from the Manobo tribe from Barangays 22-C, 23-C, 31-D, 39-D and 40-D, underwent to the Basic Literacy Program, which provides free training in reading, writing, math and basic work skills, Alingalan said.
The Life Recovery Program teaches spirituality, whatever their religions are.
They are taught about love for self, family, and humanity in general.
Though this is beyond the 4Ps function, Alingalan said, to see the Badjao transformed into educated individuals is an achievement, not for her, but for the Badjao community; a priceless gift for the people like them who has been deprived of several things.
 
For the poorest 
The 4Ps operate in 17 regions in the Philippines, covering 79 provinces, 143 cities, and 1,484 municipalities.
Record obtained from the DSWD revealed that as of March 2015, it has enlisted 4,425,845 households, of which 558,609 are indigenous and 223,344 have at least one person with disability .

The program also covers 11,058,303 schoolchildren aged 0 to 18, from the total registered with an average of two to three children per household.

They are selected through the National Household Targeting System for Poverty Reduction , which identifies who and where the poor are in the country.

In general, the following criteria must be satisfied to become eligible for the program: residents of the poorest municipalities, based on 2003 Small Area Estimates  of the National Statistical Coordination Board  Households whose economic condition is equal to or below the provincial poverty threshold Households that have children 0-18 years old and/or have a pregnant woman at the time of assessment Households that agree to meet conditions specified in the program The 4Ps has two types of cash grants that are given out to household-beneficiaries: Health Grant: P500 per household every month, or a total of P6,000 every year Education Grant: P300 per child every month for ten months, or a total of P3,000 every year  For a household with three children, a household may receive P1,400 every month, or a total of P15,000 every year for five years, from the two types of cash grants given to them.

These cash grants are distributed to the household-beneficiaries through the Land Bank of the Philippines or, if not feasible, through alternate payment schemes such as Globe G-Cash remittance and rural bank transactions.

As of March 2015, a total of P9.2 billion cash grants were paid to eligible and compliant beneficiaries in the first period of 2015 covering January to February disbursements.
From this amount, P5.3 billion was paid for education, and the remaining P3.9 billion was disbursed for health.

In order to receive the abovementioned subsidies, all the succeeding conditions must be met by the household-beneficiaries:
* Pregnant women must avail pre and post-natal care, and be attended during childbirth by a trained professional.
* Parents or guardians must attend the family development sessions, which include topics on responsible parenting, health, and nutrition.
* Children aged 0-5 must receive regular preventive health check-ups and vaccines.
* Children aged 6-14 must receive de-worming pills twice a year
* Children-beneficiaries aged 3-18 must enroll in school, and maintain an attendance of at least 85 percent of class days every month.
High compliance rates were recorded for the months of January and February 2015: 99.17 percent for the de-worming of children aged 6-14; 96.89 percent for school attendance of children aged 6-14; 96.53 percent for school attendance of children in daycare aged 3-5; 95.82 percent for health visits of pregnant women and children aged 0-5; 95.30 percent for attendance in family development sessions; and 92.74 percent for school attendance of children aged 15-18.
Envisioned lives after 4Ps, Envisioned lives after 4PsAce June Rell S.
Perez, WHAT happens after a family graduates from being beneficiaries of the Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program , the government2019s conditional cash transfer program?
With around 4.1 million household beneficiaries of the 4Ps, the Department of Social Welfare and Development  is still determining whether the program has changed the lives of families for the better.

But it admits that they still do not have any graduates from the program yet, because of the additional two years to the education of the children before they graduate from high school following the passage of the Kinder to 12 years Enhanced Basic Education Program .
As of March 2015, the program has a total of 333,673 High School graduates, 14,411 of which are from Davao.
The 4Ps beneficiaries were also monitored and evaluated regularly through the Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation Office to gauge the program2019s effectiveness.
Monitoring progress 
201cWe do the planning, monitoring and evaluating, we are responsible of providing data, information or idea about the program, where it is heading to and what are the challenges of it,201d said Margie G.
Cabido, monitoring and evaluation officer.
In monitoring, different tools are being utilized, the internal and external monitoring.
The Monitoring and Evaluation team assessed the program2019s beneficiaries according to its Social Welfare and Development Indicator or the Level of well being.
The beneficiaries will be determined into three levels: survival, subsistence and self-sufficient.
Those beneficiaries identified as "survival" means they are below the poverty threshold, subsistence means they can provide just enough necessities like food and shelter to live with the program2019s intervention while beneficiaries under the level of self-sufficient means they can already provide on their own without the assistance of the program, the highest level among the categories.
201cLevels of well being of the specific beneficiary is identified and assessed not just with its economic status but including many indicators like education, health condition, employment,201d she added.

Current picture
4Ps beneficiary Rosalinda Bongulan, 39, a resident of Barangay 23 in Davao City, and belonging to the Badjao tribe from Jolo, Sulu, said four of her children have been under 4Ps although there are only two now since the two other elder children already graduated from high school.
 
The money they get not only goes for school expenses but also used as additional capital for her husband who sells sunglasses on the streets.

According to the DSWD2019s data of 2013, a total of 1,065 beneficiaries are under self-sufficient category, two percent of the total population, subsistence individuals are 167,940 almost 90 percent of the total beneficiaries, and 15,502 who are under survival about eight percent of the figure.

Empowering beneficiaries 
Other than the welfare of the children, one of the requirements of the 4Ps is the Family Development Sessions  wherein one of the parent beneficiaries is required to participate one a month.
DSWD-Davao City Link Elena Alingalan said that through these sessions, they have encouraged their beneficiaries, especially the Badjaos, to send their children to school.
201cIf we will compare education for them before, it is nothing, walang bearing sa kanila, walang value but now with this program , makita nimo nga ang nanay gusto na magpa-eskwela ng anak niya ,201d Alingalan said.
Road to self-sufficiency
With the ultimate goal of self-sufficiency for beneficiaries, DSWD created the Sustainable Livelihood Program  in 2013.
SLP, according to Maria Victoria Arancon, DSWD-Davao SLP program development officer II, has two tracks: first is the micro-enterprise development wherein they provide skills training and cash assistance of as much as P10,000 for them to start their business.
The second track is the employment facilitation, which is done in partnership with Technical Education and Skills Development Authority wherein they encourage the participants to acquire a National Certificate II and helps them find jobs fit for their skills earned.
 
For this year, DSWD-Davao is targeting a total of 21,190 beneficiaries for its Sustainable Livelihood Program.
Quo vadis, 4Ps?, Quo vadis, 4Ps?Karina V.
Canedo, PANTAWID Pamilyang Pilipino Program  has become the life and sustenance of many poor families.
But with elections looming ahead, there is no assurance that this will be continued by the next administration.
What would happen then to the beneficiaries?
Elena Alingalan, a social worker of Barangay 23-C, Davao City, said she believes 4Ps will be continued by the next administration because this is part of the programs designed to meet the Millennium Development Goals , which incidentally is supposed to be reached this year.

201cWe can2019t say for sure, but since this is part of the MDGs that we signed as a commitment to fulfill, then it is likely that the program will be continued by the next president,201d she said in the vernacular.

During President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, when the conditional cash transfer program was first implemented, the beneficiary should have children between 0-14 years old.
Just last year, under President Benigno Aquino III2019s time, the age was increased to 18 years old because of the additional years in high school as mandated by the Kinder to 12 years Enhanced Basic Education Program .
Sheryll Fernandez, 4Ps information officer for Davao Region, said that it is important to ensure that the children covered finish high school.

201cMore opportunities await those who graduate from high school and that is what the DSWD is looking at,201d she said.
Gelin Amelita Rendo, 43, a resident of Barangay 23-C, Davao City and a member of Badjao tribe, said the 4Ps allowance enables her to send her three younger children to school.
Her five elder children did not reach high school.
She added that many among her tribe have also learned how to read and write like she did in the attached basic literacy program thus weaning them away from begging.
Rendo sells ukay-ukay at the Agdao Public Market while her husband sells cellphone casings and belts around the city.
The cash she receives from 4Ps every two months goes to her children2019s school expenses and additional capital for her ukay-ukay.
201cPadayunon lang unta hantod sa hantod ,201d Rendo said.
Arlyn Limato Quimque, 37, a housewife in Barangay 23-C, also has words of thanks for the program as it lightens the burden of sending six children to school.
201cNaa jud koy ginapaabot kung nay bayronon ang mga bata ,201d she said.
 
Quimque has one at Sta.
Ana High School and two at Sta.
Ana Elementary School who covered by 4Ps.
Her husband works as an automotive technician who can earn as much as P4,000 to P5,000 a week when he has a client, but this does not happen all the time.
Aside from financial help, Quimque most appreciates the Family Development Seminars, which she said, empowers her.
201cKaron nakasulod nami sa 4Ps nakabalo nami nga bawal diay magpadaugdaug, isog nang mag asawa karon kay sa una magpakulata lang man karon makabalo nami asa mudagan sa panahon nga ing-ana ,201d she said.
Both Quimque and Rendo always attend the Family Development Seminars, afraid that they would face sanctions and be delisted.
Despite this positive feedback, 4Ps is not free of controversies.
There are talks that this is being used by politicians to get votes.
While this has been denied, there has been a series of delisting of beneficiaries included due to error, fraud, and those who were found to have regular income sources.
Last May, DSWD Davao Region removed 18,024 families from the list of Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program  beneficiaries since 2009.
As of last April, Davao Region, had 232,553 households in the program, with 85,535 coming from Davao del Sur, 47,961 from Davao del Norte, 41,718 from Davao Oriental and 57,339 from Compostela Valley.
In a report on Manila Bulletin earlier this year, it was said that as of March 2015, the bill for the institutionalization of 4Ps has already been approved by House Committee on Poverty Alleviation.
Meanwhile, the government increased the budget for the 4Ps program from P62.6 billion in 2014 to P64.7 billion this year.
DSWD: 4Ps is epal-free, DSWD: 4Ps is epal-freeKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, AMID suspicions that the conditional cash transfer  program of the National Government, the Department of Social Welfare and Development  in Davao assured that politicians do not have a hand in selecting beneficiaries.
CCT gives cash assistance to the poorest of the poor provided they fulfill some obligations with regard maternal and child health and education.
DSWD-Davao information officer for the Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program  Sheryll Fernandez they are ensuring that their operations are 201cepal-free.201d
4Ps is a conditional cash transfer program initiated by the government.
It aims to address the poverty problems of Filipino households on a short-term basis, investing in health and education of kids ages 18 years old and below.

The family beneficiaries are given P1,400 cash assistance every two months of the year.
"Wala po silang  power to include and delist families as beneficiaries of 4Ps," Fernandez told Sun.Star Davao in a recent interview at their office.
Fernandez said that the enforcement of the anti-epal campaign is one of their initiative to inform the beneficiaries that politicians are not involved in the implementation of the program.
201cWe repeatedly tell beneficiaries that they should not believe claims by politicians that they can delist families.
They don2019t have that power,201d she said.
 
In order to strengthen their anti-epal campaign, DSWD has been partnering with other government agencies including Commission on Elections , Department of Education , and Department of Interior and Local Government  to monitor the actions of some national and local candidates.
All agencies are collaborating, she said, to finally put a stop to these wrong impressions.
Fernandez said that beneficiaries who experienced being threatened or influenced by any politicians through DSWD's program may submit their grievances and reports to their regional office.
"Kung may grievances sila on the matter, pwede sila magsubmit  through our social workers who are stationed in each specific areas.
If we receive any complaints, we will forward it to the Comelec and DILG sa Manila and they will be calling the attention of the involved candidates," Fernandez said.
The 4Ps program has also been criticized by some for being the roots of corruption among its implementers.
But Fernandez insists that government personnel do not have access to the funds.
"Yung ayuda na ibinibigay natin sa ating mga isang beneficiary ay hindi dumadaan sa kamay ng ating mga personnel.
Pumapasok derecho yung mga incentives sa kani-kanilang mga ATM accounts," Fernandez said.
Listahanan or Talaan ng Pamilyang Nangangailangan is a database used by DSWD to determine and identify which households are eligible and qualified as beneficiaries.
Arlyn Limato Quimque, a mother of six kids, and a resident of Barangay 23-C in Davao City, who has been a beneficiary since 2008, admitted she did not know anything about 4Ps before.
201cSa una abi namo hinabang lang gikan kay Mayor pero kadtong naexplain na gyud sa amoa didto mi nakabalo na dako diay ni ug pwede maitabang sa amoa ," Quimque said.
Quimque said that 4Ps has been helping them a lot, especially when their house was razed along with more than 1,000 others in the April 2014 fire at Isla Verde and Mini-Forest that affected more than 3,700 families.
She said that not once had any politician approached her family with regards 4Ps.
"So far, wala man pud mi nakaexperience na duolun ug pulitiko ug pugsun mi na mubuto sa iyaha ," Quimque said in a separate interview at their residence.
Elena Alingalan, a social worker designated in the barangay, said that they don't allow any gatherings for 4Ps beneficiaries during election period so that the program cannot be taken advantage of.
"Even gani mga brgy.
officials ginamonitor nato ," she added.
According to Alingalan, the implementation of the anti-Epal Campaign is essential to avoid any forms of abuse.
Meanwhile, Fernandez said that the implementation of the 4Ps program is also extended even to the Indigenous People  and peasant groups in far-flung areas.
But as of late, some lumads and peasants in provinces of Davao del Norte and Davao Oriental have accused the Armed Forces of the Philippines  of threatening them of being delisted as beneficiaries in the said program.
In a recent statement furnished to Sun.Star Davao, Pasaka spokesperson Isidro Indao said: 201cParents of students enrolled in Salugpongan Ta Tanu Igkanogon Community Learning Center  and MISFI Academy in Sitio Mantapay, Limot and Bagangan, Brgy.
Binondo, Baganga, Davao Oriental are threatened by elements of the military that they will not be able to receive their CCT if they continue to patronize the schools which the military maliciously accused as NPA institutions.201d 
However, Army's 10th Infantry Division  spokesperson Lieutenant Vergel Lacambra denied the accusations, saying these claims are just forms of propaganda of the said groups.
"Hindi gawain ng mga sundalo yan na mag-threaten ng mga civilians.
Gusto nga natin silang madevelop yung areas nila at mabigyan ng government interventions," Lacambra said.
Lacambra said they do not have power to delist beneficiaries since the program is under DSWD.
Fernandez affirmed the statement of Army, saying that only committee members of the program can delist them should they violate parameters that include fraud, among others.
"Walang right and power and military to remove beneficiaries from the program.
Yan yung tandaan nila.
DSWD lang naay capacity to add or remove beneficiaries," Fernandez said.
As of April, Davao Region had 232,533 households in the program, with 85,535 coming from Davao del Sur, 47,961 from Davao del Norte, 41,718 from Davao Oriental, and 57,339 from Compostella Valley.

201cThat2019s why you are here .

The road back home, The road back homeEVERYONE was in a hurry.
 Some rushed down the stairs while others waited patiently for the elevator.
The class just ended and the students had new lessons learned.
Lessons that would help them create an article for their new assignment.
 
The assignment was due tomorrow before 12 noon and she knew she had to get home soon.
So she rushed to the elevators like everyone else, pushed in just so she can fit in.
It was just a few minutes ride but it was taking up too much time for them who had to meet deadlines.
 Ding! The elevator door opened and noise filled her ears.

A lot of people were rushing to the gates and she felt like she had seen the same scene before, last night, the night before and the night about a week ago.
Every night was the same, it was like d\xe9j\xe0 vu.
  The same scene over and over again, for her it was tiring.
She always had to rush that she wasn2019t able to notice what was happening around her.

That night was different.
  She looked at the people around her, some were talking to someone on their phone, some were texting, and some were chatting about their day while others waited for their rides.
  She felt the thin air touched her skin and it was quite cold matched the dark colors that filled the sky and stars that shone their brightest.
She hoped others have seen how that night changed.
  
The engine of the car started, it was time to start the journey back home.
 The streets were busy and crowded.
It was not new to her.
 It was filled with cars, jeepneys, motorcycles, bicycles, buses and people.
There was honking of horns, loud music played by different vehicles and barkers shouting as loud as they can in hopes of finding passengers ready to go back home.
 
Roxas Avenue was the same as every night.
It was crowded with vendors and their different products.
 It was luminous and appealing to different kinds of people: students, family, lovers or group of friends.
  Aside from the variety of products and colors displayed which are pleasing to the eyes, this street offered a lot of products needed for her survival as a student.
  
The smell of the cooked street food, she remembered spending most of her time at this street, especially after night class when she can no longer control her hunger.
The bright and orange kwek-kwek, the green sides like cucumber.
The smell of fried isaw, proven, adidas, helmet and other chicken parts dipped into sweet red sauce with a little kick of spice and acidity.
  
The aroma of meat burnt in charcoal, barbecue-style was also her favorite and usually paired with sticky rice.
Most of the time it was the reason she survived as a student because it filled her stomach like no any other kind of food could.
  The memories made her hungry, and then they turned right to Quimpo Boulevard.
A busy street also but was very calm at that night.
Nothing was out of the ordinary then she looked at a jeepney full of sleepy and tired passengers.
  
A student, teacher, worker, men, women even a child, she gazed at them and saw nothing but need to go home but it was a long way.
  A lamp post, a man, road and cars repeat.
She thought of what she could write in her article due for tomorrow.
There were a lot of things that she observed that night, information overload.
She was enjoying the ride, the breeze, sceneries and felt comfortable.
Then she drifted, drifted into a sleep for it was a long way.
  
Honking of horns, sudden breaks and the smell of dark smokes from vehicles woke her up from her nap.
It was traffic.
She knew then that they have reached Matina, a place near home.
  It was bright and filled with lights from the different establishments though the smell of fish from the public market filled her nose.

It was awful but she was excited because she2019s almost there, to the place where she can finally lay down and rest, her home.
  Then, they reached home.
It was peaceful and everyone was asleep.
Another day has passed, just how fast the night changes.

Tomorrow is a new day for her, a new day to appreciate what was going on around her.

A chance for her to take it slow.

Earn it , Earn it TODAY2019S generation has been more about the numbers of likes a selfie gets on Facebook, the number of views a video has on YouTube, and the number of favorites a tweet makes on Twitter, that sometimes others tend to forget to think before they click.
As long as something appears to be interesting to many, it doesn2019t matter anymore how it would seem to some.

A perfect example of this would be girls complaining about being offended after posting pictures of them wearing bikinis online.
It is with no doubt that this could help them earn hundreds of likes, even thousands, but that doesn2019t mean they are safe from what others might think of.
 
Yes, this is a free country.
We are allowed to express ourselves and be whoever we want to be.
But are we really looking at the bigger picture here? If, in the first place, they didn2019t want to earn negative comments, maybe they should2019ve been more careful and thoughtful before they posted attention-seeking images of them.
They want to be respected but they do things that earn disrespect.
 
Respect is really earned.
It is never given.
If you want people to give you positive feedbacks, maybe you should start portraying yourself as someone who deserves respect.
You can2019t just walk around and tell people to respect you as you do something that do not seem to be appropriate for them.
How can others respect you if you, yourself, do not respect you? It is as easy as that.
 
So as much as possible, before hitting that post button, think twice or even more times.
Think whether this could or could not ruin your image.
Weigh things heavily.
Filter your desired posts.
At the end of the day, it2019s not always the number of likes that matters most but the amount of respect you would earn.

Julie Jean is an AB Mass Communications student of Ateneo de Davao University
On letting go and becoming a shoreline, On letting go and becoming a shorelineOUR professor told us that most of the hours she allots in cleaning her large office are consumed through reading the exam papers of her former students2026 before throwing them away.
 
She admitted that she was fond of keeping things she did not really need, thinking that she might need it sooner.
That was why she kept exam papers.
But when she realized that those sheets of paper cannot be recycled given their condition, she decided to throw them in the garbage bin.
Before disposing them, however, she made sure that she scanned the papers for the last time, making her recall the owner of the paper and the memories she shared with him or her.
Then, when this was done, she finally let go.
 I, myself, was an unapologetic keeper of all things which I thought I needed: from clutch pins to old, worn elementary books.
Like my teacher, a part of me believed that something about them was worth keeping.
I was very much aware, however, that I would less likely to use those things.
Yet, I kept them still, like what I did with people.

I used to keep people close to me.
It was a long, unforgettable process: you have to get to know them, make friends with them, eat with them almost every lunch, give them books before Christmas breaks, have an overload of sleepovers, argue with them, laugh with them, drink with them.
Then I got too attached that sometimes I would thought my world revolved around them.
It was when I reached Third Year College that I realized I started treating them not as my friends but as my possessions 2013 like how I treat remarkable clutch pins and old, worn elementary books.
 
When some of the people I got used being with changed the way they treated me, it made me realize that I had no control over them2026 and will never have.
People are not something we contain in a box and expect to stay there forever.
 Cheesy as it sounds, but undeniably true, they are waves in the sea that cannot stay in the shoreline but, from time to time, come back carrying different intensities.
But the waves that kiss the shoreline might not be the same waves that abandon it.
 
I realized I am the shoreline.
I have to watch them leave while taking parts of me.
I can wait for them to come back but should never expect for them to.
 I have disposed the things which I used to keep.
Rusts were already all over the clutch pins.
And the worn elementary book had nothing but outdated information.

I was wrong: I no longer need them.
I have to empty the box sometimes to let new things fill it.
I had to stop eating lunch with people who do not want to eat lunch with me.
I have to stop laughing with people who do not find happiness in my company.
I have to recognize that the tighter I grip, the more it hurts my knuckles.
I have to let go.
I should be the shoreline.
 I have to be the shoreline.

1st Philippine eagle nest in Luzon sighted, 1st Philippine eagle nest in Luzon sighted
A mother Philippine Eagle feeding her one-month-old chick on the eagle nest in Apayao.

IN JULY of 1896, a local Samare\xf1o acting as guide to British Ornithologist John Whitehead brought back to camp one of the largest forest birds that Whitehead has ever seen.

Then a new species to the western world, this first Philippine eagle specimen from Samar was a jewel among Whitehead's wildlife collections.
It was then one of the world's greatest discoveries for a biological expedition.
     
One hundred nineteen years later today, the same spirit of scientific discovery is celebrated as the Philippine Eagle Foundation  announces another first in the history of Philippine Eagle research and conservation -- the discovery of the first ever active Philippine Eagle nest on Luzon Island.
    
The first Philippine Eagle nest on Luzon with a downy chick was finally located by Philippine Eagle Foundation  biologists and Isnag research assistants in the lush lowland forests of Apayao Province in the Cordillera Administrative Region of Luzon last April 24.
Finding the elusive nest involved a total of 3,456 hours of observations, which is equivalent to watching television 24/7 for over three months straight.
 
Field work spanned five years in rugged and remote jungles.
In the field, observers spent time mostly on platforms atop trees, scanning ridges and valleys for the highly secretive national bird.
 
"In the thick lowland jungles of Apayao, finding an eagle nest is like searching for a needle in a pile of hay," said PEF Biologist and expedition team leader Tatiana Aba\xf1o.

They kept seeing the eagles during four consecutive years of summer field work, but no hints of a nest.
Not until this year.
  
On a clear day in April 21, a bird carrying a decapitated prey took a long, diagonal dive towards a huge tree.
Nearby, another eagle on a perch was also spotted.
Together, these observations indicate nesting.
  
A meticulous nest search followed.
For three days, additional eagle sightings helped the team home in on the nest.
After climbing 15 different trees around the spot where the eagles repeatedly emerged and disappeared, the nest tree was finally singled out.
And on the center of the sturdy nest bowl was a month-old eagle chick dozing off.
   
"New information generated from observing the newly discovered nest will definitely bring eagle conservation in Luzon to the next level" said Dr.
Theresa Mundita Lim, director of Biodiversity Management Bureau  of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources .
 
The PEF works with the BMB in securing the few remaining eagle pairs across the archipelago.
Three reasons make the nest discovery important.
First, this active nest allows a detailed study of the behavior of eagles in Luzon.
The island's flora and fauna and its climate pattern are very different from the other three islands -- Leyte, Samar and Mindanao -- where eagles are also found.
 
A unique environment leads to new habits and lifestyles.
Close observations of nesting adults and their young give researchers the opportunity to understand and explain how distinctive Luzon eagles are from the rest.
Second, the nest is the eagle's center of activity.

For a bird that occupies a large territory, it is only when eagles breed that one can carry out a focused and detailed study of its behavior and food needs.
 Last, eagles are also very loyal to the places where they nest; they use the same set of nests repeatedly.

Maintaining the health and integrity of nest sites therefore ensure reproduction and the perpetuity of their kind.
Knowing where nests occur also helps conservationists protect nesting territories better.
Eagles become sedentary and tied to a particular place only when nesting.

Breeding birds therefore become vulnerable if nests are unprotected.
Fortunately, the eagles of Apayao are secured through an Indigenous habitat conservation scheme.

The town of Calanasan, in particular, is leading the way.
Through the ancient Isnag observance of Lapat, forest habitats were set aside as "taboo" or "sacred sites" where logging, mining, farming and wildlife hunting are completely banned.
  
Rooted in culture and religious tradition, the adoption of lapat has set aside forests as Indigenous "protected areas."  
"The presence of nesting eagles within Calanasan's lapat areas is a strong proof that the Isnag way of protection is resulting to clear biodiversity conservation outcomes," said Elias K.
Bulut Sr., mayor of Calanasan and staunch supporter of Philippine eagle conservation in Apayao.

In 2010, he penned a town ordinance that sets aside 25,000 hectares of forest as lapat.
Right after the nest was found, PEF, DENR and the LGUs of Calanasan and Apayao renewed research and protection of the nesting eagles and it's young.
The PEF held public education outreach and conservation planning with funding from the San Roque Power Corporation .
SRPC has been supporting eagle surveys across the Cordillera since 2011.

"We are glad we invested on this very important initiative.
We are very proud that our support has not only helped the PEF advance its work in Luzon but is also benefiting the Cordillera region's biodiversity conservation program.
 We encourage everyone who has a stake in the Cordillera to also invest on our national bird," said SRPC President Kenshi Iseri.
In 2014, the Philippine Tropical Forest Conservation Foundation  began providing small grants to support further eagle conservation work in the area.
A food habits and nesting behavior study also began in May and will end in August once the young flies off the nest.
The result so far is a collection of pioneering information on Luzon eagles' diet and demeanor.
 
For example, the latest tally show that a total of 38 animals belonging to five species of mammals, three species of snake, a huge lizard and a large bird were fed by the eagle parents to the growing young.
At an average feeding rate of one prey every other day, the young appeared well-fed and healthy.
The timing of nesting and the ways the Apayao adult eagles behave when breeding also differed slightly with the eagles found in Mindanao.
The PEF currently knows of 35 wild eagle pairs on Mindanao.
"What our biologists are seeing and recording are precious pieces of biological information," said Dennis Salvador, Philippine Eagle Foundation Executive Director.
"For over a hundred years, knowledge about the ecology of Luzon eagles was, at best, speculative.
Now we are slowly gathering solid scientific evidence which can help bring about informed conservation actions," Salvador added.
Today, the whole Cordillera Administrative Region is celebrating its Founding Day anniversary and the province of Apayao is hosting this year's festivities.
As host to the world's first active nest in Luzon, the public announcement of this landmark discovery is one of the highlights of its biodiversity forum.
Elias Bulut Jr., governor of the Province of Apayao, is equally delighted of the nest discovery.
"We are very proud to host a nest site and several more pairs of the Great Philippine Eagle in our own backyard," he said.
"As a fellow Filipino and resident of Apayao, we will help secure the eagle's safety so future generations of Iya Apayao can still enjoy its magnificence."
The Philippine Eagle is a large forest eagle which is found only in the Philippines where it is the national bird.
No more than 400 pairs exist in what's left of tropical forests on the islands of Luzon, Leyte, Samar and Mindanao.
 The species is an IUCN "critically endangered" species.
Jayson C.
Iba\xf1ez
When poetry meets film , When poetry meets film 
THE TEAM.
Liryc with his team for "Sa Pagitan ng Pagdalaw at Paglimot" nominated for Locarno Film Festival's Pardi di Domani: 15-year-old cinematographer Jiro Garbes, producer and production manager Alex Poblete, actress Tin Velasco, and production manager Joel Griffiths, and a scene from the short film .
At right is Liryc showing off his old Samsung Note 2, which he used to video part of the film.
Stella A.
Estremera, IF AFTER watching Liryc Paolo dela Cruz2019s film you feel like there2019s something poetic about it, don2019t be surprised because it2019s based on a poem.
 
201cBefore ako gumagawa ng film, gumagawa ako ng tula.
Ang mga images sa film binabagay ko sa tula,201d Liryc says of his art.

The poetry must have been detected by pioneering independent film producer Kidlat Tahimik  when the artist recognized him with the Bamboo Camera Award in 2008 for his film Tundong during the Mindanao Film Festival.

That was his first foray into film after attending the Guerilla Filmmaking Workshop, the workshop that precedes the local filmfest to gather participants who hold some promise.
He was in second year college then.
 
Locarno Film Festival
At 23 and on his third year taking up AB Mass Communications at the Ateneo de Davao University he is one of only two Filipino independent filmmakers whose films have been selected as part of the official line-up under the Pardi di Domani of the 68th Locarno Film Festival in Switzerland from August 5-15, 2015.
The other one is Carlo Francisco Manatad2019s 201c/7410u| Liryc with team nilyn Has201d, which tells the story of a nightclub dancer who had to temporarily take a break during the visit of Pope Francis.
 
Pardi di Domani is a section in the festival that showcases future talents of World Cinema.
Liryc2019s entry is his short film 201cSa Pagitan ng Pagdalaw at Paglimot 201d.
With barely a month left, however, Liryc still has to raise enough funds to make it to Switzerland, and here2019s to hoping that this story can crowdsource his ticket to his dream.
Locarno is among the major international film festivals on the level of Cannes, Venice, and Berlin.
  
A homecoming
What came between 2008, when he received the Bamboo Camera from Kidlat Tahimik and 2015, when he is back in school? He pursued his dream of making films and learned the craft and the hardships from the icons of the industry, among them master filmmaker Lav Diaz , whom he worked closely with for two and a half years.
Learned the ropes of casting in Regal productions and got guidance on film finance from Kristine Kintana, and managed to save some from regular work in reality shows at TV5 enough to go home and fulfill a promise.
His return to school is to fulfill his promise to his father to finish his studies.

His father died a few years back.
It was in his father2019s VHS shop in Tupi, South Cotabato when he first appreciated films as a child.
The temporary break in full-time work in filmmaking is a necessary sacrifice.
That does not mean he will take a break from filmmaking, anyway.
AN OLD 
Samsung Note 2
Part of his competing film was shot using his Samsung Note 2, a very old one with crack on the screen.
This is the part when he filmed what is described in the film credits as the 201cBabae sa Eroplano201d, the scene that inspired the whole story.
He was with his mentor ADDU Prof.
Hadji Balajadia on a flight to Manila at that time.

201cSa unahan namin, may babaeng sobrang amazed sa nakikita niya, kumakaway pa.
Tapos yung kasama nung babae parang tinuturuan pa siya, 2018O, ano, nakapaglipstick ka na ba?2019 Yung ganun,201d he said in an interview at the Sun.Star office.

201cNalulungkot ako sa image, siguro yun ang unang sakay niya sa eroplano, tapos yung you2019re taking a last photo of your country,201d he said.

201cMinsan, bagong tao ka na pagdating mo sa ibang bayan.
Siguro gagawin mo lahat para masalba mo ang pamilya mo sa kahirapan.
Malungkot yun.
Hindi natin alam baka minor pa siya.
Pumapasok ka sa dimension na walang kasiguraduhan.201d  
Just an exercise
But he did not produce the film out of this scene expecting to win any awards.
In fact, he made the film as an exercise.
His team includes a 15-year-old videographer Jiro Garbes, who along with Joel Griffiths from De La Salle University who is the film2019s production manager, he met in a film camp.

His main actor, Tin Velasco, he just met less than an hour before they started filming in Pampanga, recommended by one of his companions while taking breakfast in McDonald2019s already somewhere in Pampanga.
This companion could not even say for sure if Tin knew how to act.

201cDapat kasing huwag masyadong seryoso pag gumagawa ng pelikula,201d he said.
With the same nonchalance, he submitted the film as entry to the Locarno just for the sake of submitting.
Taking the phrase 201cwala lang201d to a new level.
Thus, when he received the notification, he literally stumbled to the ground.
It was 8 p.m.
and he was walking home from school.
The first person he broke the news to was Prof.
Balajadia, who is the film2019s associate producer, and they stayed up till 4 a.m.
still not believing.

201cSi Sir Hadji wala nang nagawa kungdi magtititili,201d he recalled.
 
Home is where the stories are
Liryc is excited to explore his hometown Tupi, which he describes as a place that has many stories to tell.
His town is also known for its focus on the arts, in fact, the Tupi National High School has been a consistent winner in Kadayawan Festival2019s Indak-indak, and it is where Liryc as a young boy learned the basics of story-telling.
In fourth year, he produced a documentary as a mini-thesis in school on rebels in a village, without even realizing that he and his groupmates were entering a dangerous zone.

201cStory is king.
Sa technical, hindi kasi ako technical na tao, ang mas importante talaga ang istorya,201d he said.
Here2019s to hoping that Liryc makes it to Locarno in August.
You can email him through lirycpaolodelacruz@gmail.com.

The rough road back, The rough road back
DAVAO.
At 21, Ana Luisa Calix already wanted to leave the world of a prostituted woman, but it is never that easy.
The photos above show some of the girls of LawigBubay in a workshop.

Stella A.
Estremera, YOU2019D see her whenever there are activities about women and children rights, especially when it comes to prostitution.

She2019s been there and she2019s trying to help the new ones see a way out.
It2019s not easy, but she2019s trying.
The recent graduation of her son in a maritime course was a beam of hope in the dark world of the prostituted.
Yes, it can be done.
Just resolve never to go back.
Ana Luisa 201cAnalou201d Napone Calix2019s life story is one that can put full-length sob films to shame.
Raped at 14, prostituted at 16, pretending to be the sister of her son for years, until the whole complex situation was finally revealed as the son was well into becoming an adult.

201cNung na buntis ako, bata pa ako, buntis rin ang nanayko,201d she said.
Dirt poor with not much to raise another child, the mother gave up hers and then raised Analou2019s son as hers.

Yes, it2019s that complicated.
I had to probe further to understand.
Let it be said that the details need not be known by all.
Living in the slums of Sasa right outside the port, her claims of having been raped was brushed off by all except one, the erstwhile barangay captain Cornelio Reta Sr.

201cSiya ra gayud ang nitabang nako ,201d Analou said.
But the odds were still stacked against her, and so through the instigation of her parents, she agreed to an amicable settlement.
201cMay pera kami from the settlement, pero nagkasakit ang stepfather ko at that time,201d she said.

201cAlthough hindi diretsong sinabi ng nanay ko, pero yun bang puslan man nabasa ka na, maligo ka nalang.201d Soon, she joined the 201cakyat-barko,201d the prostituted women and children who climb up ships docked at the port to render sexual services to the crew.
She was organized by Talikala Inc., the non-government organization working with prostituted women and children, when she was 15, but she did not stop the trade.

She also became a bargirl with a bar fine.
She had a child to support, her other only took the role of being called mother, but it was Analou who was working hard for their family, her son alias brother included.
At 21, she had this longing to start a new life.
She started volunteering for Talikala doing just about everything, from typing to errands.

201cGrab all opportunities.
Pati yang Avon, Natasha, pinasok ko yan, malaki ang natulong niyan sa akin,201d she added.
She then became an officer of LawigBubay, the organization created by the prostituted women who have been tapped by Talikala, and she devoted her time reaching out to women and children like her.
Then she left LawigBubay for two years to work at their barangay as an all-around errand girl.

201cMahirap,201d she said, of her resolve to leave her situation.
201cPara yang tattoo na hindi basta-basta ma-erase.201d Thus, she understands when women whom they have already organized and have encouraged to return to the mainstream fall back in.
The resolve to start life anew is a difficult one as the once prostituted will realize that she has been marked for life and that there will never be money as much as she once had even for one night.

In the meantime, Analou is encouraging her son to find a job and hold the final year as a cadet seaman because this will require a large amount.
They will have to save up for it first.

201cGusto ko rin maranasan niya gaano kahirap mag hanap-buhay,201d she added.

She2019s back at Lawig, but this time, just giving guidance to the new ones who are now having to deal with much younger girls at much greater numbers.

201cHindi n aako suited dahil hindi na ako bata,201d she said of organizing the prostituted young.
 
She said that in gatherings of LawigBubay, the ratio will be two-thirds teens, one-third adult.

201cHindi na kami maka-gel sa 14, 16-years-old, lola na kami,201d she added in jest.

Talikala Inc.
executive director Jeanette Laurel-Ampog confirmed the growing number of minors who fall into the trade, adding that they now have very young social workers because even their long years of experience working with the prostituted is not much of a help when dealing with children with a whole different situation and values.
Their most difficult issue these days is that of the young recruiting and pimping the young.

201cYou can2019t just condemn the pimps because they are children too, you have to help,201d she said.

201cTapos sasabihan ka pa nila hindi man yun bugaw, referrals man yun.201d Then, there are the young who sustain a whole family plus their partners, who do nothing but partake of their earnings.

201cSophisticated na masyado ang issues ng mga bata, may mga strategies na dapat mag-evolve at suriin kung appropriate pa ba ang mga ganitong interventions.
It2019s now a balance of protecting the child and at the same correcting her ways,201d she said, 201ckasi kung pabayaan natin, we will be making it worse.201d 
But they2019re not giving up and still are out there convincing the children to go back to school, and helping them along the way to stay in school.

201cHindi rin natin masisisi ang mga bata dahil ganyan ang kanilang kinalakhan,201d she said.

They celebrate every small success they make, knowing that the odds are growing faster than this small 28-year-old organization can.
And among the good news they are giddy is that they were able to bring back five girls to school 2013 two attending regular schools, and three enrolled in the alternative learning system .

There is hope, even if most of the time it2019s just flickering.
Now, if only more people can pitch in and help.

Galolo, SUN.STAR Publishing Inc., the company behind Sun.Star Cebu, Superbalita, www.sunstar.com.ph and Bisdak Magasin, has expanded its presence to Carcar City.
Sun.Star officials led the opening of a 50-square-meter office in Gaisano Grand Mall Carcar yesterday.
The new office extends its advertising, marketing and circulation services to its clients and readers in the south.
Sun.Star Chairman Atty.

201cCarcar is a booming city, therefore, it has a need for news and information.
We believe that we have a lot of news consumers and also contributors to the news here,201d said Garcia in an interview.

Sun.Star Carcar is the fourth Sun.Star office in Cebu, after the main office on P.
Del Rosario St.
and other branches in Fuente Osme\xf1a  and Mandaue City.
Garcia said that at 32, Sun.Star is also working to boost its digital presence, primarily through the Sun.Star Network Exchange.
He said the management will meet next month to further discuss digital matters.
Presently, there are no immediate plans to open another branch.
