He assured that the growing economy of Carcar will be supportive of the growth Sun.Star is anticipating from this thriving city.
5 rules of proper 2018netiquette2019, 5 rules of proper 2018netiquette2019THE Internet is filled with opportunities to explore, create and collaborate.
But to make the most of these opportunities, it2019s important to keep the web safe and secure.
This task is a shared responsibility among every netizen.
Learning Internet etiquette or "netiquette" is the first step in helping promote a safe and friendly online environment.
When you keep yourself safe and secure online, you minimize the power of cybercrime, which includes identity theft, information theft, and even cyber-bullying.
Here are five key things to remember when navigating the World Wide Web:
1.
Download with caution.
One of the most wonderful things about the Internet is the vast amount of content it offers; we can find just about anything online if we look hard enough.
While some of the things we come across are so awesome that we want to be able to access them while we2019re offline, we have to be cautious when it comes to downloading.
Only download from credible and trusted sources.
Sometimes it2019s not the things that we find that we have to be careful about, but the things that come to us.
Be wary of opening or downloading email attachments even if it2019s from someone you know, and especially if it isn2019t something you expect to be receiving.
Double check that the email address is from the reputable source it may claim to be from and that the content does not look suspicious.
2.
Safeguard delicate information.
There are so many ways our over sharing can leave us vulnerable to identity or information theft.
Aside from creating strong passwords, keep usernames, account numbers, and any sort of information that could be used to verify your identity, safe.
Think before you tweet your dog2019s name if it2019s a security question on any of your accounts -- or better yet, opt for more reliable methods of authentication, such as 2-step verification codes or back-up email addresses.
3.
Don2019t contribute to spreading false or hurtful information.
We2019ve all fallen victim to believing -- or at least coming close to believing -- a viral hoax.
Just as gossip or juicy stories spread like wildfire offline, it can do so at an even greater scale online.
And it doesn2019t have to be hurtful to be harmful, either.
Employ a healthy skepticism with anything you hear or see online, and do some fact checking before you share.
4.
Act courteously, even in anonymity.
Remember, the Golden Rule or the universal ethical code to "treat others as you would like to be treated" also applies on the Internet.
Be kind and courteous.
The use of tormenting, harassing or humiliating language is as real and as damaging online as they are face-to-face.
Appropriate language is not only necessary in formal letters, but also in day-to-day chats on social media.
5.
Flag or report inappropriate content.
Online communities often rely on users to generate content and flag ones that violate community guidelines.
In the case of YouTube, with more than 300 hours of videos being uploaded every minute, flagging or reporting questionable content is invaluable to preserving it as a safe and enjoyable resource, just as in most online communities.
If you come across content that you think shouldn2019t be there, report it.
These are only the basics of proper netiquette.
The Internet is always evolving, so it2019s important to maintain an up-to-date understanding of how to stay safe and secure online.
Share these five rules of netiquette with your friends and family to help promote an enjoyable and useful Internet for all.
If you are interested in taking a more active role as a positive force online, look up Google2019s Web Rangers program on https://www.webrangers.ph.

Her own way to serve, Her own way to serveNelson C.
Bagaforo, HER charisma and makamasa traits could have easily catapulted her to power, at least in Tagum City where they are a prominent political clan.
But politics isn't her cup of tea.
Emerald "Adi" Uy has her own way to serve, which she said "doesn't need to be in power," unlike her father Rey Uy, who was an undefeated city mayor for nine years, and her brother Oyo, who used to serve as the city's No.
1 councilor.
"Samok, wala'y privacy" is her definition of politics.

Just like her mother, Alma Uy, a successful businesswoman who has also been actively involved in the promotion of Davao's tourism, Emerald prefers to put her hands in business, which she believes is also a very effective way in serving the community.
So when the offer from her parents came to establish a food business in her hometown in Tagum, she gladly accepted it without second thoughts, considering the fact that cooking has been her passion since she was a young girl.
In fact, after graduation from high school, she went to the United States to study Culinary Arts at Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, New York.
She was in Singapore, where she just finished a crash course on pastry making at Sunrice Globalchef Academy, when the offer to do business in Tagum came.
She was then planning to stay in that country to work and hone further her skills in baking and cooking.
But for Emerald, putting up a food business is a realization of her dream to also serve.

She said her food business -- which she named YuYu Cafe and Dessert Shop -- is a manifestation that she also cares for Tagumenos whom she promised to provide quality food at affordable cost.

At the start, she observed that Tagumenos appeared not ready yet for "just a coffee shop," a reason she includes in her menu a selection of rice meals to address demand of her prospective market.
"I offer food I learned to cook while studying in the US.
It was my desire to let my kababayans try what I have learned," she says.
Other than coffee, pastries and meals, YuYu also offers sandwiches, pastas and pizzas.
True enough, after five years since she opened the business, YuYu has become synonymous to Tagum City -- a must place to visit not just for Tagumenos, but for those who are visiting the place, which is now becoming one of the fastest growing city in the country today.
One proof of Yuyu's success is its expansion three years after it opened in 2010 at a small place along the city's National Highway.
In 2013, it has moved to a bigger location, also on National Highway to accommodate its growing market.
"This is much bigger.
Four times bigger than our original place.
We have to transfer, because surprisingly the business is doing very well.
Our market continues to grow," Emerald said.
Also, she was proud to say that from the original eight employees, the cafe's manpower has grown to 20.
"This is also one way of serving the community, to provide jobs and to train interested Tagumenos how to cook and bake," Emerald said.
With her loyal crew and her strict, but tender supervision, Emerald says they have won the hearts of Tagumenos whom they continue to serve food they can afford without sacrificing its quality.

"If you look at our prices, our coffee is much cheaper than any other coffee shops in the city.
All our cakes are less than a hundred bucks.
For our sandwiches the most expensive is at P100.
If we go beyond that magre-react talaga ang market," the 27-year-old entrepreneur says.
"I see to it na ang quality ng food andun.
I take charge of the kitchen.
I only have assistants but I personally prepare almost everything." 
"Okay naman ang market but there are some who really have to think twice bago pumasok dito.
Kaya when we did the menu, we controlled the prices kahit na hindi mataas ang mark up," she adds.
Emerald also trusts her 20-man crew whom she credits for the success of her business.
"I always told them to just love their work, like I do.
I can now entrust the business to them everytime I'm out on a trip abroad," she says.

"They can copy my recipes.
Kase ako, I really don't believe that there is a secret recipe.
The secret is always on your passion to do it, the techniques and the ingredients that you are using," she stresses.

Celebrating Eid'l Fitr, Celebrating Eid'l FitrMUSLIMS in Central Mindanao gathered to celebrate Eid'l Fitr which marked the end of the fasting month of Ramadan last July 17.

Eid'l Fitr, which literally means "festival of breaking the fast" symbolizes faith and gratitude towards Allah for giving them the strength to endure the fasting month of Ramadan.
It is a spiritual thanksgiving observed by the Muslim communities all over the world.

Aside from its religious essence, Eid'l Fitr is celebrated with great excitement.
Muslims exchange gifts, share food and greet their neighbors as a symbol of solidarity within the community.

Sumptuous food and drinks are the highlight of the festivity, and the women in the household play a major part in preparing mouth-watering traditional sweets and delicacies to liven up the feast.

In Cotabato City, different delicacies from different tribes were showcased at mock Cultural Villages built inside the Armm's Office of the Regional Governor's compound.

Two of the featured attractions were the Maguindanaon and the Iranun villages, headed by Armm Tourism Assistant Secretary Shalimar Candao and Armm Tourism Secretary Maritess Maguindra.
The most common recipe during the festival was a Maguindanaon dish called "sinina" usually made from beef or mutton.
Crabs which are bountiful in the province are also part of the traditional food offerings during the celebration.

Families shared their blessings by providing food to everyone who visits their homes.
Of course, Muslim delicacies like dudol , tinagtag , and putrimandi  were present in each household.

According to Maguindra, these delicacies are specially prepared with much time, effort, perseverance, and prayer.

The Cultural Village display will be open to the public until September 2015.

So, if you are interested in experiencing life from the perspective of our Muslim brothers and sisters, you can still head on to Cotabato City where you can see a wide array of arts and food items that are being displayed in the traditional village.

The feminization of a Disney Princess, The feminization of a Disney PrincessIT WAS back in 2013 when I first saw the article about the redesigning of Princess Merida from a spunky, tomboyish princess to a sexy, glittered princess.

This drew fire from people all over the world.
Comments varied from 201cKeep Merida brave201d to 201cMerida was created to break the mold2014to give young girls a better, stronger role model, a more attainable role model, something of substance, not just a pretty face that waits around for romance201d.
The article made me think.
I couldn2019t help but ask, what2019s wrong with a sparkly Merida?
This issue tackles how women at a very young age are affected by society to be stereotypically 201cfemale201d.
They are constantly told2014in both visual and audio aspects2014that they have to be, in the simplest terms, girls.
A sexist society would give the word girl a definition of being pretty, submissive, and helpless.
A girl is someone who always needs help from men.
A girl is someone who cannot think for herself and therefore must rely on men for guidance.

Princess Merida in her new sparkly clothes is viewed as a disadvantage.
Apparently, it would discourage girls from being brave, taking on their own destinies, and choosing their own roles2014simply because redesigned Merida is sexier, and therefore, more unattainable.

Eventually, society believes that this would affect girls mentally believing that all they need is sparkles and glitter to be a female.

Does wearing sparkly clothes mean she wouldn2019t, couldn2019t choose her own fate? Does that mean she wouldn2019t, couldn2019t use her bow and arrows anymore?  Does being fond of glittery things stop a person from taking control of their own lives?
Redesigned Merida actually presents a predicament all girls can relate to2014the quest to be beautiful inside and out.
Merida is strong, yes, brave too, but that doesn2019t mean she can2019t be pretty.
Calling her out on becoming beautiful would just confuse young girls all over the world.
It2019s like a woman is forced to choose between two stereotyped personalities - to be tomboyish, not like girly things but be strong or to be girlish, like girly things but be dumb.

Redesigned Merida abolishes these foolish beliefs.
Redesigned Merida tells girls, yes, it2019s okay.
It2019s okay to be brave, to be strong, and to choose your own life.
At the same time, Merida sends a message that it2019s okay to be beautiful while you2019re at it too.
Realizing all of this, I also saw the other princesses in a new light.
Other Disney Princesses such as Cinderella and Snow White are dismissed as 201cjust a pretty face that waits around for romance201d.
On the other hand, Mulan and Merida are glorified for going against the norms, for being the captains of their ships, the masters of their souls.

Mulan is idolized because she set off to war and defied her father2019s commands despite living in a patriarchal China where women are suffering gender inequality.
Merida is hyped up because she can use a bow and arrow, challenged men, and redefined what it meant to be a princess.

Cinderella was physically and mentally abused by her own family.
She could have rebelled and run away, yet she remained strong and positive.
  Belle was stigmatized by her own town as 201ca beauty but a funny girl201d just because she liked to read.
Yet she did not let that stop her from reading her books.

Jasmine was as deviant as a princess could be in facing her duties.
Prepared for being married off to a prince, Jasmine defied her whole kingdom and married a thief.
 Snow White who was 14 years old and was an orphan, was ordered to be murdered for being beautiful, yet having survived, remained a gentle soul.
Tiana is a woman of color.
Despite her race and gender, she believed that if she worked, she can make her dreams happen.
And she did.
 Ariel sacrificed her beautiful voice for a chance to be human, and despite popular belief, not to be with Eric.

They were abused, stigmatized, and unjustly labelled.
Saying that these brave women are just pretty faces is just another case of what2019s wrong in our society.
 Not all women have to go to wars, to be able to shoot arrows, to not like girly things, to be strong.

Sometimes, to be a woman, all it takes is to face life2019s challenges with grace and an iron will to survive.
Sometimes to be strong means smiling despite the hardships.
Sometimes being strong means sacrifice, working hard, and putting up against the injustices in the world.
Sometimes, really, all it takes is to just be yourself.
Reading the article about Merida really changed me.
It gave me a new outlook on life.
I realized that in our society today, it is hard being a woman.
Society tells us to do this, to be that, and sometimes, we do not even question it.
I realized that I should not listen too much to society.
It2019s okay if I like to read, to dress up in girly outfits, to shoot arrows, to marry a prince, to save China, or to open up a restaurant.
Heck, it2019s okay if I do them all at once.
What matters is that I remember society will not and cannot dictate who I am.
 I am my own person.
I cannot live inside a box.
 In the end, who I want to be, will always be my choice, and my choice alone.

When they wake up on their 18th birthday, the law sees them as adults.

They are now also forced to pay taxes if they have jobs.

Looking forward to my 18th birthday was the one thing that kept me going because I knew that when I become an adult, I can finally have the freedom I so longed for.

So being the silly person I am, I started provoking arguments whether it may be about what to eat for dinner just to rile them up.
I even started again with the whole 2018I2019m running away2019 saga.
It was until one day when my parents have had enough that they sat me down and said the one thing that got through to me.
201cWhy don2019t you focus on something you hope to accomplish as an 18-year-old? Do you just want to be considered as an adult or is independence the only thing you want? If living with us is making you so unhappy, then you may go and live the life you want to live.
We just want our baby girl to be happy again.201d
That2019s when I knew that I had to stop with all these because the truth is I do need them.
I need my parents just as much as I need air.
Thoughts about me living on my own, being in the real world scared the life out of me.
Who knows how long I2019d be able to last out there? I2019d say maybe half a day.
I guess being 18 doesn2019t really mean a thing unless you2019re no longer living under your parents2019 rule, but if you still are, then you are still bound by the rules they set.
This is the story of how I realized that I will never stop needing my parents.
I choose to be by their side today and forevermore.
So I learned that we should always be grateful that our parents are still around because we never know how much we2019ll miss them when they2019re gone.

My uncles and aunts are all in the field of health.
Basically, my family is my own hospital.

I was supposed to be the first to continue the supposedly heirloom of our clan.

I am proud after all.
I am everything after all.

Pressure? The affirmation of my family2019s legacy? I don2019t have an idea.
All I know is I am happy where I am right now.

They are now registered pharmacist.

 Wrong.

I felt proud.
I felt their happiness.
That is the exact time where I know that I am truly and deeply happy with my decision to change direction.
I don2019t know how to explain it.
I just know.
Two years of delay is nothing.
In life, there will always be a lot of 201cwhat ifs201d.
What if I continued my original course? What if I studied one more hour for a test? What if I ordered one more cup of coffee just to stay awake just for the slightest time?
Millions of what ifs will always pave their way into our mind.
Yet, they are just that2014inside the mind.
What matters is what we already did.
I never regretted a single decision in my life.
If I never enrolled in Pharmacy, I wouldn2019t be able to meet my truest and loyal friends.
A med course is not easy.
I wouldn2019t be able to survive those three years without them.
Failure is inevitable.
We can never be perfect.
We will always have flaws.
There will always be a glitch in us.
 But that doesn2019t matter.
We can still be everything we want to be.
I will never be perfect but I can be everything.
This is my mantra.

Rich cultural heritage, with dash of modernism, Rich cultural heritage, with dash of modernism
The Adasa Ancestral House 2013 then and now.

Ben O.
Tesiorna, KNOWN as the Shrine City of the Philippines, Dapitan has a lot of heritage houses and old churches and buildings that are rich in history.

Among them is the Saint James Church located at the heart of the city.
The St.
James Church is considered as a lasting heritage and symbol of Christianization of the region.
It was built in 1871, in honor of St.
James the Greater 2013 Dapitan2019s patron saint.
It houses the priceless 1827 heritage piped organ which is German made with European pipes and a manual pump.
It was brought to Dapitan in 1864 by the Augustinian Recollect Father.

St.
James Church is also where Rizal stood while hearing mass on Sundays during his 4-year exile in Dapitan from July 17, 1892 to July 31, 1896.
In 1944, Japanese soldiers used the church as a resting/sleeping area for about five days.
Across St.
James Church a huge map of Mindanao, resting on a total land area of roughly 900 square meters, was constructed by Rizal.
He intended it as a motivating device for teaching history and geography to the townsfolk.
A shrine was also erected at the site where Rizal disembarked from the steamer "Cebu" in 1565.
The shrine is called Punto del Desembarco de Rizal and is located along the Dapitan beachfront.
It is also here where A 20-foot cross was erected to symbolize the propagation of Christianity in Dapitan.
Another shrine is the Rizal Shrine which is a major historical landmark of Dapitan City.
The 10-hectare piece of land was bought by Rizal from his winnings in lotto on August 1892.
It is here where Rizal's mother, Do\xf1a Teodora Alonso, his sisters, and some relatives from Calamba, Laguna came and lived with him until 1896.

Kinabayo Festival
Aside from shrines, Dapitan City is now also known for its Kinabayo Festival, which is celebrated every 25th of July, in honor of the city's patron saint, St.
James the Greater.

It was believed that in the year 722, an apparition of St.
James, atop a horse carrying a sword, guided the Spanish into victory over the Moors in the Battle of Covadonga.
Thus, Kinabayo Festival's highlight is a re-enactment of the Battle of Covadonga.
The performers enact the Christian and Moorish players, while riding horses made of bamboo and rattan.
Hence, the term "kinabayo".
On July 24, a "Halok sa Reliquias" is conducted from 8 a.m.
until 12 noon.
For four hours, thousands of devotees lineup for a chance to pay homage to the relic statue of St.
James before it is paraded at the town plaza just outside the cathedral.
As the clock strikes 12 noon, the statue of St.
James the Greater is then paraded around the plaza as thousands of devotees shout "Viva Sr.
Santiago" while waving bunch of San Francisco leaves.

Ancestral Houses
One of the few remaining original ancestral houses in Dapitan is the Antera Adaza Bajamunde residence more popularly known as the Pablo Page Ancestral House.
It was built in 1919 and is a combined Spanish-American domestic architecture.
Like any old houses, it has decorative and ornate woodworks with numerous huge windows.
Its walls and wide floor slabs is of hardwood like narra and kamagong.

Often the venue of various functions among the local social and political elite in the 1950's to 1970's, national dignitaries like the late President Ferdinand Marcos and world-famous violinist Gilopez Kabayao have been to this old house.

Another very prominent old house in downtown Dapitan is the Aniano Adasa ancestral house which now houses the Dapitan Tourism Office.
This house was built in 1900 and symbolizes American architecture with a touch of Spanish influence.

All in all, there are forty heritage houses in Dapitan City which forms part the Dapitan Heritage Zone as declared by the National Historical Commission of the Philippines in 2011 in time for the 150th birth anniversary of Dr.
Jose Rizal in June 2011.
Gloria de Dapitan/Fantasy Land
Amidst the old buildings and churches, Dapitan City is also home to Mindanao's one and only theme park called the Fantasy Land.
It is located inside the 3-hectare Gloria de Dapitan owned and operated by the Jalosjos family.
Fantasy Land is a smaller version of Disneyland in Hong Kong and the Universal Studio in Singapore.
It has about 35 rides and attractions including a horror house.
Every weekend, a light and show parade is held capped with a fireworks display.

Dakak Park Beach Resort
Another modern facility Dapitan has to offer is the world-renowned 5-star Dakak Park Beach Resort.
Aside from the white sand beach cove, it also has two huge swimming pools, three tennis courts, billiards and bowling alley, and a golf course.

Their latest rooms called the Garden Rooms are way, way better than their "old rooms".
 Garden Rooms have much modern amenities.

For those who love food, Dakak also has a Chinese restaurant that can cater to 1,500 people in one sitting, an Italian restaurant, a seafood restaurant that also serves as the view deck for the famous Dapitan sunset, a bar, and a cafe.

For the adventurous, they also offer horse backriding, all-terrain vehicle, zipline, rock climbing, wakeboarding, airsoft war game, rappelling, cove hopping, scuba diving, snorkeling, kayaking, banana boat ride, hobie cat, and jetski.
And for the romantics, they have the river cruise and sunset cruise.

JUSTY Rhea Go Gesalem has been working since grade one.
Growing up in a business-oriented family means delivering service crew duties at a young age to obligations at the office in her teens.
But when she got the hang of it, things didn2019t seem so bad after all.
Justy2019s early exposure to business stems from being the daughter of a Cebuano businessman, the force behind major donut and fireworks brands, among many other established local ventures.
When they were capable enough, she and her three other siblings started training for rotational jobs for the family businesses.
Summers and semestral breaks would usually translate to job opportunities, from basic cashier roles to more advance descriptions like document control.

All about breastfeeding, All about breastfeeding
BREASTFEEDING tightens the bond between mother and infant.
An emotional bonding is being developed during the act of breastfeeding.

Marianne L.
Saberon-Abalayan, THERE is much to learn in breastfeeding, the breastmilk being a dynamic fluid.
Doctor Ameleen B.
Bangayan bared this during a press conference held Friday at the Medical Tower of Davao Doctors Hospital.
Hence, they are organizing the 1st International Breastfeeding Conference and 3rd Breastfeeding Congress on August 8 at the SMX Convention Center in Davao City.
Bangayan, over-all chair of the event, said: "This is the first breastfeeding congress to be held in Davao as it is usually held in Manila.
This is also the first international breastfeeding conference that will be held in our city and we are very proud to host it."
She said two foreign experts American Jennifer Thomas, MD and Australian Julie Smith, PhD are keynote resource speakers of the conference.
Thomas holds a masters degree in public health  and she is also an international board certified lactation consultant .
She is a fellow of the Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine  and also a fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics .
Smith has a Bachelor's degree in Economics, Bachelor's degree in Asian Studies and a doctorate in Economics.
Thomas will tackle maintenance of breastfeeding the infant - the normal newborn and appropriate supplementation; birth weight, Bilirubin and blood sugar, breastfeeding in special circumstances - an approach to the fussy breastfed infant, breastfeeding: medications, including illegal substances , and breastfeeding and the clinician - breastfeeding strategies for a successful practice.
Meanwhile, Smith will tackle marketing and the economics of breastfeeding - marketed environment: formula for fatness, seven deadly sins of obesity, how the modern world is making us fat and lost milk? Counting the economic value of breast milk.
Davao Doctors Hospital-based Doctor Sigrid A.
Barinaga, MD, FPOGS will discuss breastfeeding the preterm infant - feeding the preterm infants with donor's breast milk, is there a risk of CMV infection? 
While Dr.
Jeanmarie Cabrera-Salvador, MD, FPOGS, FPSREL, FPSGE will talk about breastfeeding and the family - breastfeeding, fertility and birth spacing, and using the lactation amenorrhea method.
Open forum and feedback evaluation will be held after each speaker's topic.
Davao Doctors Hospital Department of Pediatrics chair Doctor Jo-anne J.
Lobo, MD, FPPS, DPIDS-P also said that they target 800 registrants.
As of July 23, 373 have registered, half of which are doctors, 30 percent are nurses and the rest are students, midwives, health workers and lay people.
"By lay people we mean mothers and fathers.
We have partnered with the Department of Health as their facilitators will spearhead the workshop set in the afternoon for those who want to get their hospitals and lying-in clinics accredited with the department.
We hope more stakeholders will sign up and join us in this very rare opportunity of learning," Lobo said.
Davao Doctors Hospital lactation counselor Marianne V.
Tan said pre-registration is set until July 30.
Pre-registration fees are P600 for government medical professionals and students, P1,200 for nurses, midwives, allied health professionals, medical residents-in-training and lay; private practitioners.
On-site fees are P900, P1,500 and P1,800.
Mom-baby friendly 
Davao Doctors Hospital and Brokenshire Hospital are the only two hospitals in Davao City that were given certification as mother-baby friendly hospitals.

Dr.
Bangayan said, "Meaning, we at DDH have complied with the requirements.
We are also strictly implementing the milk code, promoting breastfeeding.
In our NICU , it's part of our policy that mothers are asked to sign that they are giving birth to an institution that follows the milk code."
She also said that their lactation counselors and nurses anticipate that mothers who just gave birth will have difficulty expressing milk in the first three hours so they help mothers with their lactation.
They also police donated breastmilk and check out its source so that diseases could not be passed on to the infant.
Optimum source 
Bangayan said, "Breastmilk is the optimum source of nutrition.
The main goal of this congress we wanted to have exclusive breastfeeding up to six months, nothing else."
Tan also said breastmilk contains colostrum that is very rich in antibodies that help protect a baby from infection, strengthens immune system of the baby and contains essential vitamins and minerals that help develop the brain and help prevent the infant from developing jaundice.
Bangayan added that breastfeeding doesn't only benefit infants but also their mothers.
"Breastfeeding give mothers a degree of protection from various illnesses.
There is an observation, a trend in studies that mothers get a degree of protection from ovarian and breast cancers.
The impact on economy, those breastfed have lesser incidents of diarrhea and respiratory infection.
As a community, if almost all are breastfeeding, there are lesser incidents of illnesses in the very young.
Breastfeeding is very important for mothers, babies and the community as a whole," Bangayan said.
Breastfeeding, according to her, also tigthens the bond between mother and infant.
An emotional bonding is being developed during the act of breastfeeding.
A chemical interaction between mom and baby happens during breastfeeding.
"Breastfed infants will grow emotionally bonded with you, easier to discipline them.
They are more calm and closer to their mothers," she said.
However, the decision to stop breastfeeding is a family decision.
Bangayan added, "If your breastmilk is still available then breastfeed until the child stops.
Before we encourage breastfeeding up to two years, now we advise them to breastfeed two years and beyond.
It's perfectly okay as long as the mother is still up to it, and if her routine is not being affected, then stop when the baby stops."
After breastfeeding a child, she advised that solid foods given to a child must provide the basic calcium requirements that can be found in milk as the child's demand for calcium grows when the age grows.
But she was quick to add that there is no other substitute for breastmilk.
Thus, it's still wise to consult lactation counselors and professionals when a decision to stop breastfeeding is finalized.

"Stopping breastfeeding, after all, is a family decision," she said.
Well, just like what Bangayan said, even a breastfeeding mother like me still has so much to learn.
And the best way is learning from the experts themselves.
Disabilities defined , Disabilities defined Ivy C.
Tejano, ACCORDING to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, persons with disabilities  include those who have a long-term physical, mental, sensory or intellectual impairment.
Globally, over 1 billion people or about 15 percent of the world2019s population have some form of disability.
Approximately 110 to 190 million people 15 years and older have some significant difficulties in functioning.
 The rapid spread of chronic diseases and population aging contribute to the increasing rates of disability.
About 80 percent of the world2019s PWDs live in low-income countries, wherein majority are poor and cannot access basic services.
 The World Health Organization  in 2012 reported that PWDs have less access to health and other services therefore have greater unmet needs.
This holds true to many.
 
Davao2019s PWD Affairs Section representative Bong Comiling said that 80 percent of the government owned buildings violated the accessibility law.
He added that law remains a big issue on this matter.
 
201cHindi lang accessibility ang problema kundi pati na rin sa mga taong hindi marunong umintindi.
 
I am telling my brothers, we do not beg for their mercy, but we are availing our rights,201d said chess international master James Infiesto and president of Association of Differently-Abled Persons Inc.
.
  
A law states that no permit or license for construction shall be given unless it complies with the requirement of the accessibility law as stipulated in Section 1 of the Batas Pambansa Bilang 344.
 
Dr.
Sharon Lilly B.
Valdez, medical officer for the Department of Health2019s  non-communicable disease  Cluster Health in Davao Region, said with PWDs health and conditions, they need greater attention and considerations without discrimination.
Based on an administrative order obtained from the Office of the Secretary of the DOH, Census of Population and Housing  result on 2010 revealed that the country, of the 92.1 million household population, has 1.443 million or 1.57 percent PWDs.
The Calabarzon Region was recorded to have the highest number with 193,000 PWDs among the 17 regions, while Cordillera Administrative Region  had lowest number with 26,000 PWDs.

National Statistics Office2019s  record in 2013 revealed that for every five PWDs, 19 percent was aged 0 to 14 years, 59 percent were in the working age group , and 22.1 percent was aged 65 years and above.
With this concern, the DOH came up with a National Health Program  for PWD based on the Republic Act 7211 or The Rehabilitation and Self-Reliance of Disabled, to address barriers and improve the access to inclusive health and rehabilitation services.
Transcending disabilities, Transcending disabilitiesKriztja Marae G.
Labrador, 201cDISABILITIES201d as defined by the World Health Organization , 201cis an umbrella term, covering impairments, activity limitations, and participation restrictions.201d WHO views disability not only as a health problem but a complex phenomenon, 201creflecting the interaction between features of a person2019s body and features of the society in which he or she lives.201d  
One of them is Wilmo B.
Capoy, who was diagnosed with congenital visual impairment, a hereditary disease which can skip about six to eight generations.
 Being the eldest out of five siblings, three of them are affected of this disease.
  
Education is a struggle Life was not easy for Capoy, growing up with his disability during the time where there are still no special schools present yet for persons with disability  and he has to finish his elementary and high school education together with normal students.

201cKung naa kay disability lisud gyud siya mu-eskwela especially sa ako-a, sa panahon sa akong pag eskwela wala pa may school for the blind, I have to be in a regular school ,201d he recalls.
Then there is the mockery that comes with the bullying.
 
Capoy remembers that during his elementary years, his teachers would often tell him that he cannot finish high school but he did and during his high school years his classmates would tell him he cannot finish college but he did.

With his low vision during that time, Capoy finished school without the help of Braille.
He would read his books with his nose almost touching the pages.
Capoy learn Braille at the Davao Special School before he went to college.
 He finished his bachelor2019s degree in education major in English and law from the University of Mindanao.
 
201cIt2019s a childhood ambition , I2019ve entertained that one since I was a child but I was not lucky enough, I did not make it in the bar,201d he said.
He took his law studies while he was teaching English to the student of the Davao School for the Blind.
 
Local scene for PWDs With most local government units  in the region having established the required Persons With Disability Affairs Office  pursuant to Republic Act 10070 or the amended 201cMagna Carta for Disabled Persons201d, Department of Social Welfare and Development XI regional focal person for PWDs Cythina Umda\xf1a said that education and unemployment are still a challenge faced by most PWDs in the region.

Umda\xf1a said that not all public schools that offer special education are accessible to those PWDs especially the ones in the far flung areas and even though they have finished school not all of them are given a chance to be employed.
 
But she added that, with their continued measures in raising awareness together with private support groups, most of the PWDs, in the region are now aware of their rights and privileges through the many activities initiated both by the government and private organizations to advocate such.
Just like the recent celebration of the 37th National Disability Prevention and Rehabilitation  week last July 17-23 wherein their talents were showcased and services and seminars not only for the PWD sectors but also to the business sectors were conducted in order to raise more awareness to the laws in support for PWDs.
  
A vision for others 
Now at 61, Capoy serves as the principal of the Davao School for the Blind wherein he is also teaching English subject to his students and serving as an inspiration to them.
 Their school, supported by a German organization, provides free elementary and high school education for children with visual impairment, helping them live a normal life.
 
201cI want them  to be a productive member of the society through any endeavor that they will enter as long as it2019s a dignified way of living the most important there is they know how to persevere.
This is a highly competitive world, likened to a race you have to have proper stamina to survive, I always tell my students: you always prepare yourself, double your efforts so you can be at par with the sighted individuals because if you can do that I2019m sure you will have a place under the heat of the sun,201d he said.

What to do during an earthquake, What to do during an earthquakeRuth Abbey Gita, HAVE you prepared yourself just in case a destructive earthquake hits your area?
An updated map of the Philippine Institute of Volcanologist and Seismology  released in May showed that the West Valley Fault, which traverses Manila, Bulacan, Laguna, Rizal and Cavite, has the potential to generate up to 7.2-magnitude earthquake.
According to the 2004 Metro Manila Earthquake Impact Reduction Study, a 7.2 magnitude quake in Metro Manila could cause 33,500 deaths and 114,000 injuries itself and additional 18,000 deaths from the fire that could break out.
But tremors occur without warning, thus the public is urged to prepare ahead of time.
In this video, Phivolcs geologist Jeffrey Perez gave some reminders on how to be safe when you are indoors, outside the home, and in a moving vehicle during an earthquake.



How to survive a tsunami, How to survive a tsunamiRuth Abbey Gita, ONCE an earthquake occurs, the next thing that the public should prepare for is the possible tsunami.
In a leaflet from the Philippine Institute Volcanology and Seismology , tsunami is described as a series of waves commonly generated by undersea earthquakes.
Tsunami can occur if a quake is shallow  and strong enough to displace parts of the seabed and disturb the mass of water over it.
Tsunami wave heights could be greater than five meters.
Tsunami moves so fast, travelling at speeds up to 800 kilometers per hour across the ocean, according to the United States Geological Survey.
 
Will a tsunami strike Manila and other nearby provinces if a 7.2-magnitude earthquake occurs?
Phivolcs geologist Jeffrey Perez assured the public that the West Valley Fault, which traverses Manila, Bulacan, Laguna, Rizal and Cavite, is not capable of generating a tsunami unless the tremor is due to the movement of the Manila Trench.

In case of an undersea earthquake, Perez said residents along coastal areas in Manila and Camanava  will be affected.
Watch this video for some tips on how to escape a tsunami.
 


Facts and myths about earthquakes , Facts and myths about earthquakes Third Anne Peralta-Malonzo, AS RESIDENTS in Metro Manila prepare for the magnitude-7.2 earthquake which might result from movement of the West Valley Fault, Sun.Star collated facts and misconceptions about ground shaking.
 
The ground can open up and swallow people and buildings
It happens only in movies.
During an earthquake, the ground moves across the fault and not away from it.
201cIt will not be like what was seen in the movie 'San Andreas' where the ground opened and swallowed everything.
During an earthquake there will only be displacement as far as three meters,201d Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology  resident volcanologist Jeffrey Perez said.

Faults do not gape open during an earthquake, according to the United States Geological Survey.

 An earthquake cannot be predicted  
At present, Phivolcs said the science of earthquake prediction has not yet matured to the point that imminent earthquakes can be predicted  using a rational model.

201cThe exact date and time which the earthquake will occur cannot be identified by science.
All we know is that there is a fault which may be the source of the earthquake,201d Perez said.
 One should for head for the doorway during an earthquake
Duck, cover and hold  is still the best thing to do when you are inside the house or a building.
Those outside their homes can rush to an open field and stay away from power lines and buildings because debris might fall off the structure.

 201cTriangle of Life" as way to survive an intense quake  
Self-proclaimed rescue guru Doug Copp said that people should take cover next to sturdy objects, disputing the widely accepted practice of duck, cover, and hold.
201cIt is not true.
You will not be 100 percent safe with that .
What if the shelter or anything you are leaning crush on you, you will still be in danger,201d Perez said.
 An earthquake cannot cause death unlike flood and landslides 
The earthquake can't kill but its effects do: falling debris, fire and tsunami.

Serving the under-served  , Serving the under-served  Karina V.
Canedo, THE newly organized Davao City Persons with Disability Assistance Office  has been hard at work to ensure that they can reach out to the persons with disabilities in Davao City.
First step: make sure everyone is accounted for through the issuance of identification cards.

Teogenes Comiling of the PDAO, which is still under the Davao City Social Service and Development Office, said that very few persons with disabilities  have the PDAO IDs.
 
"Para ma-avail ang privileges and discount sama sa number one 20 percent discount sa tambal, kung magpalit silang devices dunay 20 percent discount ug ang ilahang pamasahe 20 percent discount ," Comiling said.

PWDs are even entitled to 30 percent discount in big food chains and 5 percent discount from groceries from a maximum of P1,500 grocery bill a week.
All these they can have access to if they have the ID.

"Ang uban wala pay ID, ang uban PWD wala pa kabalo nga naa diay ID ," he said.
The PDAO would only be sought out when the PWD needs medical care.

"Pag naa na sa hospital diha pa magpa-ID.
 Unta beforehand asikasuhon daan ," Comiling said.
So far, they have issued a total of 6,000 cards including children, when the population of PWDs in Davao City for adults alone is already 12,000.
 
Last July 22, the highlight of the National Disability Prevention and Rehabilitation Week celebration was the issuance of more IDs where doctors were brought in to certify the specific disability the person has, still PDAO is calling out to those who are now aware.

"You won't be asked any certification if the disability is apparent.
Examples of these are those who have no arms or feet.
To those who had stroke and cannot come, the PWDs in the barangay level shall certify that they are indeed PWDs to avoid exploitation," Comiling said.

Apart from that Comiling said they already oriented the barangay captains on Executive Order 417 that allots 1 percent of the Internal Revenue allotment of the barangay for PWDs.
In this way, the barangay will always have a fund for the needs of PWDs, especially for emergency cases.

Organizations of PWDS can also submit project proposals for training seminars, mobility, and livelihood to further enhance their economic independence, the funds of which can be tapped from the Gender and Development Fund.

So far, only five barangays have implemented this law.
Also among their tasks, Comiling said, is to ensure the implementation of Presidential Decree 10524, which mandates the employment of the 1 percent PWDs in the total population of employees in government and non-government offices and the accessibility law.
Accessibility alone is already a major setback because 80 percent of the government offices in the city do not have the facilities for PWD access.

"Dili lang ni siya access sa structure, access  pud sa pagsakay, access sa communication labaw na sa mga deaf ug sa tanan nga PWD ," Comiling said.
Schools have no ramps and are not equipped with Braille books, there are very few government offices who have staff who can communicate in sign.
 
The City Social Services and Development Office CSSDO office is also a helping hand of the PWDs in attaining their programs.

"We work with our barangays we have social workers and one of the things that we do is organizing our differently abled persons because we believe that they are our partners in our livelihood programs" said Maria Luisa Bermudo, CSSDO Department Head.

Bermudo said they provide livelihood assistance for the families of children with autism, educational assistance and technical skills training for PWDs with their partners, the Department of Labor and Employment  and Technical Education Skills Development Authority  although at a limited scale, as yet.

She added that the Department of Social Welfare and Development is also providing support under the Bottom-up Budgeting in the shared livelihood, skills training and capacity training that includes computer repair, solar light making, food processing , agriculture, radio repair manicure and pedicure training.

The PDAO, she said, will hopefully be a full-fledged city office before the year ends as mandated under the Magna Carta for Persons with Disability.

"There are still many things for us to do not just government sectors but also private sectors and facilities to provide equal opportunities of for employment.

We also encourage private sector to hire PWDs as part of their corporate social responsibility and as a mandate of Magna Carta for PWDs," Bermudo said.
Suffering in silence , Suffering in silence Karlo Paolo R.
Pates, IF THERE is any person who will most likely be bullied, it is a person with disabilities.
 
The bullying starts as a child when fellow children would make fun of them or maltreat them knowing they cannot hit back.
As a grown-up some still experience various forms of discrimination and are not given equal treatment and opportunities for employment or in their work places.
 Robert Buenvineda, 36, who hails from Tagum City, and who was born with a deformed right hand, admitted that PWDs including himself have difficulty finding a job.
 
He has been on a job hunt for a year now, he said.
"Hantod karon wala gihapon nadawat sa akong giapplyan ," Buenvineda told Sun.Star Davao in a recent interview.
He does not know why, but he hopes that it's not because of his physical condition.
He has been applying as laborer, a job he once held.
 
"Dili man ko mahimong sagabal sa companya ug kaya man nako ang mga responsibilidad ," Buenvineda said.
 
Who are the PWDs 
In a 2005 data by the Philippine National Statistics Office  showed that many of the PWDs belong to the poorest sector in the society or below the poverty line.
  
The Republic Act of 7277 or the Magna Carta for Persons with Disabilities states that no PWD person shall be denied access to opportunities for suitable employment.
All should have the same terms and conditions of employment and the same compensation, privileges, benefits, fringe benefits, incentives or allowances as a qualified able bodied person.
 The same law gives PWDs incentives and exempts them from taxes.
 
Lawyer Jayson Balais, assistant regional director of Department of Labor and Employment, said they are aware of these provisions.
 
"Ang aming ahensya naman ay consistent na nagpapatupad ng ating mga batas upang walang mga incidents of discrimination among the PWDS," Balais said in an interview at his office recently.
But, he said, as in hiring of able-bodied applicants, the final say on who gets employed are the employers and company officers who know what skills and aptitudes they are looking for.
 
The provision about discrimination, Balais explained, is that when choosing between an able-bodied and a PWD applicant, the focus should be not on the physical attributes but on the qualifications of the position.
 
"We always make sure that the PWD community gets fair share of allocation of the DOLE budget every year.
We allocate the money for different livelihood programs for them," Balais added.
 
Various training programs are being prepared and organized for those PWDs particularly the blind, deaf and mute people who have the most difficult time getting a job.
 
Balais also advised PWDs who feel they are being discriminated at work to address their complaints at the provincial offices of Dole.
 
"They can seek help from our provincial offices in Tagum, Panabo, Mati, Davao del Sur or even directly dito sa regional office.
Yung complainants nila will be entertained kasi easy access ang office namin," Balais said.
The discriminated PWDs can also file their complaints addressed to the National Labor Relations Commission, a quasi-judicial agency attached to DOLE.
 
"If may mga termination complaints from the PWDs, titingnan muna natin yan kung toto ba.
Kung basis ba ng termination ng employers ay yung performances nila or primarily because of their disability," he said.
 
Sanctions against the employeers who violates the labor code of DOLE will be facing appropriate sanctions.
 
"Yung level ng sanctions may depend on the severity of the complaint or evidences presented against the employers," Balais said.
 
Grace Consolacion, 34, a resident of Kilometer 11, Sasa, Davao City, in a separate interview, said that she never gelled well with her workmates.
 
"Ginapafeel nila na lahi gyud ko.
Pasagdan nalang pud nako kay aron walay gubot ," Consolacion said of her work in a shirt manufacturing company.
 It's that preference to just keep quiet that draws a blind on what the regular PWD goes through in his daily work.
Balais confirmed that their office has not received any complaint from the PWD community in Davao with regards discrimination.
"Honestly, wala talaga," Balais said.
Their vision is clearer, Their vision is clearerRhealyn C.
Pojas, WHILE most of the people showered with more than enough light have complained with their daily hustle and bustle in life, students at Davao School & Rehabilitation for Visually Impaired , a private-run institution for people with visual impairment, embrace life despite its subtlety and emit brighter aura.

For them, life did not stop when their eyes fail to give light, instead life for them has become brighter even if darkness has been their constant companion since birth.
Laughter, smiles, music, and ability to compete -- these are some of the things that make their life colorful, beautiful and challenging.
And visiting a classroom in that institution, life itself, with all its complexities, will welcome you.
  
Meet Edmund Montecillo, president of the student council of the Davao School & Rehabilitation for Visually Impaired.
Like the rest of the students, he also has visual impairment.
It has been five years since he entered the school.

He recalled that he used to study in a regular school at Paitan Elementary School in Bukidnon when he lost his sight hen he was in second grade due to eye cataracts.
Because of that, even if it was against his will, he was forced to stop for three years because of his visual impairment.

But in June of 2010, Edmund was able to attend school again after being informed that there is a special school catering to young people like him who has visual impairment through a recruitment done by the personnel of DSRVI upon their visit to Bukidnon.

Edmund now stayed at the school's dormitory for free where he and the other students were taught not only how to read and write but as well as how to do basic household chores and even taught them sports and music.
Edmund, who is now 18, also narrated that in 2011, the school helped him to undergo operation but since his eye condition was already worst, his sight was not restored.

But Edmund never lost hope and he continued his study.
Now he is already in Grade 7 and even plays tenor and alto saxophones and actively participates in the school's judo club.
All of these, he learned in the school.
Edmund admitted that he had a hard time adjusting to the new way of teaching at first as he was used to the teaching done in the regular school.
He narrated that he had started again from the beginning since he had to use Braille.
According to the American Foundation for the Blind website, "Braille is a system of raised dots that can be read with the fingers by people who are blind or who have low vision."
"Naglisod ko og pag practice sa Braille pag-abot diri kay lahi ra ang porma sa alphabet sa Braille ," Edmund saidd.
Edmund said that special schools for people like him who has visual impairment are a big help.
Learning through touching
Learning through touching, that was how Jam Garde, a Physical Education teacher, explained the students' way of learning especially in physical activities.
Garde has been a volunteer teacher at the said school for four years now.
The ages of the students she was teaching range from 18 and below, she said.
"It is difficult because in teaching them actions you really have to do it yourself to show and let them learn through touching," Garde said.

School principal Wilmo Capoy said they already produced over a hundred graduates since its establishment in year 1981.
The school which was formally inaugurated in 1982, was the first school for the blind outside Luzon, explained Capoy.
Capoy narrated that the idea of putting up a school for the blind sparked from the program of eye doctors in Davao City for blindness prevention where they wrote a letter abroad and unexpectedly gained 100% support for an establishment of a school for the blind from the Hildesheimer Blidenmission  in Germany and Christian society.

Capoy said that during the school2019s first operation, it only had few students.
"Parents at first had apprehension basin gamiton sa syndicated mendicancy ang ilang mga anak ,"Capoy explained.
There are already eight alumni in their school who graduated from college and one of them is a social worker.

At present, the school has 52 students, and only three of them are staying out of the school's dormitory.
 Others are allowed to be home every weekend.
Though the school only caters grade school and high school students, Capoy explained that they were able to help some of their graduates to earn a scholarship for college education.
Capoy, being a person with visual impairment himself, aims for the students to become "productive member of the society."
He graduated at the University of Mindanao with a degree in Education and also graduated law in the same school afterwards.
"If you want to be in a race, you have to have the right stamina to survive," he said.
"If you will give up, you will not earned a place in the world."
Education for All
Everyone has the right to education, regardless of who they are, this is the reason why the educational program for the children with special needs is important, according to Davao City Special School principal Alma Tac-on of the elementary department.
The goal of education is to educate people regardless of their nationality, tribe, and even their special needs, Tac-on said.
She said the Davao Special School is the first school in Davao City to cater students with special needs.
It was established in 1975 but was first known as the Rizal Sped, located in Sta.
Ana, but was later transferred to Bangkal.
Students will first attend the self-contained class which has no grade-level and where their behavior will be tamed and parents2019 support is necessary.
If later on, the child is observed to be ready, they will be transferred into a regular class so that they will be moved to graded classes.
Parent-teacher partnership in a child's education is necessary, Tac-on added.
Teacher's Dilemma
While there are few schools in the city that offer education to children with certain disabilities, these are now faced with challenges and needs.
Capoy said there is still a big cut from the budget allocated to them by German organization that supported the school, but they are thankful the organization added a funding of P200,000 to their last year's budget.
From what was originally P4.5 million, the budget had been cut in half and is now amounting to only P2.4 million and this affects the students' budget for food and others which the school offered for free.

Tac-on, for her part, said that like regular schools, they too experienced different challenges.
"Kung challenges lang, dili gyud na siya mawala.
Kung naay challenges sa regular, how much more sa special?" Tac-on said.
No matter how organized your class is, there will come a time these special students throw tantrums and their behavior will be one of your challenges, Tac-on said.

But the number one problem lies on the parents who do not show much support on their children, she added, reiterating that education of children involved partnership between the teacher and the parents.

Collie Marvas of the Tugbok Central Elementary School and Amelyn Kantriman of the Imelda Elementary school also shared the major challenges that they experienced as teachers at Sped schools.

They both shared lack of special books for Sped class, lack of teachers, and assessment are some of the things that made their job difficult.
They both expressed that Sped students must have a special book for their education because if they will take the same books used by the regular, they can no longer be distinguished from the students taking the regular class.
Also, they said that there are not enough teachers who specialized in teaching special children and they also had problems with the assessment of the students enrolled in SPED schools since there are only few developmental pediatricians in the area.
But they all agree that one of the problems that they see is that the children with special needs are not exposed by their parents because they are embarrassed with them.
That is why the program advocates and campaigns for this matter so that the children with special needs who are just kept in their houses will also enjoy their right to education, they said.

According to the National Council on Disability Affairs website, in Davao del Sur there are eight public special elementary schools and 11 in high school while there are eight in the private special schools.
Top 5 most destructive earthquakes in the Philippines, Top 5 most destructive earthquakes in the Philippines
The Philippines straddles the western fringes of the Pacific Ring of Fire where most of strong earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occur.

Third Anne Peralta-Malonzo, THE Philippines straddles the western fringes of the Pacific Ring of Fire where most of strong earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occur.
Since the 1600s, the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology said the country has experienced 106 earthquakes with a magnitude of 6.0 or higher.
Of this number, the deadliest earthquakes took place in the last 50 years.
August 2, 1968:  A magnitude-7.3 tremor shook Casiguran and some areas in Luzon, including Manila, where 268 tenants of six-story Ruby Tower in Binondo, Manila were killed when it collapsed.
August 17, 1976: A 7.9-magnitude earthquake and resulting tsunami hit the Moro Gulf, leaving over 5,000 people dead.

July 16, 1990: Parts of Luzon, particularly Baguio City and Cabanatuan City, were damaged following a 7.9-magnitude earthquake.
At least 1,200 people died from the quake.

February 6, 2012: Nearly 60 people were killed when a 6.9-magnitude earthquake hit Negros Oriental
October 15, 2013: Centuries-old churches in Bohol and Cebu crumble down to a 7.2-magnitude tremor, which also killed 222 people and injured 976 others.

Personality Profile: Music & law, Personality Profile: Music & lawGOING to law school and pursuing one's love for music is surely not an easy task to make.
Balancing two completely different things is at best an elusive ideal and at worst a myth.
For Kimberly Gayle Fabular, a 21-year-old law student and aspiring musician, the key to balance is simple: dissolve yourself in the process so the rest will come naturally.
"The moment that you think of it as a separate thing from your life, I think that's when you realize that you do not inherently have it," she said.
Kim, as she is fondly called by people around her, has inspired a lot and amazed many with her achievements in life.
She has aced academics and is now making ways to progress as a musician.
She was greatly influenced by her musically inclined family.
She recalls as a child that her father would convince her to sing for him while he plays the guitar.

"Pero naging interest ko is not entirely singing, I wanted to learn how to hold the guitar; gusto ko matuto paano tumugtog ," she said.
She graduated as top 6 in Magugpo Pilot Imelda Elementary School.
"I'll never forget that kasi wala akong part sa graduation yung top 5 lang meron ," she said.
Her interest in scouting grew when she was assigned as camp director of the senior camp and was chosen as the most outstanding girl scout of Davao del Norte in 2010 in fourth year high school.

She was champion in the First Communication Arts Festival - held in Manila on the same year.
This time, she graduated top of the class at St.
Mary's College of Tagum.
 
"Even in college, I still did scouting.
They asked me to represent Davao for a climate change forum in Manila," she said.

She went to the event and came back to Davao as an environmentalist, which was a huge factor on making her way to law school.
She was very dedicated on her advocacy to protect the environment, her thesis was entitled: "The role of democracy in environmental policy making".
It is centered on democracy in policy making.

It was also during college that her love for music has resurfaced because of the many opportunities laid for musicians to showcase their talents during University activities.
"It was my drummer boyfriend who really wanted to join in Awitenista and Musikahan ," she recalled.

Part of the rules of these events is to submit an original composition.
Kim's first entry, entitled "Home" was a contemporary song about love, which she wrote from her boyfriend's perspective.
Another song, "Black and Blue" is about being beaten up by the circumstances of being loved.
The song says, "Your love is raw, it does not pretend.
It may have hurt, at least I know it's true".
She explained "When there is pain in the relationship, it only goes to show that there are no pretenses that are happening." 
Her songs can be purchased in the Kalasag Office of Ateneo de Davao University.
Today, she is planning on releasing an extended play, which will be independently recorded and reproduced.

She has new additions on her play, one of which is called, "Happy Tears".
It is inspired by "friends who are stuck in the mud", the sad and depressed ones.

The purpose of the song is to tell people that it is alright to cry but also they must not let themselves get stuck on being sad.
There is always a time to cry happy tears.

The thought was beautifully encrypted in the lines, "Little tiny trembling heart, push the bottles to the side and start; Living with eyes open, life is just waiting to happen".

Right now, she is concentrating on her music but never releases for her goal to become a lawyer to gain more means in promoting for the preservation of the environment.

"The game-changer is politics.
I'm trying to be a lawyer for that," she said.
Kim added that becoming a lawyer is not the end-goal of her career but to be a part of a team who offers change to the world-a team who is capable of giving positive change.
Kim, now 21 and satisfied, shares how to stay focused even if others come your way, "I tell myself that I am strong, intelligent, and beautiful.
In the long run, if you keep on telling that to yourself, you will become one."Christine Joice C.

Man who studied Cecil the lion for 9 years talks impact , Man who studied Cecil the lion for 9 years talks impact 
In this undated photo provided by the Wildlife Conservation Research Unit, Cecil the lion rests in Hwange National Park, in Hwange, Zimbabwe.
Two Zimbabweans arrested for illegally hunting a lion appeared in court Wednesday, July 29, 2015.
The head of Zimbabwe2019s safari association said the killing was unethical and that it couldn2019t even be classified as a hunt, since the lion killed by an American dentist was lured into the kill zone.

JOHANNESBURG 2014 When Cecil the lion's carcass was finally found after he was lured out of a Zimbabwe wildlife reserve to be killed by an American hunter, it was a headless, skinless skeleton the vultures had been picking at for about a week.
Conservationists decided the most natural thing was to leave the bones where they were for hyenas to finish off, said Brent Stapelkamp, a lion researcher and part of a team that had tracked and studied Cecil for nine years.
Stapelkamp darted Cecil and put his last GPS collar on in October.
He was probably the last person to get up close before Minnesota dentist Walter Palmer used a bow and a gun to kill the now-famous lion with the bushy black mane, its head and skin eventually cut off as trophies.
Stapelkamp had first alerted authorities that something might be wrong after Cecil's GPS collar stopped sending a signal.
The killing of the big cat in early July has unleashed global outrage, sending Palmer into hiding back home in suburban Minneapolis, leading to the arrest of the local hunter he employed, and prompting Zimbabwe's environment minister to say the southern African country would seek Palmer's extradition to face charges.
Stapelkamp shares the anger, not just because of the demise of Cecil.
Also because, he said, it's not the first time a lion has been killed illegally around Hwange National Park in northwestern Zimbabwe, a reserve known for its rich wildlife.
About a dozen lions in the region were killed illegally in recent years, Stapelkamp said, and no one was caught.
"I think this was just the final straw," Stapelkamp told The Associated Press in a phone interview from the Hwange reserve.
"Everyone locally just thought, no ways, we're not letting anyone get away with this anymore."
Cecil had an intriguing story, making him a celebrity in Hwange.
He arrived as a kind of lion refugee, alone and wandering after being displaced from another territory.
Cecil befriended another male lion, Jericho, and together they grew and watched over two prides, one with three lionesses and seven cubs and another with three lionesses.
Cecil's killing will have an impact on the area, explained Stapelkamp, a field researcher for an Oxford University study on lions.
Jericho may not be able to hold their territory alone and could be chased away by rival lions.
Unprotected, the lionesses and cubs would then be under threat and also move away or be killed.
Safari operators who invested millions of dollars in the area would lose one of their biggest attractions for tourists.
"They're burning fire breaks.
They're grading roads.
They're pumping water," Stapelkamp said.
"They're spending a lot of money in the management of lions and then someone just draws it across the railway lines having not paid a penny in its management and shoots it and runs away with its skin.
It's unacceptable."
Stapelkamp, unsure of the details of Cecil's killing, described the usual tactics of hunters to draw an animal onto private land and out of the park where it is protected.
The two areas are separated by a railway line.
Hunters shoot a zebra or giraffe and hang it on a tree; the main bait.
They then drag the intestines of that animal, "something that really smells," Stapelkamp said, up and down the park boundary behind a vehicle.
Sometimes they'll even play the sounds of a dying buffalo over a loudspeaker to attract a lion.
The lion "comes across that scent trail and it leads him straight to this bait," Stapelkamp said.
"It rushes in for a free meal and they're waiting ...
and they kill him like that."
Even on private land, this hunt was still illegal, Stapelkamp said, because no hunting quotas for lions were issued in the region this year.
Legal hunts do happen, he said, but only after authorities consult with ecologists and decide that it won't adversely affect the area.
This didn't happen with Cecil, Stapelkamp said, and he doesn't believe Palmer's story that he trusted his professional guide to ensure a legal hunt.
"He's a well-educated man, he's got a lot of resources," Stapelkamp said.
"You could do your homework.
Due diligence.
You would know that you're hunting in a controversial area.
You've got a GPS you could have in your pocket and you have a look at the map, and you say, 'listen, friend, I think we're in the wrong area.' There's no excuse."
Palmer came "with the intention of getting the biggest lion that he could and getting out.
And he got caught," Stapelkamp said.
