Small town takes on big mines, Small town takes on big mines
DAVAO.
With officers and members of of Nagkahiusang Mananagat para sa Kalambuan sa Ayoke.

Stella A.
Estremera, RED bald mountains loom over the green stretch of the coastal town of Cantilan, Surigao del Sur, the last town in the ore-rich region of Caraga to resist the encroachment of giant mining companies.

The people, however, are not just fighting mining through mass mobilizations and campaigns, they are offering an alternative that can bring in the money to more people: tourism.
On an outrigger boat toward Ayoke island, a sitio of Barangay General of the more 233 years old settlement, you catch glimpses of the barges and ships loaded with mounds of red soil that dwarf the backhoes that shovel the soil in.
No wonder the bald expanse of red mountains in the background looked angry...
But it's not just the mountains that are angry...
"People have barricaded the road made by Marcventures Mining and Development Corporation MMDC in barangay Cagangahan toward the neighboring town of Carrascal," said Emma Hotchkiss, president of Baywatch Inc., the organization rallying the people of Cantilan against mining.
Carrascal hosts the biggest mining operations in the province of Surigao del Sur and has mountains upon mountains traversed by hundreds of heavy equipment kicking thick clouds of red dust that reach the island group of Barangay General.
Hotchkiss was referring to the barricade set up in April 2013 that forced Marcventures to stop its incursion in Cantilan territory.
The Municipal Government of Cantilan has been waging a legal battle against Marcventures after it started mining operations in Barangay Cabangahan, through what town officials claim is a cancelled mining production sharing agreement  from another company, the Ventura Timber Corporation.
Marcventures has been insisting that its operation is aboveboard.
In May 2011, continuous rain unleashed floodwaters thick with silt that covered the rice fields with a mass of thick red mud.
The mud killed the rice plants and rendered the rice fields infertile until the residues were washed away for several planting seasons.
The fields became too acidic for rice to grow.
The greater source of unrest is that the slopes of Barangay Cagangahan are the headwaters of two of its major rivers -- Carac-an and Alamyo -- and irrigation sources.
The floods happened again in 2012, Mayor Genito B.
Guardo said.
"We have 2,200 hectares of rice lands, 1,800 hectares are irrigated.
The 2011 floods destroyed around 80 percent," Guardo added.
Worse, the mountains that nurture the minerals are not just where the headwaters are but also the watershed from where the town gets its drinking water.
"If our waters become polluted, what will happen to us?" Hotchkiss asked.
Voices from the fields
Anamae Fernandez Lico, a mother of four whose husband is an overseas Filipino worker , was supplementing their income through rice farming.
Rice farmers in Cateel observe two planting seasons a year.
For each planting, she spends P15,000, which she can recoup after harvest.
But when the floods came in 2011, the yield from her one-hectare field was just around 11 sacks.
"When the floods came, I could no longer recoup my capital and even until the second cropping I couldn't harvest enough because the floods brought in sand from the river when the dike broke," she said in the vernacular.

She stopped planting for two years and had to make do with what her husband earns for all their family's needs.

Chito Trillanes, spokesperson for the Vicariate of the Carcanmadcarlanpar  and chief of staff of the mayor, said that while the Alamio River regularly breaches its banks when the regular week-long rains in Cantilan would pour this would take hours even days, since the buildup of water is steady.
In the 2012 floods at the time that Marcsventures was operating in the mountains of Cantilan the Alamio overflowed in just 45 minutes.

"The flooding not only came from the minesite but also from the road widening made in their forestland, bringing silt two feet deep," he said.
The soil became very acidic.
The advice from agriculture technologists: increase the nitrogen.
This cost the farmers more, aside from the fact that too much nitrates from soil pollutes water sources.
The siltation also reduced the capabilities of irrigation systems to the point that as much as 450 hectares could no longer be irrigated.
The sad part is that while the people were trying to protect their land from mining, they were being sued for various offenses.
"This is a big blow to the people who are just protecting their livelihood when they are now the ones threatened," Trillanes said.
"All those mountains are our watershed, that is where all mining operations are," Barangay Cabas-an Councilor Agustin Andoy said.
Fr.
Frank Olviz, San Pedro Apostol Parish priest, reminded his people, "Atong kabukiran, tinubdan sa tubig .
No trees, no water, no water, no rice.
Dili dapat ta magduhaduha ."
Fishers, too
Carlos Consigna, vice chairman of Nagkahiusang Managat para sa Kalambuan sa Ayoke  said the northeast monsoon usually triggers flooding but for as long as they can remember, it lasts only up to three weeks.
Since mining started, their waters remain brown for up to two months.
"Silted ang tubig ," he said.
As a result, fishermen need to go farther to fish, as far as Siargao.
They also can't catch octopus that they can readily harvest in knee-high waters because the waters have become so silted they can no longer see where the octopuses are hiding.
"The dust from the mines reach our island during habagat.
The wind turns red," Consigna said in the vernacular.
Using a straight line from the beachfront of Carrascal's cove using Google Earth, Ayoke is around 12 kilometers away.
Nagmakaayo has a marine protected area with a 23-hectare core zone and a 19-hectare buffer zone.
General Island, the main barangay to which Ayoke belongs, also maintains a marine protected with a core zone of 28 hectares and a buffer zone of 19 hectares.
Ayoke is around three kilometers across the sea from General.
The MPA in General is maintained by the Islahanon Andam Magdumala Nan Kinaiyahan , a people's organization.
Islamdunk chair Eustaquio "Jojo" Juralba Jr.
said the waters around them become "kulay kape" during the rainy season.
"It's like a three-in-one coffee mix," he said.

Juralba, who is among those tapped to represent the grassroots aquatic sector in the court-appointed committee to study the environmental situation of Cantilan following a counter-charge of environmental case filed by the Cantilan government, said the initial studies made from samples gathered July 14-23 showed that all the town's rivers are polluted.

The case can drag on; the people meanwhile could go hungry and forced willing to sell anything to whoever lusts for their land.

Nature trips
Cantilan's name said to come from the word Tilang, the local name of giant clams , which used to be abundant in the town's water.
There are still enough remaining, but the mine's tailings and silt can easily kill everything in its path.
For as long as the floodwaters from the denuded mountains are not brought down by the rains, Cantilan's waters are very clear, you can see the seabed from your boat.
On General Island is the Bills' Sanctuary or Inijakan, a sanctuary privately managed by the William K.
Hotchkiss Foundation, Inc.
Foundation executive director Tanya Hotchkiss, Emma's niece, said the endangered Napoleon wrasses, can be seen scooting about at low tide along with some humphead wrasses.
Tanya said the island is also home to rufus hornbills.
Ayoke boasts of surfs that can give Siargao and Lanuza a run for their money, while the mainland has vast stretches of very fine black sand beaches.
Baywatch's Hotchkiss said that only Cantilan has both sunrise and sunset, and this can be experienced on Ayoke.
These, aside from the fact that this tiny town has already produced five generals of high ranks including the 24th and now retired Commanding General of the Philippine Air Force Lieutenant General William K.
Hotchkiss, who is current Director General of the Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines; and the newly installed Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces of the Philippines, Lt.
Gen.
Hernando Delfin Carmelo Arreza Iriberri, who before his appointment last July 10, 2015, was the 56th Commanding General of the Philippine Army.
"They were all raised from rice farming," Emma stressed.
They are drumming up interest in ecotourism to bring in the visitors and make people realize that there is more to be gained from tourism than from mining.

"From the person who produces the food to the souvenir makers, everyone benefits," Emma said.
They are inviting friends to come over and are earning some space in the media for their largely undiscovered destinations, and are encouraging organic farming to serve as food destinations, as well.
It's a race against time.
A look at the Mines and Geosciences Bureau website shows that there are 43 existing mining production sharing agreements in Surigao del Sur and Surigao del Norte, out of the total of 338 MPSAs all over the Philippines.
The agreements cover 3.91-million hectares, most of them for chromite, gold, copper, silica, and nickel.
More than half of the total area of the two provinces.
The two provinces have a total land area of 6.906-million hectares.
Cantilan has a total area of 240,100 hectares.
The two provinces also have four of the 30 existing exploration permits.

In the Ateneo de Manila University School of Government Policy Brief on Mining in the Philippines entitled "Is there a Future for Mining in the Philippines?" released in October 2012, it reads:
"According to the Mines and Geosciences Bureau , the mining  sector's contribution to national total employment has always been below 1 percent .
Recent data has shown that it has been 0.5% since 2008 until 2010.
So far, for the first half of 2011, contribution has been reported as 0.6% .
All over the world, extractive mining is known as a low-employment generating activity.
The Tampakan project, with expected investments of $5.9 billion, will provide only 2,000 permanent jobs."
In Surigao del Sur and del Norte, the only town putting up a fight against mining is Cantilan.
In the meantime, the 2016 elections loom.
Will the people decide for those who are for the sustainable or will the mining companies win the people over?

Teacher on the streets, Teacher on the streetsRhealyn C.
Pojas, IF YOU search for her name on Google, you will be bombarded with her web images holding a microphone with a group of protesters at the backdrop raising big posters with markings in bold letters or find her name being mentioned every once in a while in different news websites in Davao City.
Her name is Sheena Duazo, 29 years old, the spokesperson of Bagong Alyansang Makabayan  in Southern Mindanao.
She could have been a teacher or a scientist like what she dreamed of as a child, but she has chosen another path which she herself never anticipated.
But indeed, she has become a teacher, not inside a classroom, but on the streets.
Duazo shared in an interview with Sun.Star that it never occurred to her that she will become a member of a militant group.
As a child, she said she wanted to be a scientist or a teacher.
She said she likes teaching children when she was just a kid that is why when she enrolled at Ateneo de Davao University , she took up a degree in Education, major in English.
Before that, she spent her elementary and high school years at Assumption College.

She was born on August 14, 1986 to Teresita and Eufenio Duazo, being the youngest among the two offspring.
Bravely speaking before the crowd while rallying in front of government offices, one could only wonder whether what could have pushed her to become what she is right now.
It was in 2005 when Sheena entered AdDU but she said that way back then, she did not care about social issues the way she cares about it now.
She shared that when she was in first year college, some friends from different organizations based in their school would invite her to join discussions, forum, and the like but at first she would refused.

But reality strikes her when she became a writer of the Atenews, the official university publication of AdDU which is a member of the College Editor2019s Guild of the Philippines .

The CEGP would conduct activities such as writer's trip where she had been exposed to various socia issues.
She had also once become a member of the League of Filipino Students , the first organization she joined in college.

During her third year at ADDU, her path had totally shifted, and it was a turning point in her life.
She had finally decided to leave school and become a full time activist/member of Anakbayan, another militant group.
She expressed in the interview that a lot of her classmates and even her family were against the idea.
"Sayangan daw sila sa ako," Sheena narrated.
She had just parted ways from her colleagues in school by saying not to worry about her because she is alright with what she had chosen.
Her decision to be a full time activist also did not skip her family's anger.
She said that there were times where she had been at odds with her family regarding her decision and those where the times where she left home.
But now her family and she are already in good terms.
She said that her family had eventually understood the path that she had chosen and the cause she is fighting for.
"Ang pag-ulsad sa sistema dili lang sa atong nasod kundi sa uban pud ," Sheena said.
"To reverse the pyramid where only 1 percent of our population, the capitalist and the bourgeois, are favored and enjoying the privileges," She added in the vernacular.
Being a militant, Duazo had already faced three charges and even received threats due to what she is fighting.
But she said that nothing can stop her from what she believes which is worth fighting for.

At present, Sheena is still working as a full-time activist with a militant group Bayan.
She was one of those who stand with the lumads during the commotion at Haran and continuously fights for the plight of the lumad bakwits and other activities where Bayan is organizing or involved.
 
Beauty Queen with a Purpose, Beauty Queen with a Purpose

Richmond Anthony Alfonso, NEWLY-crowned Queen Universe of the Queen Philippines 2015 pageant held in Cebu on August 1, 2015 Carla Marie Madrigal of Alubijid town in Misamis Oriental is bent to push her gender equality advocacy for the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender  community.
201cI want to push through my advocacy which is gender equality for my brothers and sisters in the LGBT community.201d  
Besting 24 other candidates from all over the country, Carla Marie, born Ben Carl Embradura Galarrita of is the embodiment of poise, beauty, and brains, bringing much pride not only to the LGBT but the entire Misamis Oriental.

Carla Marie is the third of five children born to Benjamin and Jean Galarita.
She grew up in Zone 5 Lanao, Alubijid, Misamis Oriental and is a BS Tourism undergraduate of Liceo de Cagayan University.

At a very early age, she realized that there was something very different about her; she didn2019t like playing with toys made for boys and was more interested with Barbie dolls and playing with girls.
It was not easy growing up, but Carla Marie was luckier compared to others like her because she had a very supportive family.
 
201cThe hardest part of being a transwoman growing up is that you face discrimination in your society.
In my case, I2019m a bit lucky because my family accepted me.
My dad accepted me for who I am because, he said, at a very young age he already saw a potential in me.

Hey, wala naman kaming ginagawang masama.
Why is that? The best thing to do is just to keep silent and be professional.
Just think that you are special, there2019s something in you.
I always keep that in mind.
I always think positive and besides, my parents raised me well.
So I always forgive all of them.201d
She dreamed of becoming a doctor, or an attorney, or even a scientist when she was young but realized after joining numerous pageants that what she really wanted to become was a beauty queen and inspire other people through her advocacies.

She has been joining gay beauty pageants since she was 17 years old just after she had to stop going to school.
For the young 520199 stunner, it was all about the fame and cash prizes in the beginning but slowly came to understand that there is a higher purpose to these pageants.
 
201cI realized that this is not just about the crown.
 I2019m joining because I have a goal, and that it to become an inspiration to everyone.
I have an advocacy that I want to be heard of and I want to promote,201d said Carla Marie in an interview.

201cI want to indulge myself in new things which will benefit me and my people, to be active in LGBT activities, to be fully aware of LGBT rights, involve myself spiritually and morally.
This is not just all about glamour, this also include service, because I am not just here in this pageant to win.
 I2019m here to make a difference.201d
Before competing in the Queen Philippines 2015 Pageant, Carla Marie trained with Kagandahang Flores, the prestigious pageant camp that has produced winners in the international pageantry circuit, for Pasarela or catwalk training and how to act like a beauty queen.
 
To maintain her 36-26-38 figure, she exercises regularly and makes sure that she has a healthy diet.
 
201cSometimes to get what we want the most, we have to do what we want the least and that includes the sacrifices I have made in joining this pageant.

Bringing BBL to non-BBL land  , Bringing BBL to non-BBL land

Estremera, MINDANAOANS get a glimpse of it every time Bangamoro and peace in Mindanao becomes the topic 2013 people outside Mindanao love to cast judgment but are basing these judgments on the life-long prejudices they were fed by an equally prejudiced environment starting from the family, and then the school.

This was very apparent in the gathering of Cordilleran student leaders to tackle the Bangsamoro Basic Law  held at the Ating Tahanan of the Girl Scouts of the Philippines  last Friday in Baguio City.
Initiated by the Kaya Natin Movement for Good Governance and Ethical Leadership and the ForumZFD-Civil Peace Service, a German non-government organization working on peace concerns in Mindanao, the forum gathered some 40 college students from various state and private colleges and universities in the Cordillera Administration Region  to learn from and interact with young Moro leaders.

201cIt is similar to what Al Qalam Institute is doing in Mindanao for the last three years of Youth Peace Camps.
Our main objective is to educate our youth about the history of Mindanao and the Bangsamoro people,201d said Mussolini Sinsuat Lidasan, executive director of the Ateneo de Davao University based Al Qalam Institute for Islamic Identities and Dialogue in Southeast Asia, who was among the speakers in the forum.

Lidasan tackled 201cUnderstanding the BBL as a result of the Bangsamoro Peace Process201d.
From the responses of the student-participants on how they feel about the BBL and the peace process, what they understand and not understand about the BBL and the peace process, what is clear is that there is very little understanding, but that there is a willingness to understand.

201cThe whole law is unclear as to its position in answering the call for justice for the people who have lost their lives in bringing about peace in Mindanao,201d one of the participants wrote.
201cThe peace process is certainly not working, not for the people in Mindanao and not for the Philippines.201d 
201cIt is clear to me that the reason why they are pushing this is because they want peace in Mindanao.
But I still have the question in mind, is it the only thing that they want? Or is the issue on peace just being used to advocate simply their real motive,201d wrote another.
 
With the morning and afternoon session tackling the issues of BBL and the Moro conflict, the students were more accepting of what the Moro people are asking for, with the various resource speakers shedding light and sharing experiences on how it is to live in a land of conflict.
There is little they know of Mindanao, in the first place.

201cNoong elementary, ang tinuturo lang tungkol sa Mindanao na yung mga tao doon, barbaric sila,201d said Maureen P.
Pulido, a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science student of Saint Louis University in Baguio City said in an interview when asked what she recalls of Mindanao in their Araling Panlipunan in school.
 
201cIn school, we were made to believe that doon lang tayo naging civilized pagdating ni Magellan, we were never taught about the kingdoms in Mindanao and how advanced they were there long before the Spaniards came,201d said Kenneth R.
Fabia, a Bachelor of Arts in Legal Studies also of Saint Louis University.
Pulido hails from La Union and is just in Baguio to pursue her studies, while Fabia was born and raised in Baguio.

201cI only know of BBL on the surface level lang, that the Autnomous Region for Muslim Mindanao  will be replaced by the Bangsamoro and that this will be like a parliamentary system,201d Fabia said.

While Pulido said, 201cAng pagkilala ko sa Bangsamoro is that with Bangsamoro, Mindanao will separate from Luzon and Visayas as a substate or in a Federal system.201d It is this lack of knowledge that these peace camps are trying to address, Lidasan said.

201cOur main objective is to educate our youth about the history of Mindanao and the Bangsamoro people.
We re-designed the program in order to reach the youth from the northern part of country,201d he added.
 
It is of note that most combatants of the government, whether they are special forces of the PNP or foot soldiers of the Armed Forces of the Philippines come from the Cordilleras.

Driven by poverty and the dream for a better life, these men join the service and are sent to parts they are not familiar with, including those among the Mamapsano2019s ill-fated SAF44.
201cThey  sent soldiers mostly from the North to fight the rebellion in the Muslim South.
Why? ....
both are victims of oppression, structural violence..
and both wants autonomy...201d Lidasan wrote as a status update in his Facebook page earlier.
Rep.
Teddy B.
Baguilat of the lone district of Ifugao shared during one of the sessions that tackled hearing and the peace process, specifically after the Mamasapano incident.

Baguilat2019s brother Capt.

Yung question niya , if you were there what will you do? Parang hindi ko kaya.201d

Five new education supervisors together with Deped Regional Director Alberto T.

Melanie Ple\xf1os Estacio is second from left.
Maria Gemima C.
Valderrama, MELANIE Ple\xf1os Estacio recently transferred to the Department of Education Regional Office with the same position as education program supervisor but with greater responsibilities.
While in DepEd Davao City division, Melanie developed modules in Multiple Intelligences in Teaching English and Arts used by English teachers in Davao City.
 
Aside from that, she chaired the group that developed Assessment Modules which were used by two other regions 2013 Armm and Soccksargen.
Melanie shared that she always wanted to become a nurse but her mother who was an elementary teacher then convinced her to follow her footsteps.
 
So right after graduating Bachelor of Secondary Education at Holy Cross College of Davao in 1992, Melanie began her teaching career at Stella Maris Academy of Davao  as an English teacher.
She stayed in SMAD for six years and made teaching her vocation until she decided to move to public school.
 
In 1999, she started teaching at Sta.
Ana National High School.
She was an English teacher, a class adviser, and School English Coordinator.
From 2005 to 2009, Melanie became the Regional Student Assessment Officer of the Basic Education Assistance in Mindanao, a project geared towards the improvement of the quality of and access to basic education in Central Mindanao.
 
In 2007, Melanie was promoted as education program supervisor in DepEd Davao City division.
  
She obtained her Doctor of Philosophy Major in Educational Leadership at the University of Immaculate Conception in April 2015.
She finished her Master of Arts in Teaching with Specialization in English Language Arts at the Philippine Normal University in 2002.
  
For short courses, Melanie had her E-Learning Graduate Course in English as a Foreign Language in Indiana University2019s School of Education, a scholarship sponsored by the Embassy of the United States of America.
  
For two weeks, she attended the Summer Institute for English Language Educators in 2009 sponsored by the US Department of State, Hawaii Pacific University in Hawaii, USA.
 
She also went to Melbourne, Australia for the Assessment Fellowship Training Australian Council for Educational Research in 2006.
Melanie is one among the DepEd Davao Region officials who passed the Career Executive Service Board  Assessment Center.
 
Along with Melanie are four new education supervisors in DepEd Regional Office namely Pedelina O.
Huevos, Maria Cielo D.
Estrada, Maria Liza I.
Berandoy, and George N.
Wong.
Melanie is married to Jessie, a mechanical engineer of Hitachi based in Tokyo, Japan.
  
Although they only get to be together every six months, the couple made sure the children grow with wit and conviction.
Their two children, Justin Matthew and Jerald Martin, are consistent honor students in Ateneo de Davao University grade school department.
Sanitation is key, Sanitation is keyKarina V.
Canedo, DAVAO City Health's office sanitation division Chief Robert "Bobet" Oconer is known to be firm and strong leader such that he earned monickers like "Messenger of Death" and "Berdugo ng City Health Office ".
One mediaman even said, "Pag naa si Oconer, naa ju'y makulban ug kaldero ."
While many may think this is negative, this is actually a peek into his straightforward ways.
Oconer earned quite a reputation in his irrefutable good performance as a chief of the division which the primary concern is the safety of our food and environment.
Oconer is a sanitary inspector for 25 years already and still counting.
As a chief, Oconer brought changes in the landscape of sanitary health especially in Davao city.
It was Oconer who called official attention on sexual acts done by masseuse at the once dark and neglected Osme\xf1a Park.
Now the park has been renovated, is properly lighted and has CCTV cameras and security guards.
He has been tough against illegal vendors selling food along sidewalks, establishments found violating the sanitary code, and livestock farms that endanger people's health.
Just last few months ago, he led the closure of 19 maternity clinics which did not pass the sanitary code.
His job is not that easy, he says, he even had death threats.
"Marami yung mga threats sa akin pero sabi ko nga kung matatakot ako sino pa ang mag-iimplement ng batas," Oconer said.
He said that he would sometimes feel guilt for those whose stores he has ordered close, but he has a job to do.

"Iniiyakan ko lang pag nagpapasara kami ng mga one hundred plus, two hundred plus employees ang nawalan ng trabaho, at nagpapademolish ako ng vendors na alam kong yun lang ang bread and butter nila, pero wala akong magawa e yun yun.
I get over it by thinking that I am serving Davao city well, yun ang iniisip ko kaya nakakaget-over ako sa guilt ko.
I have this mindset that, we are paid to make people's lives better," he said.
"Gusto ng tao paggising niya ay mabango yung hangin na inaamoy niya,  hindi yung amoy piggery or septic tank, gusto ng tao na makatulog ng maayos wala yung ingay ng videoke shop.
Implementers po kasi kami, we implement law kami ang sinasandalan ng mga tao pag may complaint tatakbo sila sa amin," Oconer added.
A product of a broken family Oconer said that who he is now is because of his mom who raised him and his brother by herself after his father left them.
"She's one of my idol, nakayanan niya yun, my mother was very strict, she is raised a very devoted Catholic.
Typical na parang Spaniard ang nanay ko konting pagkakamali, konting pagkakamali, babalutin ka ng palo, with that kind of discipline we were raised by my mom well, hindi kami naligaw ng landas considering 80 percent ng broken family naligaw ang landas," Oconer said.
He did not see his father for a couple of years.
His parents separated when he was in grade 2.

Oconer himself is a happily married for 31 years and has three sons.
His wife Rosario Oconer is a Dean of San Pedro College.
His three sons are graduates of Information Technology, Nursing, and Business Management.
"My wife is very understanding to me, especially in my work, because my job requires no specific time, tatawagan ka kung may nahuling ganito...
septic tank, merong food poisoning...
Sunday kailangan ka, nandyan ka kung merong calamity.
One time may bumaha at birthday ng anak ko December 18 two years ago, I formed my team, sabi ko wala akong magawa, baha sa Davao city noon," Oconer said.
He said his sons are like friends, and drinking buddies, and they tell him his problems.
He also said that he also disciplined his sons well and none of them have gone astray.
Right now he handles 24 sanitary inspectors and it's been quite a tough job since some of them are older than him.

"I have 24 sanitary inspectors who are hard headed believe me, before it looks like it's hard for them to accept me as chief.
I am quite young compared to those who've been inspectors for 30 years or 40 years even, those senior sanitary inspectors, the oldest served for 44 years, it's hard for them to accept me.
I told them give me half of your quality time para sa katawhan, masaya na ako doon." Oconer said.
Under Oconer's stewardship this August 20 next week their office will be receiving the Best Sanitary Division Award at Royal Mandaya Hotel, which is the first time for the Department of Health to give such award.
Oconer himself won two best sanitary inspector awards in a row.
But he's not content and gives himself just 80% rating.
He also looks forward to the 20 more sanitary inspectors promised by Mayor Rodrigo Duterte.
Oconer was born on May 25, 1965.
His father who used to be a manager of what once was Sarmiento, now Tefasco, and his mother used to be a government employee at city economics office.
He is the eldest in many ways: the eldest son, the eldest nephew and the eldest cousin in the family.
He has one brother now working as a supervisor at Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation .
Oconer is a graduate of Bachelor of Science in Biology at Davao Doctors College and Zoology at the University of Perpetual Help Rizal, Las Pi\xf1as City, Metro Manila.

He chose biology because his family wanted him to be a doctor or a dentist and proceeded with zoology because during that time he aimed to work in Saudi Arabia where fisheries is a major industry.

He did work in Saudi for three years but not as a zoologist but as an assistant maintenance supervisor without the slightest idea on pipes and the swimming pools.

He got hired there with his aunt and uncle's help, it was the time of the first Gulf War.
He also worked at hotel Nikko in Makati as a supervisor, but little did he expect that his next job would be something that changed the course of his life forever.
"After doon  dito  na.
Pinasok ako ng mother ko.
At first I was hesitant kasi government maliit ang sweldo, but eventually nagustuhan ko naman din kasi pagkapasok ako sanitary inspector agad ako.
Up to now.
I have been a chief for five years now," Oconer said.

More than able, More than able
DAVAO.
Danilo Roman flashes his gold medal as he poses with his parents Danilo and Julieta.

Ruji Peter S.
Abat, WILLPOWER, the passion for the sport and having surrounded by supportive family and peers was enough for Danilo Roman, a swimmer with intellectual disability, to reach the pinnacle of special athletes, as he went home with two gold medals in the swimming event of the 2015 Special Olympics World Games held recently in Los Angeles, California.
A Nicaraguan who found a home in Davao City topped the M8 200-meter freestyle and the M6 division 100-meter breaststroke events while adding a bronze medal in the M4 100-meter butterfly.
Danilo's mother Julieta, who is the president of the Special Olympics Davao Chapter, told Sun.Star Davao: "We are extremely grateful to Philippines, with our current home city, Davao, and especially thankful to Special Olympics Philippines for giving Danilo the opportunity to make his dream come true."
But she said Danilo's gold medal performance was a hard road as it took him 10 years to fulfill his dream.
Danilo, now 33, took a dip in the pool and started training at the age of 23 when he developed fondness for swimming.
"Swimming requires devotion, sacrifices and hours and hours of training to be able to master the techniques of each style and to become a better swimmer every day.
Danilo is a very disciplined and responsible person and this helped him with the rigorous process of 2 1/2 hours of training per day including weekends," Julieta said.
His passion for the sport grew until he became part of the Ladislawa Village swimming team and later the Monteritz.
Under the tutelage of coaches Edgardo Lora and Carlos Rodriguez, Danilo managed to learn the different swimming strokes.
Training Danilo, however, also posed a challenge for the coaches due to the language barrier since Danilo spoke Spanish.
Yet the patience of his coaches and Danilo's determination to become a better swimmer paid off, as he learned to speak English and it became easier for the coaches to train him.
His very supportive teammates also inspired him to excel in the sport.
"Me and the coaches always train Danilo the same as a regular swimmer.
No special treatment.
This is what we call inclusion in the society.
For the coaches, it will take more time with Danilo to train him, but there is no difference when we are in the pool," Julieta said.
Year 2013 became the breakout year for Danilo, as he tested his mettle in the Special Olympics Mindanao Games held in Cagayan de Oro City where he was able to dominate the competition.
This ultimately led him to earn the right to represent the country in the Special Olympics.
It also became apparent that his hard work made him one of the world's man to beat, as he blew past his competition in the M8 200-meter freestyle.
He clocked in at three minutes and 59.76 seconds -- way ahead of Costa Rica's silver medalist Luiz Ortiz who finished at 4:21.94 and bronze medalist Maximo Mejia at 6:57.72.
His close call in the M6 division 100-meter breaststroke and his bronze medal finish in the M4 100-meter butterfly, meanwhile, is now another motivation for Danilo, as he poised to win it all the next time around in dominating fashion.
But first, he has to ensure wins when he plunges into action in the 2015 Special Olympics Mindanao Games in Tagum City slated in October.
Danilo then advised his fellow special athletes, "Train very hard, concentrate and in the training you should also enjoy it."
James Infiesto, president of the Philippine Sports Association for the Differently-Abled -Davao, once said that sports is one of the powerful tools that can transcend one's disabilities and in the case of Danilo, he was able to do so but with an ample help from his family, friends and his own tenacity.
Tadeco: Playing a vital role in PH exports, Tadeco: Playing a vital role in PH exportsMAINTAINING high quality products is its utmost concern.
As it continues to play a vital role in the export industry, supplying top brands in the world market, the Tagum Agricultural Development Company, Inc.
 never stopped in coming up with new innovations to ensure freshness and quality of its produce from the farms to the tables of their clients.
The company, in fact, prides itself in using the most advanced technology and research in producing world-class cavendish bananas being exported to the world.
This has been an image attached to the company -- an image that Dabawenyos can always be proud of, considering the fact that Tadeco is a homegrown company being a subsidiary of the Floirendo-owned Anflo Group of Companies.
Last year, Tadeco was cited by a prestigious international award-giving body for its strong corporate social responsibility programs and good and responsible agricultural practices.
A feat that sets it apart from all other agriculture-based companies in the country.
Tadeco joined three other big agricultural companies from various parts of the world -- Kakuzi Limited from Kenya, Tropical Nordeste SA from Brazil, and Standard Fruit de Honduras from Honduras -- to be awarded with the 2014 GlobalG.A.P.
Good Agricultural Practice  award during a ceremony in Abu Dhabi, United Arad Emirates in October, last year.
These companies bested 40 others coming from the United States, Chile, Costa Rica, Ecuador, India, Egypt, Turkey, Japan, South Africa, Peru, Sri Lanka, Argentina, South Korea, France, Romania, China, Israel, New Zealand, United Arab Emirates, and Serbia for demonstrating high standards and excellent implementation of GlobalG.A.P.
principles in farms and production facilities.
The winners were judged based on their responsible water use and programs on increasing biodiversity, social responsibility, and role and involvement of women and youth.
"The award is a recognition of what Tadeco has been doing for a long time," said Reagan D.
Navarro, Tadeco manager for quality manangement systems, statistics and information management, and chemistry laboratory.
He was proud to say that even before such accomplishment, they have already adopted certain measures or practices on responsible use of water.
For instance, the company has been engaged in the recycle and treatment of water used for washing the bananas at the packing plants which was recycled in the same manner.
He said before they started practicing the recycling of water, 150 liters  of water had been used for each box of banana.

"Our water use went down from 150 L/box to 20 to 25 L/per box.
And one packing station can save up to 700 cubic meters  per day," Navarro said.
At present a water treatment system has already been installed at Tadeco's packing stations to continue saving water without compromising the quality of their produce.

In a bid to ensure food safety both in their plantation and production, Navarro said that they have invested in research and "strict biosecurity measures" in order to avoid banana diseases such as the panama disease and fusarium wilt to penetrate their plantation.
"We have a tire dip and foot bath at the entrances of the area in which the disinfectant used was studied by our researchers to really kill such diseases which comes from contaminated soil," he said.
Tadeco Plant Pathology and Tissue Culture department head Dennice G.
Catambacan, said in an earlier interview that they are continuing their researches on how to avoid such banana diseases once it contaminates their soil.

He said they also have a trial site where they are expanding their research.
Tadeco has also invested on the expansion of its research center and acquiring advance research equipment.
In terms of increasing biodiversity, social responsibility, and role and involvement of women and youth, Tadeco developed socio-economic programs to realize this -- the Sagip Kabuhayan, Sagip Kalusugan, Sagip Kaalaman, Sagip Kultura, Sagip Kalamidad, Sagip Kalikasan, Sagip Katuwang-Pamayanan and Sakip Pagpapahalagang Espiritwal.
Sagip Kabuhayan empowers non-working spouses and their dependents, through skills and capability trainings and seminars, enabling them to earn extra income for their family.
This covers the company's commitment to strengthen and empower women whose expertise are focused on pre-market delivery operations by employing them in the meticulous operations which require female abilities and expertise.

The women comprise 60% of the total manpower at the company's packing stations.

Through Sagip Kalusugan, healthy lifestyle among company employees and their families is given focus, promoting a work life balance.

Under its Sagip Kaalaman, Tadeco, in partnership with the AOF Foundation, donated several school buildings, provided school supplies and sponsored and advocated other education-related programs.
The company also grants full college education scholarships to qualified dependents with almost 100 scholars today and provides them employment opportunities after graduation.

Sagip Kalikasan is Tadeco's program commitment to the protection and securing of the environment.
Some activities they do include the Tree Growing Program, Coastal Clean-up Drive, maintaining diversified crops, wetlands, and reservoirs to preserve habitats of other species; usage of vermiculture or vermicomposting as a natural way of growing vegetables and other crops, employment of water-recycling facility in packing stations, and usage of Soil Moisture Balance Method, among others.
 
The lumad kids of Pag-amoma, The lumad kids of Pag-amomaRhealyn C.
Pojas, WHAT started as just a leisure activity led into an unexpected twist of fate for a group of orphaned lumad children who now became recording artists.
Exposure was never in their minds when they sing for fun at their new home at Robillo compound in Calinan, the so-called Pag-amoma Children's Place, where the children found refuge after being orphaned, neglected, or abandoned by their parents while the others belonged to broken families.

Though these children's story may what other people consider as sad or tragic however hope had been there constant companion towards their different journeys in life.

"Kanta-kanta lang ang amo, lingaw-lingaw lang.
Wala mi gahuna-huna og exposure ," said Lisa Templado, executive director of the Pag-amoma and the one who taught the children the proper voicing, the right tempo, blending and other important details relating to singing or music.
The lumad children composed of Manobo, Bagobo, Songkitin, and Ata Manobo tribes started out as Bangaw Chorale.
The word Bangaw means rainbow in English, according to Templado.
It was first established to help uplift the children from the discrimination they experienced through songs or singing.

The ages of the children range from 11 to 17 years old and they had been singing in schools during special occasions or programs and had been invited as guests at GMA2019s regional network in Davao even before they had their first album and had been invited to guest in a studio taping of ABS-CBN.
They had also been invited or recommended to sing or guests in various occasions such as during school programs, birthday celebrations, and church anniversaries.
They had also been able to sing twice in Manila, one of these was their participation for the Katutubo Exchange by the National Commission on Culture and the Arts .
They also performed in some malls in Davao City like the NCCC, SM, and was also able to perform at Pearl Farm.
Shiela Royo, now 16 years old and a Matigsalong Manobo, was one of the lumad children whose voice rings in their first album called the 201cTunog Bubongan.201d Royo, who was then eight years old when she came to the orphanage, recounted that her mother had sent her and her sister to the orphanage after the separation of their parents.
She said that her mother had nothing to raise them and that was the reason why they were sent to the Pag-amoma Children2019s Place.
Royo said that even in the mountains where they lived, they had been into singing since it is part of their culture.
Aside from that, they also do traditional or cultural dance and these happens during fiestas in their place.
Royo was one of the five lumad children who echoed the unheard voices of their fellow children in the mountains through the songs featured in their album.

201cNalipay mi kay pinaagi ana kay naa mi2019y matabangan nga mga lumad ,201d Royo expressed.
The proceeds of the album will be extended as help to the lumad children in the mountains.
The music album featured the songs Salugpongan, Bisan Kami Bata, and Batang Gagmay among others.

According to Executive Director Templado, the first set of the album2019s copies which were composed of about a thousand had already been sold and another batch of copies from the said album had been released just recently.
 
Though the children also dance and play stringed instruments like Bandoria, Octavina, and laod, they had been more known in their singing, Templado said.
As of the present, the children lived at the Pag-amoma Children2019s Home.
Some of them were already in High School while the others are in elementary.
King of Fruits: It's the season once again, King of Fruits: It's the season once againTHE name of this fruit is synonymous to Davao City itself.
Now that it's Kadayawan Festival, it's the season of ubiquitous durian touted as the "king of the fruits" once again.
Unfair it might seem, durian holds an unthinkable popularity for its foul odor; a notoriety that is distinct to only one fruit that grows abundantly on the rich plains of this beguiling city.
To some local tourists though, durian is not for the faint of heart, as it takes a lot of courage to get a taste of its meat that ranges in color from creamy white to yellow.
The pungent smell could be so discouraging, not to mention, unappealing that even the taste buds would refuse for a moment or two to fulfill its task in knowing the flavor before it even gets into the mouth.

But for the same reason as well, many tourists make sure that Davao's gastronomic adventure will not be complete without durian-tasting as part of its itinerary.

It is best done while getting lost on the busy streets at the height of the festival rush downtown.

Although durian stalls abound everywhere, ask the locals where to eat durian nearby.
Best to try each variety to know its different characteristics, from sweet to bittersweet and thick to creamy.

Just a word of caution though: if you have come to love durian, eat slowly, take one bite at a time, and savor its flavor, lest you suffer from high blood, they said.
There are also durian candies such as pastillas and yema to bring some home.
If you never wish to immerse in the festival heat, head north to SM Lanang Premier.
There, the fruit is aplenty at the 3rd Davao Durian Festival, located at the mall's Fountain Court.
The festival was opened last Friday and on-going until September 20, 2015.
To the benefit of the tourists, the Bureau of Plant and Industry  has put in place an exhibit should they want to learn the varieties that the non-picky few delight themselves with.

Among the exhibited varieties are the thornless ones, considered as the black sheep among the durian fruits.
What turned heads though are the durio graveolens, the red-fleshed durian that has a fruity taste while that of the orange-fleshed is a truce between tablea and tiesa.
If you think the city is awash with durian fruits, not yet.
Davao Durian Industry Council president Larry Miculob said bulk of the supply will come next month.

It's no brainer to understand the law of supply and demand, so good news for durian suckers! Expect the prices to go much cheaper in few weeks' time.

The Kadayawan through the years , The Kadayawan through the years Nelson C.
Bagaforo, A SPECTACULAR street dancing, a colorful parade of florally-dressed floats of various shapes and sizes, a food and musical extravaganza -- these are just few of highlights of this year's celebration of Kadayawan sa Dabaw.
Thousands of local and foreign tourists flock Davao City to celebrate with Dabawenyos a fun-filled festival, which depicts Davao's rich cultural heritage.
Its remarkable success in the past made it at par with all other festivals in the country, such as Sinulog in Cebu, Ati-Atihan in Aklan and and Dinagyang in Iloilo.
Kadayawan has been touted as Mindanao's Festival of Festivals.
In fact, it is one among the Philippine festivals being promoted to the world by the Department of Tourism.
Kadayawan, indeed, is an attraction.
What used to be a cultural rite, where ethnic tribes around Mt.
Apo usually gathered during harvest-time to give thanks to their gods especially the all powerful Bathala  for a bountiful harvest, has metamorphosed into the biggest festivbal on the island.
It has transformed into a festival, not only of thanksgiving, but to honor Davao's rich heritage, its past personified by lumads and its people and to promote Davao City as an investment haven where lumads, Christians and Muslims co-exist in harmony.
All these can be witnessed through various activities and events, depicting the city's rich and colorful culture.
The thanksgiving festival was institutionalized in 1986 to unite Dabawenyos after the turbulent Martial Law years.
It was then called 201cApo Duwaling,201d a contraction of the famous icons of the city, namely Mt.
Apo, durian and waling-waling.
Two years later, it was renamed 201cKadayawan sa Dabaw201d to better reflect the merry spirit and indigenous theme of the celebration.
Dayao, the root word of kadayawan, is a Dabawnon meaning good.
Its derivative Madayaw is an all-positive lumad word that connotes happiness, beauty, bounty festivity, and good fortune.
Each year, the festival has grown bigger and more spectacular, marked by street dancing, floral float parade, agro-industrial trade fair, cultural shows and food festival.
A milestone in Kadayawan celebrations is the live coverage of the festivities and beamed live all over the world, giving Davao City a positive exposure and big media mileage.
To be featured live before an international audience is Indak-Indak sa Kadalanan on Saturday and the Floral Float Parade on Sunday.
These two highlight events serve as the main attraction of the festival.
The Floral Float Parade, a colorful parade of florally-dressed floats of various shapes and sizes and adorned with thousands of flowers, fruit and fresh produce in wild abundance, will also be beamed live to world TV audience.
Viewers will surely be amazed by a deluge of flora and fauna in the region, thriving amidst forests and marshes protected by mountains and fertile land.

The Indak-Indak, on the other hand, features various delegation from all over Mindanao competing in the street dancing competition.

Tadeco: Playing a vital role in PH exports, Tadeco: Playing a vital role in PH exportsNelson C.
Bagaforo, MAINTAINING high quality products is its utmost concern.
As it continues to play a vital role in the export industry, supplying top brands in the world market, the Tagum Agricultural Development Company, Inc.
 never stopped in coming up with new innovations to ensure freshness and quality of its produce from the farms to the tables of their clients.
The company, in fact, prides itself in using the most advanced technology and research in producing world-class cavendish bananas being exported to the world.
This has been an image attached to the company -- an image that Dabawenyos can always be proud of, considering the fact that Tadeco is a homegrown company being a subsidiary of the Floirendo-owned Anflo Group of Companies.
Last year, Tadeco was cited by a prestigious international award-giving body for its strong corporate social responsibility programs and good and responsible agricultural practices.
A feat that sets it apart from all other agriculture-based companies in the country.
Tadeco joined three other big agricultural companies from various parts of the world -- Kakuzi Limited from Kenya, Tropical Nordeste SA from Brazil, and Standard Fruit de Honduras from Honduras -- to be awarded with the 2014 GlobalG.A.P.
Good Agricultural Practice  award during a ceremony in Abu Dhabi, United Arad Emirates in October, last year.
These companies bested 40 others coming from the United States, Chile, Costa Rica, Ecuador, India, Egypt, Turkey, Japan, South Africa, Peru, Sri Lanka, Argentina, South Korea, France, Romania, China, Israel, New Zealand, United Arab Emirates, and Serbia for demonstrating high standards and excellent implementation of Global G.A.P.
principles in farms and production facilities.
The winners were judged based on their responsible water use and programs on increasing biodiversity, social responsibility, and role and involvement of women and youth.
"The award is a recognition of what Tadeco has been doing for a long time," said Reagan D.
Navarro, Tadeco manager for quality manangement systems, statistics and information management, and chemistry laboratory.
He was proud to say that even before such accomplishment, they have already adopted certain measures or practices on responsible use of water.
For instance, the company has been engaged in the recycle and treatment of water used for washing the bananas at the packing plants which was recycled in the same manner.
He said before they started practicing the recycling of water, 150 liters  of water had been used for each box of banana.
 
"Our water use went down from 150 L/box to 20 to 25 L/per box.
And one packing station can save up to 700 cubic meters  per day," Navarro said.
At present a water treatment system has already been installed at Tadeco's packing stations to continue saving water without compromising the quality of their produce.

In a bid to ensure food safety both in their plantation and production, Navarro said that they have invested in research and "strict biosecurity measures" in order to avoid banana diseases such as the panama disease and fusarium wilt to penetrate their plantation.
"We have a tire dip and foot bath at the entrances of the area in which the disinfectant used was studied by our researchers to really kill such diseases which comes from contaminated soil," he said.
Tadeco Plant Pathology and Tissue Culture department head Dennice G.
Catambacan, said in an earlier interview that they are continuing their researches on how to avoid such banana diseases once it contaminates their soil.

He said they also have a trial site where they are expanding their research.
Tadeco has also invested on the expansion of its research center and acquiring advance research equipment.
In terms of increasing biodiversity, social responsibility, and role and involvement of women and youth, Tadeco developed socio-economic programs to realize this -- the Sagip Kabuhayan, Sagip Kalusugan, Sagip Kaalaman, Sagip Kultura, Sagip Kalamidad, Sagip Kalikasan, Sagip Katuwang-Pamayanan and Sakip Pagpapahalagang Espiritwal.
Sagip Kabuhayan empowers non-working spouses and their dependents, through skills and capability trainings and seminars, enabling them to earn extra income for their family.
This covers the company's commitment to strengthen and empower women whose expertise are focused on pre-market delivery operations by employing them in the meticulous operations which require female abilities and expertise.

The women comprise 60% of the total manpower at the company's packing stations.

Through Sagip Kalusugan, healthy lifestyle among company employees and their families is given focus, promoting a work life balance.

Under its Sagip Kaalaman, Tadeco, in partnership with the AOF Foundation, donated several school buildings, provided school supplies and sponsored and advocated other education-related programs.
The company also grants full college education scholarships to qualified dependents with almost 100 scholars today and provides them employment opportunities after graduation.

Sagip Kalikasan is Tadeco's program commitment to the protection and securing of the environment.
Some activities they do include the Tree Growing Program, Coastal Clean-up Drive, maintaining diversified crops, wetlands, and reservoirs to preserve habitats of other species; usage of vermiculture or vermicomposting as a natural way of growing vegetables and other crops, employment of water-recycling facility in packing stations, and usage of Soil Moisture Balance Method, among others.

Saberon-Abalayan, ON Friday, August 20, is a special day for Davao City's indigenous peoples  as the 30th Kadayawan sa Dabaw 2nd Lumadnong Dula unfurls at the People's Park.
Some 250 participants from five of the city's 11 tribes - Ata of Paquibato District, Klata of Calinan, Matigsalog from part of Marilog, Tagabawa of Toril and Ovu-Manuvo of Marilog will vie for honors in the one-day P580,000 sportsfest presented by the city government of Davao through the Sports Development Division of the City Mayor's Office .
Datu Rudy Mande of Matigsalog Tribe, during Thursday's Davao Sportswriters Association  Forum at the NCCC Mall Davao Food Cove function hall, said: "Kining Lumadnong Dula mura ni sya'g reunion namo.

There will be rituals in the opening ceremonies where our fellow lumads will showcase the life and culture of our tribes)."
From 20 tribal events, he said that only 12 common ones will be played.

It was on Sept.
13, 2007 that the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the declaration of the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

Depicting lumads' tradition thru songs and dances, Depicting lumads' tradition thru songs and dancesKarina V.
Canedo, MUSIC and dance competitions and performances during this year's 30th  Kadayawan Festival will feature the beauty of culture, arts and tradition of Mindanao's indigenous people.
These much waited competitions once again inspire us to delve on the richness of our culture and tradition.
These are the Tunog Mindanao and Sayaw Mindanao.
The Tunog Mindanao is a yearly musical competition that integrates local instruments with contemporary  or world music.
It is open to all Mindanao based musicians and enthusiasts.
James Zimmerman, one of the organizers of the event, said that what makes the Tunog Mindanao unique is that the songs can be sung in Filipino or other dialects.
 
Major requirements set for each entry is that it should have a clean music, with no distortion and alterations unlike pop or rock music.
 Gadgets or any devices that can change the original sound of the instrument are discouraged as the original sound of the instruments should be retained.
The songs must be also be an original composition which is not played or recorded anywhere else and Indigenous and contemporary instruments can be used.
This year's Tunog Mindanao is unique because it will be the first time that the final performances will be availed by the public live at San Pedro Street.
Meanwhile, Popong Landero, singer and also one of the current organizer of Tunog Mindanao said that the winning pieces and other pieces of the finalists will be archived at the City Tourism2019s office.
Another much awaited competition for the Kadayawan event is the Sayaw Mindanao.
According to Edmund Superada, the chair of the event, Sayaw Mindanao is an indoor Mindanao  dance competition of theatrical and tribal suites of dance and music, depicting Mindanaoan epics, folklores and tradition.
The competition is open for all dance groups of students, out of school youth and community based performers all over Davao.
Sayaw Mindanao is designed to preserve and promote the Mindanao2019s tangible and intangible cultural heritage and to promote Davao city as the center for cultural heritage.

201cIt is a venue and opportunity for you artist to promote culture of Mindanao not only in davao city but entire Mindanao because some of the participants are coming from other provinces.201d Superada said.
Meanwhile another dance showcase that you should set your eyes on is the Lumandnong Bantawan, this is a showcase of  major 11 tribes sa Davao city.
The tribes will have an eight-minute time allotment will showcase their music, dances and other rituals.

Oca Casaysay one of the organizers of the event said that this event is one way of knowing the life and culture of the tribes.
Unique and unrivaled cultural richness, Unique and unrivaled cultural richnessSHOWCASING each tribe's unique and unrivaled cultural richness and preserving traditions and beliefs amid the rapid changes in present day society are no easy tasks.

But having the kind of commitment and willingness to fulfill that role, keeps the future brighter for the next generation of their tribes and for the country as well.
Iranun tribe has recently been recognized as the 11th tribe in Davao City by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts .
The Iranun tribe led by Datu Pamikiren Latip "PJ" P.
A.
Arumpac Jr., as the tribe's deputy mayor, presently inhabits the area bordering Lanao del Sur and Maguindanao, also believed to be the origin of these two ethnic groups.
The Iranun tongue is also strongly believed to be the origin of the language of the Maranao and Maguindanao.
Iranuns are known to be excellent in sea explorations having inhabited near the Sulu Sea, Moro gulf, and Celebes Sea.
For the Matigsalug tribe, although commonly reffered as part of the Manobo tribe, has an estimated 147,000 in population.
The Matigsalug, which means "people living along the Salug River or Davao River, are said to be inhabited in some areas in San Fernando in Bukidnon and Marilog District.
Matigsalug's rich culture are oftenly showed in the bright-colored outfits that they were including their way expressing themselves through songs, dances, poetry, and spiritual expressions.
Meanwhile, the selection of the leader or datu of the Manobo tribe is normally placed on the skilled and socially powerful individual through the alliances and partnership he had garnered.
Production of different crops including rice, corn, legume, yams, and sweet potatoes has been the tribe's source of living, mainly into agriculture culture while being backed up by hunting and other source of food gathering.
The unique characteristic of Maguindanawon tribesmen is their ability to adapt in marshland.
Maguindanawon are more into arts and crafts as they are more specialized in weaving and metalworking which shows their distinct ethnic character.
The Maranaos are still moving from Davao City to the Lanao provinces.
 
They are also noted in the aspect of weaving and metal craft.
But their biggest contribution in the Philippine architecture is the construction of a torogan or their "place for sleeping."
Maranao textiles are also famous for their very ornate designs and colors that reflects the present state of person using it.

The Tausug tribe hails from the extreme southern parts of the Mindanao Island where the religion they practice is Islam.

Tausug tribe still practices the traditional structure where there is a sultanate.
The sultan will be the head of all rans within the sultanate while replacement of the sultan will be based on the election done by his staff but can also be chosen among his bloodline.
Trade is the popular occupation for most of the Tausug members.
Sama tribesmen, on the other hand, uses music as a means to express themselves and their emotions towards another person or to their supreme being.
They use various kind of instruments particularly the agong, gimba, koglong, and among others.
In terms of practicing rituals among the Sama tribe, the balyan performs the ritual dances that are usually performed in different circumstances like dance of happines, dance of sickness, and others.
For the Ovu-Manobo tribe, most of them are circulated in Agusan, Bukidnon, Cotabato, Davao, Misamis Oriental, and Surigao del Sur.
Ovu-Manobo also uses weaponry and jewelries as they believe that all of these possess souls.

Inspiring their own tribe, Inspiring their own tribeKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, IT takes a lot of effort to preserve one's culture -- the tradition, beliefs, and even their very own dialect.
But all 11 beautiful ladies from 11 major ethnic tribes in Davao City who are vying for this year's Hiyas sa Kadayawan title are all determined to do so.
Tausog, Maguindanao, Maranao, Kagan and Sama, Ata, Matigsalug, Klata-Djangan, Tagabawa, Ovu-Manovo, and Iranun tribes are entered in this year's competition whom the equally talented and smart candidates vow to bring honor and prestige to their own tribe.

For Aj Ruth H.
Sumandang, who represents the the Ovu Manubo tribe, said she will make use of the opportunity of this year's event to be an inspiration to her fellow tribesmen for preservation of their rich cultural background of their tribe.
"Isa ka blessing ning Hiyas ng Kadayawan prepared by the City government of Davao.
We can preseve our cultures and traditions by organizing activities that can inform the young generations how rich our culture is.," said Sumandang during the presentation of the candidates recently at the I-Speak Media Forum.
But Sumandang was also quick to add that her tribesmen should not forget their tribes culture amid the trying changes in the development in the society.
"We should not forget to preserve our culture because that who we are and it's our identity.

Myra D.
Calihim, of the Kagan Tribe, said educational awareness is key in the challenge in preserving their culture.
"Educational awareness about our culture.
It's a reminder to all of us that we are now is our greatest debt to our cultures and to our ancestors," Calihim said.
Haifan Rica B.
Bansilan of the Maguindanawon tribe, however, bared that no influences would let them turn their back from the culture they've been used to from the previous years.
"We can preseve our culture by its continuous practice.
Despite being influenced by the new aspects of development particularly by technology, I make it to a point to remember my roots, ancestors, and the tribe that I came from," Bansilan said in the vernacular.
"Ipagmalaki namo ang among tribu and kung asa mi gikan," said Sitti Sara Sakkam of the Tausug tribe.
Michelle D.
Ansal, who takes pride as a member of the Bagobo-Klata tribe, said: "There is a hope to preserve our culture through education as it provide awareness to the people, to the community, and to every child.
Through education we can learn about the culture, religion, and even the traditions of every tribe in Davao City.
"As a teacher in profession, it inspire me to do voluntary work especially in our tribe.
I teach them the language, lifestyle, traits and everything about our tribe and other tribes as well," Ansal added.
Flormea D.
Manyawron of the Ata tribe, also shared that the same sentiments that there is a need for the non-stop practice of their cultures and tradition for them to reminded what they came from.
"In order to preserve culture and tradition, by using the dialect everyday in our family and every households.
Ipadayon namo unsa ang nasugdan sa among mga ancestors before."
Haida Dawn J.
Ainin of the Sama tribe, said her participation in the competition is more centered with her as a role model to her tribesmen.
"I want to be the role model for our tribe so that our cultures and traditions will not be forgetten.
It's our way to appreciate our own tribe by inspiring and enriching them about who we are," Ainin said.
As for Rechel B.
Dumalag of the Matigsalog tribe, she wanted to teach for fellow tribesmen to love their own culture and not be swayed by the advancement of the technology.
"Turuan ko sila na hindi nila ikahiya ang tribe and cultura nila.
Hindi dapat nila ikahiya kung ano sila," Dumalag said.
For Alamaida Casanguan Agasor of the Iranun tribe, she said that her will is to preserve their tribes culture in honor of their ancestors who passed on the traditions to their generation and instead to the same to the next offsprings.

"Hinding-hindi ko po kakalimutan yung mga tradition namin noon na itinuro sa aming ng aming mga ninuno.
Ipagpapatuloy ko po iyon at hindi ko gagaya sa ibang kabataan na naimpluwenyahan ng makabagong technolohiya," Agasor said.
Fatma Jaheema Malatus of the Maranao tribe, also said that they need to preserve their culture for their future generations to be able to experience it.
"Kelangan itong alagaan ang kultura at tradisyon dahil bigay ito ng ating ninuno."
Wenallie Ivy A.
Atan of the Bagobo-Tagabawa tribe, was also quick to answer by saying,:"I want our fellow tribesmen to continue to preserve our cultures and tradition.
We should be passionate in preserving a culture."

Dawaw River: The seat of Davao civilization, Dawaw River: The seat of Davao civilizationChristine Joice C.
Cudis, THE Davao River Festival will once again kick off the celebration of the Indigenous People's Day on August 21, starting at 7 a.m.
at Tionko Soccer Field.
Davao City's 11 tribes -- Ata, Matigsalug, Ovu-Manuvo, Klata Djangan, Tagabawa, Tausog, Maguindanaon, Maranao, Kagan, Sama, and Iranun -- will once again put to life their good olden days with what they called then as Dawow River.
The tribes on board their decorated boats will parade from Bankerohan river bank to Tionko field with festive music and graceful movements by each ethnic groups.
It is staged to honor the days of the past when the river played a huge part in building the civilization of Davao.
It was the center of trade and commerce of both the locals and foreigners.
It was the main source of life and livelihood of the city's first settlers.
Davao Dragonboat Association and Davao Jetski Association will also grace the ceremony, showcasing their skills in the surface.
The event will be assisted by the 911, Task force Davao, Philippine maritime, abd Philippine navy to secure the safety of the participants.
After the fluvial parade will be the convergence of all the tribes.
There will be a wonderful presentation of their dances and rituals.
Arts, artifacts, and products of the tribes will also be featured on the course of the event.
During lunch time, there will be an ambahan of foods.
The tribesmen will bring their special delicacy and share it with one another.
Contingents will proceed to the Lumadnong Bantawan which is a musical contest for local artists, then the Hiyas ng Davao will follow.

Davao's very own fruits and flowers, Davao's very own fruits and flowersDURIAN, mangosteen, rambutan, marang and waling-waling -- where do these fruits and flowers come from? The answer is Davao City.
Its abundance, in fact, has made Davao as the fruit basket and the promising garden in the country.
Davao is known for its flowers and fruits which can only be found and grown in the city.
Let's take for instance the two famous fruit and flower which are distinctively Davao, durian as the "King of all fruits" and waling-waling as the "second national flower."
This 30th Kadayawan sa Dabaw Fstival, fruits and flower will take center stage again as major and minor events during the celebration will highlight the diverse and bountiful natural resources of the city.
Pamulak sa Kadalanan, Durian Festival, Farm and Agro Trade Fair are just some of the events which will highlight Davao's fresh fruits and blooming exotic flowers.
Fruits of Kadayawan
This year2019s Durian festival which is spearheaded by the Durian Industry Council of Davao City  will feature the nine agricultural districts in the city to showcase its native and hybrid durians at the SM Lanang Premiere from August 14 to September 20, 2015.
201cWhen we say Durian, nothing comes in mind but Davao alone.
Durian can be enjoyed by so many ways, from fresh whole Durian fruit to processed fruit products, fruit-based products and food and beverage services,201d Larry Miculob, president of DICDC said.
Also one of the leading homegrown durian products makers, Apo ni Lola, has expanded its product lines from only durian candies to various delicacies like yema, jam, sandwich spread, pie , among others.
201cThere so much to do in Durian, that is something we can be proud of, in fact we will be launching our new 201cdurian coffee201d this year, it is a coffee with a real processed durian meat in it,201d Imee Anabesa, operations supervisor shared adding that the 201cDurian candy food poisoning issue did not affect their business since their brand is already trusted by the buying public and the issue is just an isolated case.
Other fruits such as mangosteen, rambutan, marang are among the most-wanted fruits during the festival.
Flowers of Kadayawan
Pamulak sa Kadalanan, the Kadayawan2019s way of showcasing the various beautiful plants and flowers in the city, but the one that would stand out if we talk about Davao2019s flowers is the famous Waling-waling.
Victoria Jimenez of the Mindanao Floriculture and Ecological Development  said that as a player in the floriculture industry, she advocates to promote the Davao2019s very own flower, the Waling-waling.
201cActually one of my advocacies is to promote our Waling-waling, It would be ideal if all of the household here in Davao would plant and grow his/her own Waling-waling, through this we take part in promoting our very own flower,201d she expressed.
Also this year2019s Farm and Garden Agro Trade Fair offers and highlights a wide array of plants and flowers varieties.
The around 150 exhibitors features flowers and plants like orchids, cacti, bonsai, herbs, succulents, hanging plants, among others.
For this year, in its 20th anniversary, the Sun.Star Davao geared up to participate this year2019s  Kadayawan Pamulak sa Kadalanan.

Masbad: NASA on Tumblr or is it Tumblr on NASA?, Masbad: NASA on Tumblr or is it Tumblr on NASA?Roark L.

Whatever it is, this has got to be the best mix of news coming from two big things that I have daily dealings with - technology and social media.
Sadly though, I2019m not on Tumblr.
Facebook, Twitter and Instagram are too much already for my brain cells.

Tumblr.

This, to me, is an awesome example of marrying an organization2019s thrusts and reaching out to more people through social media.

Going back.

Better still: 1.) make sure you get notifications on Facebook whenever they post something; and 2.) follow them on Instagram.

Reclaiming identity, Reclaiming identityChristine Joice C.
Cudis, THERE is almost no trace of the indigenous peoples in our lives.
Among themselves, their heritage, their practices, and their garments are slowly fading to modernity.

Is this because of the progressive lifestyle? Is the advancement of the world really the one that is killing them?
On a trip to South Cotabato, you can meet the exceptional tribe of the Blaans, the first settlers of Koronadal's lower valley.
It is ironic to see them struggling to exist in a community they used to own and suffering discrimination from people who do not understand the roots of their culture.
Educator Senyorita Monday Tony shares her sentiments as a young Blaan student being discriminated.
"Kapag may pangit na bata, kahit hindi namin siya ka-tribo, sinasabihan ng ibang tao na 'hoy para kang Blaan.' Kapag maingay, 'hoy para kayong mga Blaan!'" she says.
She admits that circumstances like this result in lower self-esteem and thus, lower productivity of the Blaan people.
Some of the people around them insult and look down on them for the way they dress and talk.
In fact, the new generation of Blaans sees acculturation as a way to escape this kind of treatment.
"Yung ilang kabataan sa amin, iniisip nila na mabuti pa mag Bisaya na lang para walang diskriminsayon, para hindi laitin," Tony says.
But being the thinking people that they are, they resist abuse and embrace possibilities of better living.
They demand education for their children.

"Yung dati sa Department of Education na books, we cannot find the story about our tribe, we should have our own story published there.
This way the children will never forget who we are," she says.
They have the Department Order 62, series of 2011 from DepEd that mandates a culture responsive education for the indigenous people.
Windy Rose Bansil, 13 years old, 7th grader, says she takes pride in her tribe.

Although young, she has the spirit of maturity with regards her siblings and her people.
She treks nine kilometers everyday just to reach school.
When asked about what kind of profession she wants to be in, "Teacher.
Para marami ang trabaho sa mga bata sa sunod.
."
The local government arranges activities that help promote preservation of their culture.

Three days a week, they celebrate Indigenous People's Day.
During Mondays and Wednesdays, the little kids and the adults traditional wear their traditional Blaan attire.
And on Fridays, they conduct activities such as dancing and singing.
Maybe, if we stop putting our indigenous brothers and sisters down for practicing such traits from their culture, they will not be ashamed.
They will no longer squeeze into the outer borders of their comfort zones.
And maybe by this time, you already know that modernity is not the one to blame for the slowly diminishing culture of our natives.
