Abat, FOR two decades, Sun.Star Davao has established itself as the forerunner among the community newspapers in Davao Region hence, there's no way but up as what the 20th anniversary celebration slogan "Up!" would say.
Sun.Star Davao is not new to upping the ante and pulling ahead of its competitors.
Even during the time of Ang Peryodiko Dabaw and before the paper was acquired by Sun.Star's family of community newspapers in 1995, it went ahead of its local competitors as it was the first to utilize desktop publishing back when all of its competitors were using typesetting machines.
Fast forward to 2015, Sun.Star Davao has recently acquired the global web machine, a cutting-edge printing machine that promises a more refined quality for the daily copies.
Through the years, Sun.Star Davao has also carved a niche in journalistic excellence as it has established itself as the winningest community paper in the region having reaped around 70 awards.
The most recent of which was the award won by Sun.Star Davao editor-in-chief Stella Estremera in the European Union  Peace Journalism Awards for her story "Rituals for Peace." She also won the Best News Story in the 1st Sarihay Media Awards for her story "Davao Gulf: Rich Spawning Ground." 
Sun.Star Davao also showed that it has guided the community particularly the business sector in making sound decisions after winning the Best in Business and Economic Reporting Award given by the Philippine Press Institute .
Sun.Star Davao has earned citations from various government agencies as well which includes the Social Security System having been cited as one of the most compliant SSS contributors in the region; the Department of Social Welfare and Development  for its support in the different projects that the agency implements; the Davao City Police Office for its strong stance in promoting peace and order in the city and from the So Kim Cheng Foundation and Davao City Sports Council for its undying support for sports development.
While the digital age is already taking its toll on the print media industry, Sun.Star Davao refused to falter to the changing times as it started adapting to the digital platform through the Sun.Star website which saw the first few online publications in 2010.

Bolstering its bid as one of the most versatile media platforms in the region, Sun.Star Davao has also launched its Sun.Star Davao E-Paper which is now available at the Google and Apple apps stores.
This shows the commitment of Sun.Star Davao to serve the community with its daily news whether it is on the newsstands in the streets or establishments or in the comfort of their mobile phones, computers and other digital platforms.
Sun.Star Davao came close to the hearts of Dabawenyos when it chronicled the different cultures, personalities, economy and landscape through the re-launch of the Sun.Star Davao Yearbook in 2013.
But Sun.Star Davao's dedication to serving the community has gone beyond the bounds of delivering daily news.
Sun.Star Davao has been steadfast in its drive to serve the community by conducting outreach programs in different parts of the region.
Just recently, Sun.Star Davao led by its general manager Tessie Alcoriza conducted a series of outreach programs in different schools in the region where Sun.Star Davao employees handed out school supplies and assisted in the rehabilitation of school facilities.
True to its slogan, Sun.Star Davao remains and will remain above its competition as it is bent on leveling up its standards and service to appease the ever-growing demands of the community.

Meet Sun.Star's Gawad Dabawenyo awardee, Meet Sun.Star's Gawad Dabawenyo awardeeIvy C.
Tejano, IN CELEBRATION of its 20th year in the newspaper industry in this part of the country, Sun.Star Davao bestows the prestigious Gawad Dabawenyo Award to a church worker and a respected anthropologist, artist and peace advocate based in Mindanao.
Bro.
Carlito M.
Gaspar, Ph.D CSsR, simply Bro.
Karl to his colleagues and friends, has been cited for being "a true authority on life's purpose and spirituality."
Bro.
Karl joins past awardees, namely: Perfecto Yasay, former Security and Exchange Commission chair; Davao-born songwriter/singer Joey Ayala; civic leader Irene Santiago; the late staunch advocate of peace and federalism Rey Magno Teves; Mother Ma.
Assumpta M.
David RVM, and former Philippine Women's College of Davao president lawyer Rosa Santos Munda.
A Redemptorist brother, Bro.
Karl is also a poet-songwriter, a professor, a prolific book writer especially about the indigenous peoples and a political detainee at the height of the Marcos dictatorship and still standing up for peace decades hence.
He is described most by his colleagues as a man with spirituality that embraces the poor and the oppressed.
Born on June 8, 1947 in Davao City, Bro, Karl completed his doctoral degree in Philippine Studies from the University of the Philippines  in Quezon City in 2001.
He is a post graduate of Master of Science in Economics from Asian Social Institute in Manila in 1971, and a graduate of Bachelor of Arts in Sociology from Ateneo de Davao University in 1967.
Bro.
Karl grew up in the cities of Davao and Digos.
His parents Salvador and Josefina Gaspar, who originated from Capiz and Pangasinan, respectively, decided to transfer to Davao City just before the outbreak of the World War II.
"Being a brother has always been my first choice when I thought of my religious vocation.
I did not want to become a priest.
Why a brother? Mainly because the choices of a brother are much better and wider than becoming a priest," Gaspar, in an e-mail, said.
As a writer, Karl has authored several books, including novels, and contributed a number of articles and essays to various publications in the Philippines and abroad.
"I also wanted a greater sense of freedom and not be ne confined to doing parish work or maintaining sacramental duties.
 As brother, my choice of ministry is also much wider.
Thus I could be a professor, a non-government organization  worker, do grassroots work among the poor, and be a journalist, among the others," he added.
Bro.
Karl was a victim of Marcos Dictatorship.
He was arrested on September 23, 1972 and placed under house arrest for three months.
Then, he was arrested and imprisoned overnight in Lake Sebu in South Cotabato in 1974, detained for 22 months at Davao Metrodiscom stockade, acquitted by Regional Trial Court  and released in February 1985.
It was in 1985 when Karl joined the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer  as a Religious Brother.

At present, Bro.
Karl is also a lecturer, resource person, evaluator and consultant of various educational institutions, church and non-governmental organizations with several awards and citations.
He considers travelling different parts of the world as his greatest achievement, saying he had visited places which he only dreamed of when he was a young boy.

But at the same time, he said: "I have also reached practically all corners of the Philippines and Mindanao, thus I could claim to have been able to be familiarize with what is Filipino, what is Mindanawon.
To have been able to actually live among Muslim and Lumad communities, know their culture, be in touch with my roots and yet remain a strong advocate for their rights to their land and their struggle for self-determination."
Bro.
Karl also said that he is extra proud of the fact that he has hundreds of close friends representing various cultures, faith traditions, genders, races, ages, classes and able to appreciate the richness of Mindanawon cultures, adding that in his advanced years, he was able to mentor young people so that they too are inspired to continue the struggles for justice, peace and integrity of creation.
When asked if he is already happy and contented with his life, Bro.
Karl said: "By and large, I am most happy with my life right now as I am still able to do things I love to do including to travel, strengthen my family ties and my vocation as a redemptorist brother, meet new friends, write books, do art work, nurture a garden work, nurture a garden of flowers and herbs, deepen my spirituality and find time to have fun and enjoy the blessings of life."

Tech Tips: Stuff you didn't know you could do on Facebook, Tech Tips: Stuff you didn't know you could do on FacebookNEW YORK -- Did you know you can add a pronunciation guide to your name on Facebook? Overlay colorful text on the photos you post? How about mark the end of a relationship without your 500 closest friends getting notified?
Many of these tips and tricks aren't well known, even to veterans of the 1.5 billion-strong people-connector and time-waster.
Facebook is constantly updating its service, adding new features or tweaking old ones.
A lot can slip through the cracks even if you are scrolling through your friends' updates several times a day.
Here are a few ways to enhance your Facebook experience:
HOW DO YOU SAY THAT?
More than 83 percent of Facebook's users are outside of the U.S.
and Canada, and they use over 80 languages to communicate with friends and family.
That's a lot of people, and a lot of different ways to say your name.
To add a pronunciation guide, go to the "about" section of your profile and click on "details about you,"  then "name pronunciation." Here, Facebook will offer suggestions for your first and last name that you can listen to before selecting.
If none work, you can also type in your own phonetic pronouncer.
ONE-TIME PASSWORD
Logging in from a public computer? If you don't feel comfortable typing in your password on a shared machine that might have malicious software.
Facebook lets you request a temporary one by texting "otp" to 3404 for Smart and 2933 for Globe Telecom.
You'll get an eight-character passcode that works for the next 20 minutes and cannot be reused.
UNSUBSCRIBE
Anyone who's commented on a popular Facebook post, or belongs to a particularly chatty group, knows that those notifications telling you that "Jane Doe and 4 others also commented on a post" can get a bit annoying.
You can turn off notifications for individual posts by clicking on the globe icon on the top right corner of your Web browser, then on the "X" next to the individual notification.
You can also change your notification settings here to get fewer or more of them for each group that you belong to.
To do this on mobile, click to view the original post, then click the down arrow in the top right corner of the post.
You'll see an option to "turn off notifications."
KEEP IT ON THE DOWN-LOW
Announcing engagements and marriages on Facebook is fun.
Post and watch the likes and congrats roll in.
Bask in the love and glory.
Fast-forward a few years for some couples, and the glory fades, not to mention the love and marriage.
In this case, you might not want to announce the irreversible breakdown to 450 of your closest friends.
Thankfully, you can still mark the end of a relationship without notifying everyone.
Go to your profile and click on the "about" section, then "family and relationships on the left." Under relationship, you'll see a gray icon that probably says "friends," or maybe "public." Change it to "only me." Then change your relationship status.
After a while, you can change it back if you wish.
Your hundreds of acquaintances will be none the wiser, unless they are stalking your profile to see if you are single.
PICTURE PERFECT
Thanks to a popular but little-known new feature, Facebook lets you spruce up the photos you post by adding text and quirky stickers, such as drawings of scuba gear, sunglasses or a corn dog.
This tool is available on iPhones and is coming soon to Android devices.
To use it, choose a photo to upload and click the magic wand icon.
Here, you'll find text overlay options as well as the same stickers you can use in other parts of Facebook.
SECURITY CHECK
Another recent addition to Facebook's trove of tools is a "security checkup" that guides users through a checklist aimed at making their account more secure.
This includes logging out of Facebook on Web browsers and apps they are not using, and receiving alerts when someone tries to log in to their account from an unfamiliar device or browser.
To use it, go to https://www.facebook.com/help/securitycheckup on your computer 2014 this feature is not yet available on the mobile app.

For the first time, 1 billion people used Facebook in a day, For the first time, 1 billion people used Facebook in a day
In this March 25, 2015 file photo, Mark Zuckerberg talks about the Messenger app during the Facebook F8 Developer Conference in San Francisco.
For the first time, a billion people used Facebook in a single day on Monday, Aug.
24, 2015.
Zuckerberg marked the occasion with a post on his Facebook page, saying that one out of seven people on Earth logged in to the social network to connect with their friends and family.

NEW YORK -- For the first time, a billion people used Facebook in a single day on Monday, August 24.
CEO Mark Zuckerberg marked the occasion with a post on his Facebook page, saying that one out of seven people on Earth logged in to the social network to connect with their friends and family.
The one billion figure is different from the daily user numbers Facebook discloses each quarter when it reports its financial results.
Those are the average number of daily users, counted over a 30-day period.
Facebook had 968 million daily active users in June.
Overall, Facebook has nearly 1.5 billion users who log in at least once a month.
It hit the one billion user milestone in October 2012.
Most people on Facebook live outside the US and Canada.

They who bring light, They who bring light
RAFI awardee
Karlo Paolo R.
Pates, CEBU CITY -- Amid our collective wailings against a society that has seemed to have been corrupted to the core, it is heartening to get to know individuals willing to sacrifice and committed in making the lives of others better without getting something in return, not even attention.
Anita 201cNanay Anit201d Castillon, a retired teacher, and Kadtabanga Foundation for Peace and Development Advocates Inc.
 made up of former Moro rebels turned peace advocates, were hailed as the modern-day heroes by the 6th Ramon Aboitiz Foundation Inc.
 Triennial Awards.
Castillon received the Ramon Aboitiz Award for Exemplary Individual while the KFPDAI was declared winner for the Eduardo Aboitiz Award for Outstanding Institution.
The awarding ceremony was held last August 14 at the Grand Cebu Convention Center in Cebu City.

Castillon, principal and founder of the Marmylone Learning Center in Lake Sebu, South Cotabato, dedicated more than 35 years of service for the T'boli tribe by establishing three Indigenous Learning Schools for the T'bolis who did not have access to schools in the mountainuous barangays in Lake Sebu.
At 62 years old, Castillon, who hails from Antique, nurtured the T'boli families as if they were her own siblings and helped their communities in becoming more self-reliant while helping provide access to basic services.
Called as Nanay Anit by most of her acquaintances, she herself experienced early life struggles as she became a widow at 22 and from hence focused on raising her only daughter, who's currently based in US, and pursued a career in teaching.
Dedicating her service to the T'boli tribe since 1979 as part of the Sta.
Cruz Mission, Nanay Anit established three IP schools in Lake Sebu where a child can enroll for a monthly fee of P50.
She also collects P20 per month from each child for the school's feeding program that is complemented by the vegetables from the school garden.
Aside from her duties in the schools, Nanay Anit also works hand in hand with the Municipal Nutrition Office, which helped reduce malnutrition among children.

Castillon at first was regarded as an insurgent by the T'bolis and the military, but she was unfazed and continued her work until she earned the trust of the T'bolis.
Nanay Anit also found ways to preserve the intricate crafts of the tribe.
T'Boli's handcrafts, brass casting, and beadworks are brought to the local tourism office to be sold providing income to the families.
201cMany people have ignored the IPs ,201d Nanay Anit explained, adding that she wants to dedicate the rest of her life with the T'bolis as it makes her heart blossoms with happiness.
"I'm really thankful for this award.
This will mean a lot not just for me but for the T'bolis in Lake Sebu.
Thank you RAFI for this recognition," she said.
When asked about how she will make use of the cash prize that she won, Castillon answered that she plans to construct a water system for three Indigenous Learning Schools she established in Lake Sebu.
She also said that she will allocate some amount to purchase a carabao to help their farming programs for the T'boli.
Meanwhile, Diacolano said that the KFPDAI plans to use the money to fund a microfinancing program for their PDCs.
KFPDAI, a foundation based in Datu Odin Sinsuat in Maguindanao, was established in 2000 by members of the Moro National Liberation Front after the signing of the Final Peace Agreement between the Philippine Government and the MNLF.
Hadja Giobay Diacolano, KFPDAI's executive director, admitted that she was a former MNLF combatant herself but she along with other members decided to lay down their arms and leave the battlefields to transform the war-conflicted areas to a Peace and Development Communities .
Around 50 former members of the MNLF are now serving as staff of the foundation mainly focused in organizing peace building and development oriented activities including emergency assistance and delivery of other basic social services.
Diacolano became emotional during the press conference for the awardees while recounting her past experiences as an MNLF combatant.
She also admitted that after the foundation was established, they had a hard time convincing other communities to be declared as PDCs since taking arms was foremost in the minds of the people.
"We made them realize that we are not their enemy.
We told them that we are working for peace and not for war and through that their allowed us to be more involved in their communities," Diacolano said.
For the last 15 years, the KFPDAI helped 28 municipalities be declared as PDCs in Maguindanao.
During her acceptance speech, Diacolano said that the award is dedicated for all those who struggled to bring peace and development in Mindanao.
Winners received trophies and P484,000 cash prize each.
Other nominees for the individual category are Fr.
Carmelo Diola of the Archdiocese of Cebu and Agusan del Norte, first district Representative Lawrence Lemuel Fortun.
While the finalists for the institutions category are Balay Mindanaw Foundation Inc., Cantaan Centennial Multi-Purpose Cooperative , Sibog Katawhan Alang sa Paglambo, Inc  and Western Samar Development Foundation Inc.
.
All finalists also received P121,000 from RAFI.
Gina Garcia-Atienza, chairman of the 6th Rafi Triennial Awards search committee and also the Sun.Star Media Group's president, said that they had a hard time picking out the finalists and winners from 295 nominations.
201cWhat is common in this year's finalists is that they went out from their comfort zones to help people,201d said Atienza told the media in a press conference held after the awading ceremony.
The RAFI Triennial Awards in the Visayas and Mindanao was launched in 1996 to give recognition to individuals and institutions who committed themselves to building a more humane, equitable, and caring society.
Tech Tips: Windows 10 privacy settings worth checking, Tech Tips: Windows 10 privacy settings worth checking
This screen shot provided by Microsoft shows Cortana, Microsoft2019s voice-activated digital assistant  in Windows 10.
Microsoft2019s new Windows 10 system offers more personalization than before, but it also collects more data than people might be used to on PCs, from contacts and appointments to their physical location and even Wi-Fi passwords.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Microsoft's new Windows 10 system offers more personalization than before, but it also collects more data than people might be used to on PCs, from contacts and appointments to their physical location and even Wi-Fi passwords.
The information is used by Cortana, Microsoft's voice-activated digital assistant, and other new features that try to be helpful by remembering a user's likes and habits.
Apple and Google have developed similar services for smartphones in recent years.
Microsoft's new features are a big part of its strategy to make Windows more relevant in a world where people use multiple devices throughout the day.
Most of these features get turned on when you set up Windows 10 with the "Get going fast" option.
But you can take back control and disable features in the settings.
Here are some examples:
Wi-Fi worries
A feature called Wi-Fi Sense promises to make it easy for users and their friends to connect with new Wi-Fi networks.
It lets Windows 10 computers log in automatically to known networks, so your friends don't have to ask for the password when they visit.
Despite some initial reports, Wi-Fi Sense doesn't hand over your password to all your friends.
Instead, it stores your password online in an encrypted form.
It then provides that encrypted code to your friend's Windows 10 device so it can automatically log into your network.
Your friends never actually see the password, and Microsoft says your friends won't get access to other computers or files on the network.
Even so, critics say the feature shares too freely, as you can't choose which friends to share with 2014 only with your full list of friends or contacts on Facebook, Outlook.com or Skype.
To disable this, open the "Settings" menu in Windows 10, select "Network & Internet" and click on "Manage Wi-Fi Settings." You can uncheck groups you don't want to share with.
You can also choose not to share access to a particular network when you log in for the first time; just uncheck the box next to "Share network with my contacts."
But if you let friends manually log into your network by giving them your password, be aware they might be able to share the password via Wi-Fi Sense with their friends.
You can ask them not to, or completely block Wi-Fi Sense by changing your Wi-Fi network's name to include the underscore followed by these characters: optout.
Cortana knows you
Many people are used to voice-activated services like Apple's Siri or "OK Google" on smartphones and tablets.
Windows 10 brings Microsoft's digital assistant, Cortana, to desktops and laptops.
Cortana can answer questions, remind you of appointments and even recommend nearby restaurants.
But to do that, Cortana uploads and saves information about your Web browsing, search queries and location, as well as some details from your messages, contacts and calendar.
Microsoft says it doesn't use the Cortana personalization to target ads.
Nor will it use your emails, chats or personal files for advertising.
But it does tailor ads to websites visited with its Edge browser and queries made on its Bing search engine, including queries through Cortana.

You can review what Cortana knows about you: Click on the search field in the lower left of your screen, then click the "Notebook" icon and select "About Me" to edit or delete individual items.
If you want to turn Cortana off, open "Notebook," click on "Settings" and toggle Cortana to "Off." That clears information stored on the device, but not the data uploaded to Microsoft's servers.
To get to that, open "Notebook," choose "Settings" and click "Manage what Cortana knows about me in the cloud."
More privacy settings
Anyone concerned about privacy should take a run through the "Privacy" section of the Windows 10 "Settings" menu.
This is different from the "Settings" menu for Cortana.
You find it by clicking on the Windows icon in the lower left of your screen.
Windows 10 assigns each user on each device a unique "advertising ID," which lets app developers track how each person uses the device and apps.
If that bothers you, you'll find the button to turn it off by going to "Settings" and opening the "Privacy" section.
You might have to hit the back arrow at the top left if you're already in another section.
Click on "General" in the left-hand column to turn off advertising ID.
You might still get ads, but they won't be tailored to you.
Similarly, open "Privacy" and click on "Location" to turn off location tracking or clear the history of where you've traveled with your laptop, tablet or Windows phone.
Another heading under "Privacy" has the innocuous title of "Other devices." That's where you can turn off the ability to "Sync with devices." That feature lets apps on your device share information with things like store-tracking beacons, which send you ads as you walk nearby.
If that sounds creepy, turn it off.
Some critics complain that Microsoft hasn't been more up front about all the ways Windows 10 collects user information.
But you can find most of them by scrolling through the nooks and crannies of the "Settings" menu.
That's a good thing to do with any new software program or Internet service.
It's also good to go back there from time to time to make sure the settings match your comfort level.

It is an iconic building with LED lights that will glimmer at night and the looks will surely captivate Dabawenyos.
"The Aeon Towers is a structure that will embody the spirit of residents of Davao, towering over the Davao City landscape.
A monolith that stands for the endless possibilities that life in the fast evolving city has to offer.
It is a perfect balance between boldness and tradition, between a carefree lifestyle and a progressive mindset," Cruz had said.
Strategically located at the heart of Davao City's commercial hub on JP Laurel ave.
in Bajada, Aeon Towers is touted to be the next iconic symbol of the city and the most ambitious, so far.
Development works onsite are in full swing.
With almost 400 workers, construction of the tower is going non-stop on a 24-hour shift.
"We're almost done with underground works.
The four-level basement parking is almost complete," Marchan said.
She said construction of the podium or the ground level up to the second and third levels of the tower has also started.
"The basement structure is well planned and we make sure it will hold the 33-storey tower, plus it is also our parking area for the whole building," Marchan said.
Aeon Towers training head Al Punzalan said underground works, including the construction of the basement parking took them 18 months to finish.
"It was the reason kung bakit wala pang nakikitang structure in the past months.
Tinatrabaho pa 'yong ilalim.
And this is the only structure in the city na may four-level basement parking," he said.
With massive development works onsite, Marchan and Punzalan are optimistic it won't take a year before the 466-unit tower is sold out.

Building communities for 20 years now, Building communities for 20 years nowNelson C.
Bagaforo, FOR 20 years now, a national player in property development has remained confident in the potential of Davao City's property market.
It is among a few players that weathered the challenging times in the past, including the 1997 Asian financial crunch that obviously had adverse effects on real estate industry that time.
Camella Davao, a subsidiary of the country's largest homebuilder, Vista Land, which is controlled by the family of former senator Manuel Villar, was then establishing its mark in the Davao market when the crisis struck that prompted property developers to put their projects on hold.
Camella was unfazed and went on with its first residential development in the city -- the master-planned Caribbean-themed community called Solariega in Talomo.
Because Solariega offered a new concept in residential development, it didn't take long before the project's first phase was sold out.
This development project was immediately followed by another master-planned mid-end residential project in Puan, the grand Italian-inspired Toscana.
Another horizontal project followed, this time in Mintal, the Mediterranean-inspired Cerritos, which is at present undergoing expansion.
But even before Cerritos, Camella embarked on a multi-billion vertical residential project, the British-inspired Camella Northpoint, a condominium complex located in the emerging business center in the city's southern district in Bajada.

Northpoint is Vista Land,s first condominium project outside Metro Manila.
Five years after the project was launched, the complex is now home to four mid-rise condo buildings, comprising of 898 units.
The construction of another 10-storey residential building is set to start in the second quarter of 2015 with at least 300 units.
"Our presence in Davao City only proves how confident we are in the city's growth potential.
We want to be part of its growing economy and we are bent to dominate the market by providing quality yet affordable housing to Dabawenyos," former senator Manuel Villar said during the lunch of their first township project in the city -- the Camella Davao located in Communal in Buhangin District.
This 35-hectare development, which comprises from low-end to high-end residential component, a commercial center, a park, church, school and other amenities, is in partnership with the family of Compostela Valley Gov.
Arturo "Chiongkee" Uy.
Development works for this project starts in early 2015.

"Davao City is among the focus areas of our massive expansion at present.
We want to take advantage of its growing property market," Villar assured.
in doing so, Vista Land is infusing P30 to P40 billion from its capital expenditures in the next five to six years, which will include investments for shopping malls and lifestyle centers that will be developed in its existing and new projects in the city.
Other than Davao City, Camella is also expanding in nearby cities of Tagum, General Santos City and Koronadal, where it already has existing master-planned development projects.
For the first semester of 2015, Camella Davao is set to lunch more big projects in the city, including the development of another township to rise in the 130-hectare property in Catigan, Toril area.
Development works are also set to start simultaneous with the Communal township.
Another condominium project will also be developed in Ma-a.
"In Toril project, we will introduce Lessandra, a townhouse model which is very affordable that fits those migrating in the city and starting family who want to own a house," said Marlon Nino Escalicas, Camella South-Central Mindanao Cluster head, referring to a new market segment that is emerging in the city -- the affordable market.
The emergence of this market segment is triggered by entry of more big companies engaged in manufacturing and service sector that generate thousands of jobs in the city.
Escalicas said they are also taking advantage of the growing investors market which comprises a bulk of their buyers, particularly for their condo units.
"Most of our buyers are actually not end-users but investors who are also looking at the demand for housing to grow further," Escalicas said.
"Camella's respectable image in property development, this market segment is aware it will not be difficult for them to look for renters once the units are turned over to them," he added.

The workforce: Striving for excellence, The workforce: Striving for excellenceKriztja Marae G.
Labrador, FOR 20 years, Sun.Star Davao has been operating as a daily local community newspaper in this part of the country, giving its readers only the best of the best content from local news, lifestyle features, entertainment, sports, columns and a whole lot more.
It has continued to strive for excellence, giving utmost importance to its partners for growth, including its people, readers and advertisers.
And each issue and this community paper and other products published by the company, such as the annual Davao Yearbook, are a collaborative efforts from all of its departments, each taking part to Sun.Star Davao's success.
As the anniversary celebration continues, here's a glimpse of each of the publication's department.
Marketing and circulation
Known as the "lifeblood" of a newspaper because its main task is to make sure that the paper is well-marketed and -circulated, Sun.Star Davao general manager Tessie A.
Pa\xf1a shared that their journey towards the transition of the trend from print to digital has been quite a challenge that they have embraced.
But she was quick to add that although some national papers have been affected with this change, Sun.Star Davao, as a community newspaper, stood strong along with the continuous economic progress of Davao City where a lot of sectors and big investors still want to get involved with.
"Through this digital boom, we have created new sources of revenue, presented unique contents and repackaged our marketing offers.
We continue to innovate," she said.

As the company continues to publish daily newspapers, it also has a website and an e-paper version for its growing digital audience.
For marketing, Pa\xf1a also bared that Sun.Star Davao continues to capture 70 percent of advertising market share in Davao City with its growing readership as shown by the recent survey conducted by Ateneo de Davao University.

The survey showed that Sun.Star Davao and Sun.Star Davao Superbalita reached 40.9% readership among other local newspapers in Davao.
As Sun.Star Davao goes "Up," she added that their future plans are still on coming up with more innovations that will suit its readers and the changing times.
The editorial
The producer of the newspaper's content, Sun.Star Davao editor-in-chief Stella A.
Estremera said that as the department's leader, "the constant challenge is enabling the department to produce quality reports and stimulate the passion of the staff towards their tasks."
The department also has different sections: the field reporters, who are the ones going on field to get the news or feature materials; the editors, the ones who edits the reporter's articles; the layout artists, the ones who arrange the papers content and beautifies the paper; the proofreaders, the ones who make sure that the paper's content are text error free.

As a daily, the pressure is really in the editorial department especially in the afternoons wherein everyone is expected to submit their reports before the set deadline.
But despite the pressure, "creating good, highly productive citizens," is what Estremera said when asked on what has been their greatest achievement.
Fast forwarding for future plans, Estremera has vowed that the department will continue to pursue "to always be the best."
The production
The "all-nighter" department who makes sure that Sun.Star Davao's newspapers hit the streets first before others.
Pa\xf1a said the recent challenge is to produce colorful and quality printed paper to compete with what online contents can offer.
With this and in order to be able to keep up with the growing demand, Sun.Star Davao recently upgraded its printing machine.

Pa\xf1a shared that the upgraded machine's speed is triple than the old one which means it can print more in a shorter period of time.
For future plans, other than the newly acquired machine, she said that they are continuously aligning the operations of the production department to the business strategy of the company.
The accounting
The department responsible for the company's finances, check and balancing profit and expenses, this department has a lot of math to deal with on a daily basis.
Sun.Star Davao's accounting supervisor Lovella Panio said that two of the challenges are in compromising existing systems and policies so as to provide assistance for various departments and strictness in budgeting funds.
"Our purpose is for accountability and our duty is to count up to the last centavo," she explained.
For their plans, Panio said that they will still continue to strive to manage all the lapses that they have seen and continue to "strengthen the company's internal control for the good of everyone."
Credit and collection
The department responsible for billing and collecting customers' payments, credit and collection supervisor Andrew Leo Ocot shared that some of the challenges are hitting the set collection period and dealing with account complications.
Patience is indeed important under this department as they have to constantly deal with different customers during their collection day and making sure that they are paying right.
Included in their future plans, according to Ocot are for the improvement of their terms policy and having "more trainings for collectors to improve skills and to learn strategies in collection."
The human resource
The last but not the least, when all the departments are under pressure and stress, the HR department comes to the rescue.
With its role to ensure the welfare of Sun.Star Davao employees, HR supervisor Vic L.
Purgatorio said that other than dealing with hard-headed employees being a challenge, they still make sure that all of the employee benefits are provided for.
They also organize programs such as inter-department tournaments and team building to distress employees from work and encourage them to build more teamwork within the different departments.
Purgatorio also shared that they also take part in looking for community projects that the company can get involved in towards helping others like the current student scholar that Sun.Star Davao sends to school.
For their plans, he said that they will still continue to create more fun activities for the employees to participate.

The justice beat: Amid the grueling legal terms, The justice beat: Amid the grueling legal termsRhealyn C.
Pojas, YOU need to understand yourself first before you should demand to be understood by others.
That's the thought that sinks through my mind as I try to recall what my days as a reporter assigned to cover the justice beat are like.
I have come to realize that certain level of understanding is necessary to be achieved and this begins in the writer.
If one cannot reach this point of understanding then it is impossible to expect readers to understand what you are trying to convey.
Thanks to the editors who are there to back me up when the words I had sewn together to write the story seemed to rumble with each other.
Never mind the day when a storm of writ of amparo, habeas data, in abeyance, moot and other legal terms come flooding your mind, leaving your brain a little woozy at times while reading resolutions, decisions, or orders coming from the court.

It is given that the beat is very technical and being new to this craft is not an excuse because it is part of your job to convey to the readers whatever data you gathered in the simplest form.
You have to write it too in the shortest time possible as deadline is a relentless enemy you would have to beat every day.
You need to carry that weight on your shoulders while striving to be accurate, unbiased, ethical and legal at the same time.

But there is always that rewarding feeling after I have seen the story I have written being printed in the newspaper.
In just that instant, all the dramas I had experienced upon stitching the data together suddenly fades i to oblivion.
What will then remain are the values and lessons you I had taken out of those experience.
   
Indeed, writing the story is a different thing and experiencing it happened before your eyes is another.
The awe of watching the action in progress is a luxury to keep and the lessons you earned along the way is something you will carry on for the rest of your life.
And there's the realization that even the stories you are writing have their own stories and that the moment the ink strikes the paper, you give birth to a new chapter of history.

I admit that as a young reporter, I have asked both wise and stupid questions and cried and laugh at those, but the bottomline is, I have learned from each mistake.
There is so much to learn yet.
Amid all the drama, one line that fuels me to continue this path I pursue is from my favorite poem Desiderata by Max Erhmann which goes this way: "Keep interested in your own career, however humble, it's a real possession in the changing fortunes of time."
So now, I just have to enjoy the front seat to history as my days as a reporter goes on.
The governance: The long wait isn't over yet Karina Ca\xf1edo, The governance: The long wait isn't over yet Karina Ca\xf1edoKarina V.
Canedo, COVERING local governance is not an easy job.
It entails a lot of patience and persistence.
You need to have pools of curiosity within you to be aware of the latest issues confronting the community that serves as basis in pursuing the story.
Understanding issues sometimes take a lot of time for me because some of these have long stretches of origin and some of its details need research not just electronically but also by asking other proper sources.
 
Upon the time I started, I observed other reporters how they interview, particularly on how to get the right information and tried to apply it to myself.

Developing a routine on how to get news was a hard act to do during my first month in the beat.

Even if Davao is my birthplace, and has been my dwelling place for four years, I am not well versed on its offices even its streets.
But then with the help of my fellow reporters, I found my way to seek the right people in right places to ask for whenever information I need for my stories.
My regular routine in the beat includes attending the flag ceremony every Monday and the city council regular session on Tuesdays.
I also do a round of different offices at the City Hall on Wednesdays, go to I-Speak media forum on Thursdays and on Fridays I go back to doing my visits to different city offices.

As for my sources, I've experienced a lot and long wait is a very common thing, I was surprised at first, but I used to later on and considered it as just part of a reporter's life.
Anyway, some of these officials, considering their busy schedules, can only be interviewed once in a while.
It's also quite a challenge to be on time, the need to be there when important announcements, like that of a city mayor, are made.
But you always need to adjust to them because, I believe, these news sources will never adjust to you.

Being late is very crucial, since you do not only miss what the sources had said but the way these details that you needs in your story are delivered, You need to understand the context of that source.
Interviewing sources is also challenge as it measures how abreast are you of the story you want to pursue.

Apparently, I could say that being a governance beat reporter would be harder if you do not care a single thing about the city, but I guess it's not a hard thing to do on my part.
I had grown to love Davao more because of this job, and surely I guess it would still continue as I am here trying my best to always give the people the information they need to know.

Cudis, IF FLATTENING a mountain is not impossible these days, so is making an organic farm in a city like Davao.

Wynward Valley Organic Vegetable Garden, a farm which started as a hobby of plant pathologist, Dr.
Rodelio "Milo" Dalisay is also open for the public to enjoy delicious organic recipes.
Dalisay earned his doctorate in the University of Kentucky.
To make ends meet, he had several jobs; he teaches Plant Biochemistry in the graduate school and works as a chef in a Japanese restaurant for at least 11 years.

Until the whole inherited land was converted to an urban farm.

His farm-cum bistro also houses plants which are not commonly grown in a tropical country like ours.

Aquaponics, a type of aquaculture system wherein the waste produced by farmed fish will supply nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn will purify the water will be used.
Dalisay being a scientist and a teacher that he is knows he will not settle for establishing the bistro as his end-goal.
He continues his advocacy to show organic farming as highly beneficial and profitable.
His new project is to put up another organic farm in the Marilog district which will benefit the residing elementary and high school students who are staying at Balay Pasilungan.

It is kind of a transient house for the children to stay so they would not have to trek five to seven kilometers from their houses going to the school.
Dalisay aims to educate the children so they could have at least something to eat whilst they stay at the Balay Pasilungan.
At the same time, he teaches them and the parents how to plant properly so they could earn from it as well.

Kahayag: Lighting up the way to sustainable agri, Kahayag: Lighting up the way to sustainable agri
DAVAO.
Daycare kids lead the way as they excitedly tour the farm with the owner, Mikhal Evasco.
Karina V.
Canedo, KAHAYAG Farms is Davao based organic farm but not only on the commonly labeled organic that usually pertained to plants but also to their livestock and poultry.
Mikhal A.
Evasco, the resident farmer at Kahayag Farms, runs the three-hectare farm with the plants, herbs, chicken, pigs, wild pigs, rabbit, sheep and goat, and believe it or not they are not tainted with anything artificial or synthetic.
They all consume organic food and only take organic medicine.
Kahayag Farms started to be all organic in the year 2011 and it's been since that they also conducted transition period from commercial breed piglets into organic ones.

"The transition is based on the Philippine national standard nag-start 2011 kadtong sa organic for one year wala na me naggamit ug synthetic based on farm materials such as chemicals." 
They also raise and breed wild pigs for meat and lechon sold at their all organic restaurant called Minkah's kitchen where they serve organic food down to the meat up to the spices and herbs used.
Evasco said the technologies that they used came from the practices in Maribojoc, Bohol, which inspired him to do organic farming.

He developed the other technologies himself in the within the two years of their operation as an organic farm.
"For two years, we only did research and development sa farm, thus we only had limited production because we wanted that once we go full-scale, we should be prepared," Evasco said.
Evasco said that his research was done through a lot of farm tours in different places with good practices he also cited the help of the advantage of Internet.
"We did benchmarking at Maribojoc, a farm in Bohol.
It's not copy paste but it's there where the formulation were given.
 Along the way we have developed it and right now we really achieved it, it's competitive and at par with the quality that we saw there.
 Relatively, we succeeded in our trial," Evasco said.

Evasco said that they started establishing their livestock and after a few months their poultry.
"They have the same food, it's only the management and handling transition especially that time we still did not have a sow, so we were dependent on the piglets outside.
Once the source is outside, you need a month to process the pig from commercial grade to organic.
Now we do not depend on outside farms because we already have 11 sows existing, and three sows of wild pigs," he said.
Among the things unique in Kahayag Farms is their breeding of wild pigs.

Evasco said that wild pigs are tastier and have less fat compared to domesticated ones.
The disadvantage is that wild pigs take longer to grow.
"Instead of 80 kilos within four months, it would take eight to ten months before they would weigh 80 kilos.
We also have fattening pigs for our meat.
What we do for the wild pigs, we use it for lechon so that it will not increase the production cost.
Native wild pigs are preferred in the market as there are market for the native wild, but as far as I know we are the only one who sell and breed wild pigs," Evasco said.
 
"We plan to expand for another 50 heads for the sow and then another 500 heads for the breeder and in the poultry 500 heads and for fattening also 500 heads," Evasco added.

He said that since their farm is sustainable, profit is assured.
Last year, their farm netted half a million.
As of this time, they target P700,000.
They are targeting a P1-million profit next year.
"Organic farming is labor intensive.
But since our cost for inputs like fertilizer and feeds is low, it is still balanced.
We still get big profit from it.
The labor cost is well compensated," Evasco said.

The farm is labor intensive because the farmers prepare for everything, the feeds from organic sources, and the concoctions that are fed to the animals.

Another good feature of the Kahayag farms is that they do not believe in trade secrets and share their learning and technology to farmers who are interested to know about.
Within their farm you can find training halls and dormitories where the farmers who do their farm tour and training can actually stay.
A one-day learning tour costs P1,300 head, three days P4,800, and five days  P8,400 inclusive of meals and accommodation.

"On the one day per commodity it would depend on the interest of the farmer and the would-be farmer.
On the three days, it's not the introductory anymore, but there are also integration of the commodities, the five days, all the commodities were offered.
We offer inputs on farm livestock, poultry, crop production, gardening, vermiculture, concoctions, fertilizer, production and feed formulation.
Kana wala man mi trade secrets sa farm ginatudlo jud namo tanan ," he said.

Evasco also said they also offer buyback program to those whom they have trained.
They have also conduct monitoring and consultation to the farmers who availed the training.
Most of those who availed the buyback program are those who are still struggling to find their markets.
"It's part of our commitment to those who taught to us, aside from open consultation and mentoring anytime, one of the highlights of the services that we offer is once we are assured that the products of other trained farmers are fully organic, we buy it to encourage farmer to continue organic agriculture.
We get the products straight from their farm, buying them at prevailing rates," Evasco said.
Currently, they have tied up with buyback programs with all other organic farmers in Mindanao.
Those who availed were mostly from people's organizations including individual farmers at Agusan, Sta-Josefa , Sigaboy , and Antipas for the coco sugar.
Apart from that they have also tapped their own farm worker s in their dispersal program where they give piglets to their farmers workers in the community.

"Not only that they are simply farm workers because we taught them all the kinds of technology used in the farm to replicate it in their houses.
We encourage them so that is why we the dispersal program to the sow pigs and poultry.
These are not freely given, if you would like to buy it would be cash to cash.
The deductions will be per harvest," Evasco said.

The workers know the organic farm technologies themselves and they themselves are part of the training of visitors.
Kahayag is planning on expanding its work force soon once they increase the number of heads of their livestock.
"Additional jobs na pud sa community," Evasco said.
Aside from that, they also resorted to contract farming among their neighbors in the community.
"It's the same for the workers we give them options between livestock or contract growing of corn, soybeans because that is essential to our feeds.
It is the same concept actually in the chicken or pigs but instead of feeds, we provide them fertilizer and they would sell it to us and we buy it at a premium price, instead of selling it to the local market we are the ones who pick them up at market price," Evasco said.
He added that only molasses, rice bran  and fish are not sourced from their farms.

"It is not possible for us to produce molasses.
Hopefully we can build a fish pond, and acquire a rice field for the rice bran, but sustainability wise, it can all be provided here," Evasco said.
He said the products that they buy back goes to their restaurant along Maa Road beside S&R, the Minkah's Kitchen and also the farm for visitors.
He added that the yield of their farm primarily goes to their restaurant and they only sell the surplus of what they need.

For Minkah's Kitchen, which they have formally operated since last December the average meat consumption is two heads of fattening pigs per week.
Evasco said they have not experienced shortage because they have not yet fully opened for the public.
They also do catering, from which they source the ingredients from the farm and the contract farms.
Evasco said they are certified under the Participatory Guarantee System, a certifying body for organic farms and organic food.

He said that based on law farmers cannot claim that they produce organic products without a supporting document from a body or organization.
"Our plan is within the end of the year we could get a third party certification.
This certification means you can supply your organic goods to the whole Philippines," Evasco said.

Evasco added that since they are planning to expand the number and the poultry, they are set to supply meat in mall groceries, once they boost their production.
Coffee for Peace is coffee for peace, Coffee for Peace is coffee for peaceRhealyn C.
Pojas, A DELICIOUS sip and more, this is what the Coffee for Peace offers by serving coffee to people while helping the people behind the coffee production.

Coffee for Peace which is situated at G/F Fredric Building, MacArthur Highway, Matina in Davao City offers people more than just a cup of coffee either served hot or cold as it has become a tool to help farmers in the highlands to generate profit through using their own land for coffee production.
A glimpse of the history of Coffee for Peace will tell you that the business started as an income generating project for the Peace Builders Community Inc.
, a non-government organization that advocates peace particularly in Mindanao.
"Coffee for Peace does not want to branch out.
We don't want to be like the other coffee shops in the Philippines.
Coffee for peace showcases the coffee of the farmers," said Coffee for Peace roasting and logistics manager Daniel Byron Pantoja in an interview with Sun.Star Davao explaining further that while they do not want to branch out, they provide coffee to other entrepreneurs and export some coffees abroad.
"So our dream is to supply coffees to other entrepreneurs because the more we could supply and grow that way the more we could buy coffee from farmers," Pantoja explained.
Pantoja narrated that it was on 2006 when his family came here in the Philippines and started the Peace Builders Community Inc.
During that time, his parents would go to conflict area and every time they sit down they would drink coffee.
The birth or idea of coffee for peace as an income generating project for the organization began from casual sips of coffee during those travels or visitation in the conflicted areas in Mindanao.
Though the CFP started in 2006, the actual incorporation began in 2008.
In the beginning, their coffees came from Sulu where they made contacts through the peace network.
The source of their coffee first came from there however the contact was lost and eventually the deal died out.
As time went on, they found another source and that was when they came across a certain Pastor in General Santos City named Fred who is also into coffee growing and who liked the vision of CFP and their advocacies.
CFP then supported PBCI, which worked in the communities especially among the farmers and 25 percent of the profit was forwarded to the said organization.

The good thing about the business is that the profit they earned will be injected back to the business to help the farmers.

"We want to do whatever we can, that will help them the most even if re-investing all of the project back to buying or back into funding our harvest, we don't use the process to scale up," Pantoja explained.

"It's about moving the bean and getting the farmers to make better quality coffee all the time," Pantoja uttered referring to the main goal of CFP.
Why Coffee?
When asked why they had chosen coffee over any other products, Pantoja explained that it is because coffee crosses all economic, cultural, and age boundary.
He also said that based on his research, he found that coffee is the second largest traded commodity in the world which is second only to oil.
Also, Asia used to be a tea-drinking country but is now becoming coffee-drinking country, Pantoja said, adding that more people want coffee.
Coffee is also a means to connect people from all walks of life.
People from the highland, who are producing the coffee beans, will have a place to connect with people from the lowland over a cup of coffee.

More Bitter
Though the help extended by CFP to the farmers is contributing not just on the economic aspect but as well as of the cultural aspect among others, they also faced certain problems in the operation.
 
"The main challenges in the industry are scaling up and quality control," Pantoja said.
Scaling up their production had become a problem, Pantoja explained, since another company could just buy the land that the farmers owned and then hire all the farmers to work for them which results into the farmers becoming employees in their own land.
"But the CFP doesn't want that to happen because what we want is that the farmers will do it  for their own land," Pantoja said.
Aside from that, the other challenges they are facing is the quality control, which means getting the farmers to follow certain processes in drying their coffee beans and also man power.
Pantoja also expressed that they also need to guarantee the people through their show and tell approach that they can really earn out of growing coffee trees.
The farmers might think that planting coffee trees is pointless if they do not have a buyer.
"If they don't see it, they won't do it," Pantoja said adding that the farmers needed to see that they will earn an income from it.
Also in an article posted in peacebuilders.org which is written by Jonathan Cranston, Coffee for Peace Barista Catherine Moreno Olitao expressed the common things experienced by the farmers where she explained that there are businessmen who prey on farmers and dictate very low prices for their produce and she had also stated the fact that middle class Filipinos prefer the imported coffees over the locally produce coffees.
A Reason to Be Excited
Against all odds, the CFP together with their farmer partners continue to work for their dream of producing good quality coffee.
Pantoja expressed that they are excited over a new plan which they had come up for the business.
He said that they are trying to buy a land and make a memorandum of agreement.
Now they are going to help the farmers in the area of management, research, and development of the coffee.
If before, CFP is only touching the quality control, now they are more hands on, Pantoja said.
Through this new plan, they are going to make clear partnership with the farmers and co-manage the facility.
What they are going to earn from the operation will be injected back to the business to help the farmers more.
"So what are we going to focus on is train the farmers to make better process control and better product knowledge, focus effort, ecological processing method, and waste management," Pantoja explained.

Pantoja also remarked that one should be involved with the community so that one can find a way that is sustainable economically, socially, and culturally.
Hot Chili rebuilds, Hot Chili rebuildsKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, IT'S been three years since Super Typhoon Pablo  that devastated the provinces of Davao Oriental and Compostela Valley in Davao Region which primarily affected the agriculture sector.
Typhoon Pablo, the strongest until typhoon Yolanda, left thousands of people dead and injured and their houses flattened.
Worst, the coconut plantations and farmlands were flattened as well.
While the people of Davao Oriental at first were in the doldrums for having lost their livelihood, now they are slowly rising back with the introduction of hot chili processing.
Davao Oriental has been known among those familiar with the town for their "dumang" or powdered siling labuyo, but these were produced in backyard operations, the products sold in shoddily tagged "lapad" bottles.
It was through the initiative of Department of Trade and Industry  11 and it's Hot Chili or Hot Pablo that changed the lives of the local communities in Boston, Bagangam, and Cateel in the aftermath of Typhoon Pablo.
DTI's Hot Chili Project encouraged the farmers to plant, process, and market of hot chili and its by-products.
The project is a collaborative effort of the provincial government of Davao Oriental led by Gov.
Corazon Malanyaon, local government units , Department of Agriculture and Department of Science and Technology .

El Tigre Chili Products, which started its operation on March 2013, three months after the devastation of Typhoon Pablo, was one of the recipients of the DTI's initiated assistance project.

Aside from the El Tigre Chili Products, other beneficiaries of the project in the province were Dory Dumang Products, Edelia's Dumang Products, Ayana's Siling Kinamayo, and Subangon Dumang Makers.
MAMA Trees Farmers Association which started the El Tigre Chili Products presently have 225 workers who were all victims of Typhoon Pabo.
Luis C.
Bueno, Jr., president/owner of El Tigre Chili Products, in an interview with Sun.Star Davao during the Mindanao Trade Expo Foundation, Inc.
held last Aug.
13 to 20 at the Abreeza Ayala Mall, said that they started this initiative to provide a source of income for fellow kababayans who were affected by Typhoo Pablo.
"Sa hirap ng buhay pagkatapos kaming bagyohin, ito ang nakita naming solusyon upang malayo ang mga residente sa paggawa ng krimen.
At para na rin mabigyan sila ng trabaho," Bueno said.
Beuno said that most of our farmers were victims of the Typhoon while some are Indigenous Peoples .

"Sa simula konti pa lang kami but later on marami nang sumali sa aming grupo," Bueno said.
El Tigre Chili Products has been partnering with DA-Agribusiness and Marketing Assistance Division  for the promotion of their sili products.

Local chili producers are not only producing chili powder but also selling other by-products chili extract and chili paste, and are now producing other processed agricultural products as well like banana chips, danggit, turmeric and guyabano products, suka tuba, mango puree, and salabat.
"Okay naman ang market as of now.
Marami na kaming potential buyers pero kulang pa rin ang naiproproduce namin na mga supplies.
Limited muna ito sa aming mga direct buyers and local communities dito sa Oriental.
Bueno said that their 20 hectares hot chili plantation is not sufficient to meet the demands of the market.
They are currently supplying dried chili to Kablon Farms in Tupi, South Cotabato, for their spiced chocolate bars which are being exported in Malaysia.
Just this month, samples of 300 kgs of the dried chili varieties were sent to Australia for market test.
If it comes back positive, then they have a potential exporter in the future.
Farmers in the Davao Oriental get to harvest chili varieties once a week which in turn are bought by the sellers.
Farmers sell the fresh chilis at P50/kl.

El Tigre Chili Products are also processing the registration of their business under the Food and Drugs Administration  which would allow the micro small medium enterprises MSMEs) like them to penetrate the bigger market.
But Bueno also bared that the construction of a processing plant in Davao Oriental is underway.
"Akala namin kasi harvest at benta lang pero kelangan pala na may magandang handling din sa mga products," Bueno said.
"We were also taught how to dry and grind chili varieties upang hindi ito masira."
Mary Ann Balilaon, secretary of El Tigre Chili Products, also shared that their products have health benefits.
"Marami ito benefits to high blood and hyperacidity," Balilaon said.
   
Bueno said that the farmers have benefitted a lot in terms of their earning from the chili plantation ever since their business has started.
Prices of their products are the following; Chili powder , chili extract , chili paste , banana chips , bukayo , danggit , suka tuba , Turmeric , salabat , and Guyabano .
El Tigre Farms is located at Barangay Malibago in Cateel, Davao Oriental.

El Tigre Chili Products is set to participate in the Agrilink 2015 set October 15 to 17 to be held at the World Trade Center in Metro Manila.
"Sumasali talaga kami sa mga expo para mas makilala pa nila ang mga products namin," Bueno said.

Due to the favorable weather conditions in the Davao Oriental, local farmers are also planting falcata trees.
Although they would have to wait seven to 10 years before it can be sold in the market, still, this can be considered as an investment.
"Stable ang China and dito sa ating ang Butuan City for this industry," Bueno said.
Davoc: The organic chicken brand, Davoc: The organic chicken brandAce June Rell S.
Perez, ENVISIONING a sustainable market with organic products, Davao Organic Chicken or commonly known as Davoc leads the way in organic living.
Davoc is a naturally-grown chicken developed after two years of genetic research conducted by Dr.
Ernesto Gonzales, owner of Gonzales Nature Farm and a Gawad Saka 2014 awardee of the Department of Agriculture in Davao region.
"I envision that someday the market will be dominated with organic chicken for a sustainable living," he said.
Sustainable Nature Farming System, this is the Davocs core values applied in its way of farming with a holistic approach.
Located in Barangay Eden, Toril, Davoc chickens are raised free-range with no chemicals and antibiotics intakes within a three-hectare farm.
Management, nutrition, breed and biosecurity, these are the essentials of poultry industry that have been given focus by Davoc.
"Davoc is more than just a chicken supplier.
We do not just sell the chicken but we also introduce the system of how to raise naturally-grown chicken for sustainability purposes, a through this we create an impact to the society,201d Gonzales said on how to raise chicken the Davoc way.
Davoc partners with the Department of Agriculture through Agriculture Training Institute and non-government organizations  to conduct a two-day hands-on seminar and training on 201cSustainable Nature Farming System201d focusing on how to raise Davoc chicken to small farmers almost every month.
201cOne of the farm2019s advocacies is livelihood to small farmers.
We encourage the customers not just   buy Davoc chicken but also be trained in Davoc farm because we will introduce to them the sustainable way of raising chicken as well,201d he said urging the small farmers to go  natural 201cwe envision to see small farmers supplying food to consumers making the food supply chain with natural and healthy food.
It2019s what we call 201cFarm to table201d process,201d he added.
Davao takes pride in supplying hybrid-native chicken which has fast-growth characteristics.
201cDavoc looks exactly as a native chicken but it is more tender and tastier above all it grows faster.
For example, it takes six months  for a native  chicken to gain one kilo compared  to Davoc which only takes three months for it to weigh a kilo,201d he said.
With an average production of 700 chickens a month, Davoc with its distributor Century House of Spice supplies a number of hotel, supermarkets, livelihood and restaurant including Toryanos chicken house.
At present Davoc has 2,000 organic chicken breeders housed in over eight satellite farms in Toril, Calinan, Tagum, Compostela Valley, General Santos, Butuan, among others.

Meanwhile, Green Bounty, a marketing arm of the Gonzalez Nature Farm located in Barangay Eden, Toril, sells farm fresh, 100 percent naturally-grown vegetables as a way of introducing healthy living.
The organic farm sells only quality fresh garden salads, like romaine, green and purple leafy lettuces, salad tomatoes, cherry tomatoes, arugula, cucumber, and native pechay.
It also sells herbs of different kinds like arugula, sweet basil, Thai basil, oregano, tarragon, rosemary, dill, silantro, peppermint, and stevia.
All of the Green Bounty's products came from its farm, which strictly implements good agricultural practices  and sustainable nature farming system, and planted and grown by its small farmers partners.
"Our vegetables are distributed through Century House of Spice to Robinson's groceries and a number of hotels and restaurants like Marco Polo Hotel," said Luzviminda Gonzalez, Green Bounty owner and wife of Ernesto Gonzales.
Introducing the gift economy, Introducing the gift economyRuji Peter S.
Abat, WHILE agriculture ventures are mostly profit-oriented, a group in Davao City has been giving out vegetables for free while being bent on teaching children and adults alike on the methods of organic farming in a bid to promote backyard farming which could in turn create a sustainable food and natural medicine source for every household.
The group Organic Minds founded by Alter Picar and Freeda Lyf  organized the Sharing Garden project in 2012 to train people on the fundamentals of organic farming and gardening while at the same time donating the produce of their little backyard farm in Country Homes, Cabantian.
201cAng vision gyud sa Sharing Garden kay mag-establish ug community gardens ug para magraise ug awareness sa mga gardeners ug volunteers nga maghuna-huna sa food security ug sustainable nga environment ,201d Picar told Sun.Star Davao.
He also said that Sharing Garden, as the name suggests, aims to promote gift economy where the community can have access to free and organic food while also showing a strong stance against an otherwise capitalistic way of living where people have to pay for virtually everything they eat.
Lyf likened what they are doing to community building.
201cSince we want to build a community that could help others and we also want to establish a seed bank so that we could donate organic seeds to the community as counter against GMOs,201d he said.
For three years now, around 100 children and adults have visited Organic Minds2019 little garden to learn and do volunteer work.
Most of the visitors are the neighborhood kids but Picar said there were also foreign indie bands and non-government organizations who assisted them and at the same time learned from them.
Visitors are then shown instructional videos during film viewings and they also provided with reading materials.
Later on, the visitors will then conduct hands on work as they assist Organic Minds in cultivating crops in their garden.
"We teach the basics of organic farming like how to produce organic fertilizers, natural pesticides and fungicides.
We also teach them transplanting and how to make seeds sprout," Picar said.
Organic Minds is currently cultivating okra, eggplant, tomatoes, long beans, pechay, kang-kong and some culinary herbs which includes oregano, basil, peppermint, rosemary and turmeric which they claimed could also be used as alternative medicine.
But Lyf clarified that their crops are not 100 percent organic just organically grown 2013 meaning free from harmful pesticides, fungicides and other chemicals.
As expected, their neighbors find it odd that they are giving away vegetables and herbs for free.
"They don't get why we are a promoting a sharing or gift economy and at times they are hesitant to get some free vegetables.
But we try to let them understand that it is really free," Picar said.
But while the Sharing Gardens project is community-driven, Organic Minds refused to coordinate with the barangay officials in the area as Picar said they don't want to be involved in any politicking schemes of the local officials there.
"There was this one time when one of the barangay officials here visited our neighbor who also had the same project as ours.
That official took a picture of the garden and claimed that it was one of the initiatives of the barangay when that official didn't actually give any support to that garden.
Since then we didn't connect with them," Picar said.
Lyf, on the other hand, said that they are often misunderstood and it seems it has already been ingrained in the minds of the residents there that almost everything should be bought.
"It's that false sense of ownership and entitlement.
That is why some of the neighbors are still hesitant.
But for us, it is basically for sharing and as long as we have the time and manpower to maintain our crops, we will give them out for free whenever we have harvests," Lyf said.
Elaborating Lyf's concern on manpower, Picar said he hopes to have more volunteers who are willing to commit their time and effort citing that some of the volunteers just come and go.
Picar, however, remains optimistic especially that more children are getting involved in the Sharing Garden project saying, "At times, the children are the ones knocking on our doors and asking us if there are any activities in store for them.
We are pleased that kids, who are more active than the adults, have shown their intent to pursue our project."
Organic Minds is now eyeing another area within Country Homes where they could expand their organic farming so that they could provide a more healthy food choice for the residents in their area as well as mentor children and adults.
He added that a bigger land area would be the best way for them to develop their Sharing Garden project yet his only concern is that they don't have enough funds and patience to procure land and they don't want to be tangled in the bureaucracy that comes with it.

Until then, Organic Minds will continue to pursue their advocacy of promoting backyard farming and building a community where gift economy thrives.
"We envision that our sharing gardens would be replicated and more people could share our realization that we can't solely rely on the markets and pharmacies since we can actually grow our own food and medicine in our backyards," Picar said.

Rebirth of Bahay Bata under Tulay Foundation, Rebirth of Bahay Bata under Tulay FoundationIan Ocampo Flora, A BEACON of hope now shines for street children in Pampanga as Angeles Bahay Bata Center is now reborn under the management of Father Rocky Evangelista's Tuloy Foundation, Inc.
The facility will soon open its doors not just to street children, as according to Fr.
Evangelista, the facility is open to any youth needing support.
The Angeles Bahay Bata Center is an institution in Central Luzon that seeks to uplift the welfare of "street children".

This, as the facility was again presented under new management on Monday.
The event was attended by Clark Development Corporation president Arthur P.
Tugade, Carmen McTavish as representative for Rotary Club of Clark Centennial and Mayor Edgardo Pamintuan among others.
Until recently, the Bahay Bata Center was managed by the Rotary Club of Clark Centennial members.
However, according to the deed of donation, the organization could no longer manage it, and thus transferred the responsibility, management and operation to Tuloy Foundation.
It should be noted that Rotary has patterned its formula of taking care of street children on Tuloy Foundation2019s comprehensive rehabilitation program for street children.
Tuloy Foundation, Inc.
is a non-stock, non-profit corporation based in Muntinlupa City and started by Father Evangelista in 1993.
It is a comprehensive rehabilitation program for street children in Manila that has achieved outstanding success and worldwide recognition since its inauguration.

The Tuloy Project is designed to help poor and abandoned children to regain self worth and dignity, giving them a chance for a better life; acquire Christian values and habits for a decent, humane and Christian life; and develop the skills and training for self-reliance and integration into society.
Mayor Pamintuan has transferred the management of the Bahay Bata Center to Tuloy Foundation under a usufruct agreement.
 The lot, where the center is located, was donated to the local government in November 16, 2000 by Timog Silangan Development Corporation.
Mayor Pamintuan is very optimistic that the project will be a further success under Fr.
Evangelista.
Set in its own grounds, the center has a three-storey building and has four spacious dormitories that can house 60 children.
However, Fr.
Evangelista said that they need the support of the private and business sectors in the city to fully operate the facility to its full capacity.

Fr.
Evangelista notes that they have tapped help of Clark Development Corporation and locators like Luen Thai for their support.
 
Taking the lead was Laus Group of Companies  chairman Levy P.
Laus, who initiated the donation of one Haima FStar for the use of the foundation and its other logistical requirements.
 
The donation was formally presented by Maria Theresa Laus to Fr.
Evangelista.
Mrs.
Laus said that they are in full support of the Salesian initiatives in Pampanga adding that they hope to work on common initiatives through LGC's corporate social responsibility programs.

Prominent Architect Andy Gulapa is the lead architect for the future projects of the foundation in Pampanga.
 
Gulapa has volunteered his services to the foundation after knowing of its worthy advocacies.
 He said that helping the foundation will further bring much needed Christian charity where it is most needed.
"I believe in the project of Fr.
Evangelista and I have been in contact with other people to help the foundation.
 The more children we could help, the better," Gulapa, a well known supporter of Christian advocacy programs in Candaba and Angeles City, said.
Fr.
Evangelista was quick to note that the "Tuloy experience" impresses that fact that street children are not treated as marginalized and different.

"In fact they are treated as family.
 It is our objective to give them the needed well-rounded formation and skills so that they can be able to fully care for themselves," Fr.
Evangelista said.
This claim is not surprising as Tuloy Foundation's formula emphasizes Christian values, discipline, vocational skills and training for future productive employment.

Following a six-phase program, the street children are gradually and systematically rehabilitated.
Through apprenticeship and on the job training the children are exposed to the working world to prepare them for future employment.
