Pilgrim's note, Pilgrim's notePILGRIM is defined as someone who travels to a holy place to search for the meaning of life and faith.
In our context, we are indeed pilgrims in our way to soul searching.
Last August 28-31, we went to Lucban Quezon, a three-hour drive away from Metro Manila to visit our friend Jervie de Guzman, a former seminarian and now a successful businessman.
Also, it is a time for us to relax and reflect from very tiring months.
As a school instructor, we live in an arena wherein we train our students to be competent individuals and make them nation builders by sharpening their minds, giving them weapon to combat the challenges in life.
Literally, it is a battle between ignorance and knowledge.
As we go along in our journey to Lucban, we reflect on the things that we met.
Those things deepened our faith and changed our perceptions in life.
So here are the things that we reflect on our way to Lucban.
* Delayed flight
Before we leave Iloilo, we met one of the things that really irritated the travelers -- flight delay.
Hearing the announcement from a person in authority seemed like hearing a politician's promises.
Lots of passengers got irritated, while others curse the receptionist.
Some of us slept and watched the basketball game on TV.
Reflections:  Flight delays are not new to us and I think it is normal to get upset in that event.
Charles Swindoll reminded me of something that I carry every time there's an event that will trigger your negative reaction.
He said, "Life is 10% what happens to you and 90% how you react to it."
Really, we sometimes tend to forget who we are and what we are when those things happen.
We cannot control the things that will happen along the way; we cannot blame the receptionist that announced the flight delays and we cannot blame God if this thing happened to us.
Let us think rationally.
It really pays off if we rationalize because the more we blame, the more the situation becomes worse and others will look at us as uneducated.
Patience is really out of the context nowadays.
What really caught my attention is the old man who smiles at the receptionist not because of the receptionist's pretty face but because he understands that those things happened beyond their control and if all of us have that mindset, "what a wonderful world," just like what Louis Armstrong said in his song.
* Zigzag road
After a five-hour flight delay, we took a ride and went straight to Lucban.
We met a zigzag road that led us to Lucban.
It's a quite difficult road to drive especially for the new ones but for the expert, it's easy as ABC.
Reflections:  Zigzag road is similar to our lives -- full of obstacles or hurdles.
There are some changes in your plans and the more you encounter those obstacles, the more you become stronger to face the challenges in your life.
Life doesn't make sense if we can't face those obstacles.
You cannot call it life if you try to evade those hurdles that block your way.
Those hurdles measure your strength as a person and the more you face it, the more you become stronger than you think.
So the next time you see those zigzag roads, always keep in mind that "this too shall pass."
* Mt.
Banahaw
The first thing that comes into our mind upon entering Majayjay is the Mt.
Banahaw, a 7, 119ft above mean sea level that is considered the holy mountain and popular among the pilgrims and mountain climbers.
It really gives you an impression of the majestic creation of God.
The mountain gives you an impression that we are lucky to have these landforms because we are blessed by the gift of nature.
The mountain offers spiritual and serene ambiance, giving you time to reflect and meditate.
Reflections: Mountains are often associated by the word "problem" because upon seeing it, we sometimes tend to think that we cannot overcome it.
Let us think in a positive way -- that mountains in our life are a challenge that we must overcome.
It is conquering the Goliath that crosses our way.
Climbing the mountain implies hard work and learning new skill.
I still remember how the Iloilo, once known as the simple city, became one of the most livable cities in the Philippines because of its innovations and dynamic improvement in terms of business and facilities.
No doubt that the city administrators and the government of Iloilo City overcome the challenges that hinder their way to progress and now, they dubbed it as "tiger economy." Thanks to the leadership of Hon.
Jed Patrick Mabilog and Sen.
Franklin Drilon and also other city administrators who catapult the city from simple city to a progressive city.

* Kamay ni Hesus Shrine
One of our brothers, Jervie de Guzman, toured us in Kamay ni Hesus shrine in Lucban, Quezon.
It is also a popular pilgrimage site for the devotee and a popular Holy Week destination.
Healing mass is also conducted at the chapel.
One of the main attractions in the shrine is the 305 steps before you reach the 50-foot statue of the Ascending Christ.
The image of ascending Christ welcomes you to his arms, embracing the sinners and the lost one into his loving arms.
Reflections: We tend to forget to thank our Lord in every great moment we have and we always remember him in times of our troubles.
During that time, one of our brothers is in his soul searching journey and he keeps on asking himself, why those things happened to me? Why is it that I can't go to my next destination? Bro.
Jervie answered him: "Kaya ka nagkaganyan kasi may isang bagay ka pa na kailangang ayusin at ang Diyos ay tutulong sa iyo para ayusin ang mga bagay na sasagabal sa daan mo ."
God never abandon his children.
Every time we encounter some problems in our way, always remember to pray.
We may not receive the exact answer but that answer is best for us.
Let us have humility in our hearts, humility that will bring us in peace and into his arms.
Wherever we go, we always leave a mark in that place and that place leaves a mark in our hearts.
The mark that is embedded in our hearts signifies the place that gave us a lesson to learn, an experience to remember and a challenge that we face after we leave.
Every journey teaches us a lesson, which will help us to be strong and wise with hope in our hearts.

2015 Korean Film Festival highlights depth of human relationships, 2015 Korean Film Festival highlights depth of human relationshipsTHE Korean Cultural Center in the Philippines  and the Embassy of the Republic of Korea will be opening its annual Korean Film Festival this September to October with the theme 201cStrings of Affinity.201d
In cooperation with the Film Development Council of the Philippines , the Film Cultural Exchange Program, Korean Film Council, Korea Copyright Commission, Korea Tourism Organization, SM Cinema and SM Supermalls., the film festival will be featuring seven films that showcase the depths of human relationships in different scenarios.
The film festival will kick off in SM Lanang Premiere in Davao from September 17 to 20 and will be stopping by SM City Iloilo from September 24 to 27.

From October 1 to 4, the film festival will move to SM City Cebu and will have its final run in SM Megamall in Manila from October 8 to 11.
The Films
One of the top grossing films in Korea, 201cThe Thieves201d is about a group of South Korean thieves led by Popie  and Hong Kong thieves commissioned by the master thief Macao Park  to steal the diamond 201cTear of the Sun201d.


Having their own special skills in stealing, the two teams work together in the biggest heist of their lives, but little do they know that the 10 thieves all have their own agendas.
In 201cMiss Granny201d, the 74-year-old widow Oh Mal-Soon is transformed back to her 20-year-old self after having her photo taken at a mysterious photo studio.


With no one recognizing her, Mal-soon decides to make the most out of this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

She renames herself Oh Doo-ri and decides to pursue her dream of becoming a singer together with her grandson Ji-ha who doesn2019t realize that she is his grandmother.
Han Hyo-Joo plays the role of Yoon-Joo in 201cCold Eyes." 
She is a newly accepted member of the surveillance team in the police department.


Together with the team2019s leader Detective Hwang , they are tasked to take down James'  bank robbing criminal group.

However, the surveillance team is having a hard time to track down the robbers due to their masks and efficiency during the heist.
Set in the 1950s, 201cFront Line201d tells the story of Kang Eun-pyo  who is sent to join the Alligator Company at Aerok Hill.


Upon arriving at Aerok Hill he is surprised to see his old friend Kim Soo-hyuk , who was missing and presumed dead, alive and an officer of the Alligator Company.

Soo-Hyuk is now a ruthless officer and does not always follow commands from the South Korean army.

The situation within the Alligator Company raises many questions in the eyes of Eun-Pyo: South Korean soldiers wear North Korean uniforms inside due to the cold weather; a young officer leads the troops as a captain; the sudden reappearance of Soo-hyuk; and a secret communication box wherein North and South Korean soldiers can exchange letters and presents to each other.
Based on a true story, 201cHope201d tells the story of a family coping up with the tragic incident that happened to their daughter.


A young girl named So-won  was on her way to school when she was sexually assaulted and nearly beaten to death by a drunken old stranger.

As a result of the incident, she suffered from both physical injuries and severe emotional trauma.
As they continue to recover on the incident while pursuing justice, the family also begins to strengthen their relationship.
A romantic comedy film, 201cMarriage Blue201d tells the misadventures of four engaged couples who are having second thoughts about marriage.


The first couple, Tae-Kyu  and Joo-Young , is in the middle of planning their wedding when Tae-Kyu discovers that Joo-Young is a divorcee.

Tae-Kyu feels betrayed making him think twice about their marriage.
2PM2019s Ok Taecyeon plays the role of Won-Cheol, who is about to marry his longtime girlfriend So-Mi.

A few days before their wedding date, So-Mi travels to Jeju Island where she meets the tour guide and web comic writer Kyung-soo  and she falls in love with him.

The third couple is about an old bachelor, Gun-Ho, and his young foreigner fianc\xe9e Vika.
Gun-Ho is afflicted with impotency caused by his insecurities and stress thinking that Vika is only marrying him to obtain Korean citizenship.

The last couple, Dae-Bok and Yi-ra, is about to have a shotgun wedding due to Yi-Ra2019s pregnancy.

In the middle of their wedding preparations, Dae-Bok is starting to think twice about the marriage because of Yi-Ra2019s attitude so he tries to convince her to postpone the wedding.
Shot in documentary style, 201cDuresori: Voice of the East201d is based on a true story of Seul-Gi and Ah-Reum who are third year students at the National High School of the Traditional Arts.

During their final summer they are forced to join the school choir in order to fill the remaining requirement.

A conflict also arises between Ms.
Ham, their instructor who majored in western music, and the students, who majors in traditional Korean music.

However, as Ms.
Ham and the students begin to grow interest in each musical forms, the school decide to cancel the class2019s annual summer concert.

Life as a pro, Life as a pro
Tancontian Diao
Karina V.
Canedo, ERIC Tancontian Diao, aka Erick Montre, is a professional singer/composer/record producer and part time host.
Davao-born and raised, he is currently based in Osaka.

He's been around in the entertainment world for the past 30 years.
He travelled to Hong Kong and Indonesia as a lead singer of different bands.
He was a stage TV and concert hall performer at Holiday Inn Hotel, Philippine Plaza, Sheraton Hotel, Dusit Hotel, Araneta Coliseum, Philippine Icc, Folk arts Theater, Eat Bulaga, GMA SUPER SHOW and more.

As a singer, he's been through a lot as he already performed with some big names in the Philippines such as Jun Polistico, Lovely Rivero, Richard Reynoso, Lloyd Umali, Chad Borja, 747 Band, Pilita Corales, Max Surban, Yoyoy Villame, Arthur Manuntag, WADAB and a lot more.

He had also performed together with world renowned artists Christopher Cross, Peabo Bryson and Paul Williams.
"It just happened that I met then in a concert, then jamming.
Ang feeling dili kabayran ug kwarta ," Diao said.
He said he performs a wide variety of music from jazz down to standard, rock and roll, pop disco and more.

His music influences are The Earth, Wind and Fire, Stylistics, Manhattans, Barry White, the Temptations, Four Tops, Lou Rawls, Barry White, Matt Blanco, Chuck Berry and More.

In 1994, he was lucky to become a member of a boy band Flippers 3rd generation under Alpha records.
This is the group who popularized the song Di Ako Iiyak.
As a composer, he started writing songs since his high school years in the early 80's and in 2004, some of his songs were aired by ABS-CBN during the Araw ng Dabaw.
The song was entitled "Ciudad sa Dabaw" and performed by Yoyoy Idol Suave.
Another song composition "Magkaisa sa Mundo" was used for Pasko Fiesta ni Mayor Rody Duterte performed by WADAB artists.
Another song still by him, "Ikaw ang Miss Universe Sa Puso ko," was used for the Mutya ng Dabaw 2004, which he performed himself.

Six years ago, he released his self produced CD under Wadab records an Indie Label in Japan and it became a huge success.
He followed this up in 2011 with "Girl from Ternopil." 
Diao is a son of a carpenter, who is proud of having helped build the newer building of Kapitan Tomas elementary school way back 1970s.
His mother was a stay at home mom.
He grew up in Catalunan Grande.
He discovered his talent when he was in grade school way back 1975, and since then, he involved himself in every contest or in school programs.

Eric was only 15 years old when he started competing in amateur singing contests.
He had his big break when he won as runner up for the Super Wheel Search for Singing Stars for the year's 1983 and 1984.
He also became a three-week champ of Bagong Kampeon in 1986 and a grand finalist of Pasikatan sa Trese with Imelda Papin in 1994.
Diao remembers how he struggled hard as a local artist.

"In Davao, there are a lot of talents but then, there are very few opportunities for us.
That is the reason I have to try my luck in Manila back in the early 80's and luckily, I've got an offer to work in Olongapo in 1985 and since then nagtuloy-tuloy na and I would like to take opportunity to thank my brother Ronnie for helping me when I was still struggling during my early years in my music life," Diao said.

Diao said that his brother Ronnie had a band in Olongapo and it became his training ground on music.
After his brother's band was disbanded, he was hired as a regular band member/singer at El Camarote bar in Holiday Inn Manila.
It was in 1988, when his band got an offer to perform at Kyoto.
 
"Well, ever since, I was always dreaming about music and I just want to fulfill it in it in the land of the rising sun.
As we all knew if you say Japan, sabi nila andito na halos lahat but it took me a lot of courage, hardwork, patience, sacrifice and hearthaches before I consider myself as a successful singer/composer/producer in Japan," he said.
He said that Davao city formed a big part of where he had honed his skills and talent that is why he wants to go back here someday, it's part of his dream to share his original compositions to the new pool of young talents.

Diao was born May 12, 1966.
He is the youngest of eight siblings of the family.
 He is currently living in Osaka, Japan.
 He is married to Kumiko Hashimoto for 17 years and he is now a Japanese national.
They have no kids but they have a dog, their eight-year-old little angel they named Brutus, a golden retriever.

The right over Davao's water, The right over Davao's water
 DAVAO.
A motorcycle driver gets a hand to bring his motorcycle loaded with farm produce across Upian River in Barangay Marilog, Davao City.

Tyrone Velez, THE Earth we have is covered with water.
But only two percent of this is fresh water, in which two-thirds are frozen and one-third is surface water and groundwater.
The scarcity also affects us in Davao City and the rest of Davao Region.
For this reason, the Ateneo de Davao University held a Right to Water Conference on September 7 to discuss with stakeholders from environment groups, public utilities corporations, business groups, indigenous peoples, academe, religious, lawyers and the consuming public the balance between utilizing and protecting the vital resource.
Protection
The main threat to water aside from the impact of climate change is the 201ca problem of perspective201d as Professor Lourdes Simpol from Ateneo's Tropical Institute for Climate Studies  points out.
201cWe have a very populated people in a very small area.
But there's a matter of looking at water resources, do they just look at what they can profit without looking at the upstream like IP communities and farms and at the downstream such as lakes,201d she pointed out.
Environment groups such as Interface for Development Interventions  and the Save Mainit River Campaign based in Nabunturan showed the threats of agribusiness and mining affecting rivers and biodiversity in their areas.
IDIS' executive director Mary Ann Fuertes pointed out that even banned substances such as DDT can still be traced in plantations, and she warns the continued use of toxic chemicals in plantations near watersheds could contaminate our source of drinking water permanently.
201cThe examples of other countries show that they abandon groundwater as it takes years of natural treatment,201d she told reporters during the conference.
But for now, Fuertes said our water source is safe but 201cif we tap surface water there is the threat of contamination from agricultural chemicals.201d
Nabunturan Councilor Alexander Agustin from the Save Mainit Campaign also raised concern that mining activities have encroached on the national conservation area that is Mainit.
He points out the value of Mainit River to the provinces of Compostela Valley and Davao del Norte.
201cMainit is part of the headwater basin for Manat River, which is one of the main tributaries of the Agusan River.
It is the source of biodiversity, natural medicines and natural capital for our ecotourism,201d warns Agustin.
Fuertes and Agustin both said it's been an uphill battle to lobby with local governments and agencies to strictly enforced laws to protect water systems.
201cWe hope the government would declare the whole area of our drinking source as a watershed protection area,201d said Fuertes.
Agustin has lobbied with provincial officials to enforce the protection of Mainit as National Integrated Protected Areas System  area and expansion of this area.
But he finds opposition from miners who want to classify some of the conservation area as part of the minahang bayan.
Mining's threat to water, according to Philippine Misereor Partnership's Edel Garingan, consists of exploiting water for their mineral processing, deforestation that leads to defiling of water resources.
Misereor has launched its 2Big campaign, a play on the word tubig, to highlight the need to oppose the Tampakan Copper Project in Southern Mindanao that threatens farms and rivers.
Garingan points out that the Tampakan Project requires digging holes up to 785 feet deep and 500 hectares wide, big enough to displace 80,000 farmers in South Cotabato province alone and affect three main river sources including Taplan, Alip, and Padada.
Utilizing water
The conference also gave the proponents of the Apo Agua Davao City Bulk Water Project a venue to present the rationale of their project that will source water from the Tamugan River.
The project is a joint venture between the power company Aboitiz Group with the Davao City Water District and JV Angeles Corporation.
Aboitiz' First Vice President Manuel Orig explained the P10-billion project targets Tamugan River as the new source of water for Davao City in order to rest the dependency on the city's ten groundwater sources and reduce cost in the process.
Stakeholders raised concern on the impact of climate change to the water resources as well as the possibility of the rising cost of water using this new technology.
Apo Agua's engineer Ronald Munoz assured that the water supply will cost lower from the current P17 per cubic liter to P12, and it targets to serve a growing city with a projected population of 1.7 million by 2019.
Conflict
With such issues from utilities to investments affecting water sources, there are these words of caution from the Ateneo community.
Ateneo's Fr.
Dan McNamara from the Environment Studies Program noted the niche of the Philippines is it ranks among the top five in biodiversity areas.
But he warns of the dangers of agribusiness.
201cTo wipe them out for monocropping is not the way to proceed.
For monocropping is a capitalistic motivation using artificial means,201d he warned.
McNamara is also initiating a monitoring scheme in the University on Aboitiz' Therma South coal-fired power plant in Binugao, Toril, in which environment groups raised concern on the possible air and water pollution brought by this venture.
The plant's operation has been moved from this year to 2016.
201cAboitiz is profit-driven, but not necessarily.
We citizens have to step forward,201d he said.
Prof.
Simpol also urged leaders to strictly stop mining activities.
201cThere are No-Go Zones , but there are still existing MPSAs operating, and we have an over-saturation of mining operations.
We already have a diminishing forest cover, personally, we have to stop everything and make an inventory on how much forest cover we have.201d
Atty.
Romeo Cabarde from Ateneo's Community Engagement and Advocacy Council said 201ca statement will be drafted to highlight the people's right to water as a right to life, which should be tied as an important agenda for the 2016 elections.201d
University President Fr.
Jose Tabora rounded up the discussions with his criticism on mining and other investments as inevitable in the process of development.
201cLet us look at Surigao, Benguet and other areas and see the great environment destruction and great harm.
It now threatens us here in Southern Mindanao,201d Tabora warned.
Tabora echoed Pope Francis' encyclical Laudito Si to take care of the environment.
The Pope mentioned that 201ccontrol of water by large multinational businesses may become a major source of conflict in this century.201d
201cWe're not talking here about the right to have gold or copper, but the right to water that we all must decide.
If we stand for our right to water and food not only against foreigners but also against Filipino capitalist,201d he urged.

OUT-OF-THE-BOX BEATS.
With top-notch talent and a bit of luck, Alexander Cabig Jr.
topped 201cBeatbox Battle: The Uprising 2014,201d making him Cebu City2019s top beatboxer.

Brighter Giant Lantern Festival this 2015, Brighter Giant Lantern Festival this 2015Ian Ocampo Flora, THERE is no stopping this year's Pampanga Giant Lantern Festival scheduled on December 19 at its long time venue, host Robinsons Starmills Pampanga as 11 barangays will join this year's competition that aims to promote the popular cottage industry into the national and international scene.
Giant Lantern Festival Foundation president Alfrito Mah said that the participants this year are an improvement from the previous competitions as more and more barangays are joining in the festival.
 
Some P3 million has been allotted to help the festival and as way of support to the participants for this year's competition.
Now at its 107th year, the festival remains strong and vibrant.
City Tourism Officer Ching Pangilinan was quick to note that the festival is a testament to community involvement and the bayanihan spirit.

The lanterns are made and funded by the community, aside from the funding subsidy coming from the city government.
Lantern makers, electricians and ordinary folk volunteer time and effort to make the lanterns beautiful and up to competition standards.
 
This is not a surprise since the winning barangay takes the honor of having produced the best lantern for the season and each award is a bragging right against competing barangays.
Mayor Edwin Santiago said that they are also focusing on helping the industry penetrate the international market through more quality made lanterns.
 
This is in response to the current situation in which lanterns made in ordinary lantern makers could not penetrate the international market due to safety issues.
 
Despite of this, the city's lanterns, locally known as Parul Sampernandu, have been exhibited abroad.
Aside from China, the Parul Sampernandu has been in Hollywood in 1993, a year before, at the World Expo in Spain, the Philippines' embassies and consulates in Canada, Malaysia, Poland, Russia, Thailand and the United States, among others.

The city's lanterns had also decorated areas such Austrian landmarks as the Rathausplatz and Ethnology Museum in Vienna, as well as the Stadtturm in Innsbruck, including the Lord Mayor's House in Dublin and the Good Shepherd Cathedral in Singapore.
What started as a lantern contest to honor and thank then President Manuel Quezon for converting Mount Arayat into a tourist resort had turned into a yearly spectacle.

The Giant Lantern Festival has become an annual festival held in December  in this city.

The popularity of the festival has earned the province the nickname "Christmas Capital of the Philippines".

The GLF is a competition of 10 to 12 feet height lanterns that are made by barangays with standing lantern-making traditions.
The award is seen as a recognition from atop of the significance of the lantern industry here in helping local tourism and craftsmanship of local craftsmen and artisans.

This city's Giant Lantern Festival has been named first runner-up for Best Tourism Event, Arts and Culture category city level, during the National Pearl Awards held in Legazpi City in 2013.
 
In 2014, the Giant Lantern Festival  committee has made another historic first with the release of the first ever coffee table book chronicling the Giant Lantern Festival and a children's book on the world famous tourist attraction.
This year, the competition aims to draw more crowd to the annual event.
 Festival Committee chair Ernesto Cunanan is optimistic that this year's event will add another dazzling color to the proud tradition of lantern making in the capital city.

Bee stings, research that makes you go 'huh?' win Ig Nobels, Bee stings, research that makes you go 'huh?' win Ig Nobels
Michael Smith, left, accepts his trophy from Dudley Herschbach, the 1986 Nobel Laureate in Chemistry, while being honored during a performance at the Ig Nobel Prize ceremony at Harvard University, in Cambridge, Mass., Thursday, Sept.
17, 2015.

BOSTON 2014 A Cornell University graduate student who allowed honeybees to sting him in 25 places and a group of scientists who concluded it's possible for one man to father 888 children are among the winners of this year's Ig Nobels, which honor humorous scientific achievement.
Michael Smith estimates he was stung about 200 times during his 2012 honeybee study.
His conclusion: The three most painful places to get stung are the nostril, the upper lip and the male sex organ.
"A sting to the nostril is so painful it's like a whole body experience," he said.
Other winners being honored Thursday night at the 25th-annual ceremony at Harvard University include a trio of linguists who discovered that almost every language in the world uses the word "huh" for clarification in a conversation and researchers who found that corporate CEOs take less professional risk if directly affected by a natural disaster as a child.
Real Nobel laureates hand out the prizes, and winners receive a cash award: a Zimbabwean 10 trillion dollar bill, the equivalent of a couple of U.S.
dollars.
Smith shared the Ig Nobel for physiology and entomology with Justin Schmidt, an adjunct professor at the University of Arizona who devised a pain scale for insect stings.
His advice: Do not get stung by the tarantula hawk, a nasty looking wasp found in the Southwestern U.S.
with a stinger about a quarter-inch long.
"The sting is entirely nontoxic but hurts like the bejesus," Schmidt said.
Mark Dingemanse and two colleagues at the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics in Nijmegen, Netherlands, won the Ig Nobel for literature for determining that the word "huh" is used in languages around the world, including some of the most obscure.
"A system for fixing misunderstandings is clearly a crucial part of language," he said.
"'Huh?' is one element of this system: It's the basic error signal people fall back on if all else fails."
Elisabeth Oberzaucher and a colleague at the University of Vienna in Austria won the mathematics prize for figuring out whether it was possible for Moroccan Emperor Moulay Ismael to have sired 888 children 2014 and that's the conservative estimate.
Ismael fathered the children during a roughly 30-year reign that ended in 1727.
It sounds exhausting, but the bottom line is, yes, it is possible to father that many children if he had sex daily.
The study found that it could be done with as few as 65 women, not the 500 in his harem.
Raghu Rau, professor of finance at the University of Cambridge, and his colleagues won for their study that found business leaders more directly affected by natural disasters as children took less risk during their careers.
Rau uses Apple as an example.
Late CEO Steve Jobs, who lived through a deadly landslide near his home in San Francisco as a child, ran the company conservatively.
His successor, Tim Cook, witnessed few fatalities despite regular tornadoes while growing up in Alabama and has made more risky business decisions.
"Think of yourself as a member of a board of directors: When you try to hire a CEO, do you want a risk taker or not?" Rau said.
As usual, the winners were thrilled with the honor.
"Sometimes these crazy things provide a lot of insight," said Schmidt, the bug guy.

A life lived with God, A life lived with GodChristine Joice C.
Cudis, TODAY, students are educated in a more advanced way, encouraging them to practice an open mind On sensitive issues such as religion.

As a result, most of the millenials show acts of doubt when confronted with the topic of God's existence.
With this pattern in hand, we can ask: Does acquiring heightened intelligence really translate to realizing that God is not that useful at all? 
Maybe for some, it's a yes.
But for Jeffer Joy Orteza, a Cum Laude graduate from Humanities Division of the Ateneo de Davao University and a dedicated member of the Jehovah's Witness Church, it's definitely the other way around.
"I believe that a truly intelligent being should acknowledge that there can be no intellect without God's presence; that the cause cannot be irrelevant to the effect.
God is the Great Cause of every intelligent effect that this universe sees.
Discounting him from this world's equation is, therefore, impossible." said Orteza.
She is also aware of the prejudice on intelligent people that they should not believe in anything spiritual because it is too much of a leap of faith, "in reality, those who do not believe in what transcends the physical universe is taking a plunge to irrationality." she clarified.
Orteza grew up in a Christian household of Jehovah's Witnesses.
They had Bible study sessions where she learned so many things about the world- why things are not perfect now and why that does not mean that God is not doing anything about it.
While her family's spirituality has certainly played a huge role in her beliefs, she did not choose to become a Jehovah's Witness until the age of 14 when she was sure that she fully understood what she believes in.

"Choosing to live and think as a Christian has its challenges, especially when I get to meet people who do not view spiritual things the way I do," she said.

She and her family takes part in different avenues of sharing Bible-based messages--either by distributing the Awake! and Watchtower journals or by encouraging people to visit their website, www.jw.org.

Being an Atenean, people could immediately think that she comes from a well off family, but she's not.

If not for the full scholarship granted by the institution, she would never have had been able to get her Bachelor's degree.

In fact, she can recall one of the darkest  part of her life was during her 2nd year high school.
Her family had to transfer to a house that did not have the luxury of running water or electricity.
For six years and 11 months, her family had to live with all the inconvenience.
Her school uniforms never got the chance to experience being ironed, and dinner was always by the candlelight.
Every day, they had to fetch water with pails from their neighbor.

Naturally, since they had no electricity, she had to rely on newspapers for news.
Since she could not afford to buy daily, she relies on the scraps of information that she would find on the front pages of newspapers hanging on newsstands then read more in the school library.

"The world is not beautiful now, and I do not disagree.
But just because things are ugly now does not mean that God is useless.
We need to remember that we, humans, are simply tinier than drops of water in God's eyes." Orteza said.
Indeed, we are the bearers of our future and it is up to us whether what to believe in and how to live our lives.
But certainly in Orteza's case, a life lived with God is a life lived accordingly.

Liyang: Weaving the Ata2019s future, Liyang: Weaving the Ata2019s future
Their native dresses may be faded, but the pride in what these represent shines through.

Ace June Rell S.
Perez, LIYANG, and how the intricately traditional basket weaves the Ata tribe2019s future.
Culture preservation, how the Ata tribe in Sitio Pegalahan, Barangay Pandaitan, Paquibato District, Davao City pass their cultural practices and authentic products to the next generation through weaving.
Liyang is an Ata word referring to a multipurpose basket which comes in many sizes and designs crafted by the women of the Ata tribe.
It is primarily made out of 201cBagtok201d, a family of the Bamboo tree usually found in the forest, Uway  and abaca.
More than just a basket, Liyang weaves the picture of Ata tribe in the next generation.

201cThis is authentically made by my tribe and our descendants shall know how to master the art of Liyang making.
This is part of the rich culture Ata tribe has and the best way of passing it to next generation is through the youth,201dConchita L.
Maclaan, 53, vice president of the Tribal Women Organic Village of the Ata tribe and a mother of seven said in vernacular.
Teaching the youth how to make such Liyang will define the tribe2019s future.

Learning the art of Liyang weaving from the young age of 8 years old, Maclaan shared that her parents did not teach her, she learned by watching and doing as she observes.
201cNagsugod ko otso anyos pero nientrada na gyud ko sa paghimo og Liyang apil na sa pagpanguha og Bagtok sa kalasangan mga dise otso ako anyos ,201d she said.
Paggama of Liyang 
From the main Barangay where the tribe lives to the forest where 201cbagtok201d, the major material for Liyang can be sourced, the Ata women will walk on a rough trail to the 201ckalasangan201d or forest, which translates to a four-hour walk .
Normally, they will get around eight tall 201cbagtoks201d from the forest.
This is enough to make five big Liyangs, which can be sold at P300 each.
A big Liyang takes three days to make.
201cUsually we go to the forest in two to five individuals but sometimes I go just by myself with my dagger, and basket.
This is our additional source of income aside from farming, it is more a way of livelihood,201d Maclaan said.
Liyang can be a basket where one puts grains of rice, vegetables, fruits, corn, among others.
The biggest Liyang is called Bukog while smallest one is named as Tahakan, which can be sold at only P10 to P20 each.
A Liyang with a cover is called Loban.
201cWe use Rattan or Uway as our thread and Puthaw or a narrow metal as some sort of needle in weaving Liyang,201d she narrated.
According to Maclaan, only three of them in their place are really into commercial Liyang making as other women in their area are only making for their own use.

201cBut we are encouraging them to continue doing it until they master the craft so they can sell it at the city and even to other market outside Davao,201d she added.
They were able to sell during the Kadayawan Festival, she said, they also display during special events for the indigenous peoples while Davao-based women2019s organizations order in bulk.
201cWe do it carefully and artistically to sustain our relationship with our customers,201d she said.
From the ancestors to the descendants
Liyang is intrinsically Ata and is a silent witness of the tribe2019s rich culture.
201cWe cannot imagine Ata life and culture without Liyang,201d Maclaan shared, thus, they are letting the young watch them weave the baskets.
 201cI2019d like the young Ata to learn the art of weaving Liyang the way how I learned it from my parents, they never taught me but they allowed me to learn by simply letting me watch them weave,201d she said.
Her18-year-old youngest daughter now knows how, but she still has to master the craft.
201cWe allow them to learn from us by just letting them watch us but one of our biggest challenges is how to convince them to do it with mastery because sometimes they get discouraged.
Mostly because weaving bagtok can wound the weaver,201d she said, a fact her daughter knows so well.
But she is confident that her daughter is learning and will soon pass on the craft to her offsprings.
Aside from Liyang the Ata Tribe also capable of producing Banig, Nigo, Tribal costumes, Baliog or accessories made of beads, among others.
Liyang, in weaving these baskets and passing on the craft, the Ata tribe likewise weaves their culture and passes this on to the generation next.

Cudis, A TOTAL of 15 chefs from the top hotels, restaurants, and catering services from the Davao Region, Cagayan de Oro, and General Santos gathered at the Davao Convention and Trade Center on Thursday to face off in the Elite Chef Challenge of Unilever's Chefmanship Academy.
The chefmanship academy is the-first-of-its-kind seminar/workshop initiative in Southeast Asia.

The academy was developed by Unilever Food Solutions  to meet the diverse needs of the food industry's market players to enhance skill sets for service efficiency, customer satisfaction, and business profitability.
The challenge is the highlight of the 8th leg of the Chefmanship Academy in the Philippines.

Alex Destriza of Marco Polo went home with the bacon as he came out the champion, winning a P20,000 cash prize.
Although already in the industry for 18 years, he still did not expect to win knowing that he was competing with the top guns in Mindanao.

"It was really overwhelming," Destriza said, saying he enjoyed the competition.
"The contest itself is an inspiration.
I dedicate my win to God and my family.
Also, I am thankful for the support of my Marco Polo family and mentors," he added.
According to the judges: Jonathan Brando Santos, Senior Chef of UFS; Anton Abad, Executive chef of Vikings, and BJ Carreon, National sales manager of Unilever, it was a one tough competition to judge and the scores were really close.
In fact, the two runner-ups both received a score of 9.23 percent.
Rhyan Bahi-an from Chippens and Edward Buas from Waterfront Hotel won P10,000 each.
  
Executive Chef of USF, Joanne Limoanco-Gendrano said, "Consumers today has heightened their quality demand, with this expectation, the chefs must also continue to innovate with their dishes."
Gendrano added that creativity should be practiced in plating the food without losing the authenticity of its taste since a lot of consumers now are meticulous about what they eat.
Other chefs who attended the challenge were also applauded as they made the show very interesting.
Those who participated are Nilo Sumalinog from Royal Mandaya Hotel, Karlo Mercado from Jack's Ridge, Nazario Mamites from Garden Oases, Elias Ontolan from Pinnacle Hotels & Suites, Josephine Viray from Sy Bee Tin, Cervantes Buenaventura from Garden Bay, Gemboy Malicse from Delongtes, Precious Guinto from The Farm, Joel Gazo from Emars, Eduardo Repetillo from D'Leonor Hotel, Leo Bunani from Lim Kitkai Luxe Hotel, and Franklin Medina from Davao Convention.
The Chefmanship Academy will kick off next year in a bigger venue to cater to a bigger audience.

Revel and revelation, Revel and revelation
MANILA.
Dr.
Gemino H.
Abad is an award-winning author of several books of poetry, short story and essay and a professor emeritus of the University of the Philippines.

Dr.
Gemino H.
Abad pays homage to language and literature and the power of imagination
, 201cWITHOUT language, the finest invention of the human imagination, there is no memory, no history, no culture, no civilization,201d said Dr.
G\xe9mino H.
Abad, revered poet and literary luminary, as he addressed a gathering of writers and the culturati during the awards night of the 65th Carlos Palanca Awards, the most prestigious literary contest in the Philippines.
Abad is a multi-awarded poet, essayist, fictionist and editor of several landmark literary anthologies and books that chart the history of Philippine literature in English.
 He has also won the Palanca Awards many times in the Poetry in English category, alongside other literary accolades such as the National Book Awards by the Manila Critics Circle, the Gawad Pambansang Alagad ni Balagtas and the Patnubay ng Sining and Kalinangan from the City of Manila, among others.
A democratic writing world
For him, the plurality of styles and schools of writing is indicative of a true democracy even in the writing world, and that not one true school should be considered the sole acceptable standard or even canon.
201cThere isn2019t, for instance, one way of writing the poem, for there are kinds and kinds of poems, depending only on one2019s principle of classification, and even the criteria of excellence for any literary work change over time, like any literary taste, fashion, or fad,201d he explained.
Language is the soul of a culture
Dr.
Abad also extolled on language being the essence and soul of a culture, and that writers are committed to forge and reinvent it for the latter to survive.
201cHe must work the language even as the farmer works the soil to produce his crop; as the writer works the language, he might also note that the ground of the language he employs is his people2019s culture and history, their day-to-day living in their own time and place.201d
Using poetry as the embodiment of all kinds of literary work, Abad told the audience of its importance in the culture of all humanity.
201cThe poem, the literary work, is a verbal artifact, its soul or inner form is its meaningfulness from reader to reader.
On its own terms, the poem, the literary work, is already an interpretation of a human experience.201d
The Filipino-ness in Philippine literature
Abad also spoke on the quintessential role of literature in the identity of the Filipino race.
201cOur own literature speaks in/from many tongues; what we have then is an archipelago of letters.
The hidden 2018diwa2019 or spirit there is our Filipino-ness which isn2019t an essence but a faith.
Filipino-ness is one2019s own individual sense of his country: his own people, their own culture and history as he understands it,201d he essayed.
Abad was conferred the Gawad Dangal ng Lahi, the Palanca Awards2019 special honorary award, by Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature Director-General Sylvia Palanca-Quirino and Carlos Palanca Foundation Vice President, Carl Anthony S.
Palanca, during the 2015 awards night held at Manila Peninsula.
A prolific writer, he has authored ten volumes of poetry, nine books of critical essays, and two short story collections.
 He also edited a landmark three-volume anthology of Philippine poetry and a six-volume historical anthology of Philippine short stories in English.
As professor of English literature and creative writing at the University of the Philippines, he also served at his alma mater in various capacities -- Secretary of the University, Vice-President for Academic Affairs and Director of the UP Creative Writing Center .
 He is now a professor emeritus of the University of the Philippines.

Explained: What is Mazda2019s KODO Soul of Motion Design Language?, Explained: What is Mazda2019s KODO Soul of Motion Design Language?IN RECENT years, with every new or redesigned Mazdas being unveiled, the automaker2019s 201crevolutionary201d design language was mentioned more often.

While it is easy to notice its impact on the automaker2019s lineup2014showing very sleek and attractive cars2014 perhaps, the actual philosophy needs more explanation2026
After its former chief designer, Laurens van den Acker left the company, taking his Nagare design language with him, his successor wanted to rework Mazda2019s design approach.

While Nagare focused on the flow of wind and water in nature, Mazda2019s global design head Ikuo Maeda2019s idea was to portray the pent-up energy of an animal about to pounce.
Hence, KODO2014--Japanese for 201csoul of motion201d2014was born.
KODO is an interpretation of potential energy in stationary forms .
The inspiration was taken from the stance of a powerful animal waiting to pounce or a sword ready to strike in the ancient Japanese martial art of kendo.
Mazda has three keywords which describe KODO: speed, tense, and appeal.
The design language aims to bring art and life into vehicle design, reflecting the heart and soul of the creator into the machine.
The model is poised with the power in its rear, rather than leaning forward.
201cThere2019s more to creating a car with soul than simply sculpting its physical form,201d explains the automaker2019s website.
201cMazda imbues its cars with soul through its quest to capture the dynamic beauty of life beyond the confines of conventional design.201d
Since then, KODO has remained the foundation of Mazda2019s model designs, influencing many vehicles in the most recent years.

Starting today until Sunday  Mazda LausGroup and Berjaya Philippines will showcase its 2015 Mazda Collection at Marquee Mall, Angeles City.
The weekend autoshow will feature Mazda 2 , Mx-5, CX-5, BT-50, and Mazda 6 .
Mazda enthusiasts will get a chance to see the all-new models up-close and will learn more about their specs, special features, and lowdown payment rates from the Mazda LausGroup2019s team itself.

For more on Mazda, visit the new Mazda Pampanga showroom today along Jose Abad Santos Avenue, City of San Fernando Pampanga or call 0918-854-2711 or log on to www.LausAutoGroup.com.

Follow your dream, Follow your dreamRhealyn C.
Pojas, TALKING to this man is like talking to a philosopher who would urge you to go after your dreams lest be left wondering over what ifs.

He is Emmanuel Nim, a 34-year old visual artist who was born in Polomoloc, South Cotabato.
At the age of five, he began to notice that he has this fascination in drawing and as the days unfold, he started to wield a brush to paint, but when he started to learn the art of replicating nature he also started to learn the art of crafting his dreams.

From that moment on, he did not only visualized objects and things of beauty, but he too visualized his dreams into reality.
He was not faltered by the obstacles that came his way as he continued to venture into that career.

201cPag may focus ka sa dream mo, walang impossible,201d Nim said with a hint of determination in his voice as he narrated his story to Sun.Star Davao in an interview.
So in 1998 after he graduated at Silway 8 National High School in Polomoloc, he packed his clothes to go to Manila where he knew he will find a job to support himself while pursuing a degree in Fine Arts at the University of the Philippines .
He needed to save money for school since his parents cannot support him financially what with his father working as heavy equipment operator and his mother as a housewife who needed to raise eight children including him.

When he reached Manila, he was able to work at an advertising shop where he designed billboards and was able to establish acquaintances with artists who frequented the shop.
By the year 2000, he stumbled into a Japanese man in Makati City who owned an art studio and later earned a living through it.
He also met a lot of fine arts students and that was the time when he was discouraged to pursue the same degree especially after meeting these students who sought help to him and even ask him to teach them do art when in fact he had not earned any degree in fine arts.

201cWhat are the Colleges teaching these students?201d Nim could not help but asked and so he did not go to College especially after that experience.
So he spent his time instead learning to paint on his own and through artists he had known and made friends with.
He recalled the times when he would often visit the Ayala Museum and got mesmerized by Amorsolo2019s paintings.
He also shared having to glue his eyes on books about Arts to read them.
Even though he did not earn any degree in College, he continued to explore and learn the field of visual arts until such time came when he become a member of Kapatiran at Ugnayan ng Natatanging Sining at Talentong Pilipino  through a fellow artist he met in 2011 through Kristy Fermin2019s Gallery.
Since then he had been doing a series of group exhibits with his fellow artists inside the country.
He was also one of the artists who painted the large portrait of the 44 members of the Philippine National Police Special Action Force  who had been slain in the Jan.
25 Mamasapano clash.
He collaborated with Fine arts graduates and professors for the piece and was lauded by his colleagues for his performance.
201cGi-appreciate nila ang presence nako sa pag paint namo atong SAF 44 incident,201d Nim said and further shared that a former dean at the College of Fine Arts in UP told him that he was humbled by Nim2019s story especially in knowing that Nim had learned the skills in art outside the four corners of the classrooms.
201cSabi ng Former UP Dean sa akin na napatunayan niya sa kanyang sarili na pwede ka palang matuto at maging magaling sa labas ng silid-aralan,201d Nim shared.
Nim continues to tour in the country to conduct art exhibits and workshop together with his colleagues in Kunts while he is also going to launch his first art exhibit outside the country by May next year in Germany.
Just last September 18, Nim together with his fellow artists had conducted an art exhibit and workshop at the Mezzanine of the Royal Mandaya Hotel in Davao City and proceeded to Makati the following day for another exhibit.
201cIf one really wants to do something, they just need to continue doing it and cultivate whatever it is that they have,201d Nim encouraged those aspiring visual artists before the interview ended.
Seeing or believing , Seeing or believing MOST people say that seeing is believing.
That only when proof is present will they remove their doubts and place their trust and understanding to the matter at hand.
Yet the same people rarely see.
They just take a glimpse and absorb the first thing they notice.
Whether it be how the environment is dying, or this politician is a fraud or the government2019s lack of concrete progress.

The point here is, how gullible we can be.
And how a situation can change depending on where we stand.

At a glimpse, a certain politician maybe considered perfect.
One that brings a refreshing change, a brave choice of actions and words and one that captured the hearts of the people.

At a close look, this brave and loud Mayor of our city has become a mass favorite.
One that speaks to the impatient and critical minds of the nation.
He is seen to be the ideal 201cnext president201d, one that can move and elicit change.

He is praised to be influential and powerful.
Powerful enough to dictate discipline from citizens and non-citizens alike.
From groups no other city makes deals with and groups most people fear.

Innovative in citywide decisions that promote growth and safety.
Like the strict implementation of the speed limit, the anti-fireworks ban and no smoking rule adorn his positive political image.
But like everything else, when you take a closer look, or pick a different part of the scene to observe, you see the cracks.
The flaws.

The fact that this politician might be sharpening his seemingly polished image for the 2016 Elections is present in thought.

Could this all be an act? A well played manipulation? A game observed for a long time to see the present government2019s weakness and prey on this?
And how about the so-called concern for the fairness and equality of all the citizens in Davao?  Is the promise for fairness and equality only applicable to a chosen few? Or the audience of TV only?
Perspective is a powerful tool.
It is a choice, a discernment that defines our choices and our beliefs.
It may be a sunny and green patch at one look, then a foggy unclear landscape the next.
Know where to look and where you2019ll believe in.
Because it2019s not just a small piece of the puzzle, but a big picture to discover.

Light up like magic  , Light up like magic  Stella A.
Estremera, TECHNOLOGY never fails to surprise, and nothing is more surprising than being able to light up a bulb with your own thumb.
That was the fun we had with the Apua emergency LED bulb introduced over dinner by Winchester Lemen, president of Envirotech Waste Recycling Inc., last week.

It2019s a Malaysian technology, he said, and comes in 7, 9, and 12 watts.
It2019s like any other LED bulb, except that it has a built-in lithium ion battery that lights up when power is shut down.
You charge it to your regular socket for six hours and it2019s ready for use for up to five hours in very bright but not glaring white light.
And it2019s plastic.
Meaning, there is no risk of breaking it and you can carry it in your bag should you be going out for a camping or some outdoors activity.
Just moisten the electrical contact.

That was where the fun was because you can use your thumb to moisten the contact.
Just moisten your thumb, hold the bulb, and place the wet thumb on the bulb2019s contact and voila! You have just become a human torch.
Dinner with friends Emil, Christian, Mabelle, and Nina was highlighted with the game of who can light up the bulb fast.

For some unknown reason, it took Nina several tries before she could light it up.
The fast lighters? Me and Christian.
Suggested retail price is P1,200 and is handier than any rechargeable lamp in the market because it2019s just a bulb.

Salvador, JUST like old times.

The taste buds saying hello again to pork , making rice a staple with every meal and coming up with lame excuses to skip the diet.

I will never learn.

But 201cwalang basagan ng trip201d and good vibes rule, so be it! Their movie star looks can make up for the way they move on the dance floor.
Walking for kilometers, refusing to hail a cab because the pocket map showed how close the destination was.
Here2019s where the adage 201cit2019s not the destination but the journey201d will hold water, the path showed surprises- good ones.
Getting stuck in heavy traffic while rain is pounding heavily on the vehicle2019s rooftop and nodding to an affirmation as to why I don2019t like the place and love my hometown so much.

It2019s always good to touch base with what yourself and do things you love doing most.
Keep it alive and say 201cjust like old times201d and never let it turn into 201cthose were the days.201d

Filipinism: What makes art Filipino?  , Filipinism: What makes art Filipino?  Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, ART works from Filipino artists featured during the recently held art exhibit at the mezzanine of the Royal Mandaya Hotel brought both something familiar and new to the eyes of the audience with its vibrant colors and themes.
  
The exhibit entitled 201cFilipinism: What makes Art Filipino?201d served as a venue to show the talents of our own local artists who are recognized internationally through their distinctly Pinoy art works.

Virgilio Godoy Cuizon, art critic and curator, explain that Filipinism 201cis not a new movement but a way of showing the real identity of artists as Filipinos in their works.201d 201cKung ano ang pinanggalingan mo, ilagay mo sa canvass.
That is your soul, that is Filipinism,201d he said.

The idea started with Cuizon2019s passion in promoting Filipino art and artists which led to the creation of KUNST  Pilipino in 2005 which helps in training aspiring Filipino artists in putting their identity on their art works which are then exhibited to European countries.

He added that other than helping artists, their goal is also to educate people and teach them to appreciate art.

201cWe produce a lot of great artists here, but we only have a few people who are appreciating them and collecting their works,201d he said.

Works from international Filipino artists Aris Bagtas and Emmanuel Nim were featured during the one day event last September 18, wherein other than showcasing their works they also conducted a free workshop and art demonstration.

Aris Bagtas2019 works carries a contemporary form of realism with his works mostly features beautiful vivid colors and metallic luster which mostly pictures about his mother and also familiar subjects like fishermen, the market and flower vendors.
Bagtas is the first Filipino who had exhibited his works at the Museum of the Your Art in Vienna, Austria and also has a number of followers waiting for each art work he releases.

Emmanuel Nim, on the other hand, a self taught artist has also displayed his art works that featured more about countryside scenery in his as he grew-up in the same environment, he is also known for doing on the spot portraits wherein he had a demonstration during the event with the event2019s organizer Teresita D.
Golez as model.

Golez during the opening of the event said that the art exhibit was her way of sharing art to her fellow Dabawenyos.
She first met Bagtas during his art exhibit in Germany.

As the saying goes: 201cKung hindi ka marunong lumingon sa pinaggalingan ay di ka makakarating sa paroroonan201d which translates to 201cIf you do not look back to where you came from, you will not reach where you are going,201d this really pictures out that wherever we go, where we came from will always have an indelible mark in our hearts and to us as a whole.
Supermoon plus eclipse equals rare sky show, Supermoon plus eclipse equals rare sky show
This Sept.
13, 2015 image provided by NASA shows the moon  and the Earth  transiting the sun together, seen from the Solar Dynamics Observatory.
The edge of Earth appears fuzzy because the atmosphere blocks different amounts of light at different altitudes.
This image was taken in extreme ultraviolet wavelengths, invisible to human eyes, but here colorized in gold.
A total lunar eclipse will share the stage with a so-called supermoon Sunday evening, Sept.
27, 2015 as seen from the United States.
That combination hasn't been seen since 1982 and won't happen again until 2033.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Florida -- Get ready for a rare double feature, starring our very own moon.
A total lunar eclipse will share the stage with a so-called supermoon Sunday night or early Monday, depending where you are.
That combination hasn't been seen since 1982 and won't happen again until 2033.
When a full or new moon makes its closest approach to Earth, that's a supermoon.
Although still about 220,000 miles away, this full moon will look bigger and brighter than usual.
In fact, it will be the closest full moon of the year, about 30,000 miles closer than the average distance.

NASA planetary scientist Noah Petro is hoping the celestial event will ignite more interest in the moon.
He is deputy project scientist for the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter, or LRO, which has been studying the moon from lunar orbit since 2009.
"The moon's a dynamic place," Petro said Wednesday.
"We're seeing changes on the surface of the moon from LRO.
We're seeing that it's not this static dead body in the sky ...
it's this great astronomical object that we have in our backyard, essentially.
So people should get out and start looking at it."
Many stargazers, professional and amateur alike, dislike the term "supermoon," noting the visible difference between a moon and supermoon is slight to all but the most faithful observers.
"It's not like the difference between an ordinary man and Superman," said Alan MacRobert, a senior editor at Sky & Telescope magazine.
"It really ought to be called a tiny, slightly little bit bigger moon, rather than the supermoon."
The full eclipse of the moon will last more than an hour and be visible, weather permitting, from North and South America, Europe, Africa and western Asia.
Showtime on the US East Coast is 10:11 p.m.
EDT ; that's when the moon, Earth and sun will be lined up, with Earth's shadow totally obscuring the moon.
In Europe, the action will unfold before dawn Monday.
No matter where, the preshow will begin two hours earlier.
There won't be another total lunar eclipse until 2018.
This eclipse marks the end of a tetrad, or series of four total lunar eclipses set six months apart.
This series began in April 2014.
The 21st century will see eight of these tetrads, an uncommonly good run.
From 1600 to 1900, there were none.
Observatories are marking the celestial event with public telescope viewing, although magnifying devices won't be necessary; the eclipse will be easily visible with the naked eye.
Astronomers are urging stargazers to simply look to the east.
In Los Angeles, Griffith Observatory also will serve up Beethoven's "Moonlight Sonata" on the piano and other moon-themed music.
NASA will provide a live video feed of the entire eclipse 2014 an option in case clouds obscure your own view.

Sacrificing for others, Sacrificing for othersKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, TO SACRIFICE one's desire and time for the greater welfare of others is indeed an admirable act of selflessness and love.
This was proven by the story of a person who always tries to find life's true value of happiness be it through his work as a professor and as a family man.
Christopher Ryan B.
Maboloc, 39, a Philosophy professor at the Ateneo de Davao University  and a contributor to a national daily newspaper, emphasized that success should not be the basis of a person's happiness.
"Success will always be a relative term.
If you measure your happiness on the basis of success, then you will soon realize that success is never permanent.
What I find most valuable is the meaningfulness of the things that I do," Maboloc said.
Maboloc, who's been teaching for the last 19 years, explained that each one has that moral obligation which is to try to see the best things in life.
"I always imagine poor children who are not in school and how difficult life is for them.
My task as a teacher is to emphasize to my present students that they carry a moral burden.
We can't change the world but we can do basic things in order to promote the well-being of others," said Maboloc, who's happily married to Marietta Casia-Maboloc and blessed with two kids, Jean Francoise Marie, 15; and Kitt Ludwig Conroy, 12.
Maboloc said that he finds fulfillment from his work as a teacher whenever he gets to draw out the inner gifts of his students.
"The answers of bright students do not really excite me.
It is the answers of the less serious type of students that concern me.
You know, the future depends on people in the margins.
The lives of good students are predictable.
The focus should be on those students who have so much in them and yet don't recognize their gifts," Maboloc said.
 
For him, the role of the professors is to create an environment and atmosphere in which they will be able to contribute meaningfully to the learning process.
There are no difficult courses since all things can be learned but there are difficult people, teachers included, Maboloc said.
"But the most important role that a teacher can play is to be able to point what is wrong with world.
The four walls of the classroom provide an atmosphere not only for learning but for unlearning perverted values.
It is improbable that a course in ethics will change their perspective in life.
But your task in the classroom is to at least tell them the right thing to do," he said.
But for Maboloc, the best life lessons he has taught to most of his students is that life will always triumph over despair.
Maboloc received his Bachelor's degree in Philosophy from  AdDU, his Master's degree in Philosophy from Ateneo de Manila University , and another Master's degree in Applied Ethics from Norwegian University of Science and Technology.
He always makes sure that he always spends majority of his free time with his wife and kids at home.
"I don't usually go out.
I only go out for meetings.
My only vice in life is my crush for Marian Rivera.
Whenever we can, we visit the farm of my father-in-law near Eden in Toril.
Right there, we are transported into a rural setting.
No electricity and just the beauty of nature.
," Maboloc said.
Reading books together is considered as their form of bonding as a family.
For Maboloc, Reading books keep their family together.
He consider it as a form of expanding a child's imagination.
He also admitted that there are similarities of his role as a professor in school and a father at home.
"You have to impart good moral values.
But you can only do that if they see in you what it is that you are preaching," Maboloc said.
NEW BOOK
Just recently, Maboloc also ventured into writing which resulted to the publication of a book he wrote, entitled:"THe Harshest Things You'll Learn About Love."
Maboloc said the book contains poems, short essays, letters, and aphorisms on love, life and philosophy which was inspired and influenced by the style and works of individuals that include Michel Foucault, Friedrich Nietzsche, Ludwig Wittgenstein, Arthur Miller, Gabriel Garcia-Marquez and Pablo Neruda.
"Young adults need to read something that will assure them that love is the only thing that makes life truly beautiful," he said.
The theme behind the publication, according to Maboloc, is based on love.
Maboloc dedicated this book to all young people who believes how beautiful life is when you are in love.
"Young people tend to idealize love.
I believe that they have to realize that true love means being aware of our limits as human beings," he added.

Dabawenyo develops new system to address traffic, Dabawenyo develops new system to address traffic
DAVAO.
Inventor Jose Guardo Jr.
and his team pose with an "approved" sign that indicates their wish to have their project funded and turn into a real one.
From left: UBC Bearing Support, Emeliano Belen Sr.; mechanical and marketing man, Rodrigo Miguel Jr.; inventor Jose Guardo Jr.; mechanical and marketing manager Edward Geguerra, and electronics and electrical man, Jemshyd Mumar.
Christine Joice C.
Cudis, THE world's third magnetic levitation system for transportation, after Germany and Japan, which will be funded by the National Government, can be found in Davao City.
And it is developed by a young Dabawenyo.
Jose Guardo Jr., from Agdao, Davao City, developed the technology, which is already patented in the World Intellectual Property Organization .

"The alarming state of traffic in the country's key cities inspired me to develop this technology," said Guardo.
In the Global Innovation Index , Metro Manila ranks fifth, losing at least P2.5 billion a day from potential businesses due to traffic.
If not mitigated, it can go as high as P6 billion a day.
Guardo and his team believe that the solution developed by their company, the Maglev Vision Corp.
with partners UBC Bearing, AXPB Bearing, and Protean Motors, is a game changer.
The people behind Maglev Vision are as follows: chairman Domingo Penalosa; UBC Bearing Support, Emeliano Belen, Sr.; Mechanical and Marketing man, Rodrigo Miguel Jr.; Inventor Jose Guardo Jr.; mechanical and marketing manager Edward Geguerra; electronics and electrical man Jemshyd Mumar; electronics head Engr.
Dennis Estrella; mechanical man, Engr.
Nonato Bolos; chief technology officer Engr.
Yehuda Ortal; prototype developer, Warren de Castro; prototype developer, Cyrus Dominic Guererro; programs and controls man, Ken Policarpio, and electronics man, Hiocer Sadio.
"The problem calls for an urgent solution that should be invented and built," Guardo said.
The technology used in Germany is room temperature electromagnets, which are magnetically attracted upwards to iron rails positioned under the edges of the guide way structure.
In Japan, they use superconductor, which works through a 270 degrees Celsius temperature, while Guardo's invention works using the gyroscopic spin induced lenz's law.
It uses a permanent magnet that is twisted, then returned to the conductor , and then refilled, causing the train to levitate.
The technology aims to decongest urban population, encourage technological tourism, and spur manufacturing jobs for the Philippines.
At present, the team is looking for investors who can finance the construction of this project.
Recently, they were awarded second place in the Davao Regional Invention and Contest Exhibit of the Department of Science and Technology and Davao Investors Association.
"We joined to introduce this invention to the Filipino community, we are hopeful that we can get investors to fund us," Guardo said.
DOST-Technology Application and Promotion Institute  has expressed willingness in financing their invention.
Incubation center
If the Davao Inventors Association can generate enough fund, they, together with the DOST-TAPI, will push through with the five-hectare incubation center project, which will house several stations which will embody different avenues for inventors and researchers to experiment and build prototypes.
If pursued, there will be a test trail, which is a six-seater prototype of the maglev technology to be constructed in the project to transport the viewers from one station to another.
The center, which will be erected in the Mindanao Science and Technology Centrum, will enable the end products of the investors to be marketed to the investors.
It will not only be the center for children2019s educational tours but it will motivate the other age brackets in the community to find a way to make tangible their ideas.
Regional Invention Contest
This year's Regional Invention and Contest Exhibit  in Davao Region, which was slated last October 1 to 3, 2015, had nearly hundred entries responding to the call of the Department of Science and Technology  to showcase Davao's inventions at NCCC Mall of Davao.
Rice 2015, organized by the Technology Department and Promotion Institute  and the regional office of the Department of Science and Technology , in cooperation with the Davao Inventors Association , will be participated in by the region's inventors, developers, professionals and student researchers.
DOST regional director Anthony C.
Sales said earlier that the contest is aimed at showcasing the potentials of Davao inventors.
"We have a lot of entries of inventions, utility models and other patented intellectual properties to take center stage during the three-day contest," he said.
Rice 2015 carries the theme: "Philippines: A Science Nation Innovating and Inventing for Global Competitiveness."
The event will show the capacity of the Filipino inventors to turn raw materials to innovative finished products.
The contest will have six categories -- Outstanding Invention ; Outstanding Utility Model; Outstanding Industrial Design; Outstanding Creative Research ; Outstanding Student Creative Research  for High School; and Outstanding Student Creative Research  for College students.

Cargo ships that have sunk with fatalities since 2011 , Cargo ships that have sunk with fatalities since 2011 ON MONDAY, the Coast Guard said a US cargo ship carrying 33 people sank.
It disappeared four days earlier, after encountering high winds and heavy seas from Hurricane Joaquin.
One body has been found, and planes and ships are still searching for the rest of the crew.
Here are some past incidents in which cargo ships have sunk:
Jan 3, 2015: Cargo ship Cemfjord, carrying cement from Denmark to England's west coast, capsized north of Scotland and sank in stormy seas without issuing a distress call.
An extensive search failed to find any of the eight-member crew.
Jan 2, 2015: Philippine cargo vessel Bulk Jupiter sank near the coast of Vung Tau City, Vietnam.
One crewman was rescued, two were found dead, and 16 were never found.
May 5, 2014: A Chinese cargo ship with cement sank after colliding with a container ship near Hong Kong.
One crew member of the Zhong Xing 2 was rescued, but 12 were never found.
April 4, 2014: The bodies of two North Korean sailors were recovered after their cargo ship went missing off the southern coast of South Korea.
Three were rescued, but 11 remained missing.
Oct.
15, 2013: Chinese cargo ship the CHENGLU15 sank off South Korea's southeastern coast in strong winds and fierce waves.
Eight people were rescued and nine bodies were recovered, leaving two people missing.
July 4, 2013: Eleven crew members from a Bangladeshi cargo ship went missing after their vessel capsized in rough waters in the Andaman Sea near Thailand.
Six were rescued.
December 5, 2012:  Three people were killed and 10 went missing after cargo ship Volgo Balt 199 sank in a severe storm off Turkey's Black Sea coast.
February 1, 2012: A Cambodian-registered cargo ship sank in a Black Sea storm near Turkey.
Eight of 11 crew members went missing.
November 27, 2011:  Russian cargo ship Swanland sank off Bardsey in the Irish Sea after it was hit by a freak wave in gale force winds.
Two crew members were saved, but six died.

HAU entry named Best World Film in New York, HAU entry named Best World Film in New York"ARI: My Life With A King," produced by Holy Angel University, won the Best World Film award in the recent Harlem International Film Festival held in New York City.
The award represents the top recognition among the foreign films submitted to the festival, second only to the Best Film Award which is given to the US entries.
The award came just after the HAU film was accepted as official selection in the Vancouver International Film Festival in Canada and shortly before announcement of its acceptance as lone Filipino entry to the Chicago International Film Festival.

The two are among the biggest film festivals in North America, with Chicago recognized as the oldest in the United States.
The Chicago festival calls the HAU film "a celebration of a vibrant culture's poetic legacy that pulses with local color."
Directed by HAU student Carlo Enciso Catu and produced by HAU alumnus Ferdinand Lapuz, the Kapampangan-language film is the first filmmaking attempt of the University.
According to HAU senior administrator Robby Tantingco, the University previously funded Brillante Mendoza2019s early film "Manoro" which eventually won at the Cinemanila and Torino  International Film Festivals.
"Ari: My Life With A King" is the first film with HAU students, employees and alumni in the cast and crew, Tantingco said.
The film is a coming-of-age story of a Kapampangan boy who refuses to speak in Kapampangan until he meets the so-called King of Kapampangan Poets.
Ronwaldo Martin, brother of popular actor Coco Martin, plays the boy's part with real-life Kapampangan poet laureate Francisco Guinto in the king's role.
The film is part of the University's advocacy to promote local culture through its Center for Kapampangan Studies.
Last year, the University2019s two entries to the Animahenasyon, a national competition for animated films, both won first prize in their respective categories.
Lapuz, recipient of the University's outstanding alumnus award last year, arranged the film2019s participation in the international festivals, which he also does for all the Filipino films that deserve international attention if not recognition.
Early this year, Lapuz donated P250,000.00 to the University2019s scholarship program.
The amount represented the proceeds from the screening of the award-winning films he recently produced, including Vilma Santos' "Ekstra," Nora Aunor's "Dementia" and "Bwakaw," a Philippine entry to the Oscar Awards.
"Ari: My Life With A King" will be shown to various schools in Pampanga and HAU alumni and Kapampangan groups in the US and the Middle East as part of the University2019s scholarship fund-raising campaign, according to Tantingco.
