First lady pilot of Vietnamese airline is a Filipino, First lady pilot of Vietnamese airline is a FilipinoFILIPINO pilot Captain Antonette Ortiz Parocha has made history by being the first female co-pilot of Vietnam2019s privately-owned new-age airline, Viet Jet Air , airport authorities said on Thursday.
The Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines  said that Parocha paid a courtersy call to CAAP director general William Hotchkiss III on Thursday after submitting her application for Airline Transport Pilot License .
This, CAAP said, is a requirement before taking the ATPL, or the highest-level pilot license that allows the license holder to fly professionally as a pilot in command of multi-crew aircraft with any commercial airline company.
Certified pilot licenses are categorized under four classes: Student Pilot license , Private Pilot License , Commercial Pilot License , and Airline Transport Pilot License , CAAP noted.
Parocha, has logged over 5,000 flying hours.
The minimum requirement is to accumulate 1,500 flying hours.
A native of Cantilan, Surigao del Sur, Parocha graduated from Patts Collage of Aeronautics in 2001 and Flight School International in 2005.
She meanwhile expressed hope that she will pass the exam she will take this month and soon become a commercial pilot.

The heart of a soldier , The heart of a soldier Rhona Goc-ong-Villariasa, HE HAS been serving in the military for twelve years now.
He has suffered being away from his family as all soldiers have to, just to protect the country.
 
Is it not an easy task, but because of his big love for his profession Capt.
Mario Atendido Tena, the Operations Officer of Task Force Davao , faces these challenges with great confidence.
Capt.
Tena was born on September on 15, 1974 in Quezon Province.

The youngest of eight siblings, he is the only one who's with the military, a job he did not plan for.

"Since 1993 nag-college ako, nag-ROTC ako hanggang sa naging ROTC Officer ako dire-diretso na yun hanggang sa na-commission ako as reservist officer, nag-graduate ako sa advance officer course, sa provisionary, then na-commission ako ng 2001.
So lahat ng natutunan ko sa military nakuha ko sa ROTC," Capt.
Tena said in an interview.

He first took upp Civil Engineering Technology at the Technological University of the Philippines, but he decided to shift to another course and got a Bachelor in Technical Teaching Education, which he finished in 2001.
Before he became a soldier, he was a teacher first.
 
He also tried working in a construction firm where he was involved in testing materials.
 
But, apparently, being a soldier is his fate.
When he finished his preparatory course in the Officer Candidate School, Davao City was his first assignment.

"Palipat-lipat lang ako till nakarating dito, naging platoon leader, company commander, nag S3 pa ako, hanggang sa naibigay sa akin itong posisyon ko ngayon," he said.

He also had his sting in the battlefield, admitting that he lived years of fearing for his life.
 
"Nung mga lieutenant days ko halos puro operations kami sa Paquibato District.
Madaling araw, minsan dis-oras ng gabi lumalakad ka, walang tulog, lahat ng damit mo basang-basa tapos minsan di ka na nagpapalit ng damit.
Di na nga namin nararamdaman na ang baho-baho namin.
Minsan tumutulo na ang luha mo, natatanong mo ang sarili mo ano ba 2018tong pinasok ko," he said.

He admits sacrificing his time for the family whenever work demands.

Still he tries to give his best as a husband and a father to his eight-year-old son.
"Yung trabaho namin na 24/7.
Pag nakabakasyon ka on-call ka naman.
Mula ng pumasok ako ng sundalo hindi na talaga ako nakapagbakasyon na talagang bakasyon.
Nasanay ako sa mga previous commanders ko na kahit nakabakasyon kana open mo pa rin yung cellphones mo kasi on call ka pa rin, kaya minsan nag-aaway kami ng asawa ko.
Pero yung responsbilty din kasi," the officer, who is also the Chief Officer of Task Force Agila, said.

There2019s still a lot he intends to do while in service.
 "Siguro makaabot lang ako ng 20 years sa service okay na ako.
Napaka-challenging maging isang sundalo at marami akong natutunan.
By the time nga magreretiro na ako una talaga is babawi ako sa pamilya ko.
Simpleng buhay lang, di ko naman aim na yumaman o ano, basta you survive lang, okay na sa akin," he said.

Capt.
Tena is often described by his men as strict, but he brushes this off saying he is just doing his job.
 He encourages his men to give their all and serve with their heart to maintain the dignity and respect on soldiers.
 
"Mahalin nila yung trabaho nila.
Di mo naman papasukin yung isang trabaho na di mo gusto.
Andiyan kana sa mundong yan patunayan mo ang sarili mo, di lang yungginagawang compliance, ipakita mo yung best mo sa lahat ng ginagawa mo," he said.

Indeed, the mud caused by the rain was as significant as the event.

Something that is homegrown.
And that is what Vispop is trying to get across -- to serve as a reminder for us Bisayas to never forget how colorful our homegrown Bisaya culture is.
The Vispop Music Festival may be too young -- with only its first run to show.
Nevertheless, it has already made a giant leap in keeping the Bisaya spirit alive amid this fast-paced world.

Leticia Guzman, a 65-year-old resident in Isla Verde said that there were already three Barangay Captains since she resided there, not one has fulfilled the promise of a public toilet accessible for all.
She has been living at Isla Verde since 1978 and never had the luxury of a sanitary toilet in her house.
They cannot afford one.
Most of their earnings are spent on the basics - food.
"Of course, we would prioritize food over the comfort room," Guzman said, adding that among the members of the family, it is only her who is earning an income by purchasing clothes in Uyanguren and selling it in Bankerohan for a higher price.
The highest she earns is P800 gross.
"Only those who have a bungalow house in the area have access to proper toilets," Guzman said.
Guzman said that when they defecate or pee, they would use an "arinola" the contents of which they would later throw to the sea.
Others do their thing in a plastic bag and throw this to the sea as well.
They are aware that it has negative effects on them especially when it comes to their health.
But Guzman said that is a reality.
A daily run
Imagine yourself ready to go but have to run to where you can do it.
Jeanie Fe Grace T.
Sangkula, 38, is another resident of Isla Verde who shared similar stories as Guzman, including the lack of money to build a toilet.
When asked what they do when there is an urgent call of nature, Sangkula said that if it is daytime they would use a public toilet at the other side of the coast where they would pay P2 for every use.
It is a kilometer away from where they are so if they could no longer hold it, they'd just go to the sea.
"The CR is too far from here," Sangkula's husband voiced out.
They have just been there three months after the last house they were renting collapsed from disrepair.
There is a multipurpose comfort room built by government where they live now but this is locked.
"Maybe because there is no water that is why they do not let people use the multipurpose CR," Sangkula said in the vernacular.
Her husband is a police volunteer under the Davao City Police Office-Unified Force Multiplier .
He doesn't get any income from this work.
Sangkula works twice to thrice a week at Lovely Boneless Bangus.
They earn barely enough to feed their family with six children, four of whom are in school.
Sangkula said that she could earn P750 if she works three days a week, but she could not work more days because she has her small children to attend to.
"My husband's job is not also permanent since it is a voluntary work," she said.
Hosing off
There's open defecation, there's throwing plastics to the sea, and then there's hosing it off.
That's what they do.
But don't be deceived by those that have toilet bowls.
These, too, lead directly to the sea via plastic hoses buried in the ground.
Sangkula showed to Sun.Star Davao some of this hoses which she is referring to.
"At night, the air emits a foul smell since it is mostly during that time when people would dispose their wastes to the sea through the hoses and others," Sangkula said.
Different garbage composed of plastics, cellophanes, and sometimes even feces flattened in the sand decorated the shores.
"One of our concerns is the garbage thrown by the residents to the sea which is hurled by the large waves back to the shore so for us who lived near the coast, it is quiet a struggle," Sangkula said.
How much?
Residents say they can't afford one.
How expensive then is a toilet? 
Sanitation Inspector Curtis Lazarraga said that with just P3,000 to P4,000, a person can already build their own CR.
But P3,000 is not money these people can easily come by.
According to Lazarraga, there is an estimated P300,000 people living on the shoreline and riverbanks of Davao City.
 
When asked about the clamor of the people to ask the government to put up a public toilet in Isla Verde, Lazarraga said that the real concern is really moving the people out of the bayside.
"If they can be relocated they can be in a more appropriate area where they can put up their own individual toilets because according to the law, you cannot put up a house without a toilet.
It is your responsibility," Lazarraga added.
It is not also advisable to put up a toilet in the coastal area because it will still result into sea contamination especially when the water flooded the toilets during high tide, Lazarraga explained.
Though the government had already provided solutions to the problem, they cannot compel the people to relocate due to the economic downside of it.

The people living in Isla Verde are informal settlers and are financially challenged, Lazaragga explained.
The government cannot impose on the people to relocate because there is no readily available space for them except in Paquibato which the people themselves do not like and that is another problem, Lazaragga admitted.

Informal settlers in Isla Verde are mostly of the Sama tribe, whose lives have always been connected to the sea.
The government does not also encourage putting up a communal toilet because sustainability cannot be attained through it and it often causes quarrels among the families living in the area in the issue of maintaining cleanliness.
Living on the bayside is discouraged, but these people would not have any other area to live.
Government, too, does not have an appropriate relocation site for them.
Thus, they stay.
Government cannot act.
The sea remains the communal toilet of hundreds of thousands.
The clean and the unclean  , The clean and the unclean  Christine Joice C.
Cudis, DABAWENYOS brag about our drinking water being among the second best in the world.

However, having the best does not translate to having enough.
Due to the growing population and rapid urbanization of the city, the demand of water supply has dramatically increased.

Being the third largest urban area in the country and the economic center of southern Philippines, Davao City is home to 1,612,100 people.

By 2014, the demand of the water supply per year is equivalent to 98,149,311 cubic meters which the 57 production wells of Davao City Water District  wasstil able to supply sufficiently.
 
But by 2019, the water demand is expected to elevate up to 117,265,313 cubic meters, which will require additional 10 production wells.
 
In 2025, it will go high to 141,101,904 cubic meters; in 2030, it will be 164,392,803 cubic meters which calls for the need to provide at least 94 production wells.

At the time, DCWD serves 61% of the city's population which translates to 108 barangays who have access to potable water out of the 182 total number of barangays here.
Of the total potable water extracted, 99.3% of the production were sourced from groundwater, only .70% were from their spring source in Malagos.
 
Groundwater although renewable, is a finite resource.
And being groundwater dependent is power intensive, in fact, the impact of groundwater over-extraction in the national map can already be obseved.
In the case of Cebu and Manila, wherein brackish water have intruded into the aquifers of Cebu and a huge portion of Metro Manila sunk due to over extraction of groundwater.
 
Due to excessive use of groundwater, Manila bay has risen by 1 meter from 1964 to 2002, an effect attributed to subsidence.
Levelling data from National Mapping and Resource Information Authority  reveal that areas in Metro Manila sank 0.68 meters to 1.43 meters in 30 years .

Thus, in 2008, National Water Resource Board  issued a memoratorium of the issuance of water permits, a regulation prohibiting extraction of water from deep wells as groundwater condition in Metro Manila has become extremely critical.

To not suffer the same fate with Cebu and Manila, DCWD in partnership with the Apo Agua Infrastractura Inc.
 proposed the Davao City Bulk Water Supply Project.
 
Land subsidence is among the negative effects of groundwater over-extraction, if continued, it will result to damage to highways, buildings, wells, and pipelines.

If groundwater level falls, the existing wells need to be drilled deeper, new wells need to be drilled, or an alternative source of water must be located.

The worse that could happen from over extraction is salt water intrusion in the water pipelines, a clear threat to fresh groundwater.
All of the water in the ground is not fresh; most in the deeper area, below the ocean is saline.
 
The boundary between the freshwater and salt water is called brackish water.

Naturally, it will be stable until over extraction which will lead to migration, or intrusion of salt water into freshwater aquifers.

Once salt mixes with freshwater, either treating the water or locating and developing an alternative water supply are only options, however costly.
 Septage and Sewerage Same goes with the issue of septage and sewerage.

Today, there is an estimate of 300,000 population living along the river banks and coastal areas of the city.
Large number of population means large responsibility.
 
City Health Office monitors the excavation of septic tanks in the city's households with an interval of three to five years.
The problem is out of the 11 septic tank excavators who applied for accrediation, only three of them passed: Aquino septic tanks and plumbing services; Hardcore septic tank excavators; and Surop septic tank excavators.

This means that only three excavators operate legally for all the household in the city.
Which will not cater to all, especially through time where the population is expected to increase.

With this, the city, in accordance to the clean water act of the Philippines, must take responsibility.
A memorandum of agreement between the city council and DCWD was signed in 2014, instituting for the establishment of a P200 million septage treatment facility.

Unfortunately, the completion of the project is delayed due to the 'not approved' condition given by the city council for the second MOA passed by DCWD stating that they should be the exclusive provider of the facility.
City administrator Atty.
Melchor Quitain said in an interview, "because there will be a monopoly if DCWD will hold exclusive provision for the project." 
The presence of E.coli bacteria has been found out to have increased in the Davao river where the wastewater from household, establishments, and other factories are confluent.
And just like the rest, if not addressed, the level of bacteria will continue to rise.

"The city council will have to hasten the implementation of this ordinance," said City Health Office  Sanitary Inspector, Curtis C.
Lazarraga.

Davao City is blessed with water sources that can still provide for its people, but this will not be so if we continue to disregard its value and treat water as if the supply will never run out.
 
Now, we have the ground water source that will soon be complemented by surface water.

The population grows, the people are not mindful about their wastewater; they pollute the ground and waterways with their sewage and use their clean water for washing.

How is the septage law? , How is the septage law? Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, CRAFTED back in 2010 and with its Implementing Rules and Regulation  signed back in 2013, Davao City2019s Septage and Sewerage Management Ordinance of the City has come a long way.

However, after almost two years since the release of its IRR, the said ordinance has not yet been fully implemented in the City.

Data from the City Health Office  - Environment Sanitation Division showed that as of 2014, there are a total of 10,058 households in the city without toilet and 25,643 households with insanitary toilet out of the 322, 419 households in the city.

Most of the households found with no toilets and insanitary ones are from District 3 wherein Toril had 2,085 households without toilet and Marilog had 3,858 households with insanitary toilets.

Based on the IRR of the City2019s Septage and Sewerage Management Ordinance, 201call building plans for residential, commercial and industrial, including those for apartelles and condominiums, before it is approved by the City Engineer2019s Office, shall conform to the design of the sanitary plumbing and septic tanks specifications.201d The specifications included in the IRR states that the septic tanks shall be built of solid durable material, shall be watertight and shall conform to the applicable Philippine materials standards.

The IRR also required for the septic tanks not to be constructed under any building and not within 25 meters from any existing source of water supply.

It also stated that existing septic tanks that cannot be repaired or upgraded shall be dislodged within one year from the affectivity of the ordinance, which was back way back in 2013 when its IRR was approved.
All septic tanks are required to be dislodged by an accredited mobile service provider every five years or when the sludge volume is already one half of the total capacity of the septic tank, or when the septic tank becomes ineffective.
Also stated under the IRR, the City through its barangay unit, may construct communal toilets and/or septic tanks in areas where informal settlers cannot afford to build.
The barangay will be responsible for the maintenance of the toilets and/or septic tanks but the community shall pay for its usage.
For the construction, the City Government will bear the cost through its annual appropriation for the implementation of the IRR.

Under the Section 22, Rule 9 of the IRR, a septage and sewerage and sewage treatment plant/facility shall be established by the City Government or by an accredited service provider.

The purpose of the facility will be for the unloading of the sludge for a certain fee and treatment by Department of Health approved individuals and companies.

The IRR stated that the facility shall be established pursuant to the memorandum of agreement between the City Government of Davao and the Davao City Water District wherein the city government shall provide an appropriate land which shall serve as the site for the septage, sewerage and sewage treatment facility.

Anyone who violates the provisions shall be fined not less than P1,000 but not more than P2,000 for first offense; second offense has a fine of less than P2,000 but not more than P3,000; and for third and succeeding offenses shall be fined no less than P3,000 but not more than P5,000 and imprisonment of not less than one month but not more than six months.

It was previously reported that the Davao City Council Committee on Environment chairperson Councilor Leonardo R.
Avila III has been requesting for the for the full implementation of the Septage and Sewerage Management Ordinance due to the findings of the rise in the coliform level found in some of the city's rivers due to human and animal wastes, houses located near the river, poultry and hog farms disposing their wastes in the river, and the city not having sewerage/septage treatment facility.

Based on the 2014 water quality assessment of the Environmental Management Bureau, total coliform found for both downstream and upstream of Davao River was estimated at 4,900 to 1,887,000 most probable number  per 100 ml wherein the standard level should only be 1,000mpn per 100 ml.

With a downstream standard level of 200mpn per 100 ml, fecal coliform in Davao River was estimated at 9,600 to 293,000mpn per 100 ml while for the upstream, with a standard level of 100mpn per 100 ml, it was found with 1,700 to 8,700mpn/100 ml of fecal coliform.

Talomo River was found with a total number of 1,006 to 456,000 MPN per 100 ml with around 414 to 183,000mpn per 100 ml of fecal coliform.
The report showed that the rise in the coliform level was due to human and animal wastes, houses located near the river, poultry and hog farms disposing their wastes in the river, and the City not having sewerage/septage treatment facility.

Two years hence, the situation could be worse now as no proper implementation has been commenced.
So, what septic tank design is standard? , So, what septic tank design is standard? Ruji Peter S.
Abat, AS IF having functional septic tanks are not problems enough, by virtue of the Davao City Ordinance No.
0363-10 Series of 2010 otherwise known as Septage and sewerage management ordinance of Davao City, households and establishments are now required to install a three-chamber septic tank instead of the standard two-chamber tanks of before.
 
The Design
Unlike the two-chamber design where the bottom of the tank is layered with gravel to separate the sludge from the water, the three-chamber design has a sealed bottom.
Other than the sealed bottom, the three-chamber septic tank has two leaching chambers that dispose the wastewater from the septic tank.
In the specifications cited in the ordinance, septic tanks should have a 50 millimeter-diameter inlet where wastes from the toilets pass through that then leads to the first chamber called the digestive chamber.

The digestive chamber should have at least one half to two thirds of the entire tanks volume while the next two chambers may have equal dimensions.

There should also be maintenance holes or manholes in each of the chamber for easier access in case there is a need to remove the sludge from the septic tank.
Sought out to describe the difference, Assistant City Building Official lawyer Joseph Felizarta told Sun.Star Davao in an interview that there is no significant difference between the two-chamber to the three-chamber septic tank.

But he was quick to add that somehow, having three-chamber septic tanks with sealed bottoms can come in handy for households that are using water from deep wells since this will be a protection against contaminations from human wastes being absorbed by the soil.
Felizarta also assured that no septic tank will be allowed to be built near underground water resources or watersheds as mandated by the ordinance.
 
Conflict of Law
Felizarta said that the septic tank design being followed by the ordinance is compliant with the Department of Health  guidelines.

Yet as cited Plumbing Code of the Philippines, residents and establishment owners are only required to have two-chamber septic tanks.

"The national law has more weight so basically for us, we just have to implement the building of three-chamber of septic tanks in our own discretion since we also cannot disregard the national law," Felizarta said.
He said in some areas especially those in the dry areas in the city or uplands they don't require residents or establishment owners to build three-chamber septic tanks.

But for those near bodies of water like coastal areas and riversides, they are required to do so.
Households and establishment owners should also have their septic tanks desludged every after three to five years since failure to do so may mean penalties ranging from P1,000 to P5,000 and imprisonment for not more than six months.

"We give more focus on establishing cluster or communal three-chamber septic tanks in slum areas so that we could minimize the pollution.
Since they are informal settlers, most of them don't have septic tanks.
So might as well build a large septic tank that could catch the wastes from households in a particular slum area," Felizarta said.

The budget for the communal septic tanks, however, is reliant on the appropriation of the City Government.

Best Solution
Felizarta, however, described the use of the three-chamber septic tank as a very small contribution to the overall implementation of the law since the best solution is the establishment of a sewerage system and a water treatment facility.

"The ordinance's focus is really the sewerage system and the treatment facility because whether we use a two-chamber or three-chamber septic tank, we still need to treat the wastewater.
That is why we should develop a sewerage system that could catch the wastewater from the septic tanks and take the waste to the treatment facility," Felizarta said.

He estimated that the cost of building the sewers and the treatment facility would be around P100-million.

But after five years since the implementation of the law, the project hasn't started yet since there is no budget to begin with.

The City Health Office's Environment Sanitation Section is the lead implementing agency for the ordinance while the Davao City Water District is tasked to construct the water treatment facility as prescribed by the law.

In the meantime, with the shrinking sizes of residential lots, there is not enough space for three-chambered tanks.
Desludging yet polluting , Desludging yet polluting Karina V.
Canedo, TWO years after the release of the implementing rules and regulations  of the septage and sewerage management program and management of Davao sewage is still being released to the environment untreated.

The IRR of the Septage and Sewerage Management Ordinance of Davao City was released in 2013.
 
Septage or the combination of scum, sludge, and liquid that accumulates in septic tanks that are not disposed properly when these are extracted defeats the purpose of septic tanks.
This is also a major contributor of E.
coli and fecal coliform in major river systems.
 
Based on the Water Quality Assessment of Davao River, total coliform for both downstream and upstream of the river are 4,900-1,887,000 most probable number  /100 ml, while the standard is 1,000 mpn/1000ml.

With a downstream standard level of 200mpn per 100 ml, fecal coliform in Davao River was estimated at 9,600 to 293,000mpn per 100 ml while for the upstream, with a standard level of 100mpn per 100 ml, it was found with 1,700 to 8,700mpn/100 ml of fecal coliform.

Coliform may be considered indigenous in waters but fecal coliform is another thing because it can only be attributed to human and animal wastes.
The identified Water Quality Assessment Area Stations 1-4a which are considered as downstream waters includes the mouth of Davao River, below the Bolton Bridge, Marfori Heights Purok 17, Barangay 5-A, Quarry Area at Purok 8, Barangay 19-B Bacaca, San Rafael Bridge, Purok 9-A, Barangay Ma-a, River Walk, Crocodile Park, Barangay Ma-a, Davao River, Diversion Bridge Ma-a, and Waan Bridge, Purok 5, Barangay Waan.

Talomo River was found with a total number of 1,006 to 456,000 MPN per 100 ml with around 414 to 183,000mpn per 100 ml of fecal coliform.

This rise in the coliform level is due to human and animal wastes, houses located near the river, poultry and hog farms disposing their wastes in the river, and the City not having sewerage/septage treatment facility.
This problem reported last year remains.
 
According to City Health Office Sanitary Inspector II Curtis Lazarraga, one of the most prevailing reasons for these are the fly by night desludgers who provide immediate service for households.
Lazarraga said that there are a total of 11 septic tank excavators within the city but only three have secured disposal facilities for the sludge extracted.

In their list, only the Aquino Septic Tank Excavator and Plumbing Services with its disposal site in Magtuod, the Hardcore Septic Tank Excavator with its disposal site located is in the Mudiang, Bunawan District, and Surop Septic Tank Excavator and Plumbing Services and its disposal site is located at Tacunan, Tugbok are the accredited excavators.

Unaccredited excavators do not have the facilities to dispose and treat the sludge.
Many operate in the dark of the night to pour out the sludge in open areas, canals, estuaries, and even on the beach.
If the Septage and Sewerage Management Ordinance of Davao City is fully implemented, Rule XV of the ordinance, improper sludge disposal belongs to the prohibited acts and omissions and a first violation will be penalized with not less than 1,000 but not more than P2,000, at the discretion of the court.

The second offense will be a fine of not less than P2,000 but not more than 3,000 at the discretion of the court and the third and succeeding offenses fine of not less than 3,000 but not more than 5,000 and the imprisonment of not less than one month but not more than six  months year.

Apart from the illegal excavators that dispose of the sludge directly to waterway, some barangays in Davao City still have no toilets.
Based on records of the City Health Office in the year 2014, in the 322, 419 households in Davao, or 10, 058 or 3.12% have no toilets, 25, 643 or 7.
95 % have insanitary toilets and 286,718 or 88.
32% have sanitary toilets.
 
Out of 10, 058 households without toilets, Toril got the highest number with 2,085, succeeded by Paquibato with 1,194, then Tugbok with 1,098, then Bunawan with 1,045, and Talomo North with 761.
City Health Officer Dr.
Josephine J.
Villafuerte said that Sanitary Inspectors do constant monitoring on coastal areas and are reminding households without toilets to put up one.

Villafuerte also said that they put up toilets if requested by the community but the maintenance will be a collaboration between the community using the toilet and the barangay.
 
But, Lazarraga said that communal toilets stated by the Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Septage and Sewerage Management Ordinance of Davao City is ill-advised especially in coastal barangays because there will be the tendency of the community not being concerned about the facility since this is for everybody.
 
She insists that the real solution is in relocating sea- and riverside residents; a solution that cannot be acted on given the enormity of the problem.
All these, however, would have been alleviated had the city invested on the septage and sewerage facility that the ordinance provides for.

A septage treatment facility is a facility which receives septage or the liquid sludge periodically removed from individual septic tanks and thereafter separates the solids and the liquids and treats the liquids and solids, and presses the solids into a sludge 201ccake201d that is transported for disposal.

The treated sludge which qualifies as biosolids, may be utilized as soil conditioner and for other beneficial use.
This Septage and Sewerage and Sewage Treatment Plant/Facility is where the sludge will be unloaded for a fee provided by the IRR.
The treatment of sludge must be done by any DOH-accredited individuals, companies, whether public, in any DOH-approved treatment facility.
 
The establishment as mandated by the IRR shall be pursuant of the Memorandum of Agreement entered into by and between the City Government of Davao and the Davao City Water District  in accordance with the Section 28 of PD and Section 8 of RA 9275.

Based on the IRR in 2013 the city government shall provide an appropriate land which shall serve as the site of the septage and sewerage and sewage treatment plant and facility.

Its construction, however, was bogged down by a confusion of who really has the responsibility in managing this facility.
Is it the local government or the Davao City Water District, who has the mandate of providing sewerage systems as well.
 
Pollution Control and Safety Officer of the DCWD John Baynosa also bared that the cause of the delay of the implementation of the facility is because of confusion on some responsibilities.

201cWe are confused before who will really be in-charge of Septage facility, if it2019s the Local Government Unit or them, but then it was clarified that it was DCWDs responsibility201d Baynosa said.

This was also confirmed in a separate interview with Lazarraga saying that the finding of lot then has been transferred to the DCWD.

201cDili explicitly stated in the ordinance that they would be the exclusive persons in authority, but in the Implementing Rules and Regulations ang nabutang was it was DCWD which garnered opinions of the council.
201d Lazarraga said.

Lazarraga said that a Memorandum of Agreement  is now crafted between the Davao City and the DCWD to put up the treatment facility.

201cIt2019s already being processed now and we are seeing light in the end of the tunnel,201d Lazarraga said.
Meanwhile in the end of the DCWD, Baynosa said that they only need the MOA to start the project is needed for the DCWD to operate and make the facility.
He said that once it would be signed preliminary activities such as information dissemination about the importance of a septage treatment plant.
In the meantime, it2019s all talk.
Celebrating Iloilo2019s heritage online with Google, Celebrating Iloilo2019s heritage online with Google
UPV Main Building   by CWVS Collection, University of the Philippines - Center for West Visayan Studies 
Iloilo heritage joins Google Cultural Institute collection
, MANILA -- Google has collaborated with the University of the Philippines  Western Visayas to launch Iloilo2019s rich collection of heritage structures on Google Cultural Institute, an online platform that helps to make the world2019s culture accessible and available to anyone.
The collection shows off Iloilo2019s rich cultural backdrop, dating back from the pre-colonial period up to the 20th century.
201cThis collection is set to make Iloilo join the growing list of historic cities featured on the Cultural Institute.
It highlights the significance and importance of preserving culture, history and heritage among the Filipinos,201d said Joyce Christine Colon, University Research Associate II of UP Visayas.
The exhibits describe Iloilo2019s transformation into one of the leading provinces in the country.
With the Cultural Institute, viewers can zoom in to appreciate the unique details and diverse influences on the architecture of religious landmarks such as the Miagao Church, a Unesco World Heritage site, the Jaro Cathedral, and the Molo Church.
The Cultural Institute also makes it possible to view structures such as the Miagao Church over time, by enabling users to place old and new photographs side by side.

Iloilo2019s prosperity resulting from the textile and sugar export trades can be seen in its grandiose ancestral homes, and in the construction of a number of public buildings also featured on the Cultural Institute.
Prime examples include Iloilo2019s first City Hall and the Baluarte Elementary School, the first public school in the Philippines established in 1905.

The history of Iloilo2019s City Hall, which was later donated to the University of the Philippines and declared a National Historical Landmark, can also be traced in a special exhibit.
Old photographs and documents tell the story behind its transition from city hall, to a garrison during World War II, to a university.

Another exhibit on the River Esplanade also puts the spotlight on the importance of Iloilo River in history and the government2019s bid to protect it and promote environmental consciousness among Ilonggos.
201cThe Philippines has such a rich culture to be proud of.
Every city and every province has something to show off and the Cultural Institute aims to make all these available to everyone in a format most accessible to them -- digital.
This is our effort to educate and inspire future generations,201d said Dennis Dizon, Google Cultural Institute program manager.

Pates, THE education sector has been doing its part to educate children about the importance of water and sanitation.

Fabia, who was part of Deped inspectors who checked the schools in the region for the health and sanitation cases, admitted that there are schools particularly in the Davao del Norte and Davao Oriental which have problems in poor drainage and septic tank problems.

But she said that these problems materialized since these provinces have been used for different local, regional, and even national sporting events which is usually held every year.
201cEvident ito na mga problems especially sa mga schools na poor yung drainage system tapos dun pa nagho-hold ng mga sporting events like Davao Regional Athletic Association , Private Schools Athletic Association , and even Palarong Pambansa,201d Fabia said.
She admits encountering problems like septic tanks that have not been desludged.

201cIniform namin sila about it pero walang action,201d Fabia said, referring to LGUs.

The LGUs concerned should dispatch sanitary inspectors to the different private and public schools for them to see and verify the complaints with regard to the strict compliance in sanitation issues.
Other diseases which could affect the students include dengue, fever, colds and cough.

201cMarami kaming nao-observe na ganito ang issues at ini-admit naman naming na yung mga schools sa hinterland ay hindi talaga natin namo-monitor but we are now coordinating with the Division offices for updates on the situation,201d she added.
 
SYLLABUS INTEGRATION
The health programs have long been integrated in the syllabus of the subjects taught by the teachers in both private and public schools in the country.

201cThe integration of our programs is per subject basis.
When it comes to eating nutritious food and paglilinis ng surroundings as mafa-fall na siya sa Home Economics na subject.
So ganyan na ngayon,201d Fabia said.

There are also school-based programs but it is initiated by the Department of Health  where the students are the recipients of it.

These programs include feeding program where they are treated to free meals, food which majority of it came from their vegetable gardens inside the schools.
Aside from those programs, they also conduct seminars and lectures still spearheaded by personnel by DOH on topics on personal hygiene particularly on hand washing, tooth-brushing, and how to take care of their teeth.

201cThese lectures are done together with their parents so they would be guided properly even at home,201d she said.
Although the priorities of the program are those students who are malnourished, all students are qualified to avail both health and dental services.

The DOH will also provide toothbrush, toothpaste, along with iron-backed supplements.
Even with Deped2019s Essential Health Care Program  where the students are taught how to do proper hand washing, there is also a deworming program.
 
Fabia said the students are also taught waste segregation.

201cWe are still implementing the 5Rs in waste segregation which is to reduce, reuse, recycle, repair, and rethink.
We also tasked the schools to do composting,201d Fabia said.
 
True, children are being taught the proper way.
But usually, when they arrive home, the environment they live in does not support the learning they get, and there lies the problem.
Beyond just clean water: Health, marine resources, Beyond just clean water: Health, marine resourcesAce June Rell S.
Perez, UNTREATED waste water goes all the way to sea killing marine resources and contaminating waterways resulting to water-related diseases to men and degradation to the environment.
Recently, foreign interns from the Department of Science and Technology  in their study entitled 201cAssessment of Water Situation and the Safety of Wastewater and Sanitation in Selected Parts of Davao City201d showed that nearly all the wastewaters in Davao City is released back to the environment without treatment as hundreds of thousands of houses and shanties do not have septic tanks.

For the part of the regional office of the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources , though big companies are mandated and regulated through its Pollution Control Officer, if small to medium companies and residents living in near coastal areas are not observing proper water waste disposal and proper sanitation, the waters are still at risk.
Maria Loida M.

Avorque, BFAR Davao chemist said that waste water treatment is important.
201cWe have what we call Decomposition process, it is a way of cleansing wastewaters before itatapon sa nature, and also water sampling should take place in order to measure the chemical and toxic content of the water,201d she said.
She said that autoclave process can ensure harmful chemical-free waters.
Autoclave uses high pressures and temperatures to achieve a specific purpose.
IN this case, steam sterilization.

201cAutoclave enables the wastes to be sterilized thus cleansing it to ensure that when it reaches our sea water it is already harmless to the environment,201d she said.
 Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Escherichia Coli , though it is normally found in warm-blooded mammals, like in human body, when it reaches to the 201cintolerable201d level it causes illnesses and poses threat to the environment.
Intolerable levels of E.coli are normally caused by fecal contamination by human and animal wastes through houses located near rivers, poultry and hog farms disposing wastes to the river, and not having sewerage and septage treatment facility.

E.Coli is an indication that there is fecal contamination, and when there is fecal contamination, bacteria will proliferate.
Under the Codex International Standards, the tolerable level of E.Coli content is only at 11 most probable number  per milliliter.
But report showed that total coliform found on both downstream and upstream of Davao River was estimated at 4,900 to 1,887,000 mpn per 100 ml.

Fatma Idris, BFAR Davao director, said that as their office only has jurisdiction over monitoring of water temperature and chemical content parameters she is urging local government units to strengthen measures on wastewater treatment and sewage disposal.
She was quick to add that E.coli contamination of waters poses greater risks to humans in the short term than marine animals.

201cAt some point it can destroy our marine resources but very minimal only.
Still we would not want that to happen but our very concern here is our health, we humans are more susceptible to the ill effects of the E.
coli bacteria contamination because if the fish or any seafood that we come to eat has a very high content of E.coli surely it can pose threat to our health,201d she said.
She added that there higher risk when beached marine animals are consumed by humans as beaching is an indication of something wrong with the creature.
It could be that it is sick or even has high metal contents.

201cThe bigger the fish, the bigger the possibility na mataas ang content nito that is being absorbed by their body,201d she added.
Because the effect of E.coli contamination to one2019s health and environment is usually not immediate, people should work together to ensure that E.
coli does not end up in the waters just because of improper wastewater and sewage disposal because once the effects are felt, the contamination level will most likely be irreversible or be very difficult to return to normal.
 
On Effects to tourism As beaches as one of our tourism assets in the region, high levels of coliform can be a threat to the tourism industry too.
201cIt can scare away our tourists and visitors,201d Roberto Alabado III, Department of Tourism -11 director said.
In a report, Councilor Leo Avila III had cited that some beaches in the city are 201cnot healthy for swimming,201d as per Environmental Management Bureau  water quality assessment.

Caring for nature , Caring for nature 

Ace June Rell S.
Perez, WITH all the disheartening reports and stories in the news of cases of different endangered species being killed as game, one man in Sta.
Cruz, Davao del Sur stands firm with his principle of preserving and conserving the biodiversity.

Bernardo L.
Apal, a 36-year-old, a Bagobo-Tagabawa mason carpenter and farmer rescued a Pinsker's hawk-eagle christened as 201cMabikker201d last September 7 at 7:00 in the morning at the Mt.
Apo Natural Park within the protected area of Sibulan Hydro Plant of Hedcor.

Apal shared that the moment he saw Mabikker, helpless, injured and entangled in tree-roots within the protected area of Sibulan Hydro Plant, he rescued the eagle and walked for about two hours just to bring it to Brgy.
Sibulan Hall and Hedcor to surrender the eagle for medication.

201cAkong gibati, naluoy ko sa langgam kay nasangit sa bakilid, nalikos sa bagnot ug ugat, ako gikatkat ug gitabangan unya gidala dayun nko sa Barangay Hall ,201d he shared.

He said that even though he has just finished high school, he is well-informed about the need to conserve biodiversity.
 
A father of two children, Apal said that he is teaching his son and daughter to do the same.

201cSama ra gud na sa tao, kung nanginahanglan ug tabang walay rason aron dili sila tabangan ,201d he added.

He narrated that animals like eagles are not meant to be kept in captivity with the unauthorized individuals like him and the best thing to do is surrender it to the authority that can provide shelter and medication in order for the eagle to soar back to the wild where it truly belongs.
Mabikker when rescued was dehydrated and had an injury on its left eye.

It has since been rehabilitated and was released back to the wild at the Mt.
Apo Natural Park Wednesday after a month-long intensive care provided by a wildlife veterinarian, Dr.
Roberto "Bo" Puentespina Jr., who was contacted by Hedcor.
201cIf by chance I will encounter the same situation, I will respond the way I responded when I saw Mabikker.
My advice to the people who will encounter the same thing is that they should not shot or put in their hands the fate of the eagle rather surrender it to the authority for the safety and welfare of the bird,201d he said in the vernacular.
He dreams of the day when eagles and all birds fly free, without fear of being caught.
 
201cI don2019t think what I did was extraordinary, what I did is just something a person should do when confronted with that situation,201d Apal said.
Apal, more than just a former Citizen Armed Force Geographical Unit, a farmer, a carpenter, and a father is a hero in the eyes and heart of Mabikker.

Mary's favorite prayer, Mary's favorite prayer201cThe Rosary is Christocentric setting forth the entire life of Jesus Christ, the passion, death, resurrection and glory.201d 2014 Mariology, Juniper B.
Carol, O.F.M.
THE month of October is known to be the month of the Holy Rosary for the Catholic believers.
Way back 1206, Mary appeared to St.
Dominic after he had been praying and repenting for his lack of success in combating the Albigensian heresy -- taught that there were two gods: the good god of light usually referred to as Jesus in the New Testament and the god of darkness and evil usually associated with Satan and the 201cGod of the Old Testament .
Mary praised and gave him the Rosary as a mighty weapon, according to an account by Alan de la Roch, a fifteenth century Dominican.
Friday, October 16, 2015, the Fiat organization of the University of the Philippines Cebu  organized an event called Living Rosary, where students, together with Emma Gandionco, organization2019s adviser and UPC2019s libririan, Father Thomas Dunton, brothers Kees van Duijin and Peter-Andrew Frossard, joined forces in commemorating the month of Rosary.
In line with that celebration and before the actual prayer of rosary, Father Thomas brought up five important points to ponder upon why Catholics have to pray the rosary.
Remembering Christ with Mary.
It is through praying the rosary that God is revealing Himself to those who believed in Him.
According to Father Thomas, praying the rosary is a way of healing the wounded, giving remedy for the burdened and that rosary promotes spiritual health and well-being of the souls.
201cThe Rosary honors and contemplates Mary too.201d 2014 Mariology, Juniper B.
Carol, O.F.M.
Learning Christ.
A way to know more Christ and how related is Mary to Him is manifested while praying the rosary.
"Because of the mission she received from God, her life is most closely linked with the mysteries of Jesus Christ, and there is no one who has followed in the footsteps of the Incarnate Word more closely and with more merit than she" 142 .
Meditation on this cycle of Joyful, Sorrowful, Glorious and Luminous Mysteries makes the Rosary not only "a breviary or summary of the Gospel and of Christian life," .
The rosary is learning not just merely about Christ but Christ Himself as the Revelation.
Being conformed to Christ.
To be like Christ and to live a life how Christ wants His people to live is the latter2019s greatest challenge, given with all the circumstances and temptations present on earth.
For a believer to grow with a mind and heart like Jesus Christ and to have a spiritual journey that lives with the presence of Mary, the rosary is the greatest tool that could be used.
Praying to Christ with Mary.
Many people believe that through prayers, they can communicate with God, and it is the most fundamental foundation required to establish a strong relationship with Jesus.
Father Thomas elaborated that through the rosary, Mary shows the way to reach Jesus and she leads our way to our Father.
"Today, when dangers far greater than those of the ancient Turks threaten not only Christianity but all civilization, we are urged by our Blessed Mother to turn again to the Rosary for help.201d 2014 Mary in our Life by Fr.
William G.
Most
Proclaiming Christ.
Mary is the woman of faith, silence, and contemplation, and her way to find Jesus is by praying the rosary.
Praying the rosary is the way of proclaiming about Christ and being proclaimed as a son of God.
"Since the prayers of the Rosary come from such excellent sources 2014 from Our Lord Himself, from inspired Scripture, and from the Church 2014 it is not surprising that the Rosary is so dear to our Blessed Mother and so powerful with heaven." 2014 Mary in our Life by Fr.
William G.
Most
The event was concluded successfully as God showed his miracle.
It never rained during the whole program though there were already little drops.

The Fiat members distributed blessed rosary bracelets as souvenirs and as a sign of gratitude to those who attended and became a part of the living rosary.

As it is, 201cI am always been grateful to DSWD and all other government agencies which helped us fight poverty.201d

Chasing a dream, Chasing a dreamIvy C.
Tejano, "IT WAS a rollercoaster ride."
This is how Daryl Silapan Mislang described his life as an overseas Filipino worker  for more than four years now.
He is currently working at the Asiatica Restaurant in Kyoto, Japan as a waiter.
Born on October 1, 1988 in Sto.
Tomas, Davao del Norte province, Mislang completed his degree of Bachelor of Arts in English from the Holy Cross of Davao College in 2008.
Chasing his dream to travel around the world has encouraged Mislang to venture life abroad.
It was not easy though, he said, but he does not want to die without trying to reach his dream.
Before going abroad, Mislang worked as an image reviewer for MySpace account at Sutherland Global Services and a part-time medical representative in a pharmaceutical company in Davao City from 2008-2009.
In 2009, he worked at the Sycore Davao as outbound sales associate.
In 2010, he started a buy-and-sell computer business with his friend Deoffrey Ben Amora.
"It was actually great sa sugod kay mukita pa man ko until such time na scam ko.
Kailangan daw niya ug ingon ani na unit, nipalit pud ko unya gipadala sa Air-21 .
It took months before I realized that I was scammed," Mislang said.
"Pero wala na.
Nabaligya na nako akoang laptop, relo na niregalo pa sa akoang papa, and other valuable things.
Ang nabilin cellphone nalang.
Wala ko kasabot unsa ako gibati that time, naka-utang pa ko sa ako mga friends ," he added.
But life must go on, Mislangsaid, adding that there is nothing he can do on what was already lost.
He quit his business and entered modeling.
"I was hired as an ambassador for Cherry Mobile cellular phones.
I was also asked to join several caravans and modeling for apparels but I also came to a point where I was really down," Mislang said.
Mislang then decided to return home to find peace.
But later on, he then applied as a barangay watcher in Sto.
Tomas.
He added that he had been a barangay watcher in 2011.
"I saved up but my money it is still not enough.
Until I was not able to handle it any longer, I asked money from my parents and told them that I will work abroad," Mislang said in vernacular.
His father Isabelo Mislang Jr.
has a small business in town, while his mother Vivian is a teacher.
The couple is blessed with three children, and Daryl is the eldest.
In February 2012, Mislang went to Hong Kong.
It was also on the same year when he went to Singapore, Thailand and Malaysia as a tourist.
He also went to Qatar, Jeddah and Riyadh in 2013.
"I used the money given by my father as a chance to look for what I want to do.
From that, I invested on what he gave me and I also do modeling once in a while.
Then, I decided to work in Jeddah," Mislang said.
However, Mislang was detained in Jeddah for violating some rules.
In 2014, Mislang transferred to Al Khobar and worked as a waiter at Fresh Italian Dining.
On the same year he went to Bahrain then Dammam in January 2015 before he decided to settle down for a work in Japan.
Mislang is now in Davao City for a vacation.
He will return to Japan next year not only for work, but also to study information technology at the Urawa Tokyo International School in Tokyo City.
"I thank God for all these opportunities.
I am happy now, yes, although a part of my life is still missing.
But I know God is leading me the way, step-by-step lang.
For now, I am spending time with my loved ones," Mislang said.
Forest guardians: 6 years, still strong, Forest guardians: 6 years, still strongStella A.
Estremera, IT WAS a bumpy start six years ago when villagers were organized to protect the forest of Mt.
Sinaka in Arakan Valley, North Cotabato.
From the looks of the wary village residents, it sounded like a lot of work.
For one, the Mt.
Sinaka Bantay Kalikasan Alliance had made it part of their members' task to keep a regular inventory of the existing trees on the slopes of Mt.
Sinaka, which will require the members to stay overnight in the leech-infested forests.
The BK is made up of five barangays around Mt.
Sinaka: Lanao Kuran, Datu Ladayon, Salasang, San Miguel, and Tumanding.
Of the five, Tumanding is the purely Manobo village.
Others have Visayan settlers and lumads as residents.
For the past five years, alliance members have been celebrating their anniversaries in Davao City funded by the municipal agriculture office and municipal environment and natural resources office of Arakan Valley along with the non-government organization Kinaiyahan Foundation Inc.
But last October 19, they celebrated their sixth year for the first time, right in their village; and sans fund solicitation from the municipal offices and KFI.
It's their way of showing that they can now attend to their concerns by chipping in what they can.
Last October 19's celebration was hosted by Barangay Tumanding, although every barangay contributed for the food of everybody.
The celebration was made even more meaningful as just the Saturday before, on October 17, was the fourth death anniversary of Fr.
Fausto "Pops" Tentorio, PIME.
Fr.
Pops dedicated much of his time to Manobo people of Barangay Tumanding, teaching them ways to protect their environment and providing them livelihood projects to entice them from destroying Mt.
Sinaka.
"Unta ang iyang gibilin na mga buluhaton, atong ipadayon; ipadayon ang gisugdan ni Fr.
Pops ," Menro Jimmy B.
Montero said in his message during the program.
In a huddle with women members, the women admitted that their membership has grown but has not yet been able to involve every resident in a barangay.
"Layo pa gayud sa katunga ," one woman said.
But all three observed that even the non-members are already taking better care of the environment.
"We talked to them, we urged them not to clear areas in Mt.
Sinaka for their farms," one of the women said in Visayan, adding that those who used to slash and burn areas on Mt.
Sinaka have actually other farmlots outside the protected zone.
There was resistance, but through constant reminders, more and more are convinced that the greater good will come when they protect the mountain.
"There are still rule breakers," MAO Edgar V.
Arana said, "those who secretly destroy the forests.
We still need to intensify our campaigns for forest protection."
But he urged the members and residents to strive for "malahutayong kalamboan" or sustainable development.
"Malahutayon ang kalamboan kung naa na ta'y naipon na kayamanan - natural na capital.
Kung mapalambo ang kalasangan, mapatambok ang yuta, masulti nato na naa ta'y malahutayong kalamboan ," he said.
Kagawad Dante Dumanding, who is the pointman for the Philippine Eagle Foundation  in the area said that the Tumanding indigenous peoples organization already has 200 hectares for their greening program, while PEF has provided for an 85-hectare reforestation.
The officers and members were on in saying that it took the cooperation of all, villagers, BK members, and the local government, to put in motion this community-based environmental movement that is somehow enabling them to better provide for their families and organization needs through better farm yields.
During the celebration, barangay Salasang hauled in two sacks of rambutan for the people's snacks, while barangay San Miguel provided the "sahog", the basic ingredients like onions and green pepper, for the food the villagers had to prepare for all.
The other barangays contributed as well, all from their people and their farms.
Activities that barangays hold to impart the message of environment protection to both young and old include crafting barangay ordinances that require every child and youth to plant a certain number of trees for them to be able to join a sports league and imposing a penalty of planting 100 trees and taking care of this for one whole year for anyone caught violating a barangay ordinance banning the cutting of trees.
All five barangays are also maintaining tree nurseries to keep planting materials ready all the time.
Mt.
Sinaka has been identified as the major source of drinking water for the whole Arakan Valley and parts of Davao City.

The forests of Mt.
Sinaka are the habitat of indigenous flora and several wild fauna, including the endangered Philippine Eagle as well as civet cats, Philippine macaques, wild pigs, and deers.
"Nalipay mi'g dako na sa unom ka tuig nagadaghan 'ta, aron matanom sa atong kasing-kasing ang kaimportante sa kinaiyahan ,"Tumanding barangay captain Gayuting Tumanding said.
The challenge to ensure that the forests are protected gains magnitude as a highway now runs across these villages and around the mountain, with the project expected to be completed by February next year.
The concrete highway that will make transport of their farm produce and interaction among the different villages easier will also make it easy for poachers to come and go...

Tribute to Urbandub: Remembering the Cebuano Influence, Tribute to Urbandub: Remembering the Cebuano Influence
Local band 'Loop' performing covers of Urbandub songs from 'Influence'
IT WAS a night of music and nostalgia for everyone who came and spent their evening in KOA Treehouse on Gorordo Avenue, Cebu City, last October 17.
Urbandub fans and Cebuano local music enthusiasts alike gathered for the Urbandub Influence Cover Night, which was hosted by Escape Artist Productions and had featured local bands such as Capetown Claims, Tempest Ocean, Maria Campbell, The Line Divides, Shuffled and Loop.
The bands played songs from the 201cInfluence201d album of Urbandub, paying tribute to the critically-acclaimed album written more than a decade ago by one of Cebu2019s most influential bands.
201cTheir Urbandub2019s songs are a celebration to all Cebuanos, for me.
They have a different kind of element and effect on the audience,201d said Indy, the DJ and master of ceremony during the Cover Night, when asked why the event focused on paying tribute to Urbandub.
Bands performing in the Cover Night not only covered songs from Urbandub but also played some of their own original songs.
DJ Indy said this is a way for music artists to push themselves further and keep the local music spirit alive.
KOA Treehouse was crowded with spectators of all kinds, gathered to partake in the tribute to what many consider as one of the greatest Filipino albums of all time.
Entrance fee was at P100 per person with one free glass of beer.
The event was scheduled to start at 8:30 p.m.
but nearly all tables were already occupied before the event officially begun.
Bands started performing around 9:45 p.m.
and after every other band performance, trivia questions were asked and winners got T-shirts as prizes.
Tristan Pasia, of Escape Artist Productions, said the purpose of the Urbandub Influence Cover Night was to allow Cebuanos to celebrate one of the best bands to have ever emerged in the region.
201cMost Cebuanos already miss Urbandub.
We have already been planning this before and have talked to all the members of Urbandub.
We got a reply two months ago that they are okay with the idea of a cover event focusing on their album, so my production team and KOA decided to make it happen,201d said Pasia.
He added that another they also wanted to remind everyone, especially the youth, that Cebuano music is rooted and embedded on rock and roll or Bisrock and that that spirit is worth keeping and celebrating, rather than just focusing on the Western kind of music.
There was not a shortage of an audience at any time of the event, as people who left were replaced with more people who have decided to spend the night enjoying the live music, games, and of course, good food and drinks offered by KOA Treehouse.
The crowd cheered, applauded and even sang along to songs that have become all-too familiar to a lot of Cebuanos and even non-Cebuanos who are fans of Urbandbub and have followed them throughout their journey.
201cFor me, this event is also about nostalgia.
Urbandub has been around for more than a decade already.
Even if they have already disbanded, we Cebuanos should still celebrate them and their contribution to Cebuano music,201d said Carlos, one of the audiences.
Urbandub is a Cebu-based rock band that was formed back in 2000.
201cInfluence201d is its second album that was created in 2003.
It gained widespread popularity not only in Cebu but in the whole country.

Urbandub announced its disbandment last April 1, 2015 and held its last concert with the original members on May 9 earlier this year.

Watch this.
Ersh is a gay Cebuano slang word used to poke fun at rich people.
"'OMG! You guys! You know last year, when I spent that summer in Paris and we were on Champ Ely-ersh, ersh, ersh, ersh, ersh...' That's what gay people in my city hear when they listen to rich people," David said jokingly.
The verses are written first in English and gradually transition to Cebuano and Bali Bali/Ilab Ilab .
An English translation of the verses is offered in closed captions on the YouTube lyric video.
"I wrote it when I was venting about this user I had to see a lot of back then.
He was from out-of-town and always tried to make his life out to be glamorous but in reality, he was struggling to pay the rent and would take advantage of people I knew," David explained.
201cIt started out as a rant but the more I wrote, the more comedic it got.201d
David Wilde, an openly gay Chinese-Filipino rapper, makes up half of the duo with Zeejacob, a masked straight beatboxer.
The instrumentals consist primarily of filtered looped beats straight out of Zeejacob2019s mouth.
The newly formed pair is set to release a music video and fresh singles in the coming months.

Masbad, Wacky Tech, On Design
If there2019s one thing that I remember from my web design class, it would be that mockups are essential tools and building them is part of the design process.
This isn2019t just true for designing website and web pages.
It remains true as well when one designs user interfaces for apps.

Good or great design never comes from out of thin air.
It2019s thought out.
It2019s tested.
It2019s taken apart then put back together again.
If you2019d be doing that in a live app, it2019d be costly.

I found this great article from a website that I often visit to help you nail down your process when doing mockups.
It2019s a bit of a read but it2019s totally worth the time.
Check the article here.
On Coffee
It2019s best to watch the video.


On Photography
I2019ve been a photographer on and off since I was in high school.
Several years back, I dove deep into it and feel in love with landscape photography.
There was a certain feeling of satisfaction being able to capture a non-repeatable moment of nature.

Being into landscape photography, we imagine taking a photograph of vast scapes in front of us.
We try to capture as much as we can in one frame.
Some of us will even resort to creating a panorama for a more dramatic feel.
The bottomline really is to go wide, ultra wide.
Hence, your need for an ultra wide lens.

An Outdoor Photographer article said it well: "When it comes to landscape photography, don't just think big, think wide!"
Find out what that really means.

The new crossover is hyped as an urban lifestyle vehicle because of its small but powerful and efficient engine, sporty design, comfort and convenient features, and digital connectivity through its onboard entertainment suite.
Quite fittingly, the 2016 Chevrolet Trax was unveiled at the country2019s hottest nightlife destination where summer spirit and club music come together.

Welcoming the 201cBoracay Blue201d Trax on stage was an entertainment and fashion show, featuring 2014 Hip hop International champion A-team, a parade of models, celebrities, and fashion, art and music influencers.
As for the Trax itself, it2019s powered by a 1.4-liter turbocharged engine which produces 140 PS and 200 Nm of torque, while still maintaining excellent fuel efficiency 2013- perfect for both city and long drives.
Inside is a spacious cabin with a flexible seating configuration that can accommodate camping awnings and lifestyle equipment like bikes and surfboards.
Passengers can connect their phones for hands-free use while in the car via Bluetooth.
The top-of-the-line model will be fitted with a MyLink entertainment system that allows mobile devices to stream music through the vehicle2019s sound system.
The 2016 Chevrolet Trax comes in two variants 2013 LS and the top-of-the-line LT, with a choice of nine vibrant colors.
Each vehicle will come with a five-year warranty and free three-year, 24/7 roadside assistance.

The LS is priced at around P998,888, while the LT is available at around P1,218,000.
Sales and deliveries of the all-new Trax will commence by November.

Philippines tops international math contest, Philippines tops international math contest
The medalists from the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia  and champion Philippine Junior Team A  Jonathan Conrad Yu, Andrhea Angelina San Gabriel, Ryan Jericho Sy and Fedrick Lance Lim with Dr.
Isidro Aguilar, DepEd-Manila Division Superintendent Priscilla de Sagun, Dr.
Archieval Rodriguez and Dr.
Eduardo dela Cruz, dean of the Arellano University School of Education.

THE Philippines won the most medals and awards in the 2015 Challenge for Future Mathematicians  contest held in Manila from from October 26 to 29.
Contestants from Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam and host Philippines competed in the competition, which was organized by the Philippine Board of Studies Foundation  headed by Robert Degolacion together with the Mathematics Trainers Guild-Philippines  under Dr.
Simon Chua and the Mathematics Development Academy of the Philippines  under Dr.
Archieval Rodriguez.
In the individual contest, the Philippines won eight gold, 12 silver and 22 bronze medals, followed by Vietnam with one gold, four silver and three bronze; Thailand with one gold, three silver and four bronze; Malaysia with one gold, three silver and two bronze; and Indonesia with one gold and nine bronze medals.
In the team competition, Malaysia won as champion in the Upper Primary level while the Philippines topped the Middle Primary and Junior divisions.
In total, Filipino kids won 53 medals and trophies in the competition.

The winners were awarded by Dr.
Isidro Aguilar, overall chairman of the organizing committee; Dr.
Priscilla de Sagun, schools division superintendent of the Department of Education-Manila; Dr.
Eduardo dela Cruz, dean of the Arellano University School of Education; and Dr.
Rodriguez.
