To dream, to invent, To dream, to inventChristine Joice C.
Cudis, ALL developments in technology that we are experiencing today are because of inventions created from necessity; indeed, the world owes what it has to the brilliance of inventors.

How were inventors born? The answer: they are not.
Inventors are nurtured during their growing years.
Like Jose Guardo Jr., a 44-year-old Dabawenyo, whose invention of a Magnetic levitation train system is making currently making waves.
The technology used by Guardo, if funded by the government will be the third in the world following Germany's Inter City Express train and Japan's Shinkansen bullet train.
His invention was already patented in the World Intellectual Property Organization .
The MagLev technology will use lesser amount of electricity as compared to the Light Rail Transit  and Manila Rail Transit in Metro Manila.
This is because of the absence of metal to metal contact which means there is lesser friction and less energy is required during its operation.

There is no need for diesel for it to function as it is powered by permanent magnets which will cause the train to float.
It will also solve the problem on traffic of the country as the design of its terminal will house a parking space for those commuters who have cars.
The commuters can leave their cars at the space when they ride the MagLev train, whose rail will pass through the main offices and universities of the working people.
As of now, Guardo is hoping for the approval of the 29 million budget from the office the Department of Science and Technology-Technology Application and Promotion Institute  to create the usable six-seater prototype of the invention which will be placed at the Mindanao Science and Technology Centrum to attract more sponsors.
Guardo shared during the interview that one of the major influences he got was from watching science fiction movies.
"I was amazed as a kid when I watched the levitating vehicles in Star Wars: Return of the Jedi," Guardo said.
He added that when he was younger, he was already exposed to the machines as his father is handling different types of business.
"When I was in high school, I was already sketching levitating cars which my classmates would laugh at because they have no wheels," he said.
He believes that his idea may be a long shot but those who discourage him cannot stop him from dreaming.
"Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, and Mark Zuckerberg also went through the same challenges but they did not give up because they know that they are bound to make a difference - a good one."
Guardo also encourages the youth to use all the resources to learn.
"The youth should never stop learning.
Continue reading science books," he said.
There are a lot of things to watch out for from Guardo and one of the most recent is him opening the ACES Philippine Research Institute MagLev Energy, Engineering and Experiments.
"I want them  to be the next engineers, we need to pass this valuable legacy that is knowledge."
Strange encounters, Strange encountersRiain Alfonso, IT2019S that time of the year again when the telling and retelling of horror stories quite abound.
 
Of course, Cagayan de Oro City has its share of the supernatural or the unexplainable.
We have several noted haunted houses, schools, buildings, and cemeteries in the city and every single Kagay-anon probably has had at least one encounter with the things that go bumping in the night.
Here are some stories that were personally shared to the writer.
THE MISSED CALL
Cristina, not her real name as she requested anonymity, volunteered to be left alone in their house in Carmen while her entire family went to visit their dead at Divine Shepherd.
It was All Souls Day and they couldn2019t just all go for fear of burglars and other opportunistic hooligans.
Nobody else wanted to volunteer to watch over their place alone as it was rumored to be haunted and because it was that time of year when spirits are said to roam free.
 Cristina saw herself as one tough cookie and so she readily stepped up for the job.
The house is quite and has been standing for more than 35 years already.
The family has had several creepy experiences in the past, of things moving on their own when nobody was around, of weird sounds and phantom footsteps from the second floor, and of feeling a presence nearby sometimes.
In fact, several visitors claim to feel a bit 2018heavy2019 when visiting and their own labandera even refuses to enter the house.
 Cristina doesn2019t really mind the stories although she admits to sometimes feeling as if someone is watching even if she knows that nobody else is around.
After her family left, she got herself a snack and settled in front of their TV in the living room to binge-watch her favorite series.
Several hours into her series marathon, she heard her company, left in her room on the second floor, ring.
201cI ignored the call.
I mean, it was a holiday and I knew for a fact that there was no emergency at the office,201d Cristina said.
 
So, she continued with her marathon.
After a while, she went up to her room to check on the phone.
She got the shock of her life when she saw the number listed on the recent missed calls.
It was the company cell phone calling itself.
201cI just stared at it for some time then I checked again.
But still, no change.
The phone called itself.
I mean, that2019s not even possible, right?201d
In a daze with mounting fear, she went back to their living room and tried focusing on what she was watching, praying that her family would return soon.
201cI couldn2019t tell the family at first, kasi hadlukan kaayo sila.201d
THE HAUNTED MULTICAB AND THE FOOTSTEPS IN THE WATER
Fifty-eight-year-old Jocelyn Salvo, born and raised in the city, has been living her whole life in Tambo, Macasandig.
During Typhoon Sendong, her entire two-story house was submerged in water.
She and her family had to climb to the roof of their neighbor2019s house, which was just slightly higher than her own, to escape the rushing floodwaters.

They, and several other families in their area, were stuck there for almost 12 hours before it was safe enough to come down.
Some of her neighbors, however, weren2019t so lucky.
It was indeed a immense tragedy for her, having lost not only material possession but also a sister-in-law and several good friends in the neighborhood.
But, like most Filipinos, Jocelyn is made of sterner stuff.
The resilient grandmother picked herself up, literally wrung out the floodwater from her clothes, and started rebuilding the things that were destroyed by the calamity.
Two days after Sendong struck, she and her family went back to their house to start cleaning and salvaging the things that can still be of used.
Their house was pretty banged up; the backyard was even still submerged in knee-deep water at some parts.
They2019d work from sunup to sundown, returning to the evacuation center each night to rest.
They did this until their house was again habitable and they could return to it.

She shared how, when one night they were not able to return and had to campout in their still damaged house, she and her family heard footfalls from their backyard.

It was like several people were walking in the wet and muddy yard, she recounts, and that they can hear the sound of swishing water, as if being disturbed by a leg or a foot.
 
201cKanang among luyo, kay ubos man, naa pa jud tubig.
Nabati jud namo nga naay naglasak-lasak sa among likod, kana bitaw sound kung naay mutunob sa tubig,201d said Jocelyn, 201cPero inig tan-awon namo, walay tao sa among likod.201d
She also shared how a multicab, owned by a neighbor who perished during the flood, would start up all of a sudden, even if there were no one around to turn the ignition on.
 
201cKada na gani mag-ilog ang kahayag ug kangitngit, muandar lang ug kalit ang multicab.
 Kana pa jud andar nga murag suko bitaw.
Bisan naa na mi, naa nay tao magtan-aw, mag obserbar, muandar jud siya.201d  
What2019s even more perplexing is the fact that the multicab was submerged during the flood and that it would still turn on even without the battery attached.

201cBefore Sendong, wala man mi naka-experience ug mga ingon ato sa una, after ra man sa Sendong.
Pero pagkahuman to ni labay ang procession diri samo padulong sa misa sa Cala-cala, na undang man pod ang mga gaparamdam.
Siguro kay wala pa nahimutang ilang mga kalag kay wala pa sila nakaandam, mao naay mga ingon ato na gakahitabo diri sa amo.
Karon wala na man pod,201d she added.
CEMETERY TALES
Randolph Fuentes, the acting supervisor of the City Memorial Park in Bolonsori, Camaman-an, said that since 1982 there are more or less 50,000 of the city2019s departed buried in the cemetery.

201cPuno-puno jud diri, magpi-ot jud labi na pag November 1 ug November 2,201d Fuentes said.

With that many dead people buried in one place, it is no wonder that Bolonsori is the setting for some of the scariest ghost stories.
He said that although he himself has no personal experience, his fellow caretakers have shared with him their own goosebump tales of phantom footsteps, long shadows where there shouldn2019t be any, and inanimate object moving or falling on their own.
201cKami ang gipabantay diri sa kung asa gadagkot ug kandila diri sa likod sa simbahan,201d shared Bakang Hamlang, 201cAtong October 29, mga 10 sa gabii, imbes hapit na mi mahuman diri ug taod sa estalar, sa among stand diri, naa mi2019y na dungan dira sa sulod sa opisina.201d 
The Administrative Office of the cemetery is located just beside the cemetery chapel, and he said that they heard footsteps inside the office, 201cMurag naay tao sa sulod.
 Pirmero, murag naay galakaw-lakaw, ikaduha dayun, naa nay gatingog sa mga lamesa,201d until he said that it sounded as if there were people in the office working when they knew for sure that there was nobody inside.
Drawers were being pulled open, papers being shuffled, and chairs being dragged across the floor, 201cGrabe nako ka kulba-an bisag taga diri na gani mi.
Tinu-od jud diay ilang mga ginasulti na naa jud gatiaw.201d
201cTaga diri jud mi sa Bolonsori.
10 years na mi diri, dira sa ibabaw sa sementeryo among balay,201d said Emily Dosol, 40 years old, adding, 201cKanang magsalod mi sa gripo dira sa tapad sa chapel, mga ala-una, alas dos sa kadlawon, usahay naa mi makit-an, usahay gapanawag sila, musitsit.201d  
She shared how one time, she and two of her neighbors saw an entire family, a father, a mother, and their child, all dressed in white, came out of the chapel and floated toward the entrance of the cemetery.
 
201cNaka puti silang tulo ug abi namo naglakaw sila, pero pag tan-awon namo ang ilang ubos, wala diay sila galakaw, naglutaw sila sa hangin.
Amo lang pod sila gilantaw, wala na mi kalihok kay syempre, nakuyawan pod mi.201d
She also shared how, sometimes, the cries of the unclaimed Sendong victims buried behind the church would echo all over the cemetery, 201cMaglanog-lanog ilang mga hilak, naa pod mangayo ug tabang.201d  
This, coupled with the howls of the neighborhood dogs, would terrify anybody but she said that they2019re used to it already, 201cAnad na man mi, gapangumpra man gihapon ko ug kadlawon.
Mu-agi jud ko dira sa tunga sa sementeryo pero mao lagi, usahay naay manitsit, mu-ingon pa jud ug 2018hoy!2019201d
Kalinga: Of fulfilled dreams and permanence  , Kalinga: Of fulfilled dreams and permanence  
Mambabatok Apo Fang-od and Mj de Castro
MY HIGH school journals were full of wishes, of to-do lists before I get old.
Mundane things such as watching all Harry Potter movies in one day, cliff diving, learn how to sing a foreign song.
  But there were also wishes that would seem almost unmanageable to do, at least in this lifetime.
One of them was to get my first tattoo done by Apo Fang-od, the oldest mambabatok in the Philippines.
But I was sick of dreams that would remain just that--something you would only daydream about during a boring class or a meeting; and so booked a ticket to Manila with my best friend Kia, and went to see the cultural icon that is Apo Fang-od.

Before I start telling you about my adventure, let me tell you first that it hurt.
It was the worst form of pain I subjected myself into.
Pomelo thorn banging through your skin five times per second is not really my idea of fun.
But I would do it again in a heartbeat.

The moment we arrived at the bus station, I was so excited about the trip that I could not breathe properly.
I remember thinking years of waiting had finally come to this, an unkempt bus station with broken plastic chairs and staff that would call you 201cmadam.201d The first leg of our trip is finally about to happen! But life has a funny way of playing jokes on overly-excited people.
What welcomed us was a dreadful handwritten sign saying all trips of the day going to Tabuk were already fully booked.

Crap.
Taking the bus on another day was not an option because we would miss our flight back home.
 
I wish I could tell you I stood my ground and never wished for people who originally booked their tickets that day to miss their bus, but I did.
Lining up at the chance passenger line for five hours has a strange way of making you feel desperate.
When the bus finally came, Kia and I were lucky enough to be a chance passenger.
I have never looked forward more to a butt-numbing 10-hour bus ride as much as I did that night.

We arrived at Tabuk at the wee hours of morning, groggy and drained.
We met three other girls who were also on their way to see Fang-od.
Marionne, who headed up north to forget something , and Kim and Valerie, sisters who sneaked away from the hassle of Manila for the weekend.
 
The jeepney that would eventually take us to Tinglayan was already there.
It was a big heap of green metal that looked like it had seen better days.
 I knew the road would be difficult, but a strange fellow on the internet advised us to ride the jeep top load; and so we did the most rational thing to do, which is to follow a stranger2019s advice and climb on top of the jeepney beside packs of soft drinks, hoses, plywood, and LPGs.
 
Turns out, taking the advice was the right thing to do.
The view was truly better on top.
We passed through rough roads, cliffs, and harsh curves.
And despite the dangers of the road and the smoking locals  we felt at ease.
Three hours later, I was more than happy to arrive at the village of Tinglayan where our guide would meet us.
 
Francis Pa-In, a joyful man in his 50s,who never runs out of anything to say welcomed and accompanied us to a restaurant where we could eat our lunch.
He showed us his tattoo done by Fang-od, which resembles the Sleeping Beauty, a famous mountain that looked like its namesake.
 The roads were just cleared from the landslide that occurred because of the recent storm.
After lunch, we were on board the jeep again to take us to the starting point of our hike.

For someone like me whose idea of exercise is breathing, hiking is such a challenge.
Just when I thought that nothing could be worse than traversing pathways that were almost as narrow as a ruler, it rained.
An hour and a half of uphill trek became more than two hours.
My heartbeat was ringing in my ears, and my feet were ridden with mud.
 
But when I saw the village of the Butbut tribe, every inch of weariness was forgotten and was replaced with happiness.
When I got there, wet from the rain, catching my breath and all, Francis pointed to an old lady laughing at how tired I looked.
201cSi Fang-od,201d he shouted.
Her beauty was apparent even at her old age.
She was wearing a gray cardigan, and colorful accessories that were probably given to her by previous visitors.
 
I already knew her from photographs on the internet, but seeing her in person was an entirely different thing.
I could not believe that I was in the presence of someone who has been a master in her craft for more than 80 years, and is still practicing it.
Our host served us coffee which put Starbucks to shame.
Apo Fang-od arrived with an ice cream container of her tattoo paraphernalia.
 
I was up first.
 
Since Fang-od did not speak Filipino, Francis served as our translator.
I told him I wanted to get their tribe2019s symbol of a scorpion on my left rib.
Fang-od initially did not want to tattoo me on my rib because the spot was too painful but being the hardheaded girl that I am, I insisted and thankfully, she agreed.
The first time the thorn hit my skin, I knew she was right.
All I could hear was the sound of the bamboo hammer, I could even feel the thorn getting stuck on my skin at times.
I was bleeding profusely and my rib was already throbbing.
The other girls kept asking me if it was painful and all I could do was nod.
At times when she would stop to get more ink on the thorn or draw the pattern, I would breathe deep to prepare myself for another minute or two of excruciating pain.
 
The only way I could keep up with the sting was yelling  rock songs in my head as I was trying to match each puncture with the hard beat.
My rib was sore and bloody, but my thoughts were peaceful as I realized how privileged and humbled I was to have a mark of a living legend.
 
After we got our tattoos done, the locals constantly told us jokes and different stories about their tribe over dinner and cup of coffee.
The people spoke a different dialect that I could not understand and lived a life completely different from the one I have, but, I felt right at home.
  We met Grace, Fang-od2019s apprentice, in the morning.
She was a ray of sunlight; she really knew how to brighten the mood of people around her; and because she spoke Tagalog, it was easier to communicate with her.
 
We had not originally intended to get a tattoo from Grace, but it felt right and so we went with the flow.
Besides, what2019s a few minutes of pain to a lifetime of bearing a beautiful art piece on your body? All of us were going through their books searching on what tattoo to get from Grace, and I decided on a small crescent moon on my upper back and Kia had waves on her lower back to remind her how the sea brought her peace.
Undoubtedly, Grace was gentler than Fang-od when it came to tattooing.
Her hand was lighter and she would talk to us while getting our tattoos done.
Grace had been tattooing since she was 10 years old and now that she2019s 19, she plans on following the footsteps of Fang-od.
But just like any other journey, ours had to end too.
After we said our goodbyes, we handed out matches to the people.
It2019s heartwarming to see people smiling and being thankful for a simple thing like that.
 
Two days on the village was too short.
The place and its people found their way to my heart and it2019s something I would never forget.
The journey made me reconnect with nature and our culture.
Three newfound friends, and two beautiful scars later, I have grown a drive to encourage people to experience what I had during my journey to Fang-od.

Career advice for students goes virtual at Edukasyon.ph , Career advice for students goes virtual at Edukasyon.ph 
Screenshot from Edukasyon.ph
SOCIAL enterprise Edukasyon.ph has introduced an online career platform where high school students can get career advice for dream jobs and the education that they need to get there.

The site offers a diverse set of career options with free access to a database of 5,300 colleges and universities, 300 Senior High-ready schools, 50,000 courses, and 2,800 scholarships offered in the Philippines and abroad.

201cWe understand how frustrating it can be for our high school students to figure out what kind of jobs they want to be doing when they grow up.
 Edukasyon.ph can help young students map out the education they need depending on the careers they can imagine themselves to be doing,201d said Edukasyon.ph chief executive officer Linartes Viloria.
Students can simply find schools and scholarships just by registering at www.edukasyon.ph.
 As soon as they register they can click on career options, get updates on higher academic opportunities that correspond to their interests, preferred locality, and tuition budget.

To bring the website closer to the students, Edukasyon.ph has been conducting career clinics at high schools all over the Philippines.
It has visited 27 public high schools in the National Capital Region including the cities of Marikina, Manila, Pasig, San Juan, Taguig, and Valenzuela.

201cStudents all over the Philippines should have access to this information that can change the way they're planning their education and eventually their lives.
We want them to know the opportunities out there, so they can make better choices,201d said Henry Motte-Munoz, Founder, Edukasyon.ph.
In October 2015, Edukasyon.ph concluded its first wave of regional Career Clinic Caravan in Baguio City.
This activity was organized through the assistance of volunteers from National Youth Commission Northern Luzon, UP Subol Society, and UP Baguio Rotaract Club.
In the next few months, Edukasyon.ph is scheduled to be visiting high schools in key areas in Cebu, Bacolod, Dumaguete, Davao, and in other key cities in Regions 3, 4, 6.
201cWe are happy to be working with government, the private sector and volunteer organizations in bringing education information closer to our students.
 The responsibility of educating students on careers do not lie solely on our schools.
 It is a responsibility that we all share and we should work together on,201d said Edukasyon.ph founder Henry Motte-Munoz.
Under its volunteer program, Edukasyon.ph accepts volunteers from organizations nationwide who are willing to help in its regional career clinics all over the Philippines.

PhiSci Central Luzon conducts 6th PhiSciCLaban, PhiSci Central Luzon conducts 6th PhiSciCLabanPrincess Clea Arcellaz, ANGELES CITY -- The Philippine Science High School  Central Luzon campus recently held their annual regional quiz bee to showcase the academic skills of the youth in the region.
The sixth PhiSciCLaban is the general academic quiz contest for public and private elementary schools of Region III spearheaded by PhiSci.
The contest is composed of three segments: qualifying, semi-final and final round under the category of Science, Mathematics, Language and Literature, History, General Information and Trivia.
Around 60 schools all over the region participated in the said schools with one team per school consisting of one Grade VI and three Grade V students.
The overall champion in the academic contest was awarded to Special Education Center for the Gifted in Olongapo City, Zambales.
The first runner-up is the City College of the Holy Spirit of Tarlac and and Kalalake Elementary School-Center of Excellence and Tarlac Montessori School are second and third runners-up respectively.
PhiSci also awarded the Individual High Scorers in the qualifying round.

Awardees are Michael John Gaspar, Alyssa Joyce Segundo, Roxanne Bangsil, John Audric Ayuban, Christen Noceda, Martin Rey Belino, Keith Railey Reyes, Josh Tomacruz and Tristan Hernandez.
Head Organizer Jed Aries Castro clarified that awardees in the said contest will not be automatically admitted in their institute.
"In order to be admitted in the institute, students must take and pass the national competitive exam administered by the national office so there'll be no bearing whether you win here or not," he said.
Castro added that the contest is for to the region only since the institute did not yet coordinate with other regions as well as in the national level.

XU-GLI shares on barangay health governance in MisOr town, XU-GLI shares on barangay health governance in MisOr townTHE Governance and Leadership Institute  of Xavier University, in partnership with the Department of Health  and the local government of Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental, conducted a barangay leadership and governance training-workshop at Kinoguitan2019s Panabol Summer House on October 15 to 16.
The two-day training covered the topics on the role of barangay governance in addressing health issues of the community, the functions of the Barangay Health Board, how to achieve effective communication and quality information, and understanding the Three Health Delays Model.
As a framework for examining maternal mortality, the Three Delays Model recognizes the different hurdles women face in achieving the effective medical care needed to prevent deaths occurring in pregnancy and childbirth.
The said model, according to Maternal Worldwide, identifies three major factors which may impede women and girls in accessing the levels of maternal health care which they need: Delay in decision to seek care; Delay in reaching care; and Delay in receiving adequate health care.
The session drew together the barangay chairpersons, councilors for health and barangay health workers of Kinoguitan.
The development management officers of DOH 10 served as technical assistants for the training.
201cWe recognized the need to strengthen the barangays in order to better deliver our health services,201d said Dr.
Siegfried Hector Razo, Kinoguitan2019s municipal health officer.

Kinoguitan is a fifth class municipality in the province of Misamis Oriental with a population of 12,761 people based on the 2010 census.

Camiguin woman insists gender equality, Camiguin woman insists gender equalityCATARMAN, Camiguin 2013 Rising above any adversity is a daunting task for most people; it takes sheer will and determination, and a little help from your community.
Northern Mindanao Region has come a long way in empowering women and instill the volunteerism in the communities.
Charina Torayno, 34, from Purok 4, Kompol, Catarman town, is a Pantawid Pamilya parent leader who was chosen by fellow volunteers as chairperson for the organized Barangay Sub-project Management Committee that implements projects under the Department of Social Welfare and Development program 2013the Kapit-Bisig Laban sa Kahirapan Comprehensive and Integrated Delivery of Social Services 2013 National Community Driven Development Program .

Despite the stereotyping and resource limitations, Charina together with women beneficiaries of Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program , implemented the construction of a multi-purpose building which would serve as the barangay center of her village as an evacuation center during calamities.
Charina2019s participation in the construction of the barangay hall made her realize that women can be agents of change and eventually help in protecting the vulnerable members of society such as the elderly, women, children, and persons with disability.
"It is only through gender equality that women can help promote economic growth and alleviate poverty," stressed Charina, who also joins other women and men in her village in putting sands on sacks, piling hollow blocks, and mixing cement with aggregates during the construction of the building.
201cBefore, I would only stay at home struggling to make ends meet,201d Charina said, adding, 201cI will not bother to participate in any activities in school and in our community.201d
Charina furthered, 201cwala ko magdahom sa dako nga responsibilidad  but insisted that women like her can manage and do the tasks usually done by men.)201d 
Charina said her husband is also supportive, and added that some of her fellow volunteers had doubts if they could finish the tasks, but she insisted to them 201ckaya ra ni ninyo, kay nagseminar baya ta ani .201d
Empowerment
Charina revealed that her volunteer work led her to do almost all construction management tasks.
She also admitted that before the actual work that she did not know some of the terminologies in the construction industry.
She, however, was enlightened during the seminars.

Charina2019s tasks during the project were to organize the volunteers and served as manager.
She also revealed that she has earned the respect of her peers and fellow volunteers as the project progressed.
Charina also said that she was very hands-on during the construction by actively doing follow-ups on deliverables; she also said that she was relatively strict and non-complacent.
She insisted helping out in tasks usually given to their male counterparts, like cement mixing and segregation of aggregates and sand, but also admits that there are certain tasks that she cannot do like bending of steel materials.
After three months of construction work, Charina and her fellow village volunteers finished the building.
201cWe feel proud, this is a nice office, and during calamities, this will serve as an evacuation center and this place is also safe from floods.201d
Home and family
Charina said that despite the three-month-long construction work, she still managed to do all her daily tasks as a parent.
She shared that her usual routine is cooked meals and prepares her husband2019s things the night before so her husband can get ready for work faster, bathes her twin 2-year-old daughters, prepares milk, cooks for noontime and dinner meals, and while she constantly communicates with her fellow Pantawid Pamilya members.

Charina also said that the DSWD programs like Pantawid Pamilya and the Family Development Session really boosted her confidence as a woman and a mother.
She revealed that these programs helped her to manage her home and finances.
Now, their family can have savings, payment for school fees, and most especially for the wellbeing of her children.
Charina said that through these DSWD integrated programs she now has full confidence in her daily lifestyle and said that she has also gained the respect of others and more importantly 2013 the sense of self-respect.

From PCOS to OMR , From PCOS to OMR Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, BEFORE the 2010 elections, voters had to fill up ballots and drop these in the metal ballot boxes in their precincts.
This has changed, except for some remote areas, with the introduction of computerized voting in 2010 and 2013.
With the automated election system stipulated in Republic Act 9369, voters now only have to shade the oval and feed it to a voting machine which automatically counts each ballot.
 
From using Smartmatic's precinct count optical scan  as the vote counting machine for next year's polls the Commission on Elections had announced last August that they will be leasing an entire set of machine called an optical mark reader  still from the company.
This has been the office's decision due to the lack of time to refurbish the machines used in the last polls.
JUST THE NAME
Comelec Davao regional director lawyer Remlane Tambuang said that both PCOS and OMR use the same technology and that the name was just changed to distinguish OMR from its predecessor.
The main difference, OMR is running on newer software.
Reports show, that the government will be leasing around 94,000 new OMRs which amounts to about  P7.9 billion which is more expensive than their original plan of refurbishing the 82,000 PCOS machines and leasing 23,000 new OMR machines for the cost of about P5 billion.
December last year Comelec already looked at that option and hired Smartmatic to repair the PCOS machines but was blocked by the Supreme Court  last April as it did not go through a public bidding.
As per the SC's order, Comelec opened bidding for the refurbishment of the old PCOS machines but no company took the offer.
It was then followed by another bidding last August 1 but only one company showed up and was not qualified for the project.
With that, the Comelec has arrived in its decision for the leasing of the OMR instead.
For Davao Region, Tambuang said that they have yet to finalize the number of the OMR machines needed by the end of November after they have identified the number of cluster precincts in the region.
Tambuang said that for the past two automated election system in the region, they have not received any glitches in their reports except for the incident in Nabunturan, Compostella Vallet, where the ballots were delivered to the wrong area with the same name.
MALL VOTING?
With the Comelec looking at mall voting for next year's elections, Tambuang said that there is still a need to "fine tune" the said set-up so as not to compromise the election.
Especially with regards to the security.
"We need to fine tune it  baka kasi mamaya piliin nila kung sino ang papasukin," he said explaining that only Comelec approved personnel should be present in the voting area.
As of October 19 electoral registration board  hearing, Davao Region has a total of 2,716,846 registered voters.
2016 elections: What's new? , 2016 elections: What's new? 
DAVAO.
Nothing can stop this man from exercising his right to vote.
 
Ace June Rell S.
Perez, COMPARED to the last national elections in 2010 when President Benigno Simeon C.
Aquino III was catapulted to presidency, a lot of new features, additions and changes were included for next year's elections, all in the effort of the Philippines' Commission on Elections  to come up better and more transparent and systematic electoral process.
No Bio, No Boto
In February 15, 2013, President Aquino had signed into law the Republic Act 10367 which mandates that "all voter registration records must have biometrics information," and those records of voters who have not updated or validated their biometrics information will be deactivated, thus will no longer eligible to vote in May 2016.
Biometrics data will be registered via biometric voter verification system  by using digital camera, a fingerprint scanner and a signature pad to capture the voters' biometrics data.

"Due to this new law, all previously registered voters without biometrics are required to subject themselves to biometrics capture through the validation procedure.
All concerned is given until 31 October 2015 to comply with this requirement," the Comelec website said.
This new biometrics requirement has led to the #NoBioNoBoto nationwide campaign, aimed to entice everyone to have their biometrics validated whether as old voters or new registrants.
The Comelec's Bid and Award Committee  said that the commission leased a total of 23,000 VVS units.
A VVS unit leasing fee costs P90,000.
With the new biometrics requirements, Comelec hired a total of 4,135 technical support workers to facilitate the technology.
Comelec had poured a total of P727.215 million for the new biometrics requirement, which as they described as their added transparency measure.
With the implementation of this new requirement, the commission was confronted with challenges such as accepting a huge and significant figure of Filipino voters who have not validated its biometrics data.
As of October 24, Comelec-Davao Region data bared that a total of 195,826 voters in the region still have no biometric validation, biggest bulk of it is coming from Davao City at 120,000 out of the city's 912,959 registered voters.
Comelec Davao deputy director lawyer Marlon Casquejo said in an interview with Sun.Star Davao that there are 2,211,275 registered voters in Davao Region, and some nine percent or 195,826 of that have no biometric validation.
"These nine percent of the total voters in Davao Region who are still non-validated with biometrics information is still significant," he said
He was quick to add that with the time constraints it is impossible to accommodate the remaining numbers.
"To be realistic, we cannot cope up with these numbers with the remaining days.
For every district, we can only accommodate an average of about 300 per day," Casquejo said.
Davao City is composed of three districts.
In a recent report, Casquejo added that there are 64,684 still have no biometric validation in the first district, 36,445 for second, and 26,244 for the third district.
Biometrics systems are significantly being introduced and deployed globally as part of the new system in a bid to ensure fair and efficient electoral process.
Malls partnership
For this upcoming 2016 Election, the Comelec had forged partnership with the country's leading mall operators as part of its efforts to provide the public convenience and better voting experience.
Only for this upcoming election, the Comelec in partnership with various malls had set up satellite voters' registration booths inside their respective malls.
Comelec Chairman Andy Bautista said in a  report that "the poll body decided to bring this service to malls to help some voters who find it "difficult or inconvenient" to register in their local Comelec offices."
Bautista cited that he saw no legal impediment to elections being held in malls.
It is stipulated in section 42 of the Omnibus Election Code that "public schools or any other public buildings within the barangay shall be used as polling places."
The mall-based voters' registration and biometrics validation were made available since July of 2015.
Some of the participating partner malls are Ayala, Robinsons, SM, and Walter Mart, among others.
In Davao City Gaisano Mall of Davao , SM City and SM Lanang Premiere, Abreeza Ayala Mall and NCCC Mall of Davao had set up its voter's registration booths to cater for the three districts in the city.
However, with this suggestion of the Comelec, nothing is final yet if the 'Mall Voting" will push through.
"Though it is part of our major concern to provide convenience to the public when voting, we still have to finalize and plan this because security is still of our paramount concern," Lawyer Remlane Tambuang, Comelec-Davao regional director said adding that only Comelec approved personnel should be present in the voting area.
First "Social Media Elections"
Election campaigns go beyond the tri-media, TV, Radio and Print, now is the "social media" season.
Indeed, we are living now in a digital era where emergence of various social media sites, which is influential and powerful tool of acquiring information, is inevitable.

Comelec, had released a statement in August that more than ad spaces online, Comelec will be imposing rules on campaigns aired and published on video sharing sites, blogs, and other social media platforms like Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram.

This,all of because social media is seen to play a significant role in elections next year.
Social media now is seen to be a platform that is accessible and most used as a source of information, which can be deciding factor for a voter's choice of candidate.
According to Nielsen survey, as of 2014, 57 percent of the country's total population uses internet, which can be translated to 58,690,221 internet Filipino users.
There are some 54 millio Filipino Facebook users, 11.9 million Twitter users and 7.3 million Tumblr users.
Advanced Automated Election System
Last August, Comelec announced that they will be leasing a total of  93,977 Optical Mark Reader  voting machines from Smartmatic-Total Information Management  Corporation to be used in the 2016 polls, the same company who provided the Precinct Count Optical Scan  machines which was used last presidential polls.
The commission unanimously decided to lease over 93,000 OMR machines for the 2016 elections
"The Commission believes that this is the most viable, practical and safest option to pursue in our efforts to ensure the credibility of the 2016 elections," Bautista said.
The machines, which is reported to be fully delivered in January 2016, should it be delivered on time, it seen to give the Comelec an ample time for testing and also new machines are expected to address problems encountered in 2010 and 2013 elections, with the PCOS.
With just over six months before judgment day on May 9, 2016, the people as voters will be divided in two.
First, between those old enough to vote and those too young to vote and those well informed to candidates' profiles and those who ride the cycle of bandwagon without self-assessment.
Second is between those registered to vote and those who are not.

One thing important for the public to inculcate in minds while voting is "We are to judge," but "Are we to blame?"

What makes a nuisance? , What makes a nuisance? Ivy C.
Tejano, FILING of certificates of candidacy  for Philippine elections has become a source of entertainment to many as more than just the usual politicians beat the deadline for filing.

While in another facet of election realities in the Philippines, at least 18 past candidates face being perpetually barred after failing to submit their statements of election contributions and expenses  for two or more elections.

The list does not include known politicians nor anyone who won.
Commission on Elections  Davao Region deputy director Marlon Casquejo said even for local positions, a good number have filed their COCs for different positions in the 2016 elections.
Casquejo was quick to add that not all will be qualified.

At present, their law department is scrutinizing the COCs of all those who filed and checking on the background of the individuals.
What they are trying to do is weed out the nuisance candidates.
Nuisance candidates are those who filed their COC just to mock the election process, those who want to confuse the voters by using names similar to other candidates, and those who are not serious as manifested by the capability to launch a campaign.

"The law department has the control over the assessment of the COCs filed at Comelec office.
We will have the final list of candidates for the 2016 elections on December 10," Casquejo earlier said.

In Davao Region, at least 18 candidates face the prospect of being perpetually barred from seeking public office for failure to comply and submit their statements of election contributions and expenses  for two or more elections.

Of the 18 hopeful candidates, six are from Davao City, seven from Davao del Sur, three from Davao del Norte and two are from Compostela Valley.

He added that another list will be released soon.
Based on the report, most of the candidates would be facing perpetual disqualification.
But it was not yet clear if this would be immediately implemented.

According to the Resolution 9991 or The Omnibus Rules on Campaign Finance, the Campaign Finance Office may file motu proprio petition to disqualify a candidate.

Rule 13 said among the grounds for disqualification is when a candidate failed to submit his statement of contribution and expenditures in relation to at least two elections.
The rule added that the failures in submitting the statements of election contributions and expenses don2019t need to be in consecutive elections.

Lim assured that they would strictly implement the campaign finance rules in the 2016 election.
He added that they will not extend the deadline for the filing of the SOCE for losing and winning candidates from May 10 to June 8, 2016.

It all collected P52,300,518.
Resolution 9476 of the Comelec mandates that the filing of administrative sanction such as fine ranging from P10,000 to P60,000.
Women power, is there?   , Women power, is there?   Rhealyn C.
Pojas, PHILIPPINE laws recognize the role of women in nation-building but do the people do the same? 
Two Philippine women presidents later, women2019s rights advocates continue to drum up the plights of the marginalized sector especially for women to be given equal privileges in the right to choose a leader and to lead a government alike.
Section 14 of article two of the Philippine Constitution recognized 201cthe role of women in nation-building, and ensure the fundamental equality before the law of women and men.201d 
In an interview with Sun.Star Davao, Gabriela Davao City Secretary General Mary Ann Sapar said that while women in the country had been given equal right to suffrage and run for any position that they desired, women still cannot be considered well-represented in elections.

201cSa atong yugto although naa na2019y privilege ang mga babae nga modagan o dili, dili gihapon well-represented maski tan-awon nato sa kongreso karon ,201d Sapar said pointing out that even in congress, men far outnumber women.

For the 2016 national elections, there are women who had filed their Certificate of Candidacy  for the presidential position but if one would still look at the majority of those who have filed their COC; it is evident that the number is dominated by men, Sapar expressed.

Women are already said to be part of the forces towards change but since they are being considered as second class citizens whose fate lies inside the four corners of the house, they are hindered to take active participation in governance, Sapar added.

Sapar also narrated that even here in Davao City, one could also see that majority of the City Councilors are composed of men.
 
Gaining higher positions in the government still remains a struggle to women since it is more likely that men are chosen to have the higher positions.

In an effort to bring equality of men and women, certain laws were made and these are the Republic Act 9710 or Magna Carta of Women  which is there to help increase women2019s participation and representation in the government and the Republic Act 7192  among others, according to the Comelec website.
However, despite the existence of such laws, there is still a chink of women participation particularly in the governance aspect.

In the Comelec website, it was revealed that statistics per elective position by sex during the last May 2010 elections that the percentage of men candidates for the presidential seat is 88.89% which is way higher than the 11.11% of women candidates who ran for the same position.

For the Vice presidential seat, there was 87.50% of men candidates while only 12.50% for women.
The same is also true with the rest of the statistics shown on the Comelec site.

201cMen still has higher positions in the government that2019s why in Gabriela, we continue to convince women to recognize the potentials of their peers,201d Sapar said.

201cWomen were not only given opportunities to vote for their ideal candidates but we are also part of the so-called politics of change where one should look at what is good for the majority of the people,201d Sapar added.

Gabriela Women2019s Party is an alliance of women2019s organizations in the country that promotes 201cthe rights and welfare of marginalized and under-represented Filipino women through participation in the country2019s electoral system and organs of governance,201d according to their website.
 
Sun.Star Davao asked some people whether they put gender as one of the criteria in choosing their candidates.
Jimmy, 45, a trisikad driver and a resident of Barangay 34 in Davao City, strongly believes that gender plays an important role in governance.
But he believes the males are better.
He said gender is a basis for his decision and that he prefers males to get the higher positions in the country.

201cAng mayor nga posisyon...
pero sa dako-dako nga posisyon sama sa president, dapat gyud kay lalaki ,201d he said.

When asked why he thinks this way, Jimmy said that women are not firm with their principles or stand.

Ateneo De Davao University architecture student Pinky Qui\xf1ones, 20, and University of Mindanao architecture student Ken Alorro, 20, disagree with Jimmy.
They both expressed that gender must not be the basis in choosing the candidates.
Gender is not even a basis for their choices, both said.
That the masses still regard men as the superior gender is but an offshoot of being a patriarchal society, Sapar said.
201cWhy not give women a chance to show their capabilities in leading the country?201d Sapar asked in the vernacular, implying that one of the hindrances faced by women is that the society tends to tie them to responsibilities at home where they are left to take care of the household chores and also tagging them as incapable of leading the country.
Still the nagging question remains: when can one say that women are well-represented in elections?
The heat is on  , The heat is on  Christine Joice C.
Cudis,  THE campaign season may not have officially started, but we all know it is now being waged.
Each candidate, especially those seeking a national post, would want their names among the most remembers among the millions of voters.
It2019s a race to the top.
 
According to a political strategist and analyst, Perry Callanta, once a candidate reaches the top 5 of the surveys of SWS and Pulse Asia, they can already say that they won.
 
"Wala pang nasali sa survey na hindi na-elect.
Ang ibig sabihin lang, ang Filipino ayaw bumoto sa walang pag-asang manalo," Callanta added.
 
To understand the political mindset of a Filipino voter, reading on the Political Mindscape 2, a national psychographics survey done by the only registered lobbying and political management firm in the country, Publicus Asia will help.
 
Among the points discussed in the presentations of Dr.
Clarissa David of UP College of Mass Communication, and Ma.
Lourdes Tiquia, founder of Publicuswere the following:  
The Filipino voters can be categorized into five segments.
 
The Sparks, which makes 16 percent of the Filipino voters are found in the urban areas with higher representations of the non-working groups.
They are interested to be updated with political issues in the local government and believe voting is an expression of citizenship and politics.
 
The Detached Conservatives who are 12 percent of the total are those in the rural areas, with higher participation of the Muslims.
Most likely, they are the ones who will opt not to vote either because they consider the election system in their area as too complicated ot they are affected by personal commitments.
 
The Ambivalents who are about 26 percent of the voters are mostly Visayan-speaking residents with the lowest incidence of internet accessibility.
They see politics as irrelevant to society's progress.
  
The In-control people who are 23 percent of the voters are mostly Ilonggo speaking residents.
Voting matters to them, and they believe it is essential in improving teh society.
  
The Catalysts, 23 percent are mostly from the rural areas as well but they are those who are politically engaged and make efforts to know more about politics adn elections.
They perceive voting positively.
 
In the same survey, young voters were perceived as those who prefer character above experience, positions, and education when considering their votes for president and senator.
 
The adults, on the other hand, expects and prefers a compassionate presidential candidate to prioritize his countrymen's welfare by providing livelihood, medical care, assistance during calamities, scholarships, and housing projects.
 
During the registration of the voters in the city, Sun.Star Davao asked them on how they evaluate the candidates.
 
Esier Generale, 39, said that he went early in the satellite registration site so he can vote his President.
"I listen to the news, but if I cannot choose who to vote, I will resort to the choice of our Barangay leader because I believe that he knows who the best is."  
Loren, 24, said that he has not slept yet since the last 12 hours as he is working as a call center agent but he forced himself to file for biometrics to catch the registration before the deadline.
"I often browse into the candidates' Facebook pages so I will get to know them better."  
A 69-year-old voter who refused to be named said that she conducts thorough research before deciding who to vote for.
"I read a lot from the newspaper to discern who is worthy of my vote.
As of now, I can only see one person who deserves it, others are running for self-interest."  
Ideally, a candidate's previous political experience plays an important role in the voter's consideration.
 
There is a difference between a voter who thinks and a voter who relies on another's thinking.
  
We should stop treating the advertisements of the candidates as our only basis of who is worthy of our votes as they are only projecting one side of them; hence, we should start involving ourselves deeper in this cause.
  
At the end of this, we can say that Mahatma Ghandi was telling the truth when he said that if a person wants to see a change in the world, he shall start within himself.
 
Thus, if Filipinos are sincere in their aspiration to see and live in a better Philippines, then they should not only vote but vote responsibly.

Shopping tips to avoid the holiday blues!, Shopping tips to avoid the holiday blues!Jenny Molbog-Mendoza, As the holiday season draws nearer , shopping seems to be one of the most exciting things to do.
Well, who doesn't want to shop?
While buying the things which we have been looking forward to own before the year ends makes us giddy, we can never deny the fact that picking the right gifts for our special someone or those we love is actually more fun and exciting, right?
But wait! Do not rush to your favorite stores yet.
We have gathered some tips for you to consider before you fill your shopping cart  with numerous holiday giveaways.
1.
Keep your shopping list handy.
By having a list of what to buy , you will save on time and money.
The logic here is simple: when you are already sure of what items to pick, you can just go directly to the nook where those products are displayed once you are inside the store.
2.
Know your budget.
By knowing how much you can allocate for buying gifts, you will not end up broke, or resort to swiping your credit card once you run out of cash.
3.
Shop as early as you can.
If you think that you can already start shopping now, do it, and never wait for December before you hit the stores.
4.
Categorize the gifts that you have identified.
Prior to visiting your favorite shop, make sure to categorize your identified gifts according to which particular place you are going to get all of those.
5.
Schedule your trip.
Make a timeline of your trips to the mall for you to enjoy a smoother shopping experience.
6.
Keep your bag light.
Remember that you are bringing a number of shopping bags once you get out of the mall.
Therefore, reserve your energy for such task.
After all, you don't need to bring your entire "kikay" kit just to have all your fave lipstick shades inside your bag.
7.
Be comfy.
Apart from your budget, you also need to consider your outfit.
You need to wear your most comfortable clothes when you go shopping so that you can move easier when digging for the greatest finds.
8.
Go to the mall when everyone is somewhere else.
Don't go with the crowd.
Visit the mall when it is off-peak.
Enjoy shopping!

Sun.Star to hold first VisMin inter-school cheerdance competition 
SUN.STAR Publishing Inc.
will hold the very first Sun.Star Visayas-Mindanao inter-school cheerdance competition on December 12, 2015 at the New Cebu Coliseum, Cebu City.
Inspired by University Athletic Association of the Philippines  cheerdance competition in Manila, Sun.Star decided to create the event.
In a press conference on Thursday, Sun.Star Management President Gina Garcia-Atienza said that the competition is open to college level participants from schools in Visayas and Mindanao.
Garcia-Atienza added that cheerdance in Cebu was just for performance before, so now, they wanted it to become bigger and more interesting.
"We have four judges from Manila, who are judges from UAAP, and we have two people from Cebu," said Garcia-Atienza.
She said that Sun.Star is willing to work with Cebu Schools Athletic Foundation Inc.
 to organize future cheerdance competitions in Cebu.
"We are very willing to work with Cesafi.
In fact, if we are able to talk with Cesafi members, by next year, we can do it together.
I am sure the schools are looking forward to it," said Garcia-Atienza.
Juver Pataytay, chief consultant of the Sun.Star Cheerdance 2015, said this is the first time that all the technical requirements will be identified.

Anthony Ornejas, part of the cheerdance committee, said the registration fee is at P3,500 but with two receipts of one-year subscription of Sun.Star's e-paper, the registration fee will be lowered to P1,000.
Pataytay said the deadline of registration was supposedly on September 30, but was extended to give more time for the participants from out of town to process the requirements.
The committee is yet to set the final date for the registration.
Those interested can still sign up at specials.sunstar.com.ph/cheerdance.
The top three placers will receive a trophy, medals, and the following cash prizes: P50,000 for first place, P30,000 for second place, and P20,000 for third place.

Making Apec mobile, Making Apec mobile"BRINGING experiences to the next level."
This is a mantra that is often heard within the four walls of TeamAsia's office in Alabang and has been consistently translated to many things that the integrated marketing communications agency has been involved with in the past 23 years.
When the Department of Trade and Industry tapped them to stage some events that were connected with the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation , TeamAsia studied all their options and decided to change the game by bringing the important conversations of the summit to the mobile realm.
"We believe that through the innovative use of mobile application, we were able to really bring the discussion to the audience.
The discussion is no longer limited to the panelists or whoever is speaking at the podium because now, through technology, we have brought the conversation to the delegates' palm," TeamAsia Managing Director Bea Lim said.
The idea for a mobile application for the local Apec events started when TeamAsia President and Founder Monette Hamlin attended the Apec Women and the Economy Fora in Bali in 2013 and in Beijing last year, together with other representatives from the Women's Business Council.
Noting that there was hardly any opportunity for private sector delegates to be engaged in the discussions, she recommended that a mobile app be introduced at the Apec Women and the Economy Fora that was to be hosted by the Philippines in September 2015.
 This would allow the audience to voice out their opinions as well as join the conversation during the summit.

The mobile app designed by TeamAsia had within it an audience response system  that allowed the delegates to weigh in on the topics presented and even answer questions posited by the panel and speakers.
It was also used to gauge the opinion of the delegates about certain topics.
TeamAsia's mobile app was used in four Apec-related events hosted by the Department of Trade and Industry, namely: Public Private Dialogue on Women and the Economy ; the Women's Business and Smart Technology Seminar; the Seminar of Empowering Women through ICT for Inclusive Growth held last September; and more recently the Apec High-Level Dialogue on Inclusive Business.
The ARS system embedded in the mobile app was first used during PPDWE, the first time such technology was used for an Apec event.
TeamAsia also did the web and content design for both the Apec Women and the Economy Fora and the High-Level Dialogue on Inclusive Business.
"Apec is undoubtedly the most important event this year, and we are proud to be part of such a historic event," Lim said.
"But aside from this, we are really happy that we enabled a more interactive discussion and that our delegates were able to communicate with each other better."
TeamAsia is proud of helping Apec achieve its goals of building a better world through inclusiveness.

"We, in TeamAsia, believe in the importance of building inclusive economies, as we see this as the most viable way to really uplift the lives of not only our countrymen but also millions of people around the world," Lim said.

Social media and elections     , Social media and elections     Karlo Paolo R.
Pates, THE 2016 elections is regarded as the most challenging elections to date in the country as the Internet, specifically the social media, now plays a pivotal role as the platform for advancement of communication among Filipinos which in turn could affect to the would be results of the polls.

Social media has become an influential platform of communication in the Philippines as a driving force which encompasses all generations to be aware of the existing issues in our society nowadays.
 
As the 2015 State of the Mobile Web Report shows that the Philippines topped the survey as the "Most Social Nation" in the world.
Aside from that the Philippines was also named as the social media capital in the world by the 2014 Wave 7 Social Study after study shows that most Filipinos have logged a total number of 53 hours per week online.

With the advent of the arising trend in the Internet, Filipino candidates can now utilize digital campaign to promote their respective campaign platforms and advocacies even before the regular campaign period officially starts on February 9, 2016 to May 7, 2016 for President, Vice President, Senator, and party-list groups, ON paper, the campaign period for local candidates should start on March 25, 2016 until May 7, 2016, but campaigning is banned on March 25, the scheduled first day of local bets' campaign period, due to the observance of Good Friday.
 
But some election experts also say that as much as the candidates can really enjoy and use the wide scope of influence brought by the internet, it's also in the same platform where the fate of their candidacies are at high stake thru the demolition of one's reputation.

Lawyer Danilo Cullo, election officer of District 2 of the Commission on Election , admitted that the presence of the social media and internet could make a difference and a huge impact to the result of the May 2016 Elections for both national and local posts.
Although the Internet has already emerged during the 2010 and 2013 elections, Cullo, however, said that the aspiring candidates for both national and local positions could fully utilize the power of the internet for their gains in the upcoming 2016 elections.

Compared to the previous two elections, Cullo said that indeed the power of the social media and internet will be tested for this elections.

"In my own opinion, dako ang factor ang social media as to the would be results of the election.
Makita man gud nato na halos tanan nagagamit sa internet even kadtong dili pa voting age ," Cullo told Sun.Star Davao in an interview recently at the Comelec-Davao office.

While the Comelec is gearing up for the releasing of the final list of the candidates on December 10, they are now trying to come up with a set of rules to regulate election campaigning thru the internet.
The passage of the Republic Act  9006, an act otherwise known as the Fair Elections Act, supervises or regulates the enjoyment and utilization of all franchises or operation of media communication to guarantee or ensure equal opportunity for public service including access to media time and space.

While the passage of the "Fair Elections Act" in 2001 was to ensure free, orderly, and credible elections, the Comelec is now facing another dilemma now brought by the rise of digital age.
How the Comelec monitors and at the same time limit the use of the aspiring public servants the resources available on social media for their campaign.

In an article published on August 12, the CNN Philippines website stated that the Comelec is set to impose rules on campaign aired or published on video sharing sites, blogs, and other social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.

Comelec spokesperson James Jimenez said that the social media is sent to play a significant role in elections next year.
But Jimenez said that they need to be careful in regulating the platform of social media that it's not violating the public's freedom of expression.

The Comelec said their focus would be on how much the candidates spend on producing what would be aired on the social media and published on blogs.
As the general for the Comelec says that everything that is paid should be regulated.

Jimenez, however, admitted that regulation of the digital platform has its limits.
Cullo, for his part, said that no resolution on the regulation on the social media has yet to be issued to them from the main office.

"As far as I'm concerned yung mga ating mga nire-regulate pa lang naman ay yung advertisement time sa mga television networks, radios, and newspapers.
Patiyung mga size ng mga posters, leaflets nila at kung saan lang nila pwede ilagay ang mga campaign materials nila.
Pero on social media wala pa namang ganun," Cullo stressed.

But Cullo said that he is expecting that all candidates will utilize the presence of social media for their campaign but it would still be up to the voters to discern what to take as legitimate information.

"But I think the social media is the platform that could really make a huge difference in next year's election.
That's why the candidates will be exploring and utilize its power," he added in the vernacular.

Davao City Councilor Bernard Al-ag also believes that the rise of the social media could really play a big impact to the 2016 elections.

"It is now the primary source of information among the middle and upper class of our society.
It is an effective medium for political in the urban area," Al-ag said in a separate statement.

But Al-ag reiterated that the traditional form of campaign will remain as an effective move in the rural barangays.

Facebook tries to ease heartache of breakups with new tool, Facebook tries to ease heartache of breakups with new tool
This July 16, 2013 file photo shows a sign at Facebook headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.
The heartache of a broken relationship may soon become less painful on Facebook.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Facebook is trying to ease the heartache of breaking up.
A feature announced Thursday will allow people who have split up with a spouse or partner to turn on an option that spares them the emotional pain of constantly seeing their ex-lover's posts and pictures in their news feed on the world's largest social network.
Facebook will begin testing the breakup protection on mobile devices in the US before deciding whether to offer it to all of its 1.5 billion accountholders worldwide.
The option is designed for people who don't want to risk offending a former husband, wife, girlfriend or boyfriend by taking the more extreme step of ejecting or blocking them from their Facebook network.
After changing their relationship status on Facebook, people will also be allowed to remove their names from past posts linking them to a former partner.
"This work is part of our ongoing effort to develop resources for people who may be going through difficult moments in their lives," Facebook product manager Kelly Winters wrote in a blog post.
The breakup protection serves as another reminder of how deeply ingrained Facebook has become in society.
More than one billion people now hang out on Facebook at least once a day and those who have the network's addictive mobile application installed on their smartphones tend to visit even more frequently.
The Menlo Park, California, company has incentive to try to keep its users as happy as possible.
People who become upset with what appears in their Facebook feeds are more likely to avoid coming to the network, depriving the company of the opportunity to collect more information about their preferences and show them ads aimed at those interests.
The formula has turned Facebook into a huge success story since Mark Zuckerberg founded the service in a Harvard University dorm room more than a decade ago.
Facebook's market value now stands at $300 billion.

LOOK: What's inside the IEC Pavilion, LOOK: What's inside the IEC Pavilion
IEC Pavilion 
Laureen R.
Mondo\xf1edo, THE International Eucharistic Congress  Pavilion, built and financed by property developer Duros Development Corporation, is a 26,000-square-meter facility that will accommodate thousands of people attending the international gathering of Catholic leaders in January 2016 in Cebu City.
The facility, worth P500 million, was designed with a seating capacity of 15,000.
It now stands at the San Carlos Seminary in Mabolo, Cebu City, and will be under the name of the Archdiocese of Cebu once turned over by Duros on November 21.
It is where most of the IEC activities will be held.
Below are photos showing what's inside the IEC Pavilion.
Plenary
The plenary is where most of the local and international delegates to the IEC will be seated.
This area can accommodate around 7,000 to 9,000 people, said Architect Carlos Pio Zafra.

Gallery
This area can accommodate around 3,000 to 5,000 people.

Adoration chapel
The IEC Pavilion's adoration chapel was originally designed by Sister Celeste.
Glass walls will be installed here, said construction manager Rizal Camangyan Jr.
The chapel is still under construction, as the ceiling was changed.


Media center
The Church has allocated a space for local and international media personnel who will cover the IEC in January 2016.
This area can accommodate around 400 people.

Media personnel holding area
About seven rooms at the IEC Pavilion are designated for media personnel who will cover the international gathering of Catholic leaders in January 2016.
These holding areas will be converted into rooms for minor seminarians or those who are at the elementary level.


Sacristy
The IEC Pavilion has nine rooms for the bishops and priests who are attending the IEC.
These rooms are where the bishops and priests prepare for a service.
 These rooms will also house minor seminarians after the IEC.

PWDs ramp
The IEC Pavilion is accessible both to young and old, even to those with disabilities.
It has a ramp at the back portion of the building that persons with disabilities can use to access the second and third floors.
 This ramp leads to the media center at the third floor, which is overlooking the plenary.


IEC Secretariat office
This room will accommodate personnel from the office of the IEC Secretariat, which is handling the preparations for the international gathering.


Dining area
There's also a space at the IEC Pavilion where the priest and bishops can dine.
This will also be converted into a dining and kitchen area for the minor seminarians who will be housed at the building after the IEC.

Posts, columns and bars
The IEC Pavilion was designed and constructed to withstand a strong earthquake, considering that the Church plans to use it as an evacuation center in times of disaster.

Entrance and exit doors
Several doors can be found at the IEC Pavilion, making it highly accessible to IEC delegates.
The main entrance is located at the side of the building, just meters away from Pope John Paul II Avenue in Mabolo, Cebu City.


Aside from these features, the IEC Pavilion also has a parking area at the basement that can accommodate around 200 vehicles.
The facility will also be equipped with 27 closed circuit television cameras, 1,000 sprinkler heads, and more than 1,700 lighting fixtures.
The three-level facility, which is 97 percent complete as of November 19, will be used as a pastoral center, multipurpose hall and will also be leased for events, conventions and exhibits.
It will be operated as a regular facility by Duros Development Corporation, under the name of the Archdiocese of Cebu, after the IEC.

Masbad: In-phone photo editing, Masbad: In-phone photo editingRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, MOBILE photography is ubiquitous these days.
The majority of us will rely on our mobile devices for those quick snaps to capture a moment.
I'm seeing a steady pace towards not using a camera anymore to take photos.
And with the rising megapixel count on today's smartphones, it's not much of a surprise that this is one feature we first look at when shopping for smartphones or devices.

The higher megapixel count attracts faster but that high megapixel count won't necessarily be the only factor to look at.
But that's for another time to discuss.
Anyway, like I said, smartphones and mobile devices are our go-to devices now when snapping up moments.
It doesn't matter where and when these moments happen -- in a party, during a road trip, in a family vacation.
When it does, we pull out our devices to take a photo.

And when we have these saved, the next question is where to edit them.
Should it be transferred to your laptop or desktop computer to be edited before posting it? Or just do it in-phone.

Let me share with you my top two app choices to edit photos in-phone.
Snapseed
In most cases, well, 98 percent of the time for me, I edit in-phone.
And in a lot of those times, my go-to app is Snapseed.

It's a free app.
It's made and supported by Google.
And it's got plenty of controls to make any user happy.
Results are pretty awesome.
I get a lot of granular controls to use to come up with a better photo.
Here's a photo I took of a sunset over Talikud Island here in Davao.


Pretty, right? And that's just me using the basic tools in Snapseed.
There's a lot more to do while inside the app.

PicTapGo
I discovered this app while crawling the net for interesting images taken with mobile devices.

It's a fun app.
Lots of ready filters that you can slap on top of your photo.
Oh, and you can actually put one filter on top of the other and even set  how much a filter will affect your photo.

It's a quick fix to get a different feel out of a photo.
And you get a wide array of choices of filters too.
So much more than the regular choices in Instagram.

By the way, you can save your own "presets" or "combos" of filters so you won't have to remember everything yourself.

Here's one I did with PicTapGo.

So there.
If you still don't have these two apps, go check them out.
If you're into mobile photography, these two will surely become indispensable for you as it is for me.

Finally, don't fret too much about the editing part.
Keep it fun.
Because that's what it is all about in the first place.
