Seeing with the heart   , Seeing with the heart   Ace June Rell S.
Perez, YOU not only see with the eyes, seeing with the heart touches more lives.

Living in today2019s digital era characterized with technology that increases the speed and breadth of knowledge turnover within the economy and society, one requires complete senses to feel in and cope with the fast-changing world but not for a 29-year old Information and Communication Technology  expert and a proud visually impaired Ebenchito M.
Pabia.

Born with Congenital Glaucoma, a rare condition caused by incorrect development of the eye's drainage system before birth, Pabia admitted that life as a visually-challenged man is no easy.

201cYes, it is not easy but it also is not that hard, I didn2019t allow blindness to box me into someone I am not bound to be, our condition, whatever that is should not kill our dreams,201d he shared.

A graduate of Associate in Computer Technology in Asia Pacific College, now an instructor of the 201cComputer Eyes201d program of the IBM Philippines where he is a scholar, Pabia brightens and touches the life visions of his students who are also sharing the same situation with him.

201cI told my students that these digital and technology-driven days, it is already a need for them to master how to take advantage from these things, we need to equipped ourselves with the necessary skills, so as not to be left behind,201d he said.

He told his students that they are normal guys with extraordinary challenges which they all should be grateful for since God trusted them to face it.

201cI always make it to a point to instill with my students that they can do whatever normal students can, even outstand them, na like other people with no visual challenges that are performing in the It related activities even programming they can do it as long as they will help themselves achieve it,201d he added.

He insists that a lot also rests on those with disability to help them and make headway in life.
 
Pabia also recalled that his experience when he was still back in his elementary and secondary days, he enrolled in a regular public school not with a special education system .

201cMy family did not know that there is a Sped for someone like me but I saw it as a blessing in disguise, if not because of it I cannot experience what I should be experiencing.
It was really a struggle for me because all of my classmates are physically in condition not compared to my situation,201d Pabia shared.

He pointed out that what made it more challenging is apart from the teasing he got from his classmates and schoolmates, his teachers before also discriminated his ability.

201cMy teachers would even say that why I did enrolled in the regular school considering my situation emphasizing that I2019m too slow for learning, reading and writing,201d he said.

But Pabia did not allow anyone or anything to hinder his ultimate goal which is to learn and live like normal people do.
 
201cAko naman na eager na matuto, deadma, sulat lang, exam lang, sa kabutihang palad nakaraos naman ako, so in the end I made them proud of me,201d Pabia added.

After school, Pabia got in a number of jobs including as sales and marketing representative in a school for a blind in his hometown in Pasig, Manila and a businessmen venturing in computer related stuffs.
IBM Philippines regularly invites him as a computer instructor for its Computer Eyes program and other IT-related endeavor.

Pabia recently visited Davao City for a week rendering his knowledge in advance computer skills to visually-impaired students from Visayas and Mindanao.

201cThis is my happiness, enabling other visually-impaired youths to see beyond what I eyes can see,201d Pabia said.

Pabia, a true epitome of character for all the visually-challenged individuals has proven that we need not only our mere eyes to see the true wonders of the world, that there is more to what our naked eyes can see.

Balay Paglaum: An edifice of hope for IPs in Panabo City  , Balay Paglaum: An edifice of hope for IPs in Panabo City  

Lorenzo E.
Mendoza, THERE2019S now a place to enable young tribal youths to seek formal education without having to suffer the rigors and travel expenses of a daily travel from their hinterland villages in Panabo City.

The Department of Education, Panabo City Division under Schools Division Superintendent Dr.
Maria Ines C.
Asuncion, CESO VI accepted a Three-Room Building composed of two dormitory rooms and a mess hall/study room named Balay Paglaum from the Panabo City Local Government Unit led by Mayor James G.
Gamao on November 6, 2015 at barangay Lower Panaga, Panabo City.

Balay Paglaum is a shelter intended for the IP learners who are and who will be enrolled at Roxas Elementary School and Sindaton National High School Annex.
The structure aims to lower and eventually eradicate the dropout rate among IP learners, a vehicle to improve IP learners2019 academic performance and to help augment expenses of the IP families who are living 15-20 kilometers away from the said schools.
 
PROJECT CONCEPTUALIZATION 
The project is an offshoot of a research entitled 201cThe Unspoken Learning Landscape of an IP Student: A Process Documentation and Analysis.201d A series of consultations and dialogues were conducted to make the project relevant to the actual needs of the beneficiaries and the kinds of support systems to be established to sustain the project and maximize its benefits.

Balay Paglaum is a triangulated project of the Division of Panabo City supported by the Local Government Unit which was originally initiated by the late City Mayor Hon.
Jose L.
Silvosa Sr.
and now fully supported by the administration of Mayor Gamao with the full backing of the Tribal Leaders spearheaded by Datu Generoso Bonguyan, Datu Isagani Concian, and Datu Joel Manlangan and the Department of Education headed by SDS Asuncion.
 
THE BLESSING AND TURNOVER 
The turnover and the blessing of the shelter were attended by the LGU officials- Hon.
Mayor Gamao, Hon.
Emmanuel Pamisaran, Hon.
Wahid Ranain.
Hon.
Rodrigo Ambasan, City IPMR, 2nd District Congressional Key Staff Edwin Pardillo, BFP Fire Marshal Vilner Avillon, PNP of Panabo City, the six Tribal Leaders, DepEd Officials- Education Program Supervisors, Chiefs, School Heads and Principals.
 
The activity was timed with the 2nd Division Panaghiusa Festival attended by the IP learners, teachers and IP parents.
 
The two school heads - Dr.
Jonalyn Badua of Roxas ES and concurrent Division IPED Focal Person and Mr.
Glenn Patriarca of Sindaton NHS Annex together with Lower Panaga village chief Letecia Cabactolan received all the visitors.

Balay Paglaum will open its doors to these learners by the first week of January 2016 as a Memorandum of Agreement is still being drafted and details about its operations and maintenance are still ongoing.
Individuals, companies, NGOs and other stakeholders are invited to support the program.
 
PROJECT DETAILS 
Balay Paglaum emerged from the partnership of DepEd Panabo City Division in collaboration with the City Government of Panabo to strengthen Indigenous Peoples Education  by improving culture-based education and culture-responsive school management in Roxas Elementary School, Lower Panaga, Panabo City  One of the realizations from the consultations held was the sheer distance of mainstream education to these underprivileged children and youths, which discourage them to continue with their studies.
 
The City Government provided P2,000.000 as financial assistance in the project, which bridges DepEd curriculum competencies with Indigenous Knowledge Systems and Practices , indigenous learning systems, and community history, among others.

As the community2019s counterpart, the elders of the tribes assured Deped and the LGU that they will ensure the security of the dormitory.
The day after the turnover was highlighted with different tribal games and activities such as Piglet Catching, Tribal Food Cooking, Tribal Beadwork Making, Tribal House Visit and Display, Medical/Dental Check Up, Libre Gupit, Manicure and Pedicure and a Boodle Fight that symbolizes the unity and cooperation among the tri-people of Panabo City.
  
STATEMENTS OF COMMITMENT AND SUPPORT 
SDS Asuncion emphasized that the partnership will ensure that no child shall be left behind.
 
201cIn partnership with Indigenous Peoples' communities and with the support of other stakeholders especially the Local Government Unit, we will continue to address education concerns of indigenous learners by boosting our Indigenous Peoples Education  Program, and they have no reason not to finish their basic education because we provided them the Balay Paglaum that will translate their dreams in the past into the reality of tomorrow,201d she said.

On the other hand, Badua said, 201cOur main goal is to determine the best modes of delivering basic education to the IP communities in the city.201d 
While Patriarca extended his gratitude for the support of the partners in reviving the two schools that are seen to benefit the IP community.
 The tribal elders and parents of the students are greatly encouraged to be engaged in the implementation and monitoring of the program.
 
This collaboration also intends to help produce among the tribal young, effective leaders and advocates of the rights and aspirations of their communities.

LOOK: Things to know about Asean nations, LOOK: Things to know about Asean nationsKUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia -- The Association of Southeast Asian Nations  on Sunday signed a landmark declaration creating an Asean Community.
Key things to know about this diverse region, consisting of Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.
 
POPULATION
630 million people, accounting for almost 9 percent of the world's total population.
The region is more populous than the European Union which has 500 million and North America with 444 million people.
Largest member Indonesia has a population of 246 million, being the fourth populous country in the world.
The smallest member, Brunei, has only 412,000 people.
GOVERNMENT
10 member countries are governed by a variety of systems including elected democracies, monarchy, military junta, military-influenced civilian rule and Communist.
RELIGION
The region is home to a variety of ethnic groups, languages and religions.
Indonesia, for example, is almost 90 percent Muslim, while the Philippines is more than 80 percent Roman Catholic, and Thailand is more than 95 percent Buddhist.
Other religions include Hinduism, Sikhism and Taoism.
Among the 10 countries, summit host Malaysia is the most multi-cultural and multi-ethnic, comprising Malays, Chinese, Indians, Eurasians and indigenous tribes.
TIME ZONES
The region is spread over four time zones.
Four countries are 7 hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time, including Indonesia, some of whose eastern provinces are 8 and 9 hours ahead.
Five countries are 8 hours ahead of GMT, while Myanmar is 6 hours and 30 minutes behind.
ECONOMY 
If Asean were a single country, it would be the seventh-largest economy in the world with a combined GDP of $2.4 trillion.
It is projected to double to $4.7 trillion by 2020, and would rank as the fourth-largest economy by 2050.
Indonesia represents almost 40 percent of the region's economic output while Myanmar is still a nascent market with poorly formed institutions.

The countries represent a range of economic development.
The GDP of Singapore, one of the richest countries in the world, is more than 30 times higher than in Laos and more than 50 times higher than in Cambodia and Myanmar.
DRIVING 
Five of the countries drive on the left side of the road and half on the other.
In Myanmar, most cars are designed for driving on the left side, but traffic follows the European and American system.

Masbad: Syncing photos: Device to laptop and back, Masbad: Syncing photos: Device to laptop and backRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, WE'VE all faced this problem before.
We have tons of photos in our mobile devices and we wanna transfer them straight to our laptops without having to go through the hassle of backing up your device2019s data.
What2019s even more difficult is when you have a photo in your laptop that you want to transfer to your device.
For a lot of us, we2019d email it to ourselves or Dropbox it to ourselves.

I2019ve been in that road before and, thankfully, found a solution via an app.
It2019s called Photo Sync.
It2019s both available for iOS and Android and you can download directly from their website.
There are tons of information in their site as well that you can go through before deciding to actually download and install in your device.

Aside from the app that you download for your device, there2019s also a companion app that you need to download for your computer.
Install it and from there, it2019s eezy breezy.

Once installed in your computer , I recommend keeping that app on your dock to make life even easier during the times you2019ll transfer photos.

If you need to transfer a photo from your laptop to your device what you need to do are:
* Open the app on your device and make sure it2019s the active app.

* Go back to your laptop, select the photos you want to transfer, drag them to the app2019s dock icon and drop it there.
* After dropping it there, it will open the app2019s window and will automatically transfer to photos to your device without you having to do anything else.

If it2019s the other way around:
* Open both apps.
Don2019t worry if you don2019t see any active window on your computer.
As long as it2019s already launched, it2019s there.

* On your device, go back to the app window.
If you2019ve given it access to your Photos already, you2019ll see all the photos stored in your device.
* Select the photos you want to transfer, tap on that red icon at the top-left portion of the app.
It will open a window and ask you whether to send the photos that are 201cNew201d, 201cSelected201d and 201cAll201d.
Of course, tap on 201cSelected201d.
After that, the apps will take care of the transfer.

* On your computer, go to the Pictures  folder.
You can change the location or folder where the app will store those photos that you transfer.
This app has been a bane for me especially since I do photography with a camera.
And I shoot RAW images almost all the time.
I post process these photos on my laptop, of course.
I don2019t need to email it to myself anymore or wait for Dropbox to finish syncing folders so I can get the same file in my iPhone.

Just a few simple steps with the app and I2019m done.
It won2019t even take me more than two minutes to do the transfer.

If you2019re such a shutterbug, I highly recommend that you have this app in your device and your laptop.
You2019ll thank me for it.

Happy shooting!
Using technology to see , Using technology to see 
DAVAO.
Using technology to see.

Ace June Rell S.
Perez, IN A fast changing, evolving world driven by technology creating massive change and disruption that have forever altered the way people interact, we are seeing lightning-fast innovation and there is no other way but to cope, adapt, and catch up, able or not.

With computer-aged era, we use our hearing senses for appreciating audio and capturing messages, hands for manipulating the keyboards and other parts of the computer, and eyes for seeing what on the screen, envisioning the graphics, and other visual purposes.

For many, in order to ride the digital change one must have these physical capabilities to maximize the advantages of technology but for some, it only takes courage and eagerness to learn to be in the loop.
In the light of giving and enabling those who need more attention to cope with the digital era when computer skills are already a necessity more than just an additional skill, IBM Philippines continues its commitment to enable visually-challenged public school students to be a computer literate through its National Computer Camp for Blind Students or "Computer Eyes" program.
Computer Eyes is a joint program of IBM and the non-government organization  Resources for the Blind.
It provides training in basic and advance computer programs and how to surf the Internet using special software to young low-vision and blind students in a span of 40-hour sessions.
In a recent graduation ceremony of the 27 visually-challenged student beneficiaries from Mindanao and Visayas in Davao City last November 12, the before hopeless and unequipped students were radically turned to an optimistic and armed individuals ready to conquer the high tech world.
"With the program, I was encouraged more to lift myself to a higher heights, before I thought that people like us, visually-impaired, akala ko hindi ko kaya, hindi ko kayang mag upgrade to the point that I thought that I am only bound to be in the house only, I haven't realize that I can indeed upgrade my skills, even with computer, not until now, "Josephine R.
Abanto, a grade nine student with a congenital Glaucoma condition shared.
The 18-year-old student also shared that she now sees her condition not a hindrance to pursue her dreams but an inspiration to those individuals sharing the same situation as her to strive and thrive.
Abanto dreamed of becoming a professional singer and a special education  teacher.
"I am after teaching those who are like me, teach them what I learned and give them hope and knowledge to see the brighter side of life," she added.
A grade 10 student named Joji Brix Relatado, a 16 years old lad with a Subluxated lens that gives him a low-vision condition, wishes to also share his knowledge gained from the training to his friends with the same condition as him.
He dreams to be a lawyer someday.
"It really helped, not just by providing us technical assistance but leveling up our self confidence and on how we view our self-worth," Relatado said.
"It made us reaffirm that disability is no hindrance, it is not a reason to succumb but rather a challenge to be faced as we strive hard for excellence," he added.
He added that with the training, he has improved his knowledge on how to manipulate and navigate the computer especially in basic computer applications like document processing, spreadsheet calculations, power point, webpage creation thru Hyper Text Markup Language , including use of social media networks.
Ebenchito M.
Pabia, one of the program's instructors, who is also a visually-impaired individual, for his part said that they can prove the world wrong that they can also do what normal people does.

"I told my students that these digital and technology-driven days, it is already a need for them to master how to take advantage from these things, we need to equipped ourselves with the necessary skills, so as not to be left behind," he said adding that they can do whatever normal students can, even outstand them.
The program leverages on a software called Jobs Access With Speech .
The application converts text display into speech and allows users to navigate through the computer through audio prompts.
"In our aim to create an inclusive youth enablement program, IBM continues to support RBI on this endeavor," Pineda said adding that the program allows them to reach out to members of the uniquely-abled community and provide them useful skills and better opportunities for a better future.
For its 13th year, the program has produced over 340 graduates nationwide.

Enabling eyes to see what is beyond is maximizing our true gift of senses and this is by far the best way to keep stride with the ever changing world.

Getting the big picture, Getting the big picture
A Steady Hand, a steadfast faith.
Sun.Star photojournalist Allan Cuizon likes to build remote-controlled aircraft, then take photos with them.
Ready, aim, take off: Sun.Star2019s photojournalists are taking field work to new heights
, AS A child, Allan Cuizon dreamt of flight.

Although he ended up in a different line of work, Cuizon never entirely let that dream go.
When the challenges of work and home life allowed it, he spent his time learning about such things as flight dynamics or fiddling with remote-controlled model aircraft, often built from scratch.
In January 2014, dream and duty aligned.

He attached a digital point-and-shoot camera to a quadcopter he had made himself, flew the rig above a bridge in Bohol that was being fixed after the great quake, and took pictures that were different from those of all the other journalists at the same site.
Aerial photographs offer a new perspective, Cuizon says.
They show extent more effectively than photographs snapped at ground level.
They allow viewers a better grasp of how large or how widespread the effects of a news event are.
They also show familiar scenes from a new angle.

For the photojournalist, however, using remotely piloted aircraft  or unmanned aerial vehicles 2014more popularly known as drones2014creates a new set of challenges.
On the ground, photojournalists can focus on composition and capturing an event at the right moment.
Some things they can2019t control, like how much light is available as the news breaks.
The few, like Cuizon, who both take pictures and fly RPAs have to think about several other details besides.
They can2019t control how the wind will behave while their rigs are airborne.
Flight time is limited2014no more than 15 to 20 minutes2014so they have to cover as much of an area as they can, before they land and recharge.
Cuizon says he2019s learned to take off fast, before the sight of Sun.Star Cebu2019s DJI Phantom 2 quadcopter attracts a crowd .

201cBefore taking off, I survey the area I need to cover.
I identify the points where I need the quadcopter to go,201d Cuizon says.
When a crowd builds up around him, it can get nerve-wracking, he admits.
He is particularly thankful that, after one quadcopter he had made crashed in Cordova, no one was hurt, and Sun.Star Cebu President and General Manager Julius 201cJJ201d Neri, Jr.
encouraged him to keep flying.
It was Neri who introduced 201cdrone photojournalism201d to Sun.Star Cebu, even to the extent of covering events himself in the early days.
201cOur first major aerial coverage was the  fluvial parade in 2013,201d Neri recalled.
His shots, taken over the Cebu pier as the boat bearing the Sto.
Ni\xf1o docked, showed that from above, the dancers welcoming the Ni\xf1o home had formed , something that looked like rosary beads in the early morning light.
Neri began to operate quadcopters in 2011, but has been competitively flying remote-controlled aircraft for around 25 years.
201cI introduced this  to Sun.Star because I saw this as the wave of the future for photojournalism,201d he said.
201cIt offers a whole new perspective.201d
201cI also saw it as an opportunity for us to further differentiate ourselves from the competition,201d he added.

The urge to take photos from way above is deep-seated.

201cJournalists and photographers ascended in hot air balloons during the 19th century to cover battles and other events.
During the 20th century many media used fixed-wing aircraft and, later, helicopters to cover events from above,201d observed David Goldberg, Mark Corcoran and Robert G.
Picard in 201cOpportunities and Challenges of Drones in News Gathering,201d a study posted by the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism.
RPAs, while by no means cheap, are far more affordable than renting helicopters for news coverage.
They2019re also arguably safer.
For Sun.Star Cebu, which today marks its 33rd year, using RPAs has brought unheard-of convenience and unprecedented images.

And while it is a fairly recent practice, the use of quadcopters has helped create memorable images that have enriched Sun.Star2019s coverage, both in print and online.
Supporters and armchair athletes who couldn2019t get a firsthand look at the swim leg of the last two Ironman 70.3 races in Cebu had only to search for Cuizon2019s video, taken from the prow of a motor banca, to see what that leg of the race looked like.

For Cuizon, whose passions include architecture, 201cdrone journalism201d has also offered the chance to see the city2019s layout better.
Many familiar buildings look interesting again from above.

201cAerial photographs and video add context to story, provide rich illustrations of the scale of crowds, impact of natural disasters, flooding or drought, and allow photography in locations photographers cannot reach because of dangers or impediments to access,201d the Reuters study pointed out.
Take a look at some of the images Cuizon has taken from 15 to 400 feet above ground.
Don2019t they make you see the story better?

What is happiness according to a yoga teacher, What is happiness according to a yoga teacher
CEBU.
Brahma Kumaris Sister Denise Lawrence talks about 'The Healing Power of Happiness.' She has pioneered the establishment of Brahma Kumaris Centres and taught meditation methods and spiritual knowledge.

A SPIRITUAL teacher and practitioner of Raja Yoga meditation, Brahma Kumaris  Sister Denise Lawrence reminded the public in a press conference Thursday of what happiness is really about, citing the problems and issues the world is facing right now, including materialism among the youth.
Raja Yoga, also known as classical yoga or simply yoga, is concerned principally with the cultivation of the mind using meditation to control and subdue mental fluctuations in order to still the mind and achieve liberation , according to New World Encyclopedia.
Lawrence said that people nowadays seem to have misunderstood what happiness is.
"People are spiritually depleted.
Living in a predominantly materialistic society, a lot of people have abandoned their spiritual side and no longer know how to resource themselves spiritually."
She said the people need the element of being able to participate in a healing process that will help develop in the search of happiness, since "there can be no real happiness until the soul finds its peace."
"Happiness is really the purpose of life.
That2019s why we are here on Earth to experience happiness, to share happiness, to enjoy happiness," she said.
Happiness, for her, is a very deep inner experience that arises in a sustainable way when one does some kind of charity, some kind of act of benefit to another human being.
And when one does that, that person will actually experience real and lasting happiness, she said.
She mentioned three ingredients of happiness: having enough money, good health and good relationships.
Lawrence, 63, travels extensively to give lectures, conduct seminars, and conferences on spiritual practice and yoga or meditation.
She is in Cebu City to give a talk on the healing power of happiness.
As a Raja Yoga teacher for the BK Centres, Lawrence gives meditation courses to recovering narcotic addicts at several facilities of the Los Angeles prison system.
She has also presented television programmes on Raja Yoga meditation methods and spiritual knowledge, as well as on addiction recovery.
Brahma Kumaris Centres, which she has pioneered, is a nonsectarian and non-government organization that accepts people from all walks of life, religion, race or creed, and "seeks to help people rediscover goodness from within and encourage the development of spiritual awareness, attitude and behavior through meditation."

Morente of the Police Regional Office  in Davao region appointed him as a striker of his team.
Here are his trainings and titles, including his assignments.
The Basic Recruit Course  in Regional Training School Center; PNP-Special Counter-Insurgency Operation Unit Training  Class Alpha & Bravo; Regional Public Safety Battalion  in Davao region in 3rd maneuver company; Jose Abad Santos Police Station in Davao Occidental and currently assigned in Panabo Police Station in Davao del Norte Provincial Police Office .

"Even though I was a product of a broken family and though I was raised by a poor family, I did not let it hinder me from pursuing my dreams.
No one should use their past as an excuse to not reach their goals.
There is always a way to pursue our dreams," Helborion said.

"To all the aspiring police officers today, they should not lose hope and pray to God because it is him who will guide us to where he would want us to be.201d  Helborion2019s life story is of great value and serves as a living testimony to others.
His story is a proof that every minute and every second of our lives must not be wasted.
 
Helborion is now married to Klarisse Coronel-Helborion who is an elementary teacher of Island Garden City of Samal  in Davao del Norte.
 
Positively Living , Positively Living Riain Alfonso, AS THE world commemorates the World AIDS Day on Tuesday, December 1, advocates of Human Immunodeficiency Virus and Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome  in Cagayan de Oro City are organizing various events to raise more awareness on HIV and AIDS, help improve the plight of the people living with it and raise funds to propel more HIV-AIDS campaigns such as free HIV testing to encourage more to get tested.

Most people think of sob stories with regard to the disease and not everyone knows that there are actually positive stories out there especially with person/s living with HIV .
 
Here are three life stories of people who, upon finding out of their positive status, are still able to live positive and productive lives.
The early detection of their disease contributed greatly to the positive outcomes of each of the stories below.

The raised awareness of what HIV and AIDS is all about and the elimination of stigma is what each story aspires to achieve.

Shaf97
Shaf97 is thirty-five years old who works as waiter in a bar here in the city.
He chose this moniker because it holds a special meaning to him.
The number 97 denotes that he was patient 97 in a treatment hub in Western Mindanao, where he hails from, for plHIV.
201cMy story began when I was still in Dubai and I got raped,201d shared Shaf, 201cI worked in the UAE for eight years as cashier in an American Restaurant.201d Before going to Dubai, he saw himself as straight and had a girlfriend but had confusing feelings for other men.
He had already been working for three years when the incident happened.
He was working the night shift when a customer called to order takeout.
201cNung pinick up nya yung order nya sa restaurant, he asked for my number.201d  The customer, an Arab policeman, said he just wanted to make friends with me, 201cKasi gusto daw nya ang mga Filipinos.201d
They started chatting up and, after three weeks, Shaf agreed to meet up for a friendly outing.
A bit naive, he believed that it was going to be an innocent jaunt.
The Arab, instead, brought him to the middle of the desert and, threatened him with a gun, Shaf had no other recourse but to give in to what he wanted.
201cTinali nya ang kamay ko gamit ang Keffiyeh niya and ginawa niya yung gusto niyang gawin sa akin.
He removed all my clothes and he forced me.
Yun na.201d
201cAfter nun, tinakot niya ako.
If magsusumbong daw ako, may gagawin daw siyang mas worse pa.
Nagmakaawa ako sa kanya na ibalik niya ako sa accommodation ko.
Sabi ko, hindi talaga ako magsusumbong.201d Luckily, the Arab brought him back to where he was staying and let him go without further harm.
He was bleeding heavily and was not able to work for three days.

For more than a month nothing else happened until the Arab man started contacting him again.
201cParang sinusuyo niya ako, sabi niya it2019s better na maging kami na lang.201d Shaf, out of fear and because he also started feeling something for the man, agreed to the proposition as he fell in love with his violator.
201cSabi nila, kapag may boyfriend ka daw na police, secured ka.
So mas preferred ko na din na ganun, for security.
Every time na nagmemeet kami, pinaparamdam niya sa akin na special ako.
Naging partner ko siya for almost three years.201d 
But Shaf was not satisfied.
Despite being in a relationship, he started to see other men on the side, charging them for sex.
After work, he would go out prostituting himself.
 201cHinahanap-hanap ko na.
Para bang napariwara ako, naging sex maniac na ako.
I2019m not contented with one person only.
But I only go out with the people I was attracted to and had money too.201d
He admits that he found his lifestyle fun and that he was enjoying himself.
He was actually getting paid for something he liked to do.
201cNa enjoy ko siya kasi it2019s easy.
 Madali lang maghanap ng pera.201d 
201cAko yung breadwinner sa family ko kaya gusto ko magkaroon ng extra income,201d he said.
He was putting two of his brothers to school and was also paying for the medical maintenance of his parents.
The money he earned selling his body was almost doubled from what he was earning as cashier, sending almost all home to his family.
201cNagtitira lang ako ng pang-allowance ko.201d
During the entire time, Shaf was engaging in risky behavior by having unprotected sex with his clients.
He never thought of the consequence, that getting sick was a possibility.
 The thrill, the danger, these all excited him.
In 2010, he transferred to Saudi Arabia and worked for another company.
There, he continued his risky lifestyle.
He entertained six to 10 clients some nights, all still without protection.
201cMy night is not complete if walang nangyayari.201d In 2012, after a brief vacation home, he went back and was asked to do a medical checkup.
He was already starting to lose weight, was experiencing on and off diarrhea, and had rashes in some parts of his body.
201cSickly na ako, parating may fever.
Pero hindi ko inintindi.
Sa isip ko, siguro overfatigue kasi after work ko, lalabas pa ako, madaling araw na umuuwi tapos kinabukasan, work na naman.201d
The hospital called three days after the checkup, telling him he had to do more tests.
 201cMay something wrong daw sa result ng blood tests ko.201d He went through more tests and, after several days of anxiety waiting for the results, he was asked to report back.
201cThe hospital called, need daw ako kausapin personally.
Ang sinabi nila sa akin, AIDS daw.
 Parang na wala na ako sa sarili ko, this is the end of my life.
Nasira lahat ng mga pangarap ko.201d
He came home and was tested again in his province and was told that he was actually HIV+, that it has not yet become full-blown AIDS.
201cNahirapan ako mag accept,201d but because of the counseling he received at the treatment hub, he was slowly able to accept his condition, 201cNakatulong ng malaki yung mga peer educators namin.201d Lucky for Shaf, his condition was diagnosed early and he was able to start ARV treatment when he needed to.
Since December of 2013, Shaf97 has been undergoing ARV treatment to help suppress the HIV virus and hinder the progression of the disease.
201cI think of my ARV meds as my partner, I need to take them.
I need to live long para sa family ko rin.201d
Despite the fact that the family members he told of his condition accepted him and were supportive, Shaf97 still chose to transfer to CdeO because he wanted to get away from the stigma he was getting from some people in his hometown.
He is now in a relationship with someone who is also living with HIV and does volunteer work as a peer educator, 201cPart kasi siya ng advocacy ko, to spread awareness about HIV and AIDS to other people.201d 
Bobby Agaran
201cI am already thirty-three years old and was diagnosed in June 2013,201d shared Bobby.
 201cDuring that time I was already stage 3, AIDS stage na.201d
It all started with a mild cough which steadily progressed until he got hospitalized for pneumonia.
He was drastically losing weight and was getting sicker and sicker, 201cNatingala ko kay maski unsa akong inumon na tambal, dili ko gaka uli-an.201d Aside from the cough, he was also experiencing headaches, fever, rashes, and diarrhea.
His doctor was baffled when the meds they gave him for pneumonia, which initially worked, started to fail.
There had to be a reason why.
The doctor asked Bobby questions about his lifestyle and he received several alarming answers.
Bobby identifies himself as bisexual but is more attracted to women and had sex with men only for the pleasure of it.
He worked as the officer-in-charge in a store in Manila where, buff, fit, and a very carefree single man, he engaged in risky sexual behavior with several people.
201cGaka-meet ra nako sa mga bars, and pagnaay na ka-istorya, nagkasinabot, ug game sila, diretso na dayun.
Sometimes protected, sometimes unprotected, dili ko consistent when it comes sa ingon ana.201d 
201cDili pod ko gakuyog ug bayot kay sa akong huna-huna sa una sila ang gadala sa sakit.

After a week2019s wait, the doctor came back with the results, 201cThe doctor said, it is confirmed, positive daw ko.
 When I heard that, natulala ko.
Dili nako ma explain akong emotion at that time.
Dili ko talahilak.
Pero pagstorya sa doctor, nitulo na lang akong luha.201d
201cI wasn2019t thinking of my status, sa akong situation.
Wala sa akong mind ang akong sakit.

Ma-accept pa ba ko sa akong parents.

I was feeling hopeless.
Dili nako ma accept akong self, naay self stigma.
Akong hunahuna kay it2019s better to die than to live with the shame.201d
Bobby sees himself as lucky because the doctor who spoke to him was well equipped to handle the situation.
201cIngon siya na dili ko mabalaka kay there is still hope.
Ana siya na naay treatment, kinahanglan lang na mauli-an sa ko sa akong pneumonia.
I-make sure lang jud daw na mu-strive ko, maningkamot ko maayo kay stage 3 AIDS na ko.201d
And true enough, only a few people who reach the AIDS stage ever recover from it.
 201cWhen I heard na naay hope, I fought for my life.
Nag struggle jud ko na mabuhi.201d 
What helped him find the courage to fight was the support and love he got from his family.
He started ARV treatment by September of 2013 and has been taking his meds religiously since then.

In the beginning, he was ashamed to be seen by other people but his sister and mother convinced him to start going out, 201cIf you2019re not going to accept yourself, you will not totally recover sa imong situation.
Ang gisulti sa akong mama, 2018You must learn to accept your status para maka go on ka sa imong life.2019 If in denial ka, you are just killing yourself, dili ka maka recover emotionally if dili nimo i-face ang reality.201d 
It also helped that he was able to meet other people also living with HIV and got to talk to people who are in the same boat as he is.
201cImportante kaayo na naa kay ma-istorya, na naay mga tao na nakasabot jud sa imong gina experience.201d He is one of the founding officers of NorMAA or Northern Mindanao AIDS Advocates, an HIV/AIDS support group formed by people living with HIV.

Currently, Bobby is back to stage 1, acute HIV infection, and through the help of the ARV treatment, he hopes to remain at this stage.
He has gained back his weight and is very careful with his health.
201cNakita namo ang paglaum through ARV.
If amo lang siya i-take faithfully, we can live a normal life.201d
Red Fox 
Red Fox, a thirty-three year old gay man, did not have a great relationship with his parents growing up.
201cNag layas-layas ko and mas nag experiment ko samot sa akong sexuality.201d He admits to have had several risky sexual encounters in the past, his use of protection was inconsistent.
He, however, believes that his experimentation with injectable drugs got him infected with HIV.

In 2012, while in Manila, he met with two other men who invited him to 2018partee and play2019 or PnP, basically a hook up involving drugs and sex.
201cWhen they said na mag 2018partee2019, like mag take mi ug drugs, I was thinking na Ecstasy.201d He got the shock of his life when one of the men took out a pouch and produced a syringe.

 Being a bit of a daredevil, and seeing that it was a fresh syringe, he agreed to try.
They all got high, had sex, did a follow up, had more sex.

201cThey2019re good looking, insakto pod ilang lawas, they speak good.
 Nagpadala ko.
Kumpyansa ra pod ko kaayo then high na kaayo ko, wala na ko sa akong hunahuna.
Dili na nako mabantayan if ang mga follow, fresh gihapon ang syringe.201d The meetings only stopped when he had a realization after seeing the phrase 2018protect yourself2019 in a pouch ironically given to him by one of the men he 2018party2019 with.
He came home to CdeO late in 2012 and thought that was the end to it.
Chalking everything up to experience.
In 2013, however, two of his friends died in succession due to complications because of AIDS and Red Fox started to get scared.
He was already starting to lose weight drastically and had no appetite, had a lump appear in his nape, and was even shitting blood at times.
201cNahadlok ko.
What if maparehas ko sa ila.
Nagflashback sa akong mind ang akong mga high risk na behavior, katong sa drugs-drugs.201d
When he was younger, rumors of him having HIV/AIDS started circulating which made him depressed to the point of suicide.
It also gave him an aversion to having himself tested because he feared that people might talk about it, 201cMahadlok ko mag pa test.
 Basig i-panabi ko sa mga nurses, basig lahi ang ilang panan-aw sa ako.
Ug wala pud ko kabalo asa muadto.201d
He learned of the Alliance Against AIDS in Mindanao, Inc.
 through postings he saw and messages he received online and in gay-friendly apps, 201cBasig mao na ni na time na mag-patest na ko.201d He finally got tested after meeting up with people from ALAGAD, one of whom went with him to the hospital for support.
201cPagkabalo nako sa akong status, I was depressed.
I was scared.
Gahuna-huna ko na magpasagad na lang ko kay total feeling nako hapit na man siguro ko mamatay because I got this.
Pero nahunahuna pud nako na I would talk to my counselor and ma-minaw ko sa iyang advices and ma-minaw sa akong mga kauban, katong mga other plHIV na na met nako.201d Red Fox said he cried when he received his results but he was also somewhat expecting it to be positive.
201cIt helped me a lot that I got to talk to my fellow plHIV.201d
ARV treatment for Red Fox started in March of 2014.
201cSo far, treatment nako, okay man sad.
Wala koy mga adverse reactions or side effects na na feel.
I feel normal.
I feel the same.
I feel very healthy and happy because I have no major complaints sa health ko.201d
Red Fox found out early this year that one of the men he 201cparteed201d with died of AIDS complication back in 2013.
He also believes that he was infected on purpose because back in 2012, he received weird 2018how2019s your health2019 and 2018have you been feeling okay2019 text messages from one of the men.
201cKung gituyo man to nila, I forgive them.
Para pud sa akong peace of mind.201d
Living with HIV doesn2019t stop Red Fox from living.
201cIt2019s not too late na magbuhat pa ka sa imong gusto buhaton.201d
After being diagnosed, Red Fox2019s life made a 360 degree turn.
He no longer does recreation drugs and is in fact now trying to finish his nursing degree.
Since his diagnosis, his relationship with his parents is much better, 201cIt was a major turn of events kay ayha pa hinoon nako na feel na appreciated and loved ko sa akong family.201d 
He said his experiences made him emotionally stronger and that, although he isn2019t proud of it, he has no regrets.
Philippine tarsiers now among most endangered primates, Philippine tarsiers now among most endangered primates
The Philippine tarsier
ITS being a mascot for Philippine tourism has helped raise awareness for its conservation, but such gain could not outweigh its joining the ranks of the world's 25 most endangered primates also from the same reason.
Its popularity with visitors to Bohol, where it is a tourism mascot, is one reason it has landed on the latest edition of "Primates in Peril: The world's 25 most endangered primates."
Both threatened by habitat loss, the tarsier and the Lavasoa Mountains dwarf lemur of Madagascar are the newest addition to the list released November 25 by the International Union for Conservation of Nature .
"Many populations of Philippine tarsiers have already been locally extirpated and of those that remain some surely are at imminent risk of extinction," according to the IUCN's "Primates in Peril: The World's 25 Most Endangered Primates 2014-2016."
Tarsiers are scattered over Samar, Leyte, Bohol and Mindanao and in an unknown number of smaller islands such as Dinagat and Basilan.
Modern genetic tools reveal that Philippine tarsiers are a group of at least three evolutionary significant units, a population of organisms that is considered distinct for purposes of conservation.
Three tarsier subspecies have been described: T.
syrichta syrichta from Leyte and Samar; T.
s.
carbonarius from Mindanao; and T.
s.
fraterculnus from Bohol.
While tarsiers are used as a mascot in Bohol, the regulation of this tourism practice is weak.
Many tarsiers are on display at roadside attractions in conditions described by the report as "heartbreaking, especially as these are nocturnal animals on display during the daytime."
Given the difficulties of keeping tarsiers alive in captivity, it is assumed that mortality among these animals is high, and that replacements from the wild are found when they die, the report said.
"There is a burgeoning illegal trade in tarsiers as pets, which unfortunately, is probably promoted to some degree by the tarsiers' status as tourism mascots," it said, noting that while the use of tarsiers as tourism mascots is laudable, and proves their ability to promote tourism and thereby conservation, the industry in the Philippines is in desperate need of greater oversight.
"Unfortunately, owing to weak oversight, current practices are probably exacerbating the risk of extinction, and this needs correction," it said.

Another reason for the tarsier's inclusion on the list is forest destruction.
Noting that the Philippines has been described as a land of "mega deforestation," the report pointed out that "it remains unproven that non-forest habitats can sustain tarsier populations in perpetuity."
The Philippines has also been described as the region where "megadiversity meets mega deforestation," the report said, noting that the country ranks fourth on the list of the World's 10 Most Threatened Forest Hotspots, even ahead of Madagascar, a country that is infamous for its conservation crisis.
It said that as little as seven percent of the Philippines remain forested.

"This is particularly distressing since tarsiers may well be an obligate forest species, though this is unclear and is yet another question mark about Philippine tarsiers that must be resolved quickly," the report said.

Since deforestation has removed "nearly all" of the tarsier's original habitat in many places, the report continued, identifying the conservation priorities of the unique primate is urgent.
Global warming has also landed the tarsier on the list, as it reflects the need to understand how the increased frequency and intensity of typhoons will affect the extinction risk of tarsiers.
Super Typhoon Yolanda  in 2013 swept directly over critical tarsier habitat in Leyte and Samar.
The direct effect of the typhoon on tarsier conservation is still being studied, but it was "unquestionably devastating," IUCN said.

Remembering the Great Plebeian, Remembering the Great PlebeianUP TO this day, he is a well-known man.
His name, Andres Bonifacio, offers a sense of familiarity to the Filipinos -- vividly remembered as the indio who spearheaded the Katipunan, 201cthe first nationally successful revolution against the Spaniards201d in 1892.
Yet as much as his fame can offer, he is still less appreciated than the notable Filipino reformist, our national hero Jose Rizal.
In fact, today2019s youth do not remember his contributions for the country aside from being the 201cAma ng Katipunan.201d 
According to a survey conducted by the Social Weather Stations in 2011, 34 percent of 1,200 adults from all over the country named Bonifacio as one of the most identified heroes.
In fact, he places second after Jose Rizal, who gained 75 percent.
Bonifacio got 47 percent in Metro Manila, 35 percent in the Visayas, 34 percent in Balance Luzon, and 25 percent in Mindanao throughout the survey.
Yet how much do people really know about 201cThe Great Plebeian201d Andres Bonifacio?
Aaron, 15 years old and a high school student, remembers the Supremo solely as the founder of the Katipunan.
November 30 or August 30, he reluctantly said, was the hero2019s holiday.
When asked why it is celebrated on November 30, he answered 201cKay November 30 siya namatay ?201d
Michelle, 18, also named Bonifacio as the Father of KKK, noting that he was not an ilustrado, and was allegedly killed by Aguinaldo.
In addition to that, she said that November 30 is a commemoration of the hero2019s death.

Natalie, 18, dubbed the Supremo as the first president of the country and a historical personality who got greedy for power.
She also mentioned of him being the founder of the Katipunan.

201cBecause it helped our countrymen before to unite as one and fight for one purpose and with that, naka-inspire gihapon sa ato ang ilang nahimo ,201d she responded after being asked why the things Bonifacio did for the country are important for us now.
Bonifacio is perceived to be a brave leader who led many in the revolution against the Spaniards, our then colonizers.
But there is more to know about him than just his brand of being the leader of KKK.
Andres Bonifacio y de Castro was different from most of the well-known heroes in the country today.
For one, he was not an ilustrado.
He was a self-taught man who had History of the French Revolution, The Count of Monte Cristo, and Victor Hugo2019s Les Miserables in his reading list, aside from Rizal2019s La Solidaridad, Noli Me Tangere and El Filibusterismo, among others.
He formed the Kataastaasan Kagalang-galang na Katipunan nang nga Anak ng Bayan , simply known as the Katipunan, at the age of 29.
Yet the number one characteristic that distinguished him from the rest was his worldly views that centered on revolution.

Ilustrados did not desire radical revolution and immediate independence from Spain because of their 201crelatively well-off middle class educated background,201d said Jose Antonio Ferreros, a history instructor at the University of the Philippines Cebu.
201cBonifacio was one of the first people who articulated these views and actually manifested them on a national scale by organizing something like the Katipunan,201d Ferreros said.
201cThe Katipunan was the one that actually fought violently for radical revolution and independence from Spain.
To a certain extent, it was more successful than anything that came before it, that2019s why Bonifacio is remembered as a hero as well.201d
One of the most basic facts that most of the Filipinos do not know about Bonifacio, however, is that the holiday dedicated for him every November 30 is a commemoration of the day of his birth, not death.
201cYou have to remember that he  died because of infighting among the revolutionaries,201d said Ferreros.
201cAguinaldo semi-reluctantly ordered the assassination of Bonifacio.201d
In an ANC interview with De La Salle University professor Xiao Chua, Aguinaldo admitted through a letter that he killed Bonifacio "para sa kapakanan ng bayan."
"He had a letter in 1948 on his birthday na siya ay napilitan because of two people who told him, 'kung gusto mong mabuhay pa tayo at mapanatili ang kapanatagan ng pamahalaang mapaghimagsik ay dapat mapatupad mo ang utos ng Konseho de Giyera,'" said Chua.
Because of the circumstances of his death, the holiday is on his birthday 201cto celebrate his achievements in life.201d
Despite the ups and downs of his career and despite being compared to other renowned Filipino heroes like Jose Rizal and Emilio Aguinaldo, Bonifacio still has his own greatness worth praising.

201cHe was really the first one who spearheaded action,201d said Ferreros.
201cFor some people, they look to people whom they see as actually articulating these actions more concretely, and they find that hero in Bonifacio.
That2019s what makes him unique.201d
Though knowing the basics about the Filipino heroes is seemingly good enough for every Filipino citizen, understanding the concept deeper would be better and definitely would not hurt.
In fact, it would also improve one2019s background on the country2019s mysteries.
On the upcoming Bonifacio Day on November 30, would you remember Bonifacio beyond the Supremo fa\xe7ade?

Doctor2019s passion is helping treat Sagada2019s ailing kids, Doctor2019s passion is helping treat Sagada2019s ailing kidsLarry P.
Fabian, TWO indigent children diagnosed with congenital heart disease have been given a new chance at life, thanks to the efforts of a doctor who has fallen in love with Sagada, the popular tourist destination in Mountain Province.

Dr.
Philip Del Carmen, a consultant and pediatrician at the St.
Luke2019s Medical Center, raised the funds so that six-year-old Vhanny Bagni and Juvyliza Aligo could have surgery to repair their heart.
Del Carmen, who first visited Sagada during his pre-med days at the University of the Philippines in Diliman, admits to falling in love with the place and its people.

In 1998, he returned to Sagada as part of St.
Luke2019s medical mission.
It was there that he saw the hardships of a town that had only one doctor to look after the entire community.
Since then, Del Carmen returns to Sagada twice a year to conduct his own medical missions.
Last year, Del Carmen suspected that some young indigents, including Vhanny and Juvyliza, were suffering from congenital heart disease , but he needed laboratory tests to confirm his diagnosis.
The results revealed that Vhanny needed immediate surgery, but it would cost P200,000 in hospital and surgical fees.
With the help of a doctor from the Philippine General Hospital and Pediatric Cardiologist-Surgeon Dr.
Jonas Del Rosario, the fee for Vhanny2019s operation was reduced to P85,000.
A patient of Del Carmen2019s at St.
Luke2019s shouldered the rest of the fee.
Vhanny was operated on in July of 2014.
This year, Juvyliza had surgery at the Philippine Heart Center.
Del Carmen said he was able to raise P45,000 in just two hours.
201cI am thankful also to the PHC and Dr.
Juliet Banderas, who opened their doors to these indigent patients, while lowering their fees to accommodate these patient2019s needs,201d Del Carmen said.\xa0
But del Carmen2019s mission doesn2019t end there.
To raise more funds for other CHD patients in Sagada, he put up a photo exhibit of his picture in Sagada dubbed 201cDagdagop: A Gathering201d at the Caf\xe9 by the Ruins.
The exhibit will run from November 19 to January 9, 2016.
Caf\xe9 by the Ruins, upon learning of the photo exhibit2019s purpose waived the fees, Del Carmen said.
201cI am also thankful to my wife, Maria Cristina for being supportive of my advocacy, and understanding me why I needed to go back to Sagada, twice a year for 17 years of conducting my medical missions,201d Del Carmen said.

Nilo.
The A Voyage of Songs International Choral Festival is one of Asia Pacific2019s premier choral festivals that attract choirs from all over the world.
The objective of the festival is to promote greater appreciation of choral music, especially in the Asia-Pacific region, through an exchange of music and culture between choristers from different countries and the various judges.
This would strengthen the choral movement in the region and establish friendships among the participants.
This year, the CNUCYC competed and performed with 22 other choirs from Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and choir groups from the Philippines.

Canedo, FILIPINOS are again ectactic, as they usher in the yuletide season, what with the colorful displays of lights that adorn the malls, the parks, and the houses.
But, as they say, Filipinos go frenzy shopping for gifts, but never to miss buying food items to be shared by family and friends at the stroke of 12 midnight.

To spice up noche buena, there are a lot of food choices that are delicious yet pocket-friendly, from roasted chicken, to pork lechon, to crispy pata , and to patatim, a popular braised pork leg dish similar to paksiw na pata without the vinegar.
If you wish, you can also prepare chicken or pork barbeque.
But, of course, what noche buena is complete without ham and quezo de bola? Various brands of these products are already available in grocery stores.
If chicken is what you and your family's palate craves for, you can prepare Rellenong Manok or Stuffed deboned chicken, which is an all-time Filipino favorite.
A kilo of chicken costs around P120, based on the latest market watch.
For other chicken recipe ideas, you can go check the internet.
For dessert, you may add a personal touch or perhaps reinvent traditional favorites like Buko salad, Macaroni salad, Spaghetti, Leche flan, Mango float, Fruit salad, each can be enjoyed by the whole family at an affordable price.
In the local malls, you can find value packages for ingredients of spaghetti and macaroni.
If you also want a non-pork or chicken dishes, you may opt for sweet and sour tilapia fish, or Rellenong Bangus or , dishes that you can pull off in no time.
If simple and easy cooking is your thing, you can also just simply grill tuna 201cpanga201d  or other seafoods such as squid.
Opting to eat healthy food during Christmas dinner is also possible and attainable, according to Executive Sous Chef of Marco Polo, Alex Destriza.
201cYou can celebrate Christmas day with healthy food..you may cook chicken embutido stuffed with dried fruits, carrots, or peas, or  Lumpiang Gulay with lots of vegetables, and sprouts in white lumpia sauce, or adobo version of vegetables with tofu and lots of green beans and vegetables,201d Destriza said.
For sweets, he suggested that you can make mango float with 70% fresh mango or for a fruit salad, you can substitute mayonnaise with fresh orange juice.
To replace soft drinks, Destriza said that you can also try fresh fruit version of puree or blended, or calamansi or lemon base juices.
There are ways to enjoy Christmas, be it simple or extravagant.
A plate you share and a glass of drink you share is what makes Christmas no less than worth remembering.

Celebrate Christmas the Filipino way , Celebrate Christmas the Filipino way Christine Joice C.
Cudis, IF A global competition which country has the most felt Christmas celebration was to be held, Philippines would have a good shot at winning.
Various international magazines and newspapers have already featured a story about the Philippines for having the World's longest celebration of Christmas.
Majority of Filipinos start their preparation for the Christmas season as soon as the calendar hit the first ber-month or September.
Lavish decorations of Christmas trees and parols, Christmas light displays, as well as eucharictic celebrations usually extends until to the feast of the three kings which usually falls over early January.
A good reason behind this long of a festivity roots from the people's faith.
Being among the most populous nations in Asia, Philippines is known as a Christian nation.

Several traditions were handed down or even continued until today.

Among those are the following:
Simbang Gabi
The Christmas season is never complete with the "Simbang Gabi" or the early dawn masses.
It is a series of masses held for nine nights culminating on the eve of the 24th.
Most people believe that a person's wish would be granted if he or she completes all nine Simbang Gabi masses.
This practice is uniquely Filipino.
Noche Buena
Noche Buena or the fiesta celebration on Christmas eve is a tradition where families meet to dine together on eve of the 24th.

Christmas Lantern
In some parts of the world, people are experiencing the magical White Christmas but in a tropical country like ours, parols gives colors the households during the yuletide season.
It is the symbol of the star that the Three Kings followed that brought them to the town of Bethlehem on the night of the birth of Christ.

Filipino's poor childhood inspires 500K-light Christmas show, Filipino's poor childhood inspires 500K-light Christmas show
RIZAL.
In this Sunday, Nov.
29, 2015 photo, visitors walk around the compound of house lit by thousands of Christmas lights in Cainta, Rizal province, east of Manila, Philippines.

CAINTA, Rizal -- As a child from a poor family, Alexander Cruz marveled at the big houses adorned with Christmas lights near his Philippine neighborhood, but the gates were always closed.
Now a successful businessman with a huge house in a hilly town south of Manila, Cruz celebrates Christmas in even more spectacular style.
About half a million colorful lights cover every inch of his home: the roof, ceiling, walls, fence, doors, canopies, windows and even the trees.
And he and his wife open the gates to everyone.
"We're doing this to share our blessings, to give or share the spirit of Christmas to the people who visited our place," the 55-year-old Cruz said in an interview.
His home in Cainta has dazzled people far beyond the quiet town of around 290,000 people.
TV networks have documented his holiday wonderland, which has become the backdrop for countless selfies and sees up to 1,000 visitors per day.
"It brings back childhood feelings of Christmas, like in the movies, that you see big houses with big lights," said Ella Cosme, a 34-year-old software programmer.
"You feel like a child."
The lighting is designed by Cruz's wife, Aida, and preparations for the display start as early as August.
Alexander Cruz estimated that they used 5,000 boxes of LED lights, with each box containing a hundred bulbs.
The Christmas lighting extravaganza is crowned by four brightly lit Christmas trees atop the roof.
Inside the house and within its gardens are Nativity scenes, a centerpiece in many homes in the Philippines.
The country is a bastion of Christianity in Asia, and many Filipinos prepare for Christmas by going to Mass before dawn every day for nine days before December 25.
The Cruzes have gone all-out for Christmas for the past five years.
Alexander Cruz said this year might be the last, since his neighbors are inconvenienced by the crowds.
But with many residents and visitors urging him to carry on the tradition, he said he may reconsider.
"We're embarrassed that the subdivision is losing its privacy because of the number of people coming to see the house," Cruz said, but he added some of his neighbors may have gotten used to the upbeat holiday crowds that reach 500-1,000 people daily on weekends.
"They were the ones who said not to stop it, especially our mayor, who said there has been a good effect," Cruz said.
"At least there is good news in Cainta."

Tejano, "NEVER doubt yourself.

"Mao na akong nakuha sa pila ka tuig nako sinaka kanaog anang Apo.

"Bisan pa naa mga panahon na matunong ka imong ginaubanan, di ka kasabot sa ila ginapanulti, pero magkasinabot gihapon unya safe and happy sila, fulfillment na sa ako na.

"Kailangan kabalo ka unsa imong gusto sa kinabuhi para didto ka mag-focus.
Ako, kontento na kaayo ko sa kinabuhi2026 kauban akong pamilya, malipayon mi na nia mi diri sa bukid nagpuyo ," Entes said.
 
He said he is already blessed, and he wants to nurture what he has in life as a guide, a porter, a farmer and a family man.

Datu's Tribe rocks for Davao's Lumads, Datu's Tribe rocks for Davao's Lumads
Photo by Pol Torrente
Tyrone Velez, IT HAS been 19 years since the rock band Datu's Tribe last performed in Davao City.
Their return to Davao on November 28 at the Metro Station for The Kapit-Bisig Benefit Concert for the Lumad evacuees showed they still have their rage and roll.
Their gig stirred the young audience to frenzy right from their opening song "Feelings" to their 90s hits "And I See", "Nakakalitong mga Tao" and "Sarsa Platoon".
 They did moshpit on stage, flashed cellphones and sang along to the lyrics, to think that most songs came out when they were still in their diapers.
At times frontman Eric 'Cabring' Cabrera would pass the mic to them to finish a line and a yell.
"Galing! Pwede na akong mo-retiro!" he jokingly growled after hearing the boys belt out their songs.
But retiring is far from what this band has in mind.
Returning in 2005 after a hiatus, Datu's Tribe reformed with new bandmates - guitarist Moel Diaz, bassist Andre Umali and drummer Paolo Manuel -and with new causes to champion, while finding old and new followers along the way.
"There's a big crossover mystique for this band," said Cabring in an interview.
"On one hand we're very close to progressive groups.
On the other hand we had links to rock bands and the young ones who want to learn more.
We found that our reputation was intact, and slowly we regained that status."
Datu's Tribe is lending their presence to cause-oriented events, such as in the campaign to save OFW Mary Jane Veloso from execution in Indonesia.
 This Davao concert was organized by the All Workers' Union to support the Lumad evacuees in Haran.
The band took time to visit the Lumads in Haran before and after their concert.
On Sunday, Cabring spent a reading session with Lumad students, reliving his other profession as a teacher.
While guitarist Dr.
Moel Diaz, was joined by his wife who happens to be a nurse in a medical mission.
"To finally meet the Lumads, the real Datus, who were the inspiration of our band's name, to hear them talk of their plight in their own words, I think it is us who should be grateful to meet them," said Cabring.
The band's name is an interesting trivia.
After arguing what they should name their band, they settled to put their suggestions in an ash-tray.
"My choice was picked.
Were they pissed," Cabring smiled.
He said he thought of the name because of the mysticism and history of Datus in the country.
 
Hearing the Lumads' stories deepened the band's concern for them.
"I am incensed especially to hear the abuses against children, being a teacher and a father.
It's a burden to seem their being marginalized.
Who benefits from mining their lands, from exploiting them?" he added.
That Datu's Tribe became a politically-charged band was not by design.
"It wasn't intentional.
I wasn't even an activist.
But a large part of that was the experience growing up and studying in UP Los Banos and UP Diliman.
Then as a teacher in UP Integrated, I hear stories from my students, about their problems and about their parents.
And I couldn't pen love songs, so I write about these things."
He said the still marvelled how they were part of the 1990s wave of Pinoy rock bands that studio labels dug into.
"The 90s was a gold mine in music.
You have E-heads, and even Yano, and  milked us.
They didn't care what your songs are about.
 Universal wanted an alternative act to compete with other studios, so thank you," Cabring laughs remembering this.
As grizzled as he has been to see the music industry squeeze talents for profits, Cabring still believes artists old and new can still be instruments of change.
"No one's gonna laugh.
It's the solidarity that counts.
We don't have to discriminate.
Not everybody can be like us or be like The Jerks.
But In your own way as an artist, much more can be done if you are aware the problems, aware of the roots of this, and you're willing to join in this struggle to change the system.
You will be effective to spread your message to your mass base.
They see you working on this on the side, then that can serve to inspire.
It's that spark that makes people think.
You encourage them to think."  
Cabring promised that their support for the Lumads will continue.
He said a video documentary is in the works.
"We want to show we're not just these rockstars.
But we can be people who can express our support and inspire people to do something."
Pinoy in Rome: Countdown to the Jubilee Year of Mercy, Pinoy in Rome: Countdown to the Jubilee Year of Mercy
Sant'Andrea main altar - Saint Andrew's Passion
Robert Z.
Cortes, This is part 1 of the 6-part series of articles documenting the author's experiences as he prepares to welcome the Jubilee Year of Mercy in Rome.
Follow his trip and learn from his experiences right here on Sun.Star.
, THE Extraordinary Jubilee of Mercy announced by Pope Francis around Holy Week this year is finally starting on December 8, the Solemnity of the Immaculate Conception, just a couple of days from now.
That this special event in the Church's history begins on that date is, of course, no accident.
This Pope's devotion to Mary, shown publicly every time he passes by St.
Mary Major before any major trip abroad, should have made that choice almost predictable.
However, aside from human choices, one ought to consider above all the guidance of Providence, whose will it is that the most important events in the Church happen under the mantle of Mary, Mother of the Church and Mother of Mercy.
So the idea to prepare proximately for the Jubilee Year of Mercy by making a novena to the Immaculate Conception made a lot of sense to me.
And being in Rome, the city that arguably no place in the world can match in terms of the quality and quantity of sacred art present, I took advantage to do the following.
For nine days - including the Solemnity, hence the term "novena" - I was going to visit an image of Our Lady venerated in various churches around the city.
But which churches, though?
Given the multitude of beautiful and historic churches in Rome, it seemed the best way to approach this project was simply to be led by Providence.
This approach is not "to be too mystical about it," as I learned quite recently from, of all people, a non-Catholic ethics professor in a very secular American university whom I interviewed a couple of months ago.
His defense is that "there still is another dimension in terms of a holistic being in which our reason and our spirit and our emotions are an integrated whole...
So, you listen to the voice of the spirit." This was actually good ecumenical advice to which my experience in the following days would attest.

These experiences, culled from my journal of these novena days, are actually Church history lessons devotional, tour-guiding tips, and philosophizing all rolled into one.
I share them seeing that they can serve some purpose, however one may be preparing for the Extraordinary Jubilee Year of Mercy.

Day 1: Our Lady of the Sacred Heart in Sant'Andrea della Valle
Yesterday, November 30, was the beginning of the novena to the Immaculate Conception.
It also happened to be the feast of St.
Andrew.
Now at the other end of the street where my university is happens to be a huge, looming basilica dedicated to Saint Andrew with the name "Sant'Andrea della Valle." People with very limited time in Rome usually don't have time to visit this magnificent church, but really next time you come, you should.
This church was actually built by the very same people involved in the building of St.
Peter's and used this as their "practice" church; people like Giacomo della Porta and Carlo Maderno.
The fountain in the square fronting the church is Maderno's.
The paintings and the frescoes inside are even more breathtaking.
The dome and the ceiling are one of the best there is in Rome -- and perhaps in Christendom.
Since it was the feast of St.
Andrew, precisely, I decided to do my prayer right there, before the huge fresco of the crucifixion of St.
Andrew.
I did my rosary in one of the side chapels dedicated to Our Lady of the Sacred Heart.
And by the time I left the church, which is just a five-minute walk from my house, what else could I say, but thank You.
Really there is nothing much else one can say.
Day 2: Our Lady and Child in San Salvatore in Onda
Funny what one sees when one changes perspectives.
Going home from jogging one day, I decided to pass by the right  side of Via dei Pettinari .
I happened to look up by chance and I saw this charming image of Our Lady I had never seen before, even if I'd already passed by here more than ten times.
Then, when I looked down, I likewise noticed what should have been an inconspicuous door.
Now I saw there was a paper posted on it hinting that inside was actually a church called San Salvatore in Onda and the place where Saint Vincent Pallotti's remains are venerated.
I took mental note of the opening schedule and resolved I would do the second day of my novena there.
What was behind that inconspicuous door? Actually, a small but amazingly beautiful jewel of a church.
First, behind the green door commonly seen along the street, was another set of wider doors made of beautiful, strong, old wood.
It had a huge tarp proudly claiming that St.
John Paul II had visited this church.
For such a small church, I thought, it would be surprising any pope would do that.
But of course, if one knew JP II and St.
Vincent Pallotti and what they each stood for, one would understand.
For JP II loved to promote the apostolate among lay people, and St.
Vincent, in his own 19th century, religious way was one of the promoters of the lay apostolate at the time when it was so much lacking.
He founded the "Pious Union of Catholic Apostolate." That's a union of priests, religious and laity - but the "Pallotines" as they are called, really just consists of the religious brothers and priests, and the laity are, well...
they're there.
But that was certainly a huge start.
The church is now their home base, but it wasn't so at first.
Built near the end of the 11th and beginning of the 12th century, it was given to the Franciscans from which two popes came from.
Knowing this historicity of the church and that St.
Vincent's body is now under the altar, one then understands this church deserved the Pope's visit.
But to add to these, there's also the sheer beauty of medieval and renaissance art that one sees on the ceiling and the simple baldachin under which Mass was held, when I was there.
The image of Our Lady and Child by Cesare Mariani in the main altar is also arresting.
The church has the appellation "in Onda" which means "in the wave" most probably because of the frequent flooding of the Tiber.
I've seen some of these signs on marble stone around several parts in Rome, indicating where the river was at this or that point, and there's only one thing I can say.
The worst Manila floods are as if only two inches, compared to Rome flooding in those days! I'm not sure if this has any connection to one image of Our Lady venerated there on a huge side altar, "Virgin most Powerful" - because one certainly needed a huge power to survive such inundations!
But last night, I know I was inundated by only one thing -- thanksgiving for being surrounded by such beauty and holiness.

Elephants get love and care in Cambodia, with tourists' help , Elephants get love and care in Cambodia, with tourists' help 
This June 2015 photo shows two of the elderly elephants that are part of the Mondulkiri Project in Mondulkiri Province in eastern Cambodia.
The Mondulkiri Project aims to act as a sanctuary for elephants that previously worked for timber companies or as attractions in the tourists hub of Siem Reap.
The project also seeks to give the local indigenous population jobs and curtail logging in the area.

SEN MORONOM, Cambodia -- The trip to the hills of eastern Cambodia had all the makings of a luxurious getaway: delicious fresh fruit fed by hand, a dip in a refreshingly cold watering hole and a relaxing massage.
But I wasn't receiving these amenities.
Elderly elephants were.
And I was one of several tourists paying for the privilege of doting on them.
At the Mondulkiri Project, it's not the people who call the shots, but the elephants.
Visitors from all over the world come here for the chance to interact with the behemoth creatures by washing them, feeding them, playing with them and, of course, getting selfies with them.
One thing that doesn't happen: riding on the animals' backs.
Named for Cambodia's most sparsely populated province, the Mondulkiri Project aims to act as a sanctuary for elephants that previously worked for timber companies or as attractions in the tourist hub of Siem Reap, home to the Angkor Wat site.
The Mondulkiri Project also seeks to give the local indigenous population, called the Bunong, opportunities for jobs and help in curtailing logging and promoting forest conservation.
The Mondulkiri Project began in 2013, founded by the Tree family, who are not members of the Bunong community but who support the Bunongs with revenue from the Mondulkiri Project.
The Tree family offers trekking along with the elephant experiences, and they run Tree Lodge, a bare-bones but comfortable set of bungalows with magnificent views of the Cambodian countryside.
During my stay, I joined several other tourists, both solo and group travelers, in cleaning and feeding the elephants.
We also got an in-depth explanation of the project, its goals and why preserving the area is important.
Then came the fun part: getting up close and personal with the gigantic mammals.
The elephants spend all their time in a protected area of the forest, with local guides watching over them.
The elephants were friendly, hungry and eager to interact with us.
For the humans, there was a lunch of rice, vegetables, meat and iced coffee.
Then an English-speaking Bunong guide led us on an easy trek through the lush jungles as we headed to a chilly watering hole to wash one of the creatures.
More photo opportunity than actual cleansing, the elephant seemed to enjoy getting his back scratched and didn't mind the picture-taking.
We all had the same post-cleansing goal anyway: a nap.

Simple home decor, maximizing space tips, Simple home decor, maximizing space tips

HOME is the most valuable asset the family can have.
It provides a sense of security.
It is also the domain where the family can express their creativity in making the home a nurturing place for every member of the family.
Check out some decoration tips you may want to apply in your own home.

Space is always a challenge, making the home looks like a jungle or a warehouse.
Ni\xf1a Borromeo, an interior designer shared some storage maximization tips.
1.
Use dishes and glassware as part of the decorating scheme.
Simple shelves can hold plates and bowls.

2.
Stash wooden spoons, laddle and other frequently-used cooking toolsin in a wide canister that can be left near the stove.

3.
Deep, wide drawers are perfect for storing pans and pots in one place.

4.
Utilize the outside surfaces, including the cabinet sides, and store things where they are readily available and easy to grab.

5.
Place less used items on top of cabinets where they are out of the way.
There is a lot of precious space that you might not be taking full advantage of.

6.
Spaces under the stairs can be used as shelves to place those glasswares that are not frequently used.

7.
Line the area right underneath the ceiling with shelves.

8.
Baskets are one of the cheaper and better-looking storage solutions.
They are ideal for storing fruits, vegetables, dish cloths or other items.
