The story of Belinda , The story of Belinda Ace June Rell S.
Perez, For the poor, prostitution is an opportunity
, BELINDA, 23, , was then a minor when she was introduced into the world of prostitution.
"Matingala ko sa akong mga barkada kay naa silay kwarta.
Tapos pag manlaag mi, makalibre sila, mao akong nahuna-hunaan musabay na lang kaya ko sa ila aron makwarta ko, murag lingaw man gud ," said by a then innocent girl who at her young age at 15 unknowingly did things out of curiosity and poverty.

Belinda is now an active member of Talikala, a non-government organization combatting against human exploitation and human trafficking.

Belinda was among the 123 victims of human trafficking in Davao City since 2004 until the first half of this year, based on the Inter-Agency Council Against Trafficking  data.

But unlike any other girls, Belinda admitted that it was her choice to fall as prey by the predators of prostitution and human trafficking.

She was only 16-years-old when they were trafficked and brought to Mandaue City, Cebu as entertainers.
But she narrated that even as early as 15 she chose to live the life of her prostituted friends as "serbis girls" doing things beyond just to get through her daily living.

"My father died when I was only five years old, my mother was also left with no job, every day and every meal was a real struggle for us," Belinda said, adding that she was left with no choice but to take whatever opportunity there is around.

"I was only 15 years old then and considering my young age, I saw my friend2019s job as an opportunity with no clear understanding where I2019m heading to," she added.

After months of serving as instrument to "short happiness" for their "guest" or "customers" during late night by the sidewalks of Carpenter, Agdao, Davao City, where she was already contented with only P350 to P400 a night, Belinda with her friends were invited by their neighbor to be entertainers in Cebu.
201cOur neighbor told us that there is a greater opportunity that awaits us in Mandaue City, Cebu,201d she said.
Just like the thousands of victims in the country who were coerced and forced and controlled into the sex industry for tourists, Belinda was promised by their recruiter an attractive offer of better job.

"He said that those girls working there  already build their own houses and are now able to buy fancy things they wanted because of the job.
He also told us that we can go home here in Davao whenever we wanted," Belinda said, underscoring that they were promised to live in heaven but ended up in hell.

"Kami pud naingganyo mi sa iyang offer, wala pa man gud mi sa tarong na pang huna-huna kung unsa ang pwede mahitabo sa among desisyon, nisugotlang pud mi, ," she said, adding that she left without her mother2019s permission.

Belinda narrated that their life in the club is like living in a cage with restricted freedom and happiness.
"We were like prisoners, we can2019t go outside on our own," she said.

When in Cebu, as entertainers, they only get P800 out of P10,000 or only .08 percent of the payment made by the foreign customers.
"Mubawi na lang mi sa tip na ihatag sa customer, P800 before was already a big amount for us, so dili na lang mi moreklamo kay kung magyayaw mi, kasab-an mi sa bar owner ," she added.

After nearly four months of stay in the club as sexual exploits, Belinda and the rest of the trafficked women were rescued by Talikala.

But what made Belinda2019s story worse is that even with the intervention of the programs of Talikala against human trafficking, she still decided to go back to her work because of its stagnant economic situation.
Belinda admitted that even when they were organized by the NGO, she still chose to live again her miserable life as 201cserbis girl201d in Davao City.
201cI don2019t know with me before, I was just thinking that I was left with no choice but to go back to the dirty work because all I had in mind before was money, how can we eat, basically because of poverty, I feel hopeless that time,201d she said.

Jeanette I.
Ampog, chair of Talikala-Davao in a separate interview, said that poverty drives individual to enter such jobs and usually ended up being trafficked.

201cVictims were enticed and lured by these recruiters mainly because they are living in poverty, there is lack of job opportunity which caused them to resort to a risky move,201d she said.

201cHonestly, our battle against human trafficking is challenged by the fact that still even with the government and the private sector2019s interventions like the seminars, trainings there is still a big possibility that trafficked victims to be re-traffic if and only if nothing change in their economic situation.
They will still fall as prey to the predators,201d Ampog said.
Belinda, who used to devote her night hours in the sidewalks of Carpenter, Agdao, Davao City, and inside the club in Mandaue City, Cebu, is now an active member of Talikala, standing firm to fight against human trafficking in persons.

201cI dream that hopefully no more young girls will be trapped in the same situation where I was before, that is why I am working now in Talikala to give my share in our pursuit to a human-trafficking free city, country and even world,201d Belinda shared in vernacular.
Modern slavery , Modern slavery 
DAVAO.
Children members of the Children Against Child Trafficking group from Barangay 76-A in Davao City shows their placards in support to stop human trafficking during an event in line with the Human Trafficking Awareness Month from November 12 to December 12.

Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, THERE are about 2.5 million victims of human trafficking around the world, according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime  "at any given period."
For new parent Kristine Cantila-Veeneman, human trafficking is modern slavery which both includes sexual exploitation and forced labor.
"It is a very sad truth that it still exists especially in the Philippines.
As a mother I could never imagine myself selling my daughter to traffickers for an 'x' amount of money.
Selling your daughter to traffickers is like ruining her life forever," Veeneman said.
Mother of two Lisly Mae Dorado, describes the issue as a "market-driven criminal industry that is based on the principles of supply and demand."
"It deeply pains me just to even imagine the innocent ones that are involved; those innocent ones that cannot defend themselves and are always the victims," Dorado said.
"Each child should not be the means for a family to survive in their daily needs.
That would be the role of the parents - to provide for the family and for their kids," she added.
True enough, UNODC defines human trafficking as "the act of forcefully transporting or recruiting persons for the purpose of exploitation."
Exploitation acts include prostitution, forced labor, slavery or removal of organs.
 Sad to say, not every citizen in this country is aware of these facts about trafficking.
Interagency Council Against Trafficking Davao Region Network  unit head and Department of Social Welfare and Development -Davao project development officer Alma Acera said that there is really a need to continue intensifying awareness up to the grassroots level.
She said that there are instances that even the victims themselves do not know that they are being trafficked.
"It  is as important as going to school, because if you are well informed you have that sense of self 2013protection because we cannot protect everybody.
So it is much better that individuals would be aware so that can make sound choices," Acera said.
With their intensive information dissemination campaign which started three years ago, Acera said they are due for assessment to see the impact that their campaign has done.
No change in modes
For the modes of trafficking, Acera said that nothing has really changed.
The modes for trafficking still include cellular phones, peer to peer or relatives to relatives and the Internet.
She said that they have currently validated illegal transaction patterns through these modes but still lack the capability to counter those especially the Internet.
"All houses now a day has internet connections and it is difficult to check residences without being accused of invading their privacy," she said.
Another factor that is keeping human trafficking alive, according to Acera, is poverty.
Without access to livelihood, parents will still continue to submit their children to force labor.
DSWD in 2012 had listed a total of 1,376 human trafficking victims in the country.
However, true numbers of the victims are likely higher as there are still unreported cases.
For Davao Region from January to October this year, DSWD had catered to 77 human trafficking survivors aging from 0 to 59 years old wherein 17 of them are male and 60 are female.
Programs
Just recently, Iacat XI, together with other Mindanao based non-government organizations, launched the counter-tipster project which aims to combat human trafficking through spreading awareness and monitoring in the barangay level.
Family Planning Organizations of the Philippines , Luna Legal Resource Center for Women and Children Inc., and Tambayan Center for Children's Rights Inc.
are the lead organizations of the project.
Counter-Tipster will focus on addressing the cases of trafficking in persons in General Santos, Davao del Sur, and Davao City.
The project is in partnership with USAID.
It will run for two years to give barangay officials in the target areas orientations and trainings for them to be able to create their own barangay programs to address human trafficking in their area.
Acera said that through strengthening the barangays' awareness they will be even more vigilant on assessing and monitoring trafficking activities in their area.
Iacat 11 is also targeting to present before the Davao City Council an Anti-Trafficking ordinance to enhance monitoring in all areas in the local level.
Experiencing the mini-Christmas village in Oro , Experiencing the mini-Christmas village in Oro 
CHRISTMAS VILLAGE 
Riain Alfonso, CHRISTMAS is definitely in the air at the La Victoria household at Gran Europa as it opens its doors once again to let the public in for the yearly miniature Christmas village exhibit.
 
As you enter the La Victoria gates, the owner, Roel Lavictoria, greets you with a warm smile and a firm handshake of welcome.
201cI am sharing this to the public, especially to the kids, because I know that what I have is one of a kind.
It is my personal collection and I2019ve been collecting these for the last 10 years,201d said Roel, whose eyes light up each time he mentions his collection.

He is a man so passionate about Christmas that he gets giddy with excitement each time the month of December rolls in.
It2019s probably safe to say that there won2019t be anybody else as passionate about the holidays except maybe for Santa Claus.

"When I was a child, I was always looking forward to Christmas.
Every time na mag put up akong mom ug Christmas decors, I would always be there.
I would help her decorate our house,201d shared Roel adding, 201cI always look forward to December 16 because that was when she would start decorating.201d 
From his own personal experience, he knew how much children love Christmas and this served as his inspiration for putting up the village and opening it up to anybody interested to see his collection.

The village took almost two months to assemble and definitely a labor of love.
201cIt needs a lot of creativity as far as organizing and harmonizing all the structures so that it would look like a real community, a replica of a village during winter.201d He added that he has a creative team to help him with the execution of his vision and that he also gets input from his wife and three daughters who support him all the way.
 
The village boasts of 264 buildings, houses, and other structures.
These include several log cabins, a town plaza complete with a town hall and a local hero2019s monument, a restaurant, a lake with a lighthouse and boardwalk, a twenty-five meter train track with a moving mini train, a huge carnival, and a forest.
 
Of course, no Christmas village is complete without the Santas; the village boasts of thirteen.
The pine trees are found everywhere, 256 in total, while what appears to be 2018snow2019 has blanketed the entire village.
The village also features its own eight-meter working gondola ski cable cars that lead up to the miniature mountain where you see tiny toy figures skiing.
The total 2018human2019 population of the village is 498 and the toy figures are arranged in a way that they depict actual life in a village.
The display even has 97 animals.
Roel has been opening his household to the public since 2004 when he first put up his Christmas village on display.
201cI started with a small table with only 10 houses.
As the years go on, I was able to collect more.201d  
The only time he did not stage his miniature village was in 2011 because of Typhoon Sendong.
As the number of items in his collection grew, so did the area required for the display.
He had to expand the size of their gazebo to accommodate the ever-growing collection.
  
The majority of the buildings in his collection were bought mostly in the US while the cable cars were a Christmas gift from his German foster daughter who stayed with the family for a year in 2014.
201cThese are things that are rare here in the country so every time I travel abroad, I make sure that I bring home at least two or three.201d
Putting up the village is no joke, said Roel.
He described how they placed LED lights underneath the fabric which serves as the ground or the base for the entire display.
In doing so, they are able to make the whiteness of the 2018snow2019 stand out.
Also, this is the first time that they have not used batteries on any of the things on display.
Meticulous work was done on the wiring system of the village as they had to convert many items on display from 110 to 220 volts.

Kids and adults alike are sure to be amazed by the detailed work done on the village.
Ingenuity was quite apparent in the creation of some of the other items including the bridges which are all made of popsicle sticks and had to be assembled painstakingly.
The village lamp posts, for example, are made out of balloon sticks with bulbs from old series lights inserted into the hole so that it would look like and have the feel of an actual lamp post.

In the past, the display is open to the public starting December 16, as was their tradition when Roel2019s mother was still alive.
This year, the family decided to start the public viewing last December 8.
201cThis time we opened earlier para naman maraming matuwa,201d Roel said.

From Mondays to Thursdays, the village can be viewed from 6:00 to 10:00 p.m., extending until 12:00 midnight on Fridays to Sundays.

201cBut if there are people coming from out of town, we extend until 1:00 a.m.,201d added Roel.

201cLike last time, there were people coming from Claveria who came to CdeO just to see the village.201d 
On average, 70 to about 100 people come nightly to the La Victoria household to check out the display.
201cAkong iyaan, kagahapon, dinhi man sila.
Gipa-anhi mi kay ang ang mga bata daw malingaw,201d said Rejane Ancog from Pagatpat who, along with her husband Diode, brought along their two kids aged six and two.
201cTsada kaayo siya, ma-feel jud nimo ang Christmas.
Nice kaayo kay makita jud sa akong mga kids unsa ang Pasko.201d
For those who would like to see this unique Christmas exhibit, the La Victoria house is located at Block 25, Lot 5 and 6, Barcelona Street, La Buena Vida Subdivision, Gran Europa.
The family allows the public to view the village for free.

201cSeeing the smiles of the kids are enough for me,201d Roel furthered, 201cI really believe that Christmas is for the kids.
It2019s more than money.
It2019s really rewarding seeing the smiles and how they enjoy looking at the village.201d
Jiangsu: Where it is made in China, Jiangsu: Where it is made in China
Jiangsu hosts one of China's 25 major coastal hub ports.
Nini B.
Cabaero, FOR products "made in China," most people would think Beijing, as it is the capital city.
But it is Jiangsu province, in the eastern coastal areas of the Chinese mainland, that has the largest economic output in China.
Jiangsu's location makes it strategic for manufacturing with its huge land area, links by high-speed rail, massive road networks, and airports; access to skilled personnel and rich historical and cultural heritage.
The province plays an important role in the Belt and Road Initiative as declared by Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2013 when he called for the promotion of external exchanges.
The Belt and Road Initiative is a combination of the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road, both are programs aimed at opening up China through a trade and infrastructure network connecting Asia with Europe and Africa along the ancient trade routes.
The Philippines is part of the Belt and Road countries that would benefit from increased trade and exchange with the development of infrastructure interconnectivity, sea-and-rail and international air transport networks, and a modern telecommunications system.
Chen Zheng Ning, director in charge of the Belt and Road Initiative, told Asian journalists of Jiangsu's breakthroughs in infrastructure productivity and for being the no.
1 manufacturing province with a vibrant silk industry.
He cited also the initiative's plan to integrate the cultural aspect with the development of economy and trade.
Jiangsu made progress in developing an innovation-oriented economy after China opened up and instituted reforms in the late 1970s.
The province's gross domestic product  surpassed 6.5 trillion yuan  last year while its per capita GDP reached 81,874 yuan, ranking the top in the country.?It also ranked first in the Development and Life Index released by the National Bureau of Statistics that measures a region's eco-social development and people's livelihoods.
The Nanjing Port  Co.
Ltd.
in Jiangsu is one of China's 25 major coastal hub ports and a first-class national port to international regions and nations.
It connects the Yangtze River Delta region to provinces in China and to nearly 200 ports in more than 80 countries and regions.
The Sanpower Group, with its expertise in information service industries, financial investments, health care, and real estate development, has devoted itself to creating social wealth while contributing to the protection of wildlife.
Suning Commerce Group Co.
Ltd.
has built a network of brick-and-mortar stores across 600 cities in China and abroad and an e-commerce platform to embrace the concept of offline-to-online retail.
Its partnership with Alibaba.com brought in record sales during the Singles Day shopping holiday in China last November 11.
In another city, Xuzhou, a national development zone boasts of having the largest volume and the highest investment value.
It is home to Caterpillar, ThyssenKrupp, Saint-Gobain, Vestas, Doosan, Xuzhou Construction Machinery Group, GCL from Hong Kong and Powerchip from Taiwan.

Lianyungang city, on the coast in East China's Jiangsu province, is an important hub of the Eurasian continental bridge and a well-known seaport in China.
It highlights economic development and a high-tech industrial development zone, combined with famous and impressive tourist sites like the Kongwang Mountain.
Suzhou city in the southeast part of China's Jiangsu province is closest to Shanghai is also known as Land of Fish and Rice, Garden Capital, Silk Capital and an Arts and Crafts City.?It is home to the Hengtong group that is into fiber communication, electricity and power grids, online operations, and real estate industries; and the Wujiang Dingsheng Silk Co.
Ltd., located in the Shengze township, a center for silk production in China.
Jiangsu is a vibrant and complex province that enjoys a pivotal role in the opening up of China to other parts of Asia and Europe, without undervaluing its cultural and historical footprints in the country's fast-paced development.

Anti-Trafficking Laws: Are they addressing the problem?, Anti-Trafficking Laws: Are they addressing the problem?Christine Joice C.
Cudis, SINCE the issue on human trafficking in the Philippines has landed on the headlines, there were a lot of laws and regulations that were proposed and amended by the government.
 Women's groups and non-government organizations also participate in the call to combat human trafficking here.

But with all of these combined, why do we still see this matter as a thorny problem?
Having been instituted in May 2003, Republic Act No.
9208 or the Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act made the country the first in the Asean to legislate such law.
But quoting the assessment of the US State Department in the Philippines on 2013, "As both a source country and, to a lesser extent, a destination and transit country for sex trafficking and forced labor, the Philippines remained at Tier 2 on the state department's three-tier ranking system.
Despite making significant efforts to combat trafficking, the Philippines does not yet fully comply with the minimum standards for  elimination."
In the 2015 Trafficking in Persons Report of the same department, the Philippines once again was placed in Tier 2 on its three-tier ranking system.
 
Being rank in Tier 2, it means that those are the countries whose governments do not fully comply with the minimum standards set by the Trafficking Victims Protection Act .
The report said the Philippine government implements anti-trafficking laws, but the judicial system2019s performance remains weak, with excessively long trials and few public prosecutors focusing on cases, made worse by multi-level prevalence of corruption.

According to Talikala executive director, Jeanette Ampog, "What I want  to be captured are those who are the owners of those prostitution houses."
Although for the past years, there has been a rise of convicted people due to vilation on anti-human trafficking law, those were just the middle men in the crime.

The operators or those who are responsible for the existence of these form of labor are still out there.
Ampog added that although the Department of Social Welfare and Development  provides financial assistance on the trafficking victims, "P10,000, I believe is not the answer to this problem.
Awareness more than ever is what the people needs."
"Poverty stands as the major reason behind this activity.
Even if we have provided a few bucks to inspire the victims to change their paths, still it is not enough.
When they realize that their money are gone, they go back to their old lifestyle because their financial status has not really changed and providing these service is their only solution," Ampog added.
Traffickers on the other hand, practice it for the simple fact that the business brings them a huge amount of money without getting their hands dirty and minds stressed.
 
The only thing they have to do is to take the risk of being caught  and to become a little less of a human by thinking that they could do these injustices to other people.
                                                     
Protecting women, kids, Protecting women, kidsKarlo Paolo R.
Pates, PROTECTING the welfare of all women, including their children has been the responsibility of the state and other concerned agencies.
 Both women and children are protected in the Constitution as well as Republic Act  10364, otherwise known as "Expanded Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act of 2012."
Stated under the policy that the state will give the highest priority to the enactment of measures and development of programs that will promote human dignity, protect the people from any threat of violence and exploitation, among others.
Human trafficking has also been a significant issue not only in Davao City but in the whole country as well.

The most emerging problem concerning the issue of human trafficking is that common victims of acts including sexual exploitation, sexual slavery, and prostitution are minors.
This was the information reflected on the data furnished by the Davao City Police Office  to Sun.Star Davao.

Eighteen of 19 victims of trafficking in persons were rescued by the Women's and Children's Protection Desk  of DCPO from January to November are minors.

DCPO spokesperson Chief Inspector Milgrace Cajes Driz said that trafficking of persons refers to the recruitment, transportation of persons without the victim's consent or knowledge by means of force or threat for the purpose of exploitation.
Driz said that acts which include forced labor, slavery, involuntary servitude, sex tourism, debt bondage, and pornography are the means that determine whether an act is a form of trafficking in persons.
"Diri sa Davao City ang mga common na mga biktima na atong narescue kay mga babae ug mga minors ," Driz told Sun.Star Davao in an interview at her office recently.

Cases of sexual exploitation and prostitution are the frequent cases of the rescued victims, Driz said.
 
The Inter-Agency Council against Trafficking  in Davao Region also released a data, showing that human trafficking in the region still involves sex particularly for the young girls.
 A total of 123 victims were recorded by Iacat where 68 were female minors, 44 female adults, eight male minors, and three were male adults.

Driz said that the trafficking victims engaged in these activities due to poverty and the worst, these victims are being trafficked with the consent of their relatives or direct family members.

"Tungod gayud kay pobre ning mga biktima.
Nangihinganlan ug kwarta ," Driz said.

She also admitted the reason behind why most of the minors rescued in human trafficking cases here in Davao City are due to their vulnerability and weaknesses.
 
The average age of the rescued victims are 8 years-old to 15 years-old, Driz said.
Driz said that majority of the perpetrators arrested for trafficking were foreign nationals.
It can be recalled that an American national allegedly involved in trafficking of male minors was arrested by authorities in Davao City last August.
Village watchmen of Barangay 74-A and members of Talomo police arrested the American national identified as George William Nolana, a resident of Morales Village in Barangay 74-A, Davao City.
He was also accused of sexually abusing eight minors.
The eight minors , were rescued by personnel from the Department of Social Welfare and Development  and City Social Services and Development Office .

The village watchmen reprimanded the eight minors after they were still on the streets as part of their Oplan Sita campaign in line with the celebration of the Kadayawan Festival.
The eight minors were endorsed to the Talomo police station for questioning, wherein they claimed to have been sexually abused by the suspect.
 
The victims were given food ang money and in exchange for sexual abuse.

After the arrest of foreign nationals tagged in series of human trafficking cases, authorities are now closely monitoring some of them particularly those are now residing in the city.
"Majority of the suspects are pedophile that's why their victims are minors.
They have money and they can easily encourage the parents of some minors to engage in these acts," Driz said in the vernacular.
As for the forced labor, the DCPO has yet to record or encounter a case on it but they have intensified their intelligence monitoring especially in the bus terminals, seaports, and airports where the victims are being exited.
Personnel from the Anti-Illegal Trafficking in Persons are based and deployed in those areas where the victims who are promised for work abroad or in some areas are being transported.
All 19 victims of trafficking in the city were endorsed to personnel from both the Department of Social Welfare and Development  and City Social Services and Development Office  for debriefing, psychological assistance and other assistance before they are turned over back to their respective families.
 
Cybercrime
With the advent of technology where cybercrimes are now possible, agencies such as National Bureau of Investigation  and the Criminal Investigation and Detection Group  have the capacity to monitor acts like cyber-pornography.

Cyber-pornography in several dating sites as well as recruitment agencies not registered under Philippine Overseas Employment Administration  are some of the cybercrimes monitored in the internet.
"The amount of money is huge that's why it's very tempting for those who are in need.
They are promised for a job abroad but when they arrived in the promised work, they are forced to perform sexual activities," Driz said.

Responsibility of parents
She also reiterated to the parents of their crucial roles they need to portray in order to prevent their children from being victimized by the criminal minds in these acts.
"Their relationship with their kids are crucial as well as their guidance on what wrong and correct.
If these kids are properly oriented then there are just small chances of them being victimized by the advantageous criminals," she added.
 The money should not be the deciding factor for them to let their children to engage in selling of flesh, Driz said.
 
Lisly Mae Callino-Dorado, one of the concerned parents, said that she's also afraid that similar cases might happen to her children.
"This is for me a very sensitive issue and it deeply pains me just to even imagine the innocent ones that are involved; those innocent ones that cannot defend themselves and are always the victims," Dorado said in a Facebook chat with Sun.Star Davao.
Dorado also scored on some irresponsible parents who directly sell their children in exchange for money.
"For parents that leads their own child to be victims of such cruelty, that's just absurd and very irresponsible.
I hope they will suffer the same as what their kids are suffering and die in a very painful death.
I know I2019m ranting, but I just can2019t help it," Dorado said.
 
She added, "Each child should not be the means for a family to survive in their daily needs.
That would be the role of the parents which is to provide for the family and for their kids.
So I would say this trafficking act of mothers/parents - that is plain selfishness and indolence." 
Christmas in the eyes of a child, Christmas in the eyes of a childAce June Rell S.
Perez, I REMEMBER when I was a child that I used to confine myself inside a room and cry out load for not owning the gift I want for Christmas.
A decade after, I came to realize that I am indeed more than blessed to experience Christmas in its most wonderful and spectacular essence when I was a kid together with family and close kin.

I feel bad for myself after hearing those little wishes  coming from the little voices of children on the streets and care centers.
Because when I was at their age, I never even thought to include those in my wish list.

When I was strolling along the sidewalks of Balusong, Matina, Davao City in an early afternoon, I happened to talk with a nine-year old girl, Princess "Tintin" Lopez.

She intently oversees their Christmas lanterns being sold on the sidewalk while his father took a quick rest during siesta time.

While most of the children fell asleep or playing with their neighbors during siesta this Holiday vacation, Princess chose to help his father in selling Christmas lanterns as her way of helping her family to have a good Noche Buena to share with this Christmas.
"Tabang-tabang sa ko kay Papa karon sa pagpamaligya og mga lanterns, wala bitaw klase mao niingon ko sa iya naapil ko og bantay " she said.
She said that she used to help his father in selling Christmas lanterns since he was seven years old.
201cIt2019s fine for me, it is my way of fulfilling my wish this Christmas, to have a delicious Noche Buena,201d she said in vernacular.

From Sidewalks to the Center
It was a year ago when I visited the Archdiocesan Nourishment Center  located on Pagasa Street in Davao City.
I had the same feeling except that more children are visiting during meal times the center.
ANC is established with an aim to provide integral nourishment programs and services such as spiritual formation, medical assistance especially to the poorest of the poor.
From a nearly hundred children in the center during Monday lunch, I pulled an eight years old Donard Enriquez from his table after knowing that he was finished eating his meal.

When asked what his Christmas wish, I was so touched by his response saying that his only wish is to be with her father again.
"Nag abroad man daw to akong papa wala pa ko kabalo kanus-a siya mobalik kay wala naman gud siya nagtawag, gimingaw nako sa iya,201d the eight-year old child shared his longing to his Overseas Filipino Worker  in Dubai.

Donard shared that his family is barely able to eat three times a day now since her mother is also left with no job thus his constant visit in ANC during breakfast and lunch.
They said Christmas is for Children, I seconded.
Now, that I am years away when I was stupidly boxing myself in a room and crying out load for not owning the gift, material gift I want for Christmas, my only wish for this year is to make those little wishes of these little hopeful children, like Donard and Princess to be realized and come true.
A glimpse of Christmas   , A glimpse of Christmas   Christine Joice C.
Cudis, TO MOST cities in the Philippines, Christmas season means decorative lights filling the night sky and firecrackers making all the noise.
Here in Davao, it is total silence and a huge wave of indigenous people  in the streets singing and dancing to the beat of their festive music.
 
For many years now, IPs from the hinterlands of the city and neighboring provinces of Davao del Norte, Cotabato, and Bukidnon have made it sort of their tradition to visit the poblacion every December to ask for Christmas gifts.
 
This year, their number has reached more than 25,000 according to the records provided by the City Social Services and Development Office .
 
Hence, the eight temporary shelter areas allocated for them by City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte looks like overflowing basins and the water has not stopped flowing yet.
  
The one in Buhangin, if you happen to pass by during the wee hours or late at night has a lot of occupants.
Some have just resorted to stay at the parking areas of establishments near the gym, introducing themselves to the risk of being ran over by vehicles as the road is one of the busiest in the city.
 
Now this is where our curiosity comes in.
Why do they still go down from their villages if they know they will live like this?  
According to CSSDO assistant chair Liwayway Caligdong, "They simply don't mind.
Wala lang yan sa kanila.
Tayo lang ang nababahala pero okay lang pala talaga yan sa kanila."  
They are so used to very poor accommodation, they don2019t have any qualms about whatever sleeping arrangement is available.
 
Sun.Star editor-in-chief Stella Estremera, who has been exposed to scenarios like these throughout the years of writing articles about lumads also added up, saying, "Doon sa kanilang community sa papag lang sila natutulog, lupa na agad ang sahig." They are used to poverty, but that does not mean they deserve ridicule as this 20-something woman did while visiting one of the sites Tuesday.

"Pagbantay kay ang imohang cellphone, dalira kaayo kuhaon ,201d she said while covering her nose with a cloth.
Somebody has clearly forgotten that the lumads are here to enjoy the generosity of the Dabawenyos.
Their hair may not be as shiny as a city girl but their hearts are among the gentlest.
 
The problem is some have started to interpret the name "lumad" as synonymous to the word "poor".
For indeed, thousands of lumads are financially-challenged.

There2019s a difference, however, from the lumads coming down to see how it is in the city during Christmas and the beggars.
A very thin line may separate their financial capacity, but the spirit by which they accept is far different for this is not about survival, this is about getting a glimpse of a different world.

"Ganahan mi makadawat ug bugas.
Mais ug kamote ra man gud pirmi among kan-on didto sa bukid.
," 18-year-old Risa said.

If we think about it, they are just like some of us who dream of visiting Paris or London in the future.
So let us treat them the way we want to be treated by the French and British when we visit their cities and of course, do not forget to make them feel the spirit of this holiday which are sharing and loving.
Merry Christmas! 
It2019s never easy   , It2019s never easy   Karina V.
Canedo, CINDY, 23, a volunteer at Lawig Bubai, an organization under Talikala, was once a victim of trafficking.

In an interview with Sun.Star Davao she said that before she was trafficked, she can be considered a woman in prostitution while she was in Davao.

When she was brought to Cebu, she did not realize that she was already being trafficked.
They were brought to a Casa and made to work there for four months.
Luckily, they were rescued, filed cases and won against the perpetrators.

Sadly, when asked what happened next, Cindy only said that no assistance was given to them from the government.

201cWala, gidawat lang mi, walay livelihood programs na gihatag sa amoa ,201d Cindy said.
 She also added that the government assistance extended to them, was only minimal.
 
201cKadto lang pag-uban sa amoa didto sa Cebu, ang pamasahe came from International Justice Mission ,201d Cindy said.

Cindy2019s case was won before the RA 9208 was amended to become RA 1078 or the 201cExpanded Anti-Trafficking in Person2019s Act of 2012 which mandated different agencies to create an Interagency Council Against Trafficking .

Her situation paints a picture of what the victims may undergo, and leads us to ask as to where really the basic services of government, and non-government reaches its limits in their intervention and help the victims of human trafficking.
 
The Department of Social Welfare and Development is currently the secretariat of the council which is made up of other agencies including Department of Justice , Department of Interior and Local Government , Department of Labor and Employment , Overseas Workers Welfare Administration, National Bureau of Investigation , Philippine National Police , Non-Government Organizations , and Civil Society Organizations  and Local Government Unit  DSWD-11 project development officer Alma Acera said that their office provide various programs directly given for the victim survivors.
 
201cWe provide protection, rescue, temporary shelter, psychosocial intervention, therapy, processing and medical needs,201d Acera said.
She also added that their agency also provide financial assistance for entrepreneurial activities, and to augment the family income of those who are rescued.

201cApart from that, we also provide Balik Probinsya transportation assistance, and financial assistance for the transportation of witnesses once there are filed cases in the court,201d Acera said.

As poverty is among the major causes of the cases of Trafficking in Persons, greater financial assistance is what the clients seek and Acera admitted that these past years only a small budget has been allotted for financial support for the victims.

201cTen thousand pesos worth of livelihood assistance were given to them.
Not all of them can avail of it because it also depends on the assessment.
Also, not everyone wants to enter into livelihood, so it will really takes a long process),201d Acera said.

She said that the victims are assessed on sustainable livelihood program thru 201cHanda ka na bang magnegosyo201d.

When a victim fails the assessment, they will be recommended for skills training entitling them to P7,500 financial support.
This could be through DSWD or through the Technical Education Skills Development Authority .

Acera also said that since most of the identified victims are minors, they also offer educational assistance, and they also provide financial assistance for processing documents in aid of those who seek jobs and refer them to employment agencies and establishments.

201cFor many years, there2019s only a minimum budget that is allocated to be given directly to the client.
It is only worth P280,000 and this is what is divided for one year but next year we expect it to increase next year because of our request for its increase has been approved),201d Acera said.
 
She said that those cases they have catered were only those who are given financial support but also those who availed their other forms of services and intervention.

201cParehas anang five-year-old dili nimo na tagaan ug kwarta kay ang mas need niya kay ang ma-shelter siya ,201d Acera added.

Acera said that from January to October there are a total of 77 recorded victim survivor of human trafficking for this year, and last year there are 129 cases was also recorded.
Locally in Davao, in the Davao City Police Office, they have recorded a total of 19 cases from January to October, and 18 out of 19 cases are minors.

City Social Services and Development Office Quick Response Team for Children's Concerns Office-in-charge, Minda Silvano said that within their scope as network of the IACAT, they are in close coordination with the DCPO in terms of rescuing victims, they are a team, one cannot rescue without the other especially on children.

The CSSDO in partner with DSWD provides psychosocial interventions and also have shelters where the victims can temporarily stay.
Silvano said that within Davao, victims especially girls when preparing for their case are housed in Sidlakan and Balay Dangupan.

Aside from them other NGOs such as Tambayan, Global Impact, Luna Resource Center, Saligan Mindanao for legal assistance, Talikala for shelter, Mindanao Migrants are also active in helping especially when it comes to women and children.

She said that observably, they give more lengthy intervention to girls especially the fact that they also need values reorientation and they also provide in house education for those who stay more than six months to one year.

Other than that, Silvano said that they also rescue boys, and surprisingly they come in different areas Indigenous peoples and even Moros.

201cAmong these children we rescued were involved in drugs, sexual exploitation, pornography, forced labor.
Illegal adoption and organ trafficking,201d Silvano said adding that they have victim as young as two years old.

She said that they provide temporary shelter for those who cannot go back to their families for some reasons, but those who are capacitated enough, especially rescued adults are properly endorsed in their local social workers for monitoring and assistance.

Silvano said that their programs for anti-trafficking though already set and has many supporters there is still need to strengthen it more.
201cI-strengthen pa jud.
We will not limit our efforts because the numbers of the victims are growing,201d Silvano said.
She said that advocacy programs especially under Iacat are now garnering more boost, as they also tap private sectors to cooperate especially for the human trafficking campaign paraphernalia.
She also said that human trafficking is still tackled within the CSSDO district offices that penetrate to the barangays to give inputs to the people.
This month of November, they conducted video making contests to support their advocacy.

Meanwhile, despite these efforts of the government agencies to strengthen the campaign, rescue and assistance, individual participation is also encouraged to bear good results on anti-trafficking.

As Cindy, while she said she have not felt the government2019s intervention and dissatisfied with it, she did not limit herself and became the intervention herself to her peers, women involved in prostitution.
For years she had been organizing women in prostitution and conduct seminars for them not to be lured away to human trafficking.

201cTung na-rescue ko, nagpasalamat jud ko sa tanang nagtabang sa akoa, na feel nako na empowered ko kay nakabalo ko na naa diay kay rights, and nakatuon ko na dili na siguro magpa-traffic.
Nahimo kong volunteer karon kay bisan paman nahulog ko sa kahimtang sa prostitusyon dili ko gusto na ang akong ma-experience before, ma-experience pud sa akong ka peers ,201d Cindy said adding that among others, the women in prostitution are very vulnerable to human trafficking.

As of the moment, Cindy said that she is living by donations she received from visitors who came to see them in the center.

When asked if she still resort to prostitution to support her needs, she said only sometimes.
Awareness, a must , Awareness, a must Rhealyn C.
Pojas, TRAFFICKERS are wily in thinking up ways to trap a potential victim.
This means, persons at risk have to be wiser.
While there are law enforcers and other government agencies working together to put an end to human trafficking incidence, it is still hampered by the lack of awareness of the masses regarding the issue.
 
Department of Social Welfare and Development-11 Project Development Officer 3 Alma Acera told Sun.Star Davao in an interview that three years of intensive campaign done by the Inter-Agency Council Against Trafficking  in Davao Region could not suffice if the people in the area are not even aware that they have already fallen prey to traffickers.
  
Although the government agencies are disseminating information for public to know or spot suspicious activities which will potentially led them to trafficking incidents, there is still a greater need to inform the public regarding the issue.
 
201cPipila lang ang mga law enforcers nga naga-lihok kung i-compare nimo sa total population sa area ,201d Acera said adding that they cannot protect everybody because they outnumbered by the number of people to be protected.
 
201cIf the people are well-informed they can have self-protection and prevention which is important because through it, they will be able to make sound choices,201d Acera explained further.
    
Trafficker2019s Modus Operandi People should always be suspicious of people offering them jobs abroad or outside their towns that sound too good to be true.
 
Financial difficulties push people to be victims.
Acera said that employment abroad is most enticing to Filipinos in dire straits, thus, take stock.
Are the offers too good for one2019s educational background or skills? Are there freebies? Traffickers are glib of tongue and offer a lot, like free fare and processing of documents, even a cash advance.

Even legal recruiters have to be held in doubt, especially when the applicant is referred to another if he or she fails to pass legal screening.
 
The IACAT Davao advised the public to not easily believe any of these offers because it could be a trap.
If the process is legal then it is expected that one would spend money for the proceedings but if it is illegal it is even you who would be offered the money.

If the offers are too good to believe, report to the nearest barangay office, police station, DSWD, municipal office and other government agencies.

National Bureau of Investigation-11 Special Investigator Elias Leano Jr.
also told Sun.Star Davao in a separate interview that the people should also watch out for any falsification or alteration made by the illegal recruiters in their documents as that is a clear indication of trafficking.

201cThere are traffickers who would target to victimize minors and they would often used as an alibi the reason that they do not know that the victims are under aged every time they would be arrested,201d Leano said.

Leano also pointed out that people should be vigilant and must examine if ever the recruiter is trying to fake or forge their documents such as birth certificates and others that our often used as requirements for an employment as this is one of the signs of trafficking.

One can determine traffickers through this: victims are given the money in exchange for a promise job in another place or country to entice potential victims into pursuing it, Leano said.

201cPeople should carefully examine why they are being offered material wealth by their recruiters,201d Leano added.
 
Prevention
There must be a strong collaboration with the barangay officials because it is the first level and has a direct contact with the people.
If they spotted or noticed factors of trafficking then they should feed that information to the law enforcers and agencies such as the NBI, PNP and others so that data can be validated through investigation, Leano urged.

If the factors and elements of trafficking are found to be present in their investigations then they would file appropriate charges against the culprits and rescue the victims especially the minors.

Since it is the minors who are often trafficked, Leano also advised the parents to have a strict monitoring on their children2019s whereabouts and if the minor has no parents, the DSWD can take care of them.
201cBasically, it starts in the family so parents should be responsible enough in guiding their children,201d Leano uttered.

Since most traffic victims are exploited in their quest to find a job, Leano said that the government must give them a job.

Poverty in the country pushed them to pursue whatever jobs they encounter in their desperation to provide for their own and their family2019s needs and that is why they are victimized whenever they are offered employment or money in any forms of trafficking.

DSWD2019S Project Development Officer 3 Acera pointed out that above all, education is very important that is why the youth must be able to go to school because if they are well-informed they will be able to make sound decisions or choices which will protect them from being victimized.

If authorities work with people who are well aware and informed in the issue, then it would be easier to minimize trafficking incidents which might even lead to a point of extinction.

Pinoy in Rome: Christmas in the Year of Mercy, Pinoy in Rome: Christmas in the Year of Mercy
Photo by Robert Cortez
Robert Z.
Cortes, IN THE run-up towards Christmas -- last night in particular -- I felt impelled, for some reason, to return to Santa Maria in Monticelli.
This church was one of the shrines I featured in an article I wrote some weeks back to help me and my friends prepare for the opening of the Year of Mercy.
Since the church was just some five minutes away, walking from my house, I thought it would be a good idea to say the rosary in a shrine of Our Lady, to accompany her, as it were, on her journey to Bethlehem.
But, as with many of my plans, this one ended up being modified by Providence -- and, as always, to my advantage.

There was a pleasant surprise waiting for me inside the church.
It was the Blessed Sacrament exposed in a monstrance, in the middle of the altar.
The rest of the church was dimly lit, and the only bright light was in the front focusing on Our Lord.
There was a heightened sense of the solemn in that moment, but it was not only because of the dramatic ambiance, which included a solitary white-haired man praying the rosary on his knees.
Above all, it was because I had not expected the exposition to be there at all.
I felt I was waited upon, and by Whom! 
After 30 minutes of accompanying Our Lord, I then went to the side chapel to carry out my original intention of praying the rosary.
The chapel is dedicated to the Crucifix, handed down from the 14th century, and is a venerated image.
St.
Bridget of Sweden, whose church is just nearby, is known to have prayed before this Crucifix on many occasions.
Our Lady on the altar is the Madonna in Monticelli.
It used to be on the high altar, apparently, but has been replaced by a painting of the Presentation of Our Lady.
She is venerated here as Our Lady, Help of Christians.
As I knelt down, I saw an exhortation posted on top of the kneeler, written in Italian, which I found very touching.
It said: "Before this beautiful image of the Madonna, invoked as Help of Christians, stop for a moment and pray through the title to which, in moments of persecution, Christians have turned to Our Lady: entrust to Her your family, your sick loved ones, and suffering humanity."
The last phrase moved me, as I remembered my family abroad, my sick friends and relatives -- especially those who have personally asked me for prayers -- and the migrants who are suffering a very cold and difficult winter, many times rejected by those who should be welcoming them.
I felt that amidst my incapability of giving everyone a material Christmas present, this was the best I could do.
Many times, in fact, our prayers are the best gifts we can possibly give.
So I put them all there with all the strength of soul I could muster, not relying on my memory, which has long become poor, but on my desire, which is still gigantic.
I looked at the obviously very ancient Cross many times, already pierced in many parts with bukbok, and marveled at the fact that I had now become part of the long line of men and women in history who have found solace before it.
I was pleased to discover, as I looked at the dome above, that the angels painted on it were each holding something connected to the Passion: the Pillar of the Flagellation, the Cloth with the Holy Face, the Shroud, and Our Lord's Robe.
But I mostly looked at the image of Our Lady and the Child, and for many reasons.
First, because it was much nearer.
Then, because the figures were ravishingly beautiful: their reddish cheeks, their soft looking skin, their beautiful crowns, and the very delicate lace below our Lady's neck.

I remembered something I learned in art history class: that the red dress of Our Lady represented her humanity, and her blue cloak represented how she had been made royalty; the white tunic of Our Lord represented his purity.
Above all, the picture reminded me of Christmas: and not only because of the Mother and Child, but because the hearts they were holding -- amazingly painted as red, soft and tender things -- reminded me of those winter Christmas cherries you see on the Christmas tree.

How nice it would be, I thought, if we decorated the Christmas tree of our lives this Christmas season with a tender and soft heart for those who need it most from us.
That red, soft, and tender thing would be the constant glow lighting our living tree.
Christmas is always one of the best seasons for giving ourselves in meek and humble service to others, especially those closest to us, but even more so in this Jubilee Year of Mercy.
In our own little way, we would then be like Our Lord who came as Child for the purpose of waiting upon us, of serving us and has been waiting upon us and for us for centuries in the Blessed Sacrament.
This genuine disposition of being Christ to others is arguably the best one we can have this Christmas.
With it we can more sincerely and more meaningfully greet each and every one "Merry Christmas!"
