Statement of Cebu Citizens-Press Council on the death of Letty Jimenez-Magsanoc, Statement of Cebu Citizens-Press Council on the death of Letty Jimenez-MagsanocDec.
26, 2015
Letty Jimenez-Magsanoc was more than the editor-in-chief of a prestigious national newspaper.
To community journalists particularly, she embodied the ideals of journalism they could aspire for: her newsroom leadership, her courage in resisting repression in the dark days of martial law, and her passion and creativity in steering the "Inquirer" to its enviable place in the industry.
She knew her power to set the agenda, which Washington Post publisher Katharine Graham says is deciding what to print and what not to print, but she used it fearlessly and responsibly for what she believed was for public good.
Pachico A.
Seares
Executive Director, CCPC 
In their hands: People empowered to protect and provide, In their hands: People empowered to protect and provide
Bantay Kalikasan  members of Barangay San Miguel in Arakan Valley help prepare lunch for the BK meeting being held at their new office building.

Stella A.
Estremera, "ANG sa una, grabe man gud ang bisyo.
Inom.
Karon, naa pa pero pang-relax na lang ,201d said Mary Joy Tumanding, a resident of barangay Tumanding in Arakan Valley in North Cotabato province, one of five barangays surrounding Mt.
Sinaka, the town2019s main source of water.
What2019s here now that wasn2019t there before? Why did people change? 
201cWe used to just plant corn and bananas, now we also have rubber and cacao and fruit trees,201d she said in the vernacular.

Didn2019t you have access to rubber, cacao, and fruit seedlings before? 
201cWe had.
Those given by Fr.
Pops .
Many just died.201d Why didn2019t it prosper before? 201cThe women were busy with farm work.
Our menfolk were always drinking.201d You2019re still farming now, why aren2019t the men no longer drinking much? 201cOur men now tend the farm.201d 
What made the difference? 
201cBefore, the seedlings were just given to us, we were not taught what to do with it.
We didn2019t even know that cacao had to be planted at a certain distance from each other.
Now, I was even able to join a Farmer Field School  where I learned about budding.201d It took much longer than that to squeeze out what made the difference in the lives of members of Bantay Kalikasan before and now beyond what members and leaders from five barangays where BK has been established to protect Mt.
Sinaka six years ago are saying as 201cbetter than before201d.

But her final reply was eye-opening as it spelled the difference between giving and helping.
Tumanding is a prevalently Manobo-Tingananon village.
The four other barangays organized under Bantay Kalikasan 2013 Datu Ladayon, San Miguel, Salasang, and Lanao Kuran 2013 are predominantly Visayan settlers and some Tedurays who were brought to the area by the strife in other North Cotabato towns.

BK was initiated by Kinaiyahan Foundation Inc.
 in 2009 in partnership with Arakan2019s municipal environment and natural resources office  and municipal agriculture office  to mobilize the communities surrounding Mt.
Sinaka to protect it.

With residents harnessed to conduct inventories of the existing trees, planting of indigenous species on the mountain and its foothills, and maintaining nurseries for fruits and forest trees, slash and burn farming and illegal cutting of trees and shrubs on Mt.
Sinaka has been reduced to the barest minimum.
Even former slash-and-burn farmers have joined BK after realizing the importance of protecting the environment for sustained farm production and access to potable water.

Rita Panisa, a BK member of barangay Salasang, admits that before BK, the people were not mindful of the importance of the trees to their water sources and the sustainability of their livelihood and kaingin was a very common practice in farming.

201cKung makita ang kahoy mutubo, sigurado na kung naay sundang, putol gyud na ,201d she said in describing how rampant slash-and-burn farming was.
Born in Salasang, she never went up Mt.
Sinaka, until she joined the inventory and tree planting activities of BK.

Jonathan Tumanding of Barangay Tumanding, on the other hand, recalls how selling round lumber was their livelihood in his elementary years.
201cI would go with my father  and we2019d cut trees, make these into planks, and deliver these to wherever there are buyers,201d he said.

201cGagmay ra ang mag-uma kaniadto, tinuig ang uma .201d Joel Llegue, also of Tumanding, said that the forest was still lush during those times and so the people never gave much value to the trees.
That was then.
Logging operations and the slash and burn farming practices that followed have threatened Mt.
Sinaka.

It was in the 1990s when the people around Mt.
Sinaka, with the support of the local government, stood up against logging in their last bid to save whatever has been left.

It is from the success of this movement where BK stepped in and flourished.
To encourage participation, BKs were made beneficiaries of livelihood projects like duck, goat, hog, and chicken raising, and lately of livestock like cows and carabaos.

Each BK has thought up of its own system of distributing the benefits of these projects.
Like propagating the hogs and distributing these to each member who in turn will propagate his/hers as the BK maintains a high-quality boar.
The same goes for the livestock.

In barangay San Miguel, BK leader Bienvenido Ranario said they already have a total of ten cows with just one male, 24 goats that they were able to distribute to their members with two more females on the way, 67 chickens, and five ducks.
They are also cultivating organic bananas.
 The members are now also starting to harvest cacao and enjoying its high demand and gate price.
 
Protection and livelihood have thus sustained each other.
With livelihood as enticement, members are enjoying the fruits of their labor because of sustainable agriculture practices.
People are also made to understand how the environment works such that falcate and gmelina trees are not planted on areas around the water sources since these trees are for harvesting.
Trees planted around springs are the hardwood species.

Since then, BKs in the five barangays have been given priority in both environment and agriculture projects of Arakan.
201cIt2019s a priority of the local government because the concept of community involvement is very appropriate and we are able to revive our forests,201d Arakan Mayor Rene Rubino said.
Aside from the farm animals they distribute, the BK members are also prioritized in the National Greening Program where they get to provide the seedlings and are also tapped to do the planting, thus they earn outside of their regular farm income.

Recalling how they started the movement to protect the environment against logging in the 1990s, Rubino said, that they were not just focusing on the advocacy but were also ensuring that the people benefitted from their participation in order to imbibe the value of the environment toward sustainable development.
201cIn Arakan, environmental protection succeeded because it was given importance by the LGU,201d he added.

MAO Edgar V.
Arana however insists that what they have given the people is not even equivalent to what the people have contributed in saving Mt.
Sinaka.

201cMga livelihood, taphaw ra 2018na ,201d he said, 201cbecause the greater benefit is reaped by government which is the one tasked to protect the forest.201d 201cThe livelihood projects we have given does not even approximate the benefits the people were getting from the forests,201d he added.

From the forests, they harvested rattan, abaca, logs, and hunted game.

But all these have to stop because there is the need to protect Arakan2019s water source for today and the future generations.
At the outskirts of barangay Tumanding, Genaro Tumanding is building a new house, still of wood and bamboo, but approximately four times bigger than the regular houses of Manobos in the area.

He attributes his newly acquired wealth to the agriculture techniques he learned through BK.
He2019s now harvesting cacao, he said, and earns more than P3,000 a month from this alone.

His coffee trees are now starting to bear fruit and he looks forward to harvesting these as well on top of his bananas and vegetables and other fruits that thrive in his diversified farm lot.

201cOg madato ko, di gyud ta mo makalimtan ,201d Genaro, who once used to eke out a living hunting in the forest, told the KFI staff.
Top 10 Events That Shape 2015 , Top 10 Events That Shape 2015 Third Anne Peralta-Malonzo, Keith A.Calayag, FROM Pope Francis2019 historic visit, Mamasapano massacre to the Philippines2019 third crown in the prestigious Miss Universe pageant, Filipinos became witnesses to various events in 2015 that will be remembered for years to come.
Pope Francis charms the Philippines 
It2019s not every day that you get to see the leader of the world2019s one billion Catholics in person.
 That is why for five days in January , Filipinos from all walks of life trooped to several areas in Manila and Tacloban to get a glimpse and feel the presence of charismatic Pope Francis.
He met with priests, nuns, young people and celebrated mass at the Quirino Grandstand that drew a record crowd of six million despite the stormy weather, breaking a 1995 record when five million attended a similar event led by now Saint John Paul II in the same venue.
The highlight of the pontiff2019s visit, however, was his meeting with survivors of Super Typhoon Yolanda  which killed thousands of people and destroyed communities and livelihood in November 2013.
Francis2019 message of compassion and hope earned praises and some were even moved to tears.

 Mamasapano massacre 
Just as the Aquino government was making strides in bringing lasting peace in Mindanao, a monkey wrench was thrown into the clockwork and set back most of what it have planned to do.

On January 25, 44 members of the Philippine National Police Special Action Force were killed in an encounter with Muslim rebels and armed groups while on a mission to hunt terror suspects Abdul Basit Usman and Zulkifli Bin Hir also known as Marwan.
 
Twenty-three other people died because of the bungled operation, which brought jarring political consequences such as all-time low in the popularity ratings of President Benigno Aquino III and the stalled passage of the draft Bangsamoro Basic Law in Congress.
While Aquino assured that those responsible for the bloody incident would be held to account, he also called on Congress to hasten the passage of the proposed BBL, which was aimed at ending decades of armed conflict in Mindanao through the establishment of a political entity that will replace the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao.
Aquino remained hopeful that the measure will be passed before he steps down from power in June 2016.
 2018Tanim-bala2019 modus 
Air travelers got worried in the last three months of 2015 when news came out that some passengers were victimized by airport personnel who plant bullets in their luggage.
Various groups condemned the scam as unsuspecting individuals, including overseas Filipino workers, were forced to pay thousands of pesos in bribes under threat of lawsuit.
One of them is Gloria Ortinez, who had been working in Hong Kong for about 30 years.

Her return to Hong Kong was stalled when she became a victim of 2018tanim-bala2019 at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport.
 
Ortinez was eventually acquitted by the Pasay City Prosecutor2019s Office but upon return to Hong Kong, she found out that her employer has terminated her despite a communication from the Philippine Overseas Labor Office requesting the employer to give OFW Ortinez time and consideration to return to Hong Kong.

The National Bureau of Investigation later on confirmed the presence of such modus, which is reportedly not a handiwork of a syndicate.
201cThe NBI cannot establish that.
In these incidents, only certain people are involved,201d said Justice Undersecretary and spokesman Emmanuel Caparas in a press briefing on December 10.
Six airport personnel were also charged for the bullet-planting incidents, two from the Transportation Security  and four from the police Aviation Security Group .
 Manila scores in sea dispute with Beijing 
Malaca\xf1ang and nationalists lauded last October the ruling of the United Nations Arbitral Tribunal admitting jurisdiction over the case between the Philippines and China on the disputed territory in the West Philippine Sea.
This was despite Beijing objections that the arbitration body has no authority to hear the case brought up by Manila.
While the UN tribunal acknowledged its jurisdiction over the Philippine case against China, however, it did not include in its ruling the merits of the case as this would be subject of further hearing.
The Philippines believes it has a strong case because did not ask the tribunal to rule on maritime boundaries delimitation and the issue isn2019t about territorial sovereignty.
Instead, the Philippines is asking the tribunal to invalidate China's nine-dash line that covers 90 percent of the entire West Philippine Sea , as well as confirm the environmental degradation caused by Beijing's massive reclamation.
The Philippines is hoping that the process will be completed before the Aquino administration steps down in June 2016.
Mary Jane Veloso2019s last-minute reprieve from firing squad 
Just as her family and the nation were preparing for the worst, Filipina drug convict Mary Jane Veloso was saved from firing squad with just a few minutes to spare on wee hours of April 29.
Amid appeals from various groups and personalities including President Benigno Aquino III and world boxing champion Manny Pacquiao, Indonesia issued a reprieve at the eleventh hour as Veloso was given a chance to prove that she was a victim of drug trafficking.
Hours before the reprieve, Veloso2019s alleged recruiters Ma.
Cristina Sergio and live-in partner Julius Lacanilao surrendered to police although both still denied involvement in the 30-year-old2019s case.
In November, Indonesia announced that it had suspended the death penalty, which benefits Veloso and others, because the government wants to focus on improving Southeast Asia2019s largest economy.
Veloso was arrested in Yogyakarta airport in 2010 after authorities found 2.6 kilograms of heroin in a suitcase supposedly given by her Filipino companion who recruited her for a job as a domestic worker.
Pacquiao bows to Mayweather in 2018Fight of the Century2019 
After months of anticipation, eight-division world boxing champion Manny Pacquiao and prized American fighter Floyd Mayweather Jr.
squared off with the latter emerging as winner before a sell-out crowd at a Las Vegas hotel on May 2.
Pacquiao's camp revealed that he had sustained an undisclosed injury to his right shoulder while training, and while it had healed in time for the fight, he re-injured it in the fourth round.
Critics said that the injury contributed to his defeat.
Still, the bout earned criticisms as some had been disappointed in Mayweather's defense-oriented strategy and Pacquaio's difficulty in landing punches.
This had led to some critics and media outlets to describe the multi-million dollar bout as a complete waste of time and the 201chype of the century.201d
Pacquiao, 37, will return to the ring on April 9, 2016, just a month before he will be judged by voters if he is worthy to be promoted from congressman to senator.
The lawmaker will be facing a familiar foe: Timothy Bradley.
Pacquiao is expected to earn at least $20 million from the fight with Bradley, whom he defeated for the WBO welterweight title in April 2014.
Bradley won in their first meeting in June 2012 but observers had Pacquiao winning convincingly.

 US Marine convicted for killing transgender Jennifer Laude 
Over a year after he was charged with murder over the death of Filipino transgender Jeffrey 201cJennifer201d Laude, Lance Corporal Joseph Scott Pemberton was found guilty of homicide instead of murder as demanded by the victim2019s family.
He was sentenced to six up to 12 years of imprisonment by the Olongapo Regional Trial Court.
On the evening of October 11, 2014, Laude2019s body was found inside the bathroom of one of the rooms in Celzone Lodge in Olongapo City where she checked in with Pemberton after meeting at a nearby bar.
Pemberton admitted choking Laude after having found that she was biologically female but said he did not have the intention to kill her.

The solder said that she was still alive when he left her in the shower, not at the edge of the toilet bowl where police responders reportedly found her.
On December 1, the court delivered its verdict and said the killing of Laude was downgraded to homicide as it did not meet the standards for murder.

Aside from imprisonment, Pemberton was ordered to pay fine worth P4.5 million to Laude2019s family for civil indemnities, loss of earning capacity as Laude stood as the breadwinner of her family, for burial and funeral expenses and for moral and exemplary damages.
The court also ordered the transfer of Pemberton from his temporary detention in Camp Aguinaldo to the New Bilibid Prison in Muntinlupa City but Pemberton2019s legal counsel immediately appealed.
The court then allowed him to remain in the military camp but under the custody of the Bureau of Corrections.
 Search for next Palace occupant begins 
Vice President Jejomar Binay, Senators Grace Poe and Miriam Defensor Santiago, former Local Government chief Manuel Roxas II, and Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte all have their eyes set on the May 2016 elections2019 biggest prize: the presidency.
While they could not officially campaign until February 2016, these personalities are already facing various issues, legal or otherwise, that test their viability as candidates.
Binay is hobbled by corruption allegations while Poe needs a final ruling from the Supreme Court whether she has met the residency and citizenship requirements for presidential candidates.
Santiago2019s admission that she licked late stage lung cancer still raised apprehensions while Roxas2019 performance as Cabinet member has been touted as sub-par.

Born with a silver spoon, Roxas was also branded by his opponents as elitist in a country where a quarter of the population is considered poor.

Duterte, meanwhile, has been criticized for his dictatorial tendencies and alleged lack of respect for human rights when he admitted that he had already killed 1,700 suspected criminals in Davao City.
 Philippines hosts Apec Summit for second time 
The whole country on November 18 to 19 witnessed the coming of over 11,000 delegates from all over the world in Manila for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation  Economic Leaders' Meeting.
United States President Barack Obama, Chinese President Xi Jinping, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and social media darlings Mexican leader Enrique Pe\xf1a Nieto and Canadian premier Justin Trudeau took part in the summit which the Philippines hosted for the first time since 1996.

Apec 2015 was held amid simmering tensions between Philippines and China due to territorial disputes in the West Philippines Sea.
However, the Philippines decided to put aside the issue temporarily to focus on the summit's objective: promotion of trade, investment and inclusive growth, which is needed to defeat poverty in Apec member countries.
The summit was also held just days after the November 13 Paris attacks which left 137 people dead, forcing the country to enforce strict security and road closures near summit venues and hotels in Metro Manila that caused heavy traffic and inconvenience to commuters and motorists.
Normally, trade and economic issues are discussed at the Apec meeting.
But following the Paris attacks, the world leaders welcomed efforts to fight terrorism.
They called for continued individual and collective actions, as well as sharing of best practices, in securing infrastructure, travel, supply chains, and financial systems from acts of terrorism.
New economic strategies were also discussed: Building inclusive economies, fostering the participation of micro, small and medium enterprises, building sustainable and resilient communities and enhancing the regional economic integration agenda.
In summary, President Benigno Aquino III said the main challenge for the economic leaders is to find a way to sustain and strengthen quality growth, particularly by considering policy responses that promote inclusivity, while addressing the current domestic and external challenges to Apec countries' growth.
 Third Miss Universe crown for Philippines 
It was a victory 42 years in the making with a dramatic plot twist in the end.
Philippines2019 bet Pia Wurtzbach beat out 79 other ladies around the world to secure the country2019s third Miss Universe crown after Gloria Diaz and Margie Moran, who won the title in 1969 and 1973, respectively.
Wurtzbach's victory though was shrouded with controversy when pageant host Steve Harvey mistakenly announced her as first runner-up to Ariadna Gutierrez of Colombia.
Harvey immediately corrected the mix-up and awarded the crown to Wurtzbach.
Gutierrez was named first runner-up and Olivia Jordan of the United States placed second runner-up to complete the top three.
Celebrity judges Perez Hilton and Niecy Nash also vouched for Miss Philippines2019 victory, saying the four-man judges2019 panel gave a unanimous vote for Wurtzbach.

Prior to joining beauty contests, Wurtzbach, 26, was a professional model, actress, host, chef, beauty writer, stylist, and make-up artist.
She competed in the Binibining Pilipinas pageant in 2013 and 2014 but failed to win the title of Miss Universe-Philippines.
Wurtzbach, however, was not discouraged as she joined for the third time in 2015 and eventually bagged the title of Miss Universe-Philippines, which allowed her to represent the country in the competition held on December 20 in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Masbad: Top 3 apps for your 2016 travel, Masbad: Top 3 apps for your 2016 travelRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, HAPPY new year everyone! I trust that all your digits are all accounted for and that you had an awesome New Year's Eve countdown.
Oh, and let's not forget the media noche.
Hopefully, that was as filling as the year that was.

I'll make this a quick for everybody.

I've been told that this year will be a good year to travel.
In fact, my girlfriend is telling me that we should be going on a trip soon.
Perhaps twice this year.
Surely, there will be a bonanza of destinations to pick from.
The Philippines alone has tons to offer.
Whether you prefer to go up the mountain or swim in the sea, you won't easily run out of options.
From Aparri to Jolo, there's some place to go to and marvel at.

But wherever you may be headed to, I'd like to recommend three kinds of apps to make sure that you have in your smartphones.

Photography
I think this will be the one kind of app that you must have.
Sure, there's the stock camera app of your chosen smartphone but it won't hurt really you have something that offers more.
Moreso if you're into photography and are craving for a bit more control.

My recommendation is to get Camera+ .

PS.
I'd like to add here Snapseed  as a photo editing app to accompany your camera app.

Flights and planes
In most likelihood, you'll be travelling by plane.
There are apps out there that allow you to track airplanes and monitor flights whether they're on time or not.
I cannot stress this enough that knowing when your plane is landing so you can board or knowing the status of your flight is very helpful.

My recommendation here is Flightradar24 .

Maps
This is a no-brainer.
When you're out there on a foreign place, knowing where you are and where to go saves you time and energy.
And for the navigationally-challenged, this, will hopefully, help you out too.

My recommendation here is Google Maps .

So there you have it! 
May your 2016 be filled with travels and adventures and the photos that come out of it!
Cheers!
Agri tech: A sometimes forgotten basic , Agri tech: A sometimes forgotten basic 
Photo by Stella A.
Estremera
Stella A.
Estremera, THE farm lot that now teems with various crops and fruit trees used to host only corn, a farmer in baragnay San Miguel, Arakan Valley in North Cotabato said.
"Mais ra man gayud ang uma sa una ," he said.
Since the local government unit partnered with Kinaiyahan Foundation Inc.
 in 2009, however, diversified farming has been introduced with the town's municipal agriculture officer  Edgar Aranas taking the lead in making sure that the residents of five barangays surrounding Mt.
Sinaka in their town organized under the Bantay Kalikasan  are provided livelihood assistance and learn agriculture technology that can ensure sustainable development.
BK was organized to protect Mt.
Sinaka, the major water source of the municipality and a critical habitat of the endangered Philippine Eagle.

But to ensure that the residents are up and about to guard the mountain from poachers and slash-and-burn farmers, the municipal government had to ensure that the residents are enjoying a good harvest and have sustainable livelihood away from the forests of Sinaka.
"Dagko kayo ang challenge ka yang unang makalaban, dili man ang mga dagko kay wala na man sila diha.
Ang naa diha, mga pobre ," Aranas said.
"We were introducing technologies that go against what the ordinary people have been doing as a means of survival," he added.
The residents of barangays Datu Ladayon, San Miguel, Salasang, Tumanding, and Datu Kuran  used to eke out a living through kaingin , hunting, gathering of rattan, and small-scale logging on Mt.
Sinaka.
This means, Aranas said, by enforcing the law to keep people out of Mt.
Sinaka, they were depriving people of their means of livelihood.
That is the very reason why the LGU has made sure that members of BK are given priority for any agricultural and environment protection projects.
"It's like we dislocated them from their means of survival," Aranas said, admitting that what the LGU has been giving since BK was organized in 2009 is but a small portion of the benefits the residents were getting from the mountain before that.
"The livelihood projects we have been giving out has not yet come at par with the earnings the people got from Mt.
Sinaka before," he said.
To maximize the benefits of what the LGU is giving out, agricultural technology comes in as a major component.

Thus, from just tending to corn plots, residents now know crop diversification that mix what they call the "durable" crops  and the vegetables, root crops, and other farm produce that are harvested seasonally.
Alberto Apas, a farmer and BK member of San Miguel, expressed gratitude for the learnings he got as a farmer, which for so long, he was never aware of.
"Ang BK nagtudlo og diversified farming.
Dako kayo ang kausaban sa amoang kahimtang ," he said.
"Pinaagi sa training, na-develop ang pagsabot," BK-San Miguel chair Bienvenido Ranario Jr.
said.
"Napalawom ang pagsabot sa mga miyembro na dili lang sa mananom ta, pero nganong mananom ta ."
As reported in last Sunday's cover story about these same people, Mary Joy Tumanding of barangay Tumanding admitted that while they were given cacao, coffee, and rubber seedlings before BK came to be, they were never taught how to plant these.
As a result, the seedlings failed to provide for them a lush harvest.
Today, BK members are not only planting permanent or cash crops  like cacao and coffee and fruit trees, they are also planting harvestable trees like falcata and gmelina.
But it is clear to all members that these harvestable trees can only be planted in their farmlands, on the foothills of Mt.
Sinaka, but never around water sources.
The reason: these will be harvested in a few years and being fast-growing trees, these species also use up a lot of water.
The trees planted on Mt.
Sinaka and most especially around identified water sources are the indigenous hardwood species.
Having a full understanding of how crops and the environment interact with each other, after six years, residents are now enjoying the huge demand for cacao and coffee beans.
The seedlings they planted six years ago are now producing the beans that are providing for them a better livelihood.
It's a wonder that it took so long for rural folks to be reached by farm technologies that require not much but their daily attention and concern, which includes concern for where the water they are getting to nourish themselves and their farms come from.
But as is often said, better late than never, and we are all the better for it: the farmers, the environment, and us the people.
Inglay's kitchen  , Inglay's kitchen  Maria Elena Catajan, LA TRINIDAD Benguet - When Inglay Capuyan-Fokno first opened her
restaurant, locals would take off their shoes when they entered.
The act, although a laughable anecdote today is indicative of the culture of respect and humility highland folk have to which the restaurant pays homage to serving food in its traditional proportions, using native ingredients and making its interiors a reflection of highland culture.

Inglay herself said it took a while for the locals to get comfortable with the ambiance of the place, it being, one of the first resto in the Valley to offer a table clothed, clean, prim and proper eating place.
"They were shy to come in, thinking it was too formal and expensive," relates Capuyan-Fokno.
 
On the onset, Inglay served alcoholic drinks in the resto, but was dissuaded by the number of drunks who spent the night drinking the night away, as well as holes cigarettes wrecked on her pristine white table cloth.

When the resto first opened in 1997, Dangwa and Benguet State University employees were its frequent visitors, families would have their special occasions in the resto or come for a meal, in the time when there was no Department of Tourism accreditation, Inglay was already tourism friendly, with its ambiance, menu and staff giving the public an alternative restaurant in the Valley.

Today there is a new menu for the establishment, deciding the old food fare has become too common, the family collaborated with their in house chef and is proud to present the revitalized menu.

The Inglay Mongolian buffet is now open for lunch and dinner with the usual vegetables, meat, sauces and spices but what makes the buffet special is the freshness of the produce which is sourced from the personal rooftop garden of Inglay herself.

The Mongolian buffet also boasts to be the lone resto to offer rice wine in its choices of sauces to mix into your chosen bowl, of course, with the help of the Chef Celso Ocampo, if you need advice on how to make full use of the highland wine, now used for cooking.

A new drink defines the innovation the menu has with the refreshing torogito iced tea, made from local rice wine, lemons and sugar.
The drink is surprisingly refreshing, making you smile, especially if you know what tapuey tastes like.

The family collaboration came up with a menu that is personal, combining the choicest family recipes and tried and tested Inglay signature dishes.

Restaurant signature pinikpikan as well as the etag sinigang is still in the fray.
Added in the menu are soy honey pork chops, beef terriyaki, BBQ pork ribs and Inglays quarter chicken.

Pasta innovations include the etaglaise, the family's version of bolognaise, sandwich choices have roast pork, chicken and tuna.

Inglay's memory soup, which is a hearty mix of red beans, etag , and flour dumplings, its described to invoke memories of home, prodding you to remember good soup taken on a rainy day.

Breakfast choices include full hearty meals inspired by true life patrons of the resto labeled as the trader, energizer, climber and highlander which include favorite's like tapa, longanissa, pan de sal and corned beef.

Salads are named after Ingaly's daughter, Massinay, which is a twist on the waldorf, the Weight Watchers choice, the Cordilleras and Inglay's favorite, all of which are eternally personal, giving you a glimpse of what Inglay's family is made of.

Inglay's daughter, Katrina, recently added a pastry shop within the resto, taking care of the sweet after meal treats you may find in her quaint space.
Breads, pastries and desserts may be ordered as well.

As Inglay's tradition of food preparation has evolved with time, passing on her tradition to her children and servicing the Valley community with good food, prepared and presented in the best way possible.

Before Inglay opened her full restaurant, a small hole in the wall was set up carinderia style, serving Inglay2019s signature dishes, today, what we see at Inglay's is a testament of a woman's persistence knows no bounds.

Twitter appears ready to expand beyond 140-character tweets, Twitter appears ready to expand beyond 140-character tweets
Twitter co-founder and Chairman Jack Dorsey speaks at a campaign fundraiser for Democratic Candidate for Public Advocate Reshma Saujani, in New York.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Twitter appears ready to loosen its decade-old restriction on the length of messages in a bid to make its service more appealing to a wider audience accustomed to the greater freedom offered by Facebook and other forums.
CEO and co-founder Jack Dorsey telegraphed Twitter's intentions in a tweet posted Tuesday after the technology news site Re/Code reported the company is exploring increasing its limits on text from 140 characters to as many as 10,000.
Dorsey didn't directly address the Re/Code report that cited unnamed people, but he made it clear that Twitter isn't wedded to the 140 character limit.
He illustrated his point by posting a screenshot of a text consisting of 1,325 characters.
If Twitter were to allow tweets to span 10,000 characters, it could produce 1,700-word dissertations, based on the size of Dorsey's extended post.
San Francisco-based Twitter Inc.
declined to comment on its plans.
In his message, Dorsey wrote that Twitter has already noticed that many of its roughly 300 million users already have been including screenshots of lengthy texts in their tweets.
He indicated Twitter is examining ways to give people more room to express themselves without polluting the service with gasbags.
Imposing some restraint "inspires creativity and brevity.
And a sense of speed.
We will never lose that feeling," Dorsey pledged.
At the same time, Dorsey said Twitter isn't "going to be shy about building more utility and power into Twitter for people.
As long as it's consistent with what people want to do, we're going to explore it."
Analysts said Dorsey is probably trying to avoid a backlash among long-time Twitter users who consider the 140-character tweeting limit sacred.
At the same time, he needs to respond to company shareholders pining for a bigger audience that would generate more advertising revenue.
More revenue eventually could help Twitter turn a profit for the first time in its history.
Twitter can't afford "to become stagnant, they need to get bigger if they want to build a more relevant advertising platform," said Topeka Capital Markets analyst Blake Harper.
After a long streak of robust growth that turned it into one of the Internet's hottest companies, Twitter's growth has slowed dramatically during the past year-and-half to leave it scrambling to catch up with social networking leader Facebook and its 1.5 billion users.
Twitter's malaise resulted in the departure of Dick Costolo as the company's CEO last July and ushered in the return of Dorsey, who had been ousted as the company's leader in 2008.
The pressure has been building on Dorsey to take drastic measures to accelerate user growth as Twitter's stock has sunk further below its November 2013 initial public offering price of $26.
The shares shed 64 cents Tuesday to close at $21.92, a decline of nearly 40 percent from where they stood from when Dorsey became CEO last summer.
Dorsey helped invent Twitter in 2006 and imposed a 140-character limit on messages so the service would be easy to use on cellphones that had 160-character limits on texts at that time.
Those texting limits on phones faded away several years ago as the advent of smartphones enabled people to use other Internet messaging services, making Twitter's restrictions look increasingly antiquated.
Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter believes an increased limit on tweets would be a "good, baby step" to attracting more users to Twitter and believes it could be done without alienating the service's current audience.
One way to make an increased limit less obnoxious would be to only show a limited amount of text in users' feeds and then leave it to each individual to click on a button to see more.
"Twitter is an afterthought in social media right now," Pachter said.
"They need to do something to drive more usage of the service.
If people start using the service more frequently, other users will come join in, too."

Herradura's Faebook
Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, EVEN though she has already reached her highest educational attainment and is busy handling people under her office, this super woman still never stops learning and taking sidetrips at the same time.
Bureau of Plant Industry  Davao National Crop Research and Development Center agricultural center chief IV Lorna E.
Herradura, PhD loves learning and travelling at the same time.

She has also accepted the challenge of making a change to the lives of farmers through her work.
Herradura finished her elementary education at Davao City High School in 1977 and high school education at Holy Cross of Davao College in 1973.
She initially wanted to pursue a course on the medical field but the popular course at that time was in agriculture and so she took and finished Bachelor of Science in Agriculture specializing in Nematology at the University of the Philippines in Los Banos in 1982.
Herradura then continued on and finished her master2019s degree in Plant Pathology at UPLB specializing in Virology in 1993 and Doctorate degree in Bioscience Engineering at Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium specializing in applied biological science in 2009.
She said that being on the field where she is now studying different plant diseases and looking for solutions to them is not what she has dreamed of she immediately fell in love with it.
201cI started with fisheries talaga but eventually naging passion ko na because I have seen the need to help farmers,201d Herradura said.
One of these famous plant diseases that she has pioneered in research was for the management of fusarium wilt primarily affecting banana farmers and finding some resistance varieties.
She also has become an award winning personality on her field with her research papers and she has also authored and co-authored several scientific and technical in both national and international publications.
Other than facing the day to day challenges of handling the BPI-Davao Office since 2005, Herradura likes to take her time off through nature-tripping.
One of her favorite destinations here in the country is Coron, Palawan which she labels as the place where she would always go back to.
Herradura shares that when she travels she loves to see and know the culture of the place where she is going just like her Ilocos trip.
201cDuring my trip to Ilocos I really went to their palengke wherein I found vegetables that we thought aren2019t edible are edible pala,201d she said.
For her foreign trips one of her most memorable ones are her Europe trip and the USA which are also a part of her study stints.
When asked how she would see herself in the future, she said that she sees herself applying for different scholarships to expand her field learning and also continuing her side-trips along the way.
Remembering Raf Benaldo: A man of Integrity, Remembering Raf Benaldo: A man of Integrity
Raf Benaldo and Dolly Ilogon in New York.
 
Riain Alfonso, IF HE were given one last chance to talk to his father, former House Representative Benjo Benaldo said that he would thank his dad for instilling in him the right values.

201cIf I had another chance aside from that, I will talk to him about basketball.201d  Benaldo2019s father, Serafin 201cRaf201d Benaldo, passed away last January 3.
 He was former assistant secretary of the Department of Interior and Local Government and was a leading media practitioner in Cagayan de Oro.
He was a very big influence according to Benaldo.
201cThe way I saw who I wanted to be was mainly based from what he taught me as a kid.
He wanted me to be a leader, to influence others, to do good.201d He furthered that his father was very religious, 201cIn fact he started out in the seminary because he wanted to become a priest.
The values he instilled in me were the same values that were instilled in him by the priests while he was growing up in the seminary as a young man.201d
Raf, an only child, was born on October 20, 1941, in the town of Gigaquit in Surigao del Norte.
He studied college at Xavier University and took his Masters in Public Administration at the University of Santo Tomas.
He made his mark in Cagayan de Oro as a media person and educator.
He started with DXCC, became the manager of GMA 12, and was the founder and producer of Newscope, the first live English TV program in Cagayan de Oro.
He taught in several universities and colleges including Xavier University and Ateneo de Manila, and was a former president of Don Mariano Marcos Memorial Polytechnic State College, now MUST.
 201cBecause he was also a professor, ganahan siya mag lecture,201d said Benaldo.

Raf was also an active civic leader and was president of the Metro Rotary Club.
He joined DILG after the appointment of Senator Nene Pimentel as Secretary of the said department by then President Cory Aquino.
He worked his way up and was promoted as Director of National Barangay Operations, became Director of DILG National Capital Region, and finally DILG Assistant Secretary.
He is well remembered and loved by his former staff, an excellent testimony of the type of man he was.
Media mentor
Raf was mentor to a lot of the city2019s media folks.
201cAs producer of Newscope, he set standards for his staff in our grammar, pronunciation, appearance, and most of all ethics.
He said I have to do things right to be respected as a newscaster,201d said Dolly Ilogon who first met him in 1980 during her stint as a female disc jockey for 99.9 RK.

She recalled that her first impression of him was that he was a good looking man with a pleasantly modulated voice, 201cTsada iyang voice, pang-announcer gyud.
I noticed that he spoke very good English and talks well.
Pahiluna mo istorya, has class.
I then felt that he was one decent kind of man, a respectable man.
His personality can demand respect.201d
201cI had the opportunity of working with him as his co-anchor on Newscope.
I felt honored to be sitting beside him delivering the nightly newscast on television.
He wanted excellence in work.
He guided me through, he taught me how to conduct interviews, the right questions to ask, how to deal with people, with the politicians,201d said Ilogon.

201cHe showed me the ropes in the broadcast industry.
He always reminded me to be a decent media person, to not be corrupt, always be fair, responsible, and credible.
He said that if I planned to stay long in the broadcast industry, then I have to take good care of my credibility.201d
Ralph saw integrity as very important and demanded this from the people he worked with.
He was a key figure in the development and growth of the Cagayan de Oro Press Club.
201cAs President of the club in 1983, he set the standard and helped it grow.
He wanted the club to be well respected and gave it a good name in the community,201d said Ilogon.
She added that he inspired the young, budding radio reporters and encouraged them to hone their skills and reach for their stars.
She believes that Newscope, a nightly, Monday to Friday, thirty minute newscast, is his greatest contribution to media in CdeO.
201cWe were the first live TV English news program.
Every night, CdeO2019s eyes were fixed on Newscope.
Ralph Benaldo was an authority in CdeO2019s broadcast industry.201d Newscope became the precursor to the current live broadcasts we see on television.
Ilogon warmly recalls that aside from being her boss and colleague, Ralph was also a wonderful and loyal friend.
When her marriage ended, he was there to give her his support and advice.
201cHe lifts up your spirits too.
Once when I was home from NY, he and Benjo treated me to dinner at the Fort.
I saw all these pretty young girls walking by and so I exclaimed, 2018Oh look at these girls, they look so pretty.2019  He said, 2018Dol, when you were their age, dili man sab ka mabentaha-an.
You were also one of the prettiest girls in Cagayan.2019 I was surprised and I laughed.201d
Anti-Marcos
Jerry Orcullo, COPC president, remembers Ralph as a colleague of Mindanao Alliance Speakers Bureau for northern Mindanao for Cory-Doy.
"He was with us, lawyers Gerry Adaza , Jun Pepito , Nonong Neri, and Frank Rojas.
We spoke in rallies," Orcullo shared.

"Raf was soft spoken and cool minded man.
Very well-mannered but an outspoken and staunch anti-Marcos critic.
We attended secret meetings with the united front of the National Democratic Front of the Philippines .
During the duration of the campaign for Cory-Doy, we carried with us our bags all the time as we slept in secret places, always transferring from one place to another to secure ourselves from Marcos forces," Orcullo recalled.
 
Orcullo also shared how brave Raf forcibly entered DMMPSC  crossing barricades set up by students teachers while stones flew as he marched toward the office of DMMMPSC president Melchizedek Maquiso to takeover his seat.
"Several were wounded including our supporters until the PC/INP Capt.
Jeff Soriano dispersed the rallyists," Orcullo said.
  
Married in Oro
It is in Cagayan de Oro that he met and married Almira Abrio.
Together, they have three children: the eldest of his brood is Benjo, then daughters Christina, and Ana Maria.
  
201cHe was serious in so many ways but as a father, when he was not a professor, when he was not a media man or a government official, he was extremely witty.
And I would want, and have been trying, to be like that,201d furthered Benaldo.

He fondly remembers how his father would be able to crack jokes and find the 2018funny2019 in any situation.
 201cHe would always joke around.
In fact, during our moments, when we were travelling, when we were alone as a family, kaming duha ang sigi mag-exchange ug mga jokes, kung kinsa ang mas funny.
I don2019t know if a lot of people know that about my father.
He can always find humor in anything.201d 
Benaldo shared that his father was also very passionate about basketball and recalled that their last conversation was about the sport.
 
One of his fondest memories of his dad is how they would always tease him about his nose.
201cWe would always tease him na pango iyang ilong kay kami tanan wala niliwat sa iya.201d He shared that as a kid, when he was practicing basketball, his father would create a hoop using his hands and arms.
201cDidto ko niya ipa shoot sa ball.
Bahala daw musamot ug ka pango iyang ilong, at least makabalo na ko mu-shoot.201d
No rules 
He recalled that, growing up, his father didn2019t really impose a lot of rules but was very supportive.
 201cBasically, wala kaayo siya2019y rules because early on, at an early age, he already set the most important rules.
Integrity, hard work, and most importantly, being a man for others.
In this world, you are not just doing everything for yourself but that you are doing everything for others.201d
The late Serafin 201cRalph201d Benaldo, husband, father, friend, respected mentor, a public servant, and a media man with integrity, was finally laid to rest at the Green Hills Memorial Park on January 9, 2016.
He was 74 years old.

Rhealyn C.
Pojas, WHILE many came to know the plights of the lumad-bakwits in UCCP Haran, only few can tell what it is like to actually live with them there and that includes the 130 students from the University of the Philippines System who slept at the shelter on the evening of January 5 and stayed there the following day.
 
Though they came from different places in the country and speak different dialects to represent their different UP campuses, they were one in discovering the personal accounts of the indigenous peoples in this evacuation center and show their support on the call to stop lumad killings.

So the main reason for coming was to conduct a basic mass integration with the lumads and to discover for themselves what things there were that they did not hear from the news apart from the other activities that they had conducted over the course of their stay at the shelter.

The members of the Katipunan ng Sanggunia ng Mag-aaral sa UP , an alliance of the university2019s student councils, and the UP Solidaridad, an alliance of UP student publications had arrived at the Haran shelter at around 8pm of January 5 and had slept at the vacant bunkhouses similar to the ones occupied by the lumads.

UP-Mindanao chairperson of the College of Humanities and Social Sciences  Jelyne Alapag said that though the experienced they had sleeping at the Haran shelter is different from what they were used to, they were whole-hearted to have the integration with the lumad evacuees.

201cEven for a short while we were able to experience the life that the lumads have at the evacuation center,201d Alapag shared adding that the evacuees2019 situation at the shelter is not easy.

It was not the first time they heard about the issues that the lumads have but Kasamasa UP Chairperson Raoul Manuel said in an interview with Sun.Star Davao that the Manilakbayan, a march protest staged by the lumad evacuees in the different parts of Luzon and the National Capital Region, heightened the knowledge they had about the lumad2019s situation.
 
201cManilakbayan had played an important role,201d Raoul admitted.

The reason why the UP student leaders chose UP Mindanao to be the venue of this year2019s national student congress themed 201cPangiyakki201d offshoots from the Manilakbayan where the lumads also happened to conduct one of their agenda for the event at the UP-Diliman campus.

On January 6, the different lumad evacuees had gained a hundred listening ears who did not mind sitting on a tarpaulin laid on the ground and being hit by the sunrays as the day got hotter.
They curled up their bodies and listened intently to what the IPs had to say.
 
Kasamasa UP Chairperson Manuel also said that the 2018iskolar ng bayan2019 can somehow relate to some issues faced by the bakwits like that on the claim of lands.

201cThe lumads and the iskolar ng bayan have the same problem on land ownership issues,201d Manuel said referring to the UP campuses that are facing the same threat relating to land issues.

UP system student regent Miguel Enrico Pangalangan also said during the press conference at the evacuation center held on the same day that though the UP administration has no backbone in helping the scholars themselves they are still bringing the lumad issues to the UP officials and to the studentry that they may also open their eyes to these issues and take an active participation.

201cHindi langito share-share ng posts sa social media about lumads,201d Pangalangan said to the students, saying further that though they were able to have a heart-to-heart talk with the lumads and had spent a night and day with them, they are still not fully integrated with them.
As student leaders, what we wish to happen for the lumads is that more people will open their eyes to the real situation that the lumads are facing, we want to call the governments2019 attention regarding this so that they may be able to take actions through writing and other means they can come up with under their capacity.

The rest of the immersion of the students at the Haran evacuation center went on as they interact with the lumads, cook food and eat with them, do psychosocial activities with the lumad children and series of interviews with the adult men and women who had sought refuge in the compound.
  
A day and a night may have been a short period but the realizations and experience they had after the immersion was something they cannot just easily bury into oblivion.

As Manuel said, 201cIt2019s different when you hear the story directly from them.201d
I2019m semi-disconnected and it's quite OK, I2019m semi-disconnected and it's quite OKRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, I AM writing this while on a vacation trip in Batanes.

I consider this place to be the last frontier of the Philippines.
Our own version of Marlboro Country.
It2019s very idyllic, serene, laid-back, rustic, provincial, foreign.
It2019s out of the way.
It2019s far.
It2019s remote.
It2019s almost disconnected.
Almost.

But I2019m actually ambivalent about its connection or disconnection.
I2019ve been here a day already but I2019m not really missing the internet or cellular signal at all.
Which brings me to ask -- do we really need this kind of connectivity in the first place? Wouldn2019t this just be some ruse by companies so they can milk from us our hard earned money?
Anyway, back to my thought.
Ambivalent on Batanes2019 connection or disconnection.

When I was thinking about this, I imagined a Batanes that had one phone line housed at the post office perhaps.
There2019s only a handful of TV sets with no cable.
And most definitely, no cellular signal and no Internet.
It might actually be too extreme to imagine but if you look at it again, that2019s exactly how it was back then.
Don2019t you miss those days? I know I do.

If that was actually true, Batanes could actually be that final frontier.
It could actually be that place we go to escape the brouhaha of our technology-ridden cities and lives that we sometimes forget to stop and look down and appreciate a small, yellow flower by the side of the road.


You see, when I got off the plane after arriving in Basco, I checked for cell signal.
What did I get? EDGE.
When we got to the inn we2019re staying, there2019s WI-FI but it2019s erratic as some people2019s love lives.
When we all went out for our first tour , I knew right away that I won2019t be able to post nice photos along the way because signal was bad.
But there2019s the silver lining right there.
Because of this disconnection, I was able to focus more on taking photos.
I saw more of where we are.
Appreciated more what surrounded me.
I even had a selfie with a carabao.


My point here is that it2019s not bad to unplug.
Nobody will look for you, believe me.

Unless, of course, if you2019re unplugging for some nefarious reason.

I just want to leave a thought with you about our ultra-dependence on communication technologies -- cellphones, tablets, laptops, etc.
That this ultra-dependence can never be healthy for us, in the end.
That this ultra-dependence is making us miss out on more important matters in our lives.
That this ultra-dependence is blinding us from the beauty that surrounds us every day.

Technology is a tool.
Use it.
Don2019t let it use you.

Chocolate health guru    , Chocolate health guru    Karina V.
Canedo, FRANCIS Gonzales, manager of New Free Food Corporation producer of Coco Dolce chocolate and coconut sugar, was a meditation guru who hails from Manila who found his way here.
He said that he started seriously practicing meditation in the year 1987.

201cIt is the time during the 80s in Manila, there is so much frustration due to political turmoil, it is as if looking for a direction in life,201d Gonzales said.

He said as he was introduced in that philosophy that our identity as a spiritual being in a temporary body and learned that meditation was the process that will help you achieve that realization.

201cWhen I was introduced to that philosophy in meditation especially our identity, who we are, we are a spiritual being temporarily in this body and that process that will help you achieve that realization is meditation, an ancient transcendental yoga sound that you practice in a daily basis.
A year after, I volunteered to learn more and to teach other people that kind of practice,201d Gonzales said.
 
Francis Gonzales said that his meditation teachings took him to different avenues of development and allowed him to tread the path of other people2019s development.

201dThat time I was exposed in community development.
I started organizing in universities in Manila.
I was also able to stay in Cebu for three years, the same; and I was a volunteer for development in Iloilo and in Cavite, I transferred in Davao in 2007, the same, to share what I learned and it is very helpful to individuals,201d Gonzales added.

Gonzales said that the logical and very simple philosophy that is encapsulated in the meditation practice reinforced his way of dealing with other people so much.

201cThat is why I can actually go to different kinds of communities like Christian, non Christian, Indigenous Peoples  because the foundation is actually knowing they are who we are, that in fact you2019re spiritual.
 
Labels like Filipino, American, Muslims and Christians most are labels that you can change for that is not our eternal being that is just our temporary nature and understanding those is very important in developing communities,201d Gonzales said.

Gonzales said that when he was in Cebu he focused his community development goals in schools and in urban community and this goal, in helping develop communities led him to chocolate industry.

201c chocolate business is an attempt to help cacao farmers because we know farmers are working a lot but they earn too little,201d he said.
They buy beans at a premium price, he said, thus benefitting the farmers.
 Above that is the benefit to the consumers.
 
201cWe actually produce a healthy chocolate,201d Gonzales said.
He saw that doing business is a venue to help people.
201cYour fruits of labor in business can be spiritualized and can also be a form of meditation,201d Gonzales said.

201cWe believe kasi in cause and effect karma, whatever you did comes back to you and if you exploit people, their approach will be bad too.
If you help people, it will come back to you,201d Gonzales said.
 
Vegetarian for 30 years, Gonzales said they ensure that their chocolates are healthy by incorporating coco sugar and virgin coconut oil as the other ingredients in their chocolate products.

With the initial success of their product launch in 2014, he believes that satisfaction borne with is sourced from the people they2019ve helped with their product.

201cDoing your business while helping other people at the same time is already a success,201d Gonzales said adding that whether these people will succeed or not at least you gave them help while they needed it.

Gonzales as of the moment while concentrating as a manager of their chocolate business, he is also assisting cacao cooperatives and is hopeful to someday teach them  to produce not just cacao beans but also chocolates on their own because he believes that is one way that the farmers can really make increased profit out of their product.
 
Gonzales aims to ensure the quality of the products they produce but also the increased quality and sustainable lives of the farmers he2019s helping.
201cQuality is very important just like what we are doing in our business.
We are helping cooperatives also we don2019t have much resources but we have will help produce quality cacao products and quality and productive cooperative,201d Gonzales said.
To achieve quality life you must live simply but with higher thinking, Gonzales said.
 
He added that this quality life you must have awareness of yourself, understanding yourself, understanding the nature of the world and understanding other people and understanding your supreme being.
Gonzales said that his initial goal in life is the Love for God.

201cLahat ng undertaking, goals in life yun ang target, walang katapusan, yun ang wala tayo,201d he said.

He said that he is attaining this state through his practice of meditation yoga, and he is doing that 24 hours a day.
201cIt is not sitting down and closing your eyes, it is an active lifestyle, if we are talking about God, that is meditation and if you are doing business using money and teaching other people, that is also meditation, it could be meditation and it depends upon the purpose and intention,201d Gonzales said.

What dreams are made of, What dreams are made of
DAVAO.
Matanam  Jaime M.
Odo Sr.
presides over a meeting with the Apo Governance and Indigenous Leadership Acacemy  board of trustees and Bagobo-Tagabawa people in barangay Batasan, Makilala, North Cotabato.

Stella A.
Estremera, EVERYTHING started with one question.
201cWhy is it that there is a police academy for those wanting to join the police force, a military academy for soldiers, even a development academy for development workers, but no academy for indigenous leadership?201d 
This was the question raised by Fr.
Albert E.
Alejo SJ, who has been known to be working closely with indigenous peoples and Moro groups in Mindanao as he encouraged people who shared his sentiments to do something about it.
In an island of at least 13 indigenous peoples groups, this should be unthinkable.

The governance and leadership systems of the indigenous people are slowly being eroded amid a mainstreamed system of education and the penchant of the young to go with what is new and preference of not being associated with the old.
Put in investors lusting for their ancestral domains that, most of the time, are the last frontiers of the environment rich in natural resources, then there are even instances when indigenous leadership and governance are also corrupted.

In a prevailing system where traditional leadership and governance systems are left to die away, the indigenous peoples on which these systems thrive are likewise weakened.

201cWala 2018ta gihimo ni Manama para daog-daogon ,201d Fr.
Alejo told a group of people belonging to the Bagobo-Tagabawa tribe in barangay Batasan last week.
But, he said, it is up to the indigenous groups to protect their own people and ways.

201cKung dili ta mag-amping, daog-daogon gyud 2018ta ,201d he added.

Thus, a group of indigenous leaders and personalities who have interest in indigenous peoples development gathered to form the Apo Governance and Indigenous Leadership Academy  that has been provided an office space for free at the Ateneo de Davao University, and 200 hectares of the ancestral domain of the Bagobo-Tagabawa in barangays Buhay, Buena Vida, Batasan, and Biangan in Makilala, North Cotabato, that includes a huge waterfall on its northern tip, a small waterfalls and hot spring at its entrance area, and a medium-sized waterfalls a few hundred meters farther in.
First item in the agenda: Find supporters who can build the dreams of the tribes to have their own leadership academy to pass on to the young how different systems.

But before that, the group has to be accepted and welcomed into the communities that they intend to work with.

Thus, last January 13, the Agila board of trustees composed of its president businessman and Ateneo de Davao University board of trustees chair Benjamin A.
Lizada, vice president Bienvenido G.
Macalos, formerly of the Buhay, Buena Vida, Batasan, Biangan  people2019s organization; secretary Stella A.
Estremera of Sun.Star Davao; treasurer Atty.
Romeo T.
Cabarde Jr.
of ADDU, and trustees Fr.
Albert E.
Alejo SJ, former National Commission on Indigenous Peoples North Cotabato officer Jennifer Pia Sibug-Las, Jamie M.
Odo Sr., a matanam or datu of the Bagobo-Tagabawa, matanam Mercado P.
Padayag of barangay Biangan, president of the League of Indigenous People's Mandatory Representatives-Mindanao Inc.
 Robert R.
Simbahon, Ricardo A.
Palmitan of the Farmcoop, and Easterluna S.
Canoy, the executive director of the Kitanglad Integrated NGOs based in Bukidnon along with NGO workers, members of the academe, and the Development Academy of the Philippines  participated in a ritual of acceptance at the waterfalls within the 200-hectare lot.
 
Ritual of acceptance
The ritual beside the river where a table of offerings was set up was done by Agtugallan Ronel D.
Amoy, Agtugallan Manuel M.
Panggilan and Bae Analyn P.
Amoy.
Agtugallan is the title the Bagobo-Tagabawa use to address their baylans or shamans.
On the table covered with white cloth where seven pieces of boiled rice wrapped in leaves arranged in a circle.

Within the circle was a bowl also covered with white cloth that contained a knife, two betel nuts and a few leaves, and an egg.
During the ritual a black chicken was slaughtered and its blood was scattered around the ritual table, while a white chicken was held up amid some prayers uttered before it was thrown to the air, and set free.

Agtugallan Amoy later explained that they were praying to the higher spirits to accept the people who come to bring some benefits to the indigenous peoples.

The knife, he said, 201cis to clear away what separates the mortal from the spirit world.201d 
The betel nut represents relationship as it is the practice of the tribes to share some betel chews when they sit down to welcome visitors or settle some issues.
The egg represents care as rough handling of an egg can easily break it.
The white close represents the love shared between the mortal and the spiritual world.

Wish List
Soon after, the board of trustees sat down in a clearing beside the hot springs to listen to the people on what they wish the academy would have.
Top on the list is a training center.
This is also the priority of Agila.

But given that the academy should be able to sustain itself after initial assistance from willing donors, economic activities have to be introduced within the 200-hectare land that complies with the Bagobo-Tagabawa2019s Ancestral Domain Sustainable Development and Protection Plan  for their 2,973.10 hectares of ancestral domain at the foot of Mount Apo, within which is the 200 hectares granted the Agila.

The others in the list are a canopy walk with cottages for visitors, a 201ckan-anan201d or restaurant offering native delicacies and recipes, an organic farm and a facility for producing organic fertilizer, a research center, a resort, a wildlife sanctuary, a nursery for endemic species, a trading center, a ritual area, a livestock and livelihood center, solar power facility, water system, mineral water plant, a museum, a cultural center for performances, a multi-tribal village, an annual festival, indigenous sports facility, loom-weaving and handicrafts center, an entrance marker, a blacksmithery, a center to learn cultural dances, how play instruments, and chants, a meeting hall, a center for indigenous justice and conflict settlement, an indigenous wellness and health center, an orientation center, a waste management facility, and security facility.
It was clear that the residents and their leaders are expecting a lot, and need to do a lot as well.

Agila assistant director Jing Bantayan in his report to the community said that a roadshow for funders is being organized so that work on the training center can commence as soon as possible.

201cHopefully, karong tuiga, naay mahitabo na one to two buildings ,201d he said.

In the meantime, the people were reminded that there may be outsiders like some of the Agila BOT who are working to find funders, but the tribe itself has already contributed more than any funder can ever contribute, as they own the 200-hectare lot where the Agila will be built.

In the meantime, every one shares a common dream and are sharing this dream to others willing enough to listen and dream with them.

Space station astronauts grow first flower outside Earth, Space station astronauts grow first flower outside EarthWASHINGTON -- Astronauts aboard the International Space Station have successfully grown a flower to a full bloom for the first time outside our Earth.
Scott Kelly of the US space agency NASA tweeted this weekend that a zinnia has flowered in the microgravity environment of the orbiting laboratory, along with an accompanying photo of an orange flower with 13 petals.

First ever flower grown in space makes its debut! #SpaceFlower #zinnia #YearInSpace pic.twitter.com/2uGYvwtLKr
2014 Scott Kelly  January 16, 2016

"First ever flower grown in space makes its debut! #SpaceFlower #zinnia #YearInSpace," wrote Kelly, adding: "Yes, there are other life forms in space!"
A NASA article explained that zinnias were chosen not for their beauty but to "help scientists understand how plants flower and grow in microgravity."
Previously, other plants such as wheat and romaine lettuce have been grown in space.
When a batch of lettuce was harvested in August on the space station, NASA astronauts were even allowed to eat the fruits of their labor for the first time.

#SpaceFlower out in the sun for the first time! #YearInSpace pic.twitter.com/Cghu9XGv1J
2014 Scott Kelly  January 17, 2016

Growing zinnias seemed to post more challenges to in-orbit gardeners than growing a vegetative crop such as lettuce.
"The zinnia plant is very different from lettuce," said Trent Smith, NASA's Veggie project manager.
"It is more sensitive to environmental parameters and light characteristics.
It has a longer growth duration between 60 and 80 days.
Thus, it is a more difficult plant to grow."
Just more than two weeks into their growth period, astronauts noted that water was seeping out of some of the crop's leaves, a condition that occurs when a plant is experiencing high humidity.
To fix it, they adjusted the speed of the station's veggie facility fan from low to high to dry them out, but that didn't prevent two of the plants from dying.
The remaining two plants continued to thrive and one of them eventually blossomed into a flower this weekend.
More crops will be sent to the space station this year, including Chinese cabbage and romaine lettuce.
NASA said the lessons learned from these plants will help grow tomatoes in 2018.
The implications of plant life for space missions are very significant, including helping boosting astronauts' spirits while they're working there.
"Plants can indeed enhance long duration missions in isolated, confined and extreme environments -- environments that are artificial and deprived of nature," said Alexandra Whitmire, deputy scientist for the Behavioral Health and Performance element in the NASA Human Research Program.
"While not all crew members may enjoy taking care of plants, for many, having this option is beneficial."
In the long term, plant experiments will yield important information in preparation for a Mars mission.
"In future missions, the importance of plants will likely increase given the crews' limited connection to Earth," Whitmire said.
"Studies from other isolated and confined environments, such as Antarctic stations, demonstrate the importance of plants in confinement, and how much more salient fresh food becomes psychologically, when there is little stimuli around." 
Water is life and so our beautiful Lake Pinamaloy, Water is life and so our beautiful Lake Pinamaloy
CAGAYAN DE ORO.
Lake Pinamaloy is Don Carlos town2019s pride where anyone can enjoy this beautiful place and appreciate the wondrous works of God.

THERE are more things to talk about the booming town of Don Carlos, Bukidnon.
And its famous Lake Pinamaloy 2013 a 60-hectare inland body of water located right within the town proper2019s vicinity is definitely one of them.
To innocent children, the enchanted lake and its surroundings are like vast playground they could enjoy with so organic natural amenities that can be seen in fantasy movie like Alice in Wonderland.

To lovers, its lush green fields command serenity that2019s quite perfect for naughty rendezvous.
In fact, it2019s an ideal place for city-based writers as an alternative hideaway from the so-called life in the fast lane.
And for the serious types, understandably comprising just a fraction of this town2019s entire population.
Of course, it2019s a big deal for human survival being the community2019s main source of potable water.
     
The beautiful lake of Don Carlos, which is like a guitar-shaped from the aerial view, got its name from an old fable or fairy tale story shared to the new generation.
 
Legend has it that once upon a time in a plain and woody place in Bukidnon, there lived a couple who had no child.
They longed to have a child and so they prayed hard.
One day, there came an old woman.
She told them that they would soon have a child.
But the child must not step on the ground.
After several months, the wife delivered a lovely baby girl.
They named her Pina.
They gave her the abundance of life except for one thing.
She was not allowed to step on the ground.
But one day, Pina went down.
When she stepped on the land, it began to shake.
Pools of water came out and Pina disappeared.
Her parents tried to find her.
They kept on calling her name 2013 201cPina malooy ka201d 2013 a pitiful cry for Pina.
Now, the lake is called 201cPinamaloy.201d It is primarily the source of water in the municipality of Don Carlos.
It is also where some of the church activities are being held, like the Stations of the Cross during Lenten season, special wedding ceremonies and recollections.
Other occasions like batch parties during Christmas break, family bonding and dry picnic with friends and special someone are also happening here.
This place is also significant for most of the couples in Don Carlos.
It has been a part of their love story.
The serenity of the place helps each one appreciate God2019s creation especially human life.
As one of the tourist attractions in Bukidnon, the place is being developed by the municipality.
The tourism hall is aesthetically designed.
It is surrounded by different variety of flowering plants.
It2019s also the place where tree planting and tree growing activities are usually done.
It2019s a treasure that must be preserved and protected.
By not preserving, protecting and conserving Lake Pinamaloy, the whole community of Don Carlos will suffer.
Water is life.
It must be properly utilized and managed.
Managing our waste properly is the best way.
Water could easily be contaminated, thereby spreading various kinds of harmful diseases.
So let2019s be responsible for our waste.
Let2019s protect life and preserve our natural resources.
