Grow your own, never go hungry  , Grow your own, never go hungry  Kriztja Marae G.
Labrador, CONCEPTUALIZED beginning from a problem of living in a big city, this system running for years now has continued to empower households in the country.

Urban Container Gardening  by Perfecto 201cJojo201d Rom is a food-production system wherein small spaces in the urban centers are being maximized to serve as a nutrition garden of a household by recycling old containers and re-using bio-waste materials as fertilizers.
Rom is a graduate of Bachelor of Science in Agriculture Major in Crop Science from Xavier University-Ateneo de Cagayan.

Inspired by the hanging gardens of Babylon by King Nebuchadnezzar, Rom had conceptualized the system in 2002, a year after he graduated, but applied it on 2006 upon moving here in Davao City living in an apartment.

201cI started with one pot using my daughter2019s empty can of milk,201d he said, with the desire to provide fresh vegetables to his family which he eventually began teaching others and advocating for democratized agriculture.

In the UCG system, Rom also integrated a resource dynamic flow in the UCG system that facilitates including the wasted time of the family into something productive.

A recent progress on the system is the 2018bio-filtering2019 of water which is used in UCG Aquaponic System which for Jojo2019s home is now on its 5th year.
Through 2018bio-filtering2019 the stagnant water still remained fresh and is now used as drinking water for his 60 heads native chicken.

201cThe Nutrient Cycle and Water Conservation in the set-up are effective as it sustains the Crops and Chicken Above the experimental batch of Pangasius Fish underneath,201d Rom said.

The 60 Chicken are regularly fed with Black Soldier Fly Larva thus we reduced our expenses on feeds, they remain healthy despite incidences of 2018New Castles Diseases  and Avian Cholera around.
The hens continue to lay eggs and we collect an average of 5 eggs a day.
With UCG, Rom and his family can save up to 12,000 per month on the cost of food preparation.

For the UCG, one of his first projects was the Post-Ondoy Livelihood Rehabilitation Project in Banaba, San Mateo, Rizal wherein UCG was made not only to solve the problem of food stability in the household level but also solved the problem in the community level through the Social Enterprise Capital Augmentation Program .

Last year Rom conducted training to Yolanda Survivors in Biliran, Island Province of Biliran.
201cI want to encourage them to go for container gardening because in a matter of 30 days you will have food,201d he said.

Since then, Rom2019s UCG concept became known not only in the country but also by experts all around the world granting him more opportunities to share his advocacy.

201cI am a promoter of democratized agriculture through Urban Container Gardening technologies using the natural farming system, empowering households in reaching food security through participating in food production and ecological sanitation,201d he said.

Alternatives to rice   , Alternatives to rice   Rhealyn C.
Pojas, WHAT was often overlooked was actually the solution that is seen to cure the existing problem in our rice supply.
 
Who would have thought that a grass that grows uncultivated and harvested as material for necklaces and bracelets are actually staple crops that are now being considered by authorities as a promising cereal that is seen as an alternative to rice and corn? 
And who would have thought too that a mere fruit which is seldom heard by the Filipino masses is actually being considered by many countries as a solution to solve hunger? Rice supply deficit Being in a tropical country such as the Philippines, rice farmers will have to get through all the cost of damages brought about by inevitable typhoons or drought that often devastate the rice fields tilled by our farmers.
 
In fact, records from the Department of Agriculture Field Operations Division in Davao Region shows that our rice production in Davao suffered to 6,427.08 metric tons of damages caused by El Ni\xf1o and a total of 19,253 metric tons loss in production which is equivalent to a total value of P107,904,557.15.
  
This was the outcome of the reported El Ni\xf1o that started January until December 11 last year, according to DA Davao Agriculturist 2 Joedell Leliza who bared the data in an interview with Sun.Star Davao.
 
201cThere is a deficit in rice production because of El Ni\xf1o,201d Leliza said when asked what the main challenges are in rice production.

Given the 4,468,563 total number of population in Davao region according to the data from the Philippine Statistics Authority as of May 1, 2010 based on the 2010 Census of Population and Housing, to feed all the Filipinos remain a challenge with the current scenario that the country is in.

Adlay, the most promising cereal as alternative for rice In an effort to revive the foods used by our ancestors, the Department of Agriculture had conducted series of research and study that leads to the discovery of food items that can be used as alternative for rice.
One of the remarkable things that they had come up with was the discovery of Adlay, which, like the rice we are eating today, is a member of the family of grass along with wheat and corn.
  
According to Science Research Specialist 2 Merly Salaver of the DA-RFO Davao Research Division, Adlay was used by some Indigenous groups in Davao City as ornaments because it looked like beads but what they did not know was that in other parts of the country, some IPs used it as their alternative for rice.

DA Secretary Proceso Alcala directed the entire department to make a program about Adlay after he was intrigued that some IPs in Zamboanga Del Sur used the staple crop instead of rice and corn in one of his visits there, Salaver narrated.
Not all of its variety is edible though since others are hard-shelled which were used in ornamentations like necklace while the ones that can be eaten are soft-shelled.
Five varieties were used by the DA identified as Kiboa, Ginampay,Gulian, Dwarf and Tapol in the experiment and among these, the Kiboa variety performs better in terms of yield in both dry and wet season, according to Salaver.

201cIt is delicious and soft to eat unlike with corn rice which would end up hard after being cooked,201d Salaver said in the vernacular.

The good thing about this crop is that it is cheaper compared to rice and corn because it is only sold for P30 per kilo and it also takes longer time before it spoil after it is cooked compared to the other crops.
It is also a medicinal plant which has higher nutritive value compared to corn and rice, according to the result of the laboratory analysis done by the Crop Science Cluster-Institute of Plant breeding in the University of Philippines-Los Ba\xf1os, Food and Nutrition Research Institute chemical analysis and the FatSecret All Things Food and Diet.
 
Adlay was what our ancestors originally consumed for food but it is now being ignored by the people and this is why DA is trying to revive it.
Another advantage it has for the farmers is that by one plantation, they could make two harvests before they would clear the field again unlike with rice and corn where after the harvest, farmers will have to clear out the field and replant to have another harvest, Salaver explained.
It can also be made into several other products such as pop adlay, polvoron, and cookies among others.
Breadfruit, the superfood to counter hunger A fruit that is also a bread.
 
Breadfruit, according to an inventor who is the president of Davao Inventors Association, Inc.
 Virgilio Sangutan who had been studying the fruit for five years, is being used by around 90 countries all over the world to counter hunger.
It belongs to the family of jackfruits but tastes like camote and smells like bread when cooked.
What is fascinating about this fruit, according to Sangutan, is that it is the best type of fruit to grow in a tropical country where the problem of hunger is predominant.

Aside from it is resistant to drought because its roots penetrate deeply in the ground it is also not easily affected by flood because it is a big tree.
Pests also do not attack breadfruit because it has an enzyme that is resistant to it and it can bear good fruits even without using fertilizers.
It can bear fruits up until 50 years.

Sangutan explained that each breadfruit is equivalent to around 3 kilograms which can support five members of family in one meal.
 
It has higher content of protein compare to soya beans, high amino acids, higher potassium compared to banana, high fiber, and is rich in vitamins, according to Sangutan.

A hectare of breadfruit can produce up to 12 to 18 tons of fruits which, according to Sangutan is higher compare to palay production.

201cIf every barangay will devote at least 25 hectares of breadfruit plantation then it can solve every barangay2019s hunger,201d Sangutan said.

It can also be made into other food products such as bread, ice cream, and ice candy among others.
Breadfruit is also among those being studied by DA including No Adaptors   
Despite these findings and discovery about Adlay and Breadfruit, the challenge in providing food for the Filipinos remain since there are no adaptors to the idea and people lack the knowledge about these crops.

Salaver and Sangutan both expressed in separate interviews with Sun.Star Davao that there are still few adaptors and few people who are into the farming and production of the two fruits.
As for the Adlay, Salaver said that DA is giving seeds to farmers who will plant it and that there are only few adaptors to this while Sangutan also expressed that there are only few who focus on breadfruit the production.
 
Both Salaver and Sangutan expressed hope that the two fruits can help the country in countering the problem of rice supply and hunger.

An advocacy in a coffee shop   , An advocacy in a coffee shop   Karlo Paolo R.
Pates, IT IS not difficult for a business venture to immediately capture the hearts and attention of many especially if they are advocating for a special cause, and that cause is promoting the welfare and culture of the Indigenous Peoples  here in the country.
 
This was proven true by the advocacy campaign initiated by the Advocafe, a non-profit social enterprise that supports the cause and efforts of the IPs for a sustainable living.
 
Advocafe, taken from the root word 201cadvo201d which means advocacy, while cafe is an establishment which primarily serves hot coffee or other coffee related beverages, is owned by a non-government organization  Ilawan Center for Volunteerism and Leadership.
 
Contrary to the perceptions of many, Advocafe is definitely not just your ordinary coffee shop which you can easily find around the Metro as majority of the products being sold at the store are all natural and organic tea and coffee bean products were results of the hardwork and efforts of the lumads, IPs, and the Igorots from the respective communities all over the Philippines.
 
This was how Benjamin Abadiano, president and founder of Pamulaan Center for Indigenous People  Education and proprietor of the Advocafe formulated the idea of promoting and at the same time helping the cause of the IPs in the country.
 
"Nabuo ang aming layunin na magbigay ng opportunities to the katutubos at ng lumads na maimprove ang kanilang livelihood at maipromote din ang kanilang culture," Abadiano told Sun.Star Davao in a phone interview recently.
 
Before coming up with the Advocafe, Abadiano admitted they initially thought of establishing a marketing center where the products of the IPs are supposed to be displayed.
 
The plans, however, got scrapped after considering the idea of combining the coffee shop and marketing center them of venture in order to cater a wider scope of market.
   
That gave birth to the Advocafe business which initially opened its all of its first three branches in Luzon, particularly in Malate and Mendiola, which are in Manila; and another branch in Baguio City in the early 2000s.
 
Upon recognizing the steady growth of its first three branches, the Advocafe expanded its operations by opening two more branches but this time in Mindanao in 2010.

The fourth branch of Advocafe was opened inside the University of Southeastern Philippines -Mintal campus, located particularly at the Pamulaan Center for Indigenous Peoples Education while the fifth branch was also opened along the Quimpo Boulevard, both in Davao City.
 
201cAdvocafe is a social enterprise wherein our objection is to provide an avenue for the IPs to have a livelihood,201d Abadiano said.
  
Among the products offered at the Advocafe include chocolate cacao, turmeric granules, salabat tea, calamnsi juice, gumamela concentration, banana chips, carrot cakes, other organic pastries, and herbal tea.

These products came from the areas where there are communities of katutubos and lumads particularly in Zamboanga del Sur, Bukidnon, Cotabato, Compostela Valley, Datu Salumay, and Mountain Province.
 
All of these are products of years of research and experimentation just to ensure its quality and health benefits which can be bought at affordable prices compared to the mainstream coffee shops out there.
 Aside from the available beverages and pastries, there are also handicrafts including beadworks, papers, textiles, displayed at the caf\xe9 which the creative and artistic side of the IPs.
 
Abadiano said they have partnered with the Pamulaan Center for Indigenous People2019s  Education with the objective to create cultural appropriate pathways of training and formation for the IPs.
 
The partnership do not only focus to the IPs but also to the community leaders and development workers with their goal to provide graduates equipped with knowledge and abilities towards a sustainable development of the IP communities all over the country.
 
Even the people in-charge of running the operations of Advocafe are all fourth year IP students of the PCIPE.
 
The stint of the IP youth and students at the Advocafe also serves as their on the job training  and equivalent of a thesis output.

Abadiano, meanwhile, thanked the Peace and Equity Foundation for their support to their charity works even by just providing them a chunk of space along the Quimpo Boulevard for their branch.
 
Advocafe is just paying P1 per month of rental fee to the Peace and Equity Foundation.
 
In exchange, Abadiano stressed that 100% of Advocafe2019s net income are always donated to the IP communities.
 
201cAll the income we have from our operations are donated back to the IP communities in the form of basic services,201d Abadiano said who was the first Filipino to receive the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Emergent Leadership in 2004 for his commitment in doing charitable works for the IPs.
 
Among the basic services rendered to the IP communities include water, education, health, agriculture, and among others.
 
Other initiatives the group is also supporting the IPs in education for children and youth, Climate change adaptation, livelihood, and partnership and capability building.
 
201cTrainings on sustainable livelihood are also organized for the lumads, community leaders as well for them to be encouraged to start their own businesses,201d he added.
 
As of now, the Pamulaan Center for IP Education has more or less hundred scholars enrolled in different bachelors2019 degree.
      
Davao City to adapt Israeli greenhouse technology   , Davao City to adapt Israeli greenhouse technology   Ace June Rell S.
Perez, IN AGRICULTURE, input is planting, output is the produce, and the latter always is affected by the former.
 
Envisioning a bounty and abundant agricultural production, the city government is up for adapting a new technology developed by Israel dubbed as Israeli Greenhouse Technology that will further weigh our position as the 201cfood basket in the South201d.

Landing in the news last August 2015, the Israel Chamber of Commerce of the Philippines  and the City Government of Davao entered into an agreement for the utilization of the new technology presented by GurLavi, an Israel-based agriculture company.
201cThis developed innovative system like the Israeli agricultural greenhouse is designed for maximizing agricultural production with minimal expenses,201d Eyal Ben Ari, ICCP president and GurLavi chair said adding that they are willing to contribute to the Philippine agriculture progress through the introduction of a greenhouse technology.

Manny Pi\xf1ol, former North Cotabato governor and representative of Davao City Mayor, said that in a chamber meeting he presented to Israelis the great ironies of the Philippines.
 
201cWe are blessed with fertile soil, blessed with favorable climate for agriculture, blessed with water, and yet importing products like onions and garlic,201d Pinol said.

Ari said that as the city government is determined to adapt the technology, it is planned to be constructed in Mintal or Calinan, this city and will initially be planted with cucumber.
He also said that the facility is a 272 square meter  in area.
The facility costs $70 per sqm.

201cThe site is still up for confirmation.
Once realized, it will be the first in Mindanao.
At present it is already applied in San Pablo City and Tagaytay,201d Ari said.

The Israel Greenhouse Technology Greenhouse is a structure where plants, fruits, vegetables, flowers are grown attracting heat as the sun2019s electro-magnetic radiation warms the plants, soil and other component within the greenhouse.

The advanced greenhouse construction developed by Israel includes curtains, skylights, and shade netting, which moves automatically in reaction to sunlight.

It has a salient features including: a big internal space with good air circulation and ventilation, able to withstands winds up to 150 kilometer per hour, indoor drip irrigation system, aluminet shade installed outside and inside greenhouse, optinet providing protection against pests and diseases, and regulates growth of seedlings GurLavi agronomist Beatriz Cortes in a separate interview said that the new technology and facility has an innovative system on ventilation, circulation, light, humidity and temperature which are essential in climate control for better production.
The greenhouse structure has three different types, these are single , twin  and triple arch .

All types are seent to provide optimal growing conditions for plants.
In Boosting Production The gross production of a greenhouse in Israel is six times more than the gross production of an open field in the Philippines.

In a comparative analysis conducted by GurLavi, data showed that only 4,000 kilograms per year can be produced by the Philippine traditional agriculture in every 1,000 hectares .
While with the Israeli Greenhouse technology intervention it will reach up to 25,000 kilograms with the same land area of 1,000 has.

For decades, farmers are struggling with various internal and external factors making agricultural growth difficult 2013 weather, humidity, droughts, natural disasters, disease and various lesions that might harm crops.

201cAgricultural production is much destroyed due to 201cnon-development,201d decay, disease and other reasons.
This initiative is to allow farmers to increase their production crops, economic gains, and to reduce current expenditures of agricultural growth in order to develop optimum results,201d Ari said.
A box of hope, an infinite of kindness, A box of hope, an infinite of kindness
Contributed photo
IN THE Philippines, the city of Marikina alone produces one hundred and fifty million pairs of shoes every year.
That2019s one hundred and fifty million shoeboxes hoarded or turned to waste.
But what once was discarded has now been transformed into an instrument of hope.
For the past seven years, volunteers from integrated marketing agency TeamAsia, Information Technology and Business Process Association of the Philippines , as well as other industry partners came together to fill thousands of shoeboxes with school supplies for My Dream in a Shoebox Christmas campaign.
Each box is lovingly packed with two notebooks, one pen and pad paper, a box of crayons, an eraser, a ruler, and one bottle of glue.
It may not seem much, but for the parents of these children struggling to get by, supporting their child2019s future goes a long way.
The 2013 Functional, Literacy, Education, and Mass Media Survey  reported that 19.2 percent of the four million underprivileged children are unable to receive education due to poverty.
This translates to one in every 10 Filipino youth being out of school.
My Dream in a Shoebox desires to give these children universal access to education.
It is because of the aspiration to be part of the solution that organizers of My Dream in a Shoebox spend months meticulously planning a seamless initiative.
And after every successful campaign, the team sits down to evaluate what else can be done to make bigger dreams come true.
My Dream in a Shoebox Year 7 rallied together 57 organizations who as one industry gave over 45,000 shoeboxes to help bigger dreams come true.
201cAt the end of the day, it2019s not just about the number of shoeboxes or donations,201d says Bea Lim, Managing Director of TeamAsia.
201cIt2019s about the number of people who were inspired by it.201d she adds.
Over 45,000 shoebox donations meant thousands of emails sent to collaborate with benefactors.
It meant hundreds of phone calls spent coordinating with logistic suppliers and hundreds of volunteers painstakingly wrapping each box to make it more special.
Collecting shoebox donations to benefit children across the nation is just the first step of My Dream in a Shoebox.
The journey continued as organizers, donors, and volunteers hosted several gift-giving days.
Last December, children from Payatas Orione Foundation, Ascension of Our Lord Parish, SOS Children2019s Village Foundation, and Pedro Calungsod Parish enjoyed a day of fun and laughter with volunteers and organizers of My Dream in a Shoebox.
TeamAsia President Monette Hamlin also shared with these children the warmth of Christmas cheer through storytelling activities.
The joint effort of IBPAP and TeamAsia together with its partners National Book Store and Jones Lang LaSalle, along with industry partners have made My Dream in a Shoebox Year 7 a remarkable success.
IBPAP President Jomari Mercado says, 201cSeeing a smile light up on a child2019s face during the gift-giving celebrations make the countless of hours invested to put together My Dream in a Shoebox all worth it.201d
What are you going to do with a shoebox the next time you purchase a pair of shoes? Store it? Throw it? Or change someone2019s life with My Dream in a Shoebox?
Connect with Katrina Pimentel through +63 917 5079379 or email kepimentel@teamasia.com.
Be part of making #BiggerDreamsComeTrue.

Cacao is back; Davao Region rides the resurgence , Cacao is back; Davao Region rides the resurgence Ruji Peter S.
Abat, THE cacao industry in Davao Region has come a long way.
Back when cacao farmers were demoralized due to policy reforms, stumbling market prices, and economic crisis, the industry is now revitalized and it has been blossoming ever since.
The country as a whole was producing around 35,000 metric tons during the late 70's up to the mid 80's.
But due to the implementation of the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program , many big time cacao farmers were forced to relinquish portions of their farms to the farmers.

It then started a snowball which saw farms turning unproductive due to the mishandling of unskilled farmers.
Farmers back then were also forced to leave their cacaos since market prices were plummeting.
And adding to these problems, the demand for cacao was essentially low hence, farmers before were basically fighting a losing battle.
Cacao Industry Development Association of Mindanao Inc.
 executive director Valente Turtur described the early 90s as the dark age of the cacao industry in Davao Region since not only were the cacao farms left for dead, they were even cut down.
"The farmers just chose to leave the cacao industry because they can't expect any activity since the market prices were low and the demand has also low because of the economic crisis.
Basically, they just had to forget cacao," Turtur told Sun.Star Davao.
Revival of the Industry
Turtur said the country was already trying to put itself back in the global cacao industry picture in 2004 after it got help from the United States Agency for International Development  through its Success Alliance program.
Projects, however, were implemented in Luzon.
In 2007, Davao Region became part of the program but it was apparent that the program didn't sit well for the cacao industry in the region since its effects weren't felt that much and there was no take off in the industry.
Puentespina Farms and Chokolate de San Isidro, however, were already establishing their respective niche in the market being the only recognized cacao traders in the region.
Puentespina Farms made a partnership with Mars, Inc.
which led to the creation of the Mars Cocoa Development Center, a training center for cacao farmers.
Chokolate de San Isidro, meanwhile, was already mass producing chocolate tablets or tablea.
But in 2009, the US Department of Agriculture introduced the coconut, cocoa, palay  program and Davao Region became part of it.
The prices of cacao per kilo then went up to P80 hence, more and more farmers have grown their interest back in cacao.
The following year then became the advent of the revival of the cacao industry when Agricultural Cooperative Development International/Volunteers in Overseas Cooperative Assistance  conducted a cacao forum.
It was in that forum where farmers sparked an interest anew in cultivating cacao after Mars Inc.
declared that the demand has grown.
With a reinvigorated interest cacao, various stakeholders in the private sector gathered up and held a series of meetings to discuss how they could revive the industry.

By 2011, Cidami was established and they became the forerunners when it comes to empowering cacao farmers and traders in the region.
In the following year, the cacao industry earned the support of the government as the Department of Agriculture  provided funds and seedlings, the Department of Trade and Industry  helped out in organizing forums while the Department of Environment and Natural Resources  included cacao in the National Greening Program.
The production of cacao in Davao Region from 2011 to the current year has then grown significantly as Turtur said, "Our production has more than doubled in the span of five years.
In 2011, we were producing around 5,000 metric tons.
But in 2015 we produced more than 12,000 metric tons."
Best Practices
The boom of the cacao industry in the span of five years can be attributed to the best practices that the cacao farmers have undergone.
In the farming aspect, Turtur said that the bread and butter in maintaining the quality of the cacao fruits has always been pruning and putting sleeves on the cacao fruits or pods as what the farmers call them.
This method, Turtur said, is called pod-sleeving.
Turtur said pruning refers to the trimming of unnecessary branches on the cacao trees.
This technique is effective for pest control, disease prevention and nutrient absorption on the cacao plants.
With the use of pruning, cacao farmers can control pests like pod burrowers since these pests thrive on gloomy environments.

Turtur also said that cutting off the unnecessary branches allows more sunlight to bring heat to the trees which will in turn thwart the development of fungal infections such us pod rot.
He added if you leave these unnecessary branches the tendency is these branches will absorb the nutrients instead of those productive branches.
Yet there are simply instances when diseases and infestations can't be averted.
This is when pod-sleeving comes in handy since sealing the pods with plastic or paper can prevent pod burrowers and pod rot from destroying fruit.
A well-timed schedule for the application of fungicides and pesticides is also a must since trees may become more vulnerable to diseases if these chemicals are abused.
Turtur also suggested that farmers should utilize service alleys for better farm mobility and trash alleys from where decomposable wastes could be thrown away until it becomes a fertilizer.
He also said that while organic fertilizers are good, applying synthetic fertilizers can still play a huge part in providing nutrients to the plant.
As for the business aspect, Turtur said farmers should also think like entrepreneurs or what he refers to as "agropreneurs." In a bid to help farmers become more well-versed in the business aspect of cacao farming, Turtur urged them to attend investment forums which they organize in partnership with DA and DTI.
Suggested Reforms
Sharing his concern over how the support from the government has been delivered, Turtur said that DA should be more holistic in its approach citing that in some instances, there are programs where the agency merely gives free cacao seedlings to farmers, who are mostly lacking in management skills.
He said that, that if DA can't provide the technical skills and management training, at least they could coordinate with Cidamiso that they would be the one conducting the training.
Furthermore, the El Nino phenomenon has significantly affected the production of cacao for the past months.
Hence, he urged DA to pour in more funds for the construction of water irrigation systems instead of giving out free seedlings.
Lastly, an organized monitoring system on the progress of farms as well as the market prices should be established so that farmers will have some sort of quota to target.
Turtur said that during the first cacao forum in the region back in 2010, Mars, Inc.
declared the world will have a one-million metric ton deficit by 2020 and the Philippines should have produced around 100,000 metric tons by then.
Yet in the pace that the cacao industry in Davao Region has been currently moving, the cacao players here are optimistic that they can cope up with the demand.
And it's not just about meeting the demand.
Most importantly, the cacao industry aims to alleviate poverty among the farmers while improving the economic status of the region.
 
The dreaded disease is back   , The dreaded disease is back   Christine Joice C.
Cudis, PANAMA disease or fusarium wilt, the "most dreaded" disease in the banana industry, which wiped out the whole Gros Michel cultivar in the 1960,s is spreading again, infesting the major source of livelihood of most people from the Davao region.

Banana growers and exporters are already losing thousand bananas in their plantations and millions in their pockets as they remain unaware of the solution to stop the further damage it causes.
 Worst, workers are not keen on following basic procedures to stem the spread.
 
Dr.
Harry Rajamannan of the Agro-K Philippines, who has spent 45 years in Banana research and is considered as among the great minds in discovering the answers to problems in the field of agriculture shares his knowledge on the matter.
 
"The laborers fail to prevent the spread of this disease.
They walk through the hot spot areas to collect fruits, walking through the infected area to the clean soil.
It is the main distributor of this disease," he explained.
 
He added that he and his group has seen the laborers taking the stems of the banana fruits from the packing plant and leave it in clean areas to rot, not realizing that the stems from harvested in disease areas are also taking this fungus to infect non-infected plants.
 
The key to avert the further spreading of the disease is, according to him, teaching the laborers on proper bio-security protocols.
 
He added that in other countries  where the presence of the fungus is also alarming, strict practice of security is imposed.
No one can pass through their plantation especially if one has been to a land with reported cases of Fusarium wilt.
 
For now, Agro-K Philippines is developing a vaccine to be injected with the surrounding plant from the infected ones.
It should prevent the banana from acquiring the disease.
They are now providing these vaccines as samples to farmers who were devastated by the effects of the disease.
 
In another interview with the Department of Agriculture  Davao Plant Pathologist Arlene Seguiro, she said that they offer the farmers whose plantations were infected with the disease several options to aid in their situation.
 
Among these was cordoning the portion of the banana plantation infested with the wilt, then, precede on stand-burning the infected ones to ashes where they pay the farmers P500 per mat as incentive fee.
 
201cWe do this, so we can kill the fungus while it is still on its underdeveloped stage,201d she explained.
 
The worst that this disease can lead to is the production of chlamydosphores or resting spores.
It is the stage of the fungus where it has developed full resistance from any counter poison and will survive in the soil for decades.
  
As assistance to the farmers, DA Davao is also providing Trichodermaharzianum, a kind of fungus which is also used as a fungicide; it has an antagonistic capability against the disease.
It will be injected to the follower of the infected plant to prevent further development of the fungus.
 
Giant Cavendish tissue-cultured  banana is also slowly being introduced in the market as it is deemed as the new resistant variety to Panama disease Race 4.
With deformed fingers, and less hands, it is inferior to Cavendish.
Just like how Cavendish was inferior to Gros Michel before.
 
Although pesticide can protect bananas from infection, the chemicals will contaminate the water and soil in the long run.
  
Genetic research may re-engineer the Cavendish to resist this particular disease but again, we would have to come up with a new genetic solution for every future disease which is just another short-term solution.
 
Variety in the ecosystem is needed.
If we form our variety of bananas, their unique growing patterns, shapes, and imperfections emerge naturally.
This variation exists to protect the specie.

If this is pushed, we would not have to worry much if one genetic specimen catches the disease because by then we are not that reliant on one species alone.
Facebook celebrating its users' friendships for its birthday, Facebook celebrating its users' friendships for its birthday
In this Dec.
13, 2011 file photo, a sign with Facebook's "Like" logo is posted at Facebook headquarters near the office for the company's User Operations Safety Team in Menlo Park, California.
 
SAN FRANCISCO -- Facebook is giving friendship collages to its 1.6 billion users in celebration of the social network's 12th birthday.
The collages will be packaged in video presentations of photos of friends and family that have been previously been posted on Facebook.
The photos are picked out by automated technology, although each Facebook user will be able to delete some and select other pictures instead.
The videos won't be seen by anyone else unless a user decides to share the presentation.
Most Facebook users should start seeing the videos at the top of their Facebook feeds by noon Thursday, which the Menlo Park, California, company is hailing as "Friends Day."
It coincides with the 12th anniversary of Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg starting the social network in his Harvard University dorm room.

NEW YORK 2014 Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey said Saturday the social media website's stream of tweets will stay live and in real time, disputing a media report that a change was in the works.
News and entertainment site BuzzFeed reported on Friday that Twitter was going to introduce a timeline based on an algorithm rather than a real-time stream.

Masbad: Open season for story telling, Masbad: Open season for story tellingRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, TOWARD the end of the previous month, an article from Artsy describing photojournalists moving toward ditching their dSLR cameras and shooting more with their smartphones.
I2019m not really surprised with this considering that mobile photography has been on the rise ever since the birth of smartphones and mobile connectivity.
That and coupled with the fact that media consumption by the audience is ravenous, to say the least.

I2019ve noticed lately that today2019s news and media consumers have very short attention spans and they couldn2019t care less about reading a very well-written article.
In fact, one can see this phenomenon happening on your very own Facebook timeline.
I have a hunch that more often than not, you2019ll notice a lot of people reacting with comments and tirades right away about some article that was posted with only the title to go with.
It2019s almost like a shoot-now-ask-questions-later attitude.
I2019ve seen it happen on my timeline.

So, going back.
Photojournos posting more on their Instagram accounts.
This basically means, they shoot more with their mobile devices.
Okay, fine, they2019ve become quicker in posting almost-real-time photos on their social media feeds.
Personally, I actually like that better.
I get an almost-real-time look at what2019s happening at pretty much any event happening around the world.
All you gotta do is follow the right photojournos and there you are.

In relation to this, hashtags come to mind as well.
It2019s everywhere.
In fact, everyone pretty much comes up with hashtags for whatever they post online.
I even have my own hashtag for whenever I am travelling or for whenever I cooked - #byahengwacky and #lutongwacky, respectively.
Hashtags make it easier to track down photos of events relevant to you.
In some ways, everyone has become a sort of photojournalist because of the ubiquity of smartphones and mobile internet.
We journalize our own personal exploits and publish it on a platform somewhere - Facebook, Instagram, Blogspot, Wordpress, Twitter.
New media as they say.
I rightly agree with it as well.

It2019s a double-edged sword though.
It can cut both ways.
One way is what I was just referring to - the almost-real-time publishing of photographic records of what2019s happening in whatever part of the world.
The other way is the almost rampant publishing of photos that may actually be not related to a particular event; just something thrown in to the mix.

However it may cut though, my take here is that the photojournalists of today have a better platform to share their stories.
Whether you2019re an old-timer or a new-comer, the digital platform is there for you to take advantage of so you can tell your stories however you see fit.

It2019s open season for story telling through photographs.

Glorious, ain2019t it?
The 3D Torogan goes mainstream  , The 3D Torogan goes mainstream  
DAVAO.
Architect Gloryrose Dy-Metilla assembles a prototype of the Balay-Balay Ta Torogan Royal House 3D puzzle, which are now available on a limited release, during last Tuesday2019s Arttalk, a monthly arts and culture press conference.

Stella A.
Estremera, THE Balay-Balay 3D architecture puzzle of a Torogan, the Maranao2019s royal house, produced by SwitoDesigns Studio of young architects Gloryrose Dy-Metilla and Glorypearl Dy last year, is now being offered for pre-ordering until February 14.

The Torogan is the ancestral house of Maranao royalty most identifiable by its panolong or beam-ends with intricately carved floral and naga or the fern-like sacred snakesokir designs.
The Torogan Balay-Balay is handmade by artisans and artists in Mintal, Davao City, and is made up of pieces and measures 9.5201d x 11.5201d.

It is available until February 14 on a limited first release of just 50 pieces for P3,500 .
It is a 1:100 scale model of a torogan based on the published studies of the late Maranao scholar Dr.
Abdullah T.
Madale, and the architecture thesis of Henna S.
Dazo, who graduated from BS Architecture at the University of the Philippines-Mindanao.

Showing the interlocked foundation of the torogan during last week2019s Arttalk, Dy-Metilla said that it is in fact built to withstand forces of nature.

The interlocked wood and elevated piles rest on top of round boulders, which is actually an ancient version of what is now known as seismic isolation structure that is used to make tall buildings earthquake-resilient.
.

Every post of a torogan has five to six of these boulders of different sizes and the biggest torogan is known to have 56 posts.
201cEven before the Spaniards came, our building already had rollers parakung may earthquake, it will just roll,201d Dy-Metilla explained, 201cmuch like modern high-rise buildings now.201d 
In Madale2019s book, 201cThe Maranaw Torogan201d, he quoted Dr.
Jesus Peralta of the National Museum in explaining about the floating foundation of the royal house.
"he floating supports are intentionally done also because the Lanao Region land is tectonically unstable, that often, it is visited by earthquakes.
The boulders serve as protection when earthquakes strike.
The entire torogan will just roll and sway and left undamaged after the tremors," the book read.

Aside from making the structure earthquake-resilient, the floating foundation also makes it withstand very strong winds.
It is also elevated from the ground  by as high as 2.21 meters, equivalent to one standard floor height, allowing it to withstand flood and wood decay.

The panolongs, which is the distinct mark of a torogan, symbolize power, rank, and leadership.
 
"Except for the front, side, and back posts, all the other posts supporting a torogan extend only up to the floor jousts.
Another set of posts are used on the first floor.
Even the roof has its own set of posts which are usually smaller, slimmer, and intricately carved.
The rampatan or center rood beam is called a tinai a walai, intestive of the house.
It is intricately carved with the front end carved into a prow and the end carved into the shape of twin fish fins,201d Madale2019s book reads.

The ground floor is used as storage or display area, and also as living quarters of servants or the orobarang.
It is also where the brass cannons or lantakas are kept.

In some cases, this is also used as living quarters of families who cannot be accommodated in the main frloot, but this has a stigma or being of low status and the community looked down on families who lived under the house.
They even have a word for those living under the torogan: mananagawalay.
The main floor accommodates the whole clan of the Sultan.
During Muslim holidays, the torogan is the venue for the community feast.

As Madale wrote, in Maranaw society, all cultural activities in the community emanate from the torogan where the sultan holds court.
Those interested to get one of the 50 first release Torogan 3D puzzles can send their orders through here 
The puzzles will start being shipped out by last week of February.
 
The Balay-balay Torogan 3D architecture puzzle, first produced with a grant from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts  last year, was introduced last year in a series of exhibits that included a playtime with children and an okir workshop by visual artist and scholar Al Nezzar Ali in Abreeza Mall and a tour covering Manila, Cagayan de Oro, and Marawi.

It was produced with the aim of helping children aged 6-12 appreciate traditional architecture and become well-versed with the Mindanao designs beyond just the ubiquitous bahaykubo.

What sets aside Balay-Balay Torogan puzzle from other 3D puzzles available in toyshops and department stores is that it comes with a literature on what the pieces and the design is all about.

With the first release about to be done, Dy-Metilla said they are now working on the prototype of the Obo Manobo house and also the Balangay of Butuan City.

Valentine's Day tips  , Valentine's Day tips  Rhealyn C.
Pojas, ROSE are red, violets are blue and guess what?!
It is heart's day again and you must be in a dilemma whether what to give your special someone this fourteenth day of February!
Presents and presence
While chocolates and flowers may sound a clich\xe9, nothing still beats that classic feeling of receiving gifts the vintage way.
In this era where people tend to choose what is readily made or available in the market, an effort to find something out of the piles of instant things is a worthy gift for keeps.
You may consider scribbling some letters too, expressing your feelings in the sincerest way.
Admit it, not everyone does that anymore.
Now, does that sound romantic? 
But what is the best gift for some may not be the best gift for others so try to do a little contemplation or discerning over what your partner loves to do.
If he is a man, is he adventurous or sporty or a bookworm? 
If she is a woman, does she like movies, taking pictures, travelling, or a techie? You can have a list of questions going on in your mind and come up with the most brilliant gift you could ever give.
On top of all your gift list for this Valentine's Day is, of course, your presence.
Material things will not suffice if you will end up having not the slightest time spent for your special someone.
Common knowledge dictates that presence is more appreciated than presents.

Go places
If you happened to be an employee or a self-employed person who is busy doing your business then the 14th must be the best time to lighten up some work load and spend some quality time with your friends or lovers or whoever it is you are planning to spend your Valentine's Day with.
It could be a place to hang out and catch up with friends and lovers in a restaurant or a solemn place where you could let your thoughts wander off freely.

You might consider having a fine dinner together at your favorite restaurant in the city or prefer a more solemn place by the beach, particularly in your favorite resort somewhere in the island of Samal if you are in Davao City.
A get-away every once in a while surely will not hurt your pocket.
Love, now and everyday
All efforts would appear futile though if you lack this one thing which must be on the priority list: love.
You should not only love on February 14 because every day must be the season of love.
As the famous verse in the bible states:
Love is patient, love is kind.
It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud.
It does not dishonor others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs.
Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth.
- 1 Corinthians 13:4-7

Dos and dont's on a first date , Dos and dont's on a first date Karlo Paolo R.
Pates, IT'S love month once again and it's that time of the year where colorful displays of red roses and oversized stuffed toys, and heart-shaped decorations are seen everywhere.

It's also that time of the year where couples are planning and deciding where to go a date for the Valentine's day.
For long-time lovers who have been together for several years, it would be easier and comfortable for them as they have grown accustomed to dating having done this several times in their relationships.
But for those who are not yet in the status of "in a relationship," the dating part usually happens during the courtship stage wherein two persons are still on the getting to know each other stage.
Dating is the time that you can actually build a strong chemistry with your soon-to-be partner or lover.
That's why for the first timers or beginners in dating, here are some tips on the do's and don't things that you should or shouldn't do during your official dates.
All of these are based on the inputs shared by some of my close friends.
Wearing comfortable dress or clothes would be a good idea to start a date.
Choosing a place for your date also depends on the type of person you are with.
If he or she is into food then you can go with a budget-friendly restaurant but if you date prefers scenic views and spots then you should bring her to a place that does not only have food but also romantic views such as sea-side or hill-side restaurants.

Don'ts:
Bad Attitude
Do not reveal any negative attitude towards your date.
Being rude towards your partner could possibly turn the soon-to-be romantic story into a fantasy.
It could also end any chance of scoring another date.

Don't talk about the past
It's a big no-no for the two of you to bring back the wrongs of past relationships as it could possibly affect the mood of your date.
The idea of you going in a date is for you and your soon to be partner to move forward and not back.
Don't be too hard on yourself
Talking about how miserable and lonely you are is a big sign turn-off during a date.
It is possible to share these feelings only to a therapist and a trusted friend and not to your date.
It could reflect how desperate you are in looking for a relationship even if you are not ready yet.
Dos
Valentine's date jitters are inevitable and in order to get rid of these, you need to phone a close friend/s or family to get some words encouragement before you meet date.
As they say it's an effective way to prepare yourself before the big date.
Be real
Try to make the conversation between the two of you pleasant and positive.
You don't need to talk about about serious stuff but you can also ask him or her about hobbies and passions.
But it still depends on the interest of the person you are dating with.

Don't try to be anything.
Just be yourself.
That's the important thing.

Be optimistic
Display positive body language in order for your date or partner to realize how entertaining and comfortable to be with.
Make sure to make eye contact and listen to your date.
But it is easier for one to do these things if you really like him or her.
It's easier to score a second date if both of you feel that spark.
But if you're really interested in a second date, then don't be shy to ask for it.

What love knows...
, What love knows...
Ivy C.
Tejano, "Love knows no limit to its endurance, no end to its trust, no fading of its hope; it can outlast anything.
It is, in fact, the one thing that still stands when all else has fallen." - 1 Corinthians 13:7-10
LOVE has no labels and no flaws.
Love exists, regardless of our opinions about what it should be.
It is an unwavering concern for the well- being of the other despite his or her imperfections.
Love knows:
No boundaries
Rossel Diva and Alberto Espejo has been a couple for more than a year now.
But most of the time, the two cannot be seen together, as Espejo had to work abroad, while Diva have to work here and take care of their child named Behati.
"Being in a long distance relationship is not simple.
But as long as both of you remains faithful to each other, you can never go wrong.
Well, constant communication is really important aside from just trusting each other," Diva said.
To have a healthy relationship, Espejo said, the couple needs to communicate to each other, learn to listen and listen with undivided attention, understand, and forgive the imperfections.
No culture
Lorna Hanginon and Genevec Palma Gil Burgos were lovers for seven years before they got married for almost a year now.
Despite having different culture, Lorna is Visayan while Genevec, who also belongs to another tribe, their love binds them.
 
"We do have a lot of differences.
He is quiet while I am too loud.
He is organized while I am the opposite.
Differences have never been an issue to us, in fact, we love our differences.
We learned from it," Lorna said.
No religion
Donna Joy Intia and Mohammad Shafiuq Bin Abdullah have been bestfriends for about four years already.
Intia met Abdullah when he went for a tour in Malaysia sometime in March 2012.
Intia said even after she returned home in August 2012, their communication was constant.
She added that even if she is a Catholic and her friend is a Muslim that does not stop them from being friends.
"To respect other people's religious beliefs is already a form of love," Intia said.
No age
Nida Corpin and Ricky Deque\xf1a have been a couple for more than 10 years.
Corpin, who is 48, is 11 years older than her partner Deque\xa4a, 37.
Corpin met Deque\xf1a through her uncle.
"We started as friends until we reached to the point that what we have is more than just friends.
He courted me for a month before I answered him, yes.
Despite the significant age gap, we are still together," Corpin said.
There are flaws and disagreements, Corpin said, but these never become reasons for them to give up, instead, these give them room to improve as individuals and as a couple.
No gender
According to them, sexual orientation is not a choice.
People may have different sexual orientations but that does not make them any different from the others.
Love is celebrated and not judged.
Che Palicte and Hezel Estorpehave been a couple for six years now, and despite all the challenges they went through, the two remains to be happy and contented with each other.
"Love is someone who can stand by your side no matter who you are and no matter what happens.
We reached this far because we have so much respect to each other and we value one another despite our differences," Palicte said.
Herve Guy Abellano echoed the same outlook about love.
Abellano and his boyfriend only named as Jhysn have been together for two months now, and they are both happily in love, he said.
"Others are entitled to their own opinion.
But as long as we are not hurting anyone, we can never go wrong.
We are two months and counting more and just like other people, we are entitled to love and be loved," Abellano said.
There is no formula in love.
Being complex in so many ways, love sure makes the world go round.

Jive Highland Resort
Just an hour and 45 minutes away from the city, lovers can disconnect from the hustle and bustle of the busy city and reconnect with nature.

Jack's Ridge
In making promises sealed with faith and commitment, couples resort to love locks.
A love lock is a padlock which lovers write their names or initials on, fasten to a public fixture like a bridge or fence and throw away its key to symbolize a strong and lasting love.
Love locks have been appearing in various locations worldwide including Baclaran Church and the most famous lovelocks sites at Pont des Arts Bridge in Paris.
In Davao City, lovers can lock their relationship and say "there is forever" in Davao Jack's Ridge, Shrine Hills, Matina.
As Jack's Ridge had witnessed too many love declaration and marriage proposal, it hopes to carry on the tradition and encourage sweethearts to seal their love at the Lover's Rail.
Love Locks at Jack's Ridge are available for sale at Taklobo Restaurant, Karlo's Coffee Shop and Kais Bar Cashier's counter.
Vista View Hilltop
If you plan to share love moments with a fine panoramic view overlooking the city and serene and relaxing feeling, have a date and dine at Vista View Hilltop Barangay Langub.
The place has a romantic ambiance, especially when you view the city lights from the top.
It is an inexpensive place to bring your special someone.
La Isla Bonita
If you are planning to seclude yourself and your partner in an island, La Isla Bonita in Talikud island is the perfect place to be.
La Isla Bonita Beach Resort is a 160- meter of white sand beach and clear turquoise waters.

There are more to celebrating this red date than the usual movie and picnic dates, travel with your love and make good and romantic memories that will turn forgetting an impossible thing.

An OFW story , An OFW story Ivy C.
Tejano, 201cIT TAKES nerves of steel and the muscle to work abroad.201d 
This is how 63-year-old Judith Gonzales Reyes described her experience as an overseas Filipino worker .

Reyes has been a skilled worker in Kuwait, an Arab country on the Persian Gulf, for 12 years.
She decided to land a job abroad at the age 38 to provide a better future for her family.

The hardest battle of an OFW mother is knowing that you cannot take care of your own children and enjoy the company of the family for years on end.
It was on 1999 when Reyes left the Philippines for Kuwait.

She said she can still recall the emotion she had when she left her children, her husband and parents.

201cThe life of the OFW is not easy.
If only we can earn big in the Philippines to sustain the needs of our family, we would not have gone this far.
Kaya kahit gaano pa kapagod at lungkot, kakayanin mo alang-alang sa pamilya mo,201d Reyes said.

Reyes worked as a tailor.
Her work started at 10 a.m.
and ended at 10 p.m.
but there were times, the work extended at 11 p.m.
because of the employer2019s demand.

201cOkay naman kasi kumikita naman ako ng maayos.
Yung sahod namin na sa 300-riyal equivalent to P3,000 noong araw.
Nakakapadala na ako ng pera sa pamilya ko para sa pangangailangan nila,201d she said.

Never did she imagine that things would go wrong.
Her employer stopped paying their wages and she even got jailed for about five months because she could not renew her residence certificate, which is the company2019s responsibility to their workers.

201cYes, I was emotionally and financially abused.
Ni hindi ako nakapadala for my family.
When I went out from jail, our employer was even demanding 300 riyals from us claiming this as our monthly rental for our visa,201d Reyes said.
 
201cTiniis ko yun hanggang sa dumating yung araw na pinalitan na yung employer namin.
I am so grateful to God na wala na ang dating employer namin.
The workers were already paid until such time I decided to return home,201d she added.

Reyes went back to Davao City in 2011 for good.
She said she continued as tailor in her own shop, and now she has her own helpers.
Reyes is a purok leader, too, in Ulas from 2013 up to this present.

At her age, Reyes said, she is already happy and contented with her life.

She was also proud to say that her four children already completed their college degrees.

Beach wedding for Bajau couples in time of Valentine's day , Beach wedding for Bajau couples in time of Valentine's day 
 CAGAYAN DE ORO.
A bride performs a bridal dance as other people place peso bills between the bride2019s finger as part of the traditional Badjau wedding rite during the Bajau mass wedding at a beach resort in Barangay Bayabas, February 13, 2016.
  
Pamela Jay F.
Orias, AFTER more than five years of living together out of marriage, couple Sorayma and Arman Aralmani finally tied the knot together with 15 other Bajau couples in a mass wedding celebrated by an Imam at a beach resort in Barangay Bayabas, Cagayan de Oro City.

The Aralmani couple who lives at Saint John in Barangay Puntod has been helped by the city government to make their union official.
Sorayma, 25, shared how hard it was for her to live with a man whom she hardly knew since Sorayma and Arman went through an 2018arrange union.2019
"Sa sulod sa walo ka bulan, wala gyud ko nahigugma ana niya, hangtud nakita nako unsa siya makapasalig sa tanang trabahoon ug unsa iyang pagmahal sa among unang anak didto na dayon ko naka-feel ug gugma ," Sorayma said in an interview.
Sorayma, close to tears, shared how thankful she was as the City Government shouldered the expenses to make their wedding possible.
She had since been dreaming of their wedding day, which for her makes their union strong and unbreakable.
"Lahi ra man kung kasal gyud mo, kay kung wala gani, murag sama ra mo sa mga hayop.
Ug kung wala moy kasal, ang inyong anak sama ra pud sa hayop ," Sorayma said.
"Daku gyud among pasalamat, nga bisan kami pobre, unya ubos pa gyud ang pagtan-aw sa amo sa mga tao kay kami Bajau, gipahalagahan gihapon mi nila  give us importance)," she added.
Officiated by an Imam, the wedding rites started with the Bajau traditional dance performed by both men and women followed by the unique wedding ritual.
During the ceremony, the man, assisted by the Imam, searched for his pair among the women in the line.
Once the man found his pair, he would then place his thumb in her forehead to signify 'belongingness' or 'oneness' of the couple.
After that, they shared their 'bangkete sa kasal'  prepared by the city government together with the sponsors.
Dr.
Merle Adaza of the City Social Welfare and Development  said it is the first time in the history of Cagayan de Oro.
"Karon pa gyud na sa history sa syudad na gihatag bili ang mga Bajau.
Karun ra pud na hatagan sila ug luna o lugar na matawag nila ug ila ," Adaza said.
Adaza was referring to the coming relocation wherein about 500 Bajau individuals from Barangay Puntod will be transferred to their new abode in Barangay Bayabas.
"This symbolizes new beginning, new hope, a new start for them," Adaza added.

Photo by Robert Z.
Cortes
Robert Z.
Cortes, ONCE a year, for the last 30 years, I have had the good fortune of attending a spiritual retreat.
A traditional annual practice of piety highly recommended for every Christian, good retreats help those who make them replenish their spiritual -- at times, even physical -- strength, as they reflect on the eternal truths and see life in its proper perspective.
Oftentimes, it's not a matter of discovering new things, but of seeing old ideas in a new light.
This year, for example, one of the main insights I received was this: belonging to the Church is both blessing and responsibility.
Old message, I know, even hackneyed.
Yet it came in the fresh, new form of "mercy," in circumstances that can only be described as "dramatic," and suddenly, everything was totally "new."
The time and venue of the retreat surely had something to do with it.
Just in time for Lent, my retreat was held in a quaint, little Italian town north of Rome called San Felice d'Ocre.
It's a beautiful place where tall and erect pine trees surround the retreat house, and from which one sees a majestic range of mountains partly covered with snow.
It was then early February, but it seemed that winter had left, the first two days being quite sunny and pleasantly cool.
But in the morning of the third day, I woke up with my room much colder.
In fact, I desisted from opening the bedroom window.
On my way to the chapel, looking out the corridor windows, I saw that it was snowing.
But it wasn't the snowfall of anyone's dreams, unless one refers to a nightmare.
It's not one of those that end up in a soft white mound from which one would make a jolly Frosty, the Snowman.
Instead, this was a swirling confusion that looked like it was belched by the gray, angry-looking clouds above.
Or the leavings of a tepid, indecisive winter that was rushing to the bathroom on its way out, but didn't quite make it.
What ended up on the red concrete was messy slush, the perfect representation of everything that was outside that morning: cold, wet, and gloomy.
"How different it is inside," I thought, as I entered the chapel.
The low, curved ceiling that smoothly made its way down and eventually became the wall made one feel like one was in a catacomb, but a warm and pleasant one.
The warmth came mainly from the very efficient heating system, of course, yet I felt there was more to that here.
It was definitely not a cozy place, as no place of worship should be, and the heavy, brown wooden benches, made less austere only by the thin, green seat and kneeling cushions, were there to tell you that.
But one immediately felt that in this place one's soul could rest.
It was a place like home.
The general color of the whole chapel was off-white and beige, brought about by the clean walls, ceiling, and floor made of marble and white-painted cement.
But what could have been very drab walls was given life by a charming salmon and sea-green ginkgo-leaf pattern.
From the ceiling hung two gigantic bronze chandeliers with yellow LED lights ensconced in transparent sea-green diffusers.
However, even at the threshold of the heavy, oaken door, one's eyes were invariably riveted to the sanctuary, as if by necessity.
One had to be unconscious for one's attention not to be immediately caught by the spectacular and massive gold-leafed reredos.
Scenes from the life the Blessed Virgin were woven, as it were, into this wooden tapestry of red, blue, and gold with elegant splashes of green.
Exquisitely integrating them into a whole was the imposing figure of Our Lady, Seat of Wisdom, in the middle.
And right below the painting, was the real focal point of the chapel: a golden tabernacle lined across the middle with semi-precious stones, holding within it the Lord of Heaven and Earth.
This was the hearth of this home.
The sheer beauty of this small church reminded me once more what a beautiful home the Church is.
As a cradle Catholic, I realized, my good fortune has been that not only have I had a home which I never left, but also that this home has been kept warm by a Flame that neither burns nor dies out.
Moreover, from my childhood, I have been surrounded by graces and benefits that only the Church can afford: beauty in its liturgy, consolation in its sacraments, certitude of truth in its doctrine, and the sublime example and intercession of Her saints.
All that came together here.
Yet in such beauty and warmth, one can very easily stop there and be satisfied, thinking that the Church is only to be enjoyed.
Or say with Peter as he stood still, stupefied by the beauty of the Transfiguration, "It is good for us to be here.
Let us build three tents..." - and remain inside.
Or, as St.
John Paul II said, "to fold in upon oneself." But Pope Francis has reminded us that the Church is a field hospital.
This means that "Church troops" -- that's you and I -- must go out there in the messy slush, where it is cold, wet, and gloomy.
Out of ourselves, that is, to encounter souls and bring to them the mercy of Christ.
Where to go, and as what? Each of us has a specific position and mission, one designed for him or her that no one else can replace: a calling.
A professional is sent to his colleagues and place of work; the student to his classmates; Mother Teresa's Missionary of Charity to the poorest of the poor; the mother to her husband and children; the bishop and priest to their flock; the politician to his constituents; the cloistered nun and monk, in their prayers and work, to the whole Church.
And the encounter with each soul is not a matter of "converting" him or her, but of being available to them as Christ was to that blind man.
He asked, "What would you have me do?" to suggest to us that in the Christian apostolate it is the other person who matters, not our plans.
So this is the challenge to us who belong to the Church in this "age of Francis": to show how much we appreciate the gift of the Faith given to us by Christ by being the authentic image of his mercy to those whom we encounter.
This certainly needs a lot spiritual calories.
One needs to prepare interiorly before launching out, otherwise one falls either into the folly of activism or the ditch of despair.
The good news is that this is not impossible to do.
Pope Francis reminds us that these "spiritual calories" are nothing but the mercy we have in our soul, and "to prepare interiorly" really just means that one experience mercy oneself so that he or she can give it.

Lent is arguably one of the best moments to do that.
By going confession or maybe attending a retreat, one opens himself or herself to experience God's mercy.
And although your eventual divine encounter may not have the dramatic backdrop of snow-covered mountains, as with everything that God does, it is bound to surprise you.

I am peace , I am peace 
DAVAO.
The garden at the Agong House in Kapatagan, Digos City, has new installations declaring it as a Land of Peace.
Stella A.
Estremera, THERE'S a movement among a growing group of individuals in Davao rooted from long years of drumming up interest on peace.
This movement is seeking to encourage Mindanaoans to declare they are peace personified and not just that they are for peace.
"It's a declaration.
It goes beyond just saying that we are for peace," artist Rey Mudjahid "Kublai" Ponce Millan said in explaining the concept that he and his friends are working on.
At the start, the manifestations of these individual declarations will be seen at the Francisco Bangoy International Airport after businessman Alex P.
Montanez of the APM Ad & Promo Management, which manages all the billboards inside the Davao airport for the Civil Aviation Authority .
He's going to sponsor valuable billboard spaces to give way to murals by local artists, similar to the mural on the corridor going to Gates 6-8 of the pre-departure area, but this time with a clear message about peace.
"Mindanao has always been regarded as the land of promise," Millan said, "but this time, we are saying this is the land of peace and we are peace." 
It has been in the works since a few years back with a group of artists gathered under the name Artists Helping Artists .
Several group exhibits have been tagged at Abreeza Mall in 2013 and 2014, as the initial foray into popularizing art that speaks of Mindanao's beauty and bounty and of its people.
But the whole concept was still in the making, the idea still being threshed out, and the momentum being gathered to bring in more and more like-minded people who see into the heart of every Mindanaoan and find beauty there instead of conflict.
The Land of Promise was the blurb coined when the Philippine legislature passed the homestead program in 1903, which allowed enterprising tenants to acquire a farm of at least 16 hectares for as long as they cultivate it and make this productive.
While the program was intended nationwide, real implementation was introduced only in Northern Luzon and parts of Mindanao because these regions still had available public alienable and disposable lands.
National Land Settlement Administration , created through Commonwealth Act.
No.
441, continued the Homestead Program, in 1939.
This homestead programs throughout the three decades created a massive wave of migration to Mindanao.
The core group is of the conviction that this should have long evolved into a fulfillment of that promise.
The most "peaceful" way of achieving this can only be through the arts that seek out the positive.
In April last year, the core group drafted a peace manifesto of sorts, although still unpolished, it somehow encapsulates the very idea on which the I Am Peace movement is rooted on.
The manifesto read:
I EMBRACE
the notion of Mindanao as the Land of Peace.

The Almighty - Dios, Allah, and Magbabaya - has gifted the land with peace.
 All its people considers Mindanao their home.
Its peace is being fulfilled by the Lumad, the Moro and the descendants of the migrants, who converged for a common good.

I BELIEVE
that Mindanao Is truly a domain of Peace.

Tensions, conflicts and divisions have made Mindanao bleed, and still it is..

Even so, I have more reasons to be steadfast and look forward tomorrow when shadows will yield to light, when tears will turn to laughter, when war disappear and Peace will reign.

Collectively, Mindanao's possibilities will be explored by everyone - who gaze the precious Peace of the Land.

I HOPE AND PRAY
that Mindanao and its people in unison will journey towards a Peace-filled Land.

When the fruits of the land will be justly distributed among its peoples.

When peasants have land, workers have jobs and families' needs are well provided.

When the governance system will favor no one but will instead protect the rights of everyone.

When those who look after the people's security will truly respect their human rights of everyone.

When the Mindanawons can truly respect and value each other's ethnicities, cultural and faith traditions.

When we can safeguard nature and cultures as legacies for the coming generations.

When women find themselves reclaiming the roles of our foremothers and nurturing these even further.

When our children can run free and frolic across its mountains, hills, plains, seas, lakes and rivers.

I PLEDGE
to do my part, within the capabilities that the Almighty has bestowed me, to
Practice and live up the demands of Peace, 
Contribute to the fulfillment of these Possibilities
and to be truly part of this hope-filled
Journey towards Peace, Harmony, Justice, Equality and Freedom.

Hinaut pa unta! Harinawa KALINAW! 
I AM FOR PEACE.

A year later, saying, "I am for peace" is deemed not enough.
Millan is working with both student and professional artists, who are willing to volunteer their time and talent to make these murals at the ticketing counter, the VIP lounge, and the arrival area within the next few months.
In the meantime, the core group will be setting up billboards on peace that is more than just saying no to war, but individually but as a collective declaring, "I am peace."
These will feature Millan's works at the Agong House in barangay Kapatagan in Digos City, which has housed his creations about Mindanao life and the positive thoughts he has been nurturing since 2003.
His most recent addition to this rolling terrain full of his artworks is the "Land of Peace" garden created in 2015.
Aside from the billboard spaces that will soon be converted into art spaces inside the airport, the FBIA management has also given the go-signal to have a set of sculptures on Mindanao and peace on the ground where the sign "Davao International Airport" is at the entrance driveway.
The whole idea is to fill just about every available space with art on peace in the city, and hopefully, this will catch on and encourage everyone to stop, appreciate beauty, and then declare that he or she too is peace personified.
Pampanga: 2018Most beautiful, richest2019, Pampanga: 2018Most beautiful, richest2019CITY OF SAN FERNANDO -- There was a time when Pampanga was considered the fairest -- and richest -- of all.
And the fabled reputation was written for all the world to know by a French adventurer Jean Mallat in his book 201cThe Philippines201d during the 18th\xa0century.
201cAll the world,201d of course, meant the Europe of old dominated by Spain and Portugal, countries that virtually partitioned the new world between them.
201cThe province of Pampanga is the most beautiful and richest in the Philippines,201d Mallat wrote.
201cAnd for this reason, it has been called New Spain.201d
It was a new name the province shared with another Spanish colony in South America -- Chile.
At the time, Mallat counted 27 pueblos  comprising the province, six of which are now parts of Tarlac , Bulacan  and Nueva Ecija .
Mt.
Arayat, Mallat said, was one of the most noteworthy mountains in the province.
Apparently, Mt.
Pinatubo was just another, ordinary part of the landscape until about two centuries later.
But that2019s another chapter in Pampanga2019s history altogether.

201cFrom Manila,201d he wrote, 201cone recognizes distinctly its pyramidal point, its flanks extend widely to the environs and its peak looks like the opening of vast crater.201d Mt.
Arayat is considered a dead volcano.
Most of the rivers of Pampanga, according to Mallat, rolled gold, 201c ut most of all, those of Abayon, Matalantang and Cabiao; the waters of some others contain ferruginous material, notably near San Miguel, where iron is very abundant and found even at ground level.201d
As to the Kapampangans at the time, Mallat was captivated by the Bacolorenos.
201cThe people there are good-looking,201d he said.
Bacolor was the capital of Pampanga then.
He added: 201cThis capital was surrounded by a great number of noted for the fertility of their soil and the beauty of their sceneries.201d
Mallat divided Pampanga into two parts, upper and lower.
Upper Pampanga, from Sta.
Ana extending to Pangasinan and Nueva Ecija, was scantily irrigated 201cbecause rivers have a very rapid course there.201d Lower Pampanga was very fertile and well populated; its plantations delightful and its temperature very pleasant.
Then as now, floods inundated parts of the province.
201cCourses of water descending from Mt.
Arayat are only streams during the dry season but become impetuous torrents during the rainy period.
It is also during this period that through the meeting of the rains with the rivers is formed the pinac of Candava.201d
Mallat, for some reason, failed to mention anything about the now famous migratory birds that flock regularly to modern Candaba.
Instead, he wrote about the dalag.
 201cIt is more or less during this period that they catch in this lake a great quantity of dalacs, a fish of which the Indios are extremely fond of and which is in fact delicious.201d
Of its natural products, Mallat said the province was distinguished by its tobacco, indigo, tuba, a kind of dark sugar and jams, tapa, pots of baked clay and even lime, among others.
Nearly two hundred years later after, has Pampanga retained its old fame and glory as beheld by Mallat?
Another Mallat may provide the answer.
