Manila holds the first-ever Sustainable Seafood Week, Manila holds the first-ever Sustainable Seafood WeekMANILA -- Top hotels and restaurants in Manila joined hands with different environmental groups and fisheries non-government organizations to put their commitment onto the plates by organizing the first-ever Sustainable Seafood Week taking place from February 15 to 21.
The Sustainable Seafood Week is a celebration of food and a venue for sharing the best practices in sustainable fisheries by various stakeholders.
The event also seeks to raise awareness among seafood consumers on the problems plaguing Philippine seas, particularly on the issue of unsustainable fishing practices that not only harm the marine environment but also threaten the country2019s fisheries industry.
201cIn the last 15 years, I realized that working with sustainable products was not only my responsibility as a person, but a bigger responsibility as a chef,201d said Chef Chele Gonzalez of Gallery Vask.
201cSustainability plays a huge role in our philosophy as we want to preserve the raw products of the Philippines and this includes the local seafood.
We have to relay this message not just within the food and beverage industry but more importantly to the public and to our guests who eat our food.
It is good for them to know that they are contributing to the sea2019s sustainability and are creating an environment of change with every plate.201d
201cTraceability is the core of our Artesmar Yellowfin Fishery Improvement Program for tuna.
Fully traceable sourcing, production and delivery procedures ensure that consumers will have access to information around our tuna products -- from where our fish was caught to the status of the stock, including the name of fishers.
This ensures that the marine environment will not be harmed so we can all enjoy fish, while equitably helping the municipal fishers with profitable livelihood,201d said Christian Schmidradner, general manager of Meliomar Inc., and one of the organizers of the event.
The event was also welcomed by fisherfolk groups as it solidified the commitment of top hotels and restaurants to sustainable fisheries and allows them to gain access to high end markets in Manila.
201cThis is a huge validation for fisherfolk communities who have been struggling to fight for our rights and our place in the sun,201d said Jeremie Jumao-as, a local fisherfolk from Samahan ng mga Manggagawa sa Tunahan Sablayan in Occidental Mindoro.
201cThe continued patronage by these hotels and restaurants will allow us to inform and train our fellow fishers on the proper way to catch fish to continue supplying quality seafood to both local and foreign markets.201d
201cThe Sustainable Seafood Week is a wonderful collaboration by stakeholders and shows a strong desire to help our seas recover from overfishing and ecosystems degradation,201d said Vince Cinches, Oceans Campaigner for Greenpeace Philippines.
201cWe urge the government and the rest of the players in the fisheries sector to play an active role and find ways to champion the marine environment to ensure that we will always have seafood to enjoy and savor now and in the future.201d
The Sustainable Seafood Week will have various activities happening in various high-end partner hotels and restaurants.
These include fisheries and environmental presentations, chef classes and technical workshops on what sustainable seafood is all about.
For more information, please go to www.Facebook.com/SustainableSeafoodWeekph

2018Happiest Pinoy2019 inspires 728 honor students, 2018Happiest Pinoy2019 inspires 728 honor studentsIN 2010, he was named the 201cHappiest Pinoy.201d It was no surprise that his message during the 58th Annual Honors Day Convocation graced by 728 recipients of different academic awards centered on the value of 201chappiness.201d
Winston A.
Maxino, a corporate executive and a Sillimanian, spoke to an audience composed of honor students and their respective families on February 15 at the Silliman University Gymnasium.
His speech was powerful, inspiring and at the same time humorous.
This year2019s Convocation conferred 33 University Honors, 103 College Honors and 592 Class Honors.
It also recognized recipients of co-curricular awards:
* Most Outstanding Student of the Year -- Amyrrha M.

Bito-on 
Many were moved by Maxino2019s experiences, including suffering from a debilitating disease called ankylosing spondylitis, and how despite all that he had gone through, he remained optimistic and decided to face life with a smile.

A student in Silliman from kindergarten to college, graduating with a degree in Political Science in 1983, Maxino shared how he thought the invitation to be the Honors Day speaker was fitting.
He was not new to the Honors Day in Silliman -- he was a consistent honor student himself and was named Most Outstanding Student of the Year in his senior year in college.

201cGets na gets ko,201d he quipped, referring to the feeling that the 728 honor students before him were having.
Being a parent to children who are achievers, Maxino said he could also place himself in the shoes of loved ones in the audience who were eager to cheer on their children as they receive their certificates and medals on stage.
His entire speech  revolved around the positive topic of 201chappiness201d -- what he can be considered an expert of, after he was picked in 2010 from among hundreds of nominees as the 201cHappiest Pinoy201d in the country.

So Maxino asked: 201cHow do we stay happy even during the worst circumstances of our lives?201d
201cIf Ms.
Universe Pia Wurtzbach is confidently beautiful with a heart, I lay claim to being confidently handsome2026 with a heart2026 problem,201d he said, soliciting giggles from the audience.
  
Since childhood, Maxino said he was physically ill.
He was battling with asthma, osteoporosis, allergic rhinitis, and the incurable and debilitating disease called ankylosing spondylitis, a form of spinal arthritis.
At age 26, he was diagnosed with a serious case of hypertension.
But while there were many reasons for him to feel down, he chose to stay strong and happy.
He said life is a matter of choice, and so he made the choice of happiness.
While many think it is a mere feeling, happiness, Maxino said, is more than what beats and jumps from within.

201cHappiness is more than just a feeling; happiness is an energy that moves people to positive action that benefits others.
Happy people want to make others happy,201d he stressed.

And happiness 201cdoes not require grand gestures or a supreme sacrifice.201d 201cHappiness can circulate from doing the small and simple acts that show you care -- from greeting people warmly with a smile, from saying a well-deserved praise, from thanking people, from encouraging the hopeless, from guiding the lost, from comforting the grieving, from sharing with the needy, from taking the time to listen, and many more,201d he added.

Driving his message closer to the campus that he called home, Maxino also talked about the ultimate source of happiness common to all Sillimanians -- the 201cHappiness Seed.201d
This 201cHappiness Seed201d is the Silliman motto: Via, Veritas, Vita.
He said the Silliman motto has been his guide, giving him 201cthe indomitable Silliman spirit201d that sustained him throughout his years.

Maxino also highlighted in his speech the life-changing gift that he received in his daughter, Brina, who was born with Down Syndrome.
His daughter2019s condition at first pushed him to question God.
But over time, he embraced how Brina was a blessing from God.
It was that transformation of his view of his daughter2019s condition, from what he originally thought would be a burden to it being a blessing, that he considers to be the most important decision he had ever made in his entire life.
Brina turned out to be an excellent student.
She graduated class valedictorian from a regular high school and is now taking up AB History in college.
Brina currently serves as the first Filipino Special Olympics Global Youth Ambassador representing Asia-Pacific.
In August 2014, Brina was invited to a dinner at the White House with US President Barack Obama.
So how do we stay happy during worst circumstances?
In answering that question, Maxino reflected on the Silliman motto, Via, Veritas, Vita: 201cVia: Have faith that God is on your side and trust that He will turn your burdens into blessings.
Veritas: maintain your integrity and always do the right thing to keep a peaceful mind.
Vita: let your suffering bear fruit to transform you into a happier and more loving person who enriches the lives of others.201d 
Maxino concluded his speech by giving a tip on how to harness the force of happiness in all endeavors.
Using the University President2019s first name, he said students should always 201cBEN.201d
201cWe need to B 2013 believe we possess it, E 2013 endure the hardships and N 2013 never give up.
In short, B 2013 believe, E 2013 endure and N 2013 never give up,201d he said.

Q&A: As Zika rages in the Americas, should Asia be worried?, Q&A: As Zika rages in the Americas, should Asia be worried?
In this Feb.
15, 2016, photo, thermographic measurement against Zika virus is conducted at Narita international airport in Narita, near Tokyo.

ZIKA virus continues to rage in the Americas, and the World Health Organization has declared it a global health emergency.
Taiwan has recently issued a travel advisory for Thailand, warning expectant mothers or women trying to get pregnant to postpone their trips there.
But how big of a concern is Zika virus for Asia? Here's what you need to know:
Q: Has Zika virus been a problem in the Asia-Pacific Region in the past?
A: The disease was first identified in 1947 in a monkey in the Zika forest of Uganda.
The virus has been found in Asia as far back as the 1960s.
It has appeared in Indonesia, Malaysia, India, Cambodia, Vietnam, Thailand, the Philippines and Pakistan, but no widespread cases have been reported and symptoms have typically been mild and similar to dengue and chikungunya, which may have helped mask its presence.
Up until the first outbreak in 2007, only 14 cases were reported globally.

The outbreak occurred on the Pacific island of Yap in Micronesia, where an estimated three-quarters of the population had been infected.
No hospitalizations or lasting health issues were reported.
In 2013 and 2014, outbreaks again hit the Pacific, including Easter Island, the Cook Islands and New Caledonia.
In French Polynesia, an increase in a neurological disorder called Guillain-Barre syndrome coincided with the outbreak.
In 2015, the virus was reported in Vanuatu, Fiji, the Solomon Islands and Samoa.
Q: Are there any cases in Asia and the Pacific now?  Are precautions being taken?
A: Thailand has reported one case, and active transmission is occurring on the Pacific islands of American Samoa and Samoa.
Tonga has declared a Zika epidemic after five cases were confirmed and more than 260 suspected infections were identified.
Other imported cases have popped up in the region, mostly from tourists returning from Zika-endemic areas.
However, many more cases have likely gone undetected or been misdiagnosed as dengue or chikungunya, which are also spread by the same type of mosquito -- the Aedes aegypti -- and have similar symptoms of headache, fever rash and joint pain.
An estimated eight out of 10 people infected with Zika experience no symptoms at all.
After a Thai migrant worker was diagnosed with the disease in Taiwan, health officials there issued a February 14 travel advisory warning expectant mothers or women trying to get pregnant to put off traveling to Thailand, and for men to wear condoms after returning to avoid potentially spreading the virus via sex.
But Dr.
Nick White, a tropical disease expert who has researched mosquito-borne diseases for decades at Thailand's Mahidol University, called Taiwan's travel guidance "excessive."
He said Thailand is being singled out for having good surveillance and fast case reporting compared to other countries in the region, "but to say that it would be worse to come here than say, Cambodia, Vietnam, Myanmar, Laos, Indonesia or Malaysia, there's absolutely no evidence of that at all," he said.
Q: What is microcephaly and Guillain-Barre Syndrome? How are they linked to Zika?
A: Babies with microcephaly are born with small heads, and their brains may not have developed properly.
The condition can lead to seizures, learning disabilities, developmental problems, cerebral palsy, vision problems and other issues.
Guillain-Barre syndrome is an autoimmune disorder where the body attacks the nervous system.
People of all ages can be affected.
The condition causes weakness and loss of sensation or tingling in the arms and legs and sometimes elsewhere on the body.
Most people recover from it, but it can cause paralysis or death.

Scientists are researching the potential link between microcephaly, Guillain-Barre and Zika virus to try to understand it better.
"We don't know enough about it," White said, adding it's unclear whether the exact same virus circulating in the Americas is also prevalent in Asia.
"No one has identified rampant microcephaly anywhere else, so I think we need to know a lot more about it before panicking."
Q: What can be done to prevent Zika infection?
A: Experts say the same precautions to prevent dengue, chickungunya and other mosquito-borne diseases should be taken.
Eliminate mosquito breeding grounds by not allowing water to collect around the home in roof gutters, flower pots or other containers.
Use insect repellant and wear long-sleeve shirts, pants and socks, especially during key Aedes mosquito feeding times in the morning, late afternoon or evening.
Some health agencies, including the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, have issued guidance for pregnant women to avoid traveling to areas experiencing Zika outbreaks and for men returning from affected countries to wear condoms or abstain from sex with pregnant women.
Sexual transmission of the Zika virus has occurred in rare cases.
There is currently no vaccine or specific treatment for Zika virus.

El Ni\xf1o, a weather phenomenon, El Ni\xf1o, a weather phenomenon
Sun.Star file photo
Nicko Tubo, WHEN the temperature between the ocean and atmosphere changes, two phases of the El Ni\xf1o Southern Oscillation  cycle can be created, namely, El Ni\xf1o and La Ni\xf1a.
Enso is the fluctuations in temperature between the ocean and atmosphere in central and eastern Equatorial Pacific.
The cold phase of Enso is referred to as La Ni\xf1a, while the warm phase of the cycle is known as El Ni\xf1o, which the Philippines is now experiencing.

The El Ni\xf1o weather phenomenon occurs in the Pacific basin every two to nine years.
It often starts between December to February and lasts until first half of the following year.
However, it may be experienced longer.
El Ni\xf1o is usually followed by La Ni\xf1a, as rainfall fluctuations associated with it tend to occur again at the time of the year.
According to the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration , different parts of the Philippines may experience varying rainfall impacts.

The prolonged drought spell affects the normal rainfall pattern in the country, resulting in reduced rainfall and fewer but stronger typhoons entering the country.
Pagasa is closely monitoring the oceanic and atmospheric conditions in the tropical Pacific that could lead to possible development of El Ni\xf1o.

Pagasa furnishes rainfall outlook, updates, and advisories for the different parts of the country.
The weather state bureau classified the areas affected by El Ni\xf1o into dry condition, dry spell, and drought.
Dry condition is defined as two consecutive months of below normal rainfall condition, dry spell means rainfall condition in the area is below normal for three months, while drought is referred as three succeeding months of way below normal rainfall status.
Here is a list of provinces affected by El Ni\xf1o as of January 31, 2016:
Dry condition: Compostela Valley, Surigao del Norte, and Surigao del Sur.
Dry spell: Catanduanes, Capiz, Iloilo, Negros Oriental, Siquijor, eastern Samar, Bukidnon, Lanao del Norte, Davao del Sur, Davao Oriental, Sarangani, and Lanao del Sur.
Drought: Palawan, Aklan, Antique, Guimaras, northern Samar, Samar , Zamboanga del Norte, Zamboanga del Sur, Zamboanga Sibugay, Misamis Occidental, South Cotabato, North Cotabato, Sultan Kudarat, Basilan, Maguindanao, Sulu, and Tawi-Tawi.
Here are the provinces likely to be affected by El Ni\xf1o by the end of February 2016:
Dry condition: Abra, Benguet, Kalinga, Mountain Province, Pangasinan, Nueva Ecija, Oriental Mindoro, Romblon, Albay, Camarines Sur, Masbate, Sorsogon, Bohol, Agusan del Norte, Agusan del Sur.
Dry spell: Rizal, Catanduanes, Camiguin, Misamis Oriental, Compostela Valley, Davao del Sur, Davao Oriental, Surigao del Norte, Surigao del Sur.
Drought: Palawan, Antique, Capiz, Guimaras, Iloilo, Negros Oriental, Siquijor, eastern Samar, northern Samar, Samar , Zamboanga del Norte, Zamboanga del Sur, Zamboanga Sibugay, Bukidnon, Lanao del Norte, Misamis Occidental, south Cotabato, north Cotabato, Sarangani, Sultan Kuldarat, Basilan, Maguindanao, Lanao del Sur, Sulu, Tawi-Tawi.
Areas affected by El Ni\xf1o
The Department of Social Welfare and Development  said that in Northern Mindanao, Bukidnon has the most number of families affected by El Ni\xf1o, with farmers, laborers and forest workers numbering 52,282, followed by Misamis Oriental with 38,170 families, Lanao del Norte - 38,160, Misamis Occidental - 14,555, and Camiguin with 3,658 families.
DSWD said P304 million worth of assistance was prepared to assist areas in Northern Mindanao affected by the weather phenomenon.
The Zamboanga City Agriculture Office said that as of February 6, 2016, 750.34 hectares of crops worth P14.02 million in the city were damaged by El Ni\xf1o.
In Davao City, its Disaster Risk Reduction and Management chief Emmauel Jaldon, in an interview with Sun.Star Davao, said state of calamity will not be declared yet, as the impact of El Ni\xf1o on crops is not severe enough.
Pagasa Mactan in Cebu recorded on February 10 the highest temperature in the province for the month at 31.6 degrees Celsius.
Conserving water
The National Water Resources Board and the Department of Environment and Natural Resources gave tips on how to conserve water during El Ni\xf1o.

Pagasa said El Ni\xf1o might worsen from moderate to strong during the first quarter of 2016, and will start to weaken between March 20 and June 19.

Sources: Gov.ph, DOST-Pagasa, NWRB, DENR, US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

A positive life    , A positive life    Karina V.
Canedo, AS FITNESS instructor, the battle is not just about staying fit, but to stay alive.
 
For Nash Villa, 26, a fitness instructor at Plana Forma, dancing and maintaining a healthy lifestyle is more than just a job.

It is a statement of survival.
Standing tall with imposing muscles, no one can guess that Villa for 10 years now, is positive of Human Immunodeficiency Virus , but this never hindered Villa to reach out for more and encourage other people to be fit, and this also did not stop him to show the world his amazing dancing skills.

201cNaisip ko kasi na hindi ibig sabihin na kung ganyan ka titigil ang mundo mo.
Nakita ko rin naman na maraming naniniwala sa akin sa talent ko, maraming sumusuporta that is why mas na challenge ako but it2019s not that easy,201d Villa said.

He said that he worked hard as a performer despite his condition sucht hat many still seek him out.

201cKahit ganito aking condition maraming nagha-hire sa akin to do this and that.
Sa mga engagements ini-invite ako for dancing,201d Villa said.

Villa said he performs aerial silk, jazz, ballet, and contemporary Hiphop, he is also a member of a dance company that teaches all ages.

201cI kept on performing even though nakita na nila ako sa TV nung nagpainterview na ako as ganito.
In public nakita ng mga tao na nagtuturo ako ng Zumba, curious ang mga tao dumadami sila kasi nakikita kasi nila sa akin na I am happy even if inside it2019s, you know it2019s different but, ganoonangbuhay eh, so as a performer you know laban.
Hindi hadlang ang pagiging may HIV para matigil,201d Villa said.

Villa said that one of the memorable things he said he did was to organize a Zumba dance concert for people with HIV.

201cNag speak ako in public na yes, ganito ako, ganyan so hindi lahat ng tao nakarinig ng storya ko but at least na sabi ko that is one thing on my part because it is not easy to talk to public to listen to your story kasi ibang pananaw nila e, but at least nakita nila ako na, yes I am Nash Villa with HIV, but still kicking and dancing parang ganoon.
Pinapakita ko talaga sa kanila kung gaano ako kaswerte,201d Villa said.

Teary-eyed, Villa narrated how he felt pain with the discriminatory stares and acts of people who looked past his person and only saw his disease.

201cYung feeling na pagmakita ka ng mga tao parang lalayuan ka, yung parang isang tingin lang nakakahawa na, talagang naranasan ko yan everytime pumapasok ako sa gym ang mga tao nagsisipag tabihan,201d Villa said.

But Villa said that his dream fueled him to continue in life and he worked harder.

201cMasakit hindi easy pero mas nanaig yung pangarap kasi, pangarap ko talagang maging performer maging dance teacher so talagang pi-nush ko siya so hanggang dumating ako diyan na hindi ko namamalayan having this kind of condition, mas lalong naging malakas ako and mas lalong naging proud nga ako kasi dahil dito mas maraming na inspire kung paano ako tumayo,201d Villa said.

He is a proof that exercise and right diet can enhance a body2019s resistance, which an HIV-positive needs a lot.

His doctor was even surprised how healthy looking he is despite the fact that his CD4 is so low.
As defined in AIDS.gov, 201cA CD4 count is a lab test that measures the number of CD4 T lymphocytes  in a sample of your blood.
 
In people with HIV, it is the most important laboratory indicator of how well your immune system is working and the strongest predictor of HIV progression.201d 
201cI am a fitness instructor and I sweat a lot in my work,201d he told the doctor and all that the doctor can reply was, 201cKaya pala.201d 
It was when he realized that his being fit enabled him to stay healthy despite HIV.
He said his main inspiration is his family, whom he said was the last to know about his condition.

He really said that one legacy he thinks he would pass for those who wanted to survive HIV, is to inspire them not to hide in the corners.

201cI kept on teaching, I kept on accepting interviews saan saan para at least malaman at makilala nila, maging confident sila ganito ganyan at hindi nila dapat ikatakot kasi kung wala kang acceptance or you keep on hiding, mamamatay ka lang.
Andami nang namatay sa hindi nagstick sa gamot, hindi naalagaan ang sarili,201d Villa said.

Villa, now swinging up in the air, at the prime of his career said that his door is open for opportunities saying that apart from his current job, he also considers dance workshops outside country and he also now thinking hard on job opportunities and job offers he received.

Masbad: That tussle between Apple and the FBI, Masbad: That tussle between Apple and the FBIRoark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, THIS previous week, the tech world was all-eyes on the tug-of-war between the FBI and Apple because of an iPhone 5C.
What2019s the fuss about?
Well, to quote Slashgear, this 5C "was once owned by the San Bernardino shooter, and at the moment, no one can unlock it.201d Don2019t mind much about who the San Bernardino shooter is.
What we need to look closely here is the fight between Apple and the FBI .

Anyway, the FBI can2019t get into that iPhone because of a password/passcode.
And, yes, they also can2019t hack into it.
So they asked the courts to force Apple into creating a 201cbackdoor201d into the phone so they can retrieve the data they need.
Sounds simple enough.
But, unfortunately, it2019s not.
A part of the order from the judge reads below:
Apple2019s reasonable technical assistance shall accomplish the following three important functions:  it will bypass or disable the auto-erase function whether or not it has been enabled;  it will enable the FBI to submit passcodes to the SUBJECT DEVICE for testing electronically via the physical device port, Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, or other protocol available on the SUBJECT DEVICE and  it will ensure that when the FBI submits passcodes to the SUBJECT DEVICE, software running on the device will not purposefully introduce any additional delay between passcode attempts beyond what is incurred by Apple hardware.
It sounds so legalese, I know.
But from how I understand that, it basically means that Apple is being ordered to circumvent its own security and encryption protocols in all its products in order to protect our individual privacies.
If Apple gives in to this, I think this will mean that any government in any part of the world can now basically order Apple to provide it a way to access any of its products; circumventing and rendering our security measures null and void.

Tim Cook, in a letter addressed to all of Apple2019s customers, basically planted his foot down and said no to the government order:
The United States government has demanded that Apple take an unprecedented step which threatens the security of our customers.
We oppose this order, which has implications far beyond the legal case at hand.
And in a later part of the letter, it said:
We have great respect for the professionals at the FBI, and we believe their intentions are good.
Up to this point, we have done everything that is both within our power and within the law to help them.
But now the U.S.
government has asked us for something we simply do not have, and something we consider too dangerous to create.
They have asked us to build a backdoor to the iPhone.
Specifically, the FBI wants us to make a new version of the iPhone operating system, circumventing several important security features, and install it on an iPhone recovered during the investigation.
In the wrong hands, this software 2014 which does not exist today 2014 would have the potential to unlock any iPhone in someone2019s physical possession.
Emphasis by me.
I won2019t try and dive into the legal side of it all.
Suffice to say that I am, personally, scared about the possibilities of a 201cbackdoor201d into my iPhone.
There2019s a reason why these devices wipe their data automatically after 10 failed attempts of putting in a password/passcode -- protection of the owner2019s data and privacy.
That2019s a mighty good reason for me.

However this plays out, I think this will have a lasting effect in how cybersecurity, encryption and individual data privacy are implemented and protected.
At the same time, I think we should all take an interest in this because we are fast becoming a society that2019s data-dependent, device-dependent.
Facebook's Zuckerberg at crossroads in connecting the globe, Facebook's Zuckerberg at crossroads in connecting the globe
In this March 2, 2015 file photo, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg speaks during a conference at the Mobile World Congress, the world's largest mobile phone trade show in Barcelona, Spain.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg likes to boast that his three-year-old effort to bring the developing world online has reached millions of people in some of the world's poorest nations.
But a central element of his Internet.org campaign was controversial even before it was shut down in a key market this month.
Indian regulators banned one of the pillars of the campaign, a service known as Free Basics, because it provided access only to certain pre-approved services 2014 including Facebook 2014 rather than the full Internet.
That leaves the social media mogul at a crossroads.
Though he has vowed not to give up, Zuckerberg hasn't said whether he'll alter his approach.
Facebook declined to make executives available for comment.
Zuckerberg could shed light on his plans when he speaks Monday at Mobile World Congress, an annual industry event in Barcelona, Spain, where he has touted Internet.org in previous years.
"Everyone in the world should have access to the Internet," Zuckerberg wrote on Facebook this month, arguing that online connections can improve lives and fuel economic development.
To achieve that goal, Zuckerberg has high-flying dreams for someday providing Internet connections through a network of drones, satellites and lasers.
But his near-term plan is simpler: Facebook works with wireless carriers in poorer nations to let people use streamlined versions of Facebook and certain other online services, without paying data charges.
While the drones may someday connect people in areas too remote for cables or cell towers, Free Basics is intended for people who live in areas with Internet service but still can't afford it.
A low-income resident of urban Manila, for example, can use Free Basics to view the Philippines' GMA News site.
"He can be informed.
He can research.
He can read the news," Ederic Eder of GMA News said.
The program varies by country, in offerings and effectiveness.
In South Africa, for instance, Facebook partnered with the third-largest wireless carrier, Cell C.
But Johannesburg resident Priscilla de Klerk said she couldn't get Free Basics to work on her phone.
"Cell C is much cheaper as far as everything else is concerned, but their free Facebook is not a reality," she said.
Last fall, Facebook announced a major expansion in Africa, where another regional carrier, Bharti Airtel, said it will offer Free Basics in 17 countries.
"They're getting a lot of traction in Africa," said Danson Njue, a Kenya-based telecom analyst with the Ovum research firm.
Tech rivals Google and Microsoft also have programs to expand Internet access, he noted, but their approaches are content neutral and involve extending networks to underserved areas.
Facebook doesn't pay wireless companies for the cost of Free Basics.
Carriers make money if new users eventually move to a paid data plan.
Facebook also says it makes no money, as it doesn't show ads, though Zuckerberg has conceded it benefits from gaining users in the long run.
While the company hasn't released detailed usage figures, Facebook says Free Basics has brought more than 19 million people online for the first time.
That counts any user who didn't have Internet access before, regardless of whether they're currently active.
On the Internet.org website, mixed in with videos about impoverished students using Free Basics to study and laborers starting small businesses, Facebook boasts more than one billion people "have access" to the service.
That's the combined population of regions where it's available, not the number of users.
Free Basics is now in 36 countries.
It was suspended last year in Egypt, on the anniversary of anti-government protests that were organized partly on Facebook.
An earlier version of Free Basics, known as Facebook Zero, was shuttered three years ago in Chile, after authorities said Internet providers couldn't offer discounts for accessing some content but not others.
Similar concerns turned India into the program's biggest battleground.
Free Basics enrolled more than one million Indians in its first year, according to Facebook's wireless partner, Reliance Communications.
But critics, including many in the country's growing tech community, complained it was a predatory scheme: If low-income users couldn't afford anything besides Free Basics, opponents said, that meant Facebook was deciding which online services the nation's poor could use.
"The government should not allow big players to monopolize the Internet," said Manu Sharma, who runs a software development company in New Delhi.
Facebook responded last fall by announcing it would open Free Basics to any app that met its technical requirements for systems with limited capacity.
Zuckerberg also changed the program's name to Free Basics, after critics complained "Internet.org" sounded like a nonprofit, when it's part of a for-profit company .
But opponents still worry that Facebook could change requirements at any time, force competitors to pay higher rates to get into the program, or even block services that run afoul of powerful politicians.
"The fact that it could decide what apps could be hosted ...
was a huge problem for me," said Basit Zaidi, a New Delhi attorney.
As Indian regulators began studying the issue, Facebook drew more resentment with a public-relations blitz that critics called heavy-handed and patronizing.
The regulators effectively banned Free Basics after concluding Internet providers shouldn't be allowed to charge different rates for certain services, because that discriminates against other content.
US regulators have endorsed the concept of "net neutrality," which says all websites and apps should be treated equally by Internet providers.
They're now studying whether "zero rating" programs, which offer some content for free, should be allowed.
Net neutrality supporters are hoping India's decision will influence other nations.
Facebook has also launched a program that helps Internet providers offer reliable Wi-Fi service in underserved areas at affordable rates and without limits on content.
The program's been limited to tests in a few countries.
The giant tech company could use its resources and clout with carriers to offer a similar wireless service, perhaps at limited speeds or volume, but without any restrictions on content, said Josh Levy of Access Now, a nonprofit that supports net neutrality.
Zuckerberg has suggested in the past that such a service would be too expensive and difficult to offer.
Some Indians, meanwhile, say their country could have benefited from Free Basics.
"Ultimately, something is better than nothing, even if that something is flawed," said Uday Singh Tomar, a software engineer in New Delhi.
"If a person is hungry and getting nothing, a free meal is good enough." 
Going big on St.
Joseph, Going big on St.
Joseph
The facade 
Robert Z.
Cortes, IF ASTONISHMENT at providential occurrences demanded a correspondence in strict proportion to its magnitude, I would definitely be compelled to make St.
Joseph big with me this year -- though happily so.

A couple of weeks ago, I sat on a talk reminding me about the Seven Sundays of St.
Joseph.
It's that rather unknown custom in the Church to prepare anyone aware and willing for the Solemnity of St.
Joseph, on March 19.
It's pretty much like what the Novena to the Immaculate Conception is to that solemnity of Our Lady and the Simbang Gabi to Christmas.
The seven Sundays are a means to honor the Seven Sorrows and Joys of St.
Joseph.
 
Just in case anyone needs to recall what these are , the following are "St.
Joseph's Sorrows and their corresponding Joys":
1.
The doubts about Mary - The angel's message of joy
2.
The pain at the lowly poverty of Jesus' birthplace - The Savior's birth 
3.
Watching the first blood Jesus' spilt for us at the Circumcision - Having the honor of naming Jesus
4.
Listening to the painful prophetic message of Simeon - Knowing the effects of Jesus' redemptive work
5.
Having to take the Holy Family into exile - The idols of Egypt fell before Jesus' feet
6.
The hard trip back from Egypt - A holy life with Jesus and Mary
7.
The loss of Jesus for three days - Finding Him after three days
Familiar, aren't they -- the events, but perhaps not the packaging? Maybe I was thinking as much as the talk was going on, and maybe trying my best to be interested.
Then quite unexpectedly, and to my surprise, it occurred to me that I should make this year's feast of St.
Joseph more special by honoring him more deliberately than I have all these years.
There are many motives for this, I thought - both past and present.

For one, I was born and raised in a parish whose patron saint is St.
Joseph; indeed one where the Philippine National Shrine of St.
Joseph is standing.
Then, I was taught at a young age that I should often go St.
Joseph as the patron saint of vocations and the interior life.
Lastly, I'm in Rome, probably the best city in the world to offer -- on a physical level -- the best possibilities for honoring any saint.
The idea that came to mind was to visit, in the next seven Sundays, a different church dedicated to the Foster Father of Jesus, or at least a side chapel built in his honor within a church.
I checked an internet site dedicated solely to churches in Rome, and saw a list of four or five of the sort.
Starting with the first on the list, I found that it is quite near my house.
This blessed fact made me think that this was going to be an easy and exciting project.
The church is called "St.
Joseph of the Woodmakers" , which means that this church was built and maintained by the ancient Roman guild of carpenters.

My excitement was soon dampened, however, when I saw things weren't in fact that easy.
The website mentioned that it is the same church as that of St.
Peter's Prison , and that it was rarely open.
The article sounded rather confusing and discouraging, such that the idea of visiting one church or chapel for the next seven Sundays lay suspended for the next seven days.
In other words, the idea nearly died at birth.
Sadly, such are many of our good intentions.
But Providence has a way of saving ideas and intentions borne out of honest desires.

On the first Sunday of St.
Joseph, I and two other friends decided to explore the Caelian Hill, one of the seven hills on which ancient Rome was built.
This excursion is part of an ongoing project to get to know the Eternal City better.
I already had a route in mind, but one of us, who has been in Rome longer, suggested another.
This particular route brought us to an area labelled "St.
Peter's Prison."When I saw the mark, my first impulse was to ask them if they knew about a church in the area dedicated to St.
Joseph that was "fused" with the church of St.
Peter's Prison.
Disappointingly, neither had any idea.
We walked down a flight of stairs with the intention of cutting short our route towards the Caelian Hill by passing through the Roman Forum.
At the end of the stairs, however, we realized that a fence separated the small piazza where we were and the Roman Forum.
This meant we had to move on to the longer route.
But imagine my surprise when, as we turned to get on our way, a charming baroque church met my eyes.
It had the label, "Chiesa di San Giuseppe dei Falegnami." This was the "Church of St.
Joseph of the Woodworkers." Providence had brought me to the place I had desired when my lack of courage didn't.

My friends and I went in, delighted at this apparent "coincidence," that gave us a chance to pay special homage to St.
Joseph on the first of his seven Sundays.
It certainly didn't make it worse that the church was designed by Giacomo della Porta, the same architect who worked on St.
Peter's Basilica, the Ges\xf9, and Sant' Andreadella Valle.
Like any baroque church, the interior was breathtaking - ceiling, sanctuary, and all.
It was a pleasure to contemplate original paintings of 17th century masters that depicted the most significant moments of St.
Joseph's life 2013 among others: his marriage to Our Lady, the search for an inn, the birth of Christ, and his holy death.
Above the area which borders the sanctuary, an Old Testament passage that often comes with images of St.
Joseph was written in gold: Ite ad Joseph .
Upon reflection, I realized that it was the message I was meant to receive from this experience.
It's a message that I've been hearing since my youth, but given the providential circumstances it has been given now, I understood that the message actually meant, "From now on, allow St.
Joseph to do more for you." 
Obviously, providential circumstances or not, St.
Joseph ought to deserve my attention - and yours, as well.
He is, after all, the Foster Father of Jesus, the Husband of the Blessed Virgin, and the Patriarch of the entire Church.
He is the second most powerful intercessor after Our Lady, a fact we should all take advantage of.
Thus, given what St.
Joseph really is, perhaps it's not a bad idea to make him figure big in our spiritual life beginning now.
Going more to Joseph with the trust and determination of one who really wants to be better can only be a promise of greater things to come.

Pinoy photographer shortlisted for Sony World Photography Awards, Pinoy photographer shortlisted for Sony World Photography Awards
'Trapo' of Lawrence Sumulong 
FILIPINO photographer Lawrence Sumulong has been shortlisted for the Professional Conceptual category of the world's biggest photography competition, the Sony World Photography Awards.

Sumulong will now compete to win the Professional Conceptual category against photographers from around the world and the L'Iris d'Or / Photographer of the Year title and $25,000  cash prize, which will be announced at a Gala Ceremony in London on April 21.
Sumulong will also have his work shown in London as part of the 2016 Sony World Photography Awards exhibition in April and May, and be published in the 2016 edition of the Sony World Photography Awards book.
 
Lawrence Sumulong is a Filipino American photographer based in New York City and Manila.
He has received great recognition for his original photographic projects challenging the photographic medium.
His 201cTrapo201d series is an ongoing project focusing on politics in the Philippines.

201cMy series "Trapo' attempts to find an idiosyncratic way of working within the social documentary genre and express the invisible scourge of corruption and impunity in Philippine politics and society, which seemingly exists in all tiers of existence from the pencil pushers all the way to the president.
However, in deconstructing political portraits, I attempt to ask broader questions about the authenticity, rhetoric, and utility of photographic representations.
On the heels of the looming 2016 Philippine presidential elections, this exposure comes at an important and exigent time for this series,201d Sumulong said.
As to his success, he said: "I am extremely grateful to be shortlisted at this prestigious competition considering my project's obscure subject matter and approach."
The Sony World Photography Awards rewards and recognizes the world's best contemporary photography from the last year.
Attracting photographers of all abilities, the awards incorporate four competitions: Professional, Open, Youth and Student.
"We are extremely pleased with our jurors' choices this year.
Despite the increase in the number of photographers, and the amount of imagery that required judging, this year above all, others we have witnessed a wealth of powerful imagery in the traditionally strong social documentary categories as well as the art and conceptual work.
It is wonderful for the medium that it can offer such rich diversity," said Scott Gray, CEO of the World Photography Organisation and organizer of the awards.
For more information about the awards, visit www.worldphoto.org.

40th Jose Joya Awards reveals winners, 40th Jose Joya Awards reveals winners
Ferdinand Aragon with his winning entry 201cBullet to a Butterfly201d in 122 x 152 cm, paper 
WINNERS of the 40th Jose Joya Awards were named in a gathering held at the University of the Philippines  Cebu Little Gallery last February 24.
Third year Fine Arts student Ferdinand Aragon2019s 201cBullet to a Butterfly201d bested 51 other artworks.
201cIt still feels surreal,201d said Aragon, who claimed to be working on a series of pieces that depict Filipino children facing societal issues such as child pornography and child hunger.
201cThis time, my piece is about children in times of war,201d he said.
Second placer was Joshua Emmanuel Lim, with his painting 201cIncognito,201d while Ryan Seismundo came in third place with his 201cChange of Silhouette.201d
Seven finalists were also recognized during the awards night.
They were Cleane Padilla, Daniele Astrid Nazareno, Abigail Pajang, Jesus Codiniera, Clenneth Sala, Ninianne Sojor and Marvie Gasataya.
The annual painting competition is named after the late Jose Joya, National Artist for Visual Arts, who, as dean of the UP Diliman College of Fine Arts in 1976, decided to hold a contest for painting.
The contest was launched a year after the institutionalization of the UP Cebu Fine Arts Program.
UP Cebu Fine Arts professor Juanito Karl Roque Jr.
said that winning the award is a "distinction of belonging to a certain clique of students."
201cAfter a week or so, the financial incentives are gone, but the honor that is bestowed upon you is yours forever,201d said Roque.
201cThat has always been the idea of the late Jose Joya 2013 to inspire students to produce excellent works.201d
In her keynote speech, Josefa Joya-Baldovino, sister of the late national artist, said: 201cHis  desire to discover and to encourage art students to induce people to be appreciative of the fine arts made him adapt an art program.201d
She said the program would train the students to be ready 201cto meet the rigors of the time required201d for the fine arts.
Addressing the participants of the competition, Baldovino said laziness is a poor excuse not to meet deadlines for exhibition.
201cTalent to succeed in the fine arts is not sufficient.
You have to discipline yourselves to have a regular routine of hours to hone your craft,201d she said.
The artworks submitted for the awards are available in an exhibit that runs until March 4 at the UP Cebu Little Gallery.

Necessity the father of invention   , Necessity the father of invention   
Virgilio Sangutan.

Rhealyn C.
Pojas, HE CREATED bubbles that bubbled up his innovations.
It all started when he was a dishwasher whose hands were allergic to the soap used, in that small restaurant in Daraga, Albay, where he found employment out of his desire to finish his studies amid the financial issues faced by their families.

Born in Burias Island in Masbate, Virgilio Sangutan, current president of the Davao Inventors Association, was forced to leave his little hometown in his pursuit for higher education because their locality way back then only had elementary schools.

He ventured to Daraga to continue his studies at the Bicol College High School Department but with the little income that his family earned, he had to work as a dishwasher to stay in school.

At third year high school, with hands now pocked with sores and rashes, he concocted a multipurpose cleanser for plates and house stuff to save his hands from further harm.

This became his ticket to earn degrees in Bachelor of Science in Commerce major in Banking and finance at the Divine Word College of Legaspi and BS in Economics at the Philippine Business School of Business Administration as he eventually quit working as a dishwasher at the restaurant and instead sold his multipurpose cleanser to restaurant owners and other households.

After he graduated in College, he stopped his production and started working in a bank in Manila but fate has its way of turning things to its original plan and in 1985, the bank closed down forcing Sangutanto go to Davao City to join his family.

He returned to making and selling his cleansers to restaurants and cinemas in the city.
Since then, Sangutan had been involved in innovative projects after the Department of Science and Technology  accredited him as a Filipino inventor.

His products skyrocketed from just merely making a dish washing liquid to making herbal products, coffee, shampoo, soap, herbal liniment oil, organic fertilizers and others.

Their team became the first herbal manufacturer in the Philippines where the Bureau of Food and Drugs granted them a license in 1994 and they eventually built a laboratory in Carmen, Davao City.

This industry blossomed and brought recognition to herbal and food supplement not only in the country but as well as in other countries, according to Sangutan.

With all the innovations he was able to make with his team, Sangutan said that his constant source of information to create inventions sparked from the drive to help the country achieve development.

201cOur hearts as Filipino inventors are set on helping our countries achieve development,201d Sangutan said in an interview.

201cAs inventors, it is always our job to look for problems in the society so that out of these we can give solutions for everyone,201d Sangutan said adding that it is always their belief as inventors that necessity is the mother of all inventions.

His constant reminder to himself is to not entertain negatives as hindrances as these should be dealt with to give more rooms to innovations and improvements.
 
201cEntertain the negative comments you received as a positive,201d he encouraged the young people who dreamed of becoming inventors.
 
Sangutan is the current president of the Philippine Traditional and Alternative Herbal and Cosmetics Association in Mindanao in 2015, Mindanao Inventors Federation, and also a member of the screening committee of the DOST.

BAGUIO.

Roderick Osis, SAKURA Terrace gives diners a quaint taste of the real Japan.

The decision to set up a business in the City at the time when Hagiwara was still an English student who had a hard time looking for authentic Japanese restaurants.

to 11 p.m.
on Fridays to Sundays and 11 am to 9 pm from Monday to Thursday, Sakura authentic tonkotsu and tantanmen ramen, teishoku, bento boxes and a vast selection of sushi that goes with their selection of Japanese wine, sake, beer and korean soju.

Japanese food lovers can also enjoy the taste of Sakura Terrace right at the warmth of their house with their home delivery service by calling or texting 780-8788 or 585-2228 with delivery fee of P150.

The Heritage Buffet is the latest addition to the growing food scene in the City which is fast becoming a food lovers2019 paradise.

Tatak World: A food trip at the Lake , Tatak World: A food trip at the Lake 
Photo by Milo Brioso.
Danica Guieb, TOURISTS not just from the country but all over the world flock Baguio City during Panagbenga Festival.

At the quintessential Burnham Park2019s Lake Drive, over 50 stalls line the road which will give you a dining experience with food stalls from all over the world.

Flower festival organizers have made sure stalls are more accessible which allows people to promenade and enjoy the beauty of the American inspired park in the midst of the February festivities.

Almost 23% of stalls at the park is dedicated to food with the rest laden with dry goods, shoes, clothes, knick knacks, souvenirs and memorabilia aside from Cordilleran products like native cakes, cookies, bread, strawberry and ube jam, lengua de gato, chocolate flakes and snow balls.
For the foodies out there, a trip along Lake Drive can fulfill your big appetite with an array of dishes you can try with about P100 to P200.

The scent of food invites you as soon as you reach Lake Drive, enticing you to trod on and explore the expanse of stalls and food carts.
The classic Ilocos Empanada 
A crispy crust with the signature filling is the secret to a yummy empanada, at Lake Drive, empanadas have asado, ham and cheese, tuna, and chicken.
In Vigan town, stuffing is composed of cabbage mixed with egg whites, Vigan longganisa, and egg yolk while Batac2019s version is filled with papaya, mongo and their own longanisa mix with a whole egg.
It is said, the empanada recipe was brought by Spaniards but in the towns of Ilocos different versions of the snack have evolved.

The Piaya and Chicharon
The Piaya originated from Negros Occidental, a muscovado-filled unleavened flatbread evolving in strawberry, ube and buko pandan flavours here, sold at P40 to 60 each pack, it will already make you feel like you are in the province.
Bulacan, known for crispy, salty and savoury Chicharon is found in several stalls, perfect for pulutan and merienda with or without dipping it in vinegar.
Ninja pancakes
You will not miss their store with their bright red corner and ninja uniformed cooks.
Pancakes are supposed to be creamy, fluffy and sweet if topped with maple syrup but the Ninja pancake is different, it looks like a small cake with a sweet tangy flavour.

It is a pancake with a twist of the Pinoy bibingka and Tsinoy siopao, filled with fried egg and then topped with red eggs like your Chinese siopao, priced at P40 a piece, it is now one of the best sellers among the stalls.

The American style burger
This stall is home to delicious barbeques, steaks, and of course burgers, grilling a hot meal of P100-150 with its patties grilled to perfection.

French Crepe and Belgian Waffles
Want to dine a la Paris with a price of P65 to 75, visit the French Crepe stall, a small stand which offers French crepes in chocolate, blueberry cream cheese and strawberry.

In another stall, there is Belgian Waffles.
 
Belgian waffles unlike American-style waffles have deeper pockets which can hold more syrup and the texture is also lighter and crispier, sold in different flavours; from strawberries to blueberries and priced from 65-150.
If you are one of the millions joining the flower festival, don't forget to visit food stalls along Lake Drive and dine with the world.
Flower power in Bahong , Flower power in Bahong 
BAGUIO.
Panagbenga Festival is considered by its organizers to have ushered the introduction of tourist destinations outside Baguio City like the Rose Capital in Bahong, La Trinidad.
The barangay is now offering flower farm tours which is frequently visited by urban students.
Even the Department of Tourism is now banking on the development of agri-tourism as a sustainable approach to both sectors of toursim and agriculture.

Jessa Mardy Polonio, BENGUET -- The annual celebration of Baguio City2019s Panagbenga Festival has catapulted this town into a Flower Capital.

Aside from strawberries, the municipality of La Trinidad is also known for its flower growing villages where eco-farm tourism is being developed as a complimentary destination outside Baguio.

The towns of La Trinidad, Atok, Tublay, Kapangan, Kibungan and Buguias have been producing cut flowers sold in several local markets around the country.

Barangay Bahong in La Trinidad is dubbed as the famous flower growing community declared as the Rose Capital of the Philippines in 1998 by then Department of Agriculture Secretary William Dar.
About half of the total 410 hectares of land in Bahong are intended for agricultural use particularly for cut flower production with roses not the only flower produced because farmers have ventured into the production of chrysanthemums and anthuriums.

Bahong is considered as the center of the local cut-flower industry in this part of Benguet with cut-flower-producing barangays of this town, such as Ambiong and Alno.
A steady supply of flowers comes from Valley cut flower farmers especially during the flower festival season where the demand increases.
The Municipal Agriculture office revealed strawberries and cut flowers are still remain top agricultural products.
Growers supply flowers in Metro Manila, Ilocos Region, and Bicol Region.
The flower production of the province reached 24, 862, 467 MT for the year of 2011.
La Trinidad has the highest contribution with 18, 876, 650 MT of cut flower production.
Chrysanthemums pegged as the highest production among the flowers with 15, 833, 455 MT.
Fiji flowers are like chrysanthemum because of its resemblance but differ in their varieties of colors.
For 2012, 31, 757, 481 MT of flowers were produced by the province with chrysanthemum still having the highest production 13, 273, 223 MT and La Trinidad having the highest among the municipalities with 17, 221, 990 MT of flowers.
Cut flower farmers here sell their products at the Dimasalang area in Manila.
Benguet supplies heavily to these open markets, aside from highland vegetables.
Farm tourism
Usual tourism destinations in urban cities may no longer attract curiosity from adventure seekers thus the Department of Tourism in the Cordillera is now bent on developing farm destinations 2013 where visitors may experience nature and be educated on the realm of agriculture.
But this is easier said than done.
Willy Padio, manager of the Benguet Fresh Multipurpose Cooperative, said his group has been planning to develop a cluster of flower plantations for farm tourism but cannot locate an area suitable for the purpose since their members are scattered too.
Padio said cooperative members are in Alno, Alapang, Shilan and even in Sto.
Tomas, Baguio City as well as in Tublay and Kapangan, members have flower farms in Bahong otherwise lack funding to develop cement foot paths that would link their farms to the main road.

Unlike roses which continuously blooms, chrysanthemums are being harvested every four months, Padio said the cycle of flower propagation renders some months with no blooms 201cWe need to study how to make our farms continuously blooming if we will open these to tourist because we don2019t like to disappoint visitors also.201d 
The cooperative has a stall at the Dangwa station in Manila where their flower produce from the members are sold to florists.
With the growing number of tourists visiting the flower plantations barangay officials crafted an Ordinance institutionalizing rules and regulations for the management of tourist attractions in Bahong.
Tourists are now required to pay an environment fee of P20 per head at the Barangay Tourism Office.
The rate for students and senior citizens is P15 per individual.
For foreign tourists, admission fee is P50 per person.
An additional tour guide fee of P200 for local tourists with a 10-member group will also be imposed.
The rate for foreign tour guide fee per group of 10 persons is P300.
Aside from the regulatory fees, tourists who wish to pick flowers from the private farms will have to pay fees at the discretion of the owner of the farm.
The fees collected will be used to fund barangay programs on clean and green aside from tourism related activities.
In the recent years, visitors have flocked to Bahong to marvel the beauty of the local blooms with residents opening the plantations to visitors.
The thrill of flower picking and the magnificent view from the deck excites everyone who visits the farms.
 
Barangay Kagawad Jantor Morales said this week 300 visitors are scheduled to visit the flower farms.
In cases where visitors travel by bus, the local jeepney association has to ferry the visitors either from Km.6 in front of the Provincial Capitol or from Baguio City since the existing barangay road cannot accommodate large vehicles such as busses, 201cOf course ferrying the visitors is additional income for the jeepney drivers.201d 
Today as an emerging tourism destination, a system is sought to be set in place both for residents and visitors alike aimed to make barangay Bahong into a flower destination for all.

 Baste Duterte and Robin Padilla in Hong Kong.
HONG KONG -- They crossed paths a long time ago, one did not even remember.

The other has an incident in the past he would rather forget but would later man up and tell what it was all about.

.

He goes around without bodyguard and his constant companion is Lawyer Alexis Lumbatan.

After waving and shaking hands with the enthusiastic and screaming fans, Robin gave way to Baste who spoke first.

The crowd did not expect Baste to be as good looking even though ruggedly dressed.

Later, Baste admitted he was nervous before he spoke his first word and the adrenalin rush continued long after he and Robin left the stage.

Baste did a good account of himself, though, prompting comments from the sidelines that he could very well follow the footsteps of his father.

The loudest shrieks, of course, went to Robin who has not lost every bit of his celebrity pull.

He cajoled, he ranted, he appealed, he explained and he even sang to woe the votes of the more than 180,000 OFWs working in the Chinese autonomous territory.

He said, he paid for his own plane ticket, hotel room and meals.
All for the love of country and Duterte.
When Robin was done, he motioned to Baste to again take the center stage.
This time, Baste was already confident in asking his countrymen to make a difference and vote for his father.
And like his father, he ended by taking a bow.
 
Then Baste and Robin put each other2019s arms around each other2019s shoulder as they exited the stage.
A new friendship is born.
  
The other tandem of the 2016 election is rising.
Baste and Robin.

Honing skills on election reporting , Honing skills on election reporting 
DAVAO.
Ariel Sebellino, Philippine Press Institute Executive Director, took a group shot with the participants of the seminar-workshop during the last day of the event.

Rhealyn C.
Pojas, EVEN watchdogs have to watch themselves.
Sometimes the problem lies not only on whether the watchdogs are barking up the right tree but also on whether they are barking the right things.

This is necessary to ensure one2019s safety, considering the situation in the Philippine where journalists as targets of politics, and to make certain that one is echoing out the right voices.
Last February 24 to 26 was an opportunity for both enthusiastic puppies and 201cold-jaded dogs 201d in the media industry to learn new ways in handling their media coverage especially now that the election period is coming.
More than 20 journalists from Davao City, Cagayan De Oro City, Bukidnon, General Santos City, and other parts of Mindanao participated in a seminar-workshop dubbed as 201cOpinion Polls and Elections: Making Media Coverage Count201d initiated by the Philippine Press Institute  with the support of Nickel Asia Corporation in collaboration of the Marketing and Opinion Research Society  of the Philippines Inc.
The seminar-workshop was held at the VIP Hotel in Cagayan De Oro City.

With the election period starting to heat up, the seminar-workshop was just in time to give media practitioners a fresh perspective on how they should treat their election coverage.
What are the right things to bark and who are the people the media practitioners must give voice to?
Tess Bacalla, the PPI Training director for the seminar-workshop, reminded both young and veteran journalists to give voice to the voiceless and make an engaging and relevant story from the local that will make sense in the national scope.
Her presentation will leave one to think, 201cWhy am I writing this story? Am I making an impact?201d
Speaking about the topic on Measuring Up: Digging Out Unreported and Underreported stories, Bacalla stressed that journalists must not only report what2019s been said by who or what is seen happening but must dig deeper into the stories they are pursuing and see what2019s been missed or left out.
With politicos in this season making appearances and releasing statements hither and thither that are now dominating the news, Bacalla said reporters must opt to not only report what2019s been said but also what is not said.
Reporting election related stories do not have to be necessarily done closely with the candidates running for a position but one can also make election-related stories even by not going out to the field where the politicos are setting foot, Bacalla said.
Also with the election surveys being released and reported by different news agencies, reporters are reminded through the presentation of Nicco de Jesus of Mores titled 201cBehind the Numbers: Understanding Surveys201d that journalists must report election surveys responsibly since this could either be used for bad things, can be unused that will contribute to ignorance, and might be disused, which will result into confusion.

201cSurveys thrive in societies that value representing people2019s voices,201d De Jesus said, explaining that both the researcher and reporters writing survey results stories are accountable.
201cSurveys badly told will make consumers not trust the surveys anymore,201d De Jesus said.
De Jesus also explained that if surveys are properly conducted and disseminated, it will provide the public with a tool to measure opinions and attitudes in order to allow their voices to be heard.
The workshop did not only give journalists attack weapons to use in reporting election stories but also defense tools that they can use to protect themselves from possible harm that they might encounter in pursuing election-related stories.
Through the presentation of Associate Professor Rachel Khan of the Journalism Department of the University of the Philippines in Diliman, journalists were once again refreshed on the ethics in election reporting.
Aside from reminding the participants that the libel law can be used abusively to threaten media practitioners, she also impressed upon the participants to ask themselves whether they are the right person to write a certain story related to the election and said that stories should be issue-based and not personality based.
201cGive space to all candidates and put greater diversity of news sources,201d these are just some of what Khan had put emphasis during her presentation.
Participants were also given the chance to apply what they have learned during the seminar through the group write-shop where each were given the chance to voice out their opinions and do brainstorming on stories to pursue that is relevant to the election.
The seminar-workshop provided an interactive exchange of ideas and thoughts from both the participants and speakers, which was a good venue to bridge the gap between the reporters of all ages.
201cEven an old-jaded dog can learn new tricks,201d a reporter from Manila Times said upon sharing what she learned during the seminar.
It was indeed the time where both the innocent puppies and jaded dogs in the field of journalism learned new tricks alike.

Masbad, Wacky Tech, IN THE recent Mobile World Congress, 5G was talk of the town.
Everyone2019s got their panties up in a bunch about 5G.
What is it exactly?
Well, according to an article at Engadget, it2019s more of a concept for now.
It2019s getting there but it will be quite a while before it2019s actually implemented and rolled out for real world use.
"Broadly, it describes the next generation of wireless networks that will reach speeds at least ten times faster than LTE, with near instant latency in some cases."
I would touch up on the dismal situation of our country2019s mobile networks but I2019d be digressing already.
Let2019s just talk about 5G.

This is exciting news if you ask me.
Think about it.
The promise of near instant latency for connections.
Ultra fast connections as well.
The world as we know it becomes as connected as ever.
To quote an article from Business Insider:
5G will put 4G to shame in almost every conceivable way.
For starters.
it will be approximately 100 times faster than the fastest current 4G LTE network standard, according to Chinese mobile titan Huawei.
5G will also have more than 1,000 times the data capacity of 4G.
To put that in perspective, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said at MWC that a 5G user could download a two-hour film in one second.
With that kind of bandwidth and speed, it2019s easy to imagine the plethora of innovations and technological breakthroughs that can be attained in the mobile technology industry and beyond.
I2019ve read articles already about good things that can come out of this 5G technology.
CNET published one article.

How about a 100Gbps wireless internet speed? Interested? According to an article by the International Business Times, researchers from Japan have already developed it.
Bazinga! 
Sadly though, there aren2019t any 5G standards yet that have been published.
So things can still change.
Hopefully, the changes will be for the better.
Bottomline, and whatever these standards will be, it will most likely be a great step forward towards better mobile connectivity.
Overcoming stigma remains difficult for the mentally ill , Overcoming stigma remains difficult for the mentally ill 
CAGAYAN DE ORO.
A resident walks past isolation rooms for newly-rescued, mentally-challenged residents of the Residential Care for Elderlys and Differently-Abled Center, a city-run facility.

Pamela Jay F.
Orias, FOR the mentally-challenged and their families, there is yet another heavy cross to bear aside from mental illness, overcoming stigma.
Stella Ferrarez of the Cagayan de Oro City Social Welfare and Development  said the stigma associated with mental illness makes it doubly difficult for patients to seek treatment, or for families to accept and support a mentally-challenged family member.
"We are really fighting against it , this is actually the reason why mentally-challenged or even their families find it difficult to come out and be treated, kay ika-ulaw man sila," Ferrarez said.
Despite decades of advancement in medical science, Ferrarez said mental illness is still largely perceived as a sign of weakness and thus, a source of shame for both the individual and his or her family.

Ferrarez said the mentally challenged often delay seeking psychiatric help and deprived of crucial social support from family members and friends.
"I think families just need to accept the fact na siguro, it runs in their blood.
Kinsa may gusto magka-sakit, wala man diba," she said.
She said warmth, understanding, affection, and care are what the mentally challenged need.

With proper treatment, Ferrarez said the mentally challenged have a good chance of eventually being reintegrated to the community.
Social worker Katherine Callanta, however, said the perennial lack of funds for medicines make administering proper treatment for the mentally challenged difficult.
Callanta, head of the Residential Care for Elderlys and Differently-Abled Center, said the center does not have enough funds for medicines resulting to interrupted treatment for many of its mentally challenged residents.
"Kung dili maka-take ug tambal ang patient for one whole week, naa gyud  tendency manakit siya with fellow patients, mag-wild, mang-lakag,201d Callanta said.

Medicines are also expensive, Callanta said.
A mentally challenged individual undergoing treatment often needs to take a cocktail of medicines daily for a period ranging from six months to three years.

Psychiatric drugs range anywhere from P10 to P300 per tablet, terribly expensive for low income patients or patients2019 families.
A patient who has relapsed may have to take maintenance medicines for longer periods and have to be taken to Davao City2019s Southern Philippines Medical Center, the nearest mental facility, Callanta said.

"Mao man gayud ni ang problema bisan mag-consult lang unta maglisud ta because we do not lack only medicines, we also lack psychiatrists here," Callanta said.
According to Ferrarez, there are only four private psychiatrists in the city.

"We need a government psychiatrist, mao gayud na ang wala ta dinhi sa Cagayan de Oro, hopefully kung naa nata'y government-owned mental hospital, mabutangan na pud ta diri ug psychiatrist," Callanta said.
Access to medication remains a major reason for non-compliance to treatment, a fact long emphasized by the According to Philippine Mental Health Association Cagayan de Oro Chapter.
The Committee of German Doctors, which runs a hospital in the city, provides limited medications to selected indigent clients who qualify based on their screening procedures.

But Ferrarez said the mentally challenged come from all income groups and  treatment can be prohibitive even for middle income families.
Ferrarez said another challenge for the CSWD is the absence of current data tracking the number of mentally challenged in the city.
A Department of Health in Northern Mindanao report quoted by the PMHA-CDO shows that there are 350 mentally-ill patients in the province.
"This is something that we are still working on gayud, since importante ma-identify nato kung pila na sila and from there mahibal-an nato unsa gyud ang need as a whole," Ferrarez said.
In the meantime, Ferrarez said the CSWD, together with mental health advocates, has launched an initiative to educate people at the barangay level to and making them understand about the illness and to combat age-old stigma linked with mental illness.
"Persons with mental-illness can be productive if given proper treatment," Ferrarez said.

I may not be filthy rich, but there2019s a lot of satisfaction when you know that the people who work for you, or with you, are happy and they know that."

201cMy dream is to go back home to the Philippines and raise my new family there.
I think bawat OFW ang pangarap niya is that he never has to leave his children and parents just trying to earn money.

We will love it in Mindanao because here it2019s much brown, there2019s more cacao,201d Iman said.
 
Before finding a job in Dubai, Iman was a research assistant at the Philippine General Hospital.

After completing their first business plan and accomplishing the entrepreneurship course, Iman studied to become a professional marketer at the Chartered Institute of Marketing, UK.
  
She2019s been an expat in Dubai for 12 years now.
Her first six years were as as sales and marketing employee.
After that, she has become an entrepreneur.
 
With her hard work, she was able to put up Ahsant Premium Hotel Supplies & Specialized Gifts in Dubai, where she serves as founder and managing director.

BFF economic drivers: Session Road in Bloom success stories, BFF economic drivers: Session Road in Bloom success stories
BAGUIO.
Tess, Chiara and AA Trinidad, a family of various fields of expertise will sooth your souls and make things just a little bit better with the help of a few crystals.

Maria Elena Catajan, MAYOR Mauricio Domogan said he never imagined the Baguio Flower Festival to be what it is today.

201cI never thought it was going to be of this magnitude,201d Domogan said starting from a small community event in the 902019s, it has become the largest festival in the North.

The mayor said on the onset of the festival 21 years ago, there was barely a P3M budget to fund the entire celebration with the JPDC pledging another million just to jumpstart the brainchild of Damaso Bagaoet and awaken the City to celebration.

Domogan said the City then just had a mere P15M derived from business tax, still reeling from the effects of the killer quake.

After 21 years of the flower festival, the city has a total annual budget reaching P2 billion and an internal revenue allotment of P600M.
201cIt has directly and indirectly affected us in terms of tourism and business,201d added Domogan.

Admitted to be one of the biggest economic drivers of the Mountain City, the annual Flower Festival has empowered entrepreneurs.

Contributed photo.
AS AN ASPIRING seaman studying at the DMMA College of Southern Philippines, I stay at a dorm in Panorama Homes Subdivision in Buhangin, where every day a young boy never fails to catch my attention.

While other children his age may be hooked on some gadgets or shopping with their parents, he peddles every day.

I learned that his mother is the helper in our dorm, while his father is a driver.
As much as his parents would like to provide their children with their necessities, their combined earnings are never be enough to feed the boy and his five younger siblings.
 \t
This amazing young soul, who inspire me and touched my heart, is Ricardo E.
Estrera also known by many as Jay-R.
He dreams to be a manager someday, he says.
  
A lot of families in the Philippines are like Jay-R2019s family.
There are others who are silent but needy, voices of scarcity; the voices that have never live comfortably.
These silent voices belong to the children of poverty.

They are the unheard voices of youth.
It is just one of the usual story of poor Filipinos, typical but deadly.
This problem should be prioritized in the maximum level of the next President of the Republic of the Philippines.
It is just a mirror of our own self and our country.
This means simply means, we should sacrifice in everything that we do.
Can you imagine what people do in order to survive?  
We are indeed blessed not to experience what Jay-R is experiencing right now.
We must value our time in doing good and meaningful things; not wasting any of our efforts in taking for granted the things we think are useless.
