Birds of Shrine Hills  , Birds of Shrine Hills  
Little Egret.

THREE months was all it took for me to photograph more than 30 different kinds of birds within the Shrine Hills area alone.
By Shrine Hills, I am referring to the expanse bounded by Maa Road, Diversion Road and Macarthur Highway.
 
Dabawenyos are familiar with birding areas here in this location - like the ponds near Davao Memorial Park and at Gardena Fresca inside Coca Cola Village at the eastern tip; the big trees inside the Shrine Hills Church compound at the ridge; and, Gap Farms at the western end.
 
Not too many are aware however that within the area are so many artesian springs.
Water + Trees = lots of birds.
 
And, we are not just talking of the cute-sized birds like flowerpeckers, flycatchers, bee eaters and sparrows.
Thick-billed crows, herons, waterhens, doves and the endemic  Philippine Coucal - all are medium to fairly large-sized birds that made Shrine Hills part of their home.

The bigger thing is, this is but one of the so many number of great birding sites within an hour2019s drive from the city center.
Other sites that people all over spend so much money just to go to are Bucana, Crocodile Park, Punta Dumalag, Eden as well as other nearby areas like the Panabo coastal road to the north and the Sirawan river mouth at Darong.
 
I had zero knowledge on birds and birding 3 months back.
Everything started when I noticed during my early morning walks that there are so many different kinds of birds perched on the electric wires.

So, I just armed myself with a camera one day and clicked on as many as I could without regard for composition, picture sharpness or what not and simply posted them at my FB page, hoping that someone among my friends know the difference between a shrike and a starling.
A friend referred me to a friend who referred me to the bird experts.
Talk about how fb can connect anyone to everyone - now I2019m hooked into birding!  
The whole adventure is vastly rewarding.
I discovered some people I know from way back are certified bird gurus and I am having a grand time reconnecting while learning.
On a personal note, birding surely has a lot to do with the way my blood pressure level went down.
The calming effect of how one learns to sit patiently for that picture opportunity is the perfect prescription to those who lead stressful lives.

Birding also provides people a refreshing mind set.
In the words of pro-birder Nilo Arribas, jr.
author of the nationally awarded book: Birds of Cebu and Bohol, Philippines - 201c that as individuals...
we are not really in 2018control2019 and that applies to even the most basic like natural lighting on a tiny bird.201d 
Want to try birding? Check out the fb accounts of the Wild Bird Club of the Philippines and the Philippine Bird Photography forum 2013 FB group.
 
They are a friendly lot who are more than willing to help newbies through.
 Martin Y.
Pineda 
The flag carrier soaring higher at 75 , The flag carrier soaring higher at 75 
DAVAO.
Flag carrier Philippine Airlines celebrates its 75th foundation day on March 15.
 
Jinggoy I.
Salvador, YEAR 2016 marks the 75th year in service of the flag carrier.

To celebrate the milestone, Philippine Airlines came bearing good news for the Davao travelers with no less than the President and COO, Jaime Bautista, flying in to town to share it.
 
201cIt has been two years since PAL held a press conference here in Davao City and indeed, I am very glad to be back in this vibrant Mindanao city,201d said the PAL president in his welcome speech.
Then he started sharing PAL2019s good news.
 
When PAL reinstated the Davao-Cebu flight in March 2015 and increased the frequency to twice daily a few months after, there was a bigger plan on the drawing board.
Truth to that is the new flight to be inaugurated on PAL2019s 75th founding anniversary on March 152014the Cebu to Long Angeles route.
 
PAL2019s newest international service between the Queen City of the South and the City of Angels is a part of the ongoing route expansion in response to the market demand.
 
At present, the airline has 25 weekly flights from Manila to the US.
 
201cWe wanted to increase the flight frequency from the Philippines to the US, but the Manila hub is congested.
Cebu is a solution to this congestion,201d Bautista said.

201cThis newest PAL service will enable our customers to enjoy more travel options to and from Los Angeles.
PAL patrons from the Visayas and Mindanao may hop to Mactan in Cebu via our domestic flights and then take the flight to LA.201d  
The PAL Cebu hub also connects to Nagoya, Osaka, Tokyo , and Seoul .
 
Why we should be hopping on this new flight to LA? With a round trip all-in fare of $650 to the City of Angels booked before March 15th, why shouldn2019t we? And that includes the domestic sector , which is offered free with the promotion.
  
The new 2016 routes of PAL to LA, Kuwait, Jeddah, Doha  and Saipan  will add to the 15 other new destinations launched in 2015 as part of PAL2019s route expansion.
 
Part of this expansion will include Europe, bared the PAL president.
  
Servicing the long haul routes will be six brand new wide-bodied planes, the Airbus 350-900 , which will allow PAL to fly non-stop to the European destination, and to New York and Toronto as well.
  
With more new planes coming, by 2020 PAL can boast that they have the youngest fleet of aircraft in the region with an average age of below four years old.
 
With the growing number of travelers in the country coupled with the increase of tourist arrivals causing the airport congestion in Manila, the PAL president said, 201cIt2019s only a matter of time before Davao will be an international hub for PAL.201d  Now, that is something to look forward to.

The exhibit is open to the public.

Celebrating extraordinary women  , Celebrating extraordinary women  Pamela Jay F.
Orias, WHEN we think of empowered and successful women, what usually pops in our minds are perhaps Amelia Earhart, Oprah Winfrey, Hillary Clinton, or in the country, we think of Gabriela Silang and the unsung brave women who fought against slavery and colonialism and rose against submission.

We also the contemporary celebrities like Monique Wilson who helps in advocating the 201cOne Billion Rising,201d Gloria Diaz, Senator Miriam Santiago and those other women who have ranking positions in the society.
Truth is, there are also the other women who do the action in the community, in their homes, in the streets, sometimes we seem them too often in their offices stuck with paperworks but still go home to tuck their children in bed and whisper their husbands goodnight.
Take for example Marilyn Edzel, 34, a teacher, married and has three kids.
Marilyn is married for 10 years now, thought she was in for a treat after she married her dream guy but she thought wrong.
Barely after two years of their marriage, her husband, who's away for work abuses her emotionally, texting her hurtful messages about infidelity, and threatens to break up their marriage.

"One time, gi-text niya sa akong mga kauban sa trabaho na naa daw koy lain, dili daw ko makontento, katol daw ko," Marilyn said.
"I was on the verge of breaking down and giving the marriage up, because it's been years and it's always the same situation but I can't just do it, I can throw it all away, especially now that I have kids," Marilyn said.
When you have kids, everything else changes, she said adding that "marriage is not all about husband and wife anymore, it's all about your children."
Marilyn tried marriage counseling and hoped everything will work out again.
"I gave it a shot, I still love him and I think it was a success, so far, murag ning-work out man pud," she said.
"You really cannot blame me if I chose not to leave his side, it's a promise I made not only to him, to God, but for my children," she added.
It is a different case for Annie Casana, 45, has one kid and raised him all by herself.
Being a single mom, she said, is something she chose to have.
"It's a decision I made.
I was 20 then and did something reckless, so I got pregnant.
The guy was not my boyfriend, just someone from school I knew," she said.
"Ang naka-bilib was the guy was not a coward, he actually offered to marry me, but I said no.
I was not ready for marriage, and accepting it would just be too much especially I had a baby boy coming," Annie said.
Annie thanked her parents for allowing her to decide on her own and not forced her to do something she said she would regret for the rest of her life.

"I have never felt more empowered than that moment, I look back and I smile.
I am proud of myself, I say.
And I have someone too now, someone special.
In choosing someone, you don't have to rush it, it takes time," Annie added.
Another empowered woman is Police Inspector Maricris Mulat, former chief of Tagoloan police.
Mulat was chosen as one of the awardees of the 2015 Search for the Country2019s Outstanding Police Officers in Service .
In an interview, Mulat said there was never a time when she doubted her capacity just because she is a woman.
Instead, she took it as an advantage.
201cKaya man sa uban, nganu dili man nako makaya?201d Mulat added.
Already in her 16 years in service, Mulat said she takes the problems as 2018challenges,2019 adding that it gets 2018exciting2019 and 2018fulfilling2019 everyday as long as 2018your heart is in it.2019
Mulat specializes on domestic violence and operations against illegal drugs.
201cMy mother was a victim of domestic violence, so gihatagan sab gyud ni nako na area ug priority.
So, we conduct information drive or mga seminars against domestic violence in my area of responsibility,201d she said.
Mulat has two kids, a boy and a girl, both in their adolescence, and a supportive husband.
201cAkong pamilya dili gyud babag sa akong pagpanerbisyo, they have always been so supportive.
Akong mga bata, ang ilang namat-an gayud, akong trabaho na pagka-police,201d Mulat said.
For businesswoman Caravelle Togle-Barnido who is a mother of four, empowerment is motherhood.

201cThat's all there is to it.
Nothing else beats being a mother.
I can proudly say that all of my accomplishments in this world, being a mother 2013 becoming a mother is the best of them all.
If men were to get pregnant and endure labor and birthing pains, I think there would be fewer pregnancies, .
Childbirth is an endurance test.
I seriously thought I was going to die during my first.
It was THAT painful.201d 
It was still painful for her other deliveries.
But seeing her daughter for the first time vanished all the pain.
She said it remained that way for the three more pregnancies 2013 another daughter and two sons.
201cI say it with pride, that I delivered four babies .
I was a sucker for punishment.
My doctor said it would be nice for me to experience the actual pain of childbirth.
I went along with it.
She said it would be painful.
She never said I would feel like I was going to die.
But hey, I survived it!!!201d
Barnido felt empowered as a woman each time she gave birth.
Every stretch mark, every discomfort, every tear, every pain was her badge of honor.
201cIt was mine and mine alone.
I was proud that I carried these children below my heart and in me for nine months.
It was a bond not easily severed.201d 
She said her husband helped her with the child rearing and the children are close to their father and added, 201cbut the mother and child bond is so much deeper than that.

I was responsible for these children.
Their lives depended on me until they were ready to face the world.
How they contribute to society would be a testament to how I raised them.201d  
She hopes that the government can provide access to better and safer health care especially to expectant mothers, daycare centers in work areas for working mothers and for the schools to teach girls traditional boy skills like mechanics, carpentry and the like and also more girls in sports.
Celebrating Women2019s Month is a good enough reason for women all over the world to focus on themselves yet doing service to others whatever the means.
This month, you matter, this month, dare to shout 201cI am empowered.201d 
Masbad: USB-C and the S7 and G5, Masbad: USB-C and the S7 and G5Roark L.
Masbad, Wacky Tech, USB.
1.
2.
3.
C.
They2019re everywhere.
Almost all of our gadgets connect via and use USB.
This latest iteration of USB is here and is here to stay.
What is it exactly? Here2019s a clinical definition, description from an article by PCMag:
USB-C is the hot, new industry standard connector and cable used for connectivity and power.
The USB-C connector was developed by the USB Implementers Forum, the group of companies that has developed, certified, and shepherded the USB standard.
It counts over 700 companies in its membership, including Apple, Dell, HP, Intel, Microsoft, and Samsung.
This is important, because it's more likely to be accepted by the majority of PC manufacturers.
Contrast this with the Apple-promoted  Lightning and MagSafe connectors, which have limited acceptance beyond Apple products.
I first saw this on the brand new Apple Macbook.
It2019s quite the attractive connection if you ask me.
It2019s thin and it promises to be the one, single connection you2019ll ever need -- power, peripherals, etc.

If you already have the Macbook or any other laptop that2019s using USB-C, you2019ll probably want to go through this article from Mashable and get your hands on one or two of the accessories they featured.
On other news, the Samsung Galaxy S7 and the LG G5 might turn out to be the next iPhone2019s two biggest competitors.
And they2019re both launching within the next month.
Tech Insider describes the S7: 
The Galaxy S7 brings back two of three: Samsung's flagship smartphone once again supports micro SD storage, and it's waterproof at a depth of up to 1.5 meters.
Galaxy S7 owners will not be able to replace the battery, but they can recharge it quickly, even wirelessly, and it's more than 17% larger than the one found in the Galaxy S6.
And in the same article, the LG G5 was described as a "dramatic departure from its predecessor201d.
How is it different aside from the usual fare? 
The phone's lower bezel is replaceable, and can be swapped out for a variety of different modules that expand the device's functionality.
I2019m somehow excited about the G52019s modularity.
Hopefully, other accessory manufacturers would be able to come up with innovative modules to make the phone really fun to use.

But what I am looking forward more to is how this will turn out to be for these three companies - Apple, LG and Samsung.
Could there be more innovations to come for the smartphone category? 
Only time will tell.

Music in fight for justice, Music in fight for justice
DAVAO.
Artists from Manila join the protest in calling for justice against discrimination of lumads in Mindanao.
Christine Joice C.
Cudis, AS THE voices of human rights protectors appeared to have gone nowhere and remained to be unheard over years of rallying on the streets and in front of government offices, an organization diverted its strategy to be heard -- this time to a more creative way.
Salupongan International , a solidarity network inspired by the aspirations of the Manobo Talaingod tribe who united their villages to defend their ancestral land and rainforest from being destroyed by corporate loggers decades ago in the Southern Mindanao Region, and Save Our Schools  Network, a child rights group together with Davao-based, Kilab multimedia, formed another music video dedicated to document the long enduring struggle of indigenous people to defend what was supposed to be their rights.
SI and SOS are hoping to capture the interest of a wider audience inputting light to the situation of the Lumad evacuees who are now taking shelter in the United Church of Christ in the Philippines  Haran compound along Father Selga Street.
As part of their objective to provide awareness among those who have not fully grasp the hapless situation of the lumads who were forced to move out from their communities in Talaingod, Kapalong, Davao del Norte and Barangay White Kulaman, Kitaotao, Bukidnon, the groups launched on Saturday a simultaneous viewing of their second music video, entitled "Salupongan" which means unity at UCCP Haran and at the University of the Philippines Diliman Film Institute.
SI board member Leah Valle, in an interview, said that the incorporation of arts in their fight for justice plays a vital role for the community's acceptance of the issue.
She also added that the support from influential people in different parts of the country gained an impression to the public that whatever they are doing is not any form of rebellion against the government as some people label them as leftists for joining the cause.
"Art is the soul of a human.
We may not notice it but we understand better through art, it could be through literary, musical, and performance art.
Thus, we are educating people through these music videos which we see as a form of transjournalism.
It means it encompasses multiple media in an expansive way; hence, reaching a bigger audience," Valle explained.
Multi-awarded artist Maan Chua also graced the event and shared her songs on the roots and culture of Mindanao, reminding the lumads of their prerogative to till their lands without fear of being attacked by men who want to take them away from their communities rich in mineral resources.
In an interview, Chua said: "When you mix music with social issues, it will live forever and people will know about it.
I have the right to write songs about Mindanao because this is where I live, I have the right to tell those who need to listen, what happens here." 
Chua is also part of the first music video released by SI, SOS, and Kilab Multimedia with the title, "Mindanaw".
It is accessible through YouTube under the Salugpongan International account.
The latest music video is directed by Carlos Siguion Reyna which features over a hundred musicians and actors, including John Arcilla, Aiza Seguerra, Isay Alvarez, Robert Se\xf1a, Bayang Barrios, Mae Paner, Christopher de Leon, Edgar Mortiz, Bimbo Cerrudo, CrisVillonco, Lorenz Martinez, Myke Salomon and music groups like Baihana, Patatag, UP Cherubim and Seraphim, Coro de Sta.
Cecilia, along with a dozen lumad musicians.
The event is part of the month-long Mindalakbayan for land, environment, and human rights and justice.
It will serve as a venue to hear the voices of the Lumad and advocates speak on the current campaign against the intensifying militarization, violations, and killings of Indigenous Peoples in Mindanao.

Fittingly, "Salupongan" music video calls on everyone to come together to defend and uphold the rights, welfare, and future of the Lumads.

Kisame: Vision of Heaven on Earth , Kisame: Vision of Heaven on Earth 
Contributed photo
Stephanie Mae M.
Tujan, Celebdom, AS I LOOK up at the ceiling paintings, several thoughts crossed my mind about the beautiful paintings photographed above me.
There2019s always a strange feeling, a mix of expectations, recognition and, in some cases, an experience one had never imagined.

It is fascinating to see how the lives of Christ, the Virgin Mary, and the saints have inspired artists for centuries.
It is amazing to see these artists visualize them.
It is like stepping into a real museum where sacred art is exhibited.
You can stare at these paintings for a long time without getting bored.
Ayala Museum, the Filipino Heritage Festival, and Abreeza Mall present 201cKISAME: Visions of Heaven on Earth, 201cAn Exhibition of Photographs of Ceiling Paintings from Churches in the Province of Bohol,201d which already started last March 5 and slated to run until March 31 at the Abreeza Mall2019s ground floor expansion wing.
201cKISAME: Visions of Heaven on Earth201d showcases the Filipino2019s artistic heritage in the context of ecclesiastical art.

Featuring installations of large format photographs and video documentation of architectural paintings selected from 17 churches in Bohol, the exhibition is an up-close view of images that represent visions of heaven on earth.

It also features the historical background of each painting and the church to which it belongs in a somewhat Visita Iglesia Bohol presentation in photographs.

The photographs featured in this exhibition were taken by Honorable Executive Secretary Paquito N.
Ochoa, Jr., from the ceiling paintings of the churches in Bohol in the dioceses of Tagbilaran and Talibon in April 17 to 21, 2008.

These selected works of art that adorn the parish churches are the remaining works of two pioneering Cebuano artists, Raymundo Francia and Canuto Avila, who were executed during the first half of the 20th century.

The exhibition2019s curators are Fr.
Milan Ted Torralba and Kenneth Esguerra.
Fr.
Milan Ted Torralba was the Assistant Secretary at the Apostolic Nunciature  in Manila and the present Vice President of External Affairs of the Visayan Association of Museums and Galleries, the Executive Secretary of the Permanent Committee for the Cultural Heritage of the Church, Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines, and the Corporate Secretary of the Bohol Heritage Development Foundation.

Meanwhile, Kenneth Esguerra is presently the Senior Curator and Head of Conservation of Ayala Museum, and has over two decades of working experience in museums both in the Philippines and abroad.

He was the Director for Exhibitions and concurrent Chief Registrar of the Metropolitan Museum of Manila , has taught Curatorship and Collections Management under the Philippine Arts Program of the University of the Philippines-Manila , and was the managing director of the Balay Taliambong: The Cojuangco Museum and Art Center .
201cKISAME: Visions of Heaven on Earth201d was first presented as part of the 2008 National Heritage Month celebration organized annually by the Filipino Heritage Festival.
It was first exhibited at the ground floor Gallery of Ayala Museum from May 27 to July 20, 2008.
*****
Feel Free to email stephaniesunstar@yahoo.com for comments and suggestions.
Or visit and add Celebdom Sunstar Davao for previous Celebdom articles.

The nurse is now a policeman , The nurse is now a policeman 
Michael A.
Plarisan.

Jeepy P.
Compio, THIS is all about a former nurse who chose to become a policeman and decided to use his medical skills instead directly in the police force where accidents and other life-threatening situations are most often dealt with.
More people are deciding to go into the medical field with the knowledge that nurses make lots of money especially when one opts to work abroad,
but not with Police Officer 1  Michael A.
Plarisan, a registered nurse  who boldly embarked in a different path by taking an examination for police position even after his experience as a staff nurse at the Davao Medical School Foundation Inc.
in Davao City.
A wider scope to help people, this is what Plarisan revealed in an interview when asked why he has chosen another path.
"The police operations even have a wider scope because you can immediately render medical assistance to the people especially when there is an accident through first aid," Plarisan said.
"You also get to encounter a lot of people in different situations through police work just like in a nursing profession," he added in the vernacular.
Plarisan spent his elementary years at Lanao Central Elementary School and finished his secondary education at Kidapawan City National High School in 2002.
From 2003 to 2007, Plarisan took a degree in Bachelor of Science in Nursing at North Valley College Foundation Inc.
in Kidapawan City.
Plarisan is the second of three children of Ranulfo and Elpidia who is a retired Research Specialist 2 at the Department of Environment and Natural Resources  in Kidapawan City.
The unanticipated Middle East meltdown and the global economic risk it brought that sent lots of nurses back to their homelands had been a turning point of Plarisan's career which had been instrumental to his desire to become a policeman.

"That time daghan ang gipang-pull out nga mga nurses nga nag-work sa abroad, so sa akong tan-aw, mora'g naluya na ang mga nurses.
Naisip nako while nag-duty nako sa DMSF nga mosulod na lang ko sa training sa PNP kay makatabang lang gihapon ta sa katawhan," he added.
Plarisan took a Police Officer and Senior Police Officer Examinations and passed.
He eventually joined training for Police Officer 1 and is now currently assigned as the desk officer  at the Davao City Police Office's Sta.
Ana Police Station.
He recalled his experience in the training which he described as challenging and narrated that there was a point where his socks earned holes after times spent in combat.
"I've been through a lot of experience during the training but I had never quit until the time came when I took the Police Officer and Senior Police Officer Examinations which I fortunately passed," he narrated.
"The training at the center was tough and there, I was able to reflect that my life had turned 360," Plarisan said adding that the training had changed him into a better version of himself.
After the training, he was downloaded in the Regional Public Safety Battalion  where he was assigned to the Davao International Airport and was later transferred to the Sta.
Ana Police Station for five-month training in station2019s atmosphere.
He also received appreciations and commendations such as letters and special commendations; leadership awards, and Medalya ng Papuri from different trainings and community relations, among others.
In 2014, he finished the Medical Aidman course in Regional Health Service 11; Emergency Medical Responder  in Central 911; Basic IV Therapy training, Tactical Medicine and Planning Workshop on Non-Communicable Disease Prevention and Control for Decision and Policy Makers in Department of Health -Davao.

Plarisan is now happily married to Dr.
May Anne Casta\xf1eda-Plarisan, one of Anesthesiologists in Southern Philippines Medical Center and they are blessed with a daughter, Mikhaela Andrea.

Rise of HIV-Aids positive 2018alarming2019 , Rise of HIV-Aids positive 2018alarming2019 Ivy C.
Tejano, HEALTH authorities are becoming alarmed by the continuous rise in the number of people with Human Immunodeficiency Virus-Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome  in the country.

"It's alarming.
Di na maganda ang bilang ng mga taong may ganitong HIV-Aids," DOH-Davao director Abdullah Dumama said, adding that HIV cases increased from month to month, and the age groups that have the highest number of cases are those in the productive age: between 25-34.

According to United Nations Joint Venture on Aids, the Philippines is one of only a handful of countries at risk of a full-blown Aids epidemic if it is unable to address the problem on time.

Indeed, HIV-Aids is a problem that everyone has to face and solve.

Dumama said the country is among the nine countries which has 28 percent increase in HIV cases.

He added that there are one case per one-hour and 15-minutes.

In Davao Region, he said, the office has recorded 36 cases as of January.

Based on the figures as of January 2016, there are 804 new cases of HIV-Aids in the country which is 50 percent higher as compared to December 2015 with 650 cases.

In January 2015, the health officials recorded 536 cases.
The figures also showed that 97 of the 100 percent persons living with Aids are male.
The median age was 28 years old .
More than half belong to the 25-34 year age group, while 28 percent were youth aged 15-24 years.

Regions with the highest number of reported cases for January 2016 were National Capital Region  with 370, Calbarzon with 130, Central Visayas with 71, Central Luzon with 60, and Davao Region with 36.
The 137 cases came from the rest of the country.

The reported modes of transmission  were sexual contact with 771 and needle sharing among injecting drug users  with 33.

Meanwhile, 89 percent of those transmitted are through sexual contact among males with males .

Same data showed that there has been a sudden increase of cases, from 17 reported cases per day in 2014 to 27 cases per day in 2016.

The DOH also said that nine out of 10 patients do not show symptoms, and are males.
From January 1984 to 2016, there were 31,160 HIV cases nationwide with 1,594 deaths.
 
Of the reported deaths, 13 were children below 10 years old and 16 were adolescents aged 10-19 years old.
Almost half or 744 belong to 25-34 year age group, 481 were in 35-49 year age group, and 210 were youth aged 15-24 years.
    
According to the World Health Organization , the HIV is a retrovirus that infects cells of the immune system, destroying or impairing their function.

As the infection progresses, the immune system becomes weaker, and the person becomes more susceptible to infections.
The most advanced stage of the HIV infection is the Aids.
It could take 10 to 15 years for an HIV-infected person to develop Aids.

Antiretroviral drugs can slow down the process even further.
WHO said HIV is transmitted through unprotected sexual intercourse , transfusion of contaminated blood, sharing of contaminated needles, and between a mother and her infant during pregnancy, childbirth and breastfeeding.

To address the growing number of HIV cases, the DOH earlier implemented the HIV-STI Prevention Program, which aims to reduce the transmission of the HIV and sexually transmitted infections among at-risk groups.

The most advanced stage of the HIV infection is the Aids.
It could take 10 to 15 years for an HIV-infected person to develop Aids.

Antiretroviral drugs can slow down the process even further.
WHO said HIV is transmitted through unprotected sexual intercourse , transfusion of contaminated blood, sharing of contaminated needles, and between a mother and her infant during pregnancy, childbirth and breastfeeding.

To address the growing number of HIV cases, the DOH earlier implemented the HIV-STI Prevention Program, which aims to reduce the transmission of the HIV and sexually transmitted infections among at-risk groups.

Rodrigo Duterte: Will he be the next president?, Rodrigo Duterte: Will he be the next president?Ben O.
Tesiorna, RODRIGO ROA DUTERTE, mayor of Davao City for more than two decades -- will he make it this time as the 16th President of the Republic of the Philippines?
If you are to base on his Facebook supporters and the frequency of his name being mentioned in social media by millions of Filipinos all over the world, one could say that Duterte has a big chance of getting elected president in the May 2016 polls.
But as Duterte himself admitted, Facebook likes do not make one get the presidency.
Many would concur with this but at the same time admit that it cannot be denied how big the influence of social media is in this year's electoral race.
Some even touted that this just might be the first time that a president is elected because of the power of social media.
If so, then many Duterte supporters are already singing hallelujah this early.
According to Facebook, a total of 12 million people around the world participated in conversations about the Philippine elections from November 20, 2015 to March 8, 2016, resulting in more than 81 million interactions.
Out of over 49 million Facebook users in the country, more than 20 percent are 201cactively engaged and are sharing their opinions on key election issues."
In a Rappler report recently, it said that Duterte remains the most talked about presidential candidate.
Duterte peaked mid-November when he announced that he was running for president.

But the million dollar question however is, how will these queries and likes in the internet translate into votes for Duterte on May 9?
Peter Lavi\xf1a, Duterte spokesman, said that it is truly a big challenge for them how to convert online power to offline vote.

"We are currently running a campaign to register our supporters online through our websites so we will determine who are voters, who are not.

We will not be able to do this 100 percent but we will have a fair idea by election day if we can mobilize the bulk of this online power," said Lavi\xf1a.

True even in areas known as bailiwick of other presidentiables.

Surveys
Even in various surveys conducted by different groups, Duterte is also in the running for the top position.
In Mindanao, the mayor is the overwhelming choice with an average of 59 percent of total votes with Davao Region registering the highest points of 81 percent.

Duterte also leads in the National Capital Region , Southern Luzon/Bicol, and the Visayas, based on January survey conducted by Rappler.

Duterte has so far focused on these five-point agenda.

1.
Stamping out criminality particularly illegal drugs, kidnapping, and other heinous crimes; instilling discipline for everyone to adhere to the rule of law, and strengthening the country's justice system;
2.
Raising living standards by generating jobs, increasing employment, doing away with contractualization, promoting livelihood, agricultural modernization, entrepreneurial, technological and industrial advancement with just taxation and equitable distribution of wealth while caring for the environment for sustainable development;
3.
Intensifying and improving social services including education, health, housing, mass transportation with special attention to the elderly, women, children, youth, indigenous peoples and other marginalized sectors; providing assistance to overseas Filipino workers and their families; adapting to climate change, reducing risk, preparing for natural disasters and adopting 911 nationwide;
4.
Ending internal conflict and building peace for all Filipinos regardless of religion or political ideologies so we may all be united in confronting the threats of violent extremism, defending our territorial sovereignty, integrating well within the Asean region and helping promote international peace, understanding, friendship and cooperation.
5.
Shifting to a Federal-Parliamentary System through a Constitutional Convention, holding of plebiscite and preparing the various States to effect power-sharing, resources-sharing, respect-for-all and development-for-all as key to reforming the whole bureaucracy to effect good governance, including increasing the salaries of government workers, fighting graft & corruption and unleashing the potentials of all regions, of all ethnic groups for well rounded social, economic and cultural growth.

"We believe this is reflective of the pulse of the communities and the preference of the Filipino people.

Dr.

But a greater number still prefer no barriers.

201cIt is very volatile, because if we slip it will really rise, there is continued rise of cases in the whole Philippines, so we still have to aggressively implement prevention and access to services,201d Ramiterre said.

She added that intensified information drive, awareness education, and early testing are being promoted in Davao.

Based on Philippine HIV and AIDS registry in the Epidemiology Bureau, in Davao City there are 42 cases recorded in December 2015, while there are 332 persons living with HIV-Aids recorded from January to December 2015.

Out of 42 recorded cases in December 2015, 40 were male and 2 were female.

In the whole year 2015, 319 males and 13 females were recorded positive.

The 25-34 age group has recorded the most number of cases with for the whole year of 2015 and the Homosexuals recorded highest in the mode of transmission with 172 cases followed by bisexuals with 21 cases for the whole year.

Ramittere said that the numbers alone are alarming, but it could also indicate increased awareness among a wider population base such that more are asking to be tested.

What bothers them now is the high prevalence among men having sex with men or MSMs, and thus they are focusing their Integrated HIV Behaviorial Serologic Surveillance , done every two years on this sector to better understand the sector and their vulnerabilities.

201cWe have not yet done survey in other key populations like freelance or registered entertainers, maybe in the next round because in the past IHBSS  it is always low sa Davao City.

We focus doon sa MSM, kasi ang current driver natin ng epidemic is ang MSM,201d Ramiterre said.
 
She said that to determine right respondents of the surveillance, the team from RHWC conducted site mapping in four weeks to find out the cruising sites of the MSMs, areas where they congregate, and hang out.

All throughout the six month survey, she said, strict confidentiality is followed.
"Just like population hindi mo na man masasabi na andito lang sila.
They are present in all walks of life even among professional groups,201d Ramiterre said.

She added that their MSM peer educators also tried to map the city and look into different districts for representation.

In addition, Ramiterre said that they are keeping track of the MSMs every two years because unlike the freelance sex workers, and registered entertainers who are territorial, MSMs are mobile and do frequently change areas of concentration.

She said that IHBSS results will be used for planning strategies programs for the HIV not the RHWC but also for the Davao City Aids Council .

201cSa surveillance all about tinitingnan dito ang demographics, level of education and awareness access to services ngmga respondents at the same time meron kasing serologic studies dito.
They are screened for HIV, Syphilis and Hepatitis B.,201d Ramittere said.

The latest IHBSS was participated by around 300 respondents in a surveillance span of six months.

According to Ms.
Priscilla Senoc of the Davao City AIDS Council, the lead council which monitors and evaluates programs for HIV, as well as a coordinative body of all 19 national and local agencies, they are now trying to approve workplace policy to make seminar on STI-HIV AIDS before they can get business permit.

201cData of HIV in Davao City is rising.
We are now trying to approve the workplace policy because supposedly in the ordinance, all establishments should undergo HIV-AIDS seminar.
We have not yet ironed out kung paano siya mai-implement," Senoc said.

Senoc said that the said seminar must be done for one day as it should include seminar for gender and sexuality.

"Ang program hindilang focus sa HIV and AIDS we really have to let them understand the LGBT issue and gender and sexuality paraatleast may reduction ng stigma," Senoc said.

She also said that part of their achievement is successful lobbying of establishment of Barangay AIDS Ordinance among barangays and as of the moment they are now providing technical support on Barangay Calinan, first barangay to have the said ordinance.

She said that on the quarterly meeting of the Council this coming May, she will emphasize to DepEd the growing number of young people's early exposure to sex.

"A meeting should also be called with the Parents and Teacher's Association to remind them about the vulnerabilities of the youth especially in HIV-AIDS infection."
Senoc believes that more than the health, HIV is an offshoot of multi-faceted factors.

"It comes with the physical structure- a community stigmatizing HIV, and other economic and political factors especially as it also includes the issue of poverty," Senoc said.

She also said that the limited national budget for reproductive health pose a big risk for HIV victims as in the long run, as possible shortage of Anti-retroviral drugs, medicine that prevents the HIV into a full blown virus, ,may happen as the number of cases increase.

She said that there is a moot chance for those HIV victims even to air this kind of concern to the government as most of them refuse to come out in the open and campaign for a big budget for medicine for HIV.

She also said that biases must really be set aside to let people feel that they have right access of government services, especially with the HIV victims.

Senoc said that as Health Education Promotion Officer II of the RHWC, the secretariat of Davao city AIDS council, she's been invited in any places to talk about HIV, and apart from the information dissemination through peer education done also in aid of Department of Health, they are also in partnership with Population Division of CHO to intensify info drive against HIV.

"Today, athletes want more than just a dash board.
They want a relationship."
Nike said that the potential for shoes with adaptive lacing is huge because it provides tailored-to-the-moment custom fit.
When users step into the shoe, their heel will hit a sensor.
The athlete then can press two buttons on the side that adjust the grip.
But Nike said that in the future, it won't be manual.
The sensor could sense when the user needs to have the shoe tighter or looser.
The self-lacing sneaker, which is called "Nike HyperAdapt 1.0," will be out starting the holiday season and will only be available for members of its loyalty Nike+ app.
It will be available in three colors.
The price was not revealed.
"The adaptive lacing system is an excellent first step towards truly adaptive personalized footwear," said Matt Powell, sports industry analyst at NPD Group Inc., a market research firm.

Lacadin.

Some 2,000 motorcycle enthusiasts, mostly members of various riders organizations in Central Luzon and Metro Manila, joined the initial ride against crime, considered the biggest gathering of motor bikers in one setting at Camp Olivas, City of San Fernando,Pampanga.
Lacadin said 201cRide against Crime201d is part of the anti-crime awareness program of PRO-3, whose kick-off coincided with the launching of "Krimen I-text mo, Aksyonan Ko", a strategy aimed at neutralizing criminals.
"For every piece of information relayed to authorities that yields positive results, the informant is entitled to a cash reward," said Lacadin, adding that the scheme has been proven effective especially in combating lawless elements.
He said tipsters will receive monetary rewards "depending how valuable the information is."
This scheme is a 24/7 feedback mechanism that calls for the active involvement of communities, media and local government units in Central Luzon.
The ride against crime motorcade, Lacadin said, constitutes "a sort of show of force" by various motorcycle clubs, which the police consider as effective "force multipliers" in maintaining public safety.
"We value the potential of the riders in our anti-crime strategy, this is a big help for us," Lacadin pointed out, as he expressed thanks to participants and sponsors of the event.
"As we ride for a cause, I enjoin everyone to actively participate in our campaign against all forms of criminality," he added.
After a brief orientation on riders2019 safety, Lacadin and the riders hit the road heading to Olongapo City where they held a "boodle fight" at a resort there.

From Martial Law to People Power: Experiential Museum recreates a nation2019s journey, From Martial Law to People Power: Experiential Museum recreates a nation2019s journey
Contributed photo
ON APRIL 24, 1980, Macli-ing Dulag, village elder of Bugnay in Kalinga, was murdered.
Dulag had been leading protests against a plan by the Marcos regime to construct a dam, which would bring about the displacement of indigenous communities.
His life and struggle to defend their sacred lands, however, would be ended by bullets fired by soldiers of the Dictatorship.
Still, decades after his passing, Dulag's legacy of courageous resilience endures as his story is passed on by his neighbors.
It is a story that is told to young members of their tribe, and it continues to inspire the indigenous peoples of Kalinga.
It is a story that will now be conveyed and retold through new forms of media in the People Power Experiential Museum.

The Edsa People Power Commission  will be opening from February 25 to 26, 2016 at Grandstand of Camp Aguinaldo, Quezon City, a museum that will allow visitors to experience critical moments in history such as the fear and oppression wrought by Martial Law, the struggle to reclaim democracy, and the four miraculous days of People Power.

With the creation of the Experiential Museum, the EPPC hopes to share with young Filipinos the stories of those who bravely endured and fought against the injustice and oppression of Martial Law.
Actors will portray Filipinos who were martyred during Martial Law, including Dulag, Edgar Jopson, and Evelio Javier.
Visitors will be guided through several halls, which bring together elements of theater, cinema, photography, and other allied arts to recreate the experiences that awakened Filipinos, and sparked the Edsa People Power Revolution.
Each hall will represent not only periods in history, but also themes that underscore the enduring narrative of Martial Law and the 1986 Edsa Revolution:
1.
The Hall of Restless Sleep
The first hall represents the lulling of our nation to sleep by Martial Law and the suppression of our freedoms.
Visitors will enter a hall with bound people, sleeping on army cots.
On the walls, the announcement of former President Ferdinand Marcos, declaring the imposition of Martial is repeatedly shown.
The visitors will notice that some cots are empty.
 But when they look at those cots, they will see mirrors reflecting their own faces.
  
2.
The Hall of Hidden Truths
The second hall is a masque ball, where the privileged few of the "New Society" revel in exorbitant festivities.
But outside the ball, beggars roam while photographs documenting the poverty and social inequity during the Martial Law are era are shown on the walls.
An operatic version of "Dahil sa Iyo" is played repeatedly.3.
The Hall of Orphans
In the third hall, you will meet the orphans of Filipinos who were abducted, tortured, and "forcibly disappeared" by the Marcos regime.
They ask you: "Where are our parents?"
4.
The Hall of the Lost
In the fourth hall, the old propaganda films of the Marcos dictatorship will be projected on the walls.
But after this, you will encounter the injustices hidden by Martial Law propaganda.
 This hall will provide visitors with photographs and stories of the desaparecidos of that dark time.
5.
Hall of Pain
Be prepared to learn about Martial Law's brutal ways of torture.
6.
The Hall of Forgotten Martyrs
In the sixth hall, visitors will meet the forgotten martyrs who represent the different sectors of their generation.
Lean Alejandro , Macli-ing Dulag , and Evelio Javier  will share their stories with you.
 
7.
The Hall of Awakening
From the tarmac stained with Ninoy Aquino's blood to streets teeming with Filipinos praying for the end of the Marcos Regime -- you will re-experience the breathtaking journey of the Edsa People Power Revolution.

8.
The Hall of Action
In the last hall, you will find memorabilia and symbols from the Edsa People Power Revolution.
Do these symbols still mean anything to you? What would you do if, like the Filipinos who experienced Martial Law and People Power, you are also called to sacrifice and defend our country's future? May you be surprised by your own response.

For more information or to register for a tour, please visit edsapeoplepower.com
XU Health Services, Red Cross Youth hold medical mission, XU Health Services, Red Cross Youth hold medical mission
 CAGAYAN DE ORO.
Using a stethoscope, one of the volunteer doctors examines the breathing pattern of a senior citizen during the XU medical mission in Talongan Village.

THE joint medical mission of Xavier University2019s Health Services Office  and Red Cross Youth served the residents of Talongan Village, a relocation site in Sitio Calaanan, on Sunday, October 18.
The event, dubbed as 201cSaving Lives: One Community at a Time,201d provided free medical consultations, medicines, tooth extraction, health lectures and included a feeding program.
201cFrom the medical consultations, the common illnesses of the residents here are common colds, respiratory sickness and hyperacidity,201d said HSO director Dr.
Augusto Guitarte, who led the team of medical and dental professionals during the event.
Health services
201cWe identified Talongan Village through the help of KKP-SIO Kristohanong Katilingban sa Pagpakabana 2013 Social Involvement Office because this is their adopted community, so we decided to hold the medical mission here,201d Guitarte added.
Talongan village is a remote area in Sitio Calaanan, Barangay Canitoan with roughly 200 residents who were evacuees from the riverside communities of Cagayan de Oro City ravaged by Typhoon Sendong in December 2011.
The quadruplex houses in the said village were built through the resettlement program of Habitat for Humanity Philippines.

More than 200 residents of Talongan and its neighboring villages availed of the medical consultations while the XU dentists performed tooth extraction to over a hundred people, mostly teenagers.
201cThank you sa pag-anhi sa Talongan maski layo kaayo para mag-medical mission,201d said Therese Ipanag, president of the Talongan Village Homeowners Association.

"Timing ang event kay daghan gadaot kay tungod sa kalit-kalit nga init ug ulan ," she added.
The preparations for the actual medical mission started at 5 in the morning as volunteers needed to prepare the food for the feeding program and to set up the tents, tables and chairs.
Teamwork and leadership
The mission drew together 19 XU student volunteers who made sure everything was in place and in order, especially for the residents who came in the midst of the scorching heat.
Aside from manning the different booths, from registration to consultation and anesthetic areas and pharmacy, a group of Red Cross Youth members discussed the importance of hand washing, tooth brushing and proper hygiene routine among the kids from the sitio.
For the Talongan youth and parents, the volunteers also tackled rabies prevention, HIV/Aids, family planning programs and first aid, among other topics.
201cWorking with co-students was a challenge,201d shared Swetzel Anne Neri, Red Cross Youth project leader for this medical mission.
201cAll of us have our own schedules and we come from different colleges.201d
201cLisod itipok ,201d she said.
201cBut in the end, the will to pursue the project drove us to find the time.201d
201cCommunication was our best asset.
No matter how big the dilemma was during the preparation, it was handled gracefully because of our mutual understanding and teamwork,201d imparted Neri, a junior biology student at XU.
201cWe were a team; we were all leaders in the project.
Maybe I was the one who did the paperwork but everyone had their own share of work to do.
It was a blessing to be able to work with great minds.201d
XU-HSO and Red Cross Youth thank J&A Construction and Supply, Club XS and Cagayan RSO Hardware Inc.
for making the medical mission possible.
The two organizations plan to conduct a medical mission as their major project annually for different communities in the city in great need of medical attention.
